name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, a matter of order. Today, at twelve o'clock, Philip of Bourbon is invited to speak in this plenary session. I wanted to show our rejection. This Parliament should represent European democracy and should therefore have its doors closed to those heads of state who have not been elected by suffrage, as is the case with the King of Spain. That is why we are asking this House to amend the decision of the President of the European Parliament and not to allow a head of state who is not entitled to speak in this House.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Madam President, I cannot see any violation of democracy. We already had other guests.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The first item on the agenda is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the deadly US airstrikes on a Doctors Without Borders clinic in Kundus (Afghanistan) (2015/2891(RSP)). I would like to say to Members that there is no catch-the-eye procedure in this debate and that no blue cards are being adopted.

name: Christos Stylianides
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice—President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, this tragedy is a sad reminder of the challenges Afghanistan is still facing, against a background of instability, war and conflict. The last two weeks have seen a jihadist resurgence in the north and the east of the country, threatening the achievements reached so far in development, governance and rule of law, including the rights of women, fundamental freedoms and access to basic services. Confronted with the Taliban who wage war, we need to recommit in our support to the National Unity Government and in ensuring that Afghanistan is, and will stay, high on the international agenda. Recent developments in and around Kunduz are worrying for all of us: the Taliban attack, the suffering it has caused to innocent civilians in the area, the very serious humanitarian situation. The overall situation remains fragile and unstable.  The attack that severely hit a Médecins sans Frontières (MSF) hospital in Kunduz on 3 October was a tragedy which I profoundly deplore – as Commissioner for Humanitarian Aid and Crisis Management but also as a doctor. Hospitals and medical personnel are explicitly protected under international humanitarian law: they can never be the object of attack. The latest reported death toll indicates that 12 MSF staff are confirmed dead, as well as 10 patients, including three children.  Our thoughts are with all the families of the victims, the medical staff and the humanitarian aid workers. Our thoughts are with all those who, in Afghanistan and in the too many conflict areas around the world, dedicate their time, skills and indeed their life to assisting victims of war, saving their lives and improving their living conditions.  MSF has been operating the hospital in Kunduz under extremely trying conditions – and not only there. I have witnessed myself on numerous visits to crisis areas their dedication in their life-saving work in the most acute emergencies. MSF are there when almost everybody else has pulled out. As EU Ebola Coordinator, I particularly want to commend their outstanding work in relation to the Ebola crisis in Liberia, Guinea and Sierra Leone. Without the amazing courage and dedication of MSF, the world would still be struggling to get Ebola under control. But let me get back to Afghanistan. Afghan children, women and men are suffering the devastating humanitarian consequences of over three decades of war and conflict. Our tribute, not only to MSF but also to other humanitarian organisations for their life-saving work in Afghanistan and elsewhere, will never be strong enough. This Parliament knows very well what it means to pay tribute to humanitarian workers and human rights defenders. We all owe them a lot. And, as in other conflict situations, humanitarian workers have paid with their lives to assist the most vulnerable. But while we commend the courageous and dedicated staff of these organisations, we have to be firm and clear in affirming the absolute need to protect their lives and their work, and the lives and dignity of those they assist. This tragedy demonstrates the disproportionate risk for civilians when violent conflict reaches urban areas. All parties must do everything in their power to distinguish between military and civilian targets, including medical facilities. All parties must respect and protect medical and humanitarian personnel and facilities.  President Ashraf Ghani said that the Afghan forces and NATO’s Support Mission are obliged to ensure the safety of civilians and exercise precision in military operations. He stressed that Afghan and foreign forces alike must put in serious efforts not to target public places during military operations. At the same time, Afghanistan’s Independent Human Rights Commission (AIHRC) has called for a probe into reports of possible war crimes committed in this past week by the Taliban in Kunduz city. The organisation has appealed to security and judicial organisations to identify the perpetrators and see to it that justice is carried out. MSF and the UN have called for a thorough investigation into the attack. President Ghani and US Secretary of Defence Ashton Carter have stressed that a full and transparent investigation will be conducted. We welcome the Afghan and US commitment to that effect, and expect that it will bring clear results very soon.  But, this tragedy is a sad reminder of the fact that Afghanistan still needs to find its way out of decades of conflicts. It needs a comprehensive answer to the many difficult challenges it is facing: this should comprise continued efforts to engage the main actors, and it has to build on a revised Afghan security strategy. But the focus must also be on local governance and on connecting the local population to the Government. The Afghan Government has presented a string of actions it will take. Effective implementation is required, and we are ready to accompany the Afghan authorities and people in this difficult process. In terms of immediate action we must now quickly evaluate the need for additional humanitarian support. In the same vein, we call on the Afghan Government to facilitate better humanitarian access to Kunduz and to the internally displaced. We need improved humanitarian air services, and we have to look into the possibility of opening a humanitarian corridor in Kunduz province. We also need all regional stakeholders to come together and join efforts to create a lasting peace. This is at the centre of our diplomatic work, as we pointed out in discussions with all the relevant international players last week in New York, at the High Level Conference on the fringe of the UN General Assembly. The European Union will continue to work with the National Unity Government during this difficult period. We will stand at its side and, first and foremost, at the side of all Afghan people.

name: Arnaud Danjean
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Mr President, Commissioner, the EPP Group would first and foremost like to express its condolences to the families of the 22 victims of the Hospital in Kunduz and to condemn these bombings on which all the light must be shed and the appropriate sanctions imposed. This error, now acknowledged by the American command, after days of unbearable hesitation and squint, is all the more fatal because it destroyed the only efficient medical structure in the Kunduz region, despite the unambiguous communications of MSF staff on the coordinates and the nature of their activities. But behind this tragic event is a very worrying strategic reality in Afghanistan. Taliban offensives on Kunduz but also in Faryab province, near Turkmenistan, and in three other provinces in northern Afghanistan reveal an even more difficult transition than when it was envisaged at the time of the withdrawal of Western forces. The fact that these attacks occur in a region, northern Afghanistan, hithert relatively untouched by insurgent movements, attests that the Taliban threat remains strong, far beyond its traditional strongholds. It also shows that the Afghan security forces, despite heavy, massive and extremely expensive training programmes, still have too random capacity to deal with this type of offensive on their own. Without U.S. air support, Kunduz and other towns in northern Afghanistan would likely still be occupied by the Taliban today. We must also realize that, in parallel with the Taliban, other insurgent groups are growing in power. The Islamic State is now present in Afghanistan and is recruiting heavily among jihadist networks, especially those from Central Asia. The rallying of the Uzbek Islamic movement this summer, as well as the movements on both sides of the Afghan-Pakistan border, where several thousand Central Asian jihadists have been spotted, must alert us to the fragility of the ongoing process.  It also demonstrates that increased international involvement is needed. It is obviously not a question of considering massive military deployments that have shown their limits, but increased cooperation must be sought with neighbouring countries in particular, including with China and Russia, whose current contagion cannot leave us indifferent. Our attention is legitimately focused on other crises that are more close that directly affect our security, but we retain a special responsibility in Afghanistan, where many of the problems we face today have historically had their roots and where there has been an unquestionable legal and legitimate basis, under the aegis of the United Nations, since 2001 to enable us to intervene.

name: Afzal Khan
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, on behalf of my Group I extend our deepest condolences to the families and friends of all those who have tragically lost their lives in the attack in Kunduz. Our thoughts are with their families. We pay tribute to the Doctors Without Borders staff who bravely and selflessly worked as fighting raged in Kunduz over the past week. We also applaud all other heroic doctors and other medical staff around the world who risk their lives every day trying to save others. The hospital was clearly marked and the exact location of the hospital was communicated to all parties to the conflict. More than 22 civilians were killed in the attack – 12 medical staff and 10 patients, three of them children – and 37 more were injured. We, as a Group, strongly condemn this attack. Under the rules of international humanitarian law, a hospital is a hospital, and the people inside are patients and medical staff. To target a medical facility in this way is a violation of that law, whatever the circumstances. Given the seriousness of the harm and the gravity of the alleged legal violations, it is critical that there is a prompt and full independent investigation to ensure maximum transparency and accountability, and those responsible must be brought to justice. Constantly we see certain measures adopted to counter terrorism violating international laws. We learned earlier this month of David Cameron’s decision to carry out a British drone attack, killing citizens extrajudicially outside the UK. The US routinely violates the airspace of Pakistan and carries out drone attacks resulting in the death of civilians. The objectives are to save human lives and dignity in the face of a terrorist threat. Combating terrorism cannot be used as an excuse for the violation of international laws. There always needs to be a strong response from the EU, and respect for human rights and the rule of law must prevail. We also condemn the Taliban for the violence that they have carried out. The Taliban successes in and around Kunduz are the consequences of corrupt and abusive governance. The Afghan Government needs to be united and needs to focus on legitimate grievances and community consensus building. A political transition which features a genuine inclusive effort is needed, otherwise the security situation is likely to worsen further. The EU and the international community should assist in this through diplomacy and negotiations. Regional cooperation, with the objective of promoting long-term peace, stability and security in the wider region, is essential. The cooperation with Pakistan is especially important: we welcome their assistance in the new conciliation process and encourage continuing progress on the path of improved relations and cooperation between Kabul and Islamabad. Afghanistan must not be forgotten in more pressing crisis. We welcome the help that has been announced this morning for the civilians in the Kunduz area.  Although thousands of kilometres away, we in Europe have been experiencing the effect of the increased instability in Afghanistan. Many Afghans, too, are giving up on their country. Afghans have been devastated by over three decades of conflict. They urgently deserve peace. The US states that this attack was a mistake, but they have now offered four different accounts, hence the need for an independent inquiry. The attack has implications not only in Afghanistan but also for medical NGOs across the world. We have a responsibility to ensure that this type of tragedy does not happen again.

name: Mark Demesmaeker
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. I am largely in line with the words of the previous speaker. On behalf of the ECR Group, I would also like to express my condolences to the family and friends of the victims and to the survivors of this terrible bombing. We are all shocked and call for a thorough and independent investigation. How on earth did it happen that aid workers and patients were the victims of an air strike on an NGO hospital?  There is no other way or there have been serious errors of judgment by american and Afghan militaries and even then. The Americans have been operating in Afghanistan for 14 years. Dismissing the bombardment as collateral damage is a cheap and unacceptable excuse. In addition, Médecins Sans Frontières indicates that it has done everything possible to ensure its own safety. Even if there were Taliban fighters in the hospital - which MSF vehemently denies - aid workers had to be warned first.  But the problem goes much further. Due to structural mismanagement by the Afghan government, the Taliban are once again on the rise today. A year after the hailed unity government, there is still no defence minister and the president and prime minister are squabbling over government posts. Meanwhile, the Afghan army is fighting the Taliban with inappropriate equipment and an inept leadership. Because they don't have an Air Force that can make a difference, the Americans enlisted the help. They carried out, against their mandate, bombing. How is it that 7 000 troops have to give up control of a city against a ten-times smaller force?  There are dangerous parallels to draw with Iraq, where the army lost control of Mosul in a similar way.

name: Petras Auštrevičius
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, speaking on behalf of ALDE, I should begin by expressing our deepest condolences to the families of the victims in Kunduz. Clearly, by choosing a hospital as a target, a fatal mistake was made. However, the reasons for this tragedy still remain unclear. I therefore welcome the decision by NATO and the Afghan authorities to launch immediately a thorough and impartial investigation of this tragic event. What happened in Kunduz is a terrible accident, but we cannot view it as an isolated accident. By conquering Kunduz, the Taliban has made the biggest military advance in 14 years. The Taliban’s personnel strength has increased dramatically: by more than six times in the last seven or eight years. The conscripts are mostly from Arab countries and post-Soviet Central Asia, as far as one can read from the reports.  All this is very alarming. The Taliban must be defeated to give Afghanistan a new start. The consequences of our inaction might be unthinkable. I strongly believe that we cannot disregard the overall and unprecedented support which has already been invested in Afghanistan’s security and development. It should be clear from the outset that we cannot repeat the mistakes of Iraq and Syria, where our actions were inadequate. Currently, our efforts in Afghanistan seem far too weak.  It is fundamental to retain the progress made in Afghanistan based on our coordinated strategy, both military and developmental, among the international, regional and local players. Our effective action and determination create the future for Afghanistan. Meanwhile, inaction and confusion bring back the past, which I am convinced the people of Afghanistan are not looking for.

name: Kateřina Konečná
text: on the part of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all, let me thank you for supporting our initiative to discuss this issue in plenary. Now is not the time for a black-and-white vision of the world. Innocent people died. People who dedicated their lives to caring for others and carried out their missions in one of the most dangerous countries in the world have died. But instead of recognition and support, they received more than an hour's bombardment that leveled the area's only medical facility. Moreover, it ended the lives of completely defenseless persons and those who cared for them. An attack on medical facilities, staff, or patients cannot be described as anything other than a completely monstrous crime. This is also recognised by international law, but it was brutally trampled on Saturday morning. Instead of apologies, we now hear excuses, and cynicism alternates between lies. It must be guaranteed that, after we offer our deepest condolences to the survivors, we, as the international community, will insist on a thorough and completely independent investigation. This should unstyle what exactly happened and point to the real culprits and not to the scapegoats. This is the only way to make it clear that international law applies equally to everyone. It is not possible to measure by double standards, especially when it comes to such barbaric acts contrary to humanitarian law.  Accepting only an apology is unimaginable, and it does not change the fact that the perpetrator is a state that seeks to act as a protector of democracy and civilization. If we accept that innocent patients can die in their beds and no one takes responsibility for it and no one is punished for it, then we did not have to create international law.  Thank you for your attention and let me express my condolences to all the survivors and the entire organization. And to call on you, Mr President, to hold a minute's silence here, in the European Parliament, for the people who died.

name: Jean Lambert
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, as the Commissioner has said, many of us have encountered MSF working in challenging conditions in many parts of the world and we respect their integrity, their independence and their policy of making no distinctions based on patients’ ethnicity, religious beliefs, or political affiliation. We know this can create problems for some regimes, but it also means that MSF and other medical charities can often gain the trust of local populations.  Like others here, my Group also condemns this bombing and also wishes to extend our deepest condolences to those who have lost their loved ones, their friends or their colleagues. People should feel safe in a place of healing, and it is certainly a much needed facility. As we have been told, the coordinates were given, but for whatever reason they were not respected. I think questions are raised yet again about what is really meant by precision bombing, and what the value of such bombing is. We are told that this may constitute a war crime. It is certainly a grave violation of international humanitarian law, and so, as others have done, we support the call by MSF for an independent investigation: however uncomfortable that may be, accountability is essential. And, as was said, all war crimes should be investigated.

name: Ignazio Corrao
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, listening to the tenor of many of the previous speakers, it seems that the problem we are discussing is the advance of the Taliban, but I believe that we should pause to think about the meaning of the words peacekeeping or peace wars, peacekeeping missions, because you only have to do a simple Google search and write 'NATO error' or 'NATO friendly fire' to find dozens of , hundreds if not thousands of mistakes, wrong attacks and dead civilians.  So we should probably start calling them by the right name or war crimes. So let us stop and think for a moment about what we can do about this attack in Kunduz, where civilians died, where workers who were there trying to save lives died. We are calling for an independent, complete, transparent investigation, but one that must produce results because these deaths, which have been attacked by the United States of America, will not come back to life, so it is right that those who made a mistake should pay, and that is what we must demand here this morning.

name: Mario Borghezio
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Commission's response is evasive, it seemed like a speech drawn from the elubrations of the Jesuit lawyers of the seventeenth century.  We cannot understand what Europe thinks about this: it is a mistake, it is a war crime. Something that this Europe that always talks to us about its values should say it. It is true that seventy years later we still do not know whether it was a crime to bomb the phosphorus of civilians in Dresden, or perhaps the bomb dropped on the children of the Gorla school in Milan, but something, returning to current events, Europe should also have the courage to say. As Manzoni taught us, courage if one does not have it cannot be given, dear representative of the European Union, and you seem to me to be the very Don Abbondio of the situation.

name: Christos Stylianides
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice—President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, honourable Members, dear colleagues, thank you for this exchange and this wide consensus on the demand for a specific investigation. We expect specific results from that investigation. I would like to repeat that the European Union will continue to work with the National Unity Government during this difficult period. This is very important. We will stand at its side and we will do all we can to protect the gains made since the fall of the Taliban regime. I think this is most significant and it is a precondition for any progressive work on the ground in Afghanistan. Of course, all of us in this Parliament and in all the European institutions expect the results of the investigation as soon as possible. Thank you again for this discussion.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – Civil society organizations play a very important role in humanitarian aid. It can even be said that they are trying to make amends for the displeasures of governments. It is the specific policies of governments, also those of the European Union, that have led to the current situation in Afghanistan. Fundamentalism and violence are a consequence of inequality and poverty caused by our policies. Let us be consistent in our external action, be fair and supportive and stop impoverishing, apply international law and stop bombing.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE)
text: in writing. – In relation to the recent events in Kunduz, Afghanistan, in which 22 people were killed and more than 30 suffered severe injuries, I would like to express my deepest condolences. The information about that tragedy has shocked me, especially as it was performed by the alleged ‘warriors of human rights’. The hospital bombing was called ‘collateral damage’, and that is what worries me the most – that the developed West is not able to foresee the consequences of its actions and that, as a result, innocent people suffer and die. We are meant to protect human lives, therefore the protection of human rights and humanitarian law is essential. Unfortunately, instead of progress, I see regression in that regard. We need to take action to prevent such accidents from happening in the future, because this kind of situation is unacceptable. Once again, let me express my grief, and pay tribute to those who were killed and injured.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in Syria (2015/2870 (RSP)). It was originally planned that Minister Schmit would first speak for the Luxembourg Presidency on behalf of the Vice-President and High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. However, it has not yet arrived. The first and second scheduled speakers are also not in the Chamber. The third speaker has just arrived. If someone missed their slot here, I don't usually know a pardon. We are now making an exception for a few minutes and we shall start with the third speaker, Mr Tannock. Are you ready?

name: Charles Tannock
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, the level of political and military assistance now invested by Russia to support the brutal Assad regime ensures that neither of these actors can be ignored in seeking a solution to this bitter conflict. I have been highly critical of Russia’s actions in Ukraine in the past, but we cannot allow these difficulties to preclude working with Russia now in other areas of foreign policy where necessary. This was true of the nuclear agreement with Iran and is now true, sadly, of Syria. Reports that Russia is indiscriminately targeting areas of Syria that are known to be controlled by groups other than ISIS are a major concern to the West. Furthermore, as reports emerge suggesting that Russia will consider integrating its troops within battalions loyal to Assad, as rebel Syrian groups announce plans now to jointly fight Russian forces, and as Turkey cites violations of its airspace by the Russian air force, we are just beginning to comprehend the many effects, and the potential for conflagration of further war, that Russia’s latest moves could have. A will by the European Union to cut a deal, with a transitional role for Assad in exchange for immunity, is worth considering, however unpalatable that may appear. For me, the lesser of two evils ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Marietje Schaake
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I note with regret that there is no one to address here. I think it is a very important debate on Syria because the war in Syria must be stopped – and our Group has been calling for more EU leadership for years. We are paying a very high price for the lack of that. Not only is it unacceptable how many people continue to be killed – now with the help of Russian bombers – but it is equally unacceptable how little unity and leadership we have seen from the EU side. The High Representative should strive to find a common EU position and develop a comprehensive plan. Our Group wishes to see a political solution, and building on local ceasefires and ending the air raids on civilians should stop the bloodshed. No-fly zones are a part of ensuring that. I find it unacceptable that Russia and Saudi Arabia and now the US are taking diplomatic initiatives and that we are absent. Russia and Saudi Arabia are certainly no honest brokers, but can we be surprised that the vacuum we left was filled by others? While there are no simple solutions, there are certainties we cannot ignore. The needs of the millions of people on the run from Assad’s bombs and ISIS brutalities far exceed the funds available. We call on you to organise a major donor conference, which should contribute to much more serious commitment to refugees in the Middle East and to the countries hosting them. Also, military success often leads to an increase in refugee numbers. It is crucial to ensure there is anticipation and coordination: we need a comprehensive EU plan to end the war in Syria now.

name: Nicolas Schmit
text: President-in-Office of the Council, on behalf of the Vice—President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, honourable Members, the terrible conflict in Syria you just described is now in its fifth year, and at this point there is still little sign of peace on the horizon. That is unfortunately true. A quarter of a million people have been killed; 12 million – half of the country’s population – have been displaced. Four million of these have left to Lebanon, Jordan and Turkey, and as Europeans we are all aware that many of these refugees are now trying to reach Europe in search of peace and a more human life. Many are predicting new waves of refugees from inside Syria in the months to come. Europe has to handle the humanitarian consequences of this conflict, including the flows of refugees. A high-level conference on the Eastern Mediterranean and Western Balkans route takes place tomorrow in Luxembourg. We have spent EUR 4 billion so far, making us the biggest international donor and, faced with the additional flows of refugees this year, we are going to spend more. We will spend more on immediate aid for refugees, providing them with shelter and food, and we will also spend more on essential services such as health and education: an additional EUR 1 billion will be mobilised. The first contract opened through the new Trust Fund for Syria deals with schools and education. Syria is losing a whole generation to war and exile: only education can give a future to a whole country. We expect that, by the end of this year, the 500 million that we are putting into the fund will be matched by Member States’ contributions. It is a huge financial effort, reflecting the scale of the crisis. This effort will not in itself halt the refugee flow from Syria: only when there is hope for an end to the war and prospects to return home will the current refugee crisis head towards a conclusion. There is growing consensus in the international community that ending the Syrian war needs a two-track approach. This has been verified during a number of meetings over the past two weeks in New York and in Brussels. On the one hand, we need to successfully fight the terrorist threat of ISIL – or Daesh (a threat, by the way, which is spreading beyond the region) – and in parallel to this, we need to do all we can to support the political process led by the UN special envoy, Staffan de Mistura, to get the Syrians talking to each other again. On the fight against terrorism: the EU is not militarily involved, but we can and do actively support with non-military means the objectives of the global coalition against Daesh. Our engagement goes far, from reducing the threats of radicalisation and the recruitment of new foreign terrorist fighters in European countries to seeing what can be done to stop the flow of revenue to Daesh. But it is in supporting the UN-led peace efforts that the EU has most to contribute. Different regional and international actors have a substantial influence on the Syrian parties. They must assume their responsibilities and finally bring all the players to the table for serious negotiations. The EU is able to engage with all the relevant regional and international powers. We are talking to the Russians, the Iranians, the Saudis and the Turks. I think the Iranians understand that this is going to be their first test to see if they can play a more constructive role after the nuclear deal. The EU also underlines the importance of preserving state structures and functions, in order to ensure security, order and the provision of basic services to the people of Syria during a political transition. We can work on that together with the international community. Similarly, we can also make our contribution to bringing the different strands of the Syrian political and military opposition together behind a common vision and purpose. In July, representatives of the two main umbrella groups of the political opposition, the SOC and the NCC, met in Brussels, having been brought together by the High Representative. During the meeting they agreed a draft roadmap for the future political transition. None of this is going to be easy. The war in Syria is a very complex matter. It has multiple players with many diverging objectives. The latest phase has been marked by military escalation, both by Syrian and by non-Syrian participants. A military escalation in the civil war will lead nowhere: it will only prolong the agony of the conflict. Fighting terrorism is one thing – and in Syria that means fighting the groups defined as terrorists by the United Nations, including Daesh and Jabhat al-Nusra. It does not mean fighting alongside the regime in the civil war. That would only provoke a matching increase in the arms supplies by some regional powers to the opposition. There are measures that would promote de-escalation and peace, an end to the bombing and shelling of civilian areas and an end to the use of barrel bombs. Commitments of this kind could go a long way towards fostering sufficient trust to allow the beginnings of a real dialogue on transition. We can also intensify our humanitarian diplomacy. We can seek ways to provide access and protection, as well as to promote humanitarian principles and consensus on the guideline for the delivery of aid. As recalled by the European Council, the Union is committed to doing its part in supporting the UN-led efforts. I believe that, in the face of so much suffering on our doorstep, it is our duty to respond. You can count on our collective engagement on this. I thank you for your attention and look forward to hearing your views.

name: Elmar Brok
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for his excellent work and for Indeed, it is right that the European Union should do a great deal for refugees, to provide humanitarian aid. However, as we can see, not enough if we have looked at the food supply in the camps and Syria, and that the cuts by many Member States of the European Union have also led to the current refugee situation. But I don't want to focus on that now. Mr President-in-Office of the Council, you made it clear in the second part of your speech that we must bring about the peace process. If this does not succeed, everything else will have only a mitigating effect, but it will not be a solution to the matter. We have to see that we have a web of power-political interests that have made it difficult to bring this together. There is the struggle for regional power, particularly supported by Saudi Arabia and Iran, but also by Turkey's special, not entirely transparent, role in this matter. If it is not possible to bring these countries together and end the proxy war there, which is now threatening them, too, with the advent of Daish – because they must now have their own interest in finding a solution – then that will be nothing. But this also has to do with the great powers. I sometimes have the impression that the second level of proxy wars of the world powers Russia and America still plays a role. How far can Russia stabilize and expand its permanent position of power there? How can America prevent this? That's another level where you don't get together. I believe that the crucial role of the European Union must come into play here. We must work with Russia and America – and this has nothing to do with the Ukraine crisis, that we have to give in – as we have done on the issue of Iran's nuclear weapons. In order to find a solution at this level, to bring together the regional cocks and to find a solution. These two levels must be put together, and I believe it is crucial to achieve this. I have the impression that this is not enough so far. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Sabine Lösing
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the As early as 2012, voices around the US government warned of the possible consequences of militarizing the then-protest movement against Syrian leader Assad. But what happened? This is precisely what is being supported by the European people, including Western ones. A 2012 U.S. intelligence report predicted the emergence of the Islamic State. The real scandal, however, is that the report clearly states that this is in the interests of Turkey, Saudi Arabia, but also the Western states, in order to isolate Assad. Every means was right for assad's overthrow. Apparently, the strengthening of the radical Islamist forces was also accepted, even actively promoted. Now the proxy war in Syria threatens to degenerate into a conflagration. The left calls for an immediate end to all air bombing in Syria. Peace cannot be fought militarily, either with or without a UN mandate, regardless of whether the bombs are taken from ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Alyn Smith
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, in the tragedy that is Syria it is difficult to know where to start: 310 000 people killed, countless more lives ruined through injury or bereavement, 4.5 million refugees, seven million internally displaced people. With the scale of this tragedy there is little wonder that the humanitarian consequences are quite literally washing up on our shores and I very much echo comments of colleagues on the humanitarian consequences of this tragedy. Our Group has always stressed that the only solution in Syria, the only way in which we can create a safe environment for people to return to, is a political solution. There was a time when concerted intervention by the international community could have helped, but we remain deeply sceptical on current air strikes against the so-called Islamic State. We have seen 7 000 US strikes, and we now see informal US, UK and French engagement, but to little avail. We are tackling the symptoms, rather than the cause.  Adam Garfinkle, a US diplomat turned academic, has criticised US policy on ISIS, and I think his criticism applies to French and British policy also. Tackling ISIS is akin to thinking that you can alter the position of a shadow by doing things to the shadow. We are not tackling the right things. Likewise, we should not be fooled by the actions of Russia in this conflict. Sergei Ivanov, the Kremlin’s Chief of Staff, says, and I quote: ‘The military aim of our operations will exclusively be to provide air support to Syrian Government forces in the struggle against ISIS.’ Yet Russian attacks have been in areas with no ISIS presence – against Free Syrian Army positions in Latakia, Homs, Hama and even Aleppo.  The Assad regime has killed eight times more people than ISIS. This Parliament hosted the Caesar exhibition, evidence of brutal torture by this regime. Assad is not a partner in peace. He is the primary obstacle to it and we must not drift towards the Assad regime in order to try to build a viable peace. We must facilitate a wider international engagement and raise our game.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Syria 2015, the balance of power in the Middle East is measured on the ground of this never-ending proxy war.  No one is prepared to give in to what is now a stalemate, neither Russia, which wants to avoid yet another pro-NATO regime change and maintain its bases in the Mediterranean, nor Iran, which does not want to lose its allied principality, even though perhaps after the nuclear agreement it will be more malleable, let alone the United States, France and Great Britain. , terrified of the idea of acknowledging yet another strategic defeat, neither Saudi Arabia nor the Sunni Gulf states would have much to recriminate about their support for Islamist militias.  The UN is powerless, the EU does not yet know exactly what line to take. The solution, ladies and gentlemen, is not Assad, but it cannot but pass through an agreement with Assad and those who support him, if we want to be realistic. If many had realised this before, perhaps the war would not have lasted four years, we would not have had millions of refugees and we would not be in a seemingly no-go drama. Will you understand this before a proxy war degenerates more or less unintentionally into an Iran-Arabia war or, worse, a third world war?

name: Matteo Salvini
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all, I wonder where Mrs Mogherini is supposed to represent us, she obviously has other commitments.  Secondly, I say thank you to Russia, which is the only one that is defending the principles of peace and coexistence by force where it is needed, and I would like to ask my fellow Members whether anyone really thinks that they are talking to Islamic cutthroats, whether anyone realistically thinks that those who cruciate and burn live in people can be the subject of dialogue. It is clear to all those who want to understand that there is forced Islamisation going on, because otherwise, instead of doing thousands of kilometres, they could be housed in Saudi Arabia, in the Gulf countries that have space, that have money, that have wealth, that have cultural affinities, it is obviously a forced process.  Today is October 7, October 7, 1571 thanks to the Venetians, Europe and Christianity were saved by as many forced Islamizations. I would not like what we avoided centuries ago to happen today with the complicity of this useless and absent Parliament.  (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Alyn Smith (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card question. – Mr President, I am grateful to the colleague for giving way. Mr Salvini, I rise to give you a point of information that perhaps did not reach you: Mrs Mogherini has communicated to our services that she is ill presently and that is why she is absent. So perhaps you would care to withdraw your rather ungentlemanly remarks made earlier.

name: n/a
text: answer "blue card".   The problem for Mrs Mogherini, whom I wish best, is that even when she is well and present, she is absent, she is totally useless to herself and to the citizens she should represent, so, hoping that she will recover soon, I also hope that there will be someone who actually represents the interests of the European Union in the world, not just with a telephone call when things have already happened. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI)
text: Blue card question. - I'm going to ask you a substantive question. I agree that Russia should be seen as an important player in this settlement. However, we know that Russia is clearly seeking to restore President Assad's power. Do you see an opportunity for stability and peace when many people have just fled president Assad? So do you see an opportunity for President Assad to remain in power, even limitedly?

name: Matteo Salvini (ENF)
text: answer "blue card". Mr President, I am replying to you with the words of a Christian priest who has fled Syria not from Assad but from islamic terrorists who tells me That Assad is not the best, we are all convinced, Isis is worse. If someone in this room puts Assad on an equal footing and Isis needs to be treated and hospitalized because it's dangerous.

name: Diane Dodds (NI).
text: – Mr President, after a very shaky start it is good to see this debate get off the ground. The situation in Syria is certainly one of the most pressing of our time, and a redoubling of efforts must focus on the core of the problem: a Syria ruled by a brutal dictator, and the fanatical evil of ISIL, who are not only destroying the ancient heritage of Syria but also murdering its people and targeting groups of Christians and other minorities in a most brutal, almost medieval, fashion – certainly something that we have not experienced in a long time. The manifestation of this is a flood of people displaced to surrounding nations and now to Europe. Mr Schmit, you outlined some of the efforts in relation to Europe and this terrible humanitarian crisis, but you did not outline any of the pressures that you are putting on the surrounding states in the Gulf to do much more to help in this difficult situation. There are many of us who believe that ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Cristian Dan Preda (PPE).
text: Mr President, in my opinion, Russia's military intervention is very bad news because it is a further weakening of the situation at a time when we are extremely concerned about the source of this wave of migration to Europe. The main source, of course, is Syria.  The Russian intervention has a very clear objective, which is to support Assad. That is the fundamental objective. This military intervention, under these conditions, only produces, in a very clear way, more refugees. I consider that, politically, this intervention by Russia is a complication of the crisis and a gesture directed against Europe, in an extremely clear way.  I believe that we should not be under any illusions, this is not the first time that Russia has acted solo and that is why some people believe that Ukraine and Syria should be put on the same level, because Russia acts without consultation with other international actors.  Before this intervention, we had discussed the possibility of significant diplomatic advances, but they were cut short and Russia acted militarily. Therefore, what we can do now, in my view, is to redouble our efforts from a diplomatic point of view. On the other hand, I am very concerned that this military intervention has already violated the airspace of Turkey, which is a member of NATO. So what is at stake now is also the strength of our transatlantic alliance, a decisive element in this conflict.  When I see colleagues here who defend Putin's pacifism, I have the impression that they live in Moscow and not in Europe. I'm really sorry to witness this. I believe that it is absolutely necessary to work in the direction of diplomacy, but by no means to support this military intervention by Russia.

name: Richard Howitt (S&D).
text: – Mr President, as so often in this Chamber and its like, we have wrestled with the escalation of conflict in the Middle East through the emergence of proxy war. Now, with the Russian intervention in Syria and the potential for a clash in its airspace, we face the danger of the biggest proxy war of all. Little did we think, in debating the possible setting up of a no-fly zone, that the planes that could be shot down would be big jets from Moscow. Little did we think, in debating how to combat the problem of foreign fighters, that they could be so-called volunteers in uniforms with or without the insignia of the Russian army. Everyone involved in the Iran talks says that Russia undertook a constructive role in spite of the disagreement over Ukraine. Everyone involved in the Syria crisis believes that Iranian and Russian interests must be made to be part of the solution, rather than part of the problem.  I went to Tehran with the Committee on Foreign Affairs in connection with the nuclear talks and I have taken on the rapporteurship on Iran because I believe in the power of diplomacy. However difficult it might seem, that must today apply to Russia too. Some will say that this week’s dramatic events risk simply exposing Europe’s powerlessness. Today we have to say that bold diplomacy could be a sign of strength, not of weakness, just as much as the dropping of bombs – and, I think, more so.  Today this Parliament must call for Europe to engage in that bold diplomacy and, in doing so, call on others to respond in kind.  What are the fundamental principles that must guide our action? That there must be a political transition in Syria to end the situation as it is today, but not to return to the one as it was yesterday; that there is less, rather than more, consensus over an alternative future and that this should urgently inform our discussions; that an imperfect and painful political solution, which genuinely sought to be inclusive, was ultimately possible in Iraq and can be in Syria too; that there is no purely military solution to this war; that there is a common foe in terrorism – so let us have an honest debate on how it can be combatted and genuine common efforts to do so; and that civilians are being endangered, when all efforts should be towards their protection. My party supports the creation of humanitarian safe havens … (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Anna Elżbieta Fotyga (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by A few days ago, the united nations declared the success of the international community, its mobilisation in resolving the terrible crisis in Syria. For us Member States of the European Union, in addition to aggression in Ukraine, this crisis is one of the greatest threats to our security. Russia has brought to this agreement in the form of an intelligence-sharing agreement with Iran, Assad's Syria and Iraq. However, this information does not appear to work. The way Russia is involved, the way the airstrikes are being executed, shows that, in fact, the majority is being destroyed by the moderate opposition, the non-Islamist opposition to the Assad regime. The Deputy Defence Minister demanded the withdrawal of US troops from airspace and the provision of intelligence... The President took the speaker's vote.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE).
text: Mr President, the situation has never been so inextricable and dangerous in Syria, with fighting that will continue, probably even intensify, with ever more deaths and more injuries, with every international power and every regional power playing its own game, which is there for its own account on the ground, to defend its own interests always at odds with those of others.  Of course, the Russian intervention will be a game-changer. It will probably see the relationship evolve and change on the ground, but it will also lead to a stronger mobilization - I am thinking in particular of Saudi Arabia - to support the opponents and, therefore, again, more deaths and more war. Add to this the prospect of a unified Syria receding. In the face of this situation, what can we do? What should we do? Europe is sorely absent when it is very concerned, in particular, because of all the refugees who want to join us. It is only time that we made our voices heard. We will have to work to find a solution to the conflict, to work with all stakeholders in three directions.  First, an agreement must be reached urgently between the major American and Russian powers, in particular, to fight effectively against Daesh. Secondly, work must be made towards a political transition in Syria that guarantees the existence of minorities and the establishment of a confederal regime. Thirdly, if we are to find a lasting solution to the conflict, the various countries involved must be able to preserve their vital interests in the solution to the conflict.  It is only time for Europe to make its voice heard.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, from the outset we have denounced the financing, training, supply of weapons to terrorist groups to overthrow a government which may or may not like it, but is legitimate according to international law. Although we already know that some people don't care about international legality.  In the Committee on Foreign Affairs, I asked the head of the coalition against the Islamic State why he coordinated with the Iraqi government and not with the Syrian government. He didn't answer me. We may or may not like it, but Russia's operation is legal according to international law: it has consulted its Senate at the request of a government. I therefore find it insulting that representatives of the United States or NATO are asking that opponents such as the Al Qaeda and Al Nusra-formed Army of Conquest not be attacked. You want me to remember how many people died on March 11, 2004 and who killed them?  Let's go back to Geneva. A United Nations-led international coalition and elections, of course, but not including terrorists.

name: James Carver (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, as we have seen this week, Russia has grasped the opportunity to shore up her Middle East ally through supportive airstrikes, whilst reminding us of President Putin’s potential to commit large troop numbers to Syria. To further complicate matters, we must also consider reports that some Chinese military personnel will soon be arriving on the scene. We must wake up and smell the coffee. The West is now on the back foot with these two permanent members of the UN Security Council potentially set not just to fight against Islamic State in Syria but also possibly to change the balance of power in the Middle East, if they can determine a serious post-war settlement. The lack of ability in the West to formulate a long-term strategic plan has left us with a stark choice of whether or not we are now happy to see President Assad remain in power. Whatever the eventual outcome, the political dynamics of the Middle East may well be about to change for the foreseeable future. From what I am hearing today, it seems to me that all you can do is mumble something into your coffee.

name: Marcel de Graaff (ENF).
text: – After years of desperate fighting, Russia and Syria have now taken up arms against IS. This could be the deciding factor in the destruction of this enemy of humanity. But is the war in Syria a problem for the EU, as it allows hundreds of thousands of migrants to pour into the EU? Are they coming here to flee the war? No, absolutely not, because syrians who have fled have been living safely in Turkey, Jordan or Lebanon for many years. The problem is free money, free care and a free home in Germany and other EU member states. The problem is that the EU does not close its internal and external borders. It is precisely on this day when we commemorate the battle of Lepanto that we are firmly opposed to the abolition of visa requirements for Turkey. It opens the door to an even greater influx of unwanted economic migrants and the Islamisation of the EU. The Commission must take an example from Prime Minister Orbán who knows how to deal with this invasion. We need barbed wire and surveillance of our national borders to prevent European countries from breaking down with the urge to destroy Islam.

name: Udo Voigt (NI).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Two months ago, at the invitation of the Syrian Government, I had the opportunity to visit Syria and to see what was going on on the ground. It was the high representatives of the Orthodox Church, the Anglican and Armenian Churches who pleaded with hand to finally stop giving special rights to Christian refugees. Because Christians are not persecuted in Syria. They have never been persecuted, and they have lived peacefully with Muslims there for centuries. We are now witnessing a new view of duplicity in this House. Four days of deployment by the Russian Air Force – and there is already talk of bombing and the victims. Who is talking about the victims of the Turkish air force, the American air force, whose attacks all have only one aim, which is to support ISIS? The Islamic State must be hit there, on the ground. I welcome the use of the Russian ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Arnaud Danjean (PPE).
text: Mr President, for the past two weeks, two new countries have been intervening militarily in the Syrian chaos for obviously different reasons but all justified by the fight against terrorism. France and Russia are conducting strikes, which unfortunately will not bring a solution to the Syrian conflict. No one here should deny the grave threat posed by Islamist terrorist groups in Syria, the first of which, of course, the doomed Islamic State, but we must also be well aware that no military action will lead to a solution if it does not fit into a much more comprehensive diplomatic and political framework that goes far beyond the Syrian or counter-terrorism framework. Don't get me wrong. We are only in Syria facing one phenomenon among others of the total recomposition of the Middle East with dividing lines that cross, certainly Syria, but also Iraq, and also Yemen. In the face of this considerable challenge, diplomatic mobilization must include all regional actors. The European Union, at its modest level, we must be aware of this, must above all focus on helping to bring together countries that have divergent interests and ulterior motives that are deadly for the region. Everyone knows that the backdrop of this Syrian conflict is the tectonic rivalry, between Shiites and Sunnis, between Iran and Saudi Arabia. It is this rapprochement that we must work towards, modestly but with great determination, and there is no other way out of a conflict that will last for years.  (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph, 8 of the regulation))

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Would you agree with me that really the only concerns that anyone from the EU should have regarding Syria are (a) to make sure that any support is given to anyone who is trying to crush ISIS – the greatest threat currently out there – and (b) to ensure that the current mass flow of migrants, uncontrolled, into the EU is somehow stemmed and brought under control? All else is neo—imperialism. We should not be concerned with anything but those two factors.

name: Arnaud Danjean (PPE)
text: "blue card" answer to Bill Etheridge. It is normal for European governments to want to face the immediacy of the impact of the Syrian crisis, that is to say, two things: terrorism and refugees. It is normal that we want to react to these two elements that directly impact us.  But you will not dry up the flow of refugees or terrorism solely through ad hoc military actions. If you do not have diplomatic action to work on the recomposition of this Middle East, with Iran and Saudi Arabia, you will not dry up these two tragic phenomena.

name: Liisa Jaakonsaari (S&D).
text: – Mr President, at this stage of the debate it is good to repeat the brutal figures, a quarter of a million dead, one million wounded, four to six million people have left their homes and, globally, one in four refugees is from Syria. Here is root cause, the root cause of the European migrant and refugee crisis. It is quite right what has been demanded here. Leadership is now required of the European Union and we must put pressure on the United States and Russia in order to find a solution. Mr Howitt's idea and example of diplomacy in the Iran issue shows that progress can be made on this issue too.  Europe's crisis management policy is inconsistent. On the one hand, it is true that Europe is the world's largest donor of humanitarian aid, but on the other hand, European arms technology and European weapons are exported. On the other hand, walls are indeed being built. We have to get rid of the inconsistency!

name: Bas Belder (ECR).
text: – The military deployment of Russia and Iran on the Syrian battlefield is evident. The legitimacy for this is the reign of terror of Bashar al-Assad. Russia and Iran have been able to impose their geopolitical game, including on the west. However, the objectives of Moscow and Tehran go far beyond the Syrian battlefield. Neighbouring countries are experiencing this directly. The EU must therefore step up defensive cooperation with the State of Israel, for the sake of its own security interests. The destabilising terrorist activities of the Iranian Revolutionary Guard on the Golan Heights - I have seen this myself - speak for themselves here. That's the flip side of the bad deal, the bad nuclear deal with the Islamic Republic of Iran: self-delusion on the Western side.  (The speaker is prepared to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162(8) of the Rules)).

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Dear colleague, you spoke in your speech that the European Union should step up its military cooperation with Israel, and I have not heard a word about diplomacy and negotiation. Do you think it's important who kills? Is it not more important for the European Union to strengthen its cooperation with all states through negotiation and diplomacy and not militarily?

name: Bas Belder (ECR)
text: "blue card" answer. – I am well introduced about what Israel is doing in the region. It is the only stable country still in the region at the moment and Jordan is in fact hoping for Israel. In short, the Israelis have many diplomatic contacts and they are certainly not sitting still. The point is: where do we start and where do we try to maintain stability and then expand further? And what I see here in this House is that we are focusing on Israel as if Israel were the problem. No, the problems lie elsewhere and they are not mentioned here, unfortunately.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE).
text: – First of all, it is important for the European Union to come out of the lethargy where it has been in recent years on the Syria issue and take a clear political initiative to end the war by offering solutions. The fact that Russia has taken action in Syria should not be a surprise to anyone. We have been too surprised by Russia's behaviour in recent years, be it the invasion of Georgia, the annexation of Crimea, the invasion of eastern Ukraine - now the intervention in Syria.  While the European Union discusses, analyses and thinks, we must already solve the biggest humanitarian crisis of this century in the form of refugees. People are fleeing both the Assad regime and Islamic State extremists. As soon as possible, the creation of no-fly zones in Syria must be made and a donor conference to assist Syrian refugees must be convened as soon as possible. It is a fact that Russia is attacking anyone who is against Assad, and not just ISIL. At the same time, the premise of some sort of viable solution to end the Syrian war is only cooperation, not the satisfaction of the ambitions of one country's global confrontation at the expense of the Syrian people.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, there is a saying in my country that says 'look at what I say, don't look at what I do'. So I take this opportunity to ask, for the umpth time, the question I have already asked in this House, and which is very simple: is there or will there ever be concerted action by the European institutions and European governments to not just condemn, but a moratorium on arms sales to the conflicting territories? Will there be a moratorium on the purchase of oil from territories occupied by the Islamic State? Yes or no? It's very simple. We have responsibilities, we are excellent at talking about others, giving moral lessons and how to do it, let's look at our responsibilities. Mr. Schmit, if you can answer this question once you are, please do so. What are we going to do about the arms embargo and oil purchases?

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser (ENF).
text: Mr President, in Syria, to see our Western position sinking into ridicule would be a smile if a tragedy did not unfold before our eyes and if France did not also become ridiculous.  There is the elected government of Bashar al-Assad, leading an army of Syrian conscripts against various foreign and terrorist groups: the Islamic State, the al-Nusra Front, the local branch of Al Qaeda, and the so-called free but foreign-backed Syrian army.  On the one hand a legitimate army, a nation, on the other a conglomerate of warlords of at least 84 nationalities armed by the Gulf States and the West, with a new category, the soft Islamists, until they become tough, when they turn against us because they escape us, armed and seasoned by us.  You criticize Russia's resolute policy, but this policy finally dares to resolve the Syrian dilemma, to get out of barbarism by restoring the legitimate state to rebuild. Russia once again saves the values of the West, betrayed by us.  (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 149, paragraph 8 of the regulation)).

name: Jean-Paul Denanot (S&D)
text: "blue card" question. "Sir, do you approve of the abuses carried out by the regime of Bashar al-Assad?"

name: Jean-Luc Schaffhauser (ENF)
text: "blue card" answer. "First of all, there is propaganda, and you know it very well. We started by saying, even before the Russians had bombed, that they had bombed positions in support of Bashar al-Assad. Of course, this is all propaganda, but, having said that, we are certainly dealing with a regime that is not democratic. We have to choose between, on the one hand, Al Qaeda and the Islamic State or, on the other hand, a legitimate state. The choice must be made for the legitimate state.

name: Мария Габриел (PPE).
text: – Mr President, what has not yet been said about the conflict in Syria? It seems to me that today we need to continue to concentrate on the new elements in order to be able to participate constructively in this debate. I'il only turn three. Yes, first of all, two new countries have positioned themselves. But it is very important for us that the international community, not setting conditions but in constant dialogue and partnership, continues to seek a solution to the conflict. In our efforts, too, let us not lose the question of syria's territorial integrity. Next, yes, Islamic State is a common problem. But most importantly, ISIS poses a serious threat to the disintegration and radicalization of the region. Therefore, a clear and concrete commitment of the countries of the region would contribute to improving coordination and providing a perspective on a way out of the crisis. Finally, the role of the European Union. Our role is through our diplomacy to be a balancer in the difficult and possibly long process of redistribution of influence in the region. This is our strong point in this conflict, considering the realities.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Russia's intervention in aid of Assad, which is the source of the conflict and will never be part of the solution, is perfidious because, on the pretext of attacking terrorists, it is bombing patriots and the Syrian people. But it is also a reflection of the European Union's failure to commit to ending the war, involving Syrian minorities and regional powers, and to combat Islamic State terrorism. In Iraqi Kurdistan, where I returned last month, Member States do not coordinate either to articulate humanitarian and development aid, to secure schools in refugee camps, nor to train, equip and diplomatically support the Peshmerga, who are the only troops on the ground containing Daexe in Iraq, although the Baghdad Government continues to pay salaries in Mosul , to yield fees to Daexe, and in Syria, where the Kurds are treacherously bombed by Erdogan's Turkey. When the nuclear agreement with Iran paves the way for peace for Syria and Yemen, implying that Saudi Arabia is facing the consequences of its duplicity, European governments continue to boycott the Common Foreign and Security Policy and the Common Security and Defence Policy. They thus feed the causes of the exodus of ... (The President withdraws the floor to the speaker.)

name: n/a
text: After four years of civil war, Assad controls only a quarter of his territory. His armies are exhausted, decimated, demoralized. For Damascus, the Russian military intervention comes as a blessing, just in time. For the region's geopolitical superpowers, however, Putin's bombs are a curse. With his air strikes, President Putin wants to point to the failure of Western action in the Middle East. The moderate rebels, who were trained with the support of the anti-IS coalition, are also his enemies. But he also wants to hit the Gulf states for keeping oil prices low. Donbass is in ruins. Ukraine is nestling with Europe for good. It is clear that Putin is looking for a new story to perpetuate the cult around his person and to show what the Kremlin's new modus operandi is from now on. And the west is losing credibility and soft power. We shouldn't be involved in games like this. Cooperation between all geopolitical players is therefore the only way to both get IS small and get Assad out. Finally, let us not forget which torturer and mass murderer Moscow supports.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF).
text: Mr President, the current dire situation in Syria is a direct consequence of the crazy policy pursued by Brussels and most Western chancelleries over the past five years. Open or more discreet support to armed terrorist groups, closure of our embassies in Damascus, breakdown of all security cooperation with Syrian services, refusal to support the Syrian authorities in their fight against terrorism, bombing alongside the United States in violation of international law, the list of errors is too long to leave any legitimacy to the will to influence the current situation. Russia has chosen, at the request of the legitimate Syrian authorities and in accordance with international law, to intervene vigorously against terrorism in Syria. We should be pleased that the Russians are finally doing the job that we did not want or knew how to do. It was time, and the demonstrations of joy of the Syrians in Damascus celebrating the arrival of Russian troops are the best illustration of the inadequacy of your policy.  (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: "blue card" question. Ms Arnautu, do you not think that Russia's intervention has complicated things in Syria? At the same time, this war does not bring peace or the resolution of the situation in that country.  Do you not believe that we need an international conference with all internal, external and regional actors to finally succeed in bringing about peace in Syria?

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: "blue card" answer. "Dear Colleague, what I would like to say to you is that we must also listen to the testimonies of the Syrian people. She's tired of this war, of these indiscriminate bombings by terrorist groups. The Syrians want peace and want their future to end - and I think that is the most important thing - to be decided in Washington or Riyadh. Believe me, but you probably also know, with a little intellectual honesty, until now, the Syrian people have felt very lonely and well abandoned by all. (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – Is my colleague actually trying to tell us that all the mess that we are seeing around the world now in relation to Syria – with 10 million people becoming refugees, with a quarter of a million who have been killed – is the fault of the EU?

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: "blue card" answer. "My dear colleague, I will not make you the affront of thinking that you have not understood what I have said. You know very well that you don't. I am simply saying that we must respect the sovereignty of the peoples, that, of course, this has been said many times, we cannot endorse everything that is happening in the Syrian regime, but that, nevertheless, we are facing a fundamental problem. We must choose and fight against this Islamic state. Everybody knows it, everybody says it. So I'm just saying that we don't always have to have that interference with other states. That's what I'm saying.

name: Francisco José Millán Mon (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Syria has returned to the present day because of the refugee crisis and the sudden increase in Russian military presence. They are already more than four years of conflict, more than two hundred and fifty thousand dead, twelve million displaced.  The conflict has been aggravated by the prominence achieved by fundamentalist forces, especially the so-called Daesh. Fighting Daesh has to be one of the essential goals. We should all prioritize that goal. The Russians, too. But today it seems that Russian military escalation is primarily aimed at strengthening Al-Asad's regime. Hopes, ajar for the recent meeting in New York between Obama and Putin, of coordination of efforts to end the conflict for now have not been fulfilled. It seems clear, in any case, that, in the last fortnight, Russia has taken the lead and does not act in accordance with the broad US-led international coalition. Ladies and gentlemen, I believe that a political solution to the conflict does not seem close. Many actors are involved and with divergent positions, but a solution is increasingly needed and in the meantime the efforts of the United Nations special envoy need to be supported... (The Chair withdrew the floor to the speaker)

name: Ioan Mircea Paşcu (S&D).
text: – Mr President, with Russia’s direct military intervention in Syria, the two major challenges to the EU – Ukraine and ISIL – and the refugee crisis converge. In reality, Russia is fighting alongside Assad against all its opponents, consolidating his regime and intensifying the refugee exodus while clearing the way on the ground for ISIL. Apart from consolidating its bridgehead and demonstrating a big power status, Russia’s intervention is attempting to deflect attention from Ukraine, where the implementation of the Minsk II Agreement is directly linked to the lifting of sanctions, which they hope to achieve through the current stalemate. However, Russia has simultaneously intensified its activism in Moldova – not militarily, in view of the firm reaction to what it is doing in Ukraine, but by orchestrating a so-called ‘popular protest’ against the pro-European coalition.  This so-called ‘popular protest’ is only a prelude to a direct move against the current government, the aim being to replace it with a pro-Russian one thus ending Moldova’s European aspiration. With Ukraine and Georgia territorially crippled and with Moldova in the balance, what are the prospects for the ...  (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Sandra Kalniete (PPE).
text: – For a week now, Russian planes have been bombing Assad's opponents in Syria. For several weeks now, since Putin has instructed the separatists in Donbas not to shoot and pretend to be fulfilling the Minsk ceasefire.   Putin's main goal in Syria is Europe. He is offering Europe a deal on Ukraine, or Russian forces will further destabilise the Middle East and the flow of refugees to Europe will grow.   Putin wants an agreement with the West on his terms, but Europe must not allow such a deal.   An international political solution in Syria must be sought regardless of Putin's avant-gare in Ukraine. And the main partners in this solution are Syria's neighbours, together with the European Union, the US and also Russia.   The hybrid war against Ukraine must be halted regardless of the outcome of russia's military advances in Syria. Thank you!

name: Afzal Khan (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the Syrian crisis is the root of two of the most serious global problems right now: the refugee crisis and the threat posed by ISIS. Russia’s latest moves in Syria are not helpful. They are likely to lead to more and prolonged suffering for the Syrian people. Alleviating those global problems requires tackling them at the source, so we need a policy that (a) stems the killing in Syria, the majority of which is the result of the brutal Assad regime’s aerial bombardment, (b) reduces the humanitarian impact, including slowing the exodus, (c) combats extremism, and (d) leads to a political solution. We need to engage Russia and Iran to find a solution urgently. A no-fly zone is the first step to turning the crisis around. It is the only policy option that saves lives, reduces the exodus, reduces radicalisation, and also makes a political solution more likely.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I wish to make three points. In trying to avoid direct involvement in the Syrian crisis the EU has ended up in the role of Good Samaritan, taking care of the results of that catastrophe. I think it is now time to invest in solutions, and these involve, firstly, no-fly zones and safe areas on the ground, as well as an international donors’ conference. Second, Putin and Assad have lost all credibility. They are not part of the solution: they are part of the problem. Trying to oust ISIS with the help of Assad or Putin means ousting the devil with the help of Beelzebub. Third, a red line for the EU should be that a solution in Syria cannot be reached at the cost of weakening support for the integrity of Ukraine or watering down the Minsk criteria. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Mrs Koneen, please ask your question!  (Mr. Tannock protested because he thought the president would not allow any more questions about the "blue card")) Mr Tannock, I would like to thank Mr Tannock for his I said earlier that if I take someone's floor, I do not give blue cards because I do not want to reward someone who exceeds their speaking time by getting a blue card. When you spoke for the second time, I had to withdraw the speaker from speaking on the first intermediate question because he had exceeded 30 seconds. Mr Kelam ended his speech on time. That is why We are now allowed to ask the question to Mrs Koneen.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – Dear colleague, let me ask you, if you are saying clearly that Putin and Assad are not the solution in the region, who do you think the solution is? Because Russian planes are the only ones fighting in Syria in accordance with international law, they are the only ones who have asked legitimate governments if they can fight at all. This consent was never s requested by the Western coalition, and it has always acted only from a position of arrogant power. So who is the solution in Syria if you don't think it's even a legitimately elected current president?

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE)
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you for giving me the opportunity to explain. I think Mr Assad’s Government has lost any legitimacy, and Mr Putin never asked the UN to start his military operation in this area. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 149(8)).

name: Liisa Jaakonsaari (S&D)
