text: blue card question. – Thank you for the analytical speech. I was a little confused by the deep pessimism you had in relation to finding diplomatic solutions. Do you see any possibility of a constructive role such as Iran, which Russia could play here too?

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE)
text: blue-card answer. – I am absolutely not against a diplomatic solution, but what I tried to explain is that the EU missed out on the opportunity to be actively involved in a diplomatic solution four years ago. We have just been observing the problem, and we are not providing enough aid to help refugees. I am fully for a diplomatic solution, but it cannot be reached with the help of, or by counting on, murderers like Assad.

name: Arne Lietz (S&D).
text: Mr President, Mr Schmit, I would like to thank mr Schmit for his excellent work and for his excellent work. The agreement with Iran has shown that diplomatic efforts can succeed, even if they seem almost hopeless. We must also keep this lesson in mind for the civil war in Syria. We need a political process that brings all parties to the conflict together. Only in this way can we stop the murder. Only a political solution will allow Syrians to live in peace with each other again. Russia's unilateral military intervention is nothing new. I have been pointing out in this House for months that Russia is holding its protective hand over Assad and must be involved in resolving the conflict. This has nothing to do with giving in to sanctions on Ukraine. It is catastrophic that President Putin is now also actively interfering in the civil war. Russia is allowing Assad to continue to terrorize the population of entire cities with barrel bombs on a daily basis. This must stop! We must not forget that it is, in particular, this terror of the Assad regime that has driven millions of Syrians to flee their homeland and continues to drive them. Thank you very much for the diplomatic efforts of the High Representative.

name: Andrzej Grzyb (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by You, Minister, said that "The enormous scale of suffering at the gates of Europe must end." We fully agree with this assessment. Yesterday we had a debate about the huge wave of refugees in Europe. We talked about assessing the last summit of 23 September. What is missing from this answer is, of course, what we are trying to find an answer to today, because the cause of this great migration crisis is, among other things, Syria. We are trying to resolve this with the international community, including regional actors who have different interests. It doesn't work out for us. Russia is also involved, but we also remember that perhaps this will also be part of the solutions in Ukraine. We wouldn't want that. The Assad regime is responsible for the current crisis, because the refugees present are those who were driven out as a result of the crisis two years ago. We must at all costs strive to end the war, terror, the power of the Islamic State, because the suffering is horrific – even the suffering of a 12-year-old Christian boy who has been crucified.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that Russia's initiative will neither resolve nor resolve the conflict with the Islamic State.  We have a credibility, we Europe, we EU, especially with the leadership of Federica Mogherini, have a role and a function to spend in the coming weeks and months, because we need to return to politics, to diplomacy. Actions and armies are not enough. We need to resume a dialogue with the United States, Russia and the states in the region in order to restore balance and ensure three fundamental things. An unceasing initiative to defeat Isis militarily and politically throughout the area.  Secondly, to ensure a transitional period. We need, we know from the history of these months and years, that leaving gaps, Libya teaches us there, means opening the door, say, to other solutions. So we need to ensure a transition and that needs Assad and beyond Assad. And finally, the great theme of refugees...  (The President withdrew the speaker)

name: Michael Gahler (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I do not believe that we Europeans have different interests on the Syrian issue. My assessment is rather that we are essentially in agreement, but have not yet drawn the conclusion of doing more than providing humanitarian aid or taking in nolens volens refugees. It is now urgent to have all global and regional stakeholders at the same table. The status quo is not sustainable for the people of Syria, for their neighbours or for global actors. It is therefore not helpful for Russia to bomb in favour of the Assad regime, which is the main cause of people's flight. Even if I were to take into account Russian interests at Latakia airport or at the port of Tartus, I am convinced that there can be no future for Assad at the end of a negotiation process. The vast majority of Syrians will not accept this, even though here in the European Parliament he has support from the far right and the left.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE).
text: – Mr. President, Minister Schmidt, thank you for your opening statements and I hope that the Council will have quality conclusions next week when you discuss Syria. There is no doubt that the war in Syria is a major focal point in the Middle East and a major pressing focal point in our neighbourhood policy. 250,000 killed, 4 million refugees, eight million displaced persons who are part of the generator of the refugee-émigré crisis that destabilizes the foundations of the European Union. All regional actors are involved in this conflict – Turkey, Iran, Saudi Arabia. Of course there is also a conflict between Shiites and Sunnis fueled by the brutality of the Islamic State that we must all fight.  Russia's intervention apparently has 3 goals: one is to sustain the Assad regime with attacks on other groups in Syria as well, the other is to make a rivalry with the U.S.-led international coalition and other Western states, and the third is to find a Russian-led solution, which is not to allow the overthrow of authoritarian regimes. In this context, the European Union must play a key political and diplomatic role, support Staffan de Mistura and return to a diplomatic solution that can only be the solution ... (The President interrupted the speaker)

name: László Tőkés (PPE).
text: – Mr President, my sincere appreciation to Father Andrzej Halemba, who is providing ecclesiastical humanitarian assistance in the country of refugees in Syria. In his opinion, it should be helped not only by emigrants, but also by those who want to stay at home. Politicians are meant to create the conditions for this. President Lech Wałęsa, drawing parallels with former refugees of communism, also argued in a statement in favour of staying at home. Like many of his compatriots, he did not leave his country to change his position and fight for a liveable future. Syria can't move to Europe. The real solution is not emigration, but the settlement of the political situation, the creation of peace and security. It is not the right to emigrate, but the right of the people of Syria to their homeland.

name: Ελένη Θεοχάρους (PPE).
text: Madam President, the repeated mis choices made by the United States and the inability of the European Union to exercise a credible common foreign and defence policy did not cover the democratic deficit of the Assad regime, did not make up for the terrible civil war in Syria, and thus allowed the giant ISIS to cause thousands of casualties, enormous destruction and a major humanitarian crisis. With Turkey's hypocritical and hypocritical attitude and Russia's involvement, the crisis is escalating. Russia began bombing Syria, in my opinion, with the agreement of the United States.  Now, with the violation of Turkish airspace by a Russian fighter, NATO is convening on an emergency basis, and is referring to the creation of dangerous situations. I think we're still going blind. Turkey bombs Kurdish civilians every day, its army is a Member State of the European Union, its planes and fleet violate the airspace and territorial waters of the Republic of Cyprus every day and we all do not see. Ankara cannot solve the problem because it carries out state terrorism against its citizens and against its neighbours. It's part of the problem.  However, NATO is not reacting and the European Union must not give in to erdoğan's blackmail, which therefore requires more and more to fulfil its commitments. The European Union must convene an international conference leading to an immediate ceasefire and a transitional period with a roadmap for calling democratic elections, supervised by the international community. The peacekeeping force must be sent to protect the population and gradually return refugees safely.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE).
text: – There are several wars at the same time in Syria. It is not only a political and economic game of power in Syria and the region, it is also a civilisational conflict and a religious war. We are at war and are co-responsible – towards the helpless and persecuted people in Syria, as well as to the future of our own people. With all its political, economic, cultural and other potentials, a European union cannot afford to simply be a reserve player or observer. Our ambition must be to make peace in a pragmatic and inclusive way with all those who should sit at the common table. A clear strategy and political will to do with this is a prerequisite for this. We will not solve the problem by targeting everyone on their target or simply by a charity match. The more successful we will be in tackling the root problem, the less we will experience at home.

name: Artis Pabriks (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I believe in the European Union, but I equally believe in the need for self-criticism. Syria is a good lesson for us in how we failed because of our inactivity, our passivity and our wishful thinking in foreign policy. At the moment we are dealing with a refugee crisis which is only the tip of this iceberg of failed foreign policy. We have been listening to the cries of our neighbour beating his wife for four years and now, when the wife is knocking on our door, we either send her to a neighbour’s house because ours is full or simply tell her that she is welcome inside. No, we have to deal with foreign policy issues and, unfortunately, those who refused to deal with Turkey are now happy cooperating – or trying to cooperate – with Putin and Assad. Together with the United Nations, we need an active policy, not only in the capitals but also in Brussels and the Commission. Until we succeed with this, we will fail eternally. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – I would like to ask you – because I am most in favour of the European Union, more broadly the West, acting actively, in advance – does this mean that you are recommending something that is close to my heart, namely: taking responsibility for Syria without Russia, by the power of the West? What exactly is your postulate activity?

name: Artis Pabriks (PPE)
text: blue-card answer. – I do not think we can speak about a European army or anything like that, but obviously our Western coalition has been failing because we declined to intervene when the red lines were crossed, as Obama suggested. I saw no worthwhile proposals from our European Union side until Putin made his  tactical move, and he is now the leading guy whom we would have to obey. So, as to the possibility of a no-fly zone, better cooperation with Turkey, additional money for refugees: unfortunately there is no good solution, but better now than four years too late.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE).
text: – In Syria, as we know, there has been a war going on for four years, a war in which there are many casualties, and only a splash of refugees into Europe has finally irritated us about the scale of this war and what the global impact of this war is. The Syrian region is practically an example of how foreign policy should not be guided, an example of how, in the run-up to Iraq, we made room for terrorist groups, a place for barbaric groups that do not respect the basic values of either human life or millennial cultural heritage. It is therefore high time that the great players stop all of us, from America, the European Union, Russia, Saudi Arabia, Iran, Turkey, to play a game of great interests, but to be aware of their responsibilities and to ensure stability and peace in this part of the world, otherwise this terrorism will spread further around the world.

name: Victor Boştinaru (S&D).
text: – I would like to point out that, in the context of the debates at the United Nations General Assembly, Syria was one of the first topics, perhaps most importantly, but then, from Berlin, from Paris, from London, messages were received which did not necessarily agree. There are at least nuances that make a difference and make a difference even in relation to the platform proposed by the High Representative, Mrs Mogherini.  In this context, I would stress the need for a strategic and pragmatic approach to the role of international actors in resolving the situation in Syria, in particular with regard to Russia's intentions. While Russia declamates the support and consolidation of Allied positions, on the other hand, it adopts an agenda that is at least unpredictable about its own goals. In this regard, attacking targets as political opponents of al-Assad, not ISIS, once again confirms doubts about the sincerity of hiring. A Russian pax cannot be a solution for Syria and in no way a solution for the Near East.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Madam President, the situation in Syria is now out of control. The civil war is intensifying and millions of refugees are flooding into neighbouring countries, as well as Greece, in order to be rescued. In a region where the use of chemical weapons and the bombing of civilians are a frequent practice, the international community is proving, every day, incapable of contributing to the peaceful resolution of disputes.  Western powers' insistence on ending the Assad regime has paved the way for ISIS jihadists to continue slaughtering Christian populations and destroying the region's cultural monuments. The aim of the jihadists is to destabilise the populations of the region, destroy their cultural heritage and create a huge refugee tsunami that will literally drown the countries of Europe.  Already, my country, Greece, has been irreparably affected by the huge refugee flows and is unable to accommodate other refugees. For this reason, the European Union must learn from the mistakes of the past and take a diplomatic initiative for a sustainable solution to the crisis in Syria.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, we are mistaken if we think this crisis will end quickly, that the war in Syria will end quickly. Unfortunately, we are also mistaken if we think russia will just withdraw and not defend the Assad regime. I say all this not because I think it's all very good, but because I think we need to be realistic so that we don't make mistakes again that we often knew how to make because of our misjudgments.  In this case, it is clear that Russia will not withdraw from Syria, it is clear that it will protect the Assad regime and only a grand coalition, the agreement of all the great players of the world political scene... and unfortunately I must note, our European Union plays a minor role and we have to play our cards here if we really want to do something in Syria. And, of course, because of the refugee problem we've already talked about a hundred times.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, while I am glad that the European Parliament is dealing with such important issues as Syria and Libya, I would much rather see very concrete proposals to address the crisis situation in these countries. The European Union should certainly step up diplomatic and humanitarian efforts in Syria, but let us not forget that the problem of the Middle East must be addressed in the Middle East. Once again, we must not pretend to be the messiah of a region that knows much better than the governments operating there what the region needs. How often have we seen recently that outside interventions, especially by the United States of America, have destabilized entire regions? If there's one thing we know about this area, it's that it has a long memory and doesn't forget the damage it's suffered. However, if we act as diplomats and aid workers in the region, then we can help stabilise the situation and improve our reputation.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI).
text: Madam President, the wrong policy implemented by the European Union in the case of Syria is largely responsible for the situation in that country over the last five years. The constant insistence, over the years, that President Assad should be overthrown, and this, from the outset, was clearly not possible, has put the European Union in a position to see developments. Instead of being a leading lady, she became an extra and gave way to other countries that de facto covered the gap left by the European Union.  In this way, all we gained was to suffer the consequences of the ongoing war, namely the hundreds of thousands of dead, the strengthening of ISIS forces, the flow of millions of refugees to Turkey and, from there, hundreds of thousands to Greece and Europe and, finally, Russia's decisive and forceful intervention in the case.  Now, all we have to do to solve the Syrian problem is to work with Russia.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the settlement of the Syrian conflict depends primarily on the actors of world politics, the United States and Russia, as well as on the countries in the region. But in the meantime, europe, its more developed and richer Western countries, is the target of an ever-greater migration. This trap situation is also disappointing because the EU does not seem to be able to take decisions that have an impact on events in Syria. Instead of taking into account each other's aspects and interests, Member States will take an unprecedented majority vote in the Council on an extremely specific issue. This sends a message to eastern European states that their views do not matter. My liberal colleague also considers the maintenance of the Confederate system to be important for resettling the minority situation, but this requires two things: to end the war and to set an example within the EU by respecting the rights of minorities.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, a very complex war is being fought in Syria and, unfortunately, the Russian Government's decision to intervene militarily in this scenario does nothing but complicate the situation and exacerbate the current crisis.  The war in Syria has been going on for more than four years and is a major cause of the humanitarian catastrophe taking place on Europe's doorstep. Millions of people have left their homes in recent years and 220 thousand people have been killed, a war that has become increasingly confused and complicated and whose political solution seems to be still a long way off. There is an absolutely need for a diplomatic solution. Europe must continue to work in this direction and we cannot replicate the mistakes made in Syria in the past, and I am thinking, for example, of what happened in Libya.  It is necessary to facilitate a political transition that frees the country from dictatorship and at the same time avoids the chasm of the political vacuum, because as history has amply demonstrated, the exclusive use of weapons can only leave rubble and chaos.

name: Nicolas Schmit
text: President-in-Office of the Council, on behalf of the Vice—President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, first I would like to thank Parliament for this very rich debate and for all the views which you have expressed and which have reflected not only the complexity but also the dangers of this conflict. We are all aware that the internal and external dimensions of this conflict just make it more complex and that there is no easy solution. But we are also all aware that ending the Syrian conflict is deeply in the EU’s interest because it affects the stability of our southern neighbourhood, not to mention the refugee crisis which we talked about a lot yesterday. The Union is therefore actively working on finding a solution – a political solution – to the Syrian conflict, as I mentioned and as I described in my previous intervention. The EU needs, indeed, to do everything on the political and diplomatic front to contribute to that end, and certainly combating the terrorist groups – notably ISIS – is a very important element in that. We are also very committed to actively supporting the UN-led peace efforts. We have to talk to all external actors involved in this conflict, including Russia. How can we now come to a solution now without talking to the Russians? But we must make clear that Russia has to commit to finding a political solution that is inclusive and will strengthen, not weaken, the fight against terrorism.  Talking of a political solution, what do we mean by that? Our long—standing position is that a lasting solution to the conflict can be achieved only through a Syrian-led political process leading to a transition. These are the terms of the Geneva Communiqué. For that to be realised will require the consent of all the Syrian parties, since Geneva foresees the participation of all groups and segments of society in Syria.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: The debate is over. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE)
text: in writing. – The situation in Syria is an escalating multidimensional political and humanitarian catastrophe. The brutality of the Syrian conflict has extremely serious repercussions in the country and the region, resulting in the accumulation of the migrant crisis in Europe. The international community needs to work together to find a common strategy – this is the only way stability and peace in Syria can be restored. In addition, the recent Russian military intervention in Syria gives rise to grave concern – it is apparent that the bombings move away from the goal of targeting ISIS and terrorist groups. There cannot be any peaceful solution with the brutal, corrupt and incompetent Assad regime in power, who initially has been the driving force of the atrocities in the country.

name: Lorenzo Cesa (PPE)
text: in writing. Resolving the situation in Syria in practice also becomes crucial in helping to resolve the migration situation.  So far, the lack of a political perspective for Syria has increased pressure from Syrian asylum seekers on Europe. As we have always said, the real solution to the problem of the massive influx of refugees, the boats overturned at sea, the thousands of people drowning off our coasts, is the political solution, within the framework of a regional agreement for the stabilisation of Syria and Iraq. The Syrian transition must be credible and realistic, and that is why we must support the plan of un envoy Staffan de Mistura, a gradual and flexible plan for a ceasefire, the formation of an inclusive government and, at the same time, a common military council.  It is a priority to start a path towards a political transition, in order to be able to frame anti-Daesh (ISIS) operations in a context of pacification of Syria and its state institutions.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: in writing. In recent months, the Syrian crisis has become increasingly geopolitically important for the European Union, both because of the humanitarian issue and the migratory consequences that link it and because of the direct intervention of certain international powers, including Russia, whose unilateral actions in recent days risk further complicating the difficult peace process and destabilising an increasingly complex area.  That is why the European Union must play a more active role in the region and consolidate its political and diplomatic presence on the Middle East stage. We need to plan quickly a long-term strategic and pragmatic approach that involves negotiation between the different factions on the ground and therefore excludes unlikely unilateral military solutions. Syria's future cannot remain in the hands of Bashar al-Assad's government. I am sure that European diplomacy and the High Representative will work hard to facilitate a necessary political transition that involves all parties, ensures lasting stability in the country and prevents power vacuums, which could be dangerously exploited by the fundamentalist terrorism of the Islamic State.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. – Dear colleagues, Islamic State has been operating on the territory of Syria for two and a half to three years without Russian military strikes. So, those countries that led their geopolitical battle in Syria invested in the creation of the so-called Islamic State. "moderate opposition", militarized their military wings and provoked the civil war against Assad, bear full responsibility for what happened so far and for the refugee crisis that hit the EU. Islamic State in Syria has emerged precisely in the chaos created by the country's civil war. Undoubtedly, Russia has its geopolitical interests and they are very clear – to maintain the naval base in Tartus and the airport in Latakia. Most likely, the Russian interest is to move towards some kind of federalization of Syria, but this does not undo the interference, responsibility and geopolitical interests of the other major powers. Only through military intervention in Syria will the problem of Islamic State be resolved and the situation in the country normalized. Any diplomatic solution to the Syrian crisis is doomed to fail as long as there is an Islamic State. This means only one thing – the EU, the US and Russia must ally against Islamic State and agree on the future of Assad and Syria as a whole.

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE)
text: in writing. – It is high time for international "players" to coordinate their actions to truly appeify Syria and the region, allowing people to stay in their homelands and return there. Uncoordinated interventions lead to an increase in the chaos and danger of an even greater migration wave, which suggests whether this is not one of the objectives of the Russian intervention. An international conference with all stakeholders is needed as soon as possible. We in the EU have a duty to insist on this on a daily basis.  On the one hand, in the short term, we need to preserve and restore statehood in Syria throughout its territory, but in the medium term without Assad.  The factors that create tension – war and conflict, human rights violations and economic deprivation – that motivate people to make dangerous transitions in search of a better life must be eliminated. To eliminate these factors, military action is needed, but in order to find a lasting solution to the crisis, we need a political process. Representatives of the Syrian opposition, as well as Assad, should be involved in such negotiations in order for them to be truly successful. As part of collective efforts against the crisis, the primary measure must be the establishment of a 'security zone' that can be set up in the north of Syria. Such an area would allow the return of refugees.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. – The civil war in Syria has been going on since March 2011 and reportedly as many as 7,000 organisations are involved in the conflict in various ways. Unfortunately, the EU does not play a decisive role in the Middle East, but suffers the most serious consequences from the chaos in this area. On the other hand, the United States is finding it increasingly difficult to maintain its own position. If nothing changes in Brussels, the Americans will have to negotiate agreements with Russia and, perhaps - China. Either way, after Russia's military intervention in Syria, both the future of the region and the credibility of the West among middle eastern states are at stake. Putin does not invent our mistakes and divisions. He's just increasing them. The region itself is religiously, politically, ethnically and territorially highly divided and sinking into increasingly severe violence. In slightly better circumstances, it is precisely the combination of such diversity and the history of conflict that should guide the EU in the Middle East. However, to bring this even a little closer, today's EU must restore its own plausibleness as an unquestionable argument.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. Parliament was to discuss Syria this time focusing on the undeclared war situation involving with greater or lesser visibility several non-European powers and some Member States. Previously the debate had focused on the humanitarian situation, the movement of people seeking refuge and the general situation. Our position is summed up in demanding that all parties involved direct their efforts towards a solution in Syria, not to increase the problem. President Al-Asad cannot be part of that solution. The EU must implement bold diplomatic action and coordinate the action of the Member States. It has been demonstrated in the nuclear agreement with Iran that it is possible to design solutions when the objectives are clear. The goal in Syria is to end the war and end the danger of the Islamic State. There must be a political transition based on consensus. There is no purely military solution. Terrorism is the real common enemy and every effort must be made to hold a debate on how to combat it by legitimate means and how to protect civilians. We support the creation of corridors and humanitarian shelters for the endangered population.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. – In September 2013, I said the following to the situation in Syria at the EP: The current situation in Syria must concern every european citizen. Last year (2012) the EU was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize. Today we have the opportunity to prove that we deserve this award. Violence is perpetrated on a daily basis in Syria. It is a great tragedy that does not yet have peaceful solutions. In every war, women and children suffer the most. Even among the nearly two million refugees, most are children and women. They are desperate, they expect international help, but I do not think it should be military aid. I believe that not all options for a peaceful solution to the situation in Syria have yet been exhausted. The use of chemical weapons, whatever the use of them by any of the warring parties, must be met with fierce criticism and punished. EU leaders must make greater efforts in international negotiations and force the warring parties to negotiate and gradually end the fighting. I believe that the road leads through efforts to limit the supply of weapons to each of the warring parties in Syria. After two years, unfortunately, I have to say that we have done very little for peace and for stabilisation in Syria, and thousands of migrants from this country are proving this to us on a daily basis.

name: Indrek Tarand (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. We would not be discussing the current situation in Syria today if we had taken more far-sighted decisions in the past. If the European Union had had a genuine common security and defence policy, we could have had more influence over the surrounding regions. As President Junker has vaguely mentioned in the past, we should have common European armed forces.  I have repeatedly warned in this Chamber that we would regret France's unfortunate decision to sell Mistral warships to Russia. France itself would have been the first to regret it. In fact, after returning the money to Russia, he would be trying to sell the same ships to Egypt. This last strategy is not acceptable either, as it would be a new missed opportunity for the EU to fully implement the Treaty of Lisbon by creating a European navy. With these technologies, we really would have the opportunity to have a real impact on the situation in Syria. The European Union needs a common defence policy based on the presence of common armed defence forces.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: In writing. "The more time passes, the more we see that the war in Syria is getting worse and bringing with it its share of violence and despair. Unfortunately, between the United States, Russia, Iran and other countries in the region, the European Union is struggling to make its voice heard. However, it cannot stand back and must actively participate in the search for a solution. Indeed, Turkey, Jordan and Lebanon are greatly affected by the arrival of thousands of migrants and their destabilization would lead to a regional disorder whose consequences could be even greater than those we are experiencing at present. That is why we need to massively help these countries so that they can face the challenge they face. By providing them with the necessary assistance, we will enable all those who have fled the war in Syria to live in a dignified way, while giving them hope that one day they will be able to return home. It is therefore by combining a strong diplomatic initiative with massive aid to Syria's neighbouring countries that we will be able to stem the flow of refugees, stabilize the situation and give them hope of a return.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: The next item is the Statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in Turkey (2015/2871(RSP))

name: Nicolas Schmit
text: President-in-Office of the Council, on behalf of the Vice—President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, honourable Members, firstly I would like to thank you for giving the Council the opportunity to exchange views with you on the situation in Turkey at this pivotal moment for the country and for the whole region.  The Middle East is in turmoil, with the crisis in Syria – we have just had a lengthy exchange on that – and the presence of Daesh in the region and also in Iraq. The rest of the region is also facing dramatic challenges, from Yemen to Libya. The human tragedies in the Mediterranean, the threats posed by terrorist groups and the multiple conflicts in our neighbourhood are all issues that we can tackle only in cooperation with our partners.  Turkey is indeed a strategic partner for Europe. We need to work in partnership with Turkey if we want to tackle effectively all these crises, and in particular the Syrian one. This cooperation is not only possible, it is absolutely necessary. We share so many interests, the most important one being peace and stability in our common region. For this reason, we have started to increase and deepen further our engagement with Turkey. The visit of President Erdoğan to Brussels and his meetings with President Tusk and President Juncker on Monday are a reminder that dialogue with our Turkish partners at the highest possible level is in the interests of both sides.  The situation in Syria and Iraq has called for the reinforcement of our cooperation on foreign-policy issues and counter-terrorism. The refugee crisis that we are facing in the region shows very clearly that we share a common challenge when managing this dramatic situation. Turkey’s efforts to host more than two million Syrian and Iraqi refugees deserve not only our approval but also our full support and solidarity. The Union is providing financial help; with some EUR 176 million committed by the Commission for direct aid to refugees. The Council’s recent decision to increase the EU’s financial contribution, the Commission’s commitments in this respect and the increased contribution of Member States should help us in putting our forces together.  A couple of weeks ago, the European Union’s Heads of State and Government stressed that there is a pressing need to reinforce our cooperation with Turkey on managing these issues. The challenges we face due to the refugee crisis made it necessary to step up significantly our cooperation on migration and border management. This means too that we have to pursue even further our dialogue towards visa liberalisation. We also need to develop further operational cooperation with a view to preventing illegal migratory flows in the Aegean and Mediterranean and fighting smugglers’ networks which are responsible for the loss of so many lives at our borders.  That is why, on the occasion of President Erdoğan’s visit on Monday, the President of the Commission handed over to him a draft action plan for stepping up cooperation between the EU and Turkey on support for refugees and migration management. The draft plan, which has been made publicly available on the Commission’s website, is now being discussed with the Turkish side to reach agreement on the details.  However, our challenges go beyond that, and our actions should also look further. A reinforced political dialogue between the EU and Turkey, in addition to the accession negotiations, would allow us jointly to address key issues of mutual interest. Turkey is an accession country, but it is also a strategic partner for us in the region. We need to make sure that our work with Turkey develops strongly and consistently on these two dimensions in parallel. As regards the internal political situation, since we last discussed Turkey in this Chamber, there has been some relevant news. All major political parties won representation in parliament in the elections of 7 June 2015, but it was not possible to form a new government. We hope that after the new elections on 1 November 2015, whatever the outcome, a new government can be formed swiftly.  I believe we are all increasingly concerned by the escalation of violence in Turkey and the continuing terrorist attacks. However, measures taken by the Government must be proportionate and targeted, and they should not endanger the democratic political dialogue. A ceasefire is particularly urgent. The interim Government and all political leaders need to come together to guarantee secure and fair elections.  We have to support actively the return to the peace process. In recent years the relaunch of the Kurdish peace process has provided Turkey with the best opportunity in a generation both to resolve a conflict that has claimed far too many lives and to address the needs of all the citizens of the republic. With no peace process in place, this opportunity is at risk of disappearing and there is a risk that instability will continue or even grow.  Honourable Members have expressed on different occasions their views and concerns on this matter. Indeed, as a candidate country negotiating EU membership, Turkey needs to strengthen democracy and the rule of law – and I refer here mainly to the independence of the judiciary and the freedom of the press. These are key areas where Turkey needs to give proof of its strong commitment to the accession process.  We hope to see Turkey re-engaging seriously in reforms, and we are ready and willing to support such reforms with all the instruments at our disposal in order to increase their impact. Opening Chapters 23 and 24 would be in the interests of both Turkey and the EU and would act as a catalyst for reform. Last but not least, the issue of Cyprus: in the last months we have increased consistently the Union’s political engagement in this regard, receiving full support from the work done by the UN Special Adviser – whom the High Representative, Ms Mogherini, met last week in New York – and from the strong political will expressed by the leadership involved in the process. What we see is that the conditions are there for reaching a positive solution and that the time has come for all to put an end to this problem, for the benefit of all. The EU and Turkey need one another. We face the same regional challenges; we share the same need for peace and stability. We need to work as close as possible together, as we have been doing in these past months. We will not have the same views on everything, but this is a reason to intensify even further our exchanges and to develop common lines of action and common frameworks for our crucial partnership on the regional conflicts on counterterrorism, on refugees, on migration, and also on other key issues such as energy. This is the direction we have taken and I am more than convinced that the European Parliament will continue to be a key player, as it has already been over the past years.

name: Cristian Dan Preda
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, as Mr Schmit said earlier, we discussed Turkey in Parliament three months ago, when we were adopting the resolution on the progress report on this country, and – I said then – I now reiterate this: there is a need for a deepening of dialogue and cooperation with Turkey. The current refugee crisis, which has happened, especially in recent months, shows better than anything else the need to work with our Turkish partners to manage the wave of refugees. Without Turkey we cannot solve this problem, it seems obvious to me. On the other hand, I believe that opening new negotiating chapters is a very important thing. Unfortunately, our group is not united in this regard, but this is the message that we sent, for example on the visit of the Committee on Foreign Affairs to Turkey in the spring.  Secondly, I want to stress the importance of the elections that will soon be held in Turkey. It has been seen that, unfortunately, a compromise could not be reached in Ankara, and I would like to tell our Turkish friends that democracy is not just a one-coloured majority. Compromise and negotiation are very important and I hope that in the future political configuration in Turkey we will find a serious partner to talk about migrants but also, obviously, about new negotiating chapters.

name: Victor Boştinaru
text: on behalf of the S&D group – Minister, distinguished colleagues, the current crisis reconfirms the strategic dimension of relations between the European Union and Turkey. Refugees, Syria, energy, our access to the Muslim world in general can be considerably improved if we are aware of the importance of this relationship. I have been a supporter of strengthening this strategic relationship between Turkey and the European Union for many years, but today I am equally concerned. Turkey is going through a political crisis, the result of an economic slowdown, after years of substantial economic progress, but also as a result of President Erdogan's systematic effort to transform Turkey from a parliamentary democracy into an autocratic presidential regime.  But the most dangerous thing today is violence - violence inside Turkey, against the backdrop of terrorist attacks, but also the assault on the Kurdish minority - and violence on Turkey's borders. And this situation demands responsibility from all leaders, calls for prudent action, to avoid any escalation of violence or slippage.  President Erdogan's actions in recent times have been rather contrary. Against the backdrop of a nationalist, an attempt was made to turn the environment and political opinion against the Kurds as an electoral platform. Actions have been taken against businessmen. Brutal action was taken against the freedom of the press, the opposition. All these elements we hope will be calmed down and have a rational outcome after the elections of 1 November.  This said, however, we must stress, once again, the strategic role for the European Union – I speak primarily for the European Union – of relations with Turkey, as a long-term partner, a key partner in finding solutions to the two big problems: refugees, the fight against Daesh and stability in Syria.  And we have to say one more thing, that the European Union and Parliament have a duty to start negotiations, to support the opening of new negotiating chapters with Turkey, in order to strengthen the strategic dimension of these relations.

name: Charles Tannock
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, the complex web of relationships and partnerships that Turkey’s foreign policy has forged – from what it is doing in Syria and Libya to its dealings in Egypt and with Israel in the last couple of years – has become almost incomprehensible. As Turkey rumbles towards elections on 1 November 2015, it remains to be seen whether Erdoğan can restore his AK party’s lost majority. In the meantime, clashes with the PKK, whom he considers to be the real terrorists, rather than ISIS, continue. The ceasefire that we thought might be going somewhere – and any lasting peace – is now completely lost. The EU must now engage constructively with Turkey, a strategic country which has sadly not respected its readmission agreements with Greece and has allowed a huge exodus of migrants. Russia’s recent push to support the Assad regime results in a Russia-Syria policy that is now entirely opposed to the stated aims of Erdoğan’s Turkey, whose airspace Russia is now violating. The deterioration of human rights in Turkey, with the arrest of journalists, is also a major concern. So, altogether, the situation is pretty bleak, but I do hope that this year will see at least a solution to the problem in Cyprus under the new leadership of the Turkish community leader, Mustafa Akinci. At least there is some prospect of bright light in Cyprus, but for the rest it is all pretty depressing.

name: Alexander Graf Lambsdorff
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ALDE Group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for Refugee flows come from Syria and northern Iraq via Greece, Serbia Hungary, Austria to Europe, Germany, Sweden and other countries. The country that lies between this region and us is Turkey – a large, a proud country, a country that deserves to be treated with respect and honesty, a strategic partner. But what we are hearing here from the Council makes you pause in amazement. We must ensure that democratic values are respected in Turkey. Freedom of the press is being trampled underfoot, an unexplained war is being waged against the Kurds, the body of a Kurdish politician is being dragged through the streets by a police car, judges and prosecutors who do their job are punished, and even sometimes even arrested. Is this really an enlargement candidate? No, ladies and gentlemen. The Council is once again trying to create a life lie that we could deal with Turkey as a strategic partner and, at the same time, continue with the enlargement agenda. It is significant that the Commission, at the insistence of the Council, has postponed the progress report because the accession process has come to a standstill for all the reasons I have just mentioned. Nevertheless, let us be honest with this country to be treated with respect! We need help from Turkey, and Turkey needs our help for that. We can offer visa facilitation, we can offer more money, we can offer better infrastructural support in the refugee camps, we can do a lot of pragmatic things to address the real challenges. But let us be honest: Turkey is a strategic partner, it is an important neighbour, but the fact that this enlargement process can be revived is pure rhetoric, it has nothing to do with honesty. We must not remain silent about the violation of fundamental values there. Many Turkish friends are writing to us these days. At the same time, this country needs our cooperation, and we need its cooperation if we are to deal with the situation in Syria and Iraq. This is precisely what is needed to stop the flow of refugees crossing the European continent. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: n/a
text: question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. Madam President, I must admit that it was a confusing message for me. You once said that Turkey is a strategic partner, on the other hand you said that Turkey's accession process has nothing to do with it. He's either a strategic partner or he's not? I ask you: how do you then see a strategic partner being, if we do not treat him in the accession process as a possible member of the European Union?

name: Alexander Graf Lambsdorff (ALDE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Mrs Grapini, I would like to thank Mrs Grapini for her work on this report. The accession procedure is linked to the Copenhagen criteria. The first criterion, the political criterion, relates to the fundamental values of the European Union as laid down in Article 2 of the Treaty. These values – freedom of the press, freedom of expression, freedom of assembly, for example, of trade unions – are coming under increasing pressure. The President of Turkey is constantly breaking the Constitution by not being neutral, but by interfering in the election campaign. We have a huge problem with Turkey as a candidate country. But as a partner in the region, we cannot do without Turkey, and as a NATO partner it is and will remain an important ally and neighbour. That is the honesty I demand. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Charles Tannock (ECR)
text: blue-card question. – Mr Lambsdorff, I entirely agree that Turkey remains a strategic partner: it is a member of NATO, it is a candidate country for the European Union, etcetera, etcetera. But the fact is that, over recent years, the human rights situation is deteriorating, and democracy is basically also deteriorating. Moreover – quite clearly from all the intelligence reports – they have been supporting terrorist groups in the Syrian conflict. Do you think it is time now that we began to keep in reserve some of the Instrument for Pre-Accession Assistance (IPA) pre-accession monies – which amount to hundreds of millions of euros of taxpayers’ money to assist Turkey – as a conditionality way of trying to put increased pressure on them to improve their situation in terms of human rights and democracy and their support for terrorists?  (Applause)

name: Alexander Graf Lambsdorff (ALDE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Mr Tannock, I would like to thank Mr Tannock for his work on this First of all, I am pleased that we agree on the analysis. The domestic political situation in terms of fundamental values in Turkey is far from normal. This is a bad development. Unfortunately, the polls do not suggest that the political constellation will change after the election. As far as pre-accession aid is concerned, I think we can talk about it. They are under the wrong heading – 'pre-accession' for accession, which will certainly not take place in the next 10 to 20 years, if at all. However, I would also like to make this clear, if we want to cooperate with Turkey, we must also provide financial support for it. It is always cheaper to help there than to decide first in our reception facilities in Europe what we do with the people who then flee to us from Turkey. In this respect, I believe that yes to the EPA, but no to cutting out aid, because working with Turkey also means helping it in this very difficult situation.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in Turkey, democracy has gone 'a short walk'. It accepts foreign refugees and we recognise that, but at the same time, with handsome pay, it conflicts vertically and mercilessly with the Kurds. However, since the President-in-Office of the Council has made a fair reference to the positive prospects for a possible solution to the Cyprus problem, within a minute I have to say the following: it is a problem that hinders Turkish European orientations. There are indeed, today, more than ever, positive possibilities for resolution. However, in a solution, it is not understood that Cypriots, all Cypriots, do not have the right to reside wherever they want, anywhere in Cyprus, and no solution is understood, without every Cypriot being able to buy what he wants and whenever he wants, anywhere in Cyprus. Anything contrary conflicts with the European Union's basic principles of free movement and establishment. Cypriots cannot live in a solution where they are allowed to live wherever they want, throughout the rest of Europe, except in their own country. This is a message to my friend, representative and leader of the Turkish Cypriots, Mustafa Akıncı. (The speaker agrees to answer a question with a blue card (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).

name: Ελένη Θεοχάρους (PPE)
text: "blue card" question. – Mr Hatzigeorgiou, do you think that Mustafa Akıncı, however much goodwill he has, can do anything without Erdoğan's approval?

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: "blue card" answer. – I am a left-winger and I believe, yes, in the potential of peoples, in the potential of communities, in the potential of the people who represent a group. I believe, yes, that one can also resist In Turkey, one can resist any occupying force. Alas, if we were to degrade the ability of a citizen, a single citizen, to resist any great superpower. (Applause)

name: Bodil Valero
text: Mr President, on behalf of the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance, I would like to take Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for After all, Turkey is a democracy. That was very clear about the last election. However, it also showed that President Erdoğan is not a democrat, and that since the election he has done all he can to get his party back to power. Now he is on an election tour in Europe, paid for by the state's funds, it is to be assumed, to get exiled Turks to vote. What other parties in Turkey have the economic opportunity? Yesterday we met in the Group of the Greens, Leyla Zana, which is campaigning for the HDP. She believes that the HDP will be able to repeat the election success from last summer and perhaps also increase. I very much hope that she is right and that democracy prevails in Turkey for everyone's sake – Turks, Kurds and other minorities – because we all know that the situation of freedom of the press and other human rights is under all criticism. In Turkey, hundreds of people have been accused of crimes for insulting those in power, the army or Islam, defending Kurds or talking about the Armenian genocide. That is not acceptable in a democracy. Our problem in this is that the Union is looking between its fingers and, in principle, accepting what is happening in exchange for Turkey possibly taking in the refugees that we send back. However, to support future Turkish membership is not the same as standing behind Erdoğan's undemocratic methods. We need to be clear about that. Extremely serious, however, is what several have raised, namely the broken ceasefire with the PKK and the fact that Turkey is actually devoting more effort to cracking down on the Kurds than cracking down on IS, and despite the fact that it is the Kurds who have successfully resisted IS so far. It is therefore time for the EU to try to force the parties back to the negotiating table. We cannot afford as many open armed conflicts in the Middle East as we have today. This could be one of those conflicts that we could relatively easily resolve with greater commitment on the part of the European Union. (The speaker agreed to answer a question ('blue card') in accordance with Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. – Madam President, even in the case of Syria, now turkey, you have mentioned a series of conflicts, while the European Union is forced to negotiate with those who have arms in their hands and the European Union does not have a weapon in its hands. We're the only financial options. Do you agree that more aid and development promises should be made to the Union in its foreign policy, but with much more conditioning?

name: Bodil Valero (Verts/ALE)
text: answer ("blue card"). I do not know whether I really understood the question, but if it is a question of using more funds for development, Then I absolutely believe that we must use more funds for development in the area, both in Turkey and elsewhere. However, we must, of course, also negotiate. We must be a party that can participate in the diplomatic dialogue with various parties in the region. It is both a question of dialogue and of money in the cases that are needed.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, hundreds of HDP party headquarters set on fire, dozens of people lynched by the crowd, hundreds injured, arrests of politicians, bombings of civilian villages peddled by actions against Daesh, torture and unspeakable violence, do we share this with Turkey too, Mr Schmidt? Do you think there will be credible elections in Turkey in November?  Because this is the bulletin of a war declared by Erdogan and his loyalists towards the Kurdish people, guilty of having reached 10% for the first time at the last elections, of having entered Parliament and thus prevented him from distorting the Constitution, but yesterday this agreement was concluded and announced, useful with the Turks to deal with immigration and therefore it is better to place immigrants there , far from our eyes and consciences. The suspicion that the increase in flow was not random in recent months is more than legitimate. For Erdogan, a diplomatic masterpiece for Europe, a masterpiece of hypocrisy, both the Kurds and Turkish civil society activists will return to talk in the future if they are useful. Therefore, courageous Turks fighting against Daesh can now safely be abandoned and sacrificed.  No, ladies and gentlemen, we cannot accept that. Yes to peaceful relations but not to silence, because if the price of the agreement is the freedom of the Kurds, the activists and our dignity as Europeans, we do not want to pay for it.

name: Edouard Ferrand
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen, a veritable market of dupes... Yesterday, the European Union signed an agreement with Ankara to mobilise European funds for the reception and retention of refugees in Turkey. This call for migratory air will increase with the expected arrival of 20 million migrants from Syria, the Middle East or Africa. Turkey will be the entry window. In exchange, the EU will speed up visa liberalisation with Turkey. Turkish citizens will be able to travel visa-free in Europe.  Through this process, the European Union opens its borders and allows Turkey to become implicitly a member of the European Union. On behalf of the ENF group, we denounce this disguised membership. We refuse Turkey's entry into Europe. No, no, no, Turkey is not European! (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI).
text: Madam President, after a year of parliamentary presence, I have come to the conclusion that many colleagues deliberately suggest, because of interests, that they are not taught by history. Error, because history teaches and warns. They do not remember, for example, what the Macedonia of Alexander the Great is in ancient Greece. They do not remember Turkey's past and its change into a so-called Republic. The Ottoman Empire of six centuries offered nothing to humanity, as offered by the Empire of Alexander the Great, the Roman and the Byzantine. Only massacres, looting, familiarizations of foreign cultures and genocides of thousands of Pontians, Armenians and others. Is it possible, historically, for these six centuries to launch a neo-Ottoman state with other principles? Don't be under any illusions. Turkey is trying to use the Union and the US, for its own benefit, to hurt the Kurds, divide Cyprus, strengthen its position in the Middle East and change the status quo in the Aegean, with Merkel's blessings, through its search-and-rescue operation with Greece, ignoring the consequences that lead to the channelling of jihadists into European territory , while at the same time Islamising Europe.  Rest assured that history will write your names for your decisions. Yours will be the choice of whether to be written in black.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: "blue card" question to Edouard Ferrand. Mr Ferrand, I believe that Europe needs Turkey and Turkey needs Europe. I believe that it is you and your group that have nothing to do with Europe, Mr Ferrand. That's what you should recognize. You have no place here in the European Parliament.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her However, with all due respect to your management and presidency, I would like to ask you to comply with what has been customary up to now. If someone forgets to ask a question about the 'blue card' procedure and then asks it to the next speaker, that is unusual in this House. I would therefore ask you to do so in the future.  There are certainly a great many speeches – even under catch the eye, colleagues have spoken out: if you allow a 'blue card' here more than , as usual, it will probably be very tight with time. With all due respect, I would ask you to take this into account.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: "blue card" answer to Doru-Claudian Frunzulica. "Yes, I will respond to these childish and stupid attacks. I will simply say that I am European but I am against this European Union.  Today I denounce Turkey, your precise ally, which supports the Islamist movement everywhere in this widespread cancer of the Middle East and which occupies a European country, namely Cyprus. I denounce the crackdown on Turkish journalists and opponents in Gezi Park, Turkey. That's it, don't teach me a lesson because today Turkey has no right to a city here in Europe!

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: We have reached the end of the group's line of invoicing, and from now on I cannot give you a blue card opportunity because we have to finish the meeting on time.

name: Elmar Brok (PPE).
text: Madam President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for her excellent In this situation, we urgently need close cooperation with Turkey. There is much to criticise, in Turkish domestic policy, in the fight against the Kurds and in many more. If we want to deal with the crisis in the region, if we want to end the war in Syria and Iraq, but also, above all, to get to grips with the situation with regard to refugees, this cannot be done without Turkey. That is why I also believe that the talks that President Erdogan held in Brussels on Monday should continue and that the question of turkey's support for the financing of camps in terms of food, the issue of the conditions for closing the borders and much more, should be pursued. I hope that the negotiations that are currently taking place at official level in Ankara will be successful. I hope that the interests of President Erdogan in the context of the elections on 1 November are not an obstacle to this issue, but I believe that Turkey, which has a customs union with the European Union, is a member of NATO, has a crucial responsibility for ending this incredible, disastrous humanitarian situation and for the war to also end. I therefore hope that, as far as possible, Turkey will be persuaded, without violating human rights, to enter into cooperation that is important to all of us.

name: Tanja Fajon (S&D).
text: – Turkey is Europe's strategic partner and is a country that is taking on the enormous burden of the current refugee crisis. The internal political situation in the country is sensitive, and the public has been shocked by footage of Turkish police exhiling the Kurds. The entire Middle East is unstable. Cooperation with Turkey is therefore essential. Up to €1 billion in aid is provided to Turkey to provide for refugees. Assistance to Lebanon, Jordan, Iraq is planned. We expect Ankara to help alleviate the crisis: by registering migrants, by integrating into society, in returning illegal migrants to their countries, by fighting criminal gangs. We have a common challenge with Turkey, colleagues and colleagues, but we also have a common European future. I therefore hope that the country will also take reforms very seriously, especially when it comes to democracy, especially when it comes to media freedom and the rule of law.

name: Anna Elżbieta Fotyga (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The Middle East is mired in crisis and chaos, in conflict. In this situation, Turkey is becoming, becoming a more difficult country to cooperate with, perhaps less predictable. However, we must remember that it is our ally in NATO, it is a candidate country for the European Union and dialogue, deep dialogue with that country, is our duty. I support the initiative of the Commission and the Council, especially in migration policy, with one caveat. The issue of energy dialogue and energy security must take into account the energy security of my region , Central and Eastern Europe.

name: Nedzhmi Ali (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, a huge wave of refugees, mainly from war-torn Syria, has flooded Europe, and the Member States are having problems with shelter capabilities. The Schengen system is cracking under the weight of the refugees, and there is great divergence among the EU Member States on how to react to the humanitarian crisis. There are two indispensable players in any solution to this crisis: the EU and Turkey. In Europe, understanding has grown that without Turkey’s support no solution to the refugee crisis is possible. There is currently little that the EU can bring to the table without its strategic partner, despite some of the good intentions in the report on Turkey. Turkey has harboured 2.5 million refugees, providing all their immediate requirements and needs. The EU is only now facing these problems.  The worsening security environment and the migrants’ problems are a wake-up call for action. This time, the EU cannot simply pour in money to make this go away. It has to act swiftly if waves of refugees are to be prevented. We urgently need a united European position, a long-term and improved strategy – which includes Turkey – and strong action and solidarity to achieve real results. Turkey has already shown responsibility: now it is the EU’s turn.

name: Martina Michels (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for In 2005, the Turkish writer Orhan Pamuk emphasized at an award ceremony: "In all the novels I read in my youth, Europe was not defined by Christianity, but rather by individualism. Europe was conveyed to me in an attractive way by novelists who wanted to fight for their freedom and to make themselves a reality." At that time, conservative politicians in Europe were more concerned with Christian references to God in a constitution than Turkey's EU membership. This partnership process has failed, but the leaders of the EU institutions are in the process of issuing cheques for the isolation of refugees at the EU's external borders. Hardly a word about violence against journalists, Kurds, destroyed HDP offices, not a word about the buried hopes of the Gezi movement. This campaign support is a slap in the face to Europe's humanist values.

name: Ska Keller (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, just yesterday Leyla Zana was here in Parliament. It was mentioned and everybody who wanted to had the chance to listen to her and her report about the situation in Turkey. She was talking about how the freedom of the press is violated, how Kurds are under attack and whole Kurdish villages are under attack. Yet unfortunately, from the Commission, from the Council and also from the Member States we hear very little – surprisingly little – critique of Turkey. Instead, when Erdoğan comes to Brussels he is welcomed with full honours, and there is a reason for that. The Commission and, it seems, also the Council, want to make a dirty deal: they want to make sure that Erdoğan stops the refugees who are fleeing from the war in Syria towards Europe, so that they stay in Turkey. The other side of the deal is that President Erdoğan gets complete silence from the European arena. I think this deal is wrong. It is not a deal that is worthy of EU values, of human rights and of what we are fighting for. It is not worthy, both because of what it means for refugees and because of what it entails for human rights in Turkey. Declaring Turkey to be a safe country of origin is even more cynical. How can people be safe when journalists are being put in prison? How can minorities be safe in Turkey? They simply are not. So, yes to cooperation with Turkey, yes to supporting Turkey – because it is indeed receiving a lot of refugees – and yes to credible accession negotiations, but no to these dirty deals on the back of refugees.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, Turkey is a candidate country, as others have said, and, in consequence, Turkey has received an incredible EUR 3.8 billion in pre-accession funding in the past five years, and it is scheduled to receive another EUR 3.2 billion in the next five years. However, in the context of immigration to Member States, as a previous speaker pointed out, Turkey does not qualify as a safe country – it is not safe. But if Turkey is not a safe country, it follows that it cannot, should not and must not be a candidate country. Free movement, under Article 45, from Turkey – not a safe country – has to be a complete non-starter. We should not be paying Turkey all this money. And, to answer Mr Brok’s ludicrous point, we can cooperate fully with Turkey without admitting Turkey to the European Union. The fact is that Turkey is an Asian country and can never be an EU Member State.

name: Мария Габриел (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Turkey has a key role to play in North-Mediterranean relations. It is therefore necessary to strengthen our cooperation and common conflict resolution mechanisms in the region. I'il look at three aspects. First of all, Turkey has done and does a lot for the refugees who are on its territory. It is important that within the European Union we continue our joint action to strengthen border controls and the fight against organised crime. What is happening on the land border with Bulgaria is a good example of successful cooperation in these two areas and should be welcomed. Second, the proposal for the buffer zone in Syria. The idea makes sense, it's up for discussion. But let's be clear before that: this must be done by granting a broad international mandate, and we need to answer questions such as "Who provides security?", "How is the security of the people guaranteed?", "How do we ensure that people stationed in this territory do not become targets of radicalized groups?". Finally, there is no doubt that the liberalisation of visas for Turkish citizens will be a strong signal for Turkish business, and the positive consequences for the European Union will not be delayed either.  In conclusion, I welcome the in-depth dialogue between the European Union and Turkey. We know the challenges they face, but now it is important to focus on the important things – the crisis in the region and managing immigrant flows very intelligently. This means cooperation between all stakeholders.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Minister Schmit, yesterday and today we have talked a lot about Turkey, its two million refugees, which, together with one million two hundred thousand from Lebanon or 700 000 from Jordan, tell us about countries on the edge of their capacity. And neither this European Parliament nor the European Union alone can resolve, at source, the conflict in Syria, nor can they defeat the Islamic State on its own, nor can they stop even the harsh winter that threatens refugees. But they can and should be demanding with their neighbors and with themselves in the care and supply of clothing, medicine and food to refugees, and also to warn our partners and our neighbours—Turkey—about escalating violence, conflict in Kurdistan and the PKK, which is yet another threat to the entire region , and the repression of political and media pluralism and human rights activists, human rights lawyers and protesters in Turkey. They therefore have an obligation to warn Turkey; it is an irony for the Commission to propose to include among so-called safe countries as long as the elections on 1 November can take place in a climate of fear rather than freedom.

name: Jan Zahradil (ECR).
text: – Madam President, Turkey is in a difficult situation, it is there before the elections, so that is why the situation is tense. The separatists have activated, the PKK terrorists have activated to undermine Turkey's territorial integrity. Beyond Turkey, NATO members recall, Russia operates, and this can lead to various, now inesparable consequences, conflicts, and provocations. Last but not least, there is the refugee wave, recalling that Turkey is detaining on its territory two million refugees from Syria who would otherwise have been on their way to Europe long ago. I believe that we must work closely with Turkey, that we must respect the democratic electoral process in Turkey, that we must show Turkey that we respect its territorial integrity and stand up against separatist forces. We must also support it in the event of military provocations by Russia and we must help Turkey cope with the refugee wave, because otherwise we here in Europe will have to deal with this refugee wave.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE).
text: – We need Turkey, which respects democratic values at home and in its regional environment, as a partner more than ever in the moments of the refugee crisis. We greatly appreciate the contribution that Turkey is making to overcome the consequences of the tragedy in Syria by welcoming the masses of unhappy Syrians and in the fight against terrorists. We need to renew our interest in turkey, the candidate for membership, and take decisive steps, open and close some negotiating chapters. Our relationship with Turkey must be open and critical at the same time. We want more democracy and more freedom for all who live in this country, a clear demarcation of national functions, an end to the oppression of the media and the opposition and the continuation of internal dialogue. Such a Turkey should be welcomed not only as a partner in difficult situations, but also as a future member of the European Union. Finally, I would like to wish for a speedy recovery for Mrs Mogherini. We miss her.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, Turkey is constantly slipping towards authoritarianism. The offices of the opposition People's Democratic Party have been the target of systematic attacks by withholding elements, and politically motivated criminal charges have been brought against its officials. The government manipulates justice, violates freedom of expression, in the press and on the Internet. It carries out mass purges in the public administration and arrests dissidents, while covering up corruption scandals that touch it with terrorist methods.  In 2014, the European Court of Human Rights handed down 101 convictions against Turkey, more than for any member state of the Council of Europe except Russia. Outside its borders, Turkey continues to occupy much of Cyprus and violates Greek airspace while being denounced for supporting Islamic State jihadists.  Europe must stop tolerance towards the Turkish regime. Help for Syrian refugees, yes, for Erdoğan, no.

name: Ernest Maragall (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, peace and democracy: concepts that cannot be separated, let alone confronted. Europe and Turkey, exactly the same: concepts that should not be separated or confronted. And I am referring both to the question of refugees and to that of the internal process of peace and democracy, both issues of utmost urgency and maximum demand, but which, in no case, can be subject to marketing, exchange or silent complicity.  Turkey today has a central role, decisive for our world, and we must recognize that role and support its efforts. But that is why, too, we must now win the battle of democracy in the whole of the Turkish state, that of the recovery of the peace process with the Kurdish people and that of holding elections with all democratic guarantees.  Europe must therefore be present in Turkey with all the consequences, on the issue of refugees and on elections, with financial assistance and with close and attentive observation of the electoral process and its peaceful celebration and scrutiny. Europe must behave like the good friend of Turkey who is and wants to remain. Therefore, you must be very close to all your problems and therefore you must speak clearly. You must tell her the truth, as only friends can do, critically and hardly that this truth can be.

name: Mike Hookem (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, the total mismanagement of the migrant crisis by the EU has now led to a situation where the supposedly powerful bloc must go with an open chequebook to a Turkish President who is trying to have his cake and eat it. President Erdoğan is now using the crisis as a lever to win political and financial concessions from a weakened EU that is desperate to find a solution to this problem of its own making. Giving in to Erdoğan’s demands also makes the EU complicit in Turkey’s military actions against the PKK and other groups currently engaged in fighting ISIS. This action, in turn, could lead to more IS fighters entering Europe, like the image of the child migrant making beheading gestures that we saw published in the UK press today. When will the EU realise that, until we have a realistic solution to the wars raging across the Middle East and North Africa, no amount of political and financial concessions to other states will alleviate the migrant crisis?

name: Anna Maria Corazza Bildt (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Turkey – already receiving more than 2.2 million people – should be better recognised, and I welcome the EU—Turkey action plan in support of refugees. Turkey is part of the solution to this crisis, but we cannot only react to crises. Turkey is a strategic accession country and our goal must be a long—term and stable relationship.  I condemn the clampdown on freedom of expression and free media in Turkey. It is incompatible with a European perspective, and the upcoming election must be free and fair. The democratic rights of all the people of Turkey should be respected, and it is really important that all parties concerned now play their role by returning to the negotiating table and resuming the peace process with the Kurds.
