In this respect, the Council should be accelerating the opening of the justice and fundamental rights chapters, and we also need to accelerate visa liberalisation. Turkish cooperation is essential in combating traffickers and smugglers in the eastern Mediterranean, and a joint Greek and Turkish Coastguard effort, in coordination with Frontex, is urgently needed to save lives. The UNHCR and other monitoring organisations in Turkey need to be better funded in order to receive people with dignity. Of course, Turkey should be considered a safe country of return, but asylum seekers from Turkey should be granted individual assessment by the Member States. How can we ask Turkey to host migrants and at the same time say that Turkey is not safe? I shall finish by saying that the EU must keep a warm heart and a cool head to manage the important and complex relationship with Turkey.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Turkey and Europe have been a community of destiny for centuries. There were different phases: an open confrontation as well as the intended membership. We are currently in a very difficult situation, not only because of the refugee crisis. Our future also depends on whether we overcome these common difficulties. Cooperation is important. However, I also believe that we must be very clear that this must not lead to a deterioration in the human rights situation of refugees in Turkey, that this does not mean a carte blanche for the restriction of democratic rights, which we are currently seeing everywhere in Turkey, and that this must not lead to the halting of the peace process with the Kurds. Unfortunately, we have the experience that a great deal of things are going in the opposite, bad direction.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: – Madam President, honourable colleagues, many of the colleagues in the chamber here keep saying that Turkey was a strategic partner without which the migrant crisis could not be solved. Apparently, these colleagues, however, did not see, did not hear that Turkey was directly involved in the war in Syria, supporting Islamic State, bombing the positions of the Kurdish peshmerga. Apparently, these colleagues here have not seen that Turkey is actually funding Islamic State by illegally buying the oil from them and thus providing assistance to this terrorist organization. Apparently, these colleagues do not know and have not seen about the already 50-year genocide and violence that the Turkish state is exerting on its own Kurdish people and forcing it to leave Turkey in different directions. Apparently, these colleagues do not know that today Turkey is trying to disrupt the creation of a Kurdish state. All this says one very simple thing – Turkey is not a European country. Because maybe there is no democracy in Turkey right now, there is a dictatorship there. It takes away freedom of speech, it puts journalists in jail. Dear Colleagues, this Turkey is not a European country and it has no place in this European Union.

name: Kristina Winberg (EFDD).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for In the new proposal by Mr Junker and the Commission, which is now on the negotiating table, Turkey is to be eur 1 billion in total to cope with the ever-increasing influx of refugees into the country. Turkey is, of course, taking the opportunity in this negotiating position to demand more resources for the candidate process, because it wants to be part of the EUROPEAN Union. Furthermore, Turkey should be regarded as a safe country, despite the internal lack of security for its own citizens, and above all for the Kurdish population. How are we going to interpret this? Well, Erdoğan is an ugly fish. All people have a right to protection," his prime minister told The Guardian newspaper, regardless of race, religion or belief – except the Kurds of course. They can continue to be murdered in the meantime with the good memory of the EUROPEAN Union.

name: Renate Sommer (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Turkey has been and is an important strategic partner for us. No one disputes that. And she's very special at the moment. But do we therefore have to court them in such a way as they have now done in Brussels? Does the fire-hazardous internal state of Turkey suddenly matter? For years, we have seen almost nothing more in the country, a departure from European values. In my view, it is not a safe third country. As President, Erdogan continues to rule in defiance of the Turkish Constitution, and he will be received in Brussels as a negotiating partner. There he also says that he taught us a lesson in humanity. I find that audacity. Is it humane to use war refugees as a means of exerting pressure on the EU? After all, Turkey is very much responsible for the mass influx into Europe. Smuggling gangs are being granted, and thousands of refugees from Turkish coastal towns arrive in Greece, the European Union, every day. And, of course, people want to leave, because there are very few, only a fraction of these roughly two million in Turkey, who are in refugee camps and receive basic services there. Aren't many in the country traveling and begging and having to try to get their way with illegal, poorly paid work? These people do not have a real prospect of staying in Turkey, they do not have asylum. What does Erdogan want? He also wants financial support, of course. That is also true. I am also in favour of giving him money. But that is not the point. It is also about very different things. It is also a question, for example, of visa liberalisation. This is linked to the readmission agreement, which Erdogan disregards precisely by opening the borders to the European Union. I would like to say one more thing: I would like to know from the European Commission why the presentation of the progress report, which was scheduled for next week, has been postponed. I have heard that this progress report has allegedly been leaked to the Turkish Government in advance and that Erdogan has complained about it. However, because we now want to be so good with Mr Erdogan, this progress report is postponed until the last day of the year, because it is critical. I am asking for clarification on this!

name: Μιλτιάδης Κύρκος (S&D).
text: Madam President, in the last Turkish elections, Mr Demirtaş's Kurdish party won its entry into parliament, voted for by many other Turkish citizens. This temporarily reversed Mr Erdoğan's plans for presidential super powers. The president's response was immediate and in an attempt to incriminate the Kurdish element, it leads Turkey into conflict with the always willing PKK, which never endorsed Mr Demirtaş. And in this context, the European Union must find solutions for the thousands of refugees who come from Syria and reach the Greek islands, through the Turkish coast and a solution for relocation and solutions for traffickers and solutions for Syria.  Let us hope, then, that in the forthcoming elections, the forces that resist anti-democratic superpowers and violence will be strengthened, wherever they come from. And let us quickly find mutually profitable paths of cooperation with Turkey, such as the identification of refugees on its territory, relocation from camps to Europe and refoulement agreements. It is a fact that Turkey is already hosting over two million refugees from Syria, but let us not forget that these are people and not a weapon in its diplomacy.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Madam President, Turkey has no place in the European Union, since it continues to illegally hold 37% of the territory of the Republic of Cyprus illegally and to prevent Cyprus from exploiting its exclusive economic zone. So, here and now, the Turkish occupying troops must leave Cyprus.  Turkey also continues to maintain the casus belli against Greece, should my country exercise its sovereign rights by extending its territorial waters in the Aegean Sea to 12 miles. In addition, Turkish fighters continue to violate Greek airspace.  Turkey's involvement in Syria exacerbates the crisis, since under the guise of supposedly dealing with ISIS, it is bombing the Kurds. At the same time, there are growing reports in the international press confirming Turkey's support for ISIS forces and jihadists, not only in Syria, but also in Libya.  Finally, in the field of refugees, Turkey has set up a lucrative campaign consisting in guiding the slave trade circles that do gold jobs, transporting thousands of refugees to the Aegean islands, which have literally sunk.

name: Eugen Freund (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her We know that Turkey is doing a great deal on the refugee issue – at least more than Europe. We owe it to the country for this. However, we also know that it is important to work closely with Turkey on this issue. It helps us and it helps Turkey. However, Europe must not allow itself to be dragged over the table. President Erdogan wants to win the next elections by fighting the Kurds. However, we must not allow human rights to be trampled underfoot and exchanged for aid to refugees. We must continue to insist that these human rights are indivisible, that it is absolutely unacceptable that we will not tolerate a dead Kurd being dragged through the city in a military vehicle. We want a stable Turkey – a Turkey that accepts European values and does not move away from them more and more, even if it does so much for the refugees.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (S&D).
text: Madam President, why have we come to the point where refugees pose a threat to Europe? Why did we wait five years to open our eyes to see the drama of millions of people? Why did some people arm and back ISIS until they got to the point of beheading civilians from Western countries? Unfortunately, Europe and Turkey, which is violating the human rights of its own citizens, has strange relations with ISIS, claims territory in Syria under the pretext of creating a buffer zone, bombs the Kurds and continues to hold 37% of the territory of Cyprus.  If Mr Erdoğan really wants Turkey to become a member of Europe, which we really want, Europe must send a clear message that the principles and values of the European Union must be respected, calling on it to fulfil its obligations , for which it is committed to Europe. Otherwise, purpose and hypocrisy will again prevail, with painful results.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D).
text: – Madam President, while the EU and Turkey are meeting at the highest level and working to find common ground in order to tackle the most pressing foreign policy issues, including Syria, Daesh and the refugee crisis, there is another Turkey which is a cause of concern. The social and political achievements of the last 10 years are under threat. The Kurdish question has once again developed into confrontation and a dangerous spiral of violence. PKK terrorist attacks have claimed yet more innocent lives. Offices of the Peoples’ Democratic Party have been the object of targeted attacks. The Turkish media is under increasing pressure ahead of an important electoral deadline. The first of November represents a unique opportunity to promote a spirit of unity and to demonstrate a real and genuine commitment by the Turkish authorities to democracy and the shared values and principles which have always been at the very heart of the accession process for any candidate country. A lot has been achieved in Turkey in recent years and I hope this chance will not be missed.

name: Francisco Assis (S&D).
text: – Madam President, in the present circumstances of the Middle East, we must welcome and encourage the mutual trust contract with Turkey put in place by the European Commission and its intention to strengthen cooperation with turkey in the refugee crisis. Once again, the European Commission, on this very important issue, is acting correctly, showing itself to be in favour, in return for better control of refugee flows and a more dignified reception of refugees and for some of these refugees to be resettled in the countries of the European Union.  Turkey is and must be a strategic ally of the European Union. But that should not make us lose sight of the issue of human rights and how they are treated or mistreated within Turkey. I would like at this point to draw attention here to the way in which the current Turkish authorities have been addressing the Kurdish issue. In recent months we have seen a disturbing upturn in fighting between Turkish security forces and Kurdish nationalist militants and we cannot ignore it, we have even to value the importance that the Kurds have given in fighting the Islamic State.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE).
text: Madam President, in this Chamber, watching the debate, I have heard many times that Turkey is a strategic partner of the European Union. I want to address the European Union: the criterion for being a strategic partner must not be respect for European principles and values? A country that every day insults and writes in the oldest of its shoes the European principles and values, can it be called a strategic partner of the European Union? How can Turkey be a strategic partner of the European Union when even on the issue of terrorism its role was suspected; when it exploits everyone and everything? To allow planes to strike ISIS, it struck and destroyed and flattened Kurdish villages that are actually resisting ISIS. Today, even as we speak, and I am addressing all the Member States, a Member State of the European Union, Cyprus, is being occupied by Turkey. How would colleagues feel if Turkey or another country, in fact, brought about the suffering it brought to Cyprus and kept their country in possession? For all this, then, we must be careful when defining Turkey as a strategic partner.

name: Costas Mavrides (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I am reading directly from the last report on Turkey, which was voted on overwhelmingly by this House just a few months ago. It includes the words ‘as soon as the set criteria have been fulfilled, to start negotiations on the judiciary and fundamental rights and on justice, freedom and security’. I repeat: ‘as soon as the set criteria have been fulfilled’. Now, given the comments about the negotiations on Cyprus, I will answer the question about the Turkish Cypriot leader, Mr Akinci. He has an extremely limited role to play, given that he is always under the certain rule of Turkey and Erdoğan, and I would reiterate a phrase from my Turkish Cypriot friend, an editor of a Turkish Cypriot newspaper in the occupied part of Cyprus, Mr Sener Levent: even for a bird to fly in the occupied part of Cyprus, it needs to have the licence of the chief commander of the Turkish troops.  And – the last word – our values in Europe are in our interests.

name: Илхан Кючюк (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, honourable Members, from the establishment of the European Union to the present day, the situation in the region and in the world has never been more dynamic and unpredictable. Despite the difficult political environment, the Turkish side bears the brunt of going conflicts and a refugee wave, and the government has responded in the most adequate responsible way to ensure the security of more than two million people. The country takes a clear Euro-Atlantic position, in full compliance with our EU partners, and has a leading role in the rapid resolution of the wars in the Middle East. Of course, Europe has its rules and criteria and we must not turn a blind eye to any deviation from our principles of democracy, the rule of law and human rights. This, however, should not turn us into judges, but on the contrary – we must, with the power of constructive dialogue, seek to smooth out these differences. I therefore believe that, more than ever, we need to deepen integration and cooperation with Turkey, because only a common approach is a possible solution to the challenges that have been addressed.

name: James Carver (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, it is difficult to understand Turkey’s foreign policy strategy, bearing in mind how they initially stood by, preventing Kobane’s inhabitants from either escaping or protecting themselves, before grudgingly allowing Kurdish intervention. Turkey’s latest rationale seems to indicate that by attacking Islamic State they may somehow make the West more tolerant of their own disgraceful behaviour towards the Kurds. Furthermore, there is the question of Turkey’s aspirations in Syria, where they have now given logistical and intelligence support to Jaish al-Fatah, the very command structure for Syrian jihadist groups. One must consider whether they now support a Sunni overthrow of a Shia government. Considering all this, can we truly put our hands on our hearts and say that Turkey genuinely upholds Western values? I, for one, believe that the time has come formally to curb Turkish aspirations for eventual EU membership.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Once again, today, the Council has had to listen to the tinkering with the political situation in Turkey. And your claim that Turkey is ready for Europe is, in fact, slowly one of the European Union's life lies; Turkey is increasingly becoming a risk: war against the Kurds, toleration of ISIS, business with IS, and a president campaigning like a sultan in Central Europe. And now the next blackmail: visa relief, or we'll send you the next million refugees to Europe. It is now revenge that we have not secured enough the external borders and have not made the borders stable. I will tell you one thing: the sovereignty and stability of our countries includes secure external borders of the Union.

name: Nicolas Schmit
text: President-in-Office of the Council, on behalf of the Vice—President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, I think that, despite all the very real difficulties and the concerns which have been expressed, there is one conclusion we have to draw: we need a genuine enhanced engagement with Turkey. We share so many interests, we share so many challenges, and therefore I think we have to continue to engage with this country.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: The debate is over. The sitting has been suspended until 12:00. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Cristian-Silviu Bușoi (PPE)
text: in writing. – Against the background of the current context, the refugee crisis and the conflict in Syria, strengthening the partnership between the EU and Turkey is an essential element in the successful management of the fight against terrorism and in order to ensure security in the area. However, Turkey's internal policy and its consequences for democracy and the rule of law in that country should not be neglected. The June elections were a win for Turkish democracy by representing all important political forces in parliament, unfortunately, but this success was not achieved by a coalition government. I hope that the interim government will provide a transparent and secure framework for the elections on 1 November and that, whatever the outcome, a government will be formed to express the will of the Turkish citizens. While Ankara accuses European officials of not taking Turkey's EU bid seriously by blocking the accession process, I would like to point out that the opening of key chapters 23 and 24 can only be done after reforms to ensure fundamental rights and freedom of justice are adopted. I therefore believe that we need to strengthen relations with Turkey, a strategic partner and a candidate state, without neglecting the efforts it must make in this regard.

name: El Presidente. –
text: Your Majesty, ladies and gentlemen, it is my pleasure and a great honour to welcome King Philip to the plenary session of the European Parliament in Strasbourg today.  Your Majesty: we have had the opportunity to meet on previous occasions, and I know him as a thoughtful and informed man, as a man with great experience in international and European affairs. I therefore look forward to your speech with great interest. A very important speech in these difficult times for Europe when we try to meet the challenge of our times — immigration - and a very timely speech, given that this year we celebrate the thirtieth anniversary of the signing of spain's Treaty of Accession to the European Community.  Anniversaries are always a good time to take stock of successes and failures, but also to make plans for the future. Thirty years ago the dream of many generations of Spaniards finally came true: at the end of a long exile, after many hardships and sacrifices, Spain returned to its place within the European democratic family.  Over the past thirty years, Europe has helped make Spain better and stronger. Spain has, in turn, contributed to making Europe better and stronger. It's been a big hit.  I would like Spain to continue to contribute its passion and ideas to Europe's success in the coming years. In these difficult times, the European Union needs Spain more than ever. I am very pleased, therefore, that His Majesty King Philip honours us today with his presence. Your Majesty, I warmly welcome you to the European Parliament and give you the floor.

name: Felipe VI.
text: – Mr President of the European Parliament, Mr President of the European Commission, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin my words before this House by thanking the President of the European Parliament for his kind invitation to address, as King of Spain, legitimate representatives of European citizens. And thank you, President, for your words and for your generous presentation. I do this as a Spaniard who also feels deeply European; I do this by assuming the historical heritage that precedes us and convinced that our future is in the continuation of our great common project of the European Union. (Applause) For the men and women of my generation, Europe has always been present in our intellectual and vital development. This presence, that closeness, has given rise to affections, hopes and illusions; has generated a sense of belonging to the European project whose own being coexists constructively and naturally with our identity as nationals of the Member States of the Union. Also, this conviction in Europe stems from the clear awareness that the Union is the story of an undoubted collective success which, despite its difficulties, has managed, in an outstanding way, to complete its main and highest objectives.  Goals of peace, harmony and coexistence between nations that, only decades ago, starred in one of the most devastating and brutal clashes in universal history. Objectives of prosperity and economic growth, which have made it possible for millions of men and women from families on our continent to have lived and live on unknown material and social welfare rates over time. Objectives, above all, defined by strong universal human principles and values, which are at the basis of this immense work, built with intelligence, generosity and with great effort and work by Europeans of various nationalities and of several generations. That faith in Europe with which I have begun my words is born of the deep European identity of my country. Spain and the Spanish are , and the honourable Members know this well – Europeans by culture and geography; by history and also by political vocation. It is not possible to conceive Spain without Europe or Europe without Spain. And so I'm European, because I'm Spanish. (Applause) Political, economic and social achievements, as well as Spain's extraordinary projection in recent decades and in all fields, could not be understood without the democratic will and progress of the Spanish people and without our firm commitment to European integration. Democratic Spain in recent decades has been solidly based on a firm and sincere will to understand among Spaniards; generous and fraternal will. And it has been based on our Constitution, which is the great covenant that defends, preserves and protects the rights and freedoms of citizens, protects the peoples of Spain in the exercise of their various cultures and traditions, languages and institutions, and enshrines freedom, justice, equality and political pluralism as essential values of our coexistence. Europe has been built on the will to add, not subtract; of un combining and not dividing; to know how to share and be supportive. Therefore, ladies and gentlemen, have the security of being able to have a fair and responsible Spain towards the European project; with a united Spain proud of its diversity; with a Spain that is supportive and respectful of the rule of law. This is how I understand our contribution to the prosperity of and to the European Union as one of the most important political works built in the recent history of Humanity. On the other hand, Spain's membership of the European Union has contributed decisively to the greater economic and social development of our country. This year we celebrate the 30th anniversary of Spain's entry into the European Communities. The "return from Spain to Europe" – if I may say so – is shown as the culmination of a great collective project that starts with the illustrators of the eighteenth century and which was felt intensely from the end of the nineteenth century. The ideas of regeneration and modernization across Europe — very present in the last century in Ortega y Gasset, and in Madariaga – were linked in the 1960s to the path to the democratization of my country. Thus Europe has been one of the great basic consensuses of Spanish society. It has been the horizon of democracy and also of economic modernization and the social and political regeneration of our country; and it still is today. Europe is where the Spaniards wanted to be, where we deserved to be and where we will always stay. (Applause) During these thirty years Spain has proven to be a constructive partner, in constant commitment to the values and principles of the Union, because they are ours. Ladies and gentlemen, the Spaniards have always maintained an attitude of confidence in the idea of Europe.  My country has received much from the Union, that is undoubted; but it is also important that at the same time it has made a remarkable contribution to the Community project and to the construction of Europe. Spain has always shown its Europeanist vocation, with crucial contributions in areas as diverse as European citizenship, cohesion policy, the promotion of cultural and linguistic diversity; or the deepening of an area of freedom, security and justice, characterized by mutual recognition of judicial decisions and effective police cooperation that preserves our freedoms. In addition to building from within, Spain has provided the Union with its historical links with Ibero-America, its close relationship with the Mediterranean, its clear transatlantic dimension and, in short, its universal vocation.  In this long and positive trajectory, it cannot be hidden — ladies and gentlemen — that in recent years they have not been easy for Spain or for many other countries in Europe. We still suffer from very high unemployment rates, one of the main problems for our economy and for our society. There are many sacrifices that the Spaniards have had to make to return to the path of growth and job creation. But we must understand and value that, in order to achieve all this, for the overcoming of the crisis, the contribution of the European institutions has been decisive. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the European project, which was born more than 60 years ago, effectively creates an area of peace, prosperity, freedom, justice and solidarity for which we must be legitimately proud. However, what has been done so far cannot lead us to complacency or conformism. Nothing is won forever. And we cannot lose sight of the future, nor allow ourselves to stall or retreat in the face of difficulties or challenges, which are great and therefore require a new political impetus. It is true that, at the end of the twentieth century, Europe materialized utopia inspired by the ideals of reconciliation, peace and shared prosperity, launched by the founding fathers in the 1950s. But today we Europeans must identify – beyond the preservation of what has been achieved and the overcoming of everyday challenges – new and high objectives, new great goals that bring strength and enthusiasm to the European project; both from within, the result of the convergence between leadership leadership and the thrust and sensitivity of all our fellow citizens; as out, in our common exterior projection. For the European Union to regain its prominence in the world, it is necessary to formulate a new ideal; a new European purpose that mobilizes citizens in favour of integration and the unity project.  In this sense, the consequences of the economic and financial crisis on our societies and the social and political challenges it has created must make us reflect and lead to decisive and effective action to strengthen the European project; an irreplaceable and vital project for all. And, therefore, strengthening the democratic legitimacy of the Community project is a fundamental element and need. The time has come to evolve in Europe towards a truly enhanced political community.  We must work to build a more integrated Europe, which can successfully cope with the management of a fully globalized future and which is capable of providing its citizens with confidence and closeness. Without a strong European Union there will be no effective solution to the problems of our respective nations. As Jean Monnet stressed in 1943: "The countries of Europe are too small to assure their peoples of the prosperity and social progress that is indispensable." In this regard, and from an institutional perspective, it should be stressed that the European Parliament has taken on strong leadership and offers a powerful political impetus towards Community integration. It would not be possible to understand this project of political and democratic integration, as a union of States and citizens, without the European Parliament. But it is the task of strengthening the good governance of the Union, respecting independence and separation of powers, ensing transparency and accountability, and ultimately bringing citizens closer to decision-making. The identification of new objectives necessarily leads us to underline the importance of the principles and values that are the very foundation of Europe: freedom, equality, solidarity, the dignity of men and women, pluralism and the defence of human rights are the foundations that define us as European. We must preserve and make these values effective because our identity depends on it, and because they are our deep convictions. These values are now questioned and Threatened. The fight against this threat is an indispensable imperative for the peoples who believe in democracy, who believe in freedom and justice. Ladies and gentlemen, ensuring the prosperity, growth and employment of citizens is also one of the Union's top priorities.  And in order to ensure the economic sustainability of the Community project, it seems clear that we must deepen the strengthening of economic and monetary union. In this context, the institutional scaffolding that we have provided ourselves with must continue to be completed through mechanisms that strengthen financial solidarity and enable, through control and surveillance, to prevent past excesses.  Thus, in the near future we must continue to promote a rigorous framework for coordination and budgetary supervision; advancing the introduction of own budgetary mechanisms for the euro area; deepening the banking union to overcome the effective fragmentation of financial markets; and, above all, establishing a framework that boosts the competitiveness and convergence of European economies. I am convinced that the debate on the future of the common currency will remain enormously relevant in the coming months and will bear concrete fruits based on responsibility and solidarity, true hallmarks also of the integration process.  For Spain, the single currency is an irreversible achievement. And we are convinced that the euro area is increasingly shaping up as the core of integration that is to lead us to greater political union. But that Union would never be complete without its essential social dimension, which cannot be preteasured. I therefore think it appropriate to reiterate the commitment made in Article 9 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, which clearly reflects our willingness to achieve a high level of employment and social protection, education and health protection. (Applause) We must send a clear and unequivocal signal that social problems are at the heart of the integration process and that our task, in this area, must be to help all Member States and their citizens develop their growth and employment potential, improving social cohesion and correcting inequalities, in line with the proposed objectives. Undoubtedly, the social dimension of the Union links directly with the Europe of citizens and gives humanity, sensitivity to those who need it most, to the whole process of Community integration. I think it is right to recall at this point Jacques Delors's words: "I reject a Europe that is nothing more than a market, an area of free change without soul, without conscience, without political will, without social dimension. If it was there," he said, "where we're going, I'm sounding a cry of alarm." (Applause) Ladies and gentlemen, in the field of external relations, the European Union must be set up as a global player, from the strength of its internal cohesion and unity of action. This highlights Europe's commitment to peace and security, to the eradication of poverty and the fight against terrorism, to the protection of human rights, or to respect for the fundamental principles of international law. Our external projection must be based on a more ambitious and generous common security and defence policy, capable of consistently combining its civilian and military capabilities in order to offer a holistic approach to crisis management that we continually face. In this context, The European Neighbourhood Policy takes full sense in the face, for example, of the migration problem, and leads us to reflect on the need to provide us with tools of collaboration with our neighbouring countries to avoid mass displacement, violence or insecurity. Spain has a useful and important experience in the treatment of migration flows. Dialogue and cooperation with the countries of origin and transit of irregular migrants must be at the heart of a real European immigration policy, as they are in Spanish migration policy. Spain therefore offers to share its experience and to support initiatives in the European Union in this area. This policy should be set up as an instrument that allows us to face shared challenges and also take advantage of opportunities in areas such as trade, energy or security. I would like to recall, in this context, the impetus given by Spain to a concrete initiative: the informal inter-ministerial meeting in Barcelona on 13 April with our neighbours in the South. In addition, we must continue to work to build a dense web of relationships that transcends our most immediate environment. Spain, convinced of the added value of a Union capable of tackling the challenges of a global world, has always driven and supported the European Union's relations with those regions with which our country maintains a special link, such as Ibero-America. Nor should we forget that, in a globalized world, the trade agenda becomes particularly important, given the direct impact that creating opportunities, investments and exchanges have on the well-being and prosperity of our societies.  I also recall and stress the importance of promoting environmental preservation and climate change policies. We have the opportunity to move forward in this field, with an eye on the new generations, because it is really our duty to leave them a better world. Ladies and gentlemen, while there are many challenges we face, I cannot fail to refer more explicitly to the drama that is taking place today at our borders.  We are overwhelmed by the heartbreaking suffering of those who come to Europe fleeing violence and fanaticism. Hundreds of thousands of refugees are pursuing a project of hope, who see in the Union a territory of peace, prosperity and justice. We can't let them down. We must respond from generosity, solidarity and responsibility, with a comprehensive and comprehensive approach that helps address the causes of the exodus of these people forced to leave their countries of origin. I am fully convinced that we will succeed; as I am that the only way to do it successfully is to do it among everyone.  Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as I said, the European Union is a success story which we must recognise, value and admire much more. And thanks to this success, the Union is now at a new stage in its trajectory that must be built and promoted – as the founding fathers did – from the highest values and seeking to achieve, again, the highest goals. We'll make it. And we will achieve it firmly, with determination and with the greatest ambition. No hesitation. With the indispensable participation and with the irreplaceable prominence of all the citizens of our nations. On 19 June 2014, the day of my proclamation as King, I said to the Spanish Parliament that the time had come for "a renewed monarchy for a new time". Today I stand before this House, which represents the citizens of Europe, that we all have the exciting challenge of also building a renewed Europe for a new time in a certainly different world. There is no alternative to a united Europe. Let's have confidence in Europe. Let us have confidence in ourselves, the Europeans. Thanks a lot. (Applause)

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Majesty! I would like to express my sincere thanks for the extraordinary encouragement you have shown this Parliament in your speech. I believe that the encouragement you have given this House in your words has not gone unheeded here. The fight for a united Europe, which you also made your cause with your speech, is our common task. I believe I am speaking on behalf of Members of this House when I thank you wholeheartedly for this great speech. Thank you very much! (Applause)

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D).
text: " Mr President, Honourable Parliament, Hungary mourns. It is my sad but heartfelt obligation here to report to the European Parliament, the directly elected political body of the Peoples of Europe, that one of the wise men of Europe who died yesterday, one of the greatest figures of Hungarian democracy: Árpád Göncz, former writer, great figure of the 1956 revolution of freedom, the first man of the Republic of Hungary for 10 years after the regime change, president of the Republic of Hungary. It is a great honour to commemorate in this House one of the wise men of Europe, one of the main shapers of eastern European democracies, and perhaps also symbolic, that today, when events are happening in this House that may have taken us out of everyday political give-and-take. Árpád Göncz was a Hungarian writer, translator and politician, sentenced to life in prison for his role in 1956 and released after six years. He became a member of the first Hungarian Parliament after the change of regime, became its president, and for 10 years thereafter became president of the Republic of Hungary. Since then, there has never been a popular leader of Hungary, beloved to the adoration of Hungarian society, who in 2000 received the "Vision for Europe" award for his work to create a united Europe. Later, his daughter Kinga Göncz became your colleague and member of the European Parliament. I just want to say goodbye to him with a quote, in order to leave the thinking of us politicians of today. He said: "Somewhere the real secret to popularity is when you don't always adjust to the requirements of popularity." "Our relationship to power is what we're trying to do. I'm thinking about who used it for what." Let us remember Arpad Göncz!

name: Presidente. –
text: Thank you, we join in the mourning, in memory of all the victims of the 1956 invasion of Hungary. Let us remember this man, but let us also remember all those who have fallen in the name of freedom through him.

name: Gerben-Jan Gerbrandy (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, a point of order as well. Yesterday we discussed publicly, for more than three hours, the emission measurements of the automotive industry – better known as ‘Dieselgate’ – while at the same time in Brussels the so-called Technical Committee for Motor Vehicles met. That is a comitology committee of national experts chaired by the Commission. Since a total lack of transparency is a crucial element in the current car crisis, I believe that this House ... (The President interrupted the speaker) This is a point of order. I do believe that this House and the European public have the right to know the position of the Commission and the national governments in this field. So my request to you is: could you please ask for the full minutes – not the summary notes – including the underlying documents of this meeting?

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D).
text: – Mr President, as we are talking about the recognition of victims, I would also like to use this turn of call to say that in Spain, in less than forty-eight hours, four women have been victims of gender-based violence, killed by sexist terrorism. If we had data on what is happening in Europe, this reality would be even worse. We are talking about lives of women who are being killed by the mere fact of being murdered and I urge the European Commission to leave the words and act in this regard.  (Applause)

name: Presidente. –
text: Mr President, this was not an item on the agenda, please speak on the items on the agenda, of course we all support violence against women, not only in Spain but throughout Europe and throughout the world.

name: Morten Messerschmidt (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I want to raise a point concerning the first vote on today’s voting list, on the calendar. As you can see, there will be no vote, because none of the amendments presented were deemed admissible. I have been asking for more than a week now for a reason why the proposal from the ECR Group, to limit the Strasbourg part-sessions from four to three days, would be inadmissible according to Mr Schultz. He refers to a verdict from the European Court of Justice from 2012, but that says nothing about the length of the part-sessions here. Therefore I would like to request either that we vote on the amendment presented by the ECR or that we have an in-depth analysis so that we can actually know within what framework we can present the amendments according to the calendar. It makes no sense for this House to approve a calendar if we are not entitled to amend it. (Applause)

name: Presidente. –
text: On behalf of the ECR Group, Mr Messerschmidt has tabled an amendment to delete Thursday from all strasbourg part-sessions in 2017.  The ECR Group already tabled a similar amendment in 2014 regarding the 2015 timetable. On that occasion, President Schulz considered the amendment inadmissible, considering that it would be contrary to the case law on the application of Protocol 6 on the seats of the institutions. At the request of his group, the President asked for the opinion of the Legal Service, but confirmed the President's interpretation. Therefore, having been declared inadmissible, as in 2014 – I am not interrupting you but I do not like to be interrupted by you – since I am answering a legal question put by a Member of Parliament and a political group, please listen to what the Presidency intends to communicate to the political group that has raised a legitimate and legally relevant issue.  I was therefore saying, since the amendment that you and your group have tabled for next year's calendar, being similar or identical to that amendment, having been declared inadmissible by the President, and then the choice of President confirmed by the Legal Service, the Presidency cannot but consider the same amendment tabled this year to be inadmissible. So there will be no vote. Therefore, since no amendments have been tabled in plenary relating to the calendar of 2017 session periods proposed by the Conference of Presidents and announced in plenary on Monday 5 October 2016, I declare adopted the calendar of session periods for 2017.

name: Morten Messerschmidt (ECR).
text: – Mr President, could we have the reason in writing? That has not been presented to us. I would like to see from the Legal Service the reason why this should be inadmissible. So if you just pass that to our office we would appreciate that.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is voting time.

name: Presidente. –
text: That concludes voting time.

name: Peter Jahr (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I would just like to say here that I would have liked to have had a little more courage in the parliamentary calendar for 2017, a little more courage in that we can, of course, also agree to save meetings in Brussels in favour of meetings in Strasbourg. I think quite simply that the work should be organised more effectively, so that we also have more opportunity to discuss the problems extensively in the relevant specialist committees. I very much regret that. But I say again: it is not all day evening. Perhaps we can make improvements in this respect. My petitum would be that if we were already sitting here in Strasbourg, we should use the time and, from time to time, a mini-plenary in Brussels in favour of a regular committee meeting.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, our parliament in the United Kingdom sat for 142 days last year and it was criticised widely for only sitting for that amount of time, yet we in Brussels and Strasbourg, in the plenary and mini-plenary, sit for just five days a month, and on three of those days it is only for part of a day that we actually sit. We end up with a debate in this Chamber in which speakers’ microphones are cut off after 60 seconds, 90 seconds or two minutes, and we have no way of expanding on a point; we have no way of properly challenging a speaker; we have no means of proper scrutiny of proposed legislation that comes through. Surely it would make more sense to have sufficient time allocated for proper reasoned debate. And those who actually believe in the structures and institutions of this place should surely welcome that. I think my 60 seconds is up!

name: Peter van Dalen (ECR).
text: Mr President, you need to explain to me what we are doing now. What's happening here is totally out of the way. We were refused to vote on the 2017 meeting schedule because there were no amendments. What happens now? There are explanations of vote on a vote that should not take place. Mr President, this is totally undemocratic. I haven't spoken out yet, Mr President. I'd like you to listen to my argument. Explanations of vote are issued here on a vote which should not take place. That is undemocratic. You have to tell the Conference of Group Chairmen that we should simply be able to vote on that timetable. Because if there are no amendments to that timetable, we should simply be able to vote on that timetable. This is totally wrong. This is complete nonsense. You have to raise this at the Conference of Group Chairmen.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the 2017 session schedule. The main issue of the proposal was whether or not Strasbourg should remain as the seat of the European Parliament. The idea of making Brussels the single seat of the European Parliament poses several problems. On the one hand, why should it be in Brussels rather than Strasbourg? One might as well argue for Parliament to meet only in Strasbourg, where pressure groups are less present. The choice of Brussels as a single seat would help to further centralise the European Union. However, the concentration of powers will necessarily be at the expense of the Member States. As for the extra cost, it is often greatly exaggerated. As MPs are constantly on the move (return to their constituencies, various missions, etc.), the expected benefits would ultimately be quite small. In addition, the abandonment of Strasbourg would result in a significant shortfall for the inhabitants of Strasbourg and many businesses, not to mention the high costs of moving and moving to Brussels.  The proposed timetable maintains the seat of the European Parliament in Strasbourg, so I voted in favour.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. As proposed by the Conference of Group Presidents, I voted in favour of the proposed timetable for parliamentary session periods.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported in 2017. parliamentary part-sessions.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I have validated this timetable which, although giving more importance to the "mini-sessions" in Brussels, does not call into question the siege of Strasbourg, which is contested by the most zealous Eurocrats.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. The aim here was to determine the plenary dates for 2017.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This calendar retraces the dates of parliamentary sessions for the year 2017 adopted in the Conference of Presidents. It maintains the division between the plenary sessions in Strasbourg (which ensures the maintenance of the headquarters) and the mini-sessions in Brussels. So I decided to vote for it.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the adoption of the European Parliament's timetable for 2017, in accordance with the proposal drawn up by the political groups and the bodies of the House.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This calendar maintains the division between plenary and mini-sessions. It therefore ensures the maintenance of the Strasbourg headquarters. So I voted for that proposal.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Abstention vote, no major news in sight for 2017.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Unfortunately, the Proposal of the Conference of Presidents maintains the absurd circus that is celebrated every month when MEPs travel from Brussels to Strasbourg for plenary sittings. I therefore abstained.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this proposal because the timetable in question maintains the division between the plenary session and the "mini-session". It thus ensures the maintenance of the Seat of the European Parliament in Strasbourg.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We support and approve the timetable for parliament's 2017 sessions as it is.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The 2017 calendar basically follows that of 2016 with the appropriate changes. Of course: I would have preferred to avoid spending public money to go to Strasbourg twelve times in 2017 as well. It is a waste, unjustified and unjustifiable, because if I want to visit Strasbourg - which I recommend I do because the city seems very pretty to me - I must not be forced to do so, but it must be a pleasure.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I hereily confirm my approval of the European Parliament's calendar for the year 2017.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This decision aims to adopt the timetable for the work of the European Parliament and its plenary session periods for 2017. I note that twelve plenary sessions are planned in Strasbourg in the same way as five "mini-sessions" taking place in Brussels. In the context of a reduction in European legislative activity, in accordance with the campaign commitments of the EPP and Jean-Claude Juncker to better legislate, the merits of these mini-sessions should be questioned and such a practice should not eventually be called into question by the Strasbourg plenary sessions, which are envisaged in the treaties. Nevertheless, considering that this proposal for a timetable respects the letter of the treaties in this regard, as I did last year, I voted in favour of this timetable, but I will remain attentive and vigilant on this issue.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am abstaining because I find it genuinely embarrassing that as a Parliament we cannot choose on the issue of dual seating.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the adoption of Parliament’s calendar of part-sessions for 2017.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today for the 2017 calendar of meetings. At the same time, I must say that I have done so with reservation: I strongly oppose the hundreds of millions of expensive renovations of the dilapidated buildings at the second place of work in Brussels, which were disclosed in the Welle plan! Such a waste of money is not reasonable for the taxpayer. I call for the European Parliament to move to our only real single seat as soon as possible: Strasbourg!

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a calendar of Parliament's 2017 sessions, as I consider the proposal to be in line with the needs and workings of the European Parliament and its Members, i.e. services and other bodies.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the 2017 session schedule. At stake in the proposal was the retention of Strasbourg as the seat of the European Parliament. The idea of making Brussels the single seat of the European Parliament is a number of problems. On the one hand, why should the headquarters be in Brussels rather than Strasbourg? One might as well argue for Parliament to sit only in Strasbourg where pressure groups are less present. The choice of Brussels as a single seat would help to further centralise the European Union. However, the concentration of powers will necessarily be at the expense of the Member States. As for the extra cost, it is often greatly exaggerated. As MPs are constantly on the move (return to their constituencies, various missions, etc.), the expected benefits would ultimately be quite small. In addition, the abandonment of Strasbourg would result in a significant shortfall for the inhabitants of Strasbourg and many businesses, not to mention the high costs of moving and moving to Brussels.  The proposed timetable maintains the seat of the European Parliament in Strasbourg, so I voted in favour.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's 2017 plenary calendar. This timetable is in line with the requirements of the European treaties as the 12 parliamentary sessions in Strasbourg are maintained. This timetable has been adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. The new calendar is commuting and provides sufficient space to deal with the proposals to be considered in detail. I am therefore voting in favour of the calendar for 2017.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. We have today approved the calendar of plenary sessions for 2017. Having already drawn up a timetable for activities confirms the efficiency of the highest European representative body, and enables us to organise our parliamentary mandate in the best possible way. However, I would like to take this opportunity to point out that I am a staunch supporter of the campaign for the so-called single seat, that is, a single seat for this Parliament, in Brussels. A single location would result in lower management costs, with an annual saving of around EUR 180 million, and a reduction in CO2 emissions due to the transport of people and documents.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. In its judgment of 13 December 2012, the Court annulled the Parliament's vote on 9 March 2011 on the timing of the 2012 and 2013 session periods in a case brought before the Court by the French Republic and the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg.  According to the judgment of the Court of Justice, the "12 periods of ordinary plenary sessions" must be of equivalent duration.  The Court of Justice recalled that only Member States have the legal competence to change the seat of institutions. It is therefore right that the President has ruled that the ECR Group's amendment to destabilise Strasbourg as the seat of the European Parliament is inadmissible.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the timetable for the part-sessions of Parliament for 2017.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. —In 2012, Parliament adopts a decision on the annual work schedule on the basis of a proposal from the Conference of Presidents. I supported the Proposal of the Conference of Presidents for the Calendar of European Parliament Meetings for 2017, which will host 17 of them.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I fully supported this unequivocally important and necessary proposal, because we MEPs need to understand how we will work after two years. This is particularly important if we can work more effectively for Europeans.  Long live the European Union, long live the European Parliament, long for Martin Schulz!

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the timetable for Parliament's 2017 sessions, because this timetable, although it adequately and comprehensively promotes the legislative and other parliamentary activities of the European Parliament, nevertheless operates solely on the basis of the religious holidays of the Catholic Church and does not take into account the religious holidays of the Orthodox Churches, as defined in particular by the Ecumenical Patriarchate of Constantinople, although a significant number of MEPs and MEPs are Orthodox Christians and , therefore, they are discriminated against in this regard in the exercise of their religious beliefs, in particular in relation to the Easter holiday.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I regret that once more the calendar foresees Parliament being in Strasbourg for 12 weeks.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Determining the timetable for its sessions is one of Parliament's responsibilities. Unusually, in the proposed 2017 calendar, important national commemorations are respected. It does not propose sessions, neither on 8 May, the day of the surrender of the Nazi armies, nor on 14 July, the revolutionary beginning of the modern era, nor on 11 November on the day of the defeat of German imperialism. I vote for and strongly encourage this new attitude that respects history.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The challenge of the proposal was to keep Strasbourg as the seat of the European Parliament. The idea of making Brussels the single seat of the European Parliament is a number of problems. On the one hand, why should the headquarters be in Brussels rather than Strasbourg? One might as well argue for Parliament to sit only in Strasbourg where pressure groups are less present. The choice of Brussels as a single seat would help to further centralise the European Union. However, the concentration of powers will necessarily be at the expense of the Member States. As for the extra cost, it is often greatly exaggerated. As MPs are constantly on the move (return to their constituencies, various missions, etc.), the expected benefits would ultimately be quite small. In addition, the abandonment of Strasbourg would result in a significant shortfall for the inhabitants of Strasbourg and many businesses, not to mention the high costs of moving and moving to Brussels.  The proposed timetable maintains the seat of the European Parliament in Strasbourg, I voted in favour.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal because I consider the 2017 timetable presented, appropriate to legislative requirements.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support the proposed dates for part-sessions and finalise the days set for plenary duties next year. This is essential to help with the planning of Members’ activities.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am in agreement with the proposed Parliament calendar of part sessions in 2017 and that is why I have voted in favour.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The 2017 calendar follows the usual schedule of meetings approved by Parliament year after year. I accepted the proposal.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This calendar maintains the division between plenary sessions and mini-sessions and thus the seat of the European Parliament in Strasbourg. So I voted for this text.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of adopting the European Parliament's work schedule for 2017. It will consist of twelve plenary sessions in Strasbourg and five in Brussels. This timetable reinforces the predominant role of the Strasbourg headquarters, which is constantly defended by the French EPP delegation of which I am a member. Outside the plenary sessions, MEPs work in committees in Brussels. These committees develop, amend and adopt legislative proposals and initiative reports. MEPs review the Commission's and the Council's proposals and prepare reports which will be put to a plenary vote. Weeks dedicated to parliamentary activities in constituencies are also planned. These so-called "green" weeks allow Members of Parliament to go out on the ground to listen to their fellow citizens, as I do regularly in the riding of the Greater East.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for the new calendar of Parliament’s part-sessions for 2017.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support Parliament's calendar proposal for 2017. The timely drafting of the European Parliament's calendar is essential due to the good functioning of Parliament. The large volume of work and obligations of European MEPs requires good planning and it is essential that the calendar of sessions and other related activities is well determined. Sometimes the European Parliament seems distant and abstract for many european citizens. It is the activities of MPs on the ground that can make this work more transparent and closer to voters. Members therefore need to have schedules for committees, political groups and other parliamentary activities scheduled early enough to plan activities in their constituencies.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This calendar maintains the division between plenary sessions and mini-sessions and thus the seat of the European Parliament in Strasbourg. So I voted for this text.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. \u2012 I support the 2107 Session Calendar proposal as it meets all the protocols provided for.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am a realist, which is why I believe that approval of only one seat of the European Parliament is very unlikely in the current legal situation. On the other hand, proposals to reduce the cost of regular removals of the European Parliament should be considered. For this reason too, I would not resist the proposals put forward to change the timetable for the EP's work to vote in plenary.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament has adopted the new calendar of session periods for the 2017 financial year. This timetable is in line with previous timetables and takes into account the demands of parliamentarians' work.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the adoption of the European Parliament's timetable for 2017, in accordance with the proposal drawn up by the political groups and the bodies of the House.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this 2017 calendar proposed by the Conference of Presidents, which sets the periods and locations of the various sessions.  The definition of this timetable will enable effective work by alternating weeks of parliamentary committees, group meetings and plenary sessions.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ We need to have an organised Parliamentary calendar, and the way that this has been presented allows me to carry out my parliamentary tasks and duties, while giving me sufficient time to stay in touch with the West Midlands.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ This explanation of the vote comes as a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Regulation is complied with.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of Parliament’s calendar of part-sessions for 2017 which organises the work of the European Parliament for 2017

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I did not support the calendar of sessions for 2017 proposed by the Presidency Conference, as it still proposes to hold four-day sessions in Strasbourg. Namely, 12 times a year, european parliament staff travel to Strasbourg only for plenary sessions, which could simply be held in Brussels, where all the conditions exist.  Since I have supported the Single seat initiative since I entered the European Parliament, I have also supported an amendment in this report to advocate a position on the need to abolish the practice of plenary sessions in Strasbourg, which points out that the vast majority of MEPs also support this initiative.  Given the huge costs of transport and residence in Strasbourg and the detrimental impact on the environment, I believe these are realistic requirements that could greatly reduce the labour costs of this institution.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported parliament's 2017 part-session schedule as a technical report that will allow the smooth functioning of our work and the work of the entire European Parliament.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The calendar maintains the division between plenary and mini-sessions, which ensures the maintenance of the Strasbourg Parliament. So I voted for it.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I have adopted the meeting calendar for 2017 prepared in the usual order. The procedure follows the practice of recent years.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the 2017 calendar of EP part-sessions to be held in Brussels and Strasbourg. It is just a formal procedure to adopt the dates on which the part-sessions will be held and I did not have any objections against the suggested dates.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 We have nothing to observe about the timetable, since it stems from the Treaties and the need to follow up on the entire formal process associated with it.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I agreed with the calendar of meetings. My ECR Group tabled an amendment to limit the strasbourg part-session to three days. The EP is obliged to hold 12 monthly plenary sessions in Strasbourg. However, their duration is not predetermined anywhere. Since the legislative term, it has been accepted that the plenary will not begin until late Monday afternoon and end at noon on Thursday. However, the President of Parliament, Martin Schulz, decided, without justification, not to put our ECR amendment to a shortening of the length of stay to the vote. Only the EU Treaty still forces us to maintain the expensive travel circus. The EU institutionally supports the vacancy of 200,000 square metres of office space in several buildings over 300 days for additional costs of EUR 180 million per year. That is why I was the first Member ever to propose that we temporarily make the EP in Strasbourg a reception centre for migrants and refugees in the german-French border area. Commission Vice-President Frans Timmermans said: "I want to thank this Parliament for its leadership in this issue." Then please, let us take this seriously! Instead of expropriating private individuals, we should use the empty EU Parliament in Strasbourg as a reception centre for refugees. At least 750 single rooms are available above the Chamber, as each Member's office has its own bed and shower/toilet. And Brussels already has a fully functioning parliamentary structure.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We voted against the provision of parliament’s consent to this protocol because, on a broader point, we do not support the use of member-state taxpayers’ money, through the European Neighbourhood Policy, being used to support an EU foreign policy in the region and we are against the waste of British taxpayers’ money through projects administered by the EU overseas.  As a secondary point, the full financial implications of this decision to the United Kingdom, in terms of our overall net contribution to the European Union budgets and the money available within the UK via these programmes are unknown. We will therefore not provide blanket support for Tunisia’s access to EU funding programmes when the full financial implications are not fully worked out.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Tunisia is going through a phase of political and economic transition.  Economic and social development plays a central role in the stability of the young democracy on Europe's doorstep. This is the background to the country's strong interest in cooperating with the European Union, its main partner.  In fact, the Additional Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement signed with the neighbouring countries lays down the technical and financial arrangements for Tunisia's participation in certain EU programmes. The commitment to cooperate relates in particular to education, education, youth and university training. I voted in favour of the agreement with the European Union shoots inclusive economic growth in the North African country, both nationally and internationally, and so that the EU's concrete investment can promote the country's resources, the cradle of the Arab Spring.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. During the Ben Ali regime, the European Union and Tunisia concluded an association agreement which, while incorporating elements for political dialogue and cooperation, is mainly based on a desire to liberalise trade in the Euro-Mediterranean area through the conclusion of free trade agreements. Such agreements are precisely one of the causes of the odious and illegitimate debt incurred by the State of Tunisia and whose burden the Tunisian people unfairly bear. I have therefore not been able to vote in favour of this Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement on the general principles of Tunisia's participation in the Union's programmes as it sees a deepening of this liberalizing logic and even goes further, since the rapporteur, the Italian socialist Panzeri, considers Tunisia, newly a strategic ally of NATO, to be a strategic ally , should participate in the European Union's Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP).

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I spoke out against this report aimed at establishing an agreement between the European Union and the Tunisian Republic on Tunisia's economic and financial assistance and participation in the EU programme. The more intensive supervision of Tunisia's migration should indeed be the highest priority of the Union, which, it must be remembered, is with the United States responsible for bringing the Islamists to power through the support of supposedly democratic groups. For such economic agreements to develop between the EU and Tunisia, conditions are needed such as the intensive fight against migratory flows or, towards France, the fulfily of Tunisian commitments to develop french learning.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report, which was a consent vote on a Council decision on a protocol to the Euro-Med agreement to allow Tunisia to access EU programmes through a Framework Agreement.  The Tunisian Government that was elected last year is in favour of pluralist democracy and the new constitution is generally liberal, inclusive, pro-gender equality and pluralist, and includes protections for all religions and minorities. The Agreement will not be with a particular government but with the Republic of Tunisia I did not vote against giving consent as I did not wish to block the Tunisian Government from accessing EU civilian programmes that it could find very useful in transitioning to democracy after decades of dictatorship. Programmes named in the justification include cooperation in education, universities, research and Erasmus. However, one of the programmes Tunisia would be authorised to join is the EU’s Common Security and Defence Policy. EU and US military policy in the Middle East and North Africa has resulted in disastrous consequences and the further expansion of this policy is something I oppose, which is why I did not vote in favour of the report.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This protocol calls on the Council to approve a framework agreement between the European Union and Tunisia. This document provides for the definition of financial and technical rules that would give Tunisia the opportunity to participate in EU programmes. Through this agreement, Tunisia would be able to benefit from technical and financial assistance from the Union.  It is true that this country is currently experiencing political and economic difficulties.  But the European Union is being hypocritical. Indeed, it is partly responsible for this situation through its interference with the United States. Moreover, instead of worrying about the Tunisian economy, the EU would do better to sweep its door and help its neighbours who share a common history and civilization. Serbia, for example.  And if the European Union is keen to have links with Tunisia, it would be smarter for it to work with the Tunisian authorities on security and immigration issues. Any partnership between that country and the Member States should thus be conditioned by obligations of results in this area. That is why I voted against this text.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I do not believe that Tunisia should be allowed to participate in taxpayer-funded programmes, and therefore I voted against.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation because, within the framework of the European Neighbourhood Policy, this decision is one of many measures aimed at promoting Tunisia's reform, modernisation and democratic transition.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal. Tunisia's economic situation has deteriorated significantly both domestically and internationally in recent years, especially in terms of trade with Europe, which remains Tunisia's most important partner. I agree that the Tunisian issue is very important and that the EU should make concrete economic and investment commitments in order to support the country's fragile transition to democracy. I support the proposals set out above that the EU should cooperate more closely in the fields of university education, general education, training and youth through programmes such as Erasmus+. Tunisia should also be able to join european common security and defence policy (CSDP) missions and activities.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We voted against the provision of Parliament’s consent to this protocol because, on a broader point, we do not support the use of Member-State taxpayers’ money, through the European Neighbourhood Policy, being used to support an EU foreign policy in the region, and we are against the waste of British taxpayers’ money through projects administered by the EU overseas.  As a secondary point the full financial implications of this decision to the United Kingdom, in terms of our overall net contribution to the European Union budgets and the money available within the UK via these programmes, are unknown. We will therefore not provide blanket support for Tunisia’s access to EU funding programmes when the full financial implications are not fully worked out.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I believe that the EU should focus on security and migration issues as a priority in its dealings with Tunisia. That is why I have not supported this report, which suffers from a biased perspective and a poor hierarchy of problems.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. In order to support Tunisia's democratic transition process, it should be helped to strengthen its economy. It is in this spirit that Tunisia's participation in the Union's programmes should be considered, through this protocol, which I have approved. Tunisia's financial contribution should be kept as low as possible. The Union must also strengthen cooperation in the areas of higher education, general education, training and youth, through programmes such as Erasmus and other programmes aimed at fostering contacts between people.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement on the general principles of Tunisia's participation in Union programmes because it will benefit both countries. The Tunisian economy has deteriorated markedly in recent years, both nationally and internationally, particularly with regard to its trade with Europe, which remains its main partner. It is therefore vital that Tunisia becomes a priority for Europe and that It makes concrete economic and investment commitments to support the country's fragile transition to democracy, while also considering that the success of the Tunisian experiment is in the interests of the entire region and the Union.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean agreement on the general principles of Tunisia's participation in the Union's programmes should allow the gradual opening of certain EU programmes and agencies to partner countries, particularly those in the Maghreb. We want to accompany the country by reforming it, modernizing it and ensuring its transition. Before committing to this financial and technical partnership, the EU should address the migration and security situation with Tunisia. Moreover, through this report, the EU introduces a form of interference with Tunisian democracy as if past experience had not demonstrated the limits of the action of the EU or the United States since a regime has been replaced by the coming to power of Islamists. So I voted against this protocol.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Although it is a report with contents that we can support, in some passages I see some contradictions that make it impossible for me to give my full support to this text, which is why I voted to abstain.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour, because I support Tunisia’s wish to cooperate with the EU in the fields of research and education, and of SMEs, as these were the interests expressed by the Tunisian Government.
