However, my vote does not in any way represent a support for the participation of Tunisia in the missions and activities of the European Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP).

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Recommendation granting approval for the conclusion of the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement on Tunisia's participation in Union programmes. I believe that this Protocol can help to consolidate the country's fragile transition to democracy by boosting the country's economic and social development. To this end, I consider of the utmost interest the forecasts included in this Protocol in order to reduce Tunisia's financial contribution to the maximum possible, in line with the rebates granted to other neighbouring countries, such as Ukraine. The EU must also strengthen cooperation in the fields of university education, general education, training and youth through programmes such as Erasmus+ and other programmes aimed at developing contacts between people.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this recommendation in support of the Council decision on the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement establishing an association between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Tunisia, of the other part. Tunisia is a country in the Middle East and North Africa (MENA) region, following the path of democracy and changing the political system. Tunisia's success in the transition to democracy depends on its future economic and social development. Tunisia has a high potential for long-term growth. The implementation of the expected reforms, combined with existing assets such as Tunisia's human resources, and an open economy will unlock this potential and will stimulate the country's economy in a more sustainable and inclusive way. Tunisia's economic situation has deteriorated significantly in recent years, both domestically and internationally, especially in terms of trade with Europe, which remains Tunisia's most important partner. Against this background, it is vital that the Tunisian issue becomes a priority for the EU and that the EU makes concrete economic and investment commitments to support the country's fragile democratic transition, while bearing in mind that the success of the Tunisian experiment is in the interest of the region as a whole and the EU. Therefore, tunisian participation in EU programmes in this regard should be taken into account. In addition, the EU should cooperate more closely in the fields of university education, general education, training and youth through programmes such as Erasmus+ and others aimed at developing people-to-people contacts.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. Tunisia, as one of the countries of North Africa, and in this way practically the european Union's southern neighbour, is very important for future developments in the Mediterranean. In the light of the migrant crisis that we have faced, it is very important that we improve relations and pay much more attention to these countries. Tunisia is the most successful in getting into something normal, you could even call it a democratic state. By signing the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement, we will further improve these already good relations, which we should also follow in the attitude of other countries in North Africa. All my support for this recommendation.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Support for Tunisia and its fragile political situation are priorities that cannot be postponed. This country, unlike the others involved in the Arab Spring, is the only country to have embarked on a democratic transition which, although very fragile, has great potential for development.  The Nobel Peace Prize to the Tunisian National Dialogue Quartet awarded at this time is a very important recognition of the efforts made to stabilise an open dialogue and pluralistic democracy in the state. As we have sadly confirmed with the attacks on the Bardo museum and in Sousse, the Tunisian political experiment is, however, severely suffered and opposed. In this respect, Europe has the opportunity to play a key role, not only for the economic and democratic development of the country, but also for the stability of the Mediterranean area in the interests of European security.  I therefore voted in favour of the Panzeri report, which calls for closer EU-Tunisia cooperation, particularly in the areas of training and education and in the operations of the Common European Security and Defence Policy.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I support this process, which aims to help Tunisia cope with a bad economic situation. Tunisia is the place where the Arab Spring was "born" and as a social democrat it is extremely important to me to help this country fight for democracy and democratic principles, which are still on fragile feet.  Therefore, I believe that the EU needs to take concrete economic and investment measures, which would support Tunisia's transition to a country of democracy.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report, which was a consent vote on a Council decision on a protocol to the Euro-Med agreement to allow Tunisia to access EU programmes through a Framework Agreement.  The Tunisian Government that was elected last year is in favour of pluralist democracy and the new constitution is generally liberal, inclusive, pro-gender equality and pluralist, and includes protections for all religions and minorities. The Agreement will not be with a particular government but with the Republic of Tunisia I did not vote against giving consent as I did not wish to block the Tunisian Government from accessing EU civilian programmes that it could find very useful in transitioning to democracy after decades of dictatorship. Programmes named in the justification include cooperation in education, universities, research and Erasmus. However, one of the programmes Tunisia would be authorised to join is the EU’s Common Security and Defence Policy. EU and US military policy in the Middle East and North Africa has resulted in disastrous consequences and the further expansion of this policy is something I oppose, which is why I did not vote in favour of the report..

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I am convinced that it is essential that Tunisia, the cradle of the Arab Spring and a country in democratic transition, should be supported in its process of transition and transformation. Tunisia's participation in EU programmes is essential to enable the country to find the stability it needs to grow economically and politically.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Between December 2010 and spring 2011, that phenomenon of social protests and riots developed in the southern and eastern Mediterranean that is known journalistically as the "Arab Spring". The only country where there has been a democratic and stable conclusion to that historic path is Tunisia, the country where the protests originated before spreading to the rest of the Arab world.  Today Tunisia is a country in search of a future, a democratic and modern future, in which the will of the government and the vast majority of the population – who look with friendship to the EU and the West and who see the EU as the eu's main economic and political partner – is being put in difficulty by the destabilising actions of jihadist militias exploiting infrastructure deficiencies , the large pockets of poverty that still exist and the low literacy rate of rural areas to continue the counter-revolutionary and anti-Western campaign.  It is the Union's duty to assist the process of modernisation and democratisation in Tunisia by strengthening its public infrastructure and the role of the civil authorities, in the knowledge that what happens in Tunisia will greatly affect the stability and economic and social security of the European Union in the coming years.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. The rapporteur wants to strengthen economic and political ties between the European Union, its Member States and Tunisia in order to support the country's fragile democratic transition. The protocol aims to define the financial and technical rules for Tunisia to participate in certain EU programmes. The horizontal framework sets out the principles of economic, financial and technical cooperation and allows Tunisia to receive technical assistance from the European Union. The European Union, its Member States and their allies, in particular the United States bear a very heavy responsibility for the destabilization of Tunisia, the fall of Ben Ali and the arrival of Islamists in government. We believe that in the economic field the Union must first strengthen its links with peripheral countries such as Serbia. In return for these economic agreements, European authorities should require Tunisia to control the migratory flows that pass through its territory. Finally, these agreements should be conditioned on convincing results in the fight against terrorism. That is why I voted against this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In recent years, the Tunisian economy has deteriorated significantly in both domestic and external terms, but especially in terms of trade with Europe, which remains its main partner. However, a first EU step to support the country's fragile transition to democracy could be achieved by focusing on economic issues and investment to support the country's fragile transition to democracy. In this context, it must be borne in mind that Tunisia is the birthplace of the Arab Spring, being the only country in the region of the countries of the Middle East and North Africa (MENA) that has survived this social and political event, and the success of the transition to democracy depends on social and economic development in the future. I voted in favour of the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement establishing an association between the European Communities and their Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of Tunisia, on the other, as Tunisia has long-term growth potential and, together with the EU, existing resources such as human resources and the open economy should be expected , in such a way as to help stimulate the Tunisian economy in a more sustainable and inclusive manner.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against. The text is not strong enough to change the situation in Tunisia.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this text today, which aims to establish financial and technical standards to enable the Republic of Tunisia to participate in some important European Union programmes. Among the various countries in the North African region, Tunisia has strong long-term growth potential. Indeed, thanks to the implementation of a series of reforms, it has taken the right path towards the development of an increasingly open, sustainable and inclusive economy.  Unfortunately, in recent years the country has had to suffer a considerable deterioration in the economic system as a whole, especially in terms of trade with Europe, which remains its main partner.  It is therefore essential to make the Tunisian issue one of the European Union's priorities, through the preparation of concrete economic commitments and investments, so as to effectively support the country's fragile transition to democracy.  The protocol is a cooperation step that allows Tunisia access to the assistance, especially financial assistance, provided by the EU through its programmes, and I have therefore chosen to vote in favour of the text.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report, which was a consent vote on a Council decision on a protocol to the Euro-Med agreement to allow Tunisia to access EU programmes through a Framework Agreement.  The Tunisian Government that was elected last year is in favour of pluralist democracy and the new constitution is generally liberal, inclusive, pro-gender equality and pluralist, and includes protections for all religions and minorities. The Agreement will not be with a particular government but with the Republic of Tunisia I did not vote against giving consent as I did not wish to block the Tunisian Government from accessing EU civilian programmes that it could find very useful in transitioning to democracy after decades of dictatorship. Programmes named in the justification include cooperation in education, universities, research and Erasmus. However, one of the programmes Tunisia would be authorised to join is the EU’s Common Security and Defence Policy. EU and US military policy in the Middle East and North Africa has resulted in disastrous consequences and the further expansion of this policy is something I oppose, which is why I did not vote in favour of the report.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the provision of parliament’s consent to this protocol because, on a broader point, UKIP does not support the use of member-state taxpayers’ money, through the European Neighbourhood Policy, being used to support an EU foreign policy in the region and we are against the waste of British taxpayers’ money through projects administered by the EU overseas.  As a secondary point, the full financial implications of this decision to the United Kingdom, in terms of our overall net contribution to the European Union budgets and the money available within the UK via these programmes are unknown. UKIP will therefore not provide blanket support for Tunisia’s access to EU funding programmes when the full financial implications are not fully worked out.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I agreed to give consent as I believe that we need to provide all the support necessary for Tunisia in its transition to democracy, particularly through economic and social benefits. This can help boost their economy and their growth potential. Since Europe is one of their main trading partners it is important that this is an EU priority. With this partnership we can also help improve their education and training programmes.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 This is the vote on a protocol to be annexed to the Euro-Mediterranean agreement to allow Tunisia to participate in EU programmes.  Tunisia expressed in December 2013 its keen interest in participating in this framework agreement on general principles, which contains several standard clauses that are applied to each participant. The Protocol lays down the different financial and technical rules for its participation in certain EU programmes. It should be specified that third countries can only participate in certain programmes and, if the legal basis of the programme so permits. Tunisia will have to contribute financially, like all other countries, to the programmes in which it should participate. In practice, these are mostly programmes in the fields of university collaboration, youth and education programmes (Erasmus +...) as well as several other programmes to promote contacts between civil societies.  Given that Tunisia is a young democracy, one of the few that emerged from the Arab Spring, the European Union should support this nascent democracy. The vote indicated is positive because this protocol gives Tunisia this opportunity, which will in any case have to pay its share, like all the other countries, in order to have access to the programmes. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because, for me, the European Union should focus on the security and migration sector in its dealings with Tunisia and not on "the economy and investments, in order to support the fragile democratic transition of the country".  This transition, orchestrated by the EU and the United States, has also led to the Islamists coming to power and has resulted in a sharp loss of internal stability.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 This Protocol concerns the Euro-Mediterranean Association Agreement between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Tunisia, of the other part, on a Framework Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Tunisia on the general principles governing the participation of the Republic of Tunisia in Union programmes. In recent years, Tunisia's economy has deteriorated significantly, both domestically and internationally, particularly in terms of trade with Europe, which remains its main partner. In this light it is very important that the Tunisian issue becomes an EU priority, with the EU undertaking concrete commitments at economic and investment level aimed at supporting the Tunisian economy.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement on the general principles of Tunisia's participation in EU programmes. Tunisia's economy has deteriorated considerably in recent years, both at national and international level, especially in terms of trade with Europe, which remains its main partner and the country has been the subject of bloody fundamentalist attacks.  In order to support Tunisia, the European Union is committed to supporting its economy and investing in the country. To this end, the EU will step up cooperation in the fields of university education, general education, training and youth through programmes such as Erasmus+. Tunisia should also have the opportunity to take part in the missions and activities of the European Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP).

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal because I believe that it is legitimate, given Tunisia's interest in participating in the wide range of programmes open to partner countries, to try to improve the country's economic condition. In addition, Tunisia has a strong potential for long-term growth. , which remains its main partner. Finally, I fully agree that the Tunisian issue is becoming an EU priority and that the Eu ropean Union is making economic commitments, including through investment, leading to democratic government. Tunisia should also have the opportunity to take part in the missions and activities of the Common European Security and Defence Policy.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We voted against the provision of Parliament’s consent to this protocol because, on a broader point, we do not support the use of Member-State taxpayers’ money, through the European Neighbourhood Policy, being used to support an EU foreign policy in the region, and we are against the waste of British taxpayers’ money through projects administered by the EU overseas.  As a secondary point the full financial implications of this decision to the United Kingdom, in terms of our overall net contribution to the European Union budgets and the money available within the UK via these programmes, are unknown. We will therefore not provide blanket support for Tunisia’s access to EU funding programmes when the full financial implications are not fully worked out.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the Panzeri Report which approves the conclusion of a Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement between the EU and Tunisia whose objective is to establish the financial and technical rules enabling Tunisia to participate in certain Union programmes.  The horizontal framework established by the Protocol is a system of economic, financial and technical cooperation which allows access to assistance, in particular financial, to be provided by the Union under union programmes.  After the Arab Spring and in view of the consensual adoption of a new constitution in January 2014, relations with the EU are expected to evolve positively, and this Agreement is vital to contribute to the country's transition to democracy by stepping up cooperation. Tunisia is therefore authorised to participate in all current and future Union programmes open to Tunisia's participation in accordance with the applicable provisions on the adoption of those programmes.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Tunisia's participation in EU programmes is a key opportunity within the framework of Europe's neighbourhood policy in order to contribute to the country's modernisation and transition to democracy. I therefore believe that it is important for Europe to make economic commitments and concrete investments on Tunisian territory. The recommendation makes clear the need for the European Union to cooperate with the Republic of Tunisia, which is a source of strong long-term growth potential if the planned reforms are implemented. It is therefore necessary to assist the country with economic, technical and financial instruments, so as to allow Tunisia to participate in European programmes that would enable it to start the full development of its potential.  I voted in favour of the recommendation because I believe that it is in the interests of both parties to conclude an agreement providing for cooperation between Tunisia and the European Union in a number of areas, including the economy, education, training and the activities of the Common European Security and Defence Policy.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ EU foreign policy is strengthened by creating relationships with third countries. The recommendation for a Protocol to the Euromed Agreement will promote reform, modernisation and transition in the country as well as benefit the EU neighbourhood policy. Thus I voted in favour.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. During the Ben Ali regime, the European Union and Tunisia concluded an association agreement which, while incorporating elements for political dialogue and cooperation, is mainly based on a desire to liberalise trade in the Euro-Mediterranean area through the conclusion of free trade agreements. Such agreements are precisely one of the causes of the odious and illegitimate debt incurred by the State of Tunisia and whose burden the Tunisian people unfairly bear. I have therefore not been able to vote in favour of this Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement on the general principles of Tunisia's participation in the Union's programmes as it sees a deepening of this liberalizing logic and even goes further, since the rapporteur, the Italian socialist Panzeri, considers Tunisia, newly a strategic ally of NATO, to be a strategic ally , should participate in the European Union's Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP).

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of giving consent to the conclusion of the Protocol since this provides the right tools for the EU to make concrete economic and investment commitments aimed at supporting the country’s transition to democracy. At the moment the Tunisian economy has deteriorated both domestically and in the international sphere. It is very important that Tunisia is given support and it is also important for the Tunisian issue to become an EU priority.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 With Tunisia having great long-term growth potential, I believe that it is essential that the Tunisian issue becomes an EU priority and that the EU is committed concretely to the economic and investment plan that supports the fragile transition of that country to democracy, the success of the Tunisian experiment being in the interest of the whole region, but also of the Union.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: in writing. 2012 Twenty years after the signing of the Association Agreement between the European Union and Tunisia, which has made a major contribution to strengthening political, trade, economic, social and cultural relations between Tunisia and the European Union, Parliament's recommendation, on which I voted in favour, highlights the EU's interest in the only country in the North African region which, through considerable difficulties, is facing the difficult transition to full democracy.  It is therefore essential that Tunisia's participation in EU programmes is encouraged and that the EU intensifies cooperation with Tunis in areas such as general and university education, including through programmes such as Erasmus+, in the knowledge that the success of the Tunisian experiment is in the interests of the whole region and of Europe itself.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report proposes the conclusion by the Council of the Protocol containing a framework agreement on the general principles of Tunisia's participation in the Union's programmes. In the context of the European Neighbourhood Policy, the gradual opening of certain EU programmes and agencies to the partner countries affected by the policy is one of many measures to promote reform, modernisation and transition in the neighbouring countries of the European Union. This protocol includes financial assistance to Tunisia. While the Arab Spring has expressed the public's call for more freedoms and democracy, Tunisia is now facing the influence of radical Islamist movements, which is fuelling the country's instability and slowing down the realization of its strong economic potential. Considering that Tunisia is an important historical and geopolitical partner, I believe that the European Union must support Tunisia in its democratic transition. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. Our relations with the neighbouring countries of the Mediterranean must move towards ever more cooperation. I therefore supported this text on Tunisia's participation in the European Union's programmes. I consider that providing our technical, financial and economic assistance to Tunisia is a concrete and positive step to strengthen the exemplary cooperation that exists with Tunisia.

name: Dennis de Jong (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I support Tunisia’s wish to cooperate with the EU in the fields of research and education. However, I do not support the participation of Tunisia in the missions and activities of the European Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP). As the latter is not explicitly excluded from the Council decision on the conclusion of the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement, I abstained.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Tunisia's current transition to democracy is as important as it is delicate. The implementation of the planned reforms and the exploitation of existing resources are two key elements for Tunisia's growth, as they aim to promote the country's economy in a more sustainable and inclusive way.  In recent years, however, Tunisia's economy has deteriorated considerably and trade with Europe, its main partner, has declined considerably. The affirmation of democracy will depend on the possible economic and social development of that country.  For these reasons, I think it is important for Europe to recognise the importance of the Tunisian issue and to commit itself economically to concrete investments to promote this transition. Its success is in the interests of the whole Union.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. The follow-up report on the implementation of the European Neighbourhood Policy in Tunisia points out that Tunisia has made real progress in the field of research and innovation. This progress has been made possible by structural reforms and agreements with internationally recognized research organizations or institutions.  Tunisia is now the most advanced country in our Mediterranean neighbourhood. It is right that it will now take part in EU programmes such as the European research programme Horizon 2020. This will strengthen the links between the EU and Tunisia and will be used for the development of its economy.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This new draft Council decision concerns the European Union's aid to Tunisia, while the Union has been one of the main, if not the only, actors in the country's destabilization. What the European Union considers to be an opportune period for the country's recovery is in fact only an unstable situation, simply because of the Union's interventionism. As poverty in the Union rises and supranational policies confirm their failure, the Union prefers to spend taxpayers' money on obscure aid programmes whose effects on the ground are difficult to assess. It would make more sense for the European Union to take an interest in the migration crisis, the rise of Islamism and the security problems it creates. That is why this draft decision seems to me to be disconnected from the current problems of the French and the peoples of Europe in general. So I voted against this report.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported this technical report because Tunisia was the first country to be embraced by the "Arab Spring", and three years later it remains an example for other countries with its democratic transition. The country already enjoys strong trade links with the EU, which will be further strengthened through the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement. This treaty aims to remove barriers to trade and investment in order to create a free trade area in the region. Almost all countries in the region, with the exception of Syria and Libya, have signed similar association agreements with the EU. Through the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement, the EU provides support to countries in their economic development and democratic transition.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 We are voting against, we are opposed to the European Union's interventions in the internal affairs of third countries, we consider them a remnant and a revival of colonialism, and they are proven to create more problems than they are supposed to solve.

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: in writing. – We voted against the provision of Parliament’s consent to this protocol because, on a broader point, we do not support the use of Member-State taxpayers’ money, through the European Neighbourhood Policy, being used to support an EU foreign policy in the region, and we are against the waste of British taxpayers’ money through projects administered by the EU overseas.  As a secondary point the full financial implications of this decision to the United Kingdom, in terms of our overall net contribution to the European Union budgets and the money available within the UK via these programmes, are unknown. We will therefore not provide blanket support for Tunisia’s access to EU funding programmes when the full financial implications are not fully worked out.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this deliberation because it does not give importance to the fight against terrorism and migration flows.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is proposed to conclude an Agreement between the EU and the Republic of Tunisia. The justification for this recommendation presents Tunisia as the birthplace of the Arab Spring and the only MENA country (from the Middle East and North Africa) to survive this "social and political experience".  It is proposed to guide the Tunisia-EU relationship towards facilitating the establishment of economic commitments and concrete investments, which strengthen the trade relationship and allow for "improvements" in the Tunisian economy. Tunisia's access to some EU programmes is proposed. It is suggested to strengthen cooperation in higher education, education and training. Tunisia's alignment with EU policies, including integration into the Common Security and Defence Policy, is sought. The Protocol is an instrument of economic, financial and technical cooperation, which allows access to financial assistance, integrated into the European Neighbourhood Policy, opening the door to EU programmes promoting reforms, modernisation and the transition to the EU Neighbourhood. Agreeing with the establishment of cooperation relations with Tunisia in various areas with a view to development cooperation and mutual benefit, the alignment of this protocol with eu security and neighbourhood policies, of which we disagree, justifies that we do not vote in favour.

name: Santiago Fisas Ayxelà (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Protocol. Tunisia is one of the Arab countries that is on track to have a true democracy and, for radical Islamists, that is a bad example, so they have done everything they can to derail the democratic process and ruin the Tunisian economy with this summer's attacks. For the EU, Tunisia is a great example, and we have a moral obligation to help this small great country achieve its economic and democratic goals.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I broadly agree with the conclusion of the proposal, albeit with concerns over increased private influence over public institutions. On balance, I voted in favour.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Tunisia is the only country to have survived the so-called Arab Spring. If the European Union cares about Tunisia's future, it must make concrete economic and investment commitments and support Tunisia's economy and its transition to democracy, because this process is very complex, and if a country wants to implement the necessary reforms, it will need stable trading partners and major investments in regions and infrastructure to do so. The European Union must also consider increased support in areas such as university education, general education, training and youth through programmes such as Erasmus+.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against this report because here too we can see the hypocrisy of the EU, which has supported and supported the famous Arab spring without then acknowledging its negative effects.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Association Agreement on the general principles for Tunisia's participation in the Union's programmes, because Tunisia's economic development was based on the Arab Spring, which was designed by the Americans to destabilise the region at the expense of Europe and with negative results for the countries of the Mediterranean in particular.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The success of Tunisia’s transition to democracy will depend on its future economic and social development. Tunisia has significant long-term growth potential. The implementation of the expected reforms, combined with existing assets such as its human resources and open economy, will unleash this potential, thereby boosting its economy in a more sustainable and inclusive manner. Over recent years, the Tunisian economy has deteriorated markedly, both domestically and in the international arena, especially in terms of its trade with Europe, which remains its main partner.  In light of this, it is vital for the Tunisian issue to become an EU priority, with the EU making concrete economic and investment commitments aimed at supporting the country’s fragile transition to democracy, while being mindful of the fact that the success of the Tunisian experiment is in the interests of the entire region and the EU. I therefore voted in favour of the report.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In my opinion, the success of Tunisia's democratic transition depends on future economic and social development. It is an undeniable fact that the country has significant long-term growth potential. The implementation of the expected reforms, together with existing benefits such as human resources and an open economy, will unlock this potential, boosting the country's economy in a more sustainable and inclusive way. The Tunisian economy has declined significantly in recent years, both domestically and internationally, particularly in terms of trade with Europe, which remains the main partner.  Against this background, it is of the utmost importance that the issue of Tunisia become an EU priority and that the Union make concrete economic and investment commitments aimed at supporting the country's fragile democratic transition, not forgetting that the success of the Tunisian experiment is also in the interest of the whole region and of the Union. Tunisia's participation in EU programmes should therefore be seen in this light. I particularly welcome the objective of supporting its cooperation in terms of university education, general education, training and youth, for example through Erasmus+ and other programmes aimed at establishing personal contacts.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Protocol bearing in mind that Tunisia has become the hope of the Arab world following the success of the first steps in its transition to democracy. To achieve this very important objective, Tunisia, which has significant long-term growth potential, needs sustained economic and social development. In the face of instability in Libya, it is vitally important that Tunisia becomes an EU priority and that we commit ourselves to supporting the country's economic and social development.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement on the general principles for Tunisia's participation in the Union's programmes, as I, as ACP coordinator of my group, always advocate development cooperation on a diplomatic level.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the conclusion of the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement on the General Principles for Tunisia's participation in the Union's programmes. This will allow Tunisia to provide technical assistance of a financial nature. This will stimulate the Tunisian economy in a sustainable and comprehensive way and promote the process of reform, modernisation and transition in the EU's neighbourhood.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report given that Tunisia today is confronted with a deteriorating economic crisis after the terrorist attacks at Bardo National Museum and Sousse. In this context it is vital to make concrete economic and investment commitments aimed at supporting the country’s transition to democracy. I welcome the fact that this Protocol opens up the possibility of Tunisia taking part in EU programmes and encourages the EU to make concrete economic and investment commitments aimed at supporting the country’s fragile transition to democracy, bearing in mind that the success of Tunisia is in the interests of the entire region and the EU.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ This decision is a measure aiming at promoting the transition to democracy and at fostering growth in a more sustainable and inclusive manner in Tunisia in the framework of the European Neighbourhood policy. I therefore supported this report.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this protocol in the Euro-Mediterranean agreement between the European Union and Tunisia. This protocol aims to define the financial and technical rules for Tunisia to participate in certain EU programmes and to receive financial aid in particular. These aids must be conditional on the implementation of a genuine partnership in the fight against Islamist terrorism and the fight against illegal immigration. Indeed, Tunisia is for the moment an important transit country for illegal immigrants. I also hope that the partnership with Tunisia will also be conditional on Tunisia's compliance with its commitments as a member of the Francophonie Organization, in terms of supporting the teaching of French in Tunisia.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement on the general principles of Tunisia's participation in Union programmes. Voting is a procedural vote which allows Tunisia to be included in the Union's programmes if we vote in favour of us. The EU is currently having privileged relations with this country under the Euro-Mediterranean agreement, which is one of the links in a process that will lead to the creation of a true Euro-Mediterranean economic area.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the recommendation. This Protocol opens up the possibility to Tunisia to take part in EU programmes and encourages the EU to make concrete economic and investment commitments aimed at supporting the country’s fragile transition to democracy, bearing in mind that the success of Tunisia is in the interests of the entire region and the EU.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as the gradual opening up of certain EU programmes and agencies to ENP partner countries helps to promote reform, modernisation and transition in the neighbouring EU area.  Tunisia has a significant potential for long-term economic growth. Making concrete economic and investment commitments aimed at supporting the country’s fragile transition to democracy while at the same time being mindful of the success of the Tunisian experiment is in the interests of the entire region and the EU.

name: Anja Hazekamp (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I support Tunisia’s wish to cooperate with the EU in the fields of research and education. However, I do not support the participation of Tunisia in the missions and activities of the European Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP). As the latter is not expressly excluded from the Council decision on the conclusion of the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement, I abstained.

name: Roger Helmer (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We voted against the provision of Parliament’s consent to this protocol because, on a broader point, we do not support the use of Member-State taxpayers’ money, through the European Neighbourhood Policy, being used to support an EU foreign policy in the region, and we are against the waste of British taxpayers’ money through projects administered by the EU overseas.  As a secondary point the full financial implications of this decision to the United Kingdom, in terms of our overall net contribution to the European Union budgets and the money available within the UK via these programmes, are unknown. We will therefore not provide blanket support for Tunisia’s access to EU funding programmes when the full financial implications are not fully worked out.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement on the general principles of Tunisia's participation in Union programmes. Voting is a procedural vote which allows Tunisia to be included in the Union's programmes if we vote in favour of us. The EU is currently having privileged relations with this country under the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement, which is one of the links in a process that will lead to the creation of a true Euro-Mediterranean economic area.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Tunisia is confronted with an economic crisis after the terrorist attacks at Bardo National Museum and Sousse. We have to make concrete economic and investment commitments in order to support the country’s transition to democracy.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. - I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Association Agreement between the European Community and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of Tunisia, on the other hand, on the framework agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Tunisia on the general principles of participation of the Republic of Tunisia in the Union programmes, as it is a country in the European neighbourhood that was able to continue the process of developing a democratic political and social system after the Arab Spring. Tunisia is a country to be supported, especially given all developments in the environment. It is necessary to support the democratic system, the economy of Tunisia, to improve trade cooperation, and to increase financial assistance through various European programmes. It is particularly important to support projects in the field of human resources strengthening, education and youth areas.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This protocol calls on the Council to approve a framework agreement between the European Union and Tunisia. This document provides for the definition of financial and technical rules that would give Tunisia the opportunity to participate in EU programmes. Through this agreement, Tunisia would be able to benefit from technical and financial assistance from the Union.  It is true that Tunisia is now facing political and economic difficulties. But the European Union is being hypocritical. It, along with the United States, is partly responsible for this situation through its interference. Moreover, instead of worrying about the Tunisian economy, the EU would do better to sweep its door and help its neighbours who share a common history and civilization. Serbia, for example.  If the European Union is very keen to have links with Tunisia, let it start by working on security and immigration issues. Any partnership between that country and the Member States should be conditional on performance obligations in this area. For these reasons, I voted against this text.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the recommendation on the protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean agreement and the principles of Tunisia's participation in the European Union's programmes. Through this text, Parliament will allow Tunisia to take part in European programmes within the framework of the Euro-Mediterranean agreement. The recommendation was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which recommends deepening relations between Tunisia and the European Union because Tunisia is the only country in the Arab Spring to make a truly democratic transition. It should therefore be supported and given access to European programmes.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I am voting in favour of this proposal as Tunisia is one of the last anchors of stability in North Africa and can therefore increasingly be a bridge between the EU and this region.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the recommendation. This Protocol opens up the possibility to Tunisia to take part in EU programmes and encourages the EU to make concrete economic and investment commitments aimed at supporting the country’s fragile transition to democracy, bearing in mind that the success of Tunisia is in the interests of the entire region and the EU.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 I consider the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement on the general principles of Tunisia's participation in Union programmes to be a quite successful document and i was therefore happy to support it. The objective of the Protocol is to lay down financial and technical rules enabling the Republic of Tunisia to participate in certain Union programmes. The horizontal framework established by the Protocol is a measure of economic, financial and technical cooperation enabling Union assistance, in particular financial assistance, to be obtained under these Union programmes. Unfortunately, after the attack on British tourists, tunisia's vision as a major tourist destination was threatened. Tunisia, like the rest of the region, is dealing with the so-called 'euro zone'. Islamic State, and I am very glad that it is an effort by the European Union to support the country economically so that it does not slide to any extreme. We do not have to agree with everything the Tunisian Government is doing, but we need to promote more stable lighthouses in such a turbulent region and not repeat the mistakes of the past.

name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This report is on the ENP and in particular on Tunisia and its relations with the European Union. In 2007, ENP countries were allowed to participate gradually in European programmes. Tunisia expressed the wish to be involved in Horizon 2020 (the programme of research and development) and also in the programme COSME (which is on competitiveness and SMEs). The report seeks to permit Tunisia to join these programmes. Tunisia is the only ENP country from the Near and Middle East and North Africa where the democratic transition is still fragile. We should reinforce our relations with Tunisia. This report can achieve that and this is why I voted in favour.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. – Tunisia is the only country where democracy exports have not resulted in a bloody conflict, so far. I supported the resolution so that it could continue to do so, as the surge in trade and tourism can stabilise the economy, thereby improving the country's ability to survive and also reducing the willingness to migrate, which is a key issue today.

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Council's draft decision on the conclusion of the protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean agreement establishing an agreement between the European Union and Tunisia on the general principles of Tunisia's participation in the Union's programmes. Tunisia is indeed the cradle of the Arab Spring and is fighting to preserve the social and political gains of this popular movement. Terrorist attacks and other attempts to destabilize the state are a reminder of the fragility of the democratic transition in this country. It is therefore necessary to support it by engaging and supporting investment projects that are energizing for the Tunisian economy.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report because it gives, without sufficient consideration, EU economic support to Tunisia. However, it should have conditioned it on the country's more convincing results in the fight against the migratory flows that pass through its territory.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. The approval of this protocol is important since the EESC must ensure Tunisia's success. The protocol provides for increased cooperation in education in general.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. Not only did the Arab Spring emerge in Tunisia, but today it is the only country in which it has curdled. However, for this to be a success it is necessary to ensure economic stability and social development in the future. The North African country has great long-term growth potential thanks to its workforce and an open economy, which, along with expected reforms, is expected to strengthen its potential in a more sustained and inclusive way.   In recent years the Tunisian economy has been seriously weakened, especially when it comes to trade with Europe, which remains its main partner. Tunisia must therefore become a priority for the European Union, which is concreted by economic and investment commitments that strengthen the Arab country in its political transition to democracy.  Moreover, it is clear that political success in Tunisia will have positive consequences for Europe and its geographical environment. For all these reasons and because of the stability of a country as important as Tunisia, great benefits can be expected for all parties, I voted in favour of this Recommendation.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 Tunisia will have to pay contributions in order to participate in an inefficient system of subsidies and European redistribution. This redistribution is harmful to our economy and will also harm the Tunisian economy. I voted against this proposal.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The economic and financial crisis has hit all countries in the world, including Tunisia. But Tunisia is also the epicenter of the Arab Spring, a wave of protests started in December 2010, and the only state to survive this movement.  I supported Representative Panzeri's recommendation to agree to the signing of the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement on the general principles of Tunisia's participation in the Union programmes with a view to supporting their efforts to implement reforms, transition to a democratic society and economic and financial stability. In addition to Tunisia needing financial assistance from the Union, operational assistance is needed to develop the educational, security, health and other systems of society.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Tunisia is one of the European Union's most active partners in the Euro-Mediterranean region; cooperation with Tunisia received strong momentum after the start of the Arab Spring a few years ago. And while social, economic, political and other changes in this country are still ongoing, we must support this European neighbour on its path towards a deeper and more effective exercise of democratic and human rights norms in everyday life, not to mention such an important aspect of the existence of any country and society as economic and social development.  Economic and social reforms, scientific and cultural exchanges, more effective border control, attraction of investment, regular inter-state and people's contacts due to closer regional integration – for these and a number of other reasons, I voted in favour of this important and necessary draft resolution.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP) aims to support the reforms and modernisation of countries in the EU's neighbourhood, which also allows for the opening up of certain programmes for these countries. In 2013, Tunisia, for which the EU is the largest trading partner, expressed an interest in participating in Union programmes. The Protocol constitutes a framework for the general principles for Tunisia's participation applicable to all ENP partner countries.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council Decision on the conclusion of a Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Association Agreement between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Tunisia, of the other part, on a Framework Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Tunisia on the general principles governing the participation of the Republic of Tunisia in Union programmes , because it is important enough for the EU to increase its cooperation with Tunisia in the field of university education, general education, training and youth, through programmes such as Erasmus+.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this protocol. The text includes provisions on Tunisia's participation in European programmes, which will enable Tunisia to receive technical and financial assistance from the EU. This text is a thinly veiled attempt to bring Tunisia and the EU closer together, and to support its 'democratisation', an attempt totally fruitless considering that the support provided by the EU and the United States has resulted in the Islamists coming to power, and a sharp loss of internal stability. Any discussion with Tunisia should be conditional on Tunisia's results or convincing efforts in the fight against illegal immigrants, against terrorism and in favour of democracy.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report. Tunisia was the birthplace of the Arab Spring. Thus far, it is the only country in the MENA region to survive this social and political experiment. The success of Tunisia’s transition to democracy will depend on its future economic and social development. Tunisia has significant long-term growth potential. The implementation of the expected reforms, combined with existing assets such as its human resources and open economy, will unleash this potential, thereby boosting its economy in a more sustainable and inclusive manner.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on the protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement on the general principles of Tunisia's participation in Union programmes. The Euro-Mediterranean Agreement establishing an association between the European Communities and their Member States, of the one part, and the Republic of Tunisia, of the other part, was signed on 17 July 1995 and entered into force on 1 March 1998. The European Union must make the Tunisian issue one of its priorities. By intensifying EU-Tunisia relations, a high level of economic integration can be achieved and political cooperation deepened, in accordance with the general objectives of the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement. Action must be taken to ensure that Tunisia can develop a fair social policy, modernise its economic structure, in particular through innovative activities with a high technological content, promote private initiative and public-private partnerships, step up cooperation in the fields of education and common security and defence policy activity.

name: Stefano Maullu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document, because it is important within the framework of the European Neighbourhood Policy and because I believe that the democratic transition in Tunisia is a crucial hub for the development of the Mediterranean and, therefore, of Italy. It allows Tunisia to participate in European programmes, thus enabling the country to be reformed and modernised. In this way, Europe is helping Tunisia to develop. The Mediterranean thus returns to the centre of European economic and political strategies.

name: Emmanuel Maurel (S&D)
text: In writing. Through the Panzeri report, the European Parliament was called upon to vote on Tunisia's plan to integrate certain EU programmes. I am convinced that there is a kind of imperative for the European Union that Tunisia, at the origin of the Arab Spring, succeed in its democratic transition, despite the economic and security challenges it faces. It is in the interests of both the region and the European Union that the Tunisian experience can bear fruit. In the face of rampant unemployment and the drying up of trade with its European trading partners, it is essential that the European Union help Tunisia to re-start a real trajectory of economic and social development. At a time when more than 40% of young Tunisians are unemployed, I welcome the EU's desire to incorporate Tunisia into some of its programmes, particularly in higher education, general education, training and youth. In line with my commitment to an ambitious and protective free trade agreement with Tunisia, I voted for the Panzeri report.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. This is an opportunity for Tunisia to participate in the missions and activities of the Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP) and thereby co-finance the CSDP. However, I abstained because Too many questions have not been answered.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this draft legislative resolution to have a coherent framework between the Republic of Tunisia and the European Communities.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The aim is to allow Tunisia, as a member of the European Neighbourhood Policy and at its request, to participate in the EU's cultural, social or economic programmes. In this case, Tunisia wants above all to join the research and development programme, Horizon 2020. It places great value on competitiveness as the objective and value of research, to the detriment of the humanities and laboratories to "unprofitable" research. In fact, I abstain so as not to prevent the potential future cultural, social and research collaborations that can help support the country's fragile democratic transition in the wake of the Arab Spring. I hope that this agreement will pave the way for more cooperation in other areas, such as education and the Erasmus programme. I stress, however, that for the time being the financial participation requested of Tunisia to join these programmes is too discouraging while Ukraine has enjoyed significant discounts. This is the double standard of the Union's foreign policy.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. This protocol calls on the Council to approve a framework agreement between the European Union and Tunisia. This document provides for the definition of financial and technical rules that would give Tunisia the opportunity to participate in EU programmes. Through this agreement, Tunisia would be able to benefit from technical and financial assistance from the Union.  It is true that Tunisia is now facing political and economic difficulties. But the European Union is being hypocritical. It, along with the United States, is partly responsible for this situation through its interference. Moreover, instead of worrying about the Tunisian economy, the EU would do better to sweep its door and help its neighbours who share a common history and civilization. Serbia, for example.  If the European Union is serious about having links with Tunisia, it must start by working on security and immigration issues. Any partnership between that country and the Member States should be conditional on performance obligations in this area. For these reasons, the member voted against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. I have presented my vote in agreement with the draft resolution of the European Parliament on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of a Protocol establishing a framework agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Tunisia with regard to its participation in Union programmes. Turkey's economic and social development is the key to its transition to effective and full democracy, so the European Union has an important role as a partner in this context.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The protocol of the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement will allow the European Union to support the Tunisian economy and people while increasing our cooperation with their governmental institutions and civil society. Therefore I voted in favour of this report.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: Written. – The success of the transition to an open and democratic society in Tunisia goes hand in hand with the economic development of this country. In recent years, however, the Tunisian economy has taken a heavy hit. Trade with Europe in particular has deteriorated considerably, while Europe remains its main trading partner. Notwithstanding this economic downturn, Tunisia has sufficient economic growth potential. In addition to implementing a number of necessary reforms that will enable the economy in this country to be sustained and inclusive, it is therefore essential that the EU also commits itself. Tunisia's participation in the EU programmes must be seen in this light.  The exchange in the field of scientific research, education and the training of young people is also part of the package for better cooperation. Concrete investment commitments can help support the country's democratic transition and stabilise the region. Finally, Tunisia should also be able to participate in the missions and activities of the European Common Security and Defence Policy.

name: Anne-Marie Mineur (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I support Tunisia’s wish to cooperate with the EU in the fields of research and education. However, I do not support the participation of Tunisia in the missions and activities of the European Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP). As the latter is not explicitly excluded from the Council decision on the conclusion of the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement, I abstained.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Tunisia was the birthplace of the Arab Spring. Tunisia today is confronted with a deteriorated economic crisis after the terrorist attacks at Bardo National Museum and Sousse. In this context it is vital to make concrete economic and investment commitments aimed at supporting the country’s transition to democracy. That is why I have voted in favour of this report.

name: Angelika Mlinar (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Only cooperating with the MENA region countries, the EU will be able to build a solid and holistic response to the migratory flows. Tunisia can, and should be, a strategic partner, but a fruitful cooperation will be possible only if the country is economically and politically stable. In this regard Tunisia’s participation in the EU program is essential. Tunisia is already working together with EASO under the external action strategy and I hope that the cooperation will go on throughout the transition process towards a consolidated democracy.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. So far, Tunisia is the only country where the Arab Spring has taken a turn towards an open society, freedom and democracy. The success of the experiment is also in the interest of the Mediterranean region and the Union, and it is therefore highly desirable that the EU should also assist it with specific economic and investment commitments. I supported the proposal to provide Tunisia with concrete benefits in terms of participation in EU programmes.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. This protocol aims to define the financial and technical rules for Tunisia to participate in certain EU programmes.  It sets out the principles of economic, financial and technical cooperation and allows Tunisia to receive assistance from the European Union. The pressure exerted on the Ben Ali regime by the EU and the United States in favour of democratization has, in fact, resulted in the coming to power of the Islamists and internal instability.  Today, the EU must work with Tunisia as a priority in the fight against terrorism and illegal immigration.  Any progress in the EU-Tunisia economic partnership should indeed be conditional on convincing results in the fight against illegal migration flows through Tunisian territory.  On the economic front, the EU's priority should remain the partnership with European countries on the periphery, such as Serbia.  This protocol cannot therefore be supported as it stands.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I endorse the rapporteur's position when he states that the success of Tunisia's transition to democracy will depend on its economic and social development in the future. I believe that Tunisia has enormous long-term growth potential. With the implementation of the planned reforms, combined with existing assets such as their human resources and the open economy, it will strengthen and enhance its economy in a more sustainable and inclusive way.  I believe it is important for the European Union to see the Tunisian issue as a priority, by making concrete economic and investment commitments to support this country's fragile transition to democracy, without losing sight of the fact that the success of the Tunisian experience is in the interests of the whole region and the EU.  I also endorse the rapporteur in his position that the EU should also step up cooperation in the fields of higher education, education, training and youth through programmes such as Erasmus+ and other programmes to develop contacts between populations.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. The Euro-Mediterranean Memorandum of Understanding on the general principles of Tunisia's participation in the European Union's programmes aims to gradually open up certain EU programmes and agencies to partner countries, including those in the Maghreb, to advocate "reform, modernisation, transition" and the financial and technical modalities of such an opening. The EU and its Member States should first and foremost focus on security and migration in terms of their relations with Tunisia before considering such an economic and financial partnership. The "democratic transition" that this partnership is supposed to promote - at the repeated risk of political interference in the affairs of another state - is to date a clear failure that was supported from start to finish by the EU and the United States and which led to the coming to power of the Islamists of Ennahda and a significant decline in the rights, freedoms and development of the country. So I chose to vote against this MEMORANDUM of understanding.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which is a recommendation to consent to the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement between the EC and Tunisia.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the recommendation on the Council's draft decision on Tunisia's participation in EU programmes. In recent years, the health of tunisia's economy has deteriorated sharply, both domestically and internationally, particularly in terms of trade with Europe, which remains the country's main partner. The country's fragile democratic transition depends in large part on its economic development. It is endangered by attacks regularly carried out by terrorist groups. It is therefore essential to better support and support Tunisia by considering its participation in the Union's programmes within the broader framework of the Euro-Mediterranean agreement.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this recommendation on the draft Council decision that will enable the EU to make concrete economic and investment commitments aimed at supporting  Tunisia’s fragile transition to democracy.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I abstained on this report, which was a consent vote on a Council decision on a protocol to the Euro-Med agreement to allow Tunisia to access EU programmes through a Framework Agreement.  The Tunisian Government that was elected last year is in favour of pluralist democracy and the new constitution is generally liberal, inclusive, pro-gender equality and pluralist, and includes protections for all religions and minorities. The Agreement will not be with a particular government but with the Republic of Tunisia I did not vote against giving consent as I did not wish to block the Tunisian Government from accessing EU civilian programmes that it could find very useful in transitioning to democracy after decades of dictatorship. Programmes named in the justification include cooperation in education, universities, research and Erasmus. However, one of the programmes Tunisia would be authorised to join is the EU’s Common Security and Defence Policy. EU and US military policy in the Middle East and North Africa has resulted in disastrous consequences and the further expansion of this policy is something I oppose, which is why I did not vote in favour of the report.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Tunisia, which is still one of the few positive examples of the Arab Spring, has not been left untouched by the economic downturn. The European Union, as Tunisia's main trading partner, must support Tunisia by enabling it to participate in EU programmes, as well as intensifying cooperation in the field of education, for example.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that the Tunisian issue is a priority in European Union policy and also in view of the economic difficulties facing the Republic of Tunisia following the known events of the Arab Spring, I have decided to vote in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The European Neighbourhood Policy was created not only to help achieve close cooperation between the Member States of the European Union and its closest neighbours, but also to contribute to strengthening democracy, the rule of law and respect for human rights in the countries where it is implemented, as well as their economic and social growth and development. Political, economic and social reforms are the basis on which this policy and good cooperation are based. Tunisia has recently undergone a turbulent period that we have recently witnessed accompanied by terrorist attacks, which pose a threat not only to Tunisia, but also to Europe and the whole world. Therefore, I consider this Agreement and Tunisia's further rapprochement with the European Union and mutual cooperation as a good move on the road to further stabilisation of the country, the creation of the necessary reforms, but also the strengthening of the Republic of Tunisia through the support of the European Union. With this Protocol, we will set out rules that will allow Tunisia to participate in action plans created specifically for the needs of Tunisia and its inhabitants. The Protocol adopts standard rules applicable to all signatory countries under the European Neighbourhood Policy. It contributes to the betterment of the signatory countries, but also to the citizens of the European Union.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. The Euro-Mediterranean Memorandum of Understanding on the general principles of Tunisia's participation in EU programmes aims to gradually open up certain EU programmes and agencies to partner countries, including maghreb countries, to advocate "reform, modernisation, transition" and the financial and technical modalities of such an opening. The EU and its Member States should first and foremost focus on security and migration in terms of their relations with Tunisia before considering such an economic and financial partnership. The "democratic transition" that this partnership is supposed to promote - at the repeated risk of political interference in the affairs of another state - is to date a clear failure that has been supported from start to finish by the EU and the United States and which led to the coming to power of the Islamists of Ennahda and a significant decline in the rights and freedoms and development of the country. So I chose to vote against this MEMORANDUM of understanding.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I welcome the efforts of the Council's draft decision aimed at helping Tunisia's economic and social development, in particular in demanding that Tunisia's financial contribution within the European Union programme be as low as possible to ensure the recovery of an economy that has been in dire straits over the past few years. Furthermore, one of the fundamental connectivity instruments between the EU and Tunisia should be the just proposed cooperation in the field of general and university education. During my visit to Tunisia in 2011, I saw firsthand the commitment of the people of Tunisia to democratic reforms and I heard their demands that carried the Arab Spring, namely new jobs, schooling, security of income and democratic rights. Our task today is to ensure the democratic transition of Tunisia on which the achievement of these requirements depends and the overall sociopolitical and economic development of the state and society. Particularly commendable are efforts to secure concrete economic and investment commitments to aid and support Tunisia.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Over the last few years, tunisia's economy has deteriorated significantly, both domestically and internationally, especially in terms of trade with Europe, which remains Tunisia's main partner. Thus, it is very important for Tunisians that this problem becomes a priority in the EU, and that the EU assumes concrete economic and investment commitments to support the country's fragile transition to democracy, which is in the interest of the whole region and the EU. Also, the EU needs to increase cooperation in the fields of higher education, general education, and youth training through programmes such as Erasmus+, and other programmes focusing on people's intellectual development. Furthermore, it is of great importance that Tunisia provides an opportunity to join the Mission and activities of the European Common Security and Defence Policy (CAP). At the same time, Tunisia has significant long-term growth potential, but the long-term success of Tunisia's transition to democracy will depend on future economic and social development. I therefore support Rapporteur Panzeri's recommendation on the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement on the general principles of participation of the Republic of Tunisia in the Union programmes.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I support Parliament’s vote on the participation of Tunisia in the Union’s programmes. Tunisia has become the model country for the Arab Spring; it successfully passed through the test that much of the rest of the region is still trying to figure out. It has great potential to create another pillar of stability in a region that desperately needs it.  However, in recent years the economy in Tunisia has shown signs of deterioration and I believe that we need to do something to combat this. That is why I support Tunisia becoming a priority for the EU and including it in certain European Union programmes including, but not limited to, those involving general, university education, and youth programmes. If we can help bolster Tunisia, we can have another ally in the region, and we can show that the region has the ability to succeed.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I was very happy to support the Protocol on Tunisia's participation in Union programmes. The events of the Arab Spring marked the political direction not only of Tunisia, but also of other countries in North Africa and the Middle East. Like social developments, the economy is strongly influenced by tunisia's transition to a democratic regime. It is therefore essential that cooperation between the European Union and Tunisia is at an excellent level, particularly in this area. The rapture of Tunisia's economy from bankruptcy may lead to improvements in its political circumstances. Moreover, cooperation at education level, for example through erasmus+, can offer unique opportunities for both Union and Tunisian citizens. I am convinced that only the best will benefit from cooperation between the European Union and Tunisia.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The Mediterranean Agreement aims to create free trade areas in the region by removing trade and investment barriers. Mediterranean association agreements are already in place between the EU and almost all the region's partners, with the exception of Libya and Syria, and talks are underway to deepen them. The democratic transition in Tunisia over the last 3 years can serve as a positive example for the other countries that participated in the 'Arab Spring' events. Tunisia is a country with a higher level of prosperity than its neighbours and already has strong economic links with Europe.   I therefore support and highly value the development of the partnership with Tunisia and the commitment to work with the people and authorities of Tunisia to promote common interests, including trade, in the areas of investment, culture and security.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Tunisia is a country whose transition to democracy after the Arab Spring can be considered almost exemplional. It is a good example of how to build a democratic society after the long duration of an authoritarian regime. Moreover, Tunisia is our close neighbour, which, in today's difficult situation, is another reason why we should not hesitate to involve this country in the Union's programmes.
