name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. In the framework of the European Neighbourhood Policy and EU-Mediterranean relations, it is important to promote exchanges between Tunisia and the EU. In this context, I have expressed my support for the recommendation on the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement on the general principles of Tunisia's participation in the Union's programmes.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In July 2007, the Council set guidelines for negotiations for the conclusion of multiple association agreements between neighbourhood countries of the European Union (EU). The state of these negotiations has increased importance in the current context of political and humanitarian crisis that, in the South and Southeast, in North Africa and the Middle East, has been fracturing the social and economic fabric of peoples, with serious repercussions throughout the neighborhood. It is the aim of the association programme, hereinafter, to promote the reform, modernisation and transition of neighbourhood countries through economic policies establishing preferential regimes, with concessions for Tunisian agricultural exports, on the one hand, and unavoidative access to industrial exports from the Community to Tunisia on the other. Today, tunisia's success of political regime change also depends on its socio-economic development, which is vital for the region and the EU. To this end, the Protocol provides, in addition to the establishment of that free trade area, financial assistance measures, which are established by the Protocol under consideration, in order to contribute fully to the achievement of the objectives of the agreement, in line with the priorities of the European Neighbourhood Policy.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of concluding the protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean agreement between the European Union and Tunisia. This agreement remains of great importance as it determines the general principles of Tunisia's participation in the Union's programmes. The democratic transition currently underway in that country, which is the guarantor of the achievements of the Arab Spring, of which Tunisia spearheaded, must be based on sustainable economic and social development. The interests of Tunisia, the Union and the region as a whole are at stake.     I hope that Tunisia's access to European programmes and the opportunities they offer in terms of economics, investment, training and youth can contribute to this.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. It is vital that the European Union makes concrete economic and investment commitments to support this country's fragile transition to democracy. The success of the Tunisian experience is in the interests of the whole region and the EU. In addition to the economic sector, the EU should also step up cooperation in the fields of higher education, education, training and youth through programmes such as Erasmus+, and also give Tunisia the opportunity to integrate the missions and activities of the Common European Security and Defence Policy. Strengthening this participation will help Tunisia consolidate its institutions and reform processes and bring its legislation, standards and standards closer to European practices.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Recommendation granting approval for the conclusion of the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement on Tunisia's participation in Union programmes. I believe that this Protocol can help to consolidate the country's fragile transition to democracy by boosting the country's economic and social development. To this end, I consider of the utmost interest the forecasts included in this Protocol in order to reduce Tunisia's financial contribution to the maximum possible, in line with the rebates granted to other neighbouring countries, such as Ukraine. The EU must also strengthen cooperation in the fields of university education, general education, training and youth through programmes such as Erasmus+ and other programmes aimed at developing contacts between people.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. In the framework of the European Neighbourhood Policy, the gradual opening of certain EU programmes and agencies to partner countries affected by this policy is one of many measures to promote reform, modernisation and transition in the neighbouring countries of the European Union. In December 2013, Tunisia indicated that it wanted to participate in the wide range of programmes open to partner countries concerned with the European Neighbourhood Policy.  The text voted today therefore concerns a proposal for a Council decision on the conclusion of the protocol containing a framework agreement on the general principles of Tunisia's participation in the Union's programmes. It includes standard conditions to be applied to all partner countries concerned by the European Neighbourhood Policy with which such protocols must be concluded.  The protocol attempts to define the financial and technical rules allowing Tunisia to participate in certain EU programmes. The horizontal framework created by the protocol sets out the principles of economic, financial and technical cooperation and allows Tunisia to receive technical assistance from the European Union, in particular financial assistance, under the European Union's programmes.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. One of the objectives of the European Neighbourhood Policy is to promote the gradual opening of certain EU programmes to neighbouring European countries. Tunisia, being a country whose economy has been down sharply, in particular in terms of its trade with Europe and having already expressed its interest in participating in the wide range of programmes open to third countries of the ENP, must take priority for the EU in the assumption of concrete economic and investment commitments to support this country's fragile transition to democracy.  The Protocol to be concluded lays down principles for economic, financial and technical cooperation, allowing Tunisia to receive technical assistance, in particular financial assistance, from the EU in accordance with European programmes. In this context, I endorse the conclusion of this Agreement, I endorse the idea of this Agreement, which intensifies cooperation in the fields of higher education, education, training and youth with this country, through programmes such as Erasmus +, and other programmes aimed at developing contacts between the populations. Tunisia should also be given the opportunity to integrate the missions and activities of the European Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP).

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which sets out the technical financial rules allowing Tunisia to participate in certain EU programmes.  The gradual opening of some EU agencies and programmes to partner countries is an important part of the European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP) to promote the reform and modernisation of the EU's neighbouring countries.  In December 2013, Tunisia indicated that it wanted to participate in the wide range of programmes open to ENP partner countries.  As Tunisia continues its democratic transition and the National Dialogue Quartet has just received the Nobel Peace Prize, the European Union must support and support Tunisia more than ever. The opening of European programmes to ENP countries represents an opportunity to enhance economic cooperation and technical and financial assistance with the European Union.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement on the general principles of Tunisia's participation in EU programmes. Tunisia is one of the African countries that has been working in recent years to improve the social situation in terms of combating terrorism and democracy. Unfortunately, however, the Tunisian economy has been hit by a crisis affecting its trade with Europe. The main objective of this report is to step up cooperation in the fields of university education, training and youth through programmes such as Erasmus+ and other programmes aimed at developing people-to-people contacts.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement on the general principles of Tunisia's participation in Union programmes. Voting is a procedural vote which allows Tunisia to be included in the Union's programmes if we vote in favour of us. The EU is currently having privileged relations with this country under the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement, which is one of the links in a process that will lead to the creation of a true Euro-Mediterranean economic area.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. During the Ben Ali regime, the European Union and Tunisia concluded an association agreement which, while incorporating elements for political dialogue and cooperation, is mainly based on a desire to liberalise trade in the Euro-Mediterranean area through the conclusion of free trade agreements. Such agreements are precisely one of the causes of the odious and illegitimate debt incurred by the State of Tunisia and whose burden the Tunisian people unfairly bear. I have therefore not been able to vote in favour of this Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement on the general principles of Tunisia's participation in the Union's programmes as it sees a deepening of this liberalizing logic and even goes further, since the rapporteur, the Italian socialist Panzeri, considers Tunisia, newly a strategic ally of NATO, to be a strategic ally , should participate in the European Union's Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP).

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this proposal as I do not think the EU should be spending UK taxpayers’ money on projects in Tunisia.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ For me and my Group, Tunisia is a priority. It is where the Arab Spring began, and it is vital that the development of Tunisia after its regime change is met with support and enthusiasm. Confronted with an economic crisis and terror attacks, this support cannot wait. It is vital to make concrete economic and investment commitments aimed at supporting this country and the transition to democracy.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree with the conclusion of the Protocol and thus with the support of this country, as its economic situation has deteriorated in recent years. It is a country where the democratic processes launched in the last 3 years could also set some example for other countries in North Africa and the Middle East.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ This explanation of the vote comes as a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. Tunisia is the only country in the Middle East and North Africa region that has survived the Social and Political Experiment of the Arab Spring. However, in recent years, the Tunisian economy has been significantly declining, particularly in trade with Europe, which remains its main partner. I agree that the Tunisia issue should become one of the EU's priorities, which would require the EU to make concrete economic and investment commitments aimed at supporting the fragile process of a democratic transition. The EU should increase cooperation in the fields of university education, general education, training and youth (e.g. Erasmus+), and Tunisia should have the opportunity to join CSDP missions and activities. As Tunisia has significant long-term growth potential and the implementation of the expected reforms in relation to existing resources such as human resources and the open economy will unlock this potential and stimulate its economy in a more sustainable and inclusive way, I supported the recommendation on the draft decision.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ In view of the recommendation of the Foreign Affairs Committee (A8-0254/2015) and the Council draft decisions (16160/2014), I support this report. The conclusion of the protocol should be given, as the success of Tunisia's transition will depend on its future economic and social development. Tunisia is the birthplace of the Arab Spring, which means that it is a country at the fore leader of the Arab world's transition to democracy, which needs to be supported. With the support of the European Union, Tunisia should reach its greater potential. Over recent years, Tunisia's economy has deteriorated significantly, especially in terms of trade with Europe, which should remain a major trading partner. The European Union also needs to improve cooperation in the fields of higher education, education in general through programmes such as Erasmus+ and other programmes aimed at developing personal contacts.  Therefore, Tunisia should be given the opportunity to join the missions and activities of the European Common Economic, Social, Security and Defence Policy.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒One of the many measures to promote reforms, modernisation and transition of the European Union neighbourhood as part of the European Neighbourhood Policy (ENP), is the gradual opening-up of certain EU programmes and activities, enp partner countries.  In December 2013, Tunisia expressed interest in participating in a wide range of programmes available to European Neighbourhood Policy partner countries.  This is a proposal for a Council decision concluding a protocol containing an agreement on the framework programme of Tunisia's general principles of participation in Union programmes, and contains standard conditions that should apply to all ENP partner countries with which such protocols would be concluded. The protocol aims to define financial and technical rules that would allow Tunisia to participate in certain EU programmes. I support this protocol, as it outlines the principles for economic, financial and technical cooperation measures and provides Technical and Financial Support to Tunisia, in line with eu programmes.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal as I support the initiative to break down administrative barriers and liberalise international trade. The liberalisation of international trade is one of the ways in which the European Union can really and sustainably help the economy.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the recommendation on the draft Council decision on the conclusion of a Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement on the general principles for tunisia's participation in Union programmes. I support the strengthening of economic and investment cooperation between the European Union and Tunisia, which has great growth potential, but unfortunately the Tunisian economy has been declining in recent years. Strengthening cooperation both in the economic and educational fields will contribute to greater stability of the whole region, which is also of interest to the European Union.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The resolution aims to extend the EU-Tunisia interconnection and the country's participation in Horizon 2020. As a party we have often expressed ourselves in favour of Horizon 2020 as we believe that with the necessary reforms it can really work positively and through research and innovation to support SMEs, benefit society and serve the needs of peoples.  However, the overall objective of EU cooperation agreements with third countries is to oblige countries to implement specific neoliberal economic policies.  For these reasons, while respecting Tunisia's right to decide as a sovereign state on the path to follow, we have decided to abstain.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Tunisia's economic development was based on the Arab Spring, which was designed by the Americans to destabilise the region at the expense of Europe and with negative results for the countries mainly of the Mediterranean

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Arab Spring was a historic event of extraordinary magnitude, which changed the evolution of societies in the Islamic world of the Near East. Tunisia was the first country to show this population mobilization in support of democratisation and modernisation. However, the transition from a society governed by an authoritarian regime to a democratic and pluralistic system is a complex and difficult process that cannot work in such a short time. At the same time, the challenges to the young Tunisian democracy are multiplying. Economic and social difficulties are amplified by the intensification of the phenomenon of Islamic fundamentalism and its corollary, the terrorist phenomenon. The recent terrorist attacks in Tunisia demonstrate the vulnerability of society in transition to opponents of open society.  The European Union is Tussia's main neighbour and trading partner. From this point of view, the Union bears an important responsibility for the evolution of the young Tunisian democracy. One of the tools by which the EU can influence the situation in concrete terms is cooperation in the economic field. This requires the adoption of the agreement for The participation of Tunitia in European programmes. The longer we speed up this process, the more Tunisian citizens will feel the benefits of developing democracy in their country and the dangers of terrorism and sectarian conflict will diminish.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the text of my eminent colleague Panzeri. Tunisia was the cradle of the Arab Spring. To this day, it remains the only country in the Middle East and North Africa region where this social and political experience is still alive. The success of Tunisia's democratic transition will now depend on its economic and social development. The country has strong long-term growth potential. Implementation of the expected reforms, in addition to its existing strengths, such as its human resources and open economy, will enable it to make full use of this potential and will give a sustainable and inclusive boost to its economy. In recent years, the health of tunisia's economy has deteriorated sharply, both domestically and internationally, particularly in terms of trade with Europe, which remains the country's main partner. It is therefore essential to make the Tunisian question a priority of the Union.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I believe that Tunisia needs EU support in its transition to democracy and I therefore voted in favour of this report. The objective of the Protocol is to lay down the financial and technical rules enabling Tunisia to participate in certain EU programmes. It allows for access to assistance, in particular financial, to be provided by the EU. The success of democracy in Tunisia is to a large extent dependent on its economic and social development. However, over the last years, the Tunisian economy has markedly deteriorated, especially concerning its trade with Europe. In order to support the establishment of democracy in Tunisia, the EU should make concrete economic and investment commitments, which is an initiative endorsed by the Protocol.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. I supported the conclusion of the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Association Agreement between the European Community and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of Tunisia, on the other hand, on the framework agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Tunisia on the general principles of participation of the Republic of Tunisia in the Union programmes.  I believe this is the right step towards continuing and improving relations between the European Union and Tunisia through removing barriers to trade and investment, i.e. through the creation of a free market. Since Tunisia, as the country where the Arab Spring began, is more advanced than its neighbours in the region, I think it is realistic to expect the expected reforms to be fulfilled, given that in the last three years the democratic transition in that country is an example of optimism for other North African countries.  That is why I voted for a report supporting the further development of partnerships with Tunisia and promoting common interests in the areas of trade, investment, culture and security.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I support the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement on the general principles for Tunisia's participation in Union programmes, as I believe that the EU must also deepen cooperation with Tunisia precisely in order to ensure that tunisia's transition to democracy and reforms are successful. The events of the Arab Spring have been strongly marked by many countries, and Tunisia nevertheless enthus ing with more hope. The EU also plays an important role, as it can make a significant contribution to Tunisia's economic and social development.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement on the general principles of Tunisia's participation in Union programmes. Voting is a procedural vote which allows Tunisia to be included in the Union's programmes if we vote in favour of us. The EU is currently having privileged relations with this country under the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement, which is one of the links in a process that will lead to the creation of a true Euro-Mediterranean economic area.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome very much this new agreement with Tunisia. As the most advanced democracy in the Arab world, and with its proximity to the continent, it must be a fundamental partner for the European Union. Any mutual help that we can bring in order to share European standards with Tunisia is of the utmost importance.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The European Union should focus primarily on the security and migration sector in its dealings with Tunisia and not on "the economy and investment, in order to support the country's fragile democratic transition".  This transition orchestrated by the European Union and the United States has also led to the coming to power of the Islamists and has resulted in internal destabilization. So I objected to the text.

name: Mihai Țurcanu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Since March 1998 there has been a Euro-Mediterranean Agreement establishing an association between the European Communities and their Member States and the Republic of Tunisia. This agreement envisages the development of a strengthened policy and security dialogue, economic, financial and trade cooperation, and the promotion of social, cultural and education cooperation. The events of recent years in Tunisia, especially the Arab Spring, marked its transition to a new stage of its development on its way to democracy. However, the increasingly fragile economic situation, particularly due to the deterioration of trade with the EU, Tunisia's main trading partner, with 75% of its exports and imports, is holding back its democratic development. In this context, Tunisia needs the Union's support for better economic development, which ensures a triumph of democracy, beneficial for both the MENA region and the EU. Moreover, socially, there is a need to strengthen collaboration in education, education and youth training, being an important pillar of the democratic revolution in Tunisia. I therefore voted in favour of the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement on the general principles of Tunion's participation in Union programmes.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement on the general principles of Tunisia's participation in Union programmes. Voting is a procedural vote which allows Tunisia to be included in the Union's programmes if we vote in favour of us. The EU is currently having privileged relations with this country under the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement, which is one of the links in a process that will lead to the creation of a true Euro-Mediterranean economic area.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the recommendation on the conclusion of the Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement on the general principles for the participation of Tunisia in Union programmes. As part of the European Neighbourhood Policy, the gradual opening-up of certain Union programmes and agencies to the participation of ENP partner countries represents one of many measures to promote reform, modernisation and transition in the European Union’s neighbourhood. Tunisia expressed its interest in participating in the broad range of programmes open to partner countries, and in order to enhance international cooperation I think it is very important to set up a framework for this inclusion in the programme.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. The Protocol sets out the principles of economic, financial and technical cooperation and defines the rules necessary in this area for Tunisia to participate in certain European Union programmes, mainly in relation to neighbourhood policy. We are therefore talking about a Protocol which will help to further build better relations with a neighbouring country such as Tunisia, so I consider it necessary to vote in favour of this Recommendation.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. During the Ben Ali regime, the European Union and Tunisia concluded an association agreement which, while incorporating elements for political dialogue and cooperation, is mainly based on a desire to liberalise trade in the Euro-Mediterranean area through the conclusion of free trade agreements. Such agreements are precisely one of the causes of the odious and illegitimate debt incurred by the State of Tunisia and whose burden the Tunisian people unfairly bear. I have therefore not been able to vote in favour of this Protocol to the Euro-Mediterranean Agreement on the general principles of Tunisia's participation in the Union's programmes as it sees a deepening of this liberalizing logic and even goes further, since the rapporteur, the Italian socialist Panzeri, considers Tunisia, newly a strategic ally of NATO, to be a strategic ally , should participate in the European Union's Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP).

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'If we want Tunisia, where the Arab revolution began and paid off the most, to become a democratic society, the economic development of this country will have to improve. In recent years, the Tunisian economy, with tourism as the main victim, has been hit hard. Trade with Europe in particular has deteriorated considerably, while Europe remains its main trading partner. Tunisia's participation in the EU programmes must be seen in this light. The exchange in the field of scientific research, education and the training of young people is also part of the package for better cooperation. That is why I fully support this protocol.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Tunisia is the country where the Arab revolutions were born. Despite the difficulties in implementing its constitution and the terrorist attacks in Bardo and Sousse, it continues its democratic transition thanks in particular to the mobilization of civil society and its population more broadly.  Supporting Tunisia in this process is paramount.  The country remains a symbol for North Africa, the Middle East and beyond, as the Quartet's Nobel Peace Prize has just been highlighted. Encouraging Tunisia's participation in EU programmes, as is already the case for other countries in the Mediterranean neighbourhood, can be an appropriate tool, particularly in terms of cultural and social partnerships (higher education, research, training, etc.). This does not prevent the need for extreme vigilance as discussions about the FTA (free and comprehensive free trade agreement) begin on the establishment of a balanced partnership that prevents the pursuit of unbridled economic liberalism that will only worsen the economic and social situation of this country and turn its back on the legitimate but still unreased demands of the Tunisian population. I therefore voted in favour of this report, which only concerns participation in European programmes.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The justification of the resolution presents Tunisia as the birthplace of the Arab Spring and the only MENA country to survive this "social and political experience". It raises the establishment of economic commitments and concrete investments with Tunisia that strengthen the trade relationship and allow for "improvements" in the Tunisian economy. It also aims at Tunisia's access to some EU programmes. It suggests strengthening cooperation in higher education, education and training through programmes such as ERASMUS and other programmes of contact with the population (certainly democracy). Tunisia's alignment with EU policies, including csdp integration, is sought. The Protocol is an instrument of economic, financial and technical cooperation, which allows access to financial assistance, integrated into the European Neighbourhood Policy, opening the door to EU programmes promoting reforms, modernisation and the transition to the EU Neighbourhood. We have legitimate doubts as to whether this EU model, with the results visible in particular in Southern Europe, can be beneficial to the Tunisian people.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. This is an opportunity for Tunisia to participate in the missions and activities of the Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP) and thereby co-finance the CSDP. However, I abstained because Too many questions have not been answered.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I agreed with this resolution.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We are facing the conclusion of an Agreement between the EU and the Republic of Tunisia. The justification of the resolution presents Tunisia as the birthplace of the Arab Spring and the only MENA country to survive this "social and political experience". It guides the relationship to facilitate the establishment of economic commitments and concrete investments with Tunisia that strengthen the trade relationship and allow for "improvements" in the Tunisian economy. It also aims at Tunisia's access to some EU programmes. It suggests strengthening cooperation in higher education, education, training, through programmes such as ERASMUS, and other programmes of contact with the populations. Tunisia's alignment with EU policies, in particular with the Common Security and Defence Policy, is sought.  While this Agreement may have positive parts, we cannot agree with several of the political and economic principles that the EU wants to impose and underpinning it, conditioning the future of that country.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to explain why I supported the European Small Claims Procedure and the European Order for Payment Procedure. I consider this to be a positive step in the protection of consumers and small businesses in the European Union. These are measures that are tangible and I think citizens will appreciate them. Cross-border complaints or debt collection is a necessity, especially with regard to online shopping. A typical example is an effort to refund defective or unshipped goods purchased over the Internet from a supplier from another country. I consider it a problem that so far few people are familiar with this possibility. The competent courts should take a step in this area. People may be concerned to go directly to court, although this procedure is less complex and does not have high fees. I am glad that the upper limit has been increased from EUR 2,000 to EUR 5,000 in the approved form, although I would not recommend further significant increases. I also agree that the approved legislation does not extend the scope to labour disputes.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I supported this proposal for a regulation. As a former Minister of Justice of the Czech Republic, I know how big a problem it is to resolve cross-border disputes. Many Citizens of the European Union and companies are afraid to enter into such disputes because they objectively last longer, they are more costly than domestic disputes only. It is therefore a good thing that the European Union is trying to remove these barriers, it can be said, judicial cooperation, judicial interconnection, and it is adopting such a regulation, which may lead to future use of videoconferencing for cross-border disputes, so that individual submissions can be delivered electronically to the courts, so that the level of court fees can also be harmonised, setting certain limits and thus making the costs of the disputes cheaper. I think that this is very important for the future, because non-communicating justice is one of the barriers to the European Union's internal market.

name: Monica Macovei (PPE).
text: – Mr President, we have two regulations – one from 2006, one from 2007 – governing shorter, special procedures for low-value applications and those on the European order procedure. All this is to help people, to help business people, small businesses and mid-sized enterprises to make the whole judicial process go faster. We live and work in various countries in the European Union and, as such, judicial proceedings must be adopted.  However, we now need to go further and change these regulations, with the following objectives: we need to increase the amount for small payment applications to EUR 5 000; furthermore, electronic means of communication, notification must be used by the courts; judges should also use teleconferences in certain cases, where possible; the administration of samples, as well, can be done remotely and by teleconference; fees may be paid by means at a distance. All this will improve life and commercial activity.

name: Peter Jahr (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I can say: a good thing. The European procedure for small claims in cross-border transport already exists. The experience we have had so far has shown that we have been able to reduce the costs for those affected by 40%. The length of proceedings was also significantly reduced. This has encouraged us to raise the previous limit value, which was EUR 2 000, to EUR 10 000, and the nice thing is that, with the EUR 10 000 limit, we will be able to settle a total of 50% of all disputes under this procedure. This is particularly about citizens and, in particular, about small and medium-sized enterprises. It is particularly important for them. I think the big companies, which have legal departments, can take care of their demand, but it is particularly about the European internal market. We are talking in particular about small and medium-sized enterprises. And if we can come up with further improvements at some point, we could stick to it. On the whole, this is a good day for European citizens.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur The European Union is based on inter-transnational, interregional, inter-people cooperation. In economic terms, one of the most important roles is owned by small and medium-sized enterprises. Consequently, where, for one reason or another, there are claims or claims between partners or colleagues at a lower level of cooperation – individuals, legal persons – whose resolution requires financial compensation, it is strictly necessary for an effective system to be able to resolve such situations. In view of the fact that the report specifically mentioned the improvement of such effectiveness in the existing systems for small claims and the European order for payment procedure, I voted unequivocally in favour because I fully support the proposed amendments. A more effective system for handling claims is one of the guarantees for a fairer economic and financial system in the European Union.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I also want to explain my vote on this issue, because I supported the proposed report. In my opinion, it is really important to think about law enforcement as a whole, about a set of norms where an individual has the right to access a court. However, there is a problem that the simplified legal proceedings that this proposal actually brings have its pitfalls. It should indeed be capped, and I consider the limit of EUR 5 000, when proceedings are pending before the court in a truly simplified way, to be the maximum. It is important that citizens are aware of this possibility and that they realise their right of access to the court, but at the same time that they are also aware of the consequences when they initiate such legal proceedings. I consider capping the costs of legal proceedings to be the right move, but I think that emphasis should also be placed on mediation and the prevention of such disputes. I do not think that this report has yet to be contained.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This report concerned a proposal to legislate further on the European Small Claims Procedure by amending existing legislation. The UK Independence Party is in principle opposed to the European Union having the power to legislate for the United Kingdom and would normally vote against any report which advocated legislation or which was itself a legislative proposal. In this instance, we are very mindful of the impact of debts up to EUR 10 000 being unpaid on UK Small-to-Medium Enterprises (SMEs) and the effort and costs of recovering such sums and UKIP is therefore minded not to oppose this report. UKIP decided to abstain.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it amends the European Regulation in such a way that it is a necessary improvement in establishing a simplified process for claims of less than EUR 10 000. This amendment is an important step forward in improving speed in such processes in the European Union. The report establishes a system of fees which should not exceed the rates set by Member States and the fees must be proportional to the amount demanded; the amendment to the Regulation also removes exceptions. The report includes technical improvements and recognition obligations by Member States, such as the obligation to free practical assistance, all improving consumer legal certainty at European level. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I have spoken in favour of this report, which makes cross-border disputes resolved more quickly and more quickly. This proposal democratizes access to justice and reduces the costs of procedures for consumers and SMEs. The protection of consumers and SMEs must be a priority for Member States, helping them to cope with often very complex costs and legal procedures. This report therefore goes in the right direction, although we regret, however, that the definition of cross-border disputes in the text is too broad.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which was concerned with raising the thresholds for the value of a claim. Previously, the threshold was set at EUR 2 000. The report provides that this limit would be raised to EUR 5 000 if pursued against a natural person i.e. an individual and EUR 10 000 if pursued against a legal person i.e. a company.  By way of background, the European Small Claims Procedure applies to all claims with a cross-border element. This includes cases where the parties are both domiciled in the same Member State and only the place of performance of the contract, the place where the harmful event takes place or the place of enforcement of the judgment is situated in another Member State. This provides an important remedy for cross-border disputes which in many Member States is woefully lacking at present.  One final positive point is that Legal Assistance can also be provided to parties free of charge, which did not previously exist.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report as it aims to simplify the process of resolving cross-border small claims by up to EUR 5 000, thus facilitating cross-border trade and the movement of European citizens into the European Union.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This text aims to simplify and speed up the resolution of small-scale disputes in cross-border cases. While the objective is laudable, namely to help consumers and SMEs to make their claims, I nevertheless believe that it is not for the European Union to legislate in the area of legal proceedings. It must remain and fall within the jurisdiction of the States, which can cooperate if necessary. I therefore voted against this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this vote. Whilst there could be some advantages to SMEs, I am concerned about certain potential cross-border issues with regard to debt enforcement.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because it aims to simplify and speed up the procedures for resolving cross-border civil and commercial disputes and to reduce their costs.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to facilitate debt collection in the EU. Since 2009, the European Small Claims Procedure has enabled people and businesses to recover debts accumulated in other EU countries through standard forms of assistance due to, for example, unpaid bills for services rendered. It is not necessary to hire a lawyer to use the procedure, and the judgment given on its basis is recognised and enforced in another EU country. The updated European Small Claims Rules facilitate the recovery of debts from companies or individuals operating in another EU country. From EUR 2 000 to EUR 5 000, the debt ceiling that may be covered by this procedure is increased, stamp duty is reduced and videoconferencing is encouraged. The use of European small claims has allowed for a 40% reduction in the cost of similar claims and a five-fold reduction in the duration of the claims.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This report concerned a proposal  to legislate further on the European Small Claims Procedure by amending existing legislation.  The UK Independence Party is in principle opposed to the European Union having the power to legislate for the United Kingdom and would normally vote against any report which advocated legislation or which was itself a legislative proposal. In this instance we are very mindful of the impact of debts up to EUR 10 000 being unpaid to UK small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and the effort and costs of recovering such sums, and UKIP is therefore minded not to oppose this report. UKIP decided to abstain.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which will allow our citizens to resolve their cross-border disputes of less than EUR 5,000, although the definition of such disputes seems to me to be a little too broad.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. This regulation establishing a European small dispute settlement procedure aims to simplify and speed up the resolution of small-scale disputes in cross-border cases and to reduce costs. It was designed specifically to help consumers and small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) make their claims, thereby ensuring access to justice.  The aim of this report, which I have spoken for, is to broaden and improve the use of this developing instrument and communicate around this project.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report establishing a small European process aimed at simplifying and accelerating disputes concerning small-scale processes in cross-border matters and reducing costs. It was specifically designed to help consumers and small and medium-sized enterprises demand debt pay, thus ensuring access to justice.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on regulation (EC) No 861/2007 of the European Parliament and the Council of 11 July 2007 establishing a European procedure for the settlement of small disputes aims to simplify and speed up the resolution of small disputes in cross-border cases and to reduce their costs in order to more specifically support consumers as well as small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) to make their claims, ensuring that they have access to justice. Unfortunately, this procedure is little known to the general public and could obviously continue even outside the EU. So I decided to vote for it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The balanced and acceptable report contains concrete proposals that meet the needs of citizens and small businesses who, due to excessive bureaucracy, find it difficult to make their case in small cross-border disputes.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. The European small-scale process aims to simplify and speed up small-scale civil and commercial litigation, as well as to reduce costs. This is a reform of particular importance for SMEs, who will be able to use the mechanism to solve their problems at the transnational level faster and with lower costs, but it is also relevant to citizens, on issues such as consumer disputes. Thanks to socialist leadership, this agreement could be closed during the Latvian Presidency, including particularly positive aspects such as, inters, the increase in the threshold to EUR 5 000, with a revision clause at 5 years, to discuss the possibility of further increase in the future; promoting the use of telecommunications and videoconferences for hearings or free assistance for the use of the procedure. For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which deals and amends Regulation (EC) No 861/2007 of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a European Small Claims Procedure. This Regulation aims to simplify and speed up cross-border small claims and to reduce costs. It was designed specifically to help consumers, as well as small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), to bring their claims, thereby ensuring that they have access to justice. The rapporteur fully supports this objective. Five years after the regulation was introduced, a detailed assessment was carried out which revealed that the European Small Claims Procedure was a useful tool. However, as underlined in the November 2013 Report, the Commission adopted a proposal for a directive on the protection of the environment and the environment. The Commission's report on the application of this procedure continues to have many opportunities to extend and strengthen its uptake. Under the European Small Claims Procedure, the costs of small claims of a cross-border nature have fallen by as much as 40%, while litigation has reduced from two years and five months to an average of five months.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The regulations on the introduction of the European Small Claims Procedure and the European Order for Payment Procedure aim to simplify cross-border judicial proceedings within the European Union and to reduce the financial implications of such proceedings. These provisions mainly benefit consumers and SMEs, since the Regulation contains rules that generally facilitate the enforcement of claims before the courts. Experience has shown that the regulation has been well received and its application has reduced the duration of procedures by an average of 40%. In the light of the practice of recent years, this amending proposal seeks to make the rules of the Regulation even more suited to the needs of its users. Significant facilitation is, for example, the modernisation of the rules on electronic delivery or the amendment of the threshold. During the tripartite negotiations on the dossier, a fundamentally favourable compromise was reached and I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. -u2012 Cross-border small-value disputes are primarily about reaping the advantages offered by the EU and the common market and, consequently, significantly reducing the costs of resolving these disputes. Small businesses in particular, but also consumers, it is the consumers who will gain the most here. Above all, it is important to reduce the duration of the conflict, which sometimes has sometimes lasted on average for two years, and our aim is to reduce it to a few months. The EPP has actively participated in the trialogue and has also succeeded in highlighting its priorities in the light of promoting the development of the small economy, and therefore my support for this report is also my support.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒This mechanism means a lot to the average consumer. In situations where he buys goods online from another EU member state and realizes by delivery that he has been deprived or defrauded, the consumer most often calculates that it is not worth it for the lesser amount he paid to enter into an expensive battle with the trader. Of course, next time they will not shop online and this further harms the European economy. Until now, both small and medium-sized enterprises have used this mechanism poorly. That is why I welcome the decision to increase the value of the lawsuit, as it is estimated that about 50 percent of their lawsuits will be able to be settled through this system. The biggest problem of this mechanism is that very few citizens in the EU even know about its existence.  As many as 82 per cent of consumers and SMEs do not know they can use this instrument in situations where they have small claims, when they cannot be charged, or when claiming damages for a vehicle that has been damaged outside their country. This mechanism is commendable, but the fact that for example in Bulgaria we only register 3 applications per year, and in Spain as many as 1047 says that some consumers are not informed at all and that is where we need to make additional efforts.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for a European small dispute settlement procedure and European injunction-to-pay procedure which was designed to help consumers as well as small and medium-sized enterprises to assert their claims in cross-border cases (litigations less than 5000 euros) and to ensure them access to justice.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which was concerned with raising the thresholds for the value of a claim. Previously, the threshold was set at EUR 2 000. The report provides that this limit would be raised to EUR 5 000 if pursued against a natural person i.e. an individual and EUR 10 000 if pursued against a legal person i.e. a company.  By way of background, the European Small Claims Procedure applies to all claims with a cross-border element. This includes cases where the parties are both domiciled in the same Member State and only the place of performance of the contract, the place where the harmful event takes place or the place of enforcement of the judgment is situated in another Member State. This provides an important remedy for cross-border disputes which in many Member States is woefully lacking at present.  One final positive point is that Legal Assistance can also be provided to parties free of charge, which did not previously exist.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I believe that the results obtained from the European Small Claims Procedure and the European Order for Payment Procedure are certainly remarkable and that, therefore, the necessary measures must be implemented to extend and consolidate the use of these instruments.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. Since July 2007, the European procedure for resolving small cross-border disputes has simplified and speeded up the resolution of legal disputes. Costs were reduced by 40% while the duration of the procedure increased from an average of 2 years to 5 months. However, the Commission found that these results were still insufficient. 45% of companies involved in litigation do not initiate proceedings because of the cost involved. This report therefore proposes to set the ceiling for small disputes at 10,000 euros compared to 2,000 euros today. It also advocates better use of electronic channels and video conferis to reduce travel costs. Court costs will be capped at 10% of the amounts incurred and the parties involved will be able to pay for them through an online payment method. Finally, 86% of citizens are not aware of this procedure. This is why communication on the website portal should be improved. This proposal will speed up the proceedings as well as reduce the costs of businesses and citizens involved in a legal dispute. So I voted for this text.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Positive vote. The text deals with transnational disputes in which citizens often give up their rights because of the economic and bureaucratic costs of the proceedings.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report today, which makes significant improvements to the already effective small claims procedure, which has proved to be an excellent legal instrument that has made it possible to cut the costs of cross-border disputes by up to 40%, reducing the overall duration of litigation to an average of 5 months.  Extending the scope of this procedure would therefore bring considerable benefits to both consumers and SMEs. With the proposed corrections, for example, competence by value is increased from the current EUR 2 000 to EUR 10 000 and postal and electronic services for the exchange of documents are equal. In addition, the upper limit for court costs may not exceed 10% of the value of the dispute, greatly facilitating access to justice.  However, it is necessary to outline specific strategies to make this type of procedure known to citizens, providing concrete information on how to use it and the costs they should bear, including through national awareness-raising campaigns. The amendments proposed in this draft report further improve the functioning of the small claims procedure and I have therefore voted in favour of the report.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which was concerned with raising the thresholds for the value of a claim. Previously, the threshold was set at EUR 2 000. The report provides that this limit would be raised to EUR 5 000 if pursued against a natural person i.e. an individual and EUR 10 000 if pursued against a legal person i.e. a company.  By way of background, the European Small Claims Procedure applies to all claims with a cross-border element. This includes cases where the parties are both domiciled in the same Member State and only the place of performance of the contract, the place where the harmful event takes place or the place of enforcement of the judgment is situated in another Member State. This provides an important remedy for cross-border disputes which in many Member States is woefully lacking at present.  One final positive point is that Legal Assistance can also be provided to parties free of charge, which did not previously exist.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This report concerned a proposal further to legislate on the European small claims procedure by amending existing legislation. The UK Independence Party is in principle opposed to the European Union having the power to legislate for the United Kingdom, and would normally vote against any report which advocated legislation or which was itself a legislative proposal. In this instance we are very mindful of the impact on UK small-to-medium enterprises (SMEs) of debts of up to EUR 10 000 being unpaid, and of the effort and costs of recovering such sums. UKIP is therefore minded not to oppose this report. UKIP decided to abstain, and I voted accordingly.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. Back in 2007, a small claims procedure was created in order to reduce costs in cross-border cases. The plan was designed to help small and medium-sized companies with their claims. Enhancement is needed as the European Small Claims Procedure needs to further reduce costs and litigation time. Since some Member States differ in usage there also needs to be transparency in these proceedings along with legal certainty concerning modern technology.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Regulation (EC) No 861/2007 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 11 July 2007 established a European small claims procedure. This Regulation applies in cross-border civil and commercial disputes of a value not exceeding EUR 2 000. It aimed to help SMEs and consumers.  The European Commission's report of 19 November 2013 on the application of this regulation showed ample scope for extending and consolidating the use of this instrument. Last April, the JURI Committee voted on a text which, on the whole, could be regarded as improving the European Commission's proposal. Following the vote in committee, negotiations with the Council have opened. Unfortunately, the trialogue has made the committee's proposal worse; That is why, together with my colleagues, I voted against.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (ENF)
text: In writing. This Regulation establishes a procedure to simplify and expedite the resolution and cost of resolving small-dollar disputes in cross-border cases. It was designed specifically to help consumers and SMEs make their claims, thereby ensuring access to justice. So I voted for it.

name: Nessa Childers (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Integration among Member States involves every aspect of an EU citizen’s life. As freedom of movement and labour becomes more accessible, giving citizens greater possibilities, we are also faced with cross-border challenges.  These challenges can nevertheless be overcome through transparent cooperation between the Institutions.  For example, if a citizen needs to claim money back from a faulty product bought online, coming from a different EU Member State, it is our duty to facilitate ways to resolve these issues. This has been the case since 2007. However, today we voted on making sure that these small-claim procedures are more accessible to people as well as increasing the threshold of the claim to EUR 5 000.

name: Ole Christensen (S&D)
text: Written. It is important that consumers and small and medium-sized enterprises have a good opportunity to recover debts across national borders. Therefore, in 2009, the EU adopted a small claims procedure that makes it easier for businesses and consumers to recover small amounts across borders, avoiding lengthy litigation and high legal costs. This scheme will, among other things, extend the regulation so that the small claims procedure can be used for amounts as much as EUR 5 000.  All in all, it is a proposal that saves businesses and citizens time and money. That is why we fully support the regulation. Denmark has an exception in this area, but hopefully in December the Danish electorate will decide to change the Danish opt-out to an opt-in system. This will enable Denmark to participate in this Regulation.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 It is proposed to increase the minimum value for small claims under the European small claims procedure from the existing amount of EUR 2 000 to EUR 10 000. This new threshold will not be of great importance to consumers, as most of their claims do not exceed EUR 2 000, but this is a significant improvement for SMEs.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this measure.  Regulation (EC) No 861/2007 of 11 July 2007 on small claims and the European order for payment procedure was designed in particular to help consumers and small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) assert their rights, thereby ensuring access to justice.  After five years, the assessment is positive. Indeed, the European Small Claims Procedure has cut the cost of small cross-border disputes by up to 40% and reduced its duration from a maximum of 2 years and 5 months to an average of 5 months. With this measure, the Commission intends to raise the ceiling for small claims which can be composed through the European procedure of eur 2 000 to EUR 10 000 and to extend the definition to disputes in which the parties are domiciled in the same Member State, but which have another cross-border element, such as the place of performance of the contract, the place where the harmful event occurred or the execution of the judgment in another Member State.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal for a regulation. It has been shown in recent years that the procedure it provides for has indeed proved to be a useful tool, but there is also ample scope for extending, consolidating and improving the use of this instrument. The Commission proposes to raise the ceiling for small claims, which can be made up through the European procedure, from the current EUR 2 000 to EUR 10 000. I agree with the Commission and with the rapporteur, Mrs Oedenberg, on this point, since the proposed increase would have a marginal impact on consumers, given that disputes affecting consumers do not usually exceed EUR 2 000, but would represent an important improvement for SMEs, which I consider to be of fundamental importance.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Parliament’s vote benefits EU citizens by providing simplified procedures for cross-border dispute resolution. National barriers will no longer be an insurmountable obstacle in judicial matters for individuals, nor, in particular, for SMEs. Electronic communication tools will facilitate the process for those involved. Good faith in the execution of civil and commercial contracts will be more vigorously protected and legal security will be guaranteed for the commercial circuit

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This report concerned a proposal  to legislate further on the European Small Claims Procedure by amending existing legislation.  The UK Independence Party is in principle opposed to the European Union having the power to legislate for the United Kingdom and would normally vote against any report which advocated legislation or which was itself a legislative proposal. In this instance we are very mindful of the impact of debts up to EUR 10 000 being unpaid to UK small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and the effort and costs of recovering such sums, and UKIP is therefore minded not to oppose this report. UKIP decided to abstain.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Regulation (EC) No 861/2007 establishes a European small claims procedure with the aim of simplifying and accelerating small claims in cross-border cases and reducing specific expenditure. From the experience gained over its lifetime, although the European small claims case proves to be a useful tool, it is noted that recourse to the courts remains low. I support the increase in the cap on the use of the European small claims procedure from EUR 2 000 to EUR 10 000 which will be a considerable improvement for SMEs. The organisation of videoconference hearings will contribute to reducing expenditure and increasing the use of such actions, as it will not be necessary to travel to the court. The obligation of Member States to set up distance payment means will allow applicants to obtain savings in payment costs, which are between EUR 400 and EUR 800 when there is a need for travel. With these proposals we have contributed to improving the functioning of the European small claims process

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Small Claims Procedure is an effective judicial tool as it simplifies and speeds up proceedings relating to cross-border litigation, reducing costs and the duration of legal proceedings. The regulation was designed precisely to make it easier for consumers and small and medium-sized enterprises to assert their rights, ensuring easier access to justice.  However, the low rate of use of the procedure in the various European countries was found and the reasons for the lack of recourse to the courts in small claims are the high costs of starting the judicial procedure and the lack of knowledge of the existence of the procedure itself. In order to prevent this phenomenon, which essentially demonstrates a lack of confidence and information in the internal market, I welcome the proposed amendments to the regulation, as they would improve the functioning of the small claims procedure.  I therefore voted in favour of this report and believe that this process can improve considerably with the expected increase in the use of information and communication technologies and national awareness-raising campaigns proposed by the Commission for the Member States.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This Regulation facilitates access to justice across borders, thereby enabling for individuals as well as for companies more effective and efficient enforcement of their rights. It will provide a quicker and more cost-effective judicial remedy to enforce money claims within the internal market. This legislative instrument is particularly important to those who participate in transactions online within the digital single market, be it individuals or companies, as it provides them with a quick but just remedy. I encourage those businesses and entrepreneurs who have not as yet harnessed the potential of the digital platform for trade in goods and services to see this Regulation as another invitation to take the impetus towards harnessing the opportunities presented by the digital single market as well as to participate in the full potential of the internal market.  This simplified procedure will only obtain the trust it deserves from businesses and consumers if the safeguards stated therein, ensuring a fast but fair procedure, are correctly followed by national authorities. All too often we have been told that it is not worth pursuing a claim across borders for reasons of cost and pedantic procedures. The Regulation keeps costs to a minimum and simplifies procedures by introducing also the use of technology in collecting the evidence needed.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 This Regulation aims to amend and replace Regulation No 861/2007 of July 2007 establishing a European small claims procedure.  The intention was to simplify and speed up proceedings in small cross-border disputes and to reduce their costs and duration. The regulation was designed in particular to help consumers and SMEs assert their rights, thereby ensuring access to justice. However, it has emerged that there is ample scope to extend and consolidate the use of this instrument. Among the measures proposed by the Commission to improve the use of this instrument are: raising the ceiling for small claims from the current EUR 2 000 to EUR 10 000; scope of the Regulation: broadening the definition of cross-border dispute; procedure and telematic means: to standardize postal and electronic services for the exchange of documents; court costs: a maximum limit for court costs of 10% of the value of the dispute and a maximum amount of EUR 35 of minimum court costs and the possibility of paying electronically.  I am abstaining because it hinders SMEs and consumers.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it amends the European Regulation in such a way that it is a necessary improvement in establishing a simplified process for claims of less than EUR 10 000. This amendment is an important step forward in improving speed in such processes in the European Union. The report establishes a system of fees which should not exceed the rates set by Member States and the fees must be proportional to the amount demanded; the amendment to the Regulation also removes exceptions. The report includes technical improvements and recognition obligations by Member States, such as the obligation to free practical assistance, all improving consumer legal certainty at European level. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Small Claims Procedure has simplified cross-border litigation in the Union. However, some obstacles still persist and have prevented the full exploitation of the potential of the European process, particularly for small and medium-sized enterprises. I voted in favour of this resolution because it aims to remove these obstacles by further facilitating access to justice for both consumers and businesses, including through better use of technologies, reducing expenditure and speeding up civil proceedings in disputes falling within its scope.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Regulations on the introduction of the European Small Claims Procedure and the European Order for Payment Procedure are intended to simplify and make more cheaper cross-border judicial proceedings within the European Union. I voted in favour of this report in order to improve the provisions. In particular, these provisions benefit consumers and small and medium-sized enterprises, making it easier for claims to be brought before the courts. On the basis of experience so far, the legislation has been well received and its application has reduced the duration of procedures by an average of 40%. The current amendment, which has taken into account the practice of recent years, seeks to make the rules of the Regulation more suited to the needs of the users, i.e. EU citizens. For example, modernising the rules on electronic delivery and changing the threshold will make it easier.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Commission proposal and the legislative resolution on the European Small Claims Procedure which has the ultimate aim of simplifying and speeding up cross-border small claims litigation in civil and commercial matters.  What is particularly interesting in this report is the fact that the threshold has increased to EUR 5 000 with a 5 year review clause; the fact that the use of long-distance communication and videoconferencing for hearings are encouraged and a 5 year review clause to assess whether labour claims should be included in the scope of the regulation or not.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. The report aims to simplify and expedite the resolution of small cross-border disputes and reduce their costs. This procedure was designed specifically to help consumers and small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) assert their rights, thereby ensuring access to justice. To date, it has reduced procedural costs by 40% and reduced their duration to a maximum of 2 years and an average of 5 months. However, the report remains underutilized in some Member States and provides for a maximum ceiling of EUR 5,000 in the cost of procedure. It also increases the possibilities of using remote means of communication. Considering that this report contributes to the establishment within the internal market of a more favourable economic environment for consumers and businesses, I voted in favour.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report. This procedure was designed primarily to help European consumers and small and medium-sized enterprises to assert their rights, in the context of the settlement of small disputes. In particular, the voted report extends the application of the procedure to disputes of up to 5,000 euros, instead of 2,000 euros previously.

name: Philippe De Backer (ALDE)
text: Written. – The proposal that was voted on here facilitates the legal process of filing a small claim. People throughout the European Union will be able to make a claim without further obligations. If it is not desired, the case law can happen without a hearing. If this hearing is necessary, it will also be able to be carried out remotely, for example by means of videoconferencing. All these measures will make the case-law efficient and smooth, which in turn contributes to more transparent legislation. That is why I support this proposal.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission's proposal to extend and consolidate the use of the European small claims procedure provides for an increase in the limit value of small claims from EUR 2 000 to EUR 10 000. The need to modernise this procedure was highlighted, for example by allowing videoconference hearings to be held and thus avoiding uncomfortable and costly movements to appear during a hearing. I think it is important to extend the possibility of using this instrument, increasing the percentage of disputes that will benefit from a significant reduction in costs and the duration of litigation. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. As of 1 January 2009, any consumer in dispute with a professional from another EU country can use the European small dispute settlement procedure if the dispute is less than 2,000 euros. Since its inception, this procedure has reduced the costs of legal proceedings for small cross-border claims by 40% and reduced the length of proceedings from 2 years to 5 months. Extending the amount of the dispute to 5,000 euros and improving remote use are in line with better protection for European consumers and small SMEs by making it easier for them to access justice.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The regulations on the introduction of the European Small Claims Procedure and the European Order for Payment Procedure aim to simplify cross-border judicial proceedings within the European Union and to reduce the financial implications of such proceedings. These provisions mainly benefit consumers and SMEs, since the Regulation contains rules that generally facilitate the enforcement of claims before the courts. Experience has shown that the regulation has been well received and its application has reduced the duration of procedures by an average of 40%. In the light of the practice of recent years, this amending proposal seeks to make the rules of the Regulation even more suited to the needs of its users. Significant facilitation is, for example, the modernisation of the rules on electronic delivery or the amendment of the threshold. During the tripartit negotiations on the procedure, a fundamentally favourable compromise was reached and I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. The European procedure for resolving small disputes has been in place since 2009. It is an optional simplified procedure based on standard forms and allows the recovery of funds held by a third party in another EU country. The system is working well. It reduced the costs of court proceedings for small cross-border claims by 40% and the duration of the process increased from two years to an average of five months. I supported this report because I felt it was necessary to make changes to this procedure to allow more citizens and small businesses to use it. In particular, I support raising the debt ceiling that can be recovered through the procedure from EUR 2,000 to EUR 5,000, the proportionality of court costs, the incentive to use remote communication technologies for possible oral hearings and the provision of practical assistance by EU countries to fill out the forms and provide general information on the procedure and jurisdiction of the relevant court.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported colleague Geringer de Odenberg's report on the European Small Claims Procedure. I agree that this instrument needs to become more attractive and useful to European citizens, who increasingly enter into financial relationships of a cross-border nature thanks to the functioning of the free European market. I welcome the decision to increase the limit on the value of actions from EUR 2 000 to EUR 5 000 for civil and commercial cases of a cross-border nature. This will ensure effective protection for European citizens and small and medium-sized enterprises. I also support other proposals which I believe contribute to improving the instrument and making it more feasible in practice.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Positive, because simplifying court proceedings and increasing the financial limit for actions will help small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The regulations on the introduction of the European Small Claims Procedure and the European Order for Payment Procedure aim to simplify cross-border judicial proceedings within the European Union and to reduce the financial implications of such proceedings. These provisions mainly benefit consumers and SMEs, since the Regulation contains rules that generally facilitate the enforcement of claims before the courts. Experience has shown that the regulation has been well received and its application has reduced the duration of procedures by an average of 40%. In the light of the practice of recent years, this amending proposal seeks to make the rules of the Regulation even more suited to the needs of its users. Significant facilitation is, for example, the modernisation of the rules on electronic delivery or the amendment of the threshold. During the tripartit negotiations on the procedure, a fundamentally favourable compromise was reached and I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE)
text: in writing. This Regulation No 861/2007 was specifically designed to assist consumers and small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in their demands, ensuring access to justice. After years of application it has been revealed as an efficient tool, but there is still room for improvement. In this sense, this reform of the Regulation establishing a small European process is one of the measures that promote the effectiveness of justice in the EU. Taking into account also the economic situation of recent years in the EU, improving the effectiveness of justice in the European Union also becomes an important factor in supporting economic activity, as that regulation was adopted in response to problems caused by the inefficiency of disputes when claims are filed across the borders of EU Member States. In addition, the modernisation of the Regulation supports the EU's current political priorities to promote economic recovery and sustainable growth, promoting more efficient and simplified judicial processes and making them more accessible to SMEs.

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
