text: in writing. – This report concerned a proposal  to legislate further on the European Small Claims Procedure by amending existing legislation.  The UK Independence Party is in principle opposed to the European Union having the power to legislate for the United Kingdom and would normally vote against any report which advocated legislation or which was itself a legislative proposal. In this instance we are very mindful of the impact of debts up to EUR 10 000 being unpaid to UK small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and the effort and costs of recovering such sums, and UKIP is therefore minded not to oppose this report. UKIP decided to abstain

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report amends Regulations (EC) No 861/2007 1896/2006 of the European Parliament and the Council, which establish a European procedure for small claims and establishing a European order for payment procedure, applicable to disputed and uncontested civil and commercial claims whose value does not exceed EUR 2 000. Those regulations ensured that the decisions given in the context of this procedure were enforceable without intermediate procedures, in particular without the need for a declaration of enforceability in the executing Member State (abolition of exequatur). The general objective was to improve access to justice by reducing costs and speeding up civil proceedings relating to applications falling within their scope, both for consumers and businesses. It has been recognised that the European small claims procedure has facilitated the resolution of cross-border cases relating to such actions in the EU. However, obstacles to the full implementation of this process for the benefit of consumers and businesses, in particular SMEs, are marked, which relates to the low limit laid down in the current Regulation which deprives many potential applicants of the use of a simplified process in cross-border disputes. The amendments proposed here relate to this point in the first place. In general, the report deserves our agreement.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the legislative resolution as it provides better protection to the consumer.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The use of tribunals in small claims submissions remains very low in some Member States and more needs to be done in terms of legal certainty, language barriers and transparency of proceedings. I therefore welcome the European Commission's proposal to increase the limit on the use of the European Small Claims Procedure also for cross-border claims with a value between EUR 2000 and EUR 10 000. This amendment will increase the percentage of disputes to which a significant reduction in costs and a reduction in the length of proceedings apply.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of this report, which extends the value of small border disputes in which the regulation would intervene (from EUR 2 000 to EUR 5 000). This measure meets the needs of EU citizens, who very often give up their rights because of the different costs – economic and bureaucratic – of proceedings in this type of procedure.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the European small claims procedure and the European order for payment procedure because simplifying court proceedings and increasing the financial limit for actions will help small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: Ashley Fox (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report as it attempts to solve issues previously created and will help consumers and SMEs in small claims courts. I am happy to see an attempt to reduce the procedural burden for individuals and small businesses. Access to law should not be made more difficult by red tape and bureaucracy.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The establishment of the European Small Claims Procedure is an important step forward from the procedures existing under the laws of the Member States. I believe this report will simplify and speed-up cross-border small claims litigation in civil and commercial matters and will cut costs.  I welcome the inclusion in the report of the point that ensures that the judgement given by the European Small Claims Procedure will be recognised and enforceable in another Member State without the need for a declaration of enforceability and without any possibility of opposing its recognition. Increasing the threshold to EUR 5 000, with a 5-year review clause in order to see whether a further increase is possible, is one of the better aspects of the report as it will make the ESCP more accessible and therefore more used.  Finally I find it very positive that court fees will be proportionate to the claim and that assistance for the use of procedure will be free of charge.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The regulations on the introduction of the European Small Claims Procedure and the European Order for Payment Procedure aim to simplify cross-border judicial proceedings within the European Union and to reduce the financial implications of such proceedings. These provisions mainly benefit consumers and SMEs, since the Regulation contains rules that generally facilitate the enforcement of claims before the courts. Experience has shown that the regulation has been well received and its application has reduced the duration of procedures by an average of 40%. In the light of the practice of recent years, this amending proposal seeks to make the rules of the Regulation even more suited to the needs of its users. Significant facilitation is, for example, the modernisation of the rules on electronic delivery or the amendment of the threshold. During the tripartit negotiations on the procedure, a fundamentally favourable compromise was reached and I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the increase in the threshold for the use of the European Small Claims Procedure. By allowing for a simplified procedure for cross-border claims worth between EUR 2 000 and EUR 10 000, the proportion of cases where the cost and length of dispute settlement can be significantly reduced may increase. I believe that this change will further increase the number of cases in which businesses and consumers can achieve cost savings. The threshold for small claims should be kept lower than the average amount of claims, thereby providing the necessary procedural guarantees for claims of higher value.  It should also be remembered that if the threshold is raised, the procedure will be used more frequently, which will make it part of the daily routine in the courts. This will make it easier for potential users, in particular consumers, to have access to the necessary information. However, raising the threshold above EUR 10 000 does not currently seem feasible and the rapporteur therefore supports the value proposed by the Commission.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour after analysing the balance sheet of the last five years of implementation, which indicates that the European small-scale process has proved to be a useful tool to help consumers and small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) demand debt payments, thus ensuring access to justice. The small European process has reduced the costs of small cross-border disputes by up to 40% and allowed the duration of disputes to go from two years and five months to an average of five months, which is undoubtedly a clear step forward, but we must still work in this area, so I supported the report.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 A simplified procedure is introduced which allows great benefits for both citizens and SMEs in small claims proceedings. All too often in the past, bureaucracy has discouraged businesses and citizens from engaging in this type of process. With this vote there will be less costs and a faster and more modern procedure, capable of fully guaranteeing the needs of justice. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this important report, in the hope that this simplified procedure will be made more public in order to increase its effectiveness.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D)
text: In writing. Access to justice is a democratic issue. This is all the more true in cross-border disputes that confront litigants with many difficulties. In 2009, a European procedure for the settlement of small border disputes was set up. Despite the many benefits it brings in terms of cost reduction and the duration of dispute settlements, this procedure remains under-recognized and underutilized. That is why I voted in favour of the report by my Polish Socialist colleague, Lidia Geringer of Oedenger, which makes this procedure more accessible and transparent. Among the proposed improvements: the widening of the scope of the procedure, the increased use of remote communication technology for hearings and the obtaining of evidence and, finally, the obligation for Member States to ensure that the legal costs collected are not disproportionate. I am particularly in favour of these advances in that they bring European citizens closer to justice and strengthen the rule of law.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as overall it would further improve the functioning of the small claims procedure. The European small claims procedure can be successful but only if consumers and businesses, courts, and associations providing the advice are aware of it.  Consumers and businesses need very concrete information on how to use the procedure in practice and what it would cost. It therefore makes sense for the Member States to provide more in-depth information on court fees and methods of payment for the European small claims procedure.

name: Roger Helmer (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This report concerned a proposal  to legislate further on the European Small Claims Procedure by amending existing legislation.  The UK Independence Party is in principle opposed to the European Union having the power to legislate for the United Kingdom and would normally vote against any report which advocated legislation or which was itself a legislative proposal. In this instance we are very mindful of the impact of debts up to EUR 10 000 being unpaid to UK small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and the effort and costs of recovering such sums, and UKIP is therefore minded not to oppose this report. UKIP decided to abstain.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. The report calls for the extension of the small claims and European dunning procedure, which has been in place since 2007, and aims to resolve disputes in low-value cross-border cases more easily and quickly and to reduce costs. In particular, the procedure is intended to help consumers and small and medium-sized enterprises to enforce their demands and ensure access to justice. In its 2011 resolution, Parliament stated that 'the use of small claims courts remains low in some Member States and that more needs to be done in terms of legal certainty, language barriers and procedural transparency'. Among other things, it is proposed to raise the threshold for small claims covered by the European procedure from the current EUR 2000 to EUR 5000. The new threshold is expected to represent a significant improvement for SMEs. The increase in the threshold proposed in the trialogue by Parliament, the Council and the Commission, the improved use of electronic communications and the limitation of court fees, will enable both entrepreneurs and consumers to make savings and save costs. With this in mind, I voted in favour of this report. Incidentally, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The regulations on the introduction of the European Small Claims Procedure and the European Order for Payment Procedure aim to simplify cross-border judicial proceedings within the European Union and to reduce the financial implications of such proceedings. This is most favourable to consumers and SMEs, as the Regulation contains rules that generally facilitate the enforcement of claims before the courts. It is projected that the application of the new regulation will reduce the duration of procedures by an average of 40%. This amending proposal seeks, taking into account the practice of recent years, to make the rules of the Regulation even more suited to the needs of the application population. Significant facilitation is, for example, the modernisation of the rules on electronic delivery or the amendment of the threshold. A fundamentally favourable compromise was reached during the interinstitutional negotiations on the procedure, and I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to simplify the current procedure for settling small disputes and the European procedure for injunctions to pay in cross-border proceedings.  This simplification concerns the application of the procedure to disputes of up to 5,000 euros, instead of 2,000 euros previously, and strengthens procedural obligations. This procedure is largely unknown to SMEs and consumers. However, I see only advantages in using it: procedures are on average five times faster than conventional procedures, less than 6 months, and generate 40% less costs. A reflection on how to make this procedure better publicized would merit further study.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the European small-group process and the European monitoring process. The report takes over the resolution of transnational cases. The position of the GUE/NGL Group is to ensure access to pass the thresholds of small legal entities. In order to reduce the price of thresholds, we are also in favour of investing in technologies that ensure telematics assistance for economically disadvantaged users.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the proposal for a regulation by Parliament and the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 2012/2013; 861/2007 on the introduction of the European Small Claims Procedure and Regulation (EC) No 101/2007. 1896/2006 on the introduction of the European Order for Payment Procedure on the basis that such amendments modernise, simplify and speed up the cross-border procedure for small claims and reduce its costs. In addition, I support the proposal to raise the monetary threshold of disputes from EUR 2 000 to EUR 10000, which will be of particular benefit to SMEs, and to extend the meaning of cross-border disputes. Moreover, it is essential to encourage the use of information technologies and online payment methods, as well as to raise public awareness of the importance of such procedures. While I support this proposal, I believe it is still necessary to improve legal certainty, transparency of procedures and address difficulties with language barriers.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report regarding the regulation establishing a European Small Claims Procedure because it is in my view an indispensable tool for building a Single Market for Small and Medium Enterprises. The measures proposed will result in considerable savings for European businesses and consumers.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Lidia Geringer De Oedenberg's report on the European procedure for settling small disputes in the case of cross-border proceedings. The aim was to validate the agreement reached with the Council and the Commission on the subject, which in particular extends the application of this procedure to litigation up to 5,000 euros, against 2,000 euros before, and strengthens procedural obligations. This mechanism is very useful and fast for SMEs and consumers, but is still unknown, and is therefore not being used to its full potential. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted for this report because it will make it easier to resolve small cross-border disputes, reducing costs and speeding up civil proceedings at the same time.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I am voting in favour of the proposals in this report. In particular, I believe that the increase in the ceiling for small claims from EUR 2,000 to EUR 5,000 is appropriate and necessary.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a Standardised European Small Claims Procedure and a European Order for Payment Procedure. Such a procedure has already existed in the EU since 2009, but the amendments supported by a majority at the European Parliament plenary session in Strasbourg simplify the procedure for recovering small cross-border debts. This means that in future, more EU citizens and small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) will be able to use this procedure to deal directly with cross-border disputes arising from small sums of money. The amendments adopted to the regulation mean that the costs of litigation could be reduced by up to 40%, as they will have to be set at a proportionate level of the requirement and should not be higher than the cost of simplified national proceedings. The length of the trial will also be almost halved. Such improvements are particularly important for small and medium-sized enterprises, which is why I also join the majority of the EP in voting in favour of this regulation.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. – The volume of cross-border trade and services is constantly increasing, so it is natural that opportunities for simplified treatment and recovery of cross-border small claims have to be created and updated, so I supported the proposal. All the more so because consumers and businesses, especially SMEs, have also raised the need to further improve the Regulation.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The European small claims procedure should simplify and speed up litigation concerning small claims in cross-border cases, and reduce costs. It was designed specifically to help consumers and small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) enforce their claims, thus ensuring access to justice. This procedure has proven to be a useful tool, though it needs to be broadened in order to minimise the bureaucratic burden. The European small claims procedure has reduced the costs of litigating cross-border small claims by as much as 40 % and has cut the duration of litigation from up to two years and five months to an average of five months. Usage of small claims tribunals in some Member States, however, remains significantly low, and consequently more needed to be done in terms of legal certainty, use of modern technology and transparency of proceedings. I call on the Commission to come up with an e-solution to mediate between the different parties, by enabling digital signatures, e-identification and electronic procedure, in order further to reduce litigation time and costs.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the proposal, as it is important in terms of securing access to justice more efficiently across the EU.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. The report calls for the extension of the small claims and European dunning procedure, which has been in place since 2007, and aims to resolve disputes in low-value cross-border cases more easily and quickly and to reduce costs. In particular, the procedure is intended to help consumers and small and medium-sized enterprises to enforce their demands and ensure access to justice. In its 2011 resolution, Parliament stated that 'the use of small claims courts remains low in some Member States and that more needs to be done in terms of legal certainty, language barriers and procedural transparency'. Among other things, it is proposed to raise the threshold for small claims covered by the European procedure from the current EUR 2000 to EUR 5000. The new threshold is expected to represent a significant improvement for SMEs. The increase in the threshold proposed in the trialogue by Parliament, the Council and the Commission, the improved use of electronic communications and the limitation of court fees, will enable both entrepreneurs and consumers to make savings and save costs. With this in mind, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 7 November 2015, we voted in Strasbourg on a report on a proposal for a regulation amending the regulation introducing the so-called European Small Claims Procedure and the European Order for Payment Procedure. It should be noted that, in the case of the European Small Claims Procedure, this is an increasingly commonly used alternative to normal civil proceedings at issue. In particular, it has been introduced to assist consumers in exercising their rights in cross-border disputes. After five years of application of the original regulation, the European Small Claims Procedure has proved to be a useful and necessary tool. During that time, however, there have been some problems with this adjustment. The amendment is intended to eliminate some of the problems encountered by the proceedings since the beginning of its existence, namely to set a limit on court fees which were too high to discourage consumers from using this type of procedure, to further adjust the limit of EUR 2 000 for SMEs, which very limited them because only a small percentage of their cross-border claims fit into it. I supported the report in the vote because the result of the trilogue is a fairly balanced compromise that will hopefully facilitate access to justice for consumers and SMEs. Moreover, the final text is of far better quality than the text originally produced by the Committee.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The regulations on the introduction of the European Small Claims Procedure and the European Order for Payment Procedure aim to simplify cross-border judicial proceedings within the European Union and to reduce the financial implications of such proceedings. These provisions mainly benefit consumers and SMEs, since the Regulation contains rules that generally facilitate the enforcement of claims before the courts. Experience has shown that the regulation has been well received and its application has reduced the duration of procedures by an average of 40%. In the light of the practice of recent years, this amending proposal seeks to make the rules of the Regulation even more suited to the needs of its users. Significant facilitation is, for example, the modernisation of the rules on electronic delivery or the amendment of the threshold. During the tripartit negotiations on the procedure, a fundamentally favourable compromise was reached and I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This report is on two regulations (No 1896/2006 and No 861/2007), on cross-border cases. The purpose of this report is to find a solution, when there is litigation between several countries, through the mechanism of small claims. GUE/NGL originally had an objection regarding the threshold. To set a small threshold for the small claim procedure, in the final report the amount was fixed at EUR 5 000, and GUE/NGL supported that. Another relevant concern is the possibility for oral hearing and videoconference. I voted in favour of the report, since the small claims procedure was improved.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this proposal. Regulation (EC) No 861/2007 of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a European small claims procedure aims to simplify and speed up proceedings in small cross-border disputes and reduce their costs. This measure raises the ceiling for small claims that can be composed through the European procedure from the current EUR 2 000 to EUR 10 000. This would increase the number of disputes covered by the regulation from 20% to 50%, and the result would be a net saving in legal costs for small and medium-sized enterprises in the Member States.

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE)
text: In writing. As a member of the Legal Affairs Committee, I voted in favour of revising the regulation on the simplified European procedure for the settlement of small cross-border disputes, in order to facilitate the collection of cross-border debts, with the maximum threshold now increased from EUR 2,000 to EUR 5,000. As a result, more European citizens and SMEs will be able to use this written legal procedure in these small cross-border disputes, benefiting from both a simplification of the debt collection process, a reduction in the legal costs involved of around 40% compared to the standard procedure, and a significant reduction in the duration of the procedure from two years to five less on average. It is therefore to enable our citizens and very small businesses to recover their small cross-border debts in a less expensive, simpler and faster way that I have supported the adoption of this simplified procedure.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution on a European procedure for the settlement of small disputes, which aims to simplify and speed up the resolution of small-scale disputes in cross-border cases and to reduce their costs. It was designed specifically to help consumers and small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) make their claims, thereby ensuring access to justice.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this report because it allows French and European SMEs and individuals to resolve their cross-border civil and commercial disputes at a low cost. It remains to be hoped that this mechanism will be effectively implemented, which requires fair cooperation from the national justices concerned.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. A small European process was established through Regulation (EC) No 861/2007 at the disposal of litigants as an alternative to other existing procedures in accordance with the laws of the various Member States. The european small-scale process aims to simplify and speed up small-scale civil and commercial litigation, as well as to reduce costs. The reform of this Regulation is particularly important for SMEs, who will be able to use the mechanism to solve their problems at the transnational level faster and with lower costs, but it is also relevant to citizens (e.g. in consumer disputes). We consider these developments relevant in the European socio-economic field, so I voted in favour.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. The report calls for the extension of the small claims and European dunning procedure, which has been in place since 2007, and aims to resolve disputes in low-value cross-border cases more easily and quickly and to reduce costs. In particular, the procedure is intended to help consumers and small and medium-sized enterprises to enforce their demands and ensure access to justice. In its 2011 resolution, Parliament stated that 'the use of small claims courts remains low in some Member States and that more needs to be done in terms of legal certainty, language barriers and procedural transparency'. Among other things, it is proposed to raise the threshold for small claims covered by the European procedure from the current EUR 2000 to EUR 5000. The new threshold is expected to represent a significant improvement for SMEs. The increase in the threshold proposed in the trialogue by Parliament, the Council and the Commission, the improved use of electronic communications and the limitation of court fees, will enable both entrepreneurs and consumers to make savings and save costs. With this in mind, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported Geringer de Oedenberg's report adopting amendments to the Regulation introducing the European Small Claims Procedure and the Regulation introducing the European Order for Payment Procedure. The regulations were created to help consumers and SMEs get their claims. Raising the threshold for small claims disputes from the current €2,000 to €10,000 will ensure that more disputes are conducted under simplified procedures. It also extends the definition of cross-border disputes, limiting the maximum fee, reducing the length of the procedure and creating a document exchange platform.  I welcome the initiative to encourage citizens to use INFORMATION technologies to resolve small claims as one way of simplifying administrative, financial and geographical procedures that are a major burden on SMEs.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. I congratulate Mrs Geringer on the adoption of this important legislative dossier, which represents a further step forward in legal certainty at European level for consumers, businesses and citizens. With this first reading, Parliament is improving and extending the scope of the previous 2007 dispute settlement directive. I am thinking in particular of raising the dispute threshold to EUR 5 000, with a 5-year review clause, for a further possible increase, to encouraging the use of distance communication and videoconferencing for the parties' hearings, to facilitate resolution times, to define court costs proportionate to credit, so as not to unnecessarily increase costs for consumers.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the report on a European small claims procedure and a European order for payment procedure because I believe that unifying these rules is extremely important in the common– particularly digital – internal market. This provides legal certainty for customers and small and medium-sized enterprises involved in cross-border trade.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the implementation of the European Small Claims Procedure and the European Order for Payment Procedure. Raising the limit values is an important step in the cross-border extension of consumer and small business protection in the European Union.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, given its importance in terms of securing access to justice more efficiently across the EU. It will do this by increasing the threshold of what is considered a ‘small claim’ to EUR 5 000, with a five-year review clause in order to see whether a further increase is possible; encouraging the use of long-distance communication and video-conferencing for hearings; establishing a five-year review clause in order to assess the possibility of including labour claims in the scope of the regulation; making court fees proportionate to the claim; and providing for free of charge assistance for the use of the procedure. It is to be noted that this will not affect the current legal status in the UK, where the threshold for application is higher than the EUR 5 000 set out in the directive.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: In writing. The purpose of this report is to facilitate legal proceedings for the resolution of small disputes. These new provisions will facilitate cross-border approaches by citizens and small and medium-sized enterprises by reducing the costs of these procedures, for a more accessible justice system. That is why I supported this text.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the European small-group process and the European monitoring process. The report takes over the resolution of transnational cases. The position of the GUE/NGL Group is to ensure access to pass the thresholds of small legal entities. In order to reduce the price of thresholds, we are also in favour of investing in technologies that ensure telematics assistance for economically disadvantaged users.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Along with my colleagues in the Socialist & Democrat Group, I voted in favour of this report. I did so because I believe in the aims of the report. It will make access to legal aid easier and reduce the burden for the less advantaged in society. It is great to see agreement between Parliament and the Council on this matter.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The regulations on the introduction of the European Small Claims Procedure and the European Order for Payment Procedure aim to simplify cross-border judicial proceedings within the European Union and to reduce the financial implications of such proceedings. These provisions mainly benefit consumers and SMEs, since the Regulation contains rules that generally facilitate the enforcement of claims before the courts. Experience has shown that the regulation has been well received and its application has reduced the duration of procedures by an average of 40%. In the light of the practice of recent years, this amending proposal seeks to make the rules of the Regulation even more suited to the needs of its users. Significant facilitation is, for example, the modernisation of the rules on electronic delivery or the amendment of the threshold. During the tripartit negotiations on the procedure, a fundamentally favourable compromise was reached, so I voted in favour of the report as a member of the Hungarian delegation to the People's Party.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European simplified procedure will help in the recovery of claims, especially for consumers and small and medium-sized enterprises. The limit for proceedings in cross-border commercial and civil matters is increased from the current EUR 2 000 to EUR 10 000 vis-à-vis a legal person and to EUR 5 000 vis-à-vis a natural person. Postal and electronic delivery is equal. No later than 3 years after the entry into force of the Regulation, Member States are obliged to introduce video and teleconferencing, while the parties' right to a face-to-face hearing remains. This reduces the costs of the proceedings and also reduces the duration of the proceedings. The minimum amount of court fees will be EUR 35, the maximum is set at a ceiling of 5 % of the value of the claim. Each Member State shall set a minimum income threshold at which the parties shall not be required to pay court fees. Member States must ensure administrative support and public awareness of this type of procedure.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 1782/2003. This Regulation should therefore be amended accordingly. For the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 6/10/2015. However, I would also like to refer to the process of wage and pension seizures imposed by the troika in Memorandum III on Greece. The irrepressable fell from 1,500 euros to 1,000 euros, resulting in the state and banks "putting their hands" on the bank accounts of poor Greeks. Therefore, in Greece, the process of executing payment orders is essentially put at the service of the Memorandum State and the loan lenders. So, from the floor of the European Parliament, I would like to point out, once again, that the anti-monumental citizens will continue to fight for the abolition of the memorandums in Greece, the write-off of the shameful debt and the eviction of the troika from our country.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this regulation, which provides for the establishment of a procedure to settle small disputes in cross-border cases. This will simplify the procedure and reduce costs, allowing small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) to make their claims.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this Report. The European Small Claims Procedure can be successful only if consumers and businesses, courts, and associations providing advice are aware of it. Evidence quoted by the Commission shows that 86% of citizens and almost half of the courts have never heard of the procedure. It is therefore crucial that the Commission continue its efforts to provide information on the European Small Claims Procedure, in particular via the e-Justice Portal. It is equally important that the Member States complement the Commission’s efforts through national awareness-raising campaigns. Furthermore, consumers and businesses need very concrete information on how to use the procedure in practice and what it would cost. It therefore makes sense for the Member States to provide information on court fees and methods of payment for the European Small Claims Procedure.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission has submitted to Parliament and the Council a proposal to amend Regulation - EU - Euratom No 966/2012 laying down the rules applicable to the European Union budget. The priority objective of the Financial Regulation is the protection of the European Union's financial interests. Europe intends to combat fraud affecting its expenditure and revenue through sanctions in all the countries of the European Union. Protecting financial interests is a top priority for the European institutions.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Small claims proceedings are regulated as an alternative to proceedings under the Code of Civil Procedure, which has been in place since 2009. Today, we have discussed its modification, which aims, above all, to respond to the needs of consumers and SMEs, which have been discouraged by excessively high court fees and, on the contrary, by the too low limit by which small and medium-sized entitlements are defined. In particular, these changes should enable SMEs to recover more of their claims through management. I consider the text presented to be a balanced compromise, the result of a well-done work within the trilogue, which is why I voted in favour.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Regulation (EC) No 861/2007 of July 2007 establishes a simplified European procedure for small claims, while Regulation (EC) No 1896/2006 of December 2006 establishes a European order for payment procedure.  I voted in favour of the proposal by the European Parliament and the Council, because I believe that such simplified systems would be of particular benefit to small and medium-sized enterprises which, at present, are discouraged from taking legal action because of the high cost of ordinary or simplified national procedures.

name: Stefano Maullu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this legislative resolution because it makes it possible to increase the efficiency and effectiveness of cross-border dispute settlement procedures, both in the field of civil and commercial law. I am in favour of all regulations such as this, which make life easier for citizens and businesses and reduce costs.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. It is a good proposal to increase the threshold for small claims covered by the European Small Claims Procedure from the current EUR 2 000 to EUR 10 000. This will be a significant improvement for SMEs. We must therefore support this report.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to support this report as it helps to make litigation costs proportionate to the size of the claims. This ensures fairness and better access to justice for EU citizens.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The European small dispute settlement procedure was put in place in 2007. It aims to help consumers as well as small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) to make their claims, thus ensuring them access to justice in cross-border disputes. The Commission proposes to increase the ceiling on small disputes under the European small dispute settlement procedure from EUR 2,000, currently, to EUR 10,000, which would cover 50% of claims from SMEs. The proposal also extends the scope of the regulation by including in the definition of "cross-border dispute" disputes in which both parties are domiciled in the same Member State, but which contain another cross-border element, such as the place of execution of the contract or the place where the damage occurred. I'm voting for.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 861/2007 of the European Parliament and the Council, 11 July 2007 establishing a European small claims procedure and Regulation (EC) No 1896/2006 of the European Parliament and the Council of 12 December 2006 establishing a European order for payment procedure. After five years of implementation, the European small claims procedure has proved to be an extremely useful tool, simplifying and accelerating small claims in cross-border cases and reducing their expenditure. However, there was still scope to strengthen the application of that Regulation in order to encourage its implementation and use.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in support of the resolution. The ability for businesses and consumers to efficiently and justly pursue claims judgements across national borders is a vital component of the internal market framework. This resolution would increase the amount of monetary damages covered by the small claims procedure, which is significantly cheaper to utilise than other methods. Additionally it will further lower the costs for wronged parties to seek redress from the small claims framework, particularly the ability of SMEs to retrieve damages across borders more cost-effectively.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. I am pleased to see the outcome of this initiative taken by my group in 2011. With the development of cross-border trade, it was necessary to review this regulation in order to improve access to justice for both European citizens and SMEs. The balanced compromise that was voted on is fully in line with the broader goal of better legislation. By increasing the ceiling of a small dispute to 10,000 euros, reducing the duration of the procedure to 5 months, and the costs of it through pragmatic measures (e.g. credit card payment, remote communication for hearings, cap on court costs, etc.); we not only make savings estimated at more than 40%, but also and most importantly we help consumers and SMEs take action to assert their rights. This European procedure for the settlement of small disputes will have to be successful, and it will have to be properly communicated both at European level, via the e-justice portal, and at national level through awareness campaigns.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the European Parliament's report on the European Small Claims Procedure, which aims to simplify and speed up proceedings in cross-border small-value cases, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises. The Commission has approved a regulation to increase the threshold for litigation from EUR 2 000 to EUR 10 000, which means that the regulation will apply to several undertakings, from the current 20% to 50% of all claims. I believe that the interest in tackling disputes will also be increased by a regulation on reducing the cost of travel, court fees or the translation of documents and forms. I believe that the possible modernisation of court hearings can continue to improve the functioning of the European Small Claims Procedure, but the promotion of the use of information technology remains a priority. I appeal to the Commission to strive to provide the necessary information and to the Member States to cooperate in the campaign. I agree with the changes that will increase the number of disputes and increase savings for businesses and consumers alike.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour on the report on the European small claims procedure and European order for payment procedure, which aims to simplify and speed up cross-border small claims litigation in civil and commercial matters, and cut costs. Regulation (EC) No 861/2007 established a European Small Claims Procedure available to litigants as an alternative to the procedures existing under the laws of the Member States. The Commission proposed a revision of the Regulation in 2014, in order to raise the threshold for its applicability, as well as make it more accessible and more used. The most relevant points which are included in the final agreement are: increasing the threshold to EUR 5 000, with a 5-year review clause in order to see whether a further increase is possible; encouraging the use of long-distance communication and videoconferencing for hearings; a 5-year review clause in order to assess the possibility of including labour claims in the scope of the regulation; court fees should be proportionate to the claim, and assistance for the use of the procedure free of charge.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Regulation (EC) No 861/2007 of the European Parliament and of the Council has proved particularly useful in simplifying, speeding up and reducing the costs of cross-border disputes relating to small claims. I supported the Commission's proposal for a substantial extension of the scope of this Regulation, which seems useful on the basis of experience.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. The Regulation establishes a European procedure for the settlement of small disputes with the aim of simplifying and speeding up its resolution in cross-border cases and reducing its costs. This procedure is supposed to help consumers as well as small and medium-sized enterprises. It can therefore be considered to be a rather positive text, so it can be supported.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Regulation (EC) No 861/2007 of 11 July 2007 establishes the European small claims procedure with the aim of simplifying such actions in cross-border cases, thereby reducing the costs of legal disputes. Access to justice is the main objective, making it a useful procedure to facilitate such access to consumers and small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). The limit on small claims should be revised and court costs should be proportionate to the values of the causes, with the aim of increasing the use of this process in some Member States where small claims are significantly low. Flexible dispute resolution conditions should be provided through distance reporting methods, the abolition of language barriers and transparency of procedures.  I take a favourable position to this proposal, meeting the need to implement a swift and simplified justice, providing consumers and businesses with fair and immediate solutions.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on the European procedure for the settlement of small disputes and the European injunction procedure to be paid aims to amend the regulation (EC) No 861/2007 of the European Parliament and the Council of 11 July 2007 establishing a European small dispute settlement procedure aims to simplify and speed up the resolution of small-scale disputes in cross-border cases and reduce costs in order to help consumers and SMEs to enforce their claims, ensuring access to justice. This system would, for example, allow the French to resolve their cross-border disputes of less than 5,000 euros. I therefore voted in favour of this text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as it is important in terms of securing access to justice more efficiently across the EU. This will not affect the current legal status in the UK, where the threshold for application is higher than the EUR 5 000 set out in the Directive.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the procedures for settling small disputes and injunction to pay at the cross-border level. These procedures are particularly beneficial for SMEs and consumers as they are on average five times faster and allow for a 40% reduction in fees compared to conventional procedures. However, they remain little known and are not being used to their full potential in all Member States. The aim is to strengthen this system by extending its application to disputes of up to 5,000 euros, up from only 2,000 euros previously. More systematic use of new information and communication technologies is also encouraged, in order to further reduce the delays and costs incurred by these procedures.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome this proposal for a regulation which, by establishing a European small claims procedure, aims to simplify and speed up proceedings in cross-border disputes.  The aim is always to help consumers and small and medium-sized enterprises to assert their rights, thereby ensuring access to justice. However, further efforts are needed to improve legal certainty, break down language barriers and promote transparency in proceedings. We are convinced of the need to raise the ceiling for disputes, which can be settled through the European procedure, from the current EUR 2 000 to EUR 10 000 and of the desirability of extending the definition of cross-border dispute, with a consequent extension of the scope of the regulation.  We agree with the rapporteur on the proposal to encourage the use of information technologies in order to reduce their costs. This procedure can only work if consumers, businesses, courts and associations offering advice are duly informed of its existence. It is therefore essential that the Commission continues to provide information on this matter, in particular through the e-Justice portal. It is equally important for The Member States to accompany the Commission's efforts with national awareness-raising campaigns.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Regulation (EC) No 861/2007 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 11 July 2007 establishing a European dispute procedure aims to simplify and speed up proceedings involving small cross-border disputes and reduce their costs. The regulation was designed in particular to help consumers and small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) assert their rights, thereby ensuring access to justice.  The Commission first suggests raising the ceiling for small claims (from the current EUR 2 000 to EUR 10 000) which can be composed through the European procedure; it also proposes to broaden the definition of cross-border dispute, with a consequent extension of the scope of the regulation. In the light of the above, I have chosen to vote in favour of the report because I believe that the amendments proposed by the Commission would further strengthen the procedure.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report that will better regulate the European small claims procedure and raise the threshold for small claims which fall under the European Small Claims Procedure.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which was concerned with raising the thresholds for the value of a claim. Previously, the threshold was set at EUR 2 000. The report provides that this limit would be raised to EUR 5 000 if pursued against a natural person i.e. an individual and EUR 10 000 if pursued against a legal person i.e. a company.  By way of background, the European Small Claims Procedure applies to all claims with a cross-border element. This includes cases where the parties are both domiciled in the same Member State and only the place of performance of the contract, the place where the harmful event takes place or the place of enforcement of the judgment is situated in another Member State. This provides an important remedy for cross-border disputes which in many Member States is woefully lacking at present.  One final positive point is that Legal Assistance can also be provided to parties free of charge, which did not previously exist.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this text as it is indeed needed to speed up cross-border small claims judicial procedures in the EU. A large part of the Union economy relies on trans-border commerce and interaction and therefore it is understandable that litigation will occur. For the actors, knowing that in cases of litigation it takes a long time to solve the matter and the cost might vary greatly between Member States, this could actually be a deterrent from risking cross-border ventures of various kinds. Also, as this affects mostly SMEs, the backbone of a prosperous economy, finally addressing these issues and creating a regulation across all the EU can be very beneficial.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the EP-Council agreement at 1st reading, which significantly improves the current legislation in force since 2009. In my view, this amendment will lead to greater use of the Small Claims Institute, because consumers will no longer be deterned by excessive court fees, which often exceed the amount recovered, and small – and, thanks to the agreed increase to EUR 5 000 – even medium-sized enterprises will not limit the current limit of EUR 2 000, to which many of their cross-border claims cannot fit. I consider small claims proceedings to be an example of useful EU legislation that has been shown to make things easier for citizens and businesses in dispute with the cross-border dimension.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This report looks back at the European procedure for resolving small disputes that has been in place since 2007. This procedure aims to ensure access to justice for any consumer and SMEs wishing to file a claim concerning cross-border disputes. The reform of the procedure would increase the ceiling on small disputes entitled to access to it from 2,000 euros to 10,000 euros, allowing more SMEs to be covered by these guarantees. Also, the reform plans to re-emphasize the term of cross-border litigation by including the possibility for two parties in the same Member State to access this procedure in the event that the dispute in question took place in another territory. I'm a supporter.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The new rules will simplify and speed up the processing of small cross-border litigation and help to reduce court costs. The changes are beneficial for both consumers and businesses.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I support the report tabled.  I believe that uniform procedures must be applied throughout the EU to simplify and speed up cross-border litigation in the EU, while also facilitating the protection of consumer rights. Every citizen must be able to exercise their right of access to justice and seek prompt redress without incurring significant costs.  I support the proposal to increase the maximum amount from the current amount of EUR 2 000 to EUR 10 000. In addition, it is appropriate to include cases in which both parties have their habitual residence or establishment in the same Member State but which cover a different cross-border element.  Time, effort and costs cannot be significantly disproportionate to the size of the claim. It is therefore necessary to simplify and speed up the resolution of such disputes, as well as to reduce costs for individuals or small businesses and to limit the length of the procedure. More frequent use of the European Small Claims Procedure needs to be encouraged.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given that reducing red tape and reducing the time taken for legal proceedings are two of the european Union's major areas of interest, while stressing the importance of adequate information for the parties involved in order to achieve the objective proposed by amending this regulation to simplify and speed up proceedings relating to cross-border disputes, I have chosen to vote in favour.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the European Small Claims Procedure and the European Order for Payment. Simplifying and speeding up procedures for minor cross-border disputes is one of the measures that will facilitate cross-border business cooperation in the European Union and focus on a more single internal market. The measure is particularly useful for small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ At a time when the European Union is facing the biggest economic crisis in its history, improving the efficiency of the judiciary in the European Union has become an important factor in stimulating economic activity. One of the measures to promote the efficiency of the judiciary in the EU is the revision of the Regulation introducing a European Small Claims Procedure. I support the adoption of the Regulation, as it is considered that the problems of inefficient small claims increase in the case of low value claims brought across the borders of EU Member States. In these situations, additional problems arise, because the parties are not familiar with foreign laws and procedures in foreign courts, there is a greater need for interpretation and translation and it is necessary to travel abroad for oral hearings. Due to the increase in cross-border trade in the EU in recent years and the expected further increase in the coming years, there is an even greater need to provide effective remedies mechanisms to support economic activities.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on the European procedure for the settlement of small disputes and the European injunction procedure to be paid aims to amend the Regulation (EC) No 861/2007 of the European Parliament and the Council of 11 July 2007 inst Establishing a European small dispute settlement procedure aims to simplify and speed up the resolution of small-scale disputes in cross-border cases and reduce costs in order to help consumers and SMEs to enforce their claims, ensuring access to justice. This system would, for example, allow the French to resolve their cross-border disputes of less than 5,000 euros. I therefore voted in favour of this text.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The Commission's proposals for amendments concerning the European Small Claims Procedure are welcome given some of the shortcomings and untapped potential of the existing Regulation. The Commission correctly estimates that raising the threshold for expedited procedures to €10,000 could resolve as many as half of cross-border business claims in the EU, instead of the current twenty percent. Easier access to justice would increase trust in cross-border transactions and take full advantage of the opportunities offered by the internal market. I support the rapporteur's proposal for a three-year period following the entry into force of the Regulation, during which Member States would have the time and opportunity to provide such infrastructure. I also support the proposal that each Member State be obliged to provide only one means of distance payment, of its own choosing, and that each Member State independently sets a minimum income threshold below which the party is not obliged to pay court fees. I believe that these proposals improve the technological and legal level of implementation without inducing member states' existing national legislation. It is also of utmost importance to increase consumer and business awareness of the procedure itself, so it would be important to support national campaigns in the Member States and, if possible, to provide practical legal assistance to applicants in the procedure.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The establishment of a European minor dispute procedure should simplify and speed up litigation concerning small claims in cross-border cases, and reduce costs. The procedure is in place and specifically designed to help consumers and SMEs (SMEs) enforce their claims, ensuring access to justice. At the same time, it has proven to be a useful tool, reducing the cost of cross-border minor disputes by up to 40 % and the duration of litigation from two years and five months to an average of five months. Parliament stated in its resolution of 25 October 2011 that 'the use of small claims by courts in some Member States is much lower and still needs to be done in terms of legal certainty, language barrier and transparency of procedures'. A simplified procedure is also available for cross-border applications worth between €2,000 and €10,000, and the proportion of cases eligible for significant cost reductions and the length of litigation has increased. It is therefore of utmost importance to facilitate potential beneficiaries, in particular consumers, with access to the necessary information. I support the rapporteur on raising the threshold for the use of the European Minor Value Dispute Procedure.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Regulation (EC) No 861/2007 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 11 July 2007 establishing a European small claims procedure aims to simplify and speed up proceedings in small cross-border disputes and reduce their costs.  The Commission proposes to raise the ceiling for small claims which can be made up through the European procedure from the current EUR 2 000 to EUR 10 000. The Commission also proposes to extend the definition to disputes in which the parties are domiciled in the same Member State but which have another cross-border element, such as the place of performance of the contract, the place where the harmful event occurred or the execution of the judgment in another Member State.  I believe that the changes proposed by the Commission are a further step towards a better functioning of the small claims procedure. This report is very much in favour of the amendments proposed by the Commission, which is why I have chosen to vote in favour of it.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. Cross-border economic exchanges are very important within the Union, so it is essential to facilitate cross-border legal proceedings. The European Parliament has thus adopted the report approving the European procedure for the settlement of small disputes and the European procedure for an injunction to pay. I voted in favour of this report because these procedures provide many benefits to SMEs and consumers. In particular, they go faster and are less expensive than the traditional cross-border procedure.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal for a Regulation aims to link, as to the form, results, but also to the means, the European small claims procedure and a new European order for payment procedure. Through this regulation, the right throughout the Community area, in the field of cross-border dispute resolution and also of disputes in which there is another cross-border element, is uniform, so that Union citizens can benefit from access to justice, which is more simplified and less expensive. As regards the full development of the Single Market of the European Union, it is also essential that consumers and small and medium-sized enterprises also benefit from a safe, transparent and useful legal regime, and can thus take action without fear of legal costs disproportionate to the amount of the action, or proceedings whose length of proceedings refute trust in the courts and, consequently, in the single market. In order to address the shortcomings in the implementation of the Regulation, five years after its entry into force, amendments are proposed to extend the scope of the procedure, limit court costs, make payment methods more flexible and modernise communication channels. I voted in favour.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this legislative resolution which aims to change the European procedures for settling small disputes and injunction to pay. Behind this obscure title lies a series of very concrete measures that make life easier for citizens and small businesses with cross-border disputes. In the past, citizens or SMEs could find themselves destitute or discouraged in the event of an attempt to recover cross-border debt, not only in the face of the complexity of the procedure but also in the face of the presumed duration and costs of the procedure, especially if the funds to be recovered from third parties located in the other EU country were less than the presumed costs of the procedure... Thanks to simplification, the standardised form, and the judicial cooperation that has been in place for several years, it has become easier to recover these small cross-border claims in the EU, this goes much faster, the procedure costs much less. The numbers are there and show it.  Our proposal today is to further improve the instrument. And if the Council confirms the agreement, the rules will be further simplified, modernised, and will be able to cover more cases, especially for higher amounts.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The adoption of this report has a significant practical effect for European citizens. Wanting to return the amount spent on the purchase of a defective product is not always easy, involving bureaucracy, large expenses and even trips to the country of origin, if this implies a court decision. Often, the injured consumer gives up, because the work and expenses involved in the complaint are not justified. This decision aims to simplify and speed up small claims in cross-border cases, as well as to reduce their expenditure (making them proportionate to the amounts claimed). The main objective is to help consumers and SMEs take their action, thereby ensuring access to justice. The use of small claims to the courts remains low and efforts need to be stepped up with regard to legal certainty, language barriers and transparency of procedures.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. The European small-scale process aims to simplify and speed up small-scale civil and commercial litigation, as well as to reduce costs. This is a reform of particular importance for SMEs, who will be able to use the mechanism to solve their problems at the transnational level faster and with lower costs, but it is also relevant to citizens, on issues such as consumer disputes. Thanks to socialist leadership, this agreement could be closed during the Latvian Presidency, including particularly positive aspects such as, inters, the increase in the threshold to EUR 5 000, with a review clause at 5 years, to discuss the possibility of further increase in the future, as well as the promotion of the use of telecommunications and videoconferences for hearings or free assistance for the use of the procedure. For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on Regulation (EC) 861/2007 of 11 July 2007 establishing a European small dispute settlement procedure which aims to simplify and speed up the resolution of small cross-border disputes, as well as to reduce their costs. This procedure was designed specifically to help consumers and small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) assert their rights, thereby ensuring their access to justice.  A review from five years of implementation indicates that this procedure has demonstrated its usefulness. However, much remains to be done to expand and improve the use of this instrument. The European small dispute settlement procedure has reduced the costs of small cross-border dispute settlement procedures by up to 40% and has reduced their duration from a maximum of two years and five months to an average of five months.  However, in some Member States, the use of small-scale disputes remains rare and more needs to be done in terms of legal certainty, the use of modern technologies and the transparency of procedures.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report intends to amend Regulations (EC) 861/2007 and 1896/2006, since it has been found that the implementation of these instruments, five years after their entry into force, has proved very useful, although it is possible and desirable to extend and strengthen their scope, as the use of small claims in European small claims to the courts remains significantly low, and efforts on legal certainty, language barriers and transparency of procedures need to be stepped up. To that extent, I support this proposal which increases the limit on small claims from €2000 to €10,000, as well as the extension of the definition of what constitutes a cross-border case, and covers elements other than domicile in the Member State, such as the place of execution of the contract or the place where the harmful event occurred. At the level of the procedure, the ideas of equating the means by which notifications are carried out, the use of videoconferencing for hearings, the setting of a ceiling on court costs and the reduction of the length of proceedings are also positive. For all these reasons, I vote in favour of this report.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the measure relating to the European small claims procedure and the European order for payment procedure because I believe that protecting the interests of European citizens is a top priority. The Commission's proposal is to raise the ceiling for small claims and to extend the definition to disputes in which the parties are domiciled in the same Member State but which have another cross-border element.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the European small-group process and the European monitoring process. The report takes over the resolution of transnational cases. The position of the GUE/NGL Group is to ensure access to pass the thresholds of small legal entities. In order to reduce the price of thresholds, we are also in favour of investing in technologies that ensure telematics assistance for economically disadvantaged users.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D)
text: Written. It is important that consumers and small and medium-sized enterprises have a good opportunity to involve cross-border debt. Therefore, in 2009, the EU adopted a small claims procedure that makes it easier for businesses and consumers to recover small amounts across borders, avoiding lengthy litigation and high legal costs. This scheme will, among other things, extend the regulation so that the small claims procedure can be used for amounts as much as EUR 5 000.  All in all, it is a proposal that saves businesses and citizens time and money. That is why we fully support the regulation. Denmark has an exception in this area, but hopefully in December the Danish electorate will decide to change the Danish opt-out to an opt-in system. This will allow Denmark to participate in this Regulation

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal to revise the regulation establishing a European Small Claims Procedure and a European order for payment, as its measures aim to increase consumer confidence when buying products from other EU countries, while at the same time making it easier for small firms to do business across borders. The new legislation is designed to address current shortcomings by more than doubling the amount that can be claimed in the context of claims up to EUR 5 000. The proposal should also significantly make the small claims procedure much cheaper and easier, where it will no longer be necessary to travel in person to another Member State in the case of proceedings. Furthermore, the proposal also calls for greater proportionality of court fees.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it amends the European Regulation in such a way that it is a necessary improvement in establishing a simplified process for claims of less than EUR 10 000. This amendment is an important step forward in improving speed in such processes in the European Union. The report establishes a system of fees which should not exceed the rates set by Member States and the fees must be proportional to the amount demanded; the amendment to the Regulation also removes exceptions. The report includes technical improvements and recognition obligations by Member States, such as the obligation to free practical assistance, all improving the legal certainty of consumers at European level. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 A Commission investigation found that 45% of companies involved in a cross-border dispute do not take legal action because the costs of the proceedings are disproportionate to the value of the application, while 27% are discouraged by the length of the proceedings.  I have therefore decided to give my assent to the proposal for a European small claims procedure because I am in favour of reducing the costs and duration of these procedures. I also believe that raising the ceiling for the use of the European dispute procedure and extending the simplified procedure to cross-border disputes with a value of between EUR 2 000 and EUR 10 000 represent an important improvement for SMEs and consumers. In fact, only 20% of disputes involving companies are worth less than EUR 2 000, while around 30% are between EUR 2 000 and EUR 10 000. If, therefore, the ceiling currently imposed covers only 20% of disputes affecting businesses, with the new threshold at EUR 10 000 this percentage would increase to around 50%.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this as I do not believe the EU has a competency in this area.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report not only to support my Socialist colleagues, but also because I believe in the aims of the report. It will make access to legal aid easier and reduce the burden for the less advantaged in society. It is great to see agreement between Parliament and the Council on this matter.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal. I support the text tabled as approved in the trilogue. A simplified burden of proof and a standard form can make it much easier to recover so-called small claims. I also applaud the Commission's efforts to evaluate the implementation of the proposal after five years, which may show the potential reserves or shortcomings of this measure.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ The European Small Claims Procedure is an important instrument for citizens and businesses by improving access to justice by simplifying legal proceedings for cross-border low-value disputes in civil and commercial disputes and reducing costs. It was established by Regulation 861/2007 and has been in place since 1 January 2009. The agreement applies where at least one of the parties is resident or habitually resides in a Member State other than that of the court se which brought the proceedings.      At the parliamentary session, I voted in favour of amending several elements of Regulation (EC) No 861/2007. The main elements are: increasing the threshold for small claims from €2,000 to €5,000, member states' obligations to ensure proportionate collection of court fees and not exceeding the court fees levied on national simplified litigation, and linking the European Small Claims Procedure and the European Payment Order procedure by allowing the applicant to use the European Small Claims Procedure when objecting to a European payment order.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union is honoured that the European Small Claims Procedure has proven to be a useful tool in the last five years. I am glad that, in small claims cases, the costs of cross-border small claims procedures have been reduced by up to 40% and that its duration, which could amount to up to two years and five months, has been reduced by an average of five months. I think that, despite these positive results, we still have reserves, particularly in terms of extending and strengthening its use. The existing reserves are also confirmed by the Commission, which, on the basis of the investigation, found that 45 % of the companies that are parties to a cross-border dispute do not go to court due to the inadequacy of court costs in relation to the value of the dispute and 27 % of companies do not use the judicial path for too long a trial duration. I therefore supported the resolution because I believe that the changes proposed by the Commission can improve the functioning of the European Small Claims Procedure. I expect that the adopted regulation will further simplify and speed up cross-border procedures, which will ultimately help consumers and small and medium-sized enterprises to recover their claims.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The purpose of a unified European Small Claims Procedure is to speed up, simplify and reduce the costs of small claims litigation containing a cross-border element and to facilitate access to justice. It also facilitates enforcement by abolishing interim recognition and enforcement procedures in Member States other than the State in which the judgment was given. The European Small Claims Procedure leads to the issue of a European enforcement title which is enforceable in the Member States without the need for a declaration of enforceability in each individual State of enforcement. After five years of application of the Regulation, the Commission has made proposals to improve the procedure and facilitate the achievement of the objectives of the Regulation. The Commission thus proposes, inter alia, an increase in the ceiling for the value of small claims from EUR 2 000 to EUR 10 000, an extension of the definition of a cross-border case, a further reduction in the costs and duration of the proceedings and the fixing of a maximum amount of court fees (10 % of the value of the claim). I believe that the European dispute procedure of minor value and the European order for payment procedure are important instruments in European civil procedural law, which facilitate and simplify the settlement of disputes with a cross-border element and ensure access to justice. The amendments proposed by the Commission will further improve and update the functioning of the procedure, which is why I supported the report.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the review of the European small claims procedure and the European order for payment procedure, which will allow European citizens and small businesses to use a simplified EU procedure for the recovery of small claims from other EU countries. This procedure, which has been in place since 2009, already offers a legal remedy that allows those who have bought goods or services worth up to EUR 2 000 in another Member State to recover the amounts due through a standard forms procedure that limits bureaucratic practices, which would otherwise be necessary to resolve a cross-border dispute.  With the review that we have voted on today, the procedure for resolving this type of dispute is further expanded and simplified, on the one hand by raising the ceiling for complaints covered by the procedure to EUR 5 000, on the other hand by lowering costs for citizens, by providing states to provide free assistance in preparing the necessary documents and by encouraging the use of distance communication technology in court. , if necessary.
