The ultimate objective is to increase citizens' confidence in cross-border purchases and business by facilitating the resolution of disputes that may result.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. The report calls for the extension of the small claims and European dunning procedure, which has been in place since 2007, and aims to resolve disputes in low-value cross-border cases more easily and quickly and to reduce costs. In particular, the procedure is intended to help consumers and small and medium-sized enterprises to enforce their demands and ensure access to justice. In its 2011 resolution, Parliament stated that 'the use of small claims courts remains low in some Member States and that more needs to be done in terms of legal certainty, language barriers and procedural transparency'. Among other things, it is proposed to raise the threshold for small claims covered by the European procedure from the current EUR 2000 to EUR 5000. The new threshold is expected to represent a significant improvement for SMEs. The increase in the threshold proposed in the trialogue by Parliament, the Council and the Commission, the improved use of electronic communications and the limitation of court fees, will enable both entrepreneurs and consumers to make savings and save costs. With this in mind, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. – This adjustment is another real aid to small and medium-sized enterprises. They will more easily access their money and also save travel costs. At the same time, the benefits of modern technologies will be practically used in this case, which is another step towards building a digital single market.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I support this report because consumers should be able to make full use of the opportunities offered by the single market and therefore trust should not be limited to them due to a lack of effective legal solutions to disputes with a cross-border element. Improving the European Small Claims Procedure offers consumers an effective remedy, the same way it contributes to the exercise of their rights in practice. Furthermore, raising the threshold by up to EUR 10 000 in particular may benefit SMEs which do not currently wish to bring disputes, as legal proceedings are lengthy or the costs of the dispute are disproportionate to the value of the dispute. Also, easier access to justice increases trust in cross-border transactions and the opportunities offered by the internal market can be fully exploited. Likewise, the European Small Claims Procedure will benefit from technological developments in the area of justice that can remove geographical distances and their consequences, which are the cause of high costs and length of proceedings as a factor discouraging access to justice.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report, intended to improve upon and widen the scope of the European Small Claims Procedure as created by Regulation (EC) No 861/2007. This is important in securing access to justice more efficiently across the EU.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 Regulation (EC) No. 861/2007 as of 11 July 2007, which introduces the European Small Claims Procedure, intends to simplify and speed up the litigation process on low-value cross-border disputes and reduce costs. The Regulation is designed solely as a means of helping consumers and SMEs to enforce their disputes by ensuring access to justice. While the process has proven extremely useful, the scope for its further expansion and development is many. The European Small Claims Procedure has reduced litigation costs in cross-border small claims by up to 40 per cent, and the length of litigation from two years and five months to an average of five months. However, it should be noted that the rate of use of such small claims courts in some Member States remains very low and much more must be done in terms of legal certainty, the use of modern technology and the transparency of judicial processes.  It is precisely because of the success of this procedure so far in the past in terms of cost reduction as well as the duration of the litigation itself that I fully support this report.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal as it facilitates the resolution of small-value disputes, and I also welcome the fact that the proposal respects the principles of subsidiarity and deals only with cross-border disputes.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the European Small Claims Procedure and the European Order for Payment. There is an increasing number of cross-border trade in the European Union, so it is essential that we have fast and adequate mechanisms for resolving small claims. This applies to both individuals and small and medium-sized enterprises. Five years have passed since the european small claims procedure was put into effect, which we have set up as an alternative to the procedures that exist under the laws of the Member States, and I therefore support the improvement of the procedure. The solution goes in the direction of efficient, rapid and inexpensive dispute resolution. The claim threshold for individuals is increased from EUR 2000 to EUR 5000 and for SMEs to EUR 10000. Increasing the threshold will expand the group of people and businesses that will take part in the European Small Claims Procedure, and citizens will be able to resolve their disputes quickly and cheaply.

name: Kay Swinburne (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I was pleased to support this final agreement at the vote today: it will provide support to consumers and SMEs by ensuring they have effective redress in cross-border, small claim situations, and it will simplify the process by reducing burdens in procedures and evidence taking.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Since 2007 the European Small Claims Procedure has been established, aimed at simplifying and speeding up small claims litigation in cross-border cases as well as reducing costs. However, there were points where the regulation could be improved, which the new Commission regulation is now trying to implement. The EP report accepts the new proposals proposed by the Commission as they are considered to assist the whole process. The aim is to protect and help consumers and small and medium-sized enterprises to have easier but less cost access to justice. In particular, by raising the claims threshold from EUR 2000 to EUR 10000 many SMEs will now be able to resort to this procedure. In addition, the proposal for the use of electronic means of communication, as well as the obligation of the courts to use video conferences, teleconferences or other means of distance communication, will help both to reduce the time of completion of a procedure but also to reduce costs, particularly for consumers but also for SMEs. That is why we voted in favour of the report.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 Simplifying court proceedings and increasing the financial limit for actions will help small and medium-sized enterprises .

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The regulations on the introduction of the European Small Claims Procedure and the European Order for Payment Procedure aim to simplify cross-border judicial proceedings within the European Union and to reduce the financial implications of such proceedings. These provisions mainly benefit consumers and SMEs, since the Regulation contains rules that generally facilitate the enforcement of claims before the courts. Experience has shown that the regulation has been well received and its application has reduced the duration of procedures by an average of 40%. In the light of the practice of recent years, this amending proposal seeks to make the rules of the Regulation even more suited to the needs of its users. Significant facilitation is, for example, the modernisation of the rules on electronic delivery or the amendment of the threshold. During the tripartit negotiations on the procedure, a fundamentally favourable compromise was reached and I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 One of the main gains in strengthening the European Union and the single economic market has been the removal of obstacles of any kind to European free trade. In this complex process, multiple problems can arise, giving rise to legal disputes over small amounts. The recovery of such damage may raise additional problems for small producers or small and medium-sized enterprises, which do not have the resources to sue a transnational court. To this end, Regulation (EC) No 1493/1999 should be amended accordingly. Regulation (EC) No 861/2007 has established European procedures for small applications, and Regulation (EC) No 861/2007 should be amended; 1896/2006 established a European order for payment procedure.  These documents needed a review in order to streamline the procedures, which is carried out through this document. Thus, a limit of EUR 5 000 was set for applications by natural persons and EUR 10 000 for legal persons, with the possibility of revision after a period of 5 years; the use of remote media and videoconference for judicial hearings, as well as the inclusion of labour claims in applications and an adjustment of judicial fees in relation to the amount of injury, is encouraged. All these changes are likely to contribute to clear progress in the field.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. The new European cross-border litigation procedure has been voted on this lunchtime. The European procedure for settling small cross-border disputes introduced in 2007 has reduced the costs of legal proceedings by 40% and shortened the duration of these proceedings by more than 80%. In analysing these latest figures, the contribution to consumers is therefore undeniable. But we wanted to improve the system even more so that it would benefit as many citizens as possible; which is not the case at the moment with only 86% of citizens and almost half of the courts that say they have never heard of this procedure

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of amending Regulation (EC) No 861/2007 of the European Parliament and the Council of 11 July 2007 establishing a European Small Claims Procedure and Regulation (EC) No 1896/2006 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 12 December 2006 creating a European order for payment procedure. Importantly, it is to be amended in scope, so that it will apply to civil and commercial matters where the value of a claim is up to EUR 10 000 if pursued against a legal person, or less than EUR 5 000 if pursued against a natural person. Changes will also be made to the procedure, so that [, where the application is dismissed,] the court which ruled on the substance of the claim is to inform the claimant of such dismissal and of the possible means of appealing against the decision taken.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D)
text: In writing. The regulation aims to simplify the lives of citizens. A simplified procedure for resolving cross-border disputes of less than EUR 2,000 has been implemented by the European Commission since 2009. The Odenberg report aims to extend the eligibility of the device to purchases of up to 5,000 euros and to improve it, notably through the use of electronic tools.  It is a proposal that should make life easier for consumers. For example, a citizen of a Member State who buys a product over the Internet in another Member State and receives it in poor condition, will be able to use this procedure if he does not obtain an amicable agreement with the seller, in order to be compensated.  I therefore supported this report, because the development of such simplification procedures, which protect consumers, is a positive act towards our fellow citizens.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I supported a report aimed at providing effective remuneration for consumers and SMEs in cross-border cases, relating to circumstances where at least one of the parties to the dispute is not in the Member State where the court is located, but in another Member State.  In my view, this report achieves a reduction in the burden on taking evidence, and in particular useful for simplifying procedures, I submit a proposal to use a standard application form that should be available on national websites and for those applications to be submitted through a written procedure.  As a way of reducing additional costs, I particularly support the suggestion that oral hearings can also be held through distance communication, and as citizens are often insufficiently versed in such and similar procedures, I support the duty of Member States to provide free and accessible practical assistance in filling out forms.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. Report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 1049/2001 of the European Parliament and of the Council I supported the opening of the European Small Claims Procedure and Regulation (EC) No 1896/2006 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 12 December 2006 establishing a European Order for Payment procedure, as it simplifies and speeds up procedures relating to cross-border small claims and consequently reduces costs. This will make it easier for consumers and SMEs to enforce their claims and to ensure access to justice.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the European small-group process and the European monitoring process. The report takes over the resolution of transnational cases. The position of the GUE/NGL Group is to ensure access to pass the thresholds of small legal entities. In order to reduce the price of thresholds, we are also in favour of investing in technologies that ensure telematics assistance for economically disadvantaged users.

name: Evžen Tošenovský (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I fully support any simplification of business on the European market, especially for SMEs. The level of use of small claims courts, so-called cross-border disputes over claims, has been dealt with only sporadically or not at all by small businesses in the past. This was due to high costs, a language barrier and extremely complex access to courts in another Member State. I am glad that many of these barriers will be removed in the future.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome this step forward in order to ameliorate the functioning of the single market. Ensuring that small cross-border claims can be easily paid is important to enhance cross-border economic movements at small scale.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The European Parliament and Council Regulation of 11 July 2007 establishing a European procedure for the settlement of small disputes aims to simplify and speed up the resolution of small disputes in cross-border cases and to reduce their costs. It was designed specifically to help consumers and small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) make their claims, thereby ensuring access to justice.  However, few people are aware of this procedure, which needs to be corrected. This system is set to survive in the European Union. I voted for it.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the European small-group process and the European monitoring process. The report takes over the resolution of transnational cases. The position of the GUE/NGL Group is to ensure access to pass the thresholds of small legal entities. In order to reduce the price of thresholds, we are also in favour of investing in technologies that ensure telematics assistance for economically disadvantaged users.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: in writing. – The proposal will have a positive impact on citizens undertaking cross-border businesses and is particularly designed to support SMEs by facilitating the litigation procedure and by reducing costs and administrative burdens, with the objective of boosting cross-border business activities EU-wide.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report at first reading, agreed with the Council, which aims at boosting Europe’s economy by setting an appropriate legal framework that will boost cross-border business activities EU-wide. The idea behind it is to encourage SMEs to undertake cross-border business, as the provisions contained in the text have the objective, among other things, to facilitate the litigation procedure. This procedure would now be available for more cases and the proposal also aims at ensuring that court fees are proportionate. The use of distance communication technology in court cases would be encouraged and practical assistance would be more easily and readily available.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. Although the 2007 European Regulation established the European small-term process, after its five years of implementation this report aims to incorporate into that process elements of improvement relating to the use of new technologies, as well as the transparency of processes. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in favour of that report.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it amends the European Regulation in such a way that it is a necessary improvement in establishing a simplified process for claims of less than EUR 10 000. This amendment is an important step forward in improving speed in such processes in the European Union. The report establishes a system of fees which should not exceed the rates set by Member States and the fees must be proportional to the amount demanded; the amendment to the Regulation also removes exceptions. The report includes technical improvements and recognition obligations by Member States, such as the obligation to free practical assistance, all improving consumer legal certainty at European level. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I was happy to vote in favour of this. The legislation for small claims needed to be updated for the 21st Century by raising the amount that may be considered a small claim towards the higher British threshold and encouraging the use of long distance communication. This legislation takes us towards a more efficient and harmonious transnational system for dealing with small claims. Furthermore a 5-year review clause has been brought forward to look at making the court more accessible, by making charges proportionate to the claim being sought and free-of-charge assistance for the use of the procedure. There will also be a review about bringing labour matters within the purview of the court. These are all positive developments towards greater access to justice across Europe that I fully support.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report amends Regulations (EC) 861/2007 and (EC) No 1896/2006 of the European Parliament and the Council and establishes a European procedure for small claims. It establishes a European order for payment procedure applicable to disputed and uncontested civil and commercial claims the value of which does not exceed EUR 2 000. Those regulations also ensured that the decisions given in the context of this procedure were enforceable without intermediate procedures, in particular without the need for a declaration of enforceability in the executing Member State. The general objective of these regulations was to improve access to justice by reducing costs and speeding up civil proceedings relating to applications falling within their scope for both consumers and businesses. We have, however, reservations about the possibility of being able to deal with matters of the scope of labour law, since in Portugal we have the Labor Courts that judge these matters.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. It is a good proposal to increase the threshold for small claims covered by the European Small Claims Procedure from the current EUR 2 000 to EUR 10 000. This will be a significant improvement for SMEs. We must therefore support this report.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I agree with this resolution because the result of the trialogue negotiations is in our sense: less bureaucracy and simpler procedures in EU trade. An evaluation will take place in five years' time. Then we will see whether this decision on dunning procedures made sense or whether it needs to be further improved.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 861/2007 of the European Parliament and the Council of 11 July 2007 establishing a European small claims procedure and Regulation (EC) No 1896/2006 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 12 December 2006 creating a European order for payment procedure. According to the research conducted in this field, it seems that the already established European small claims procedure has influenced the Member States positively by reducing the costs of litigation in cross-border cases by as much as 40%, and also reducing the duration of legal disputes from around three years to a five-month period. That is a huge success. However, it seems that not all of the EU Member States use the small claims tribunals, and this has led to situations where more needs to be done when it comes to legal certainty and transparency of proceedings. The amendments to the regulations will hopefully help to stimulate better small claims litigation between the EU Member States and to reduce the costs of it.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 This proposal is linked to small claims procedures up to EUR 5 000 in civil and commercial cases of a cross-border nature. It aims to ensure effective, rapid redress by consumers and small and medium-sized enterprises in cross-border situations, i.e. where at least one of the parties resides in a Member State other than the Member State in which it is established. Until now, it has often been unprofitable to pursue claims up to EUR 5000 due to excessive costs. This created opportunities for frequent fraud without penalty. The proposed simplified procedure reduces the burden on the collection of evidence allowing the parties to be heard by videoconference or teleconference, as well as includes methods of court fees, procedures for accessing judicial decisions and assistance to the parties. I voted in favour of the report.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the European Small Claims Procedure and the European Order for Payment procedure. The new proposal rightly aims to simplify and speed up small claims litigation in cross-border cases and to reduce costs. It is indicative that at present 45% of undertakings involved in cross-border disputes do not go to court, because the cost of the proceedings is disproportionate to the value of the dispute, while 27% do not go to court because the procedure would be too time-consuming.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The purpose of this report is to amend Regulations (EC) No 861/2007 1896/2006 of the European Parliament and the Council establishing a European procedure for small claims and establishing a European order for payment procedure, applicable to disputed and uncontested civil and commercial claims whose value does not exceed EUR 2 000. These regulations were intended to improve access to justice by reducing costs and speeding up civil proceedings relating to applications falling within their scope for both consumers and businesses. The changes now introduced, among other things, increase the maximum value concerned to EUR 5000, extending the scope for the concept of matrimonial property regimes and maintenance obligations. We believe that these measures can facilitate the feasibility of such cross-border legal proceedings by improving access to and speed of justice.

name: Monica Macovei (PPE).
text: – Mr President, air pollution remains the main environmental factor causing disease in the European Union. We have medium combustion plants that are used for the production of electricity, heating and cooling in the domestic sector, heat supply for industrial processes and are an important source of emissions of sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxides and particulate matter. We have around 150 000 such installations in the European Union that are not subject to environmental legislation.  The report that I voted on today brings all these procedures up to the standards that we have adopted in the European Union and no longer leaves them out, so as to prevent them from continuing to pollute the air we breathe and practically reduce the cause of diseases to those living in these conditions.  The Commission shall also assess minimum energy efficient standards for environmental combustion plants by 31 December 2016 in accordance with the available techniques.

name: Peter Jahr (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I voted in favour of the report, but there are two souls beating in my chest. I would say: 'I hear the message, I alone lack faith', but I would also ask my colleagues in the relevant technical committee in advance to follow up and monitor things so that the things that are in the report actually happen. I voted in favour on the basis of two facts: it is explicitly stated that the proposed amendment should improve the chances of a realistic implementation of the directive, so that it can become an important instrument for improving air quality in the European Union without imposing unjustified burdens on society and the economy. And it should also be a contribution to the de-bureaucratisation, which is also stated elsewhere. If that happens, that is fine, if not, then we will have to make improvements again. So again, i would like to make an appeal to the relevant colleagues in the technical committee: please observe the further handling of this story, so that we also appreciate and realise what is in the report.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur Nowadays, human life is largely unimaginable without electricity, without heating, without other benefits, without which neither society nor economic models in developed countries can function. It is also sufficiently obvious, however, that, in parallel with the benefits, sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxide and dust emissions are emitted in the course of these processes.  And the problem is that, up to now, there were actually two directives in the European Union that are relevant to this issue: the so-called Ecodesign Directive and the large combustion plants, the so-called Industrial Emissions Directive.  In order to make it possible to differentiate more effectively between the different combustion plants and to prevent these two directives from overlapping legally, I fully support the idea of creating a third directive, that is to say, on medium-sized combustion plants, but in parallel with the creation of a new directive, colleagues, must not allow excessive administrative burdens. Thank you!

name: Neena Gill (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I voted in favour of the Grzyb report, given that it is key to the EU’s clean air package and will reduce harmful emissions and improve air quality across the UK and the EU. Recent research shows that the death toll from air pollution in the UK is much higher than the 30 000 deaths previously estimated. In the whole of Europe, 500 000 people die prematurely as a result of air pollution every year. This places a huge burden on our societies. In this context, I also want to say a couple of words about the Volkswagen diesel emission scam, which is simply outrageous, precisely because of the detrimental impact on people’s health. To end this situation, in which our citizens are paying with their lives for the criminal behaviour of large corporates that seek profits at any price, we need the Commission to establish an independent EU type-approval authority. Volkswagen has made it clear that the current system in which car makers pay national testing organisations and choose themselves where they have their models tested simply is not working.

name: Tim Aker (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, I voted against this and will vote against every single piece of environmental and energy legislation coming out of the European Union, because it kills jobs. Let us go back to the Large Combustion Plant Directive: hundreds of jobs were lost in Tilbury. And look at the Redcar plant: jobs lost last week. When will you stop this constant stream of legislation that is costing skilled jobs? What do you expect people to do when they lose their jobs in skilled industry – to go and work in Poundland? It is a disgrace. Anyone who voted for this legislation and anyone who votes for other legislation like it should explain to the people who have lost their jobs why they are in this position and why they did it.  Instead of posturing and trying to appease your own consciences, look at the fact that you are creating a trail of misery in British communities where there used to be heavy industry and now there is not. So one lesson that I want to leave with you all is that you have created mass unemployment by pushing forward this legislation that kills jobs and kills British industry.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I will only comment in brief on this point. I supported this proposal, but I was quite ambivalent in my position. I think that the European Union should first get its act together in the area of air protection, the environment, which is very much affecting us today. And that is precisely the Volkswagen case and the manipulation of emissions. I think that we should only do this further work if we know how the standards of European air pollution law are actually being respected in the existing legislation.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Today UKIP voted against the Grzyb report on limitation of emissions of certain pollutants into the air. This vote concerned the drafting of new EU legislation intended to regulate medium combustion plants in Europe. There are approximately 150 000 medium combustion plants in Europe and they are used for a wide variety of applications (including electricity generation, domestic/residential heating and cooling and providing heat/steam for industrial processes).  We in UKIP believe in the importance of improving air quality in Europe. We oppose the EU Commission’s proposal to draft new EU legislation in this field. Therefore we oppose a new EU directive which, covering all medium combustion plants, would impose unjustified burdens on our industry and economy. We do not believe this is a matter that should be regulated by the unelected EU Commission.  We also oppose the establishment of a mandatory EU registration scheme to be applied to all new plants. Nonetheless, today we supported all exceptions to the application of the directive proposed by the rapporteur in order to alleviate the impact of this over-prescriptive regulation.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Air pollution is a serious problem affecting every EU state. It is estimated that due to poor air quality in Europe there are 400 000 premature deaths every year. The Commission's intention to limit emissions of pollutants into the air was probably seen as a declaration of war by the industry's lobbies, as the changes made have made the original text meaningless. Legislation of this kind cannot be a down-to-the-bottom compromise. Thus, the final text is not acceptable for a number of reasons, in particular: it does put a ceiling on emissions but, being very high, it almost authorises plants to pollute; it lengthens implementation times and excludes from the list very dangerous substances such as mercury, dioxins and furan; It also provides for the exclusion of certain installations from the scope of the directive. For these reasons, although the proposal is designed to fill a legislative gap concerning medium combustion plants, my vote was against: the health of citizens is too important.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it eliminates the exemptions established by the European Commission as regards the emission limits of pollutants in the ultra-peripheral regions of the European Union. These exemptions initially established by the European Commission are in a position to justify in the relative isolation of European energy networks, giving greater scope to power plants located in these territories in order to further pollute the air. The report understands that these exemptions can only worsen the quality of breathed air in many urban centres in the aforementioned regions such as the Canary Islands in Spain. That is why I have decided to support this report.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 This report, which is the result of months of negotiations between the European Parliament, the European Commission and the Council, aims to reduce emissions of certain pollutants from medium-sized combustion plants.  The new legislation will make a significant contribution to improving air quality, particularly in environmentally burdened areas. At the same time, we have succeeded in extending the adjustment period for power plants located on the small islands which are not connected to the continental network as an immediate and full implementation of the Directive would jeopardise the production of electricity in the majority of our islands.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. With a rated thermal power of between 1 and 50 MW, medium combustion plants are used in a wide range of applications and are located between small facilities under the Ecodesign Directive (2009/125/EC) and large combustion plants governed by the Industrial Emissions Directive (2010/75/EU).  The report aims to make a contribution to reducing pollution of nitrogen oxide, sulphur dioxide and dust. Of course, these regulatory changes are the responsibility of the Member States and weigh heavily on the industry. For example, states are forced to apply a stricter emission limit in areas that do not comply with the European air quality standard. They must also maintain a public record of the registration date of combustion facilities and register or license an existing facility, at least one year before the compliance date.  This text is in line with these anti-industry norms under the guise of a risky ecological and public health benefit.  Together with my colleagues on the National Front, we consider this to be at odds with national and European interests. So I voted against this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I recognise the importance of improvements in air quality. However, I take issue specifically with the proposed mandatory EU registration scheme which puts power in the hands of the European Union – power which could and should be exercised by nation-states. Equally, the block vote on Amendments 1 to 86 is a matter of some concern to me; block votes on matters impacting on legislation are inappropriate in my view. I therefore voted against.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation because it sets limits for sulphur dioxide and nitrogen oxide emissions from medium combustion plants, such as electricity generators or heating systems for domestic or industrial use.

name: Guillaume Balas (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the Gryzb report because it allows for a limit on the emission of certain pollutants into the atmosphere. The scope has been broadened with the addition of carbon monoxide, and stricter limits have been introduced in areas where air quality does not meet European criteria.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal on the limitation of emissions of certain pollutants into the air. The proposal contains provisions for medium combustion plants. It aims to contribute to the reduction of NOx, SO2 and dust pollution by setting limit values for new and existing installations, as well as by introducing a simple registration system to facilitate the implementation of a significant proportion of Member States' emission reduction obligations.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Today UKIP voted against the Grzyb report on limitation of emissions of certain pollutants into the air. This vote concerned the drafting of new EU legislation intended to regulate medium combustion plants in Europe. There are approximately 150 000 medium combustion plants in Europe and they are used for a wide variety of applications (including electricity generation, domestic/residential heating and cooling and providing heat/steam for industrial processes).  We in UKIP believe in the importance of improving air quality in Europe. We oppose the EU Commission’s proposal to draft new EU legislation in this field. Therefore we oppose a new EU directive which, covering all medium combustion plants, would impose unjustified burdens on our industry and economy. We do not believe this is a matter that should be regulated by the unelected EU Commission. We also oppose the establishment of a mandatory EU registration scheme to be applied to all new plants.  Nonetheless, today we supported all exceptions to the application of the directive proposed by the rapporteur in order to alleviate the impact of this over-prescriptive regulation.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report on a draft directive to limit the emissions of certain pollutants into the atmosphere: this directive risks, first and foremost, seriously harming our industries, which are already severely penalised by unfair competition encouraged by the ultra-liberal Eurocrats in Brussels. These are still good intentions that pave the Hell of Brussels...

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. There are around 150,000 medium combustion plants in the EU which are a major source of emissions of sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxides and dust. While large combustion plants are governed by an ad hoc directive, emissions of air pollutants from medium-burning facilities are not. A proposed directive aims to regulate emissions from these medium-sized facilities with the aim of reducing pollution for new and existing facilities and effectively applying standards through a registration system. The report, which I have approved, supports the committee's proposal but clarifies the application of the new directive in relation to the existing acquis, particularly in the area of industrial emissions.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report and the first-reading agreement on the Directive on the limitation of emissions into the atmosphere of certain pollutants. I would like to thank Parliament's negotiating team for their efforts to ensure that the exclusion of outermost areas, including the Canary Islands, is incorporated into the text. This does not mean that these regions will not implement that directive, but will do so in due course and with the agreement of the regional authorities, taking into account the difficulty they face in being located in remote places.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on limiting the emissions of certain pollutants into the atmosphere must occupy a certain legislative vacuum concerning medium fuel installations used for example in electricity generation, heating, heating, heat production for industrial purposes... It must also contribute to the reduction of pollution in nitrogen oxide (NOx), sulphur dioxide (SO2) and dust. Nevertheless, it is clear that these requested changes are the responsibility of the Member States and weigh on the industry. Thus, there is an obligation to apply a stricter emission limit in areas that do not comply with the European air quality standard, to keep a publicly available register with information on the registration date of medium combustion facilities or the date on which the permit will be granted, or to register or grant a permit to an existing facility at least one year before the compliance date. This text, by these binding demands and whose ecological or health effects seem risky, is at odds with the european general interest and the national interest and will cost the industry. So I voted against it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report sets out the rules for controlling emissions of sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxides and dust from medium combustion plants into the air, as well as monitoring carbon monoxide emissions. The text is acceptable and does not present any critical issues, so I voted in favour of it.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. The approximately 150,000 medium combustion plants in the EU are an important source of emission of sulfide dioxide, nitrogen oxide and suspended particles, with serious consequences for human health and the environment. This Directive aims at monitoring and reducing emissions of sulphur, nitrogen and particulate matter in suspension. The agreement reached with the Council sets a maximum limit on emissions of sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxide and suspended particulate matter from current combustion plants with thermal production above 5 MW, which will enter into force from 2025. Smaller installations, with thermal production of 1 to 5 MW, mostly used by SMEs, will have to meet emission limits from 2030. Legislation does not prevent Member States from tightening the standards required by the Directive.  The agreement reached with the Council is good in order to continue improving the air quality we breathe in Europe and that is why I have supported it favourably with my vote.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report, which examines the Commission proposal for a directive on the limitation of emissions of certain pollutants into the air from medium combustion plants. This proposal is part of the European Union's air quality action programme set out in the revised EU thematic strategy on air pollution and is in line with and supports the Europe 2020 objectives for smart, inclusive and sustainable growth. It aims to protect the interests of small and medium-sized enterprises in accordance with the 'think small first' principle.  In order to avoid significant impact on small and medium-sized enterprises operating most medium combustion plants, less stringent measures have been considered, such as the provision that operators do not need authorisation but should notify the competent authorities of the operation of the installation, thereby ensuring registration. In addition, progress towards the long-term (post-2020) The EU's objective of further reducing the health and environmental impact of air pollution has been assessed by assessing the various policy options for finding a cost-effective toolkit. Additional EU pollution source control measures were examined, one of which was aimed at medium-sized emissions from combustion plants.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. The area of control of emissions from medium combustion plants has so far been left to the legislators in the Member States. Slovenia has already adopted appropriate and fairly strict regulation in this area. I consider it appropriate to adopt similar rules for all Member States also by introducing a European directive. In addition to regulating emissions, more effort could also be put into developing and subsidising district heating systems based on medium-power combustion plants. Such systems, such as biomass boilers, can make a significant contribution to cleaner air, as it is precisely because of the limited emissions that they are inappropriately cleaner and health-friendly compared to private and small combustion plants. The main reason for accepting the proposed directive, of course, is the aspiration for a cleaner environment and, therefore, the health and well-being of all European citizens. I therefore support the proposed report.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 To date, some 150 000 medium combustion plants (between 1 and 50 Mega Watts) in Europe, including those dedicated to electricity generation, domestic heating and cooling and the production of vapors for industrial processes, did not have a clear legal framework.  With the text of an agreement reached with the Council, the EU has committed itself to implementing a regulation that will significantly reduce harmful emissions into the atmosphere, in particular sulphur dioxide (SO2), nitrogen oxide (NOx) and other dusts. The new directive introduces a monitoring system for carbon monoxide (CO) capable of identifying its limit values and a registration system to ensure compliance with its obligations. Air pollution is a key issue for the protection of the health of European citizens, and today's vote shows a concrete commitment by the EU to address it.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe it is important for the EU to regulate emissions of NOx, SO2 and dust. It is essential, in the context of the fight against climate change that we have undertaken, that the European legislator should take care to limit emissions of these pollutants while avoiding double regulation and excessive administrative burdens, in order to combine environmental protection with the needs of businesses and citizens.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The quality of our health and the containment of climate change depend on the fight against air pollution. There are approximately 150 000 medium-sized combustion plants (thermal power between 1 and 50 MW) in the EU which are used for heating, electricity generation or industrial purposes.  However, the EU regulation on pollutant emissions from combustion plants involves plants of more than 50 MW and small domestic installations (less than 1 MW), but there is no legislation to encourage producers to design medium-power plants environmentally friendly. It is necessary to fill the regulatory gap and avoid breaches of member states' obligations to reduce air pollutant emissions, rationalising and harmonising sector discipline with the establishment of a system for recording installations and setting equal emission limit values throughout Europe in order to protect the health of citizens and avoid unjustified burdens on companies producing the plant and thermal sector.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. The aim of this text is to fill the legal void surrounding emissions of certain pollutants into the atmosphere from medium-burning facilities. They are used in electricity generation, heating, heat production or steam for industrial purposes and have a rated thermal power of between 1 and 50 MW. In order to reduce emissions of nitrogen oxide and sulphur dioxide, the report obliges Member States to set a stricter emission limit. It also requires them to keep a register that citizens will be able to consult, including the registration dates for medium combustion facilities. The Commission often touts the merits of green growth, i.e. increased production that would preserve the environment. If the objective is laudable, we regret that their policy is limited to a green tax system that will strengthen the unfair competition we face. Let them start by combating the savage globalization that has caused a sharp increase in CO2 emissions, before imposing unnecessary new regulations. So I voted against it.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 According to the Commission's impact study, air pollution leads to more than 400 000 premature deaths per year and medical costs of up to EUR 940 billion. It also contributes to significant environmental degradation, with 62% of the EU area exposed to eutrophication and economic damage, such as EUR 15 billion of lost working days, EUR 4 billion in medical costs, EUR 3 billion in crop losses and EUR 1 billion damage to buildings.  This proposal for a directive is welcome in the context that reducing emissions from medium-burning plants could contribute to the achievement of EU targets in areas such as climate and energy, reduce greenhouse emissions, while improving energy efficiency and promoting renewable energies. I voted in favour of the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on limiting emissions into the atmosphere of certain pollutants from medium combustion plants because I believe that, by acting now and covering the current legislative gap, well-defined signals can be drawn with regard to investment and stimulating the field of research and innovation in revolutionary technologies.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Positive vote. Useful and sensible legislation.

name: Cristian-Silviu Bușoi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Air pollution remains a real cross-border problem, as many Member States import a considerable part of their air pollution from neighbouring countries. There is currently no EU-wide regulation of the level of air pollutant emissions from average combustion plants (installations with a rated thermal power of between 1 and 50 MW). I support the adoption of measures at EU level to establish a coherent and ambitious regulatory framework and to address emissions of pollutants effectively.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. We must do everything possible to significantly improve air quality. This requires the introduction of limitations on certain pollutants in order to achieve the defined ecological objectives. It is essential that these limitations are ambitious and just as important as they are in line with the Union's objectives of competitiveness and economic recovery. To do this, SMEs need some time to adapt so as not to jeopardize the way their activities are run out. This legislation regulates emissions of pollutants from medium-sized combustion facilities. I voted for this report, which combines ecological protection and economic realism.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 After careful debate and debate in this House, I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the limitation of emissions into the atmosphere of certain pollutants from medium combustion plants, Because I believe that this proposal for a directive is aimed first and foremost at filling an important gap in current EU legislation, given that, as you know, there are no specific regulations at EU level with regard to emissions of air pollutants from medium-sized combustion plants. I regret the time lost so far, when I think of the number of installations present (150 000) and when we consider that they are used for fundamental applications (electricity and for domestic/residential use). I agree with the considerations that 'air quality in many parts of the Union continues to not comply with the limits set by the Union itself and the objectives set by the World Health Organisation' and 'the Commission should assess, within a reasonable period of time, the need to amend the emission limit values set out in Annex II on the basis of the most advanced technologies'.  I agree with the need to set emission limit values, but I remain of the opinion that they must still be based on proportionality and practicability criteria.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The aim of this legislation is to fill the regulatory gap which exists between small combustion plants (covered by the ecodesign directive) and large combustion plants (covered by the large combustion plant directive). Therefore, the aim is to cover the emissions of air pollutants from medium combustion plants that are not regulated at EU level, while small combustion plants can be covered by ecodesign directive, and large combustion plants by the industrial emissions directive (IED). It was for these reasons that I voted in favour of this proposed directive.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Today UKIP voted against the Grzyb report on limitation of emissions of certain pollutants into the air. This vote concerned the drafting of new EU legislation intended to regulate medium combustion plants in Europe. There are approximately 150 000 medium combustion plants in Europe and they are used for a wide variety of applications (including electricity generation, domestic/residential heating and cooling and providing heat/steam for industrial processes). We in UKIP believe in the importance of improving air quality in Europe: we oppose the Commission’s proposal to draft new EU legislation in this field. Therefore we oppose a new EU directive which, covering all medium combustion plants, would impose unjustified burdens on our industry and economy. We do not believe this is a matter that should be regulated by the unelected EU Commission. We also oppose the establishment of a mandatory EU registration scheme to be applied to all new plants. Nonetheless, today we supported all exceptions to the application of the directive proposed by the rapporteur in order to alleviate the impact of this over-prescriptive regulation.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as air pollution continues to be a significant problem in most of the Member States despite numerous European and international agreements. The proposed amendments seek, among other things, to better classify combustion plants, avoid double regulation and modify emission limits in order to lower air pollution levels.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 According to the European Commission's impact assessment, air pollution is estimated to cause more than 400 000 premature deaths each year and involving health costs of up to EUR 940 billion. It also contributes to serious environmental degradation, with 62% of the EU's territory exposed to acidification. In addition, reducing emissions from medium combustion plants contributes to the reduction of greenhouse gases, the improvement of energy efficiency and the promotion of renewable energies. The World Health Organisation and the OECD have jointly estimated that the annual economic cost of the health impact of air pollution amounts to more than EUR 1.4 trillion for the whole of Europe.  Our M5S Europe delegation cannot support the European Commission's proposal because of its lack of ambition to reduce emission limit values and because it has not included highly toxic pollutants such as mercury and dioxins and furans in the emissions calculation proposed by us. In the light of the above, we voted against.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (ENF)
text: In writing. The aim of this text is to fill a certain legislative vacuum, and to make a contribution to the reduction of pollution in nitrogen oxide, sulphur dioxide and dust. The regulatory amendments are the responsibility of the Member States and weigh on the industry, because it is an obligation for Member States to apply a stricter emission limit in areas that do not comply with the European air quality standard, to establish enhanced provisions on the level of emissions attainable for new technologies, to register or grant a permit to an existing facility at least one year before the compliance date. By Community standards introduced by the Commission, by anti-industry provisions for ecological benefit, this text is at odds with the national interest and the european general interest. So I voted against it.

name: Nessa Childers (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am pleased that my colleagues joined me in voting in favour of imposing emission limits of sulphur dioxide (SO2) and nitrogen oxide (NOx) from medium-sized combustion plants. This vote will bring the closing of a legal gap by setting standards for medium-sized combustion plants operating with a thermal input between 1 and 50 MW. Once officially approved by the EU Council of Member State ministers, the limits will be effective within three years for new plants, with gradual adaptation deadlines for existing ones. This is a very important step to improve air quality for the sake of human health and the environment. Although many of us would like to see stronger provisions in place, the directive allows Member States to enforce stricter emissions values, which countries will have to consider for areas where EU air quality standards are not met. The review clause contained in the directive should lead to increased reductions in emissions in the near future. Nitrogen oxide emissions, which are at the heart of the current Volkswagen emissions scandal, cause serious respiratory complications and are responsible for premature death. Innovation and sustainability go hand-in-hand with proper regulation. Energy efficiency stands to win from this move.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Air quality is certainly a central issue in EU climate policy. Unfortunately, more than 400 000 deaths are caused by environmental pollution every year. Despite the extensive European legislation on emissions of air pollutants, there is still a legislative gap on medium combustion plants, i.e. those with a nominal thermal power of between 1 and 50 Megawatts, which are the most numerous because they are used for a wide range of purposes (electricity production, heating and cooling of our homes just to name a few examples) and unfortunately they are also the main source of sulphur dioxide emissions. , nitrogen oxides and fine dusts which seriously harm human health. After a long work by parliament's Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Policy, an ambitious agreement has finally been reached with the Council, including the introduction of strict emission limit values to be complied with by operators and an obligation on Member States to keep a register available to the public with information on installations and changes. I am satisfied with the content of the directive because, together with the complex body of legislation, it helps to make the EU's climate policy even more credible. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 This is the draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council to limit emissions of certain pollutants into the atmosphere from medium-sized combustion plants. It is recognised that in recent years emissions of pollutants into the atmosphere have decreased significantly, but that at the same time air pollution levels remain problematic in many parts of Europe and citizens continue to be exposed to air pollution that may endanger their health and well-being.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this measure on limiting emissions of certain pollutants into the atmosphere. There are around 150 000 medium combustion plants (thermal power between 1 and 50 MW) in the EU, used for a wide range of applications (including electricity generation or domestic heating/cooling), producing emissions of pollutants such as sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxides and dust. Medium-sized plants are the only ones that have not yet been regulated at European level. The Commission's proposal aims to significantly reduce pollution by NOx, SO2 and dust by setting limit values and setting up a registration system, in order to make a substantial contribution to compliance with Member States' emission reduction obligations.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because emissions of air pollutants from combustion plants are generally not regulated at European level. The Commission's proposal therefore lays down long-term provisions for these plants. Furthermore, the report, with the various amendments, has been designed to reduce pollution in an indicative way by setting limit values for new and existing plants, together with a simple registration system, in order to help provide a significant part of the emission reduction obligations and to avoid possible compromises between air quality and the increase in biomass. Finally, the emission limit values have been modified in accordance with the laws in force and the principle of cost efficiency will be introduced, with a new distinction between categories of installations according to their nominal thermal power. One of the Main Objectives of the European Union is to safeguard the lives and health of its citizens, starting with the protection of air quality.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Today UKIP voted against the Grzyb report on limitation of emissions of certain pollutants into the air. This vote concerned the drafting of new EU legislation intended to regulate medium combustion plants in Europe. There are approximately 150 000 medium combustion plants in Europe and they are used for a wide variety of applications (including electricity generation, domestic/residential heating and cooling and providing heat/steam for industrial processes).  We in UKIP believe in the importance of improving air quality in Europe. We oppose the EU Commission’s proposal to draft new EU legislation in this field. Therefore we oppose a new EU directive which, covering all medium combustion plants, would impose unjustified burdens on our industry and economy. We do not believe this is a matter that should be regulated by the unelected EU Commission. We also oppose the establishment of a mandatory EU registration scheme to be applied to all new plants.  Nonetheless, today we supported all exceptions to the application of the directive proposed by the rapporteur in order to alleviate the impact of this over-prescriptive regulation.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the proposal for a directive put forward by the European Commission and the Council on the limitation of pollutants in the atmosphere by medium combustion plants.  Although European legislation regulates emissions from small and large plants, there is no regulation for medium-sized plants. The aim of the proposal for a directive is to reduce pollution and dust by setting maximum values for existing and new average installations. In addition, provision is made for the establishment of a system for registering installations to be applied within The Member States that does not involve excessive administrative burdens for companies, for example by avoiding double regulation of emissions and instead creating a simple and coherent regulatory environment.  I voted in favour of this report because this directive would be an important instrument for improving environmental conditions, quality of life, health costs and European development in the context of climate and energy challenges. However, there must be a balance between the costs borne by companies for monitoring emissions and the benefits to the environment and health. Only by adopting proportionate and practicable parameters can the cross-border problem of air pollution be tackled effectively.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Air pollution has caused and continues to cause irreversible damage to environmental and human health across Europe. The WHO estimated it at a cost of 1.4 trillion, equivalent to one tenth of the EU's GDP in 2013.  In particular, medium combustion plants (MCAs) contribute significantly to poor air quality as sources of emissions of sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxides and particulate matter. As these plants have not been regulated at EU level, the Commission has proposed to take measures against the emission of air pollutants from combustion plants with a nominal thermal power of between 1 and 50 MW.  Defining the emission limit value (VLE) means not only trying to solve the root problem, but also contributing to the creation of new jobs through possible competitiveness on the part of the companies concerned. I am voting against this because the project appears to be une ambitious in view of the existing technological innovations that could tackle the root of the problem more effectively. Furthermore, I do not think it is right to exclude certain plants from the scope of the directive, such as devices for converting hydrogen sulfide into sulphur.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it eliminates the exemptions established by the European Commission as regards the emission limits of pollutants in the ultra-peripheral regions of the European Union. These exemptions initially established by the European Commission are in a position to justify in the relative isolation of European energy networks, giving greater scope to power plants located in these territories in order to further pollute the air. The report understands that these exemptions can only worsen the quality of breathed air in many urban centres in the aforementioned regions such as the Canary Islands in Spain. That is why I have decided to support this report.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Although emissions of pollutants from combustion in medium-sized plants contribute increasingly to pollution, these emissions were not regulated comprehensively by European legislation. I therefore voted in favour of this report because it serves to fill a serious legislative vacuum. In addition, the directive will promote the improvement of air quality, promote energy efficiency and the modernisation of industrial plants, thereby reducing the negative impact on human health and improving the quality of the environment.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Air pollution does not take into account borders, which is why it is important to consciously limit emissions within the framework of EU law. The new proposal for a directive is in order to fill a gap in EU law, as there are currently no specific provisions for emissions from medium combustion plants. Emissions from such combustion plants have a significant negative impact on health and damage the environment, not least economic damage. Parliament's report states that the new legislation will not impose excessive administrative burdens on small and medium-sized enterprises. It is well that the majority of medium combustion plants are operated by SMEs. Against this reason, it is appropriate to improve the legal regulatory framework, which is why I voted in favour of parliament's report on the proposal for a directive on this subject.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Commission proposal and in favour of the legislative resolution. I am glad that the negotiations between Parliament, the Commission and the Council managed to reach a compromise on emission limit values for existing and new installations while maintaining the compliance dates as stipulated in the COM proposal. It includes also an extension of the scope to cover the monitoring of carbon monoxide emissions and an obligation for Member States to assess the need to apply stricter emission limit values in areas not complying with EU air quality standards.

name: Rosa D'Amato (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Setting emission limit values (VMAs) would be an effective way to solve Europe's air pollution problems by tackling the problem at source by making the environment cleaner, citizens less exposed and preventing huge socio-economic costs for Europe.  VMAs could also create competitiveness for the companies concerned and increase eco-innovation, thereby contributing to job creation in Europe. As the 5-Star Movement, we do not support the proposal because of the lack of ambition to reduce the VLE emission limit values and because we have not included highly toxic pollutants such as mercury, dioxins and furans from the calculation of the emissions we have proposed.  We are concerned about the changes that have weakened the Commission's proposal, about the longer time required for compliance with the VLE and about the exclusion of certain plants from the scope of the directive.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I agree with the rapporteur's position that the proposed amendments improve the possibility of realistic implementation of this directive so that it can become an important tool for improving air quality in the European Union, without imposing undue burdens on society and the economy.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report aims to introduce an authorized pollution limit for medium-sized fuel installations in Europe, powering electric generators, home networks and industries. While European law provides for such limits for small and large installations, medium-sized installations (between 1 and 50 megawatts) are currently outside the scope of European law. While revising the list of targeted pollutants and introducing new pollution limits, the report also plans to reduce the administrative burden for these facilities. Following my action in the parliamentary committee, this report also introduces a list of exempt facilities, including facilities used for research purposes or installed in overseas territories, given their specificities. Considering that this report strikes a balance between reducing polluting emissions, the health of European citizens and the administrative burden on the companies concerned, I voted in favour.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported the text on limiting the emission of certain pollutants into the atmosphere from medium-sized combustion plants. Pollutants such as sulphur dioxide and nitrogen oxides are not yet regulated at European level. It is therefore desirable to limit these pollutants through this directive. More broadly, and in the run-up to COP21, it is desirable for the European Union to push Member States more to mobilise against global warming.

name: Philippe De Backer (ALDE)
text: Written. – The directive voted on here includes stricter limits on emissions of harmful substances into medium-sized combustion plants (1-50 MW input), a category that has hitherto been un regulated. Furthermore, the Directive makes it possible to carry out more efficient checks on such installations. It can only improve air quality and at the same time encourages investment in better and cleaner installations.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission estimates that air pollution causes more than 400 000 premature deaths each year and involves health costs of up to EUR 940 billion. It also contributes to serious environmental degradation and causes economic damage worth EUR 3 billion for crop loss and EUR 1 billion for damage to buildings. The Commission's proposal, which aims to fill an important gap in current EU legislation by reducing emissions of air pollutants from medium-sized combustion plants, contributes to achieving the Union's climate and greenhouse gas reduction targets. I voted in favour of this report because air pollution poses a serious threat to the environment and I believe it is essential to promote a credible CLIMATE POLICY at EU level based on compliance with air quality standards and emission limit values.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. By establishing emission limits on certain pollutants into the atmosphere from medium-sized combustion plants, this directive will fill a legal void. Until then, 143,000 combustion plants of less than 1 megawatt (MW) were not covered by the Ecodesign Directive. Medium combustion facilities are used for a variety of purposes, such as electricity generation, domestic/residential heating and cooling, and the production of heat or steam for industrial purposes. They are an important source of emissions of sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxides and particulate matter (fine particles).  The adoption of this agreement is a step in line with the European Union's strategy to improve air quality.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: In writing. The GRYZB report focuses on limiting emissions of certain pollutants into the atmosphere, thus regulating emissions from medium-sized combustion plants (1 to 50 MW), which the Commission's original proposal did not regulate. That is why I voted for this resolution. The agreement will also allow Member States to explore the possibility of applying stricter limits to facilities in areas that do not meet air quality standards. Finally, carbon monoxide will have to be monitored by the Commission, which will have to take into account the results of its study on this pollutant. I welcome this important step forward in the regulation of emissions of pollutants into the atmosphere.

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE)
text: In writing. There are approximately 143,000 "average" combustion plants in Europe (i.e. with thermal power of between 1 and 50 MW). These facilities are used for domestic or residential electricity generation, heating and cooling, and the production of heat or steam for industrial purposes. They are a major source of sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxides and dust emissions. There are already European regulations for small and large combustion plants, but until now air pollutant emissions from medium-sized combustion facilities have not been regulated at EU level. That is why I have supported this directive, especially since the text sets emission limits at an ambitious level to gradually improve air quality, while preserving the functioning of existing facilities, especially the smaller ones, operated by SMEs or communities, and which are important, for example for the heating of schools. , hospitals or universities. Of course, the directive does not prevent Member States from enforcing stricter standards than those it enacts.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. Mr Grzyb's report proposed limiting the emission of certain pollutants into the atmosphere from medium-sized combustion facilities. The implementation of possible mechanisms regulating this sector is very complex and is a rush on the part of the European Commission. This proposal continues the logic of the Union's regulatory frenzy. By further disrupting industry and associated jobs, for a limited ecological interest, this proposal reveals a notorious imbalance in the consequences of this future regulation, to the disadvantage of economic activities. If environmental policy is at the heart of my commitment to the European Parliament, I cannot accept a disproportionate burden on the already weakened French industry. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because I strongly support the move to improve air quality in Europe. Of course, combustion plants, etc., are an important factor for the economy, but technological advances have given us new tools to limit the effects of such air pollutants. My country is particularly affected by this problem and it is important to set mandatory restrictions. So far, there has been no proper regulation of this issue in Bulgaria and therefore we now rank as one of the most affected countries in terms of air quality. We must ensure health and safety measures at all levels and for all citizens by avoiding the abuse of our beautiful natural heritage. The creation of mandatory restrictions on air pollutants will help to achieve this goal.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. We are voting in favour, although the report could be further improved, but it is a positive step towards the protection of the environment and the health of European citizens.

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Today UKIP voted against the Grzyb report on limitation of emissions of certain pollutants into the air. This vote concerned the drafting of new EU legislation intended to regulate medium combustion plants in Europe. There are approximately 150,000 medium combustion plants in Europe and they are used for a wide variety of applications (including electricity generation, domestic/residential heating and cooling and providing heat/steam for industrial processes). We in UKIP believe in the importance of improving air quality in Europe. We oppose the Commission’s proposal to draft new EU legislation in this field. Therefore we oppose a new EU directive which, covering all medium combustion plants, would impose unjustified burdens on our industry and economy. We do not believe this is a matter that should be regulated by the unelected Commission. We also oppose the establishment of a mandatory EU registration scheme to be applied to all new plants. Nonetheless, today we supported all exceptions to the application of the directive proposed by the rapporteur in order to alleviate the impact of this over-prescriptive regulation.

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE)
text: Written. I welcome the agreement between Parliament and the Council. It is well balanced as it maintains the level of ambition of the Commission's proposal by allowing only well-justified exceptions to the legislation. I am particularly pleased that district heating and biomass were among these exceptions – this is something I ran as rapporteur in the ITRE Committee.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this deliberation because the purported ecological benefit obtained remains low in light of the industry's binding standards.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The medium combustion plants are an important source of sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxideand particulate emissions (fine dust) and are used for very diverse purposes, such as electricity generation, domestic/residential heating and cooling and the production of heat and/or steam for industrial processes.  Emissions of air pollutants from medium combustion plants (as is the case with small and large installations) are generally not regulated at EU level. This proposal is intended to fill this gap. In the EU, there are around 150 000 medium combustion plants, i.e. installations with a thermal power of between 1 and 50 MW. The proposal sets emission limits for sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxides and particulatematter. Several amendments are made to the Commission's initial proposal, which generally deserve our agreement. We have supported the proposed exceptions for the Archipelagos of Madeira and the Azores, which seem to us to be entirely justified, taking into account their specific nature and situation, and there should be another framework.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour because I believe it has the potential to improve the health of the population.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Commission's proposal for medium combustion plants can make a significant contribution to reducing pollution of SO2, NOX or dust by setting limits for both existing and new plants. It is a simple registration system that will help Member States meet their emission reduction commitments and prevent the debates to date on trade-offs between quality and increased use of biomass.
