Small combustion plants and large combustion plants are already regulated by legislation in the directives, and it is therefore also important to adjust the emissions of air pollutants from medium combustion plants, which have not yet been modified at European Union level.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of this report, which harmonises emission legislation.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on limiting emissions of certain pollutants into the atmosphere from medium-sized combustion plants, although the report could be further improved, because it is a positive step towards the protection of the environment and the health of European citizens.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I believe that measures to tackle air pollution at the source are indispensable and therefore I strongly support the adoption and strict implementation of the Directive on Medium Combustion Plants. Medium combustion plants are one of the most important sources of emissions and a very serious threat to health and the environment. I congratulate my colleagues for being very ambitious in setting these targets, for granting a limited number of derogations and for deciding short compliance timelines for existing plants. Hopefully Member States will be as proactive on the matter and make efforts towards cooperation with the Commission by providing correct and punctual data from medium combustion plants, and will assess the need for stricter emission values in areas that still do not comply with EU air quality standards.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on emissions from medium combustion plants. In general, they are not regulated at EU level and need to be remedied. I welcome the fact that further clarifications have been added to the text in order to clarify the application of Directive 2010/75/EU on industrial emissions and to preserve regulatory consistency with the Industrial Emissions Directive. The changes proposed by the rapporteur will improve the chances of the directive being realistically implemented and becoming an important tool for improving air quality in the European Union without imposeing undue burdens on society and the economy, and in this light I voted in favour of this report.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report to help reduce polluting emissions which represent a major cross-border problem. Action is needed at Union level with the aim of establishing a coherent and ambitious framework to address the problem of emissions from medium-sized combustion plants.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Today's vote fills a long-present gap in the system and regulates average combustion plants, setting limit values for old and new plants. This is a good compromise which makes it possible to protect the health of European citizens more effectively, without at the same time having an excessive impact on the competitiveness of the industrial sector. For these reasons, I voted strongly in favour of this report.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. It is very important that we have just voted on the report presented by the ENVI Committee: with the proposed amendments to the Commission's proposal, the European Parliament is improving the possibilities of realistically implementing the directive on emissions from medium combustion plants so as to make it an important tool for improving atmospheric quality in the European Union without imposing unjustified burdens on society and the economy. It was an area in which the regulatory vacuum was likely to cause uncertainty and damage to the environment, and I welcome this important acquisition.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the limitation of emissions into the atmosphere of certain pollutants from medium combustion plants, since they are widespread and have a wide variety of uses, being found in electric generators, domestic heating systems and industrial heat or steam systems, but they are a source of emission of pollutants such as sulphur dioxide and nitrogen oxides. I therefore consider Parliament's commitment to the protection of air quality and the environment and the fight against climate change to be of fundamental importance and, consequently, I support a legislative proposal regulating emissions from these plants for the first time.  I also welcome the negotiating approach towards the Council, which aims to maintain the Commission's legislative proposals without any backtracking or weakening of the legislation: air and environmental quality is a fundamental public good for our citizens and as such must receive the greatest attention from the institutions. The regulatory approach, combining environmental protection with the proportionality of the burdens imposed, distinguishing between old and new plants and focusing on SMEs, allows for an important decision that will benefit our society and also our businesses.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the report on limiting emissions of certain pollutants into the air. In principle, as an MEP for the Family Party, the principle applies to me: we have only borrowed the world from our children. Accordingly, I support all measures that help to make our economy more sustainable in an applicable way.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on limiting emissions of certain pollutants into the air. Air pollution is a cross-border problem that requires action at Union level. The proposed amendments to the original legislative proposal will contribute to the de-bureaucratisation. This would improve air quality across the EU without imposing unjustified burdens on the economy and society.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. Although polluting emissions have been significantly reduced in recent decades, air pollution levels remain problematic in many parts of Europe, and Union citizens continue to be exposed to air pollutants that can endanger their health and well-being. In particular, emissions of pollutants from medium combustion plants are not regulated at Union level, even though they are increasingly contributing to air pollution. I therefore vote in favour of a directive whose purpose is precisely to set limits on the polluting emissions of these plants.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of limiting emissions of pollutants (such as carbon monoxide, sulfide dioxide and nitrogen oxides) in medium-flue plants, as a measure aimed at reducing the amount of greenhouse gases emitted into the atmosphere from the territory of the European Union in the context of combating climate change. We also position ourselves AGAINST the paragraph of the report which sought to exclude from the Directive certain EU territories, such as the Canary Islands, on the understanding that all EU citizens must be guaranteed the same air quality standards, regardless of the territory in which they live.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it forms a key element of the EU’s Clean Air Package and will reduce harmful emissions and improve air quality across the UK and the EU.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. While emissions of air pollutants from small and large combustion plants are regulated at EU level, there is no specific regulation for medium-sized combustion plants. Air pollution is estimated to lead to more than 400 000 premature deaths per year and causing health costs of up to EUR 940 billion. Reducing emissions from medium combustion plants can help contribute to achieving EU climate and energy targets through reducing greenhouse gases and improving energy efficiency. This instrument is very important in order to improve air quality in the EU without imposing unjustified burdens on society and the economy.

name: Roger Helmer (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Today UKIP voted against the Grzyb report on limitation of emissions of certain pollutants into the air. This vote concerned the drafting of new EU legislation intended to regulate medium combustion plants in Europe. There are approximately 150,000 medium combustion plants in Europe and they are used for a wide variety of applications (including electricity generation, domestic/residential heating and cooling and providing heat/steam for industrial processes). We in UKIP believe in the importance of improving air quality in Europe. We oppose the Commission’s proposal to draft new EU legislation in this field. Therefore we oppose a new EU directive which, covering all medium combustion plants, would impose unjustified burdens on our industry and economy. We do not believe this is a matter that should be regulated by the unelected Commission. We also oppose the establishment of a mandatory EU registration scheme to be applied to all new plants. Nonetheless, today we supported all exceptions to the application of the directive proposed by the rapporteur in order to alleviate the impact of this over-prescriptive regulation.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. This report deals with the limitation of emissions of certain pollutants from medium-sized combustion plants. As part of the air quality package, the European Commission presented in December 2013 the proposal for a directive on reducing pollution from medium-sized combustion plants. The Directive will apply to combustion plants with a heat output of up to 50 megawatts; this applies in particular to large buildings and small industrial plants. It is proposed to introduce a registration requirement for medium-sized combustion plants and to set emission limits for pollutants produced by combustion plants, such as sulphur dioxide, nitrogen and particulate matter. While small and large combustion plants are regulated, emissions from medium-sized combustion plants are not regulated. There are currently no limit value proposals. However, the Commission is working on this. Our committee, ITRE, supports this report, essentially for these reasons: air pollution is a cross-border problem – that is why regulation at EU level is necessary. The aim is to fill a significant gap in EU law. According to an impact assessment by the Commission, the health costs of air pollution across Europe are around EUR 940 million per year. With this in mind, I voted in favour of this report. Incidentally, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: Brice Hortefeux (PPE)
text: In writing. On the eve of the World Climate Conference in Paris in December 2015, the EU has proposed a directive to limit the emission of certain pollutants to help improve air quality. However, the European Commission is aware that the regulation of emissions from industrial facilities must be progressive in order to take account of the technical and economic constraints imposed on operators and adapted to the size of these facilities. The future of European industry is already in sharp decline compared to our main international partners. In addition, some facilities will be exempted until 2030, such as district heating systems, biomass-related facilities, facilities linked to isolated systems, particularly in overseas territories, and specific facilities linked to a national natural gas transmission network. I believe that this approach is proportionate insofar as it maintains the balance between the need to preserve our industries while encouraging them to favour less polluting techniques and the collective will to combat air pollution.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of limiting emissions of pollutants (such as carbon monoxide, sulfide dioxide and nitrogen oxides) in medium-flue plants, as a measure aimed at reducing the amount of greenhouse gases emitted into the atmosphere from the territory of the European Union in the context of combating climate change. We also position ourselves AGAINST the paragraph of the report which sought to exclude from the Directive certain EU territories, such as the Canary Islands, on the understanding that all EU citizens must be guaranteed the same air quality standards, regardless of the territory in which they live.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. The Action Programme which will run up to 2020 sets the framework for a review of EU air quality. It aims to lower the potential risks to human health and the environment by laying down rules to control and reduce emissions of sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxides and particulate matter into the air.

name: Anneli Jäätteenmäki (ALDE)
text: Written. " The regulation of emissions from small and medium-sized combustion plants will cover the power class that has so far been lacking. In this respect, blocking the regulatory loophole is a good thing and clarifying the situation. It is also good that, during the parliamentary debate, changes were made to the Commission's proposal to better take into account the EU's renewable energy incentive targets, especially in areas where air quality is already good and meets who's recommendations.  Air quality must be considered not only as individual point-like sources of emissions, but also as a whole. In future, we will not be able to bypass, for example, better controlled and stricter regulation of transport. In today's world, clean air is not a foregone conclusion. When regulating air quality, care must be taken to ensure a straightforward and oversimimistic analysis in which not all the costs of poor air quality are included in the calculations. We still have a great deal of work to do in better application of the 'polluter pays' principle and in taking negative external effects into account. All governments in the EU Member States have a legal obligation to ensure that the state of the environment improves and that citizens' health is promoted.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a draft european parliament legislative resolution on the proposal for a directive by Parliament and the Council to limit emissions of certain pollutants into the air from medium-sized combustion plants, as this proposal improves air quality and has established a major harm to polluted air, namely its contribution to the rate of premature death. I support the fact that this will reduce the pollution caused by nitrogen and sulphur oxide emissions and dust by establishing limit values for new and existing installations. I also believe that the purpose of this proposal is to avoid excessive administrative burdens and double regulations. I believe it is essential to ensure, through joint efforts and synergies as at European and global level, the highest level of environmental protection and to act in line with climate change.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. The medium combustion facilities are used in a wide range of applications and have a rated thermal power of between 1 and 50 MW. These facilities are therefore between small facilities under the Ecodesign Directive (2009/125/EC), and large combustion plants which are governed by the Industrial Emissions Directive (2010/75/EU).  The aim of this text is therefore to fill a certain legislative void, and to make a contribution to the reduction of pollution in nitrogen oxide, sulphur dioxide and dust. Of course, these regulatory changes are the responsibility of the Member States and weigh heavily on the industry. For example, states must apply a stricter emission limit in areas that do not comply with the European air quality standard; must also keep a public record of the registration date of combustion facilities; but also register or license an existing facility at least one year before the compliance date.  This text is in line with these anti-industry norms under the guise of a risky ecological and public health benefit. I voted against it.

name: Diane James (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ EU legislation in this area has directly impacted on the UK manufacturing sector leading to widespread business closures and unemployment. I am completely unable to support any further legislation which will continue this trend. Redcar might still be open and its workers employed but for EU interference such as this.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Andrzej Grzyb's report on limiting the emissions of certain pollutants into the atmosphere. The aim was to validate the agreement reached with the European Commission and the Council, which in particular arranges the dates for the application of the standards, depending on the size of the facilities and certain specificities. In addition, for areas where air quality standards are not met, Member States are free to apply stricter standards to facilities to help return to the norm. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted for this report because air quality in Europe is particularly badly deteriorated by the use of small combustion plants. This text raises limits on the emission of certain pollutants for these facilities.

name: Jarosław Kalinowski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Medium-sized combustion plants include, for example, According to the European Commission, nearly 150 000 Directives of the European Parliament and of the Council of 2009 and 2010 have regulated the emission limit limits for certain pollutants into the atmosphere by small (rated capacity up to 1 MW) and large (above 50MW) plants. The document we have adopted today complements the legislation by regulating emissions by medium-sized units (from 1 to 50 MW). In order to improve air quality, the limits set limit pollution by nitrogen oxides, sulphur dioxide and dust, and this is a Community-wide regulation, because only such a form of unification has a chance of success. After all, many air pollutants emitted in a certain area of the EU can reach another country or region. It was therefore necessary to supplement the legislation with the current provisions.   At the same time, post-set-off of restrictions on new-found facilities will reduce costs for both producers and final customers. Let us reduce pollution and take care of the environment, but taking into account the impact of such measures on our economy, especially in countries where energy production is still largely based on coal.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I am abstaining from voting on this legislative proposal. The reasons put forward that medium-sized combustion plants are not yet regulated, large and small ones, are perfectly understandable and worthy of support. However, since the operators of combustion plants of this size, which have often been installed for very specific purposes and obey their own standards, could incur high costs, I am abstaining.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a directive on the emission of certain pollutants into the air from medium combustion plants at the European Parliament plenary session in Strasbourg. The legislation already regulates large emitters of CO2, but the installations covered by this directive also produce a significant proportion of pollution, so it is only justified that more equal playing field is created for all. However, it must not be forgotten that there are differences in climate regulation between the EU and other countries around the world. The EU continues to regulate and tighten up its industry, but other countries do not want to do so. As a result, there is a risk that the European industry will transfer production to jurisdictions where climate requirements and, consequently, costs are lower.  After assessing the agreement reached with the Council, I believe that the final text of the directive is balanced and voted in the vote.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report, as it is a key element of the EU’s Clean Air Package and will reduce harmful emissions and improve air quality across the UK and the EU.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. This report deals with the limitation of emissions of certain pollutants from medium-sized combustion plants. As part of the air quality package, the European Commission presented in December 2013 the proposal for a directive on reducing pollution from medium-sized combustion plants. The Directive will apply to combustion plants with a heat output of up to 50 megawatts; this applies in particular to large buildings and small industrial plants. It is proposed to introduce a registration requirement for medium-sized combustion plants and to set emission limits for pollutants produced by combustion plants, such as sulphur dioxide, nitrogen and particulate matter. While small and large combustion plants are regulated, emissions from medium-sized combustion plants are not regulated. There are currently no limit value proposals. However, the Commission is working on this. The ITRE parliamentary committee supports this report, mainly for these reasons: air pollution is a cross-border problem – that is why regulation at EU level is necessary. The aim is to fill a significant gap in EU law. According to an impact assessment by the Commission, the health costs of air pollution across Europe are around EUR 940 million per year. With this in mind, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. – There is no doubt that air pollution is a cross-border problem and that many Member States receive air pollution from neighbouring countries, so action at EU level is needed, so I supported the report. All the more so because air pollution is one of the leading risk factors, which has an extraordinary impact on people's well-being, health and life expectancy. The Directive seems realistically enforceable and could be an important tool for significantly improving air quality in the European Union without imposeing undue burdens on society and the economy.

name: Gabrielius Landsbergis (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report. The importance of this report first and foremost stems from the fact that the proposal closes an important legislative loophole due to which emissions of air pollutants from medium combustion plants were left largely unregulated at the EU level. The EU must ensure that high quality of air is maintained and that the industry develops at no cost to the health of citizens. The clause on benchmarking progress and carrying out a review by the Commission every 10 years takes into account the possible progress of cleaning technology and thus contributes to the practicality of this report. However, proper implementation of this report is very much necessary as about 75% of medium combustion plants are run by small and medium-sized enterprises, which have to be safeguarded from excessive amount of red-tape and double regulation.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. This proposal on medium combustion plants, with a rated thermal power of between 1 and 50 MW, is designed to make a significant contribution to reducing pollution by setting limit values for existing and new plants and also by establishing a registration system that can enable emissions reduction obligations to be fulfilled in the Member States.  Among the most important points, I would like to point out the obligation for Member States to assess the need to apply stricter emission limit values in areas that do not comply with EU air quality standards and the inclusion of a review clause to enable progress in energy efficiency of combustion plants to be monitored in 2020. These efforts are part of the wider framework of preparation for COP21 in Paris.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the report on "limiting the emissions of certain pollutants into the atmosphere". Medium combustion facilities are used in a wide range of applications (including electricity generation, domestic or residential heating and cooling, heating or steam production for industrial purposes). By Community standards that have come out of the Commission's hat, by anti-industry provisions for a very risky ecological and public health benefit, this text is at odds with the national interest and the european general interest.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text because it is certainly aimed at reducing pollution in nitrogen oxide and sulphur dioxide, but seems unfavourable to French and European industries for a very risky ecological benefit. It creates a new handicap for them compared to industries in non-European countries. In short, it symbolizes the art of shooting yourself in the foot.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. The Grzyb report fills a gap in European legislation by addressing emissions into the atmosphere of medium combustion plants that are generally not regulated at EU level.  The document aims to contribute to the reduction of polluting gases by Member States and to avoid possible compromises between air quality and the increasing use of biomass which could otherwise lead to increased air pollution.  It is therefore an important tool to improve air quality in the European Union without imposing unjustified burdens on the economy and society. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. This report deals with the limitation of emissions of certain pollutants from medium-sized combustion plants. As part of the air quality package, the European Commission presented in December 2013 the proposal for a directive on reducing pollution from medium-sized combustion plants. The Directive will apply to combustion plants with a heat output of up to 50 megawatts; this applies in particular to large buildings and small industrial plants. It is proposed to introduce a registration requirement for medium-sized combustion plants and to set emission limits for pollutants produced by combustion plants, such as sulphur dioxide, nitrogen and particulate matter. While small and large combustion plants are regulated, emissions from medium-sized combustion plants are not regulated. There are currently no limit value proposals. However, the Commission is working on this. Our committee, ITRE, supports this report, essentially for these reasons: air pollution is a cross-border problem – that is why regulation at EU level is necessary. The aim is to fill a significant gap in EU law. According to an impact assessment by the Commission, the health costs of air pollution across Europe are around EUR 940 million per year. With this in mind, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I believe that improving air quality in Europe is important. However, I do not agree with the European Commission coming up with new legislation in this area, which will result in an additional burden on our entrepreneurs. I am also opposed to the mandatory European registration system for all new factories.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 There are currently around 150,000 medium combustion plants in the EU, which are an essential source of emissions of sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxide and particulate matter. While the operation of small combustion plants is regulated by Directive 2009/125/EC and the large Directives 2010/75/EU, emissions of air pollutants from medium-sized combustion plants are not regulated at EU level.  The Commission proposal lays out provisions for medium combustion plants. Setting a limit value for new installations with a simple recording scheme will significantly reduce pollution and help reduce emissions in Member States. I supported MPs' report, as this Union action is essential to establish a coherent and ambitious framework to address emissions. In my view, member states' obligation is to apply stricter rules to limit emissions in zones that do not comply with the EU air quality standard.

name: Светослав Христов Малинов (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament, aware of the seriousness of the problems related to high levels of environmental pollution, adopted a legislative resolution on the proposal for a directive on limiting harmful emissions to air. Despite a significant reduction in harmful emissions in recent decades, pollution levels in some parts of Europe are still alarmingly high. This necessitas the need for immediate measures with a view to finally ending such practices. The specific focus of the Directive is on medium combustion plants because they alone do not fall under European regulation and because of their increasing influence as a pollution factor. Medium combustion plants should be developed and operated in such a way as to promote energy efficiency and their activities should be subject to control by the Member State. Each medium combustion plant should be in operation only if it is authorised or registered by the competent authority. I am convinced that this Directive is the right step towards the overall objective, namely the safety and well-being of European citizens and the careful balance between consumer health, environmental protection and economic activity in Europe.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Air pollution is a cross-border problem that needs to be regulated in order to maintain health and a healthy environment. If we do not solve the problem, the costs of health care and environmental protection will increase and the economies of all states will be burdened. The Directive lays down measures in the form of air pollutant emission limits for medium combustion plants (with a thermal input of between 1 and 50 MW) for which a regulatory legal framework has not yet been established. It applies to both new and existing installations. In particular, the aim is to reduce emissions, and regulation should not impose an increase in administrative burdens and a disproportionate burden on countries' economies for EU Member States.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council to limit emissions of certain pollutants into the atmosphere from medium-sized combustion plants, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament on 6/10/2015. Furthermore, I note the huge problem facing my country, Greece, over the last two winters, due to the smog that has occurred in Greek cities and especially in Athens and Thessaloniki. The appearance of smog is due solely to the memorandum that imposed the increase in taxes on heating oil and electricity and thus led thousands of my fellow citizens to search for heating methods of the previous century, such as improvised magals and burning any kind of inappropriate fuel. These methods are extremely dangerous, for the citizens themselves and for public health. For these reasons, I call on the Greek Government to decide, immediately, to impose zero VAT and to reduce to a minimum the excise duty on electricity and heating oil, otherwise, the Greek people will also freeze this winter and we will again this year be faced with the sanitary bomb of smog, solely under the responsibility of the troika and the SYRIZA-ANEL co-government.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This proposal is important for several reasons. Firstly, according to the Commission impact assessment, air pollution is estimated to lead to more than 400,000 premature deaths per year and health costs of up to €940 billion. It also contributes to significant environmental degradation, with 62% of the EU area exposed to eutrophication and economic damage such as €15 billion from lost workdays, €4bn in healthcare costs, €3bn in crop yield loss and €1bn in damage to buildings. Secondly, reducing emissions from medium combustion plants can contribute to achieving the EU climate and energy targets, in reducing greenhouse gases, improving energy efficiency and promoting renewables. By acting now and filling the current regulatory gap, we can provide clear signals for investments and provide further incentives for research and innovation in breakthrough technologies. This will create conditions for European businesses to lead in green innovation, with enormous potential in export markets. For example, air pollution alone costs China 12-13% of GDP every year.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal for a directive aimed at limiting emissions into the atmosphere from medium combustion plants. The report introduces for the first time limits on emissions from combustion plants for certain pollutants, which will be applied to average combustion plants between 1 and 50 MW, both new and existing. Unlike small and large plants that are already covered by their EU directives, emissions from medium combustion plants are not yet regulated at EU level. The new rules are intended to fill gaps in the regulatory framework. Improving air quality and combating air pollution in the EU is a priority.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. 12012 I am voting in favour of the proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on limiting emissions into the atmosphere of certain pollutants from medium combustion plants in view of the critical levels of air pollution which, on the one hand, exceed the limits set by the European Union and the World Health Organisation and, on the other hand, constitute a danger to the health and well-being of European citizens and future generations.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, in particular with regard to the Azores and Madeira, because I believe that the poorest regions cannot be subject to higher levels of pollution just because they do not have the means. I understand, of course, the argument of scarcity of resources, but I think that the derogation from the limits is a nonsense in their results and would actually entail a double penalty of these regions, which are still poorer and by that derogation would be more polluted. The solution to this equation necessarily involves the answers to be created by the EU in order to assist and provide the regions with means to meet the limits.

name: Stefano Maullu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because emission regulations are effectively harmonised.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. In itself, uniform regulation of the emission limits of medium-sized combustion plants (as already exists in small and large combustion plants) makes sense and is desirable from the point of view of environmental protection. However, as this will mainly burden SMEs (there are around 150,000 medium-sized combustion plants [burning heat output between 1-50 megawatts] in the areas of electricity generation, heating/cooling of households, generation of heat/steam for industry) in terms of administrative and financial burdens, I will abstain from voting on this report.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report. The report seeks to avoid excessive administrative burden while incorporating medium combustion plants under EU emission legislation.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This is a proposal for a directive to limit emissions from a certain category of combustion plants in the "average" category (nominal thermal power between 1 and 50 MW). These combustion facilities are used for a wide range of cases including domestic/residential electricity generation, heating and cooling, and the production of heat or steam for industrial purposes. In the EU, 143,000 installations are affected. They are an important source of emissions of sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxides and particulate matter, but are not currently regulated at EU level (while small and large facilities are regulated). The proposal aims to limit the emission of pollutants by these facilities. While the thresholds set by the Commission are still too high and the right is trying to exclude the peripheral regions of the EU from the scope, it is in line with a reduction in emissions of pollutants, so I am voting in for it.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The medium combustion facilities are used in a wide range of applications and have a rated thermal power of between 1 and 50 MW. These facilities are therefore between small facilities under the Ecodesign Directive (2009/125/EC), and large combustion plants which are governed by the Industrial Emissions Directive (2010/75/EU).  The aim of this text is therefore to fill a certain legislative void, and to make a contribution to the reduction of pollution in nitrogen oxide, sulphur dioxide and dust. Of course, these regulatory changes are the responsibility of the Member States and weigh heavily on the industry. For example, states must apply a stricter emission limit in areas that do not comply with the European air quality standard; must also keep a public record of the registration date of combustion facilities; but also register or license an existing facility at least one year before the compliance date.  This text is therefore in line with these anti-industry norms under the guise of a risky ecological and public health benefit.  This text is at odds with national and European interests. So I voted against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on the proposal for a Directive is an important tool for improving air quality, and I have so I have put forward my positive vote on limiting emissions into the atmosphere of certain pollutants, a central issue under discussion. It is a question of establishing a more coherent and ambitious regulatory framework within the Union, closing important gaps so far, without imposing unjustified burdens.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This resolution works to limit the air pollutants expelled by a relatively unregulated classification of combustion plant while also ensuring that unnecessary burdens are not imposed. Therefore I voted in favour of the measures it proposes.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: Written. – Europe has made serious efforts in recent years to ensure cleaner air. However, despite a measurable improvement, air quality in Europe still leaves much to be desired in many places. Air quality does not yet meet the standards set by the EU, nor does it meet the World Health Organisation's objectives. After setting the emission standards for large combustion plants, the emission limit values for small and medium-sized combustion plants have now also been set.  Today, there are some 143,000 small and medium-sized combustion plants in Europe covered by this new directive. They are mostly local combustion plants that provide energy or heat to small village communities or large buildings or, for example, provide steam or hot water to public district heating networks. The directive, which parliament has tightened, now sets the maximum emission limit values for nitrogen oxide, sulphur dioxide and particulate matter. In order to comply with the directive and at the same time to guarantee energy supplies, the operators of these combustion plants are given ample time to adapt to the stricter emission standards. With parliament's adoption of the directive, Europe is taking a significant step forward in its ambition to achieve clean and healthy air.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the limitation of emissions of certain pollutants into air from medium combustion plants is part of the new EU air quality action framework set out in the revised EU thematic strategy on air pollution and is consistent with the Europe 2020 strategy objectives for smart, inclusive and sustainable growth. In fact, around 150 000 medium-sized combustion plants operate in the EU, which have a wide range of uses, including electricity generation, heating and cooling of households, as well as the provision of heat and steam for industrial processes. I appreciate that the proposal is designed to make a significant contribution to reducing NOx, SO2 and dust pollution by setting limits for new and existing installations, as well as a simple registration system to help Member States meet a significant part of their emission reduction commitments and avoid possible trade-offs between quality and increased use of biomass, which could otherwise lead to an increase in air pollution. At the same time, the administrative burden is kept at the lowest possible level, which gives real hope of applying the directive without representing an unjustified burden on society and the economy.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report since I believe that poor air quality is a serious threat to health and the environment and it is essential to promote compliance with existing air quality rules and push for maintaining tough emission limit values in line with the role of helping to shape a credible EU climate policy.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Combustion plants are a major source of sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxide and dust emissions. The Commission's proposal aims to fill the gap in the current EU legislation on combustion plants. Issues relating to small-scale installations are governed by Directive 2009/125/EC on ecodesign and those relating to large installations are regulated by Directive 2010/75/EU on industrial emissions, but there is no EU-wide regulation on the emissions of air pollutants from medium combustion plants (with a nominal thermal input of between 1 and 50 MW). I agree with the aim of the proposal and therefore supported it.

name: Bernard Monot (ENF)
text: In writing. The text aims to regulate the polluting emissions of medium-sized combustion plants, those between the small facilities covered by the 2009/125/EC directive (so-called "ecodesign"), and the large combustion plants which are governed by the 2010/75/EU directive (industrial emissions directive). The aim of this text is therefore to occupy a certain legislative vacuum and to make a contribution to the reduction of pollution in nitrogen oxide, sulphur dioxide and dust. The regulatory amendments are the responsibility of the Member States and weigh on the industry. Despite a seemingly laudable objective, it imposes standards out of the Commission's hat for a very risky ecological and public health benefit. This text is at odds with the national interest and the general European interest and cannot be supported.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The control of emissions of polluting substances into the atmosphere from combustion plants with medium thermal power is not regulated at EU level. As such, there is an urgent need to fill this gap, because this is an issue in the field of the protection of human health and the environment. The aim is to set minimum requirements for new installations and existing ones by setting pollutant emission limit values, introducing aggregation rules for new combustion plants, and the obligation for Member States to apply limit values in areas outside EU air quality standards. This proposal meets the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy and also the new air quality action framework set out in the EU Thematic Strategy on Air Pollution.  It is necessary to protect the environment and EU citizens by adopting measures that contribute to this, so i vote in favour of this proposal for a Directive.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on limiting the emissions of certain pollutants into the atmosphere aims to fill a certain legislative vacuum and to make a contribution to the reduction of nitrogen oxide pollution. Average combustion facilities are used in a wide range of applications. They are located between small thermal installations and large ones. This text imposes new constraints on Member States, on the application of a stricter emission limit in areas that do not comply with European air quality standards etc. Most of these measures, taken from the Commission's most technocratic brains, will undoubtedly have a negative impact on the industry when the ecological benefit seems very small... I have therefore decided to vote against this perfectly harmful text which would pollute the legal environment of national industries.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it forms a key element of the EU’s Clean Air Package and will reduce harmful emissions and improve air quality across the UK and the EU.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the regulation of emissions from combustion plants with a capacity of between 1 and 50 MW. It introduces more flexibility over the original European Commission proposal, calling for different regimes and implementation times depending on the size of industrial units. The report recommends that emission limits apply from 2025 for existing installations between 5 and 50 MW, starting in 2030 for those between 1 and 5 MW. It proposes that an exemption be granted until 2030 to certain facilities, including district heating systems, biomass units, those installed in isolated areas as in overseas territories, and specific facilities linked to a national natural gas transmission network. It also proposes that in areas that do not meet air quality standards, Member States should consider the possibility of applying stricter limits to facilities. The aim is to better harmonise operating conditions in the EU and to fight for environmental protection while maintaining the necessary flexibility not to jeopardise energy companies.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 There are around 150 000 medium combustion plants in the EU, i.e. combustion plants with a nominal thermal power of between 1 and 50 MW, used for a wide range of applications (electricity production, domestic/residential heating and cooling, heat/steam production for industrial processes, etc.), which are an important source of sulphur dioxide emissions, nitrogen oxides and dust.  By adopting this proposal, we intend to make a significant contribution to reducing pollution by NOx, SO2 and dust, by setting limit values for existing and new plants and also by setting up a simple registration system, in order to make a substantial contribution to the compliance with member states' emission reduction obligations, while also avoiding possible compromises between air quality and the increase in the use of biomass, which in turn could lead to an increase in air pollution.  The aim we intend to pursue is, in fact, to avoid double regulation and excessive administrative burdens, while leaving the objectives of the initial legislative proposal intact. In agreement with the rapporteur, we believe that the proposed changes improve the chances of realistically implementing the directive so as to make it an important tool for improving atmospheric quality in the EU without imposing unjustified burdens on society and the economy.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report that will establish an emission limit value for medium combustion plants, engines and gas turbines.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as I believe clean and healthy breathable air is crucial for the health of our citizens and there is nothing we should prioritise more. The emissions from combustion plants are obviously a main source of pollution and this text does an important job in calling for tighter regulation, with more control over the permits and functioning of these plants, but also envisaging a reduction in emissions in the next period. And this I believe is the key – not to preserve the current status quo when it comes to air pollution and emissions, but to strive for a reduction in the future, for a better air quality and for greener alternatives for energy production.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the Directive on limiting emissions of certain pollutants into the air, which fills a gap in EU law and introduces emission control for medium-sized combustion plants, such as boilers in apartment buildings and public buildings. While meeting the targets will not be easy and will cost some states considerable effort, I believe that this is the right way to go and, at the same time, an opportunity to ensure a healthier environment, to increase health protection for the European population and to invest in modern and clean technologies.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. After small and large combustion plants have already been regulated in their emission levels, it is now the turn of the medium-sized combustion plants. Within the European Union there are about 150,000 of them. Regulation would be another hurdle for owners. Member States can still adopt stricter standards. Limiting emissions of certain pollutants is a good idea, but there must be no double regulation and the bureaucratic burden should be limited. That is why I abstained.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this proposal for a directive to improve air quality in Europe. By setting maximum emission limits for the pollutants most harmful to health and the environment (sulphur dioxide, nitrogen dioxide and CO2) from medium-sized combustion plants, this directive aims to strengthen health and safety standards for facilities that were previously dependent solely on national standards. With this harmonisation, it is therefore a real health breakthrough that is being implemented in Europe.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The aim of the amendment is to regulate emissions of air pollutants from a medium combustion plant that has not yet been generally regulated.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – A coherent, ambitious framework for the problem of emissions needs to be established at EU level. In particular, it is necessary to close loopholes in legal regulation and to strike a balance between the costs and benefits of businesses for the environment and human health. Air pollution must be controlled. It is therefore necessary to set limit values for new and existing installations, including through the introduction of a simple registration system. However, the new regulation must not create an unjustified and disproportionate administrative burden.  It should be noted that reducing emissions from medium-sized combustion plants would contribute to the EU's energy and climate objectives, as well as reducing greenhouse gas emissions, increasing energy efficiency and stimulating renewable energy.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I welcome the work done by the rapporteur with regard to the amendments to the directive, the overall aim of which reflects the desire to commit itself to reducing emissions. For this reason, I have decided to vote in favour.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the report on limiting pollutant emissions from medium combustion plants into the air, because this is to regulate the still unregulated area of emissions. Air pollution is a source of many respiratory diseases, so I believe that emissions should be limited.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Air pollution has a significant impact on the environment and health. According to data presented to us by the 2013 Clean Air for Europe programme, annual premature deaths in 2010 reached 400,000. Total external health impact costs vary from €330 billion to €940 billion. Direct economic damage includes €15 billion from lost working days, €4 billion in healthcare costs, €3 billion in losses from crop yields and €1 billion in damage to buildings.  That is why I supported this legislative resolution and the compromise reached. Filling the legislative gap with this Directive, which builds on the Eco-Design and Control of Small Combustion Plants Directive, while using the tried-and-tested mechanisms of the Industrial Emissions Directive, which in turn covers the segment of large combustion plants, enables the objectives of further improvement of air quality in the EU to be achieved.  Some may consider the proposed transitional periods necessary for the transposition of the Directive and its full application to be too long. On the contrary, I believe that regulations such as this concerning existing devices with a lifespan of more than a decade must take into account technological cycles, without distorting the economic conditions of small and medium-sized enterprises and leaving sufficient time for the necessary technical improvements.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on limiting the emission of certain pollutants into the atmosphere aims to fill a certain legislative vacuum and to make a contribution to the reduction of nitrogen oxide pollution. Medium-sized combustion plants are used in a wide range of applications. They are located between small thermal installations and large ones. This text imposes new constraints on Member States, on the application of a stricter emission limit in areas that do not comply with European air quality standards, etc. Most of these measures, taken from the Commission's most technocratic brains, will undoubtedly have a negative impact on the industry when the ecological benefit seems very small... I have therefore decided to vote against this perfectly harmful text which would pollute the legal environment of national industries.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. \u2012 The emission of certain substances from the combustion plant and the consequent pollution of air quality is a major health and environmental problem throughout Europe, even in Croatia, despite existing regulations and laws that try to reduce this emission to minimum quantities. It is commendable, therefore, that the European Parliament and the Council have decided to propose a directive concerning the emission limit of certain pollutants from medium-sized combustion plants, as large and small installations are already covered by EU legislation. The agreed text of the proposal also contains rules for monitoring carbon dioxide emissions, and for improving the energy efficiency of medium-sized installations. Under the proposals, no combustion plant should be subject to double regulation, especially since around 75 % of the installations concerned are run by SMEs which are already sufficiently financially and administratively burdened. The Commission proposes to introduce new emission limits and a simpler process for registering and obtaining a licence for installations. For Croatia, a particularly significant proposal is to grant the extension of eligibility deadlines to regional heating systems and to plants that are part of small isolated systems (for example, on islands). In my view, the proposal for a directive in question allows for an effective reduction of emissions from medium-sized installations, clearing the way for the green economy and renewable energy and the reduction of greenhouse gases.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Air pollution is a major cross-border problem and many Member States want to introduce a limit on emissions of certain pollutants into the air from neighbouring countries. Action should therefore be taken at Union level to establish a coherent and ambitious framework for tackling emissions. The Commission proposal aims to fill an important gap in current EU legislation. There are already regulated provisions on the implementation of the Directive of the European Parliament and the Council of 21 October 2009 on the establishment of a framework for setting requirements for eco-designed energy products. The importance of the proposal is manissa. First, according to the Commission's impact assessment, air pollution will lead to more than 400,000 premature deaths per year, and health costs of up to €940 billion. Air pollution also contributes to significant environmental degradation and economic damage. Furthermore, reducing emissions from medium combustion plants can contribute to achieving the EU's climate and energy goals, and reducing greenhouse gas emissions, promoting energy efficiency improvements and renewables. If we act now, we can provide clear signals for investment needs, thereby providing additional incentives for research and innovation. This will create favourable conditions for European companies in green innovation, with huge export potential. For all of the above, I support colleague Andrzej Grzyb's report.

name: Miroslav Poche (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the fact that the European Parliament today passed legislation in favour of further emission reductions. There are still 2 directives setting limits for small and large combustion installations, today these directives have been supplemented by emission limits for medium-sized installations (interconnections consisting of two or more combustion installations with a total rated thermal power of 1 MW or more and less than 50 MW). Improving air quality is one of the Social Democrats' long-term priorities, and further emission reductions are a prerequisite for this. I, too, have long supported legislation in favour of strict emission limits, but it can only be effective if it applies to all producers and not just some of them. The gap between small and large producers therefore needed to be filled and I am glad that this has finally happened today. At the same time, I consider today's decision to be an important signal on the EU's clear air protection priorities ahead of the forthcoming Climate Summit in Paris.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report aims to reduce emissions of certain pollutants from medium combustion plants into the air. Such plants are widespread in Europe and are used in different fields: electricity generation, domestic heating, heat generation for industrial processes, etc.  Air pollution is estimated to cause over 400 000 premature deaths each year and involving quantifiable health costs of up to EUR 940 billion as well as having a significant negative effect on the environment.  In the EU, small combustion plants are regulated by Directive 2009/125/EC and large plants by Directive 2010/75/EC, while average combustion plants are not regulated at EU level. I therefore believe that setting up a system for regulating and registering these plants at European level is an important instrument for improving the quality of atmospheric emissions in the European Union, for achieving the Union's climate and energy objectives and for reducing greenhouse gases. For these reasons, I have decided to support this report by voting in favour of it.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. In order to achieve the 2030 climate targets, the EU is trying to reduce air pollution by limiting emissions from certain pollutants. The European Parliament has adopted a resolution regulating emissions from medium-sized combustion plants (ranging from 1 to 50 MW). I have spoken in favour of this text and I underline the flexibility offered by this agreement. Indeed, the text proposes differential regimes according to the size of industrial facilities. It also includes exemptions until 2030 for certain types of installations such as district heating systems or biomass-related facilities.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Since the possibility of full implementation of the Directives is limited by the degree of detail contained in the Directive and since the Directive of the European Parliament and the Council on the limitation of emissions of certain pollutants presents, on the one hand, regulatory inconsistencies with other directives and, on the other hand, formulations which can be interpreted differently, the rapporteur, in accordance with the principle of regulatory improvement , proposes amendments to the legislative text in order to clarify the Directive and to allow for a more uniform transposition throughout the Community area. It should be noted that, as a general rule, emissions of air pollutants from medium combustion plants are not regulated at European Union level and only by this proposal will it be possible to set limit values for existing and future installations, in line with the Community emission reduction obligations. Because I believe that, as defined by the proposal, the compromise solution found between the burdens of society and the economy and air quality is fair, I voted in favour of the proposed amendments.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. In the midst of the Volkswagen scandal over pollution test fraud targeting 11 million diesel vehicles worldwide, MEPs adopted important air quality legislation this afternoon. The new legislation affects around 143,000 medium-sized combustion plants in the EU. These equipments, with a thermal capacity of between 1 and 50 MW, are used for various applications (electricity, domestic and industrial heating and cooling, etc.). Unlike small and large combustion plants, they are not currently covered by EU legislation, although they are responsible for an increase in particulate emissions (PM). I supported this first reading agreement with the Council, as I did on 15 July in the Committee on The Environment. A compromise that gives national authorities the opportunity to introduce stricter limit values than those set by the directive.  Efforts will have to continue at all levels of power because, as the European Environment Agency points out, air pollution poses direct risks to humans and the environment: particulate matter concentrations are responsible for more than 400,000 premature deaths each year in the EU. An unacceptable figure!

name: Michèle Rivasi (Verts/ALE)
text: In writing. Even if this text is less ambitious than what environmentalists are advocating, it will put an end to the European legal vacuum in this area. While emissions from larger facilities were already regulated, medium combustion facilities such as those used to produce electricity, heat or steam for industrial purposes were not yet regulated. Member States had made very lax proposals to limit emissions, but environmentalists fought to improve the text. We have secured action to increase the energy efficiency of these facilities.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. At present, emissions of air pollutants from medium-sized combustion plants - i.e. electricity generators or heating systems for domestic or industrial use - are not regulated at EU level, unlike large and small installations. These facilities are responsible for significant emissions of sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxides and dust. In total, some 143,000 installations are affected in the European Union.  That is why I voted in favour of the resolution to limit emissions from medium-sized combustion plants. Given that more than 400,000 deaths a year are attributed to air pollution, that it has a considerable impact on the environment and causes significant economic damage, there is an urgent need to act to ensure better air quality for European citizens. And if the caps are ambitious, we call on Member States to introduce stricter limits in areas that do not meet European air quality standards.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. We all agree on the harms of air pollution for public health and the environment. If we want effective results we have to go to the source of pollution. This Directive presents provisions on medium combustion plants (150,000 in the EU), setting limit values for new and existing installations, together with a simple registration system, aimed at member states complying with the reduction of polluting emissions. An EU climate policy will only be credible globally if combined with a competitive industrial strategy but with a strong emphasis on sustainability and innovation. Of course, I voted in favour of this report, with the exception of two points of an amendment (87) introduced by the ENVI Commission which provides for the exception of the Directive for the Canary Islands, Madeira, the Azores and the French Islands. The argument put forward for the exception is based solely on the increase in financial burdens and logistical difficulties inherent in an island which, if true, cannot prevail over the quality of life of the population. Air quality must be guaranteed in all European regions, whether or not they are outermost regions. There are no first and second-rate citizens.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. The approximately 150,000 medium combustion plants in the EU are an important source of emission of sulfide dioxide, nitrogen oxide and suspended particles, with serious consequences for human health and the environment. This Directive aims at monitoring and reducing emissions of sulphur, nitrogen and particulate matter in suspension. The agreement reached with the Council sets a maximum limit on emissions of sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxide and suspended particulate matter from current combustion plants with thermal production above 5 MW, which will enter into force from 2025. Smaller installations, with thermal production of 1 to 5 MW, mostly used by SMEs, will have to meet emission limits from 2030. Legislation does not prevent Member States from tightening the standards required by the Directive.  The agreement reached with the Council is good in order to continue improving the air quality we breathe in Europe and that is why I have supported it favourably with my vote.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this European directive which will limit the emissions of certain air pollutants from medium-sized combustion plants, such as electricity generators and heating or cooling systems for domestic or industrial use. This vote confirms the agreement reached at first reading on 23 June by negotiators from Parliament, the European Commission and the Council of the EU on this legislation which, for the first time, will regulate the pollution of the 143,000 installations with a thermal capacity of 1 to 50 megaWatt.  Emission limits for sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxides and particulate emissions from existing combustion plants of more than 5 MW will come into force in 2025 as proposed by the European Commission. But smaller installations with a thermal capacity of between 1 and 5 MW, usually used by SMEs, will not have to meet the limit values until 2030. In areas that violate EU air quality standards, Member States will be required to assess whether to set more stringent limits. The text introduces rules for monitoring carbon monoxide.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. The fight against emissions into the atmosphere of certain pollutants from medium combustion plants is at the heart of this proposal for a directive. In fact, there is a gap in this area, which stems from the absence of any specific regulation at European level that applies to emissions of air pollutants from medium combustion plants, which deserves to be closed not only to give greater legislative coherence but also to reduce harmful impacts on the environment, and not least to combat the harmful effects that these emissions produce on human health. It is also important to highlight another important aspect which regulations in this area will include and which concerns the significant contribution that reducing emissions from medium combustion plants will have in achieving the EU's climate and energy objectives by reducing greenhouse gases, improving energy efficiency and promoting renewable energy.  With the adoption of these measures, a clear signal will be given in favour of new investments, creating more incentives for research and innovation in cutting-edge technologies, enabling European companies to take a leading position in green innovation. For the reasons put forward above, I voted in favour.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which sets emission limits for two pollutants for medium-sized combustion plants (1 to 50 MW): sulphur dioxide and nitrogen oxide. In particular, this text makes it possible to fill the European legal vacuum at the level of medium combustion facilities, since the Commission's original proposal did not regulate them. It should also be noted that the Commission will have to take into account the results of its study on carbon monoxide, which is being monitored.  This report thus allows advances in the control of certain pollutants in the atmosphere.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the agreement reached between the European Parliament and the Council on limiting emissions into the atmosphere of certain pollutants produced by medium combustion plants (thermal power from 1 to 50 MW).  There are around 150 000 such plants in the European Union that are used in various areas: electricity generation, domestic heating, heat generation for industrial processes. It was considered essential to control and limit their emissions from the point of view of the European policy of reducing pollution, with care not to increase administrative complexity and not to inhibit future investment.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of limiting emissions of pollutants (such as carbon monoxide, sulfide dioxide and nitrogen oxides) in medium-flue plants, as a measure aimed at reducing the amount of greenhouse gases emitted into the atmosphere from the territory of the European Union in the context of combating climate change. We also position ourselves AGAINST the paragraph of the report which sought to exclude from the Directive certain EU territories, such as the Canary Islands, on the understanding that all EU citizens must be guaranteed the same air quality standards, regardless of the territory in which they live.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it eliminates the exemptions established by the European Commission as regards the emission limits of pollutants in the ultra-peripheral regions of the European Union. These exemptions initially established by the European Commission are in a position to justify in the relative isolation of European energy networks, giving greater scope to power plants located in these territories in order to further pollute the air. The report understands that these exemptions can only worsen the quality of breathed air in many urban centres in the aforementioned regions such as the Canary Islands in Spain. That is why I have decided to support this report.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 There are approximately 150 000 average combustion plants in the European Union used for a wide range of applications (electricity generation, domestic/residential heating and cooling, heat/steam production for industrial processes, etc.). They are an important source of emissions of sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxides and particulates. Unlike small and large combustion plants, which are covered by Directives 2009/125/EC and 2010/75/EU, medium combustion plants were not regulated at European level to date. I have therefore chosen to vote in favour of this report.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. This legislation welcomes and positively illustrates the effort to identify and develop synergies between air quality, the impact of polluting substances on human life and the environment and the need to mitigate global climate change. The proposals voted on require the existing technology to be adjusted to the emission limits proposed by the Commission and using realistic targets. The exception to the outermost regions in this area is essential. This way recognises the impact of insularity on logistical and technical aspects of the energy response in these regions, which are characterised by a dispersed and relatively small population occupation. The Azores, the region from which I come, are an example of a broadly positive balance in terms of preserving the environment thanks to a continuous commitment to the defense of its natural, landscape and cultural heritage. This is a journey that we will continue to go realistically.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this because I do not wish for the EU to create more legislation in this field. I also oppose the proposed mandatory EU registration scheme to be applied to all new plants. I do however recognise the importance of improving air quality.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The report addresses very well the problem of poor air quality. I voted for this report because poor air quality is a serious threat to health and to the environment. We need to move towards a credible EU climate policy.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 In line with the opinion of the ECR faction, I was in favour of this resolution. Protecting the environment is a matter of survival for future generations. That is also why we must approach this issue responsibly and also commit medium combustion plants to limiting emissions emitted. The hunt for profit can never be more important than maintaining air quality.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ Over the last decade, air pollutant emissions have been significantly reduced, but at the same time air pollution levels remain problematic in many parts of Europe. Union citizens continue to be exposed to air pollutants and potentially harm their health and well-being. There are around 150 000 medium-strength combustion plants in the EU, i.e. biomass combustion with nominal heat between 1 and 50 MW. They are used for various purposes (including electricity, domestic/residential heating and cooling and the provision of heat/steam for industrial processes, etc.) and are an important source of emissions of sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxides and dust.  In plenary, I voted to change the directive containing provisions for medium-sized incinerators. They are designed to make a significant contribution to reduce pollution of nitrogen oxide, sulphur dioxide and dust where limits have been set for new and existing installations, along with a simple registration scheme, to allow for a significant reduction in emissions of harmful gases in the air.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Although emissions of pollutants into the air have decreased significantly in recent decades, we are still seeing that air quality in many areas of the EU remains problematic and citizens are exposed to substances that potentially endanger their health and well-being. I therefore believe that it is our moral duty to look for new options on the basis of which the Union will manage to fall below the limits it has set itself. As around 150 000 medium combustion plants are currently in operation in the EU, which are an important source of emissions of sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxides and dust, it is essential to take measures to help Member States reduce emissions of certain pollutants into the air. I supported the resolution because I believe that regulating medium combustion plants with a rated thermal output of between 1 and 50 MW is one of the options that can create a more coherent regulatory environment, thus closing a major gap in current EU legislation. At the same time, I expect that the changes that the report is coming up with will become an important tool for improving air quality in the EU, without representing an unjustified burden on society and the economy.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. Emissions of air pollutants from medium combustion plants of around 150,000 in the EU are currently not regulated at EU level (small combustion plants are regulated by Directive 2009/125/EC and large combustion plants by Directive 2010/75/EU). Such combustion plants are used in several areas (electricity production, heating and cooling of households, heat/steam production for industrial processes) and constitute an important source of emissions of sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxides and dust. The Commission has therefore put forward a proposal to set limit values for new and existing installations which are expected to make a significant contribution to reducing pollution by sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxides and dust. It has also drawn up a simple registration process, which would make a significant contribution to meeting Member States' emission reduction obligations and prevent any trade-offs between air quality and increased use of biomass, which would otherwise lead to increased air pollution. As I agree that the proposed amendments would improve the chances of a realistic implementation of the directive and thus contribute to improving air quality in the EU without unduly burdening society and the economy, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour today on the new directive limiting emissions into the atmosphere of certain pollutants from medium-sized combustion plants. These are some 143 000 plants used mostly for electricity generation, domestic heating and heat or steam supply for industrial processes.  This fills the gap in European legislation on air quality in the combustion sector, which currently provides for two directives for small and large plants. Noting that in many regions air pollution levels still remain above the limits set by the Union and air quality standards do not even meet the objectives identified by the World Health Organisation, the directive introduces limits on pollutant emissions from fuel combustion in medium-sized plants – which are not yet regulated at Union level – as these contribute increasingly to air pollution. , in particular because of the wider use of biomass, induced by climate and energy policy. This measure is therefore useful for reducing air pollution and consequently the serious health and environmental risks arising from poor air quality.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. This report deals with the limitation of emissions of certain pollutants from medium-sized combustion plants. As part of the air quality package, the European Commission presented in December 2013 the proposal for a directive on reducing pollution from medium-sized combustion plants. The Directive will apply to combustion plants with a heat output of up to 50 megawatts; this applies in particular to large buildings and small industrial plants. It is proposed to introduce a registration requirement for medium-sized combustion plants and to set emission limits for pollutants produced by combustion plants, such as sulphur dioxide, nitrogen and particulate matter. While small and large combustion plants are regulated, emissions from medium-sized combustion plants are not regulated. There are currently no limit value proposals. However, the Commission is working on this. Our committee, ITRE, supports this report, essentially for these reasons: air pollution is a cross-border problem – that is why regulation at EU level is necessary.
