The aim is to fill a significant gap in EU law. According to an impact assessment by the Commission, the health costs of air pollution across Europe are around EUR 940 million per year. With this in mind, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. – Combustion plants significantly pollute the environment. Their operation should be both efficient and environmentally friendly. However, the setting of specific limits must remain in the hands of individual Member States.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I support this Report because the decision of the European Parliament and the Council confirms that pollutant emissions in the air are significantly reduced, but pollutant levels remain problematic in many parts of Europe and union citizens remain exposed to air pollutants. Therefore, in order to ensure a healthy environment for all, the Action Programme calls for complementary measures at local, national and Union level. However, the Union's international commitments on air pollution to combat acidification, eutrophication and ground-level ozone have been agreed by the Gothenburg Protocol to the Convention on Far-Reaching Cross-Border Air Pollution and to strengthen existing commitments to reduce sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxides, amonias and volatile organic compounds. Therefore, I believe that Member States should ensure that the operator of a medium-sized combustion plant and the competent authorities take the necessary measures in the event of a derogation from the provisions.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it forms a key element of the EU’s Clean Air Package and will reduce harmful emissions and improve air quality across the UK and the EU.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ There are around 150,000 medium combustion plants in the European Union, and most of them have an input heat power of between 1 and 50 MW. They are used for a number of purposes, including electricity generation, residential heating and cooling or to provide heat/steam for industrial installations. They are also large sources of emissions of sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxide and particulate matter. While small combustion plants are regulated by Directive 2010/75/EU, emissions of air pollutants from medium-sized installations are almost not regulated at EU level. The Commission proposal would also cover the regulation of such installations by setting limits for new and existing installations, as well as the establishment of a simple registration system, which would oblige Member States to reduce emissions of air pollutants. Although the air in my country, Croatia, is relatively clean, some areas such as Slavonski Brod in 2015 recorded increased air pollution, which could be a sign of concern. Despite the minor disagreements within the group, I nevertheless support this proposal to minimise air quality in Croatia and other EU Member States and to minimise the amount of harmful emissions.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained from voting on the proposal. It is more important than taxing smaller power plants to fight for an end to coal subsidies and for a reduction in overall emission limits. The emission limits currently set are ridiculously strict, as due to high electricity prices, many firms are going to China or India, for example, where environmental standards are at a much lower level and therefore the total amount of emissions is ultimately rising.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ I voted in favour of the report on limiting emissions of certain pollutants from medium combustion plants into the air. We have 150,000 medium-sized existing combustion plants in Europe, and under the new directive, new installations provide for registration and control over compliance and compliance with restrictions. This will preserve and improve air quality and protect citizens from further air pollution. This achieves better air quality without putting too much strain on the actors involved. This directive is a good combination of environmental protection, economic needs and social requirements, which can be implemented without excessive additional burden on managers and end-users.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The main objective of this proposal is to set emission limit values for the control of emissions of sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxides and particulate matter into the atmosphere from medium-sized combustion plants, as minimum standards for the protection of the environment and EU citizens. The aim is to improve the realistic applicability of the directive so that it can be an important instrument for improving air quality in the European Union without imposing undue burdens on society and the economy. As ACPL we voted in favour of the proposal as we felt it would contribute to reducing pollutant emissions and thus to protecting the environment. Nevertheless, we consider that small and medium-sized enterprises do not have the administrative capacity of larger companies to adapt and carry out all these necessary procedures. After all, for the largest share of pollutants in the atmosphere, it is not only the large industrial plants that are responsible, but above all the world's largest economies (USA, CHINA, etc.) and they are the ones who have to bear the burden of reductions.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 Although the report could be further improved, it is a positive step towards the protection of the environment and the health of European citizens.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that it is necessary to regulate the structures producing the highest air pollution, such as, in this case, medium-sized combustion plants (1-50 MW). I also agree on the need for reliable air pollution measurements and ambitious targets in the Member States. Unfortunately, air quality in many zones of the Union still does not meet the limits set or the targets set by the World Health Organisation. I believe that a strong message has been delivered that the European Parliament is committed to creating cleaner air. But, of course, we have to go further, because unfortunately the constant, small regulation is time-consuming. I believe that, in addition to reducing emissions, we must support alternative energy sources.

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against this report, which further weakens the European Commission's already weak proposal to impose emission limit values for medium combustion plants. Regulating and limiting emissions from medium-sized installations is of fundamental importance in order to protect the environment and human health, as well as to reduce the social and economic costs of air pollution. First of all, to tighten the emission limits, adapting them to what can be achieved through the innovations of existing technologies. Secondly, to include dioxins, furans and mercury among the pollutants subject to an emission ceiling. Unfortunately, our efforts have been in vain. Not only that: the report that has come to the vote of the European Parliament provides for even longer periods than those outlined by the European Commission for the entry into force of emission limits and increases the number of plants exempted from the directive.  We have tabled an amendment to plenary to include at least offshore platforms among the installations subject to the directive: it has not been approved. In the light of all this, I could only say no to this report. And I said it with regret: we wasted an opportunity.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Air pollution is one of the key environmental problems that our societies are currently facing. The lack of a proper quality of breathing air can create many long-term health problems for us and our children. From this perspective, it is necessary to adopt a unified view of the European Union with a view to reducing carbon dioxide emissions at a general level.  This document represents an important step towards limiting these pollutant emissions (sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxides and particulate matter) by establishing clear rules for pollution resulting from the activities of medium combustion plants. The regulations complement existing European legislation concerning internal combustion plants of large enterprises and small plants. Overall, these measures contribute to the climate change policies that the Union has undertaken.  Of course, the application of these measures will require a transitional period for those installations to be adapted to the new environmental rules. The transition period may vary depending on the size and profile of the installations, the impact on the population. Ultimately, however, these measures will help to improve living conditions for all Union citizens.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. The proposed changes improve the prospects for a realistic implementation of the directive, so that it can become an important instrument for improving air quality in the European Union, without imposing an unjustified burden on society and the economy seem realistic to me. Unfortunately, we had to compromise, but I finally voted for the text.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report with the view to fill a legislation gap in which emissions of air pollutants from medium combustion plants are generally not yet regulated at the EU level. The directive proposal is designed to reduce pollution by NOx, SO2 and dust by setting limit values for new and existing installations, together with a simple registration scheme, in order to help deliver a significant part of Member States’ emission reduction obligations and avoid possible trade-offs between air quality and increased biomass use, which may result in higher air pollution. The directive should apply to combinations formed by two or more combustion plants having a total rated thermal input equal to or greater than 1 MW and less than 50 MW, unless the combination is a combustion plant covered by Chapter III of Directive 2010/75/EU on industrial emissions.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D)
text: In writing. While polluting emissions from small and large combustion appliances are regulated by EU legislation, there is a legal vacuum on medium combustion appliances. These appliances, with a power of 1 and 50 MW, are numerous in our daily lives since they are for example electric generators or domestic and residential heating. The EPP rapporteur wanted to lower the ambitions of the European Commission, but the Socialists fought and 150,000 aircraft will have to meet new ecological requirements. On the eve of COP 21 in Paris, I therefore voted in favour of this report, in order to enable the European Commission to quickly propose binding legislation, able to continue to achieve our targets for reducing greenhouse gas emissions.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I supported a directive to limit emissions of certain air pollutants from medium combustion areas, which has not been regulated by EU laws until now.  I believe that the environmental and health of EU citizens will be of utmost importance to limit the emissions of sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxides and dust from these installations, and I strongly support the possibility for Member States to maintain or introduce stricter safeguards, if this is in line with environmental quality standards.  As the directive recognises the need for flexibility in relation to installations used only in exceptional circumstances due to technical and logistical problems related to certain sites, I believe that a provision is particularly useful by which Member States should set limit values themselves in the case of those installations in order to reduce their air emissions and potential risks to human health.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. - I supported the report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on limiting emissions of certain pollutants from medium combustion plants into the air, as it seeks to limit sulphur dioxide and nitrogen oxide in the EU for emissions of medium combustion plants. These include electric generators and heating systems for domestic, residential or industrial buildings. In areas where the emissions of these installations violate eu air quality standards, it is right to call on EU Member States to judge for themselves whether stricter restrictions should be imposed.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of limiting emissions of pollutants (such as carbon monoxide, sulfide dioxide and nitrogen oxides) in medium-flue plants, as a measure aimed at reducing the amount of greenhouse gases emitted into the atmosphere from the territory of the European Union in the context of combating climate change. We also position ourselves AGAINST the paragraph of the report which sought to exclude from the Directive certain EU territories, such as the Canary Islands, on the understanding that all EU citizens must be guaranteed the same air quality standards, regardless of the territory in which they live.

name: Evžen Tošenovský (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported this report. As the individual measurements in the border territories of the Member States show, some areas suffer from significant air pollution. Pollution from one country thus impacts on the territory of another state, with various exceptions often in each country. Trying to solve this problem caused by smaller resources is certainly important. It is, of course, complicated to rationally influence very small resources. But limiting emissions from a large number of these resources on a large area is also a real problem. In order to achieve a real result in reducing air pollution, we need to take a comprehensive approach to this issue, so that this is not only administratively required regulation, but also that incentive tools, including the necessary awareness-raising, accompany the steps. There is also a need to stimulate interest in modernising these resources, whether in terms of promoting innovation or, for example, research into modern energy sources meeting the required tightened limits.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The Action Programme recognises that emissions of pollutants to air have been reduced significantly over the past decades, but at the same time air pollution levels are still problematic in many parts of Europe and citizens of the Union continue to be exposed to air polluting substances, potentially compromising their health and wellbeing. According to the Action Programme, ecosystems continue to suffer from excess nitrogen and sulphur deposition associated with emissions from transport, unsustainable agricultural practices and power generation. In many areas of the Union, air quality levels are still above the limits that the Union itself has set, and are still failing to meet the targets set by the World Health Organisation. I share these concerns and this is why I support this report.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The aim of this text is to fill a certain legislative vacuum and to make a contribution to the reduction of pollution in nitrogen oxide, sulphur dioxide and dust. The regulatory amendments are the responsibility of the Member States and weigh on the industry. By Community standards that have been taken out of the Commission's hat, by anti-industry provisions, for a risky ecological and public health benefit, this text is at odds with the national interest and the general European interest. I voted against it.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of limiting emissions of pollutants (such as carbon monoxide, sulfide dioxide and nitrogen oxides) in medium-flue plants, as a measure aimed at reducing the amount of greenhouse gases emitted into the atmosphere from the territory of the European Union in the context of combating climate change. We also position ourselves AGAINST the paragraph of the report which sought to exclude from the Directive certain EU territories, such as the Canary Islands, on the understanding that all EU citizens must be guaranteed the same air quality standards, regardless of the territory in which they live.

name: Владимир Уручев (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Dear Colleagues, I voted for the adoption of legislation to limit emissions from medium-sized combustion plants (1 to 50 MW) for which there have been no environmental restrictions so far. More than 143 000 such installations operate in the European Union and make a significant contribution to air pollution by nitrogen and sulphur oxides and dust. The most important thing in this legislation is adequate consideration of the small possibilities for adapting to the new requirements of small and medium-sized enterprises operating such thermal installations for heating schools, hospitals and public and residential buildings. Restrictions on new installations will take effect within three years. For installations with a thermal capacity of up to 5 MW, maximum emissions of sulphur dioxide, nitrogen dioxide and dust will enter into force from 2025.  Taking into account the statistics on air pollution in a number of cities of our country, the introduction of these restrictions will unconditionally contribute to improving air quality, healthier living conditions for citizens and especially children.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on the limitation of emissions of certain pollutants into the air, in order to achieve the improvement of air quality, with proper safeguards for the operation of existing plants. The envisaged legislation does not prevent Member States from enforcing tougher standards than are required by the directive, and in some areas national authorities would be required to assess whether to introduce stricter limits. This legislation fills a legislative gap and also addresses the ‘medium’ combustion plants in the EU, i.e. those with a thermal input rated between 1 and 50 MW. They are used for a wide variety of applications, such as electricity generation, domestic or residential heating and cooling and providing heat or vapour for industrial processes.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. We are talking about an issue that has required several negotiations to achieve a balanced compromise between political groups. As a result, it was approved by a large majority in the committee on the environment. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in favour of that report.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it eliminates the exemptions established by the European Commission as regards the emission limits of pollutants in the ultra-peripheral regions of the European Union. These exemptions initially established by the European Commission are in a position to justify in the relative isolation of European energy networks, giving greater scope to power plants located in these territories in order to further pollute the air. The report understands that these exemptions can only worsen the quality of breathed air in many urban centres in the aforementioned regions such as the Canary Islands in Spain. That is why I have decided to support this report.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it forms a key element of the EU’s Clean Air Package and will reduce harmful emissions and improve air quality across the UK and the EU. The report will improve environmental standards and although it will increase costs in certain areas the benefits far outweigh these. Furthermore, jobs in sectors where costs were deemed disproportionate (e.g. offshore oil and gas in Scotland) have been protected by specific exemptions and derogations. Therefore this legislation balances economic well-being with the overwhelming need to act now to save our planet.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This report proposes to limit greenhouse gas emissions from so-called medium-sized combustion plants, i.e. those with thermal capacity of between 1 and 50 MW.  This category was previously not regulated by European standards, although it is a major source of gas emissions and affects nearly 150,000 installations in the European Union used for domestic or industrial purposes.  I regret that the text has not been able to impose lower emission thresholds as we wished, but it is important to continue to set limits for new installations such as these. I also deplore certain parts of the directive on the exclusion of the outermost regions, in particular the French overseas departments. The decline of the French and Spanish right, justified by so-called technical problems in the installation of these standards, is quite reprehensible. It excludes a whole part of European citizens as well as the territories on which they live from the protection of nature and fragile ecosystems.  I am voting for this directive anyway because its aim is to reduce emissions of polluting gases and it allows the European Parliament to send a new signal just a few weeks before COP 21.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The proposal for a Directive sets emission limits for sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxides and particulatematter from medium combustion plants. On 23 June 2015, the European Parliament and the Council reached an interim agreement on the proposal. Around 75% of average combustion plants are managed by SMEs. Care must be taken not to impose an excessive administrative burden. On the other hand, it is important to see the context in which they operate, either by virtue of the climate or depending on the geographical location, with particular emphasis on the island territories of the EU countries.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. In itself, uniform regulation of the emission limits of medium-sized combustion plants (as already exists in small and large combustion plants) makes sense and is desirable from the point of view of environmental protection. However, as this will mainly burden SMEs (there are around 150,000 medium-sized combustion plants [burning heat output between 1-50 megawatts] in the areas of electricity generation, heating/cooling of households, generation of heat/steam for industry) in terms of administrative and financial burdens, I will abstain from voting on this report.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I do not agree with the regulation of emissions from combustion plants with a capacity of between 1 and 50 MW. The main reason is that this area has so far been without EU regulation. But two other reasons are also crucial. Firstly, it has been agreed to exclude combustion plants offshore and in certain areas, such as French overseas. If regulation is so good, it should apply in general and equally to everyone. If regulation needs exceptions from the scope, then it is bad. It makes no difference where air pollution is caused. I supported the relevant amendments. Secondly, the Commission is given the power to set the limit values. I believe that this is a task for the legislator. Since there are insufficient possibilities for the Control of the Commission by the European Parliament, and certainly no responsibility, I am opposed to the further erosion of the democratic principle, which is already weak at European level.

name: Julie Ward (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it forms a key element of the EU’s Clean Air Package and will reduce harmful emissions and improve air quality across the UK and the EU.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted on the report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on limiting emissions into the atmosphere of certain pollutants from medium combustion plants. According to the Commission's impact assessment, air pollution is estimated to lead to more than 400 000 premature deaths per year and to medical costs of up to EUR 940 billion; contribute to significant environmental degradation. The report shows that reducing emissions from medium combustion plants can contribute to the achievement of the Union's climate and energy targets.  I welcome the approach of the rapporteur who, in his proposal, took into account the special situation of the SME sector. Given that 75 % of medium combustion plants are operated by SMEs, the report states, it is necessary to proceed very carefully in order not to impose an excessive administrative burden on them.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The report concerns combustion plants with a capacity of 1 to 50 MW, which have not yet been covered by emission regulations in Union legislation. As these plants are sources of emissions of sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxides and particulate matter, the European Commission has proposed a directive on medium combustion plants as part of its proposed clean air policy package. The limits initially proposed by the European Commission were too restrictive and would result in too much cost for medium-sized combustion plants, of which there are around 3600 in Poland and more than 140 000 in the EU as a whole. The trilogue has succeeded in creating a balanced text whose regulations and emission standards can be implemented without incurring costs disproportionate to the benefits. I voted in favour of the text of the report.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which improves Community legislation and strengthens the application of the rules on pollution reduction in the EU. Medium-sized combustion plants concern sectors such as domestic heating and electricity generation.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 Medium combustion plants, unlike small and large combustion plants, did not have a common European arrangement, despite the fact that there are approximately 150 000 in operation in the European Union and as plants used to produce heat, cold or steam are important producers of air pollutants and burdensome human organisms. The report proposed emission limits for these combustion plants, which, although they will entail increased costs incurred to purchase new boilers or other necessary technical means during the transitional period after the directive took effect, we will be rewarded with a cleaner and, above all, more sustainable environment. I therefore decided to support the report after considering the positive and negative effects that the new emission limits will undoubtedly have on Slovakia, which has thousands of such medium combustion plants in operation.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on limiting emissions into the atmosphere of certain pollutants from medium combustion plants because I believe that air pollution is a truly transnational problem and that many Member States import a significant part of their air pollution from neighbouring countries.  To this end, action is imperative at EU level in order to establish a more coherent and ambitious regulatory framework to combat polluting emissions into the atmosphere. Although these have been significantly reduced over the last few decades, air pollution levels are still problematic in many parts of Europe and Union citizens continue to be exposed to polluting substances, which potentially undermine their health and well-being. This report thus emerges as an important tool for improving air quality in the European Union and is an excellent opportunity to improve the regulation on the emission of certain pollutants, without imposing unjustified burdens on society and the economy.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The medium combustion plants are an important source of sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxideand particulate emissions (fine dust) and are used for very diverse purposes, such as electricity generation, domestic/residential heating and cooling and the production of heat and/or steam for industrial processes.  Emissions of air pollutants from medium combustion plants (as is the case with small and large installations) are generally not regulated at EU level. This proposal is intended to fill this gap. The proposal sets emission limits for sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxides and particulatematter.  We have supported the proposed exceptions for the Archipelagos of Madeira and the Azores, which seem to us to be entirely justified, taking into account their specific nature and situation, and there should be another framework.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur Casein is in the group phosphoprotein, which accounts for up to four fifths of the total protein in mammalian milk. In human milk, this amounts to between 20% and 45%. In other words, casein is a completely natural chemical substance that is formed, including in the human body. More about it, casein contains all the essential amino acids and is therefore an important food protein. Despite the above and the general naturalness of casein, there are international standards that need to be correlated in Europe in order to guarantee, among other things, the availability of European casein-containing foodstuffs on the international market. Another very important factor for goods is that standardisation on this issue would help consumers to orient themselves more effectively in food products available to them in any Member State of the European Union. I voted in favour. Thank you!

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I supported this proposal for a regulation. At first glance, it may seem that this is a complex administrative regulation that will complicate the lives of citizens and businesses. But the opposite is true. I am convinced that the harmonisation of standards for caseins, the establishment of clear conditions for their humidity and composition, on the contrary, will lead to uniform rules applicable to the food industry throughout the territory of the European Union. These are standards that have been prepared and recognized by international specialized organizations. I think that this will help industry, it will also help individual consumers, because they will be sure that caseins and caseinates meet the quality that they are being asked to do, say, by these technical standards. Overall, this is another way of breaking down internal barriers in the European Union's internal market.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Today UKIP voted against the La Via report on the proposal for a directive on the approximation of the laws of the Member States relating to caseins and caseinates intended for human consumption.  We believe in preserving the health and well-being of citizens by guaranteeing transparency when it comes to the ingredients of the food they consume. We also support food business operators and understand their need to have all the necessary information at their disposal when labelling the final products, especially when it comes to allergens. However, the reasoning behind this vote concerned the alignment of the powers conferred upon the Commission by the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, which we are not prepared to support.  We do not believe that these issues should be defined at an EU level. We oppose the drafting of further EU legislation and we believe that each Member State should have the autonomy to decide whether and how to legislate on these issues. We believe in the right of sovereign nations to establish their own policies.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report on the Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the approximation of the laws of the Member States relating to caseins and caseinates intended for human consumption. I believe that it introduces more regulation on these substances and positive developments on the original proposal so that consumers have the proper information.  The products subject to the proposal (caseins and caseinates) are not oriented to the sale to the final consumer, but only between companies for the production of food products, but it is important that citizens have all the information they need in the labelling of the final products. The proposal therefore includes provisions on the labelling of caseins and caseinates intended for human consumption. In the event that the mandatory information established is not on packaging, containers or labels, these products may not be placed on the market as food caseins or caseinates or used for food processing.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The report recommends changing the maximum milk fat content of dietary acid casein (from 2.25% to 2%) and the maximum humidity level of food casein (from 10% to 12%). These changes will be imposed on producers and players in the agri-food sector. According to the Commission, these changes will improve the competitiveness of European producers who would then be placed back in "fair conditions on the world market".  In addition, the report confirms the desire to delegate to the Commission the power to adopt acts that allow the rapid adaptation of this regulation to "international standards and future technical progress (sic!)". In the context of the obscure TTIP negotiations, it is recommended that attempts to align with international standards strongly subject to the commercial aims of globalist institutions should be opposed.  So I objected to this report

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I believe in transparency in food labelling. Therefore, it follows that I also believe that food business operators must have the information they need in order to be able to provide the relevant information for the final product. As a nut allergy sufferer myself, I recognise the issues specifically surrounding allergens. My only concern is that this should be coming not from the European Union but from Member States.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this deliberation as advocated by the committee on its merits.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to repeal Directive 83/417/EEC on the approximation of the laws of the Member States relating to certain caseins and caseinates intended for human consumption. The purpose of this Directive is to replace the new provisions in force in order to take account of further improvements in legislation, in particular as regards food law. In addition, the composition requirements for edible caseins must be adapted to the international standard, the Codex Alimentarius. Such harmonisation will ensure a level playing field for food business operators on the world market. I support the labelling requirements for casein and caseinates, which will enable consumers, in particular those who are allergic to or intolerant to a particular food, to choose foods that are safe for them with sufficient information.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Today UKIP voted against the La Via report on the proposal for a directive on the approximation of the laws of the Member States relating to caseins and caseinates intended for human consumption. We believe in preserving the health and well-being of citizens by guaranteeing transparency when it comes to the ingredients of the food they consume. We also support food business operators and understand their need to have all the necessary information at their disposal when labelling the final products, especially when it comes to allergens. However, the reasoning behind this vote concerned the alignment of the powers conferred upon the Commission by the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, which we are not prepared to support. We do not believe that these issues should be defined at an EU level. We oppose the drafting of further EU legislation and we believe that each Member State should have the autonomy to decide whether and how to legislate on these issues. We believe in the right of sovereign nations to establish their own policies.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. This report aims to support the Commission in its global "harmonisation" approach: in view of the EU's trade policies, such harmonisation risks lowering our food safety standards.  In general, in the context of the TTIP/TTIP negotiations, I oppose attempts to align with international standards that are highly subject to North American interests. That is why I voted against it.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. In March 2014, the Commission published a proposal for a directive from Parliament and the Council on bringing Member States' legislation closer to caseins and caseins for human consumption. It repeals the old directive on the subject and aligns EU legislation with international standards for caseins and caseinates. The proposal must be placed in the context of general food legislation which aims at the free movement of safe and healthy foodstuffs. In this regard, the new labelling requirements will allow consumers, especially those with allergies, to make their choices by being properly informed. I approved this report.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This report on caseins and caseéinates for human consumption should allow for harmonization and updating of regulations on certain lactoproteins used in the production of food for human consumption. The report proposes two main changes in the maximum humidity level of food casein (from 10% to 12%) and the maximum milk fat content of food acid casein (from 2.25% to 2%). Nevertheless, this development should allow for an alignment with the international standards described in the Codex Alimentarius, whose provisions should not, however, be a brake on world trade. The Commission also mentions the increase in competitiveness of this directive for producers and the report finally confirms the desire to delegate to the Commission the power to take action. It is therefore argued here for global harmonisation, especially since the EU trade policies on which we rely generally cause food safety standards to be revised downwards (especially with the uncertain future of the TTIP negotiations). So I voted against it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The La Via report analyses the new legislation on caseins and caseinated products intended for human consumption, which replaces the previous Directive 83/417/EEC; This act was necessary in order to bring the existing provisions into line with regulatory developments in the food sector and with the amendments introduced by the Treaty of Lisbon, which is why I voted in favour.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Legislative Resolution repealing Council Directive 83/417/EEC and adopting a new Directive on the approximation of the laws of the Member States relating to caseins and caseinates intended for human consumption. Parliament's work has made it possible to improve the Commission's text, betting on providing sufficient food information for the final consumer in business-to-business relations; update the definition of "casein" through a technical update; introduce a specific label for caseinates exceeding the minimum composition requirements for lactose proteins provided for in the Annex to the Directive; propose that the power to adopt delegated acts to adapt the annexes to international standards should not be conferred on the Commission for an unlimited period of time, but up to five years or propose an ambitious, if realistic, date for the implementation of this Directive in the Member States (12 months after the entry into force of this Directive).

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which deals with a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the approximation of the laws of the Member States relating to caseins and caseinates intended for human consumption. In this march 2014 report, the The Commission proposal proposes the repeal of the former directive on the approximation of the laws of the Member States relating to certain lactoproteins (caseins and caseinates) intended for human consumption and its replacement with a new Directive, as there is a need to improve the existing provisions and adapt the compositional requirements of edible caseins to an international standard (Codex Alimentary). The European Parliament supports the labelling requirements for casein and caseinates, which will enable consumers, in particular those who are allergic to or intolerant to a particular food, to choose foods that are safe for them with sufficient information. The proposal should be seen in the general context of food law, which aims to ensure the free movement of safe and healthy foods, and thus make a significant contribution to the health and well-being of citizens. It should therefore also be ensured that consumers are adequately informed about the food they consume.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 In early 2014, the Commission published a proposal for a directive aimed at concertation of the different laws of the Member States relating to caseins and caseinated products intended for human consumption. The final text proposes the modification of certain parameters in order to bring them into line with international regulations. The document provides for a maximum moisture content of food casein at 12% (compared to the 10% parameter previously provided for) and a maximum fat level of milk from food acid casein at 2% (compared to 2.25%), as well as the obligation to label the finished product by the percentages. It is therefore a dossier that I support, which ensures better levels of food safety control and standards for European consumers.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. I support this report because it is actually about aligning the old Directive 83/417 with the progress of other EU laws governing food and food information. Caseins and caseinates are widely used in human diets in all types of dairy products and therefore it is essential that they are well regulated. The proposed amendments to certain definitions and technical terms are in line with the current market situation.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I consider the alignment of the composition requirements concerning food houses with the Codex Alimentarius, which will guarantee food business operators equal treatment on the world market, very positive.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This report calls for harmonized regulations on the use of certain lactoproteins in the agri-food industry. The rapporteur proposes to increase the maximum humidity level of food casein from 10% to 12% and to lower the maximum milk fat content of food acid casein from 2.25% to 2%. These measures are part of the European Commission's desire to align itself with international standards that are intended to protect the consumer but which must in no way hinder trade. The aim of the European authorities is to increase the competitiveness of agri-food players before the ratification of the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership, which will exacerbate competition with US firms. We therefore oppose this text, whose adoption will lead to a collapse in food standards to the detriment of the consumer.  That is why I voted against it.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on caseins and caseinates intended for human consumption proposes to approximate the laws of the Member States relating to caseins and caseinates intended for human consumption, the need to derivfrom the requirements of adapting the composition requirements of edible caseins to the international standard. Thus, international standards require the setting of parameters related to the maximum moisture level of edible casein at 12 % (instead of 10 % as before) and the maximum milk fat content of edible acid casein at 2 % (instead of 2,25 %). The importance of these standards arises in the light of the context of general food legislation, which provides for ensuring the free movement of food products conducive to health that make a considerable contribution to the quality of life of citizens. To this end, it will ensure that consumers are informed of the foods they consume, including provisions on the labelling of casein and caseinates intended for human consumption. I was in favour of this report because I believe that food health and safety should be given due importance so that the citizens of the Union benefit from a healthy life, conducive to harmonious development and in line with international standards.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote in favour. The Directive brings national legislation on the regulation of certain lactoproteins intended for human consumption closer together.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I have today voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the approximation of the laws of the Member States relating to caseins and caseinated products intended for human consumption and repealing Council Directive 83/417/EEC. I believe that the Commission's efforts to strengthen food safety are to be welcomed. I am therefore in favour of legislative proposals such as the one voted on, which aims to integrate EU legislation into the broader framework of international food law. This measure will also have an impact on the information on the label that final consumers will be able to obtain. Labelling requirements for caseins and caseinates will enable consumers to make informed and informed choices, particularly in the presence of food allergies or intolerances. With today's vote, Parliament has therefore given an important impetus to the development of milk products on the market, especially if they are destined for cheese processing. The European Union must support the quality of European products, which can guarantee safety standards and guarantee new outlets, prospects and competitiveness to a sector of fundamental importance for European agriculture.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. It is a simple alignment procedure to the Lisbon Treaty on edible milk proteins. The European Parliament managed to limit an indefinite period of delegated acts for the Commission to five years with a review procedure but apart from that it mainly concerned technical issues.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Today UKIP voted against the La Via report on the proposal for a directive on the approximation of the laws of the Member States relating to caseins and caseinates intended for human consumption. We believe in preserving the health and well-being of citizens by guaranteeing transparency when it comes to the ingredients of the food they consume. We also support food business operators and understand their need to have all the necessary information at their disposal when labelling the final products, especially when it comes to allergens. However, the reasoning behind this vote concerned the alignment of the powers conferred upon the Commission by the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, which we are not prepared to support. We do not believe that these issues should be defined at an EU level. We oppose the drafting of further EU legislation and we believe that each Member State should have the autonomy to decide whether and how to legislate on these issues. We believe in the right of sovereign nations to establish their own policies.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because the proposed amendments to the directive allow for harmonisation of composition and labelling requirements to international standards as set out in the Codex Alimentarius, which will allow for better regulation, which, in turn, will benefit consumers. The proposal aims to improve the flow of information between the producers whose products contain caseins and caseinates which will lead to better understanding and better labelling of the final products that will reach consumers.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report sets out Parliament's position on the proposal for a directive presented by the Commission on the approximation of the laws of the Member States relating to caseins and caseinated products intended for human consumption. Parliament's intervention brings improvements to the text of the proposal, which concern both health and food safety through labelling and precise information aimed at the consumer. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (ENF)
text: In writing. The rapporteur suggests following the Commission in a process of harmonising and updating regulations on certain lactoproteins used in the production of food for human consumption. The aim is to support the Commission in a global harmonisation and based on the Union's trade policies, which generally have the effect of lowering food safety standards. I therefore objected to this text.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Food products for human use are regulated by strict legislation, especially with regard to labelling, which allows consumers to receive the most information possible to make informed choices. It should be remembered that the harmonisation of labelling between the countries of the European Union has facilitated the free movement of food within the single market and has also facilitated greater marketing of food on international markets. Although caseins and caseinated products are intended for sale between companies and not to the consumer, it was important to provide in the proposal for a directive, the obligation for operators in the sector to affix the percentages used on the label of the finished product, especially since we are faced with substances that often cause allergies and intolerances. I therefore welcome the Commission's proposal also because it brings the requirements for the composition of caseins and caseinates into line with the relevant Codex Alimentarius rules, and this will ensure equal treatment for operators in the sector on the world market.   However, over and above the purely technical issues foreseen in the proposal for a directive, I voted in favour because the obligations to advertise the ingredients provided for in it go in the right direction: to protect and inform European consumers.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 This is the proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the approximation of the laws of the Member States relating to casein and caseinates intended for human use and consumption and the repeal of Directive 83/417/EEC. The proposal forms part of general food legislation aimed at the free movement of safe and healthy food, thereby making a significant contribution to the health and well-being of citizens.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this measure concerning caseins and caseinates intended for human consumption. The Commission's proposal aims to update Directive 83/417/EEC in order to adapt the requirements for the composition of food cases to the international standard (Codex Alimentarius), to bring the powers conferred on the Commission into line with the distinction between delegated acts and implementing acts introduced by the Treaty of Lisbon and to adapt the existing provisions to developments in food law.  With regard to compliance with international standards, the Commission proposes in particular to set the maximum moisture content of food casein at 12% (compared with the 10% parameter previously provided for) and the maximum fat content of drinking acid casein milk at 2% (compared with 2.25%). The proposal must be seen in the context of general food legislation which aims to ensure the free movement of safe and healthy food, thereby making a significant contribution to the health and well-being of citizens. Finally, this proposal includes provisions on the labelling of caseins and caseinated products intended for human consumption.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal because I believe that it should be considered in the context of general food legislation, and above all because it aims to ensure the free movement of safe and healthy food, thereby contributing significantly to the health and well-being of citizens.  I also believe that it is appropriate to ensure that consumers are properly informed about the food they consume. Although the products covered by the proposal (caseins and caseinated) are not intended for sale to the final consumer, but only for sale between food preparation companies, it is important that food business operators have the necessary data for the labelling of finished products, in particular with regard to allergens.  Finally, I agree with the rapporteur, in particular with regard to the positive assessment of the alignment of the composition requirements concerning food houses with the Codex Alimentarius, which will guarantee food business operators equal treatment on the world market.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Today UKIP voted against the La Via report on the proposal for a directive on the approximation of the laws of the Member States relating to caseins and caseinates intended for human consumption. We believe in preserving the health and well-being of citizens by guaranteeing transparency when it comes to the ingredients of the food they consume. We also support food business operators and understand their need to have all the necessary information at their disposal when labelling the final products, especially when it comes to allergens. However, the reasoning behind this vote concerned the alignment of the powers conferred upon the Commission by the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, which we are not prepared to support. We do not believe that these issues should be defined at an EU level. We oppose the drafting of further EU legislation and we believe that each Member State should have the autonomy to decide whether and how to legislate on these issues. We believe in the right of sovereign nations to establish their own policies.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report because, for me, measures for safe and healthy handling of food are a high priority. Consumers should be adequately informed about the food they eat. Although the products covered by the proposal – caseins and caseinates – are not intended for sale to the final consumer, but are only necessary for trade between companies producing food, food businesses must have the information they need to label the final product. This is especially true for allergens.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this legislative report. It is a very important objective to ensure the free movement of safe and healthy food, improving the health of European citizens.  In addition to the aspects of alignment of composition requirements concerning food cases, I supported this text because labelling requirements are introduced for caseins and caseinated products that will improve information and consequently citizens' awareness of the choice of products to buy and consume.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the European Commission's proposal on the approximation of Member States' legislation on caseins and caseinates intended for human consumption in March 2014, the ENVI Committee has proposed improvements to the amendments to which I fully support.  These include: the repeal of Directive 83/417/EEC on the approximation of the laws of the Member States relating to certain milk proteins intended for feedingstuffs; to set the maximum moisture content of food casein at 12% and that of fats in sour food casein milk at 2%, changes which will lead to fairer competition and alignment of European legislation with international legislation.  In addition, a new directive is planned in the food sector aimed at adapting the requirements for the composition of food cases to the international standard (Codex Alimentarius) FAO. Finally, the amendments provide for a more accurate transmission of information between operators and end consumers and the possibility for producers to use a higher percentage of protein than those provided for in the directive, provided that the level on the labels is clearly indicated.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report on the Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the approximation of the laws of the Member States relating to caseins and caseinates intended for human consumption. I believe that it introduces more regulation on these substances and positive developments on the original proposal so that consumers have the proper information.  The products subject to the proposal (caseins and caseinates) are not oriented to the sale to the final consumer, but only between companies for the production of food products, but it is important that citizens have all the information they need in the labelling of the final products. The proposal therefore includes provisions on the labelling of caseins and caseinates intended for human consumption. In the event that the mandatory information established is not on packaging, containers or labels, these products may not be placed on the market as food caseins or caseinates or used for food processing.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Commission proposal and legislative resolution, for since several changes have taken place since the entry into force of the directive that provides for the approximation of the laws of the Member States relating to caseins and caseinates, and these need to be taken into account. Among the most positive points is the fact that the amendments to the Commission proposal provide that the power to adopt delegated acts, in order to adapt the annexes to the directive to international standards and technical progress, should not be conferred on the Commission for an unlimited period of time, but rather for five years.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the rapporteur's position, in particular for aligning the requirements for the composition of edible caseins with those imposed by Codex Alimentarius, thereby ensuring a level playing field for all food business operators on the world market.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report proposes a revision of the European legislative framework on lactoproteins (casein and caseinates) for human consumption. In particular, it seeks to adapt existing standards to changes in food law legislation and to bring the regulatory powers conferred on the European Commission in line with the new provisions of the Lisbon Treaty. This power granted to the European Commission will be reviewed every 5 years following the implementation of these new rules. Considering that this report is balanced, I have spoken in favour.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which was not a problem. It is important that all Member States have the same legislation on caseins and caseins. Food security is one of the European Parliament's priorities.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a directive on the approximation of the laws of the Member States relating to caseins and caseinated products intended for human consumption.  With the alignment of the composition requirements regarding food houses with codex Alimentarius, food operators will be guaranteed equal treatment on the world market. In addition, the labelling requirements for caseins and caseinates will allow consumers to make informed choices, particularly in the presence of food allergies or intolerances.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This report seeks to bring Member States' legislation in line with caseins and caseins for human consumption with international standards more dependent on free trade dogmas and globalism. If we observe, in this case, stricter criteria, this is nevertheless done at the expense of national sovereignty. Aligning European food and health safety criteria with international standards is often synonymous with further integration into the global market. If the defence of consumer health is a priority of my action, I cannot support a transfer of control of our regulatory system to an ill-defined global system. That is why I voted against this project.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. We are voting in favour because the report introduces significant changes to this directive, which protect public health and at the same time limit the Commission's uncontrolled action.

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Today UKIP voted against the La Via report on the proposal for a directive on the approximation of the laws of the Member States relating to caseins and caseinates intended for human consumption. We believe in preserving the health and well-being of citizens by guaranteeing transparency when it comes to the ingredients of the food they consume. We also support food business operators and understand their need to have all the necessary information at their disposal when labelling the final products, especially when it comes to allergens. However, the reasoning behind this vote concerned the alignment of the powers conferred upon the Commission by the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, which we are not prepared to support. We do not believe that these issues should be defined at an EU level. We oppose the drafting of further EU legislation and we believe that each Member State should have the autonomy to decide whether and how to legislate on these issues. We believe in the right of sovereign nations to establish their own policies.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD)
text: in writing. I am in favour of the directive on the approximation of the laws of the Member States relating to caseins and caseinates intended for human consumption, because it proposes to set the maximum moisture content of food casein at 12% (compared with the 10% parameter previously provided for) and the maximum fat content of food acid casein milk at 2% (compared with 2.25%).  The Directive must be seen in the context of general food legislation (Regulation (EC) No 178/2002), which aims to ensure the free movement of safe and healthy food, thereby contributing to the health and well-being of citizens. With this in mind, it is also appropriate to ensure that consumers are adequately informed about the food they consume.  Although the products covered by the directive are not intended for sale to the final consumer but only for sale between food preparation companies, it is important that food business operators have the necessary data for the labelling of finished products. As a result, the directive includes provisions on the labelling of caseins and caseinated products intended for human consumption. If the mandatory information does not appear on packaging, containers or labels, the products concerned may not be marketed as food caseins or caseinated or used for the preparation of foodstuffs.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this deliberation because it seeks to harmonize with particularly questionable global criteria.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is proposed to approximate the laws of the Member States concerning certain caseins and caseinates intended for human consumption, taking into account other legislation adopted in the meantime, in particular in the food sector, and harmonising the composition requirements of food caseins with the relevant international standard (Codex Alimentarius). The products covered by the proposal are not intended to be sold to the final consumer, they are used for the preparation of food products and are therefore marketed between companies in the sector. It is important that food operators have the information necessary for the labelling of final products, in particular when it comes to allergens. For this reason, the proposal provides for provisions on the labelling of caseins and caseinates intended for human consumption. Where the mandatory information provided for therein is not contained in the packaging, containers or labels, those products may not be placed on the market as caseins and food caseinates or used for the preparation of foodstuffs. Aligning food casein requirements with Codex Alimentarius will ensure a level playing field for food business operators. The rapporteur temporally limits the Commission's power to adopt delegated acts and suggests some technical amendments in order to ensure that it is in line with the Codex Alimentarius. We voted in favour.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted favour as I believe the proposal provides for more transparency.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The food industry must be seen in the context of general food law, which aims to guarantee the free movement of safe and healthy food and thereby contribute to the health and quality of life of citizens of the Member States of the European Union. It is therefore important to ensure that consumers are sufficiently informed about the food they consume. The European Commission's proposal covers components of casein and caseinates which, although not intended for sale to the final consumer, are used for the preparation of food products. I therefore consider it important that food business operators have at their disposal sufficient information to indicate the final products, especially as regards allergens.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report which aims to include the principles underlying the recent directives on public procurement and concessions among those intended to regulate the functioning of the European institutions.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the approximation of the laws of the Member States relating to casein and caseinates intended for human consumption, as the report introduces significant changes to this directive, which protect public health and at the same time limit the Commission's uncontrolled action.

name: Ashley Fox (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it finally brings EU regulation into line with WHO standards. I support the Commission’s objective of bringing the EU to international world standards so that Member States are not at a disadvantage. This will also help clarify the existing rules on food safety for both consumers and businesses.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly support the introduction, in the Commission proposal, of the provision of sufficient information in business to business relations in order to ensure the presence and accuracy of food information for the final consumer; the updating of the definition of ‘casein’, in line with the International Food Standards as defined by the FAO and WHO; the introduction of a specific label for caseinates exceeding the minimum compositional requirements of milk protein. Moreover, I welcome the proposal that the power to adopt delegated acts should not be conferred on the Commission for an unlimited period of time, but rather for five years, thus increasing the monitoring capability of the co-legislators of the adoption of delegated acts by the Commission. Finally, I approve of the proposal to set an ambitious yet realistic date for the implementation of this directive in the Member States (12 months after the entry into force of this directive).

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The coordination of the powers conferred on the Commission and the adaptation of the requirements for ingredients in edible casein are of the utmost importance to the international standard. I urge them to be adapted to international standards and technical progress as soon as possible in the future, and to this end the Commission is also proposing the adoption of delegated acts. In line with this report, I would like to highlight that it is a priority to ensure the free movement of safe and healthy food, which contributes significantly to the health and well-being of citizens. In this respect, it is also necessary to ensure that consumers are properly informed about the food they consume.  As stated above, I support the proposal. I welcome the adaptation of the requirements for the composition of dietary casein to the Codex Alimentarius, as this will ensure that food businesses can operate on a level playing field on the world market. I also support the requirements for the labelling of casein and caseinates, which will allow consumers, especially those suffering from food allergies or intolerances, to make an informed decision.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council to adapt existing provisions to the future development of legislation in the field of food legislation and to adjust the composition requirements of food caseins to the international standard, with the aim of providing safe and healthy food.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This vote, although due to a number of technical reasons, has a significant impact on the health of consumers in the casein and caseinate sector. I particularly welcome the labelling provisions, which will finally allow for a more informed choice and, above all, greater protection for citizens suffering from allergies and intolerances. In addition, this report will also bring several benefits for the competitiveness of a sector, the dairy sector, which is particularly in difficulty. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. In the food sector, consumer safety and maximum transparency of labelling are essential priorities for the marketing of products. I therefore support the report, which has already been approved by the ENVI Committee, on updating EU rules on food cases. The alignment of the composition requirements of these products with the Codex Alimentarius and the communication to manufacturers of detailed indications will ensure clear and precise information to the final consumer regarding any ailments and allergies, promoting the circulation of safer and more controlled foods.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the report on Caseine and Caseinates for Human Nutrition, as I consider food safety to be a key issue in the European internal market. We need clear rules here – and we need to adapt them again and again to current developments, for the benefit of consumers.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. I have voted in favour of this request. This application harmonises production standards and thus not only trades in the interests of the final consumer, but also establishes uniform directives for the manufacturing industry.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this proposal, which is a technical report designed to update the existing legislation in the field of caseins and caseinates intended for human consumption. The proposal will have little impact on business as it is not introducing new legislation, only consolidating existing legislation into the directive to clarify and simplify existing rules.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report that aims to update the original directive on certain lactoproteins (caseins and caseinates) intended for human consumption to ensure that it is better aligned with the international food standards, namely the Codex Alimentarius.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We have been in favour of the European Commission's proposal to repeal the 1983 Directive regulating the presence of caseins and caseinates in food, and replace it with a new Directive in order to create a list of enzymes authorised in the manufacture of caseins, harmonise their labelling and align the levels of caseins present in food produced and consumed in the European Union with current international standards.

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of the directive on caseins and caseinates intended for human consumption, because this is an extremely important issue for public health. I supported the proposal put forward by the European Commission because I consider it necessary to adapt the requirements for caseins and caseinates to international Codex Alimentarial standards and to introduce a permanent order for the proper labelling of foodstuffs produced with dairy products. This is extremely important for people who are allergic or intolerant to cow's milk proteins, for whom their consumption is the cause of serious and often incurable diseases. Most citizens in my country do not want food of unknown origin on their tables. That is why, as an Polish, I voted in favour of this directive, which, in my opinion, proposes the correct procedure for the placing on the market of dairy products.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this proposal, which is a technical report designed to update the existing legislation in the field of caseins and caseinates intended for human consumption. The proposal will have little impact on business as it is not introducing new legislation, only consolidating existing legislation into the directive to clarify and simplify existing rules.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as its overall aim is to grant the free movement of safe and wholesome food, thereby significantly contributing to the health and well-being of our citizens. Although the products covered by the proposal are not meant to be sold to the final consumer, but only from business to business for the preparation of food products, it is important for food business operators to have at their disposal the information they need for the labelling of the final products, especially when it comes to allergens.

name: Roger Helmer (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Today UKIP voted against the La Via report on the proposal for a directive on the approximation of the laws of the Member States relating to caseins and caseinates intended for human consumption. We believe in preserving the health and well-being of citizens by guaranteeing transparency when it comes to the ingredients of the food they consume. We also support food business operators and understand their need to have all the necessary information at their disposal when labelling the final products, especially when it comes to allergens. However, the reasoning behind this vote concerned the alignment of the powers conferred upon the Commission by the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, which we are not prepared to support. We do not believe that these issues should be defined at an EU level. We oppose the drafting of further EU legislation and we believe that each Member State should have the autonomy to decide whether and how to legislate on these issues. We believe in the right of sovereign nations to establish their own policies.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We have been in favour of the European Commission's proposal to repeal the 1983 Directive regulating the presence of caseins and caseinates in food, and replace it with a new Directive in order to create a list of enzymes authorised in the manufacture of caseins, harmonise their labelling and align the levels of caseins present in food produced and consumed in the European Union with current international standards.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the proposal for a Directive by Parliament and the Council on harmonisation of Member States' legislation relating to caseins and caseinates intended for human nutrition and on the repeal of Council Directive 83/417/EEC, as the proposal thus aligns with higher international standards and increases consumer awareness. This way also enables the free and safe circulation of healthy and controlled food that contributes to the well-being of all citizens. On the other hand, this improves the labelling mechanism of products, namely labelling, which is of utmost importance for consumers, but also for the food business sector, especially when it comes to allergens. Therefore, I support this proposal which encourages Member States to comprehensively implement these processes and standards, and limits the fullness of delegated acts to five years.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. The report calls for changes to the maximum moisture level of food casein (from 10% to 12%) and the maximum milk fat content of food acid casein (from 2.25% to 2%).  These changes are first and foremost necessary for producers and players in the agri-food sector. However, international harmonization of consumer protection and health should not be a barrier to global trade. Secondly, in the Commission's words, these amendments would contribute to the competitiveness of the directive, which would benefit European producers who would then be placed back in "fair conditions on the world market". Finally, the report confirms the desire to delegate to the Commission the power to adopt acts that allow the rapid adaptation of this tune-up in line with global standards with the same oasis of progress always in sight. In the context of the obscure TTIP negotiations, it is recommended that attempts to align with international standards strongly subject to the commercial aims of globalist institutions, at the expense of food safety standards, be opposed.  That is why I voted against it.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Giovanni La Via's report on caseins and caseins in the context of human food. This text aims to replace a directive already in force, by bringing Member States' laws closer together and in line with existing international standards. Labelling requirements have also been strengthened to enable consumers with allergies to make informed choices. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which will allow a single European directive to cover several types of products, including caseins and caseinates, for human consumption. The aim is for Member States to take the same position with regard to these products.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing.
