The proposal put forward is worthy of support, as it repeals the existing Directive on certain dairy products (caseine and caseinates) and creates a new one, which will, among other things, be adapted to the Commission's current powers, to new provisions in the food sector (e.B. allergenvo) and to the international standard (Codex Alimentarius). I am therefore voting in favour of this report.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour the report, as the proposal brings compositional and quality standards for caseins into line with the international standard to enable food business operators to operate on a level playing field internationally.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 As I said a few weeks back in the debate on food origin labelling, I fully support the idea of introducing general Pan-European requirements for transparent food labelling. These measures are one of the key factors in protecting the health of our population. In particular, the present proposal aims to ensure that consumers are properly informed about the foods they consume. Although caseins and caseinates are not expected to be sold to the final consumer, but only between food production undertakings, it is still important that food operators have the information they need to label the final products, in particular as regards allergens. If the mandatory information referred to in the Directive is not contained on the packaging, these products may not be placed on the market at all. Proper labelling of caseins and caseinates will enable consumers, and in particular those suffering from food allergies or intolerances, to make informed choices. Given that we have had a number of serious scandals in the Czech Republic in recent years around the quality, composition and origin of food sold there, and I believe that we are not the only ones in a Pan-European context, I therefore intend to fully support this proposal and any other efforts that, with the help of improving consumer information, will ultimately also lead to an improvement in the quality of what we eat.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. – They cause a lot of health problems, often through a variety of over-processed dairy products, so I could not support this proposal. I have also asked the Commission questions in the past, to which I have not received reassuring answers. In fact, it is not currently resolved to properly label potentially allergenic ingredients on final products, so customers often believe that they have obtained a healthy product and in fact they have not.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. In March 2014, the European Commission presented the proposal for a directive on the approximation of the laws of the Member States relating to caseins and caseinated products intended for human consumption and repealing Directive 83/471/EEC of the European Parliament and of the Council.  This is a technical dossier, but it has indirect consequences for citizens and consumers. That is why I have worked very carefully on this proposal, together with the shadow rapporteurs, whom I thank for their excellent cooperation, which has enabled us to reach the final agreement with the Council as soon as possible. The final text provides for the maximum moisture content of the food casein to be set at 12% (compared to the 10% parameter previously provided for) and the maximum fat content of the milk of the food acid casein at 2% (compared to 2.25%).  With today's vote, therefore, Europe is paying close attention to food issues, with a particular focus on food safety, which is always at the heart of our political agenda.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. The rapporteur suggests following the Commission in a global harmonisation and updating of regulations on certain lactoproteins used in the production of food for human consumption. It would therefore be a matter of supporting the Commission in a global harmonisation and supported by the Union's trade policies, which generally have the effect of lowering food safety standards. We oppose this systematic alignment with international standards that do not go in the direction of consumers.

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text because it is doing the right job of harmonising national regulations on certain lactoproteins used for human food, with a view to promoting the adoption of the transatlantic treaty TAFTA. This is very clearly a first step towards lowering food safety standards.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. The Council Directive 83/417/EEC calls for the approximation of the laws of the Member States with regard to certain lactoproteins (caseins and caseinates) intended for human consumption. Since the entry into force of the Directive, a number of changes have taken place, in particular the development of a comprehensive legal framework in the field of food law and the adoption of an international standard by the Food Code for edible caseins. Due to the need for greater clarity, Directive 83/417/EEC should be repealed and replaced by a new Directive. The proposal aims to empower the Commission in the new legal context created by the Lisbon Treaty. It also takes into account the development of legislation in recent years. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. Among other objectives, this report seeks to adjust the composition requirements of food caseins to international standards. This is very important given that this will ensure a level playing field for the economic operators of food companies on the global market.  On the other hand, food will be correctly labelled indicating the content of caseins and caseinates so that consumers, and in particular those with food intolerances or allergies, will be able to make informed decisions.  I therefore consider that this is a positive proposal and I voted accordingly.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree that it is important for the health and well-being of consumers to know what they are consuming. However, I do not agree with this proposal, because the Member States themselves can very well deal with this matter. There is no reason why the European Union should deal with this. I am against new European legislation.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the La Vije Representative's report because it requires the labelling of caseins and cases on products, allowing consumers to make decisions about healthy eating and lifestyle based on the information available. This requirement especially helps those who suffer from food allergies or intolerance. The European Commission published a proposal for a Directive to harmonise Member States' legislation concerning caseins and caseinates intended for human nutrition and on the repeal of Council Directive 83/417/EEC in March 2014. This Commission proposal is based, inter alia, on the need to adapt existing provisions for further development in the field of food law and adaptation of edible casein ingredients. It is also necessary to come up with an ambitious but realistic roadmap for the implementation of the new Directive in the Member States and to this end several technical amendments are proposed to ensure the uniformity of the Directive with international standards.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Directive takes into account the Commission's powers under the Treaty on the Functioning of the EU, international treaties and current developments in the field of food products. Limits are laid down for caseins and caseinates in food production between producers and an obligation to indicate this information on packaging. The aim is to guarantee the free movement of safe and healthy food and to protect the health of the population.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I abstain from voting on the report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the approximation of the laws of the Member States relating to casein and caseinates intended for human consumption and the repeal of Directive 83/417/EEC, because as demonstrated by the debate in plenary the report, although it is in the right direction, it is nevertheless not complete and substantiated.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The proposal is to be seen in the context of the general food law (Regulation (EC) No 178/2002) which aims at granting the free movement of safe and wholesome food, thereby significantly contributing to the health and well-being of citizens. In this respect, it should also be ensured that consumers are appropriately informed as regards the food they consume. Although the products covered by the proposal (caseins and caseinates) are not meant to be sold to the final consumer, but only from business to business for the preparation of food products, it is important for the food business operators to dispose of the information they need for the labelling of the final products, especially when it comes to allergens. For this reason, the proposal includes provisions on the labelling of caseins and caseinates intended for human consumption (Article 5). In case the mandatory information laid out therein does not appear on the packages, containers or labels, such products may not be placed on the market as edible caseins or caseinates or used for the preparation of foodstuffs.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the proposal for a Directive of Parliament and of the Council on the approximation of the laws of the Member States relating to caseins and caseinated products intended for human consumption. The aim of the report is to adapt Directive 83/417/EEC on the use of particular lactoproteins intended for human consumption in order to achieve compliance with international standards. Regulated products are intended exclusively for sale between food preparation companies as it is important that food business leaders are aware of the basic data on product labelling, particularly for allergens.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission, in March 2014, published a proposal for a directive aimed at stimulating a rapprochement between Member States' legislation on caseins and caseinates intended for human consumption. My agreement with the proposal for a directive stems from the conviction that it is essential to guarantee the movement of safe and healthy food, in the light of full protection of the well-being of European citizens.

name: Stefano Maullu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Mr La Via's report because it brings the regulatory requirements of certain lactoproteins and food cases into line with regulatory developments in the food sector; the directive also brings national legislation closer together, ensuring greater equal treatment of operators in the global market.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. In itself, the proposal for a directive is worthy of support, as it repeals the existing Directive on certain dairy products (caseine and caseinates) and creates a new one, which, among other things, also adapts to the Commission's current powers, new provisions in the food sector (e.B. allergenregulation) and the international standard (Codex Alimentarius). I therefore agree with the report.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report as it improves the standards of edible casein and caseinates, bringing them in line with international norms.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Caseins and caseinates are proteins commonly used in agri-food (cheese making, wine collage, etc.). The proposal aims to harmonize legislation on these products at EU level. The maximum moisture content of food caseins and the maximum milk fat content for food acid casein are now set at 12% and 2% (up from 10% and 2.25% currently). The text also includes provisions on the labelling of caseins and caseins for human consumption in order to ensure the presence and accuracy of information on foodstuffs intended for the end consumer. I'm voting for.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The report calls for changes to the maximum moisture level of food casein (from 10% to 12%) and the maximum milk fat content of food acid casein (from 2.25% to 2%).  These changes are first and foremost necessary for producers and players in the agri-food sector. However, international harmonization of consumer protection and health should not be a barrier to global trade. Secondly, in the Commission's words, these amendments would contribute to the competitiveness of the directive, which would benefit European producers who would then be placed back in "fair conditions on the world market". Finally, the report confirms the desire to delegate to the Commission the power to adopt acts that allow the rapid adaptation of this tune-up in line with "international standards and future technical progress (sic)". In the context of the obscure TTIP negotiations, it is recommended that attempts to align with international standards strongly subject to the commercial aims of globalist institutions, at the expense of food safety standards, be opposed.  For these reasons, I voted against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. I have voted in favour of the draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on approximation of the laws of the Member States with regard to certain caseins and caseinates intended for food. It is a question of ensuring that the information that circulates between companies with a view to the preparation of food products is appropriate for the labelling of final products, in particular with regard to allergens.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in support of the resolution. This proposal overhauls certain aspects of the rules regarding caseins and caseinates to bring them in line with the international standards, along with furthering labelling standards.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. Caseins and caseins are substances obtained through technological processes from milk that are found in many products other than those in the dairy sector. The proposed directive harmonizes European standards with international standards. This is an important step because it puts the European dairy industry on an equal footing globally. By doing so, the internal market is strengthened and standards are updated to inform consumers of the presence of these substances in the products concerned. Caseins and caseinates are allergens. This report recalls one of the FUNDAMENTAL principles of the EU, which, in order to ensure consumer protection, ensures that strict and transparent regulations are established.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In the context of the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the approximation of the laws of the Member States relating to caseins and caseinates intended for human consumption, I welcome the effort to ensure that consumers are properly informed about the food they consume. Although the products covered by the proposal (caseins and caseinates) are not intended for sale to the final consumer, but only for intercompany sales for the preparation of food products, it is important that food business operators have the information they need to label final products, in particular as regards allergens. I appreciate that, thanks to the new rules, the consumer will come first, as he will be provided with more accurate information in a way that is also acceptable to manufacturers.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission has proposed to repeal Directive 83/417/EEC on the approximation of certain relevant laws of the Member States intended for human consumption and to bring it into force. I supported the proposal to adapt the provisions in force to other legislation in the field of food law and to adapt the requirements for ingredients in dietary casein to the international standard.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In the context of certain lactoproteins (caseins and caseinates), it is intended to approximate the laws of the Member States with a view to consolidating European legislation on the food sector by repealing Directive 83/417/EEC. The objective is to distinguish the Commission's powers and to harmonise the composition requirements of food caseins with international standards, in particular the standard issued by the Codex Alimentarius. The repeal of Directive 83/417/EEC is necessary to the extent of current food legislation. Furthermore, with the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, there is a need to distinguish between the Powers of the Commission to adopt non-legislative acts and to adopt implementing acts. With this proposal, the composition and quality requirements of casein products referred to in the Codex Alimentarius standard are established. I am in favour of the adoption of this new directive, thereby creating a level playing field for food businesses and also for consumers.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This report proposes to follow the European Commission, which plans to harmonize and update regulations on certain lactoproteins used in the production of food for human consumption.  However, this proposal is actually aimed at aligning European standards with international standards in order to enable EU producers to achieve 'competitiveness gains'. This report confirms the desire to transfer to the Commission full powers to adopt acts that would allow the rapid adaptation of this regulation "to international standards". It is therefore a matter of supporting the Commission's agricultural trade policy, the result of which is known to be in terms of lowering food safety standards. I have decided to vote against this text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which will enable food business operators to operate on a level playing field internationally. The proposal brings compositional and quality standards for caseins into line with the international standard.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on caseins and caseins. It authorizes the Commission to amend the directive that currently applies to these milk proteins. The aim is to adjust the composition criteria for these products to the international standard of codex Alimentarius and to harmonize the laws of the Member States. These measures will ensure that European companies in the milk and dairy sector have better competitive conditions in the global market. This is crucial for the EU to fight on equal terms with new emerging countries such as China and especially India, which in the early 2000s became the first milk-producing nation. The text also aims to ensure the protection of consumers, especially those suffering from food allergies, by strengthening labelling requirements. They will be able to choose their products with full knowledge of the facts.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome the adoption of this proposal for a directive on the approximation of the laws of the Member States relating to caseins and caseinated products intended for human consumption, considering it essential to comply with the requirements of the Codex Alimentarius. This will ensure equal treatment for food business operators on the world market.  The proposal must be seen in the context of general food legislation which aims to ensure the free movement of safe and healthy food, thereby making a significant contribution to the health and well-being of citizens. With this in mind, it is also appropriate to ensure that consumers are adequately informed about the food consumed. Although the products covered by the proposal are not intended for sale to the consumer, but only for sale between food preparation companies, it is important that operators have the necessary data for the labelling of finished products, in particular with regard to allergens.  We are therefore in favour of the labelling requirements, which will enable consumers to make informed choices and to prevent any food allergies or intolerances. As regards procedural aspects, the power to adopt delegated acts in order to amend the Annexes should not be conferred on the Commission for an indefinite period, but for a maximum of five years.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report that will instate provisions on the labelling of caseins and caseinates intended for human consumption. In case the mandatory information laid out therein does not appear on the packages, containers or labels, such products may not be placed on the market as edible caseins or caseinates or used for the preparation of foodstuffs.

name: James Nicholson (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ The new directive replacing Directive 83/417/EEC is intended to level up EU legislation concerning certain lactoproteins (caseins and caseinates) creating a more level playing field regarding food laws. By repealing existing laws this allows for the implementation of more recent legislation on food law. This proposal is part of the Commission’s REFIT programme designed to align existing law with the delegated and implementing powers conferred on the Commission by the Lisbon Treaty. The idea of providing the Commission with the ability to repeal existing laws would have negative implications for the UK. This proposal would align Europe with international legislation and WHO standards. I have always advocated cutting back on red tape proposed by the Commission. In this case, the agreement allows for current EU requirements for edible caseins to become more flexible at an international level.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. I support this report because the existing directive on certain dairy products (caseine and caseinates) is being repealed and a new one is being created. This is also the only one that adapts the new existing provisions in the food sector, such as the Allergens Regulation, to the international standard.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. This resolution proposes a harmonisation of legislation on caseins and caseinates, two proteins derived from milk commonly used in the food industry. For example, the new regulations would set the maximum moisture content of food caseins at 12% and the maximum milk fat content of food acid casein at 2%. It is also proposed that labelling of these two proteins on consumer food products should be systematically carried out, thereby enhancing food security for the consumer. I support this resolution.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The amendment aligns the compositional requirements for edible caseins with international standards.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 With a view to approximating the laws of the Member States and considering the great importance of ensuring that the producer, and then also the final consumer, is fully informed about the products they buy and consume, I have decided to vote in favour.

name: Alojz Peterle (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the report on casein and caseinates for human consumption, as I believe that food control is a key task because it has a direct impact on food safety and thus on human health.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the European Parliament's legislative resolution proposing the re-finality of a legislative act within the meaning of a proposal from parliament's Environment, Health and Food Safety Committee. I welcome the alignment of European legislation with the recommendations and standards of the Codex Alimentarius, and welcome the effort to bring the Directive into force as soon as possible, and for the expected benefits and assistance of the crisis-affected milk sector.  The advantage of this amended Dirketive, which prescribes provisions for adjusting the labeling of the composition of products that use caseins and caseinates in the technological production process, increases the safety of end users of these products - consumers. I agree with the need to implement the possibility of technical finishing and amendments to this regulation or annex by delegated acts, but only for the required period of 5 years. This should be made possible due to further improvements that will not have an impact on the content of the act, which in turn will be necessary for the alignment of this act with international standards and technical progress.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This report proposes to follow the European Commission, which plans to harmonize and update regulations on certain lactoproteins used in the production of food for human consumption.  However, this proposal is actually aimed at aligning European standards with international standards in order to achieve "competitiveness gains" for EU producers. It confirms the desire to transfer to the Commission full powers to adopt acts that would allow the regulation to adapt quickly to "international standards". It is therefore a matter of supporting the Commission's agricultural trade policy, the result of which is known to be in terms of lowering food safety standards. I have decided to vote against this text.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The Commission's proposal in question is important in the context of a general dietary law that seeks to improve and maintain the health and well-being of its citizens by ensuring the free flow of safe food and foodstuffs. Although the proposal tosses and cassettes that are not intended for the end-user but for trading between companies for food preparation purposes, it is necessary and necessary to provide relevant information to employees working and doing business with them. The ability of employees to clearly discern how to use the information they need to label finished products, such as allergens, or to avoid replacing products with some similar ones that are not suitable for human consumption, can be vital for the final consumer. Likewise, harmonisation of quality standards for edible caseins according to codex Alimentarius is important in order to enable equality of all the world's food producers. I am prompted to support amendments aimed at introducing these provisions by example from Croatia itself. Namely, in Croatia, Article 12 of the European Ordinance on edible cases and caseinates from 2007 stipulates a list of data to be contained in each packaging, container or declaration of products made of edible caseins and cassettes placed on the market and not intended for the end user.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒The Commission has proposed to abolish the Directives on harmonisation of Member States' laws on milk proteins (caseins and caseins) intended for human consumption, and to be replaced by a new Directive. Proposals to comply with international standards refer to parameters in relation to the maximum moisture content in casein at 12% (instead of previously 10%) and compared to the maximum milk fat content in casein at 2% (instead of 2.25%). I agree with the general food law, which aims to free movement safe and healthy food, which significantly contributes to the health and well-being of citizens. This should ensure that consumers are informed about the food they consume. Consequently, I support the report of my colleague Mp Giovanni La Vije.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal aims to adapt the composition requirements of food caseins and caseinates to those of the Codex Alimentarius standard, thus aligning itself with international legislation and updating them in the light of the new provisions introduced by the Treaty of Lisbon.  In particular, new features are introduced with regard to the maximum level of humidity of the food casein, which goes from 10 to 12%, and the maximum fat level of milk of the sour food casein which is reduced from 2.25 to 2%. I welcome the rapporteur's proposal to ensure the circulation of safe and healthy food on the EU market, thereby making a significant contribution to safeguarding the health and well-being of European citizens.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament has adopted a text replacing the current directive on caseins and caseins for human food. I have spoken in favour of this text because it aims to better harmonise food standards within the Union.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE)
text: In writing. I supported President La Via's report on caseins and caseins for human consumption. This is a technical adaptation to repeal a 1983 directive and replace it with this legislation in order to bring the Community provisions into line with international standards. Behind this technical jargon, it is a question of updating the legal framework for caseins, the protein content contained in milk. Caseinates are products obtained by drying treated caseins.  An essential point of this legislation concerns information to consumers since some citizens are allergic to casein as they are lactose. This is why it is important to report their presence in food labelling. This adaptation of European legislation to international standards will not close the debate on the good and bad sides of casein. On the positive side, casein is of great use in all situations where protein intake is limited over a long period of time. For the negative side, certain animal proteins, such as casein, would cause breast cancer and other forms of carcinoma. A nice way to rehabilitate the whey.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of updating Directive 83/417/EEC, which provides for a reconciliation of Member States' laws on certain milk proteins (caseins and caseins) for human consumption. Indeed, several changes have taken place since the directive came into force, such as the development of a comprehensive legal framework in the field of food regulation, the adoption of an international standard (Codex Alimentarius) for casein and the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty. The new directive includes a more precise calculation of milk protein content based on the absolute weight of the product (instead of the current method based on dried extract), better labelling, an update of the definition of "casein" according to the Codex Alimentarius standard and a limitation of delegated acts to 5 years.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report on a proposal by the Council and Parliament is intended only to introduce some specifications to harmonise legislation and ensure the transparency of Member States with regard to certain lactoproteins (caseins and caseinates) intended for human consumption. Among other measures, the rapporteur suggests the definition of maximum levels and, although the products covered are not for the final consumer but only for producing companies, the labelling is mandatory for consumers to make informed decisions.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this legislative resolution repealing Council Directive 83/417/ECC and adopting a new Directive on the approximation of the laws of the Member States relating to caseins and caseinates intended for human consumption. Parliament's work has made it possible to improve the Commission's text, betting on providing sufficient food information for the final consumer in business-to-business relations; update the definition of "casein" through a technical update; introduce a specific label for caseinates exceeding the minimum lactose protein composition requirements laid down in the Annex to the Directive; propose that the power to adopt delegated acts to adapt the Annexes to international standards should not be conferred on the Commission for an unlimited period of time, but up to five years or propose an ambitious, if realistic, date for the implementation of this Directive in the Member States (12 months after the entry into force of this Directive).

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. In March 2014, the Commission published its proposal for a directive from the European Parliament and the Council on bringing Member States' legislation closer to caseins and caseins for human food and repealing the Council's Directive 83/417/EEC.  In its proposal, the Commission suggests replacing the directive with a new one, mainly for the following reasons: the need to adapt the existing provisions to the evolution of food legislation and to adjust the requirements for the composition of food caseins to the corresponding international standard. These new provisions, which I have passed, will enable food operators to enjoy a level playing field in the global market. The adopted text also supports the labelling requirements for caseins and caseins, which will enable consumers, especially those suffering from allergies or food intolerances, to make their choices knowingly.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal for a Directive on the approximation of The Laws of the Member States concerning certain caseins and caseinates intended for food, because I consider it prudent to harmonise in this matter with international standards on general food legislation, which allows the free movement of safe, healthy food and that contribute to the health and well-being of European citizens.  I would like to highlight the provisions on the labelling of caseins and caseinates intended for human consumption as mandatory information on packaging, containers and labels, allowing consumers to make informed decisions regarding food allergies and intolerances.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on caseins and caseinated products intended for human consumption, because I support the role played by the European Union in ensuring food safety and I believe that all types of 'milk proteins' must be clearly indicated on food labels in order to prevent allergies and intolerances from being unleashed.  The report proposes alignment with international standards (Codex alimentarius) and an update with regard to the new provisions introduced by the Treaty of Lisbon.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We have been in favour of the European Commission's proposal to repeal the 1983 Directive regulating the presence of caseins and caseinates in food, and replace it with a new Directive in order to create a list of enzymes authorised in the manufacture of caseins, harmonise their labelling and align the levels of caseins present in food produced and consumed in the European Union with current international standards.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report on the Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the approximation of the laws of the Member States relating to caseins and caseinates intended for human consumption. I believe that it introduces more regulation on these substances and positive developments on the original proposal so that consumers have the proper information.  The products subject to the proposal (caseins and caseinates) are not oriented to the sale to the final consumer, but only between companies for the production of food products, but it is important that citizens have all the information they need in the labelling of the final products. The proposal therefore includes provisions on the labelling of caseins and caseinates intended for human consumption. In the event that the mandatory information established is not on packaging, containers or labels, these products may not be placed on the market as food caseins or caseinates or used for food processing.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for a directive on caseins and caseinated products intended for human consumption which adapts the current EU requirements for the composition of these lactoproteins to the international standards of the World Health Organisation established by the Codex Alimentarius.  The caseins are lactoproteins while the caseinated are made of the first ones and can also be used in vinification to reduce the level of bitterness and clarify the white and rosé wines. Since two milk products are derived, they could also cause intolerances or allergies, and for this very reason their presence must be indicated on food labels.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 In addition to the technical nature of this text that we voted on, one of the aspects of particular relevance has to do with the best possible information for the consumer. It is essential to have a system that allows the clear identification of potentially allergenic substances, which involves the mandatory labelling. I therefore voted positively on this proposal.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this resolution because I do not believe that these issues should be defined at EU level. I oppose the creation of any new EU legislation. I do, however, believe in transparency when it comes to the ingredients in our food.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Following the successful vote on this report in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, it is with great pleasure that I can follow up the work of Giovanni La Via with another vote of approval in the plenary.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported this resolution as I am in favour of labelling certain lactoproteins (caseins and caseinates), thereby allowing consumers, and especially those suffering from food allergies or intolerances, to make choices on the basis of this label.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ This explanation of the vote comes as a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Since food is one of the most important items in world trade, I consider it crucial, in particular, that manufacturers supply only safe and healthy products on the market, thus ensuring a high level of protection of human life and health. Although the EU's food policy has recently undergone significant changes and a number of consumer protection measures have been taken so far, I consider it extremely important that we continue to unify the concept and rules on food production in order to create a uniform procedure. Although the products we are discussing today (caseins and caseinates) are not intended for sale to the final consumer, but only for intercompany sales for the preparation of food products, I consider it sensible to harmonise international standards concerning the maximum moisture content of food caseins at 12% and the maximum milk fat content of acidic food caseins at 2%. At the same time, I believe that this is the right way to go, and I believe that there will only be products and services on the market that do not endanger health, life and overall consumer safety.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. Casein is the main protein in the milk of the transhiles (e.g. cow's milk) and gives a solid consistency to the cottage cheese, cheese and other dairy products. Caseinates are casein derivatives and are mainly used in the production of cheese, protein supplements and powdered coffee cream. Dairy products may cause allergies or cause hypersensitivity, so caseins and caseinates on animals should be labelled as 'milk proteins'. In its 2014 proposal, the Commission calls for the harmonisation of the powers conferred on the Commission, the adaptation of existing provisions, the further development of food law and the amendment of the requirements for the composition of edible caseins in accordance with the international standard. In particular, it proposes to set parameters for maximum moisture content for edible caseins at 12 % (instead of 10 %) and as regards the maximum milk fat content for edible acid caseins at 2 % (instead of 2,5 %). I agree that the proposal should be addressed in the context of general food law, which is intended to ensure the free movement of safe and health-relevant foods, thus making an important contribution to the health and well-being of citizens. It is necessary to ensure that consumers, in particular those with allergy or food intolerance, are informed about the foods they consume and have the opportunity to make informed choices. For this very reasons, I supported the report on the proposal.

name: Bart Staes (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. 'Casein and caseinates are milk proteins used as neutralising factor in food products. These proteins are often the cause of various allergies. Therefore, the demand for stricter standards requiring it to include this casein on the labels of the products in which they are used. As a result, consumers no longer remain ignorant of the nutrients and added values present in their food and drink that can cause allergies. The European Commission proposes the repeal of the European Directive 83/417/EEC and replaced it with a new directive. This will further develop the regulations on nutrition and align the Commission's implementing powers as stated by the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (VWEU). In addition, the maximum permitted percentage of caseins is adapted to international standards. The Commission's proposal obliges producers to include added nutrients that could cause allergic reactions on labels, which is widely supported by the Greens. The European Parliament does, however, want the power of the European Commission, as mentioned above, to be curtailed and limited in time. I support this proposal, as it protects and safeguards the rights of consumers.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 I support this Report because Directive 83/417/EEC of the Council proposes harmonisation of Member States' legislation relating to certain milk proteins intended for human nutrition. The Directive gives the Commission powers to implement some of its provisions. Regulation (EC) No 2020/2013 1333/2008 The European Parliament and the Council provide for the definite of processing anguics cited as catalysts in the Directive. I also believe that Member States should have a limit to adopt national measures in matters that are not harmonised with this Directive and to adapt to the national, legal and administrative environment.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this proposal, intended to update the current legislation on caseins and caseinates and ensure compositional and quality standards conform to the international standard. This will enable food business operators to operate on a level playing field internationally.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The aim of this proposal by Parliament and the Council is to harmonise member states' legislatures relating to certain milk proteins (caseins and caseinates) intended for human nutrition and the repeal of Council Directive 83/417/EEC. It is also aimed at aligning the powers granted to the Commission with the new distinction between delegated/implementing acts, introduced by the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU), then adapting existing implementations to further development of food law legislation, and adapting existing regulations on the composition of edible caseins to international Codex Aliemantarius standards. In terms of adaptation to international standards, it is proposed to increase the maximum moisture content of edible caseins from 10 % to 12 %, and to reduce the maximum milk fat content of edible acid casein from 2 % to 2.25 %. I support this proposal because I believe that upgrading existing laws, as well as adapting to international standards, are safe indicators of further successful eu development, which wants to ensure the highest quality standards for its citizens.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal as these are mainly changes of a technical nature in order to update and consolidate EU legislation.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the approximation of the laws of the Member States relating to caseins and caseinates for human consumption. The purpose of the report is to bring the Requirements of the European Commission into line with the various other provisions governing casein and caseinates for human consumption. In doing so, it takes into account legislation adopted in the meantime. I supported the report because it would protect the European consumer and his health. The packaging will have to be appropriately labelled kezeini and caseinates for human consumption, otherwise these products will not be allowed to be put on the market or be used for the preparation of foodstuffs. This means that the end-user will be able to decide what to enjoy on the basis of clear information.

name: Kay Swinburne (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this final agreement, which provides for the Commission to repeal existing laws relating to certain lactoproteins (caseins and caseinates) and to replace them with a new directive. I broadly support the REFIT programme and I support measures such as this, which will level up current EU practice in food law to international World Health Organisation standards.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The report introduces significant changes to this directive, which protect public health and at the same time limit the Commission's uncontrolled action.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Products covered by this Directive are not products intended for sale to the final consumer, but products sold exclusively to undertakings for the production of foodstuffs. It is therefore appropriate to maintain and adapt the existing legislative framework and to simplify the rules. I therefore voted in favour of this report, as I agree that sufficient information should be provided in business-to-business relations in order to provide final consumers with accurate information on food. Casein and caseinates are milk proteins, with the first category forming 80% of cow's milk protein, among others. Since we are well known that not only lactose but also milk protein can cause intolerance or allergies, it is important to indicate the ingredients on the end and intermediate products. The proposal not only means regulatory simplification and development of food laws, but also the use of international units and standards (Codex Alimentarius).

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 There is nothing to complain about this redefinition of the characteristics of casein and caseinates that have come out of the work of the ENVI Committee, I voted in favour, but I do not want this to be exploited by the Italian Government in the context of the dispute between Italy and the EU over the Italian rules that – quite rightly – prohibit the use of milk powder, concentrated milk and reconstructed milk in the manufacture of cheeses. In the context of defending these rules, the Minister of Agriculture recently stated that Italy will ask the European Commission for more information on the labelling of milk products so that consumers can have more information available. The redefinition of the casein characteristics that we have approved here in the European Parliament also provides for more transparent and complete labelling of casein and caseinates, with a view to affixing a more detailed label to the finished products obtained from these semi-finished products.  However, I would like to stress that the better labelling of casein and caseinates does not derive from Italian requests and has nothing to do with Italian requests. It is indeed important to prevent the Italian Government from slyly affixing its label to the work that we have all done here in the European Parliament.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The food safety of European citizens is one of the principles underlying the powers granted to the European Parliament by the Treaty of Lisbon in the field of food. According to this principle, we, the European parliamentarians, are responsible for regulating the rules for the processing of food to be consumed by the citizens of the Member States.  Caseins and caseinates are components obtained from the processing of milk, representing the main protein intake of dairy products. This process is to make a very important agricultural product for farmers in our countries. At the same time, however, we must consider compliance with food rules, so as not to endanger the health of the population. This involves up-to-date Directive 83/417/EEC to take account of the Codex N290 Standard in this area and The World Health Organisation rules, which require a higher mandatory minimum quantity of that protein in dairy products marketed on the European market. In this context, the adoption of the current document is a win in order to ensure a better quality of dairy products for European consumers, which is why I support its adoption.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the text.  In terms of adjustment to international standards, it is proposed, among other things, that the parameters for the maximum moisture content of food caseins and the maximum milk fat content for food acid casein should be increased to 12% and 2% respectively (up from 10% and 2.25% at present).  In order to enable the rapid adaptation of Annexes I to III (standards applicable to food acid casein, food casein and food caseins in terms of their composition, contaminants, technological assistants employed, etc.) to international standards and future technical progress, the Commission also suggests the adoption of delegated acts.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Caseins and caseinates are lactoproteins that are sold from businesses to businesses for the preparation of food products. The proposal for a directive seeks alignment of the compositional requirements for edible caseins to the Codex Alimentarius, which would help ensure a level playing field for food businesses on the world market. It also sets out labelling requirements for caseins and caseinates which will enable consumers, and particularly those suffering from a food allergy or intolerance, to make informed choices. I therefore supported this report.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. I supported the proposal to withdraw the existing laws on cases and caseinates and replace them with a new Regulation, since I believe that this is how legislation is adjusted and adapted to the international standards of the World Health Organization, prescribed in codex Alimentarius, the book of food law.  Furthermore, given that this harmonisation is part of the Commission's REFIT programme, which aims to ensure the adequacy and effectiveness of the rules through less comprehensive, simpler and more economical LEGISLATION of the European Union, I believe that this will ensure transparency of food products and end consumers, which will ultimately be of utmost benefit to people who are allergic, intolerant or vulnerable to a particular type of food.  I also consider the six-month deadline given to Member States to implement this Regulation in their legislation to be fully appropriate.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. - I supported the report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the approximation of the laws of the Member States relating to caseins and caseinates for human consumption and the repealing of Council Directive 83/417/EEC, because I believe that the amendments introduced by the proposal for a directive are positive, as we will bring them closer to international standards. However, it will be necessary in the future to further adapt the existing provisions for further development of food law legislation.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We have been in favour of the European Commission's proposal to repeal the 1983 Directive regulating the presence of caseins and caseinates in food, and replace it with a new Directive in order to create a list of enzymes authorised in the manufacture of caseins, harmonise their labelling and align the levels of caseins present in food produced and consumed in the European Union with current international standards.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. It would be a matter of supporting the Commission in a global harmonisation and supported by the Union's trade policies, which generally have the consequence of lowering food safety standards.  In the context of the obscure TTIP and TAFTA negotiations, it is recommended that attempts to align with international standards strongly subject to the commercial aims of globalist institutions be opposed.  I voted against it.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We have been in favour of the European Commission's proposal to repeal the 1983 Directive regulating the presence of caseins and caseinates in food, and replace it with a new Directive in order to create a list of enzymes authorised in the manufacture of caseins, harmonise their labelling and align the levels of caseins present in food produced and consumed in the European Union with current international standards.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on the proposal for a directive concerning caseins and caseinates intended for human consumption. The aim of the directive would be to achieve greater safety and regulation when it comes to food safety. I believe that specific rules should ensure that clear information is provided for such products in order, on the one hand, to make available to food business operators all the information they need for the labelling of the final products, for example when it comes to allergens, and, on the other hand, to avoid that these products are confused with similar products not meant or not suitable for human consumption. The directive would also ensure that terminology is in line with the Codex standard for edible casein products.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. We are talking about a technical but important issue since the Commission's proposal aims to adapt Community legislation in the food field and to adjust the composition requirements of edible caseins to international standards (Codex Alimentarius). That is why I consider it necessary to vote in favour of that report.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report on the Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the approximation of the laws of the Member States relating to caseins and caseinates intended for human consumption. I believe that it introduces more regulation on these substances and positive developments on the original proposal so that consumers have the proper information.  The products subject to the proposal (caseins and caseinates) are not oriented to the sale to the final consumer, but only between companies for the production of food products, but it is important that citizens have all the information they need in the labelling of the final products. The proposal therefore includes provisions on the labelling of caseins and caseinates intended for human consumption. In the event that the mandatory information established is not on packaging, containers or labels, these products may not be placed on the market as food caseins or caseinates or used for food processing.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 As regards harmonisation with international standards (Codex Alimentarius), it is proposed, in particular, to set the parameters for the maximum moisture content of the food casein at 12 % (instead of the 10% previously provided for) and the maximum milk fat content of the acid-fed casein at 2 % (instead of 2.25 %).  In order to allow for the rapid adaptation of Annexes I to III (standards of acid-acid food casein, food casein obtained by food curd and caseinates in relation to their composition, contamination, technological aids used, etc.) to international standards and future technical progress, the Commission also suggests the adoption of delegated acts. It is suggested that the power to adopt delegated acts to adapt the Annexes should not be conferred on the Commission for an unlimited period of time, but only for 5 years, and it is proposed that a date be set for the application of this Directive in the Member States.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. In itself, the proposal for a directive is worthy of support, as it repeals the existing Directive on certain dairy products (caseine and caseinates) and creates a new one, which, among other things, also adapts to the Commission's current powers, new provisions in the food sector (e.B. allergenregulation) and the international standard (Codex Alimentarius). I therefore agree with the report.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. I do not agree with the regulation of kaseinins and caseinates. Essentially, it is a question of adapting the rules to new requirements of the World Health Organisation. This is not a problem. However, we are taking this opportunity to give the Commission the competence to set the limit values itself. I believe that this is a task for the legislator. Since there are insufficient possibilities for the Control of the Commission by the European Parliament, and certainly no responsibility, I am opposed to the further erosion of the democratic principle, which is already weak at European level.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The final agreement concluded on this point provides for the Commission to repeal the existing provisions relating to certain milk proteins (caseins and caseinates) and to replace them with a new directive. The purpose of that proposal was to adapt the existing law, within the framework of the Commission's REFIT programme, to the delegated implementing powers and powers conferred on the Commission by the Treaty of Lisbon. It also allows for the updating of legislation on caseins and caseinates in line with 2002 Union legislation in the field of food law, and aligns the current EU rules on the composition of edible caseins with the International Standards of the World Health Organisation contained in the Codex Food. I support the REFIT programme and initiatives that adapt current practice under EU food law to World Health Organisation standards.

name: Θεόδωρος Ζαγοράκης (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 I supported this report. This initiative lays down the necessary conditions to ensure the free and safe movement of food, but also to protect consumers and public health.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on caseins and caseinates intended for human consumption, not only with regard to the fact that it is part of the Commission's REFIT programme, but also because it meets the legal requirements of European Union law on the characteristics of these substances with the international Codex Alimentarius standard. In my opinion, it is beneficial for the requirements for substances intended for human consumption to be uniform and also to ensure sufficient awareness of possible allergens, which they may contain and which are currently causing considerable problems for the people of the European Union.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on caseins and caseinates intended for food because I consider it important to approximate the laws of the Member States concerning certain lactoproteins (caseins and caseinates) intended for human consumption, through the repeal of the current Directive 83/417/EEC of the European Council. The European Commission's proposal to replace the current Existing Directive should be considered in the context of general food legislation, which aims to allow the free movement of safe and healthy foodstuffs, thereby contributing significantly to the health and well-being of citizens. In this sense, although the products covered by the proposal (caseins and caseinates) are not to be sold to the final consumer, but only between companies with a view to the preparation of food products, this proposal becomes important in the sense that it implements the need for food business operators to have the necessary information on the labelling of final products and that there is harmonisation of the composition requirements of food cases with international standards.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is proposed to approximate the laws of the Member States concerning certain caseins and caseinates intended for human consumption, taking into account other legislation adopted in the meantime, in particular in the food sector, and harmonises the composition requirements of food caseins with the relevant international standard (Codex Alimentarius). The products covered by the proposal are not intended to be sold to the final consumer, they are used for the preparation of food products and are therefore marketed between companies in the sector. It is important that food operators have the information necessary for the labelling of final products, in particular when it comes to allergens. For this reason, the proposal provides for provisions on the labelling of caseins and caseinates intended for human consumption. Where the mandatory information provided for therein is not contained in the packaging, containers or labels, those products may not be placed on the market as caseins and food caseinates or used for the preparation of foodstuffs. We voted in favour

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We support amendments that relate to tackling fraud and meeting the criteria of transparency. Amendments relating to terrorism, human trafficking and child labour; we fully support these amendments that protect nations and individuals from danger.  We do not agree with social and labour laws that are being imposed. We have to agree with the tightening of procedures that combat fraud, tax evasion and embezzlement of union funds. There are a number of amendments that require contractors to adhere to EU policies relating to labour laws and environmental laws, and require the Commission to have more empowerment to enforce certain articles. There is concern relating to amendments dealing with procurement issues. The Committee on Foreign Affairs has stated that procurement rules recognise the aims and objectives of the Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP) so that EU Military and Civilian Operations have the resources to fulfil the objectives of the CSDP.  The protection of whistleblowers and their fundamental rights is something that we can support due to the fact that we can highlight the failings of the EU in certain matters relating to the management of the budget. UKIP voted to abstain.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report, although it includes positive aspects on the control of the EU budget, because it refers positively to the implementation of public-private consortia with the Union budgets. This report proposes a relative improvement in the control system of the European Union budget, this improvement is reflected in the requirement of certificates demonstrating the sustainability of the money spent by the European Union, fraud reporting obligations, specifying the added value of each of the expenditure, etc. However, the report welcomes the development of public-private consortia developed under the EU budget, leading to a potential privatisation of many of the investments made by the EU. That is why I have not been able to vote in favour of this report.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as this report aimed to make access to EU funds simpler, more accountable and efficient whilst also addressing misappropriation and white-collar crime through the introduction of exclusion criteria and a panel to investigate claims. It also aligns the financial regulation with the new directives on public procurement and on the awarding of concession contracts by the EU institutions. Contracting authorities shall be required to take steps to ensure that, when executing contracts, operators comply with the environmental, social and labour law obligations established by the EU or national legislation, collective agreements or the international environmental, social and labour conventions. Regarding exclusion criteria, these were added to counter tax fraud, tax evasion – including tax evasion via untaxed offshore structures – the misuse of corporate assets and the embezzlement of public funds to exclude from participation in the procurement procedures of EU institutions.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the Commission's proposal to apply the new 2014 market directives to the procurement of EU bodies. The provisions of the text did not make any major changes, but they were questionable. Thus, "the allocation on the basis of the most economically advantageous offer" cannot be retained as it stands since it sets aside quality. On the other hand, I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution, because it significantly improves the Commission's text. In particular, it obliges the adjudicative authorities to justify the decision not to resort to the allotment of a contract.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this resolution as a ‘best fit’. I support the principle of tightening up on financial rules to limit waste, mismanagement and fraud, and I commend the changes in that respect. Nevertheless, I cannot support much of the remaining text which supports current EU activities. I note in particular the positivity shown in the report towards the Common Security and Defence Policy.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is a logical and necessary application of the public procurement directive to the EU itself. I welcome the improved procedures and the reduction in delays. However, the system remains perfectable.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal on the financial rules applicable to the general budget of the EU. New provisions are included: market consultation, new innovation partnership procedure, environmental, social and labour law compliance as one of the most important requirements, non-specific criteria, contract award methodologies based on the most economically advantageous proposal. It also includes works and service concessions for the first time and is subject to the same types of procedures as in the case of public contracts.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We support amendments that relate to tackling fraud and meeting the criteria of transparency. Amendments relating to terrorism, human trafficking and child labour; we fully support these amendments that protect nations and individuals from danger.  We do not agree with social and labour laws that are being imposed. We have to agree with the tightening of procedures that combat fraud, tax evasion and the embezzlement of union funds. There are a number of amendments that require contractors to adhere to EU policies relating to labour laws and environmental laws and require the Commission to have more empowerment to enforce certain articles. There is concern relating to amendments dealing with procurement issues. The Committee on Foreign Affairs has stated that procurement rules recognise the aims and objectives of the Common Security and Defence Policy so that EU Military and Civilian Operations have the resources to fulfil the objectives of the CSDP. The protection of whistle-blowers and their fundamental rights is something that we can support due to the fact that we can highlight the failings of the EU in certain matters relating to the management of the budget. UKIP voted to abstain.

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: In writing. Opposed to the Commission's proposal, I voted in favour of the report, which makes an improvement by, among other things, requiring the contracting authority to justify the decision not to use the allotment of a market.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. This resolution, which I have approved, supports the Commission's proposal for a regulation to bring the financial regulation applicable to the EU budget in line with the provisions of the new directives on public procurement and the awarding of concession contracts. However, it made several changes. MEPs made it clear that the estimated value of a contract cannot be established with the intention of circumventing the rules in force. No market could be split for the same purpose. When it decides not to divide a market into lots, the contracting authority should justify its decision. Similarly, in line with the principle of sustainability, MEPs called for the adjudicator powers to ensure that, in the execution of contracts, economic operators comply with the applicable obligations in the areas of environmental, social and labour law established by EU law, national law, collective agreements or international environmental, social and labour conventions listed in Schedule X of directive 2014/24/EU.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report as the Commission submits to Parliament and the Council a proposal with a view to adapting the Financial Regulation to the provisions of the new Directives on public procurement and on the award of concession contracts. Consistent with what I voted on earlier times, I also voted this time in favour.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. This text aims to apply the new rules on public procurement adopted by the EU in 2014 (which are being transposed by member states) to the transfers of EU institutions and bodies. This original text does not change much from the previous directives (although it is a small plus for SMEs), but Parliament's amendments go in the right direction, such as the obligation for the adjudicator to justify the decision not to use the allotment of a contract or the fact that tax evasion is grounds for exclusion of a candidate. Unfortunately, too, the criterion of "the most economically advantageous offer" may seem attractive or even necessary from the point of view of public finances, but this handicaps local production and undermines environmental criteria. However, I voted for it.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Gräßle report, which I think is balanced and acceptable. I think it is right that the principles underlying the recent directives on public procurement and concessions to be applied by the Member States should also apply to contracts by the Council, the European Commission and Parliament.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. This report proposes to adapt the Financial Regulation to the provisions of the new Directives on government procurement and the award of concession contracts. A number of amendments are introduced such as the new innovation partnership procedure, the introduction of compliance with labour, social and environmental legislation as a fundamental requirement and the award methodology based on the most economically advantageous offer. It is important to note that concessions for works and services, which are subject to the same types of procedures as public contracts, are added to this Financial Regulation. Articles on exclusion have also been amended. The grounds for exclusion are clarified and harmonised with the Directive, as well as the possibility for the economic operator concerned to take corrective action. In order to avoid confusion, the exclusion is clearly separated from the dismissal of a particular procedure.  In addition, a number of provisions have been introduced that respond to clarifications in the text and simplifications. Public procurement provisions have been revised to ensure consistency in the terminology used in the title and clarify certain rules. Support, therefore, of this EP report

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report, which deals with the Commission's proposal to bring the Financial Regulation into line with the provisions of the new directives on public procurement and the award of concession contracts. Indeed, the obligation to apply the general EU public procurement rules to crisis management measures under the common foreign and security policy and, in particular, to civilian missions under the Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP) is the reason for delays in the purchase of basic equipment and services, which has a huge negative impact on the work of missions. As usual, CSDP missions have to work in crisis conditions and for a limited period of time. They are triggered by a unanimous Council decision recognising the need for an immediate response to the crisis. The EU's credibility at international level is under threat in cases where the Union makes important commitments to peace and security. In addition, the safety of mission personnel is often crucial and they do not have the necessary equipment, such as armoured vehicles. The European Parliament therefore considers it necessary to lay down specific rules for CSDP missions, which work mainly in crisis or post-crisis situations. This is in line with the december 2013 restructuring plan. conclusions of the European Council.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The plenary of the European Parliament adopted Ingeborg Grässle's report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 966/2012 on the financial rules applicable to the general budget of the Union. The aim of the proposal was to harmonise the financial regulation with the rules on new public procurement. In view of the fact that the aim of the report was to bring eu public procurement rules into line with the financial regulation setting out the rules governing the spending of the EU budget, I supported the adoption of the proposal as a member of the Hungarian People's Party delegation in line with the European People's Party.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. The European Parliament has made considerable encroachment on the basic text of the European Commission, which has put forward a proposal to bring the Financial Regulation into line with the provisions of the new public procurement directives and on the award of concession contracts. This is not an interference with the general rules on public procurement and concessions, but rather the introduction of an exception in the area of civilian CSDP missions, where delays simply cannot be afforded. These missions take place many times in crisis areas and in crisis situations, where the execution of a classical contract can take up to six months until goods are taken over, which is pointless in this case. However, there is a great need of a great bit of caution, as we are interfering with sensitive matter, and therefore my support for the European Parliament's warnings on this point is also to be taken.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as this report aimed to make access to EU funds simpler, more accountable and efficient whilst also addressing misappropriation and white-collar crime through the introduction of exclusion criteria and a panel to investigate claims. It also aligns the financial regulation with the new directives on public procurement and on the awarding of concession contracts by the EU institutions. Contracting authorities shall be required to take steps to ensure that, when executing contracts, operators comply with the environmental, social and labour law obligations established by the EU or national legislation, collective agreements or the international environmental, social and labour conventions. Regarding exclusion criteria, these were added to counter tax fraud, tax evasion – including tax evasion via untaxed offshore structures – the misuse of corporate assets and the embezzlement of public funds to exclude from participation in the procurement procedures of EU institutions.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe it is important that Community legislation relating to the general budget of the Union is coherent and straightforward. It is therefore important that the relevant legislation takes account of the two directives on public procurement and the award of concession contracts.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. The Commission has proposed to Parliament a text to bring the financial regulation into line with the new public procurement directives for external actions. The application of the rules on the awarding of public contracts lengthens the time frames and therefore does not allow member countries to intervene quickly and effectively. Their proposal does not contribute anything on the merits, other than to add unwise criteria, in particular the one that obliges to award the contract on the basis of the most economically advantageous offer. On the other hand, the legislative resolution improves the Commission's text. In particular, it obliges the adjudicator power to justify the decision not to use the allotment of a contract. That is why I voted for this legislative proposal.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report on the proposal for a regulation on financial rules applicable to the general budget of the Union brings new regulations in the field of public procurement and the conclusion of concession contracts with the European institutions. There are three main directions pursued in this report to which I agree: aligning with the directives according to which clarifications will be introduced on how contracting authorities can contribute to the protection of the environment and the promotion of sustainable development, obtaining an economically advantageous tender and imposing certain labels and/or using appropriate award methods.  The report also covers rules on the exclusion of economic operators in order to protect the Union's financial interests. This will create a database that will centralise exclusion cases to ensure the detection and prevention of potential risk factors, and then the information on excluded operators is made public. As regards public procurement by the Union, it is intended that e-procurement will contribute to the more efficient use of public funds and to improve access to public contracts for all economic operators.  I was in favour of the report on the financial rules applicable to the general budget of the European Union because it ensures the effective, transparent and appropriate use of funds representing one of the Union's main concerns.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
