text: in writing. \u2012 Positive vote, the principles included must also apply to public procurement by the Council, the Commission and Parliament.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 After careful consideration and discussion in this House, I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 966/2012 laying down the financial rules applicable to the general budget of the Union. I particularly agree with the importance of clarifying how contracting authorities can contribute to environmental protection and the promotion of sustainable development, while ensuring that they can obtain the best value for money for their contracts, in particular through the need for specific labels and/or the use of appropriate award methods. It is also essential to use principles of efficiency, transparency and adequacy in public procurement in the Union, and clear management of possible conflicts of interest in order to contribute to a better use of public funds. In any case, I respect the view expressed by the Committee on Foreign Affairs that all efforts to improve efficiency in accordance with the rules in force must be supported, but only specific rules and more flexible procedures, which are different from the current case-by-case approach, can ensure rapid deployment in accordance with logistical and security needs.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as this report aimed to make access to EU funds simpler, more accountable and efficient whilst also addressing misappropriation and white-collar crime through the introduction of exclusion criteria and a panel to investigate claims. It also aligns the financial regulation with the new directives on public procurement and on the awarding of concession contracts by the EU institutions. Contracting authorities shall be required to take steps to ensure that, when executing contracts, operators comply with the environmental, social and labour law obligations established by the EU or national legislation, collective agreements or the international environmental, social and labour conventions. Regarding exclusion criteria, these were added to counter tax fraud, tax evasion – including tax evasion via untaxed offshore structures – the misuse of corporate assets and the embezzlement of public funds to exclude from participation in the procurement procedures of EU institutions.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I support amendments that relate to tackling fraud and meeting the criteria of transparency. Amendments relating to terrorism, human trafficking and child labour; I fully support these amendments that protect nations and individuals from danger.  I do not agree with social and labour laws that are being imposed. We have to agree with the tightening of procedures that combat fraud, tax evasion and embezzlement of union funds. There are a number of amendments that require contractors to adhere to EU policies relating to labour laws and environmental laws, and require the Commission to have more empowerment to enforce certain articles. There is concern relating to amendments dealing with procurement issues. The Committee on Foreign Affairs has stated that procurement rules recognise the aims and objectives of the Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP) so that EU Military and Civilian Operations have the resources to fulfil the objectives of the CSDP.  The protection of whistleblowers and their fundamental rights is something that I can support due to the fact that we can highlight the failings of the EU in certain matters relating to the management of the budget. I voted to abstain.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because the amendments proposed, among others, offer more efficient sanctions against those who avoid the payment of taxes and social security contributions; clearer environmental and labour rules in public procurement procedures and better monitoring of companies to prevent fraud and misuse of funds.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 With the approval of the new Procurement Directive (Directive 2014/24/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council of 26 February 2014 on public procurement repealing Directive 2004/18/EC), it was necessary to revise the corresponding articles of the so-called Financial Regulation in order to harmonise them with EU legislation. The revision actually improves the system (for example with the reports on the protection of the EU's financial interests and the rationalisation of the timing of the Court of Auditors' special reports) so I voted in favour.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. This is the draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 1605/2002 on the protection of the environment. 966/2012 on the financial rules applicable to the general budget of the Union, where the Commission is invited to resubmit the proposal if it intends to make significant amendments or replace it with a new proposal. It is important to mention that Union bodies which are fully self-financed and to which the financial rules laid down in the Framework Financial Regulation do not apply should, for reasons of consistency, adopt similar rules where appropriate.

name: Salvatore Cicu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal on financial rules applicable to the general budget of the Union. The aim of the proposal submitted by the European Commission to Parliament and the Council is to bring the Financial Regulation into line with the provisions of the new directives on public procurement and the award of concession contracts.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I agree, as my party's line also wants, on the desire to apply UNION rules on the common foreign and security policy, since significant delays in the provision of essential equipment and services have several negative repercussions on the functioning of the various missions carried out by the EU.  The Union's credibility on the international stage is at stake in these areas, so I think it would be useful, following Mrs Grässle's report, to introduce specific rules for intervention in crisis and post-crisis contexts. It is also important to make everything as transparent as possible by publishing everything done on websites for easy consultation.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We support amendments that relate to tackling fraud and meeting the criteria of transparency. Amendments relating to terrorism, human trafficking and child labour; we fully support these amendments that protect nations and individuals from danger. We do not agree with social and labour laws that are being imposed. We have to agree with the tightening of procedures that combat fraud, tax evasion and embezzlement of union funds. There are a number of amendments that require contractors to adhere to EU policies relating to labour laws, environmental laws and require the Commission to have more empowerment to enforce certain articles. There is concern relating to amendments dealing with procurement issues. The Committee on Foreign Affairs has stated that procurement rules recognise the aims and objectives of the Common Security and Defence Policy so that EU Military and Civilian Operations have the resources to fulfil the objectives of the CSDP. The protection of whistle-blowers and their fundamental rights is something that we can support due to the fact that we can highlight the failings of the EU in certain matters relating to the management of the budget. UKIP voted to abstain.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support Mrs Gräßle's report, which includes important amendments to the Financial Regulation. There was an urgent need to make changes to the Financial Regulation taking into account the new Directives on public procurement and the award of concession contracts. The rapporteur has tried well to strengthen transparency and create the conditions for a good implementation of Community resources. I welcome the results of the Commission's internal audits to be forwarded to the European Parliament in the discharge procedure. I applaud the strengthening of the evaluation processes for the implementation of the Union budget, in particular the weighting of the resulting European capital. I agree with compliance with sustainability criteria and labour rules in tendering processes. I support the exclusion of tenders from undertakings with social security debts and the stricter conflict-of-interest rules.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I agree with the proposal to bring the Financial Regulation into line with the provisions of the new directives on public procurement and concession contracts, since the obligation to apply general EU procurement rules to crisis management measures under the common foreign and security policy and, in particular, to civilian missions under the Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP) causes significant delays in the provision of essential equipment and services and has significant negative effects on the operation of the missions.  What is at stake here is the EU's credibility on the international stage, at a time when the Eu ropean Union is committed to peace and security. In addition, the safety of its personnel, who do not have essential equipment such as armoured vehicles, is also often at stake. That is why I believe it is appropriate to introduce specific rules for CSDP missions that are different from the current approach and that are more flexible. These rules would ensure adequate protection of the Union's financial interests in the context of the pursuit of the EU's key security objectives, better responding to the imperative of sound, effective and efficient financial management as a result.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Directive 2014/24/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council on public procurement was adopted in 2014. Work was needed to revise the corresponding articles of the Financial Regulation to bring them into line with EU legislation. In particular, it called for the revision of Articles 101-120 on the possibility of negotiating contracts at interinstitutional level, criteria for compliance with environmental, social and legislative standards, exclusion criteria for fraud, corruption, participation in criminal activities, the creation of a verification panel, the creation of a database for an exclusion and detection system linked to OLAF. In view of the improvements to the procedures currently under way, I voted in favour.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Shadow Sinn Fein is proposing in favour, but we abstain because the final resolution includes a positive reference to PPPs (public-private partnerships) I have not been able to vote in favour of this report, even though it includes positive aspects on the control of the EU budget, because it refers positively to the implementation of public-private consortia with the Union budgets. This report proposes a relative improvement in the control system of the European Union budget, this improvement is reflected in the requirement of certificates demonstrating the sustainability of the money spent by the European Union, fraud reporting obligations, specifying the added value of each of the expenditure, etc. However, the report welcomes the development of public-private consortia developed under the EU budget, leading to a potential privatisation of many of the investments made by the EU. That is why I have not been able to vote in favour of this report.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The financial rules relating to the general budget of the Union ensure the proper functioning of the Union and the execution of activities in EU countries. It is therefore important to have clear financial rules both for economic operators and for the protection of the Union's financial interests.  I voted in favour of this resolution because it makes important changes to the rules concerning the formation and implementation of the general budget of the European Union, for example by introducing clearer technical definitions and more precise measures in the field of procurement procedures and financial penalties, and by ensuring that economic operators comply with the applicable obligations in the field of environmental, social and labour law in accordance with European Union law.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The plenary of the European Parliament adopted Mrs Grässle's report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 966/2012 on the financial rules applicable to the general budget of the Union. The aim of the proposal was to harmonise the financial regulation with the rules on new public procurement. Given that the aim of the report was to bring eu public procurement rules into line with the financial regulation setting out the rules governing the spending of the EU budget, I supported the adoption of the proposal.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Commission proposal and the legislative resolution to allow the Financial Regulation and the related Rules of Application to enter into force on 1 January 2016. The Financial Regulation contains the rules and principles of the establishment and implementation of the EU budget and is applicable to all areas of expenditure and all revenue; and I believe that it is important to align the Financial Regulation with the new directives on concessions and public procurements.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ When, all across the European Union, governments and individuals are having to cut back budgets, implement difficult measures and save money, does the rapporteur agree that the continuation of financing a separate parliament in Strasbourg is a complete waste of taxpayers’ money?

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I believe that the 2016 budget reflects the priorities of job creation policies, but I believe that the Council's position to limit the 2016 budget to what was foreseen is a drastic one.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report proposes a revision of the financial rules applicable to the EU's general budget. It includes new principles for public procurement and a clause on compliance with sustainable development rules. The text also prescribes provisions on conflict of interest cases for agents of the European institutions. Supporting the objectives of this report, I voted in favour.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the text on the financial rules applicable to the general budget of the Union. It is necessary to implement the new directives on public procurement and concession contracts in order to have a more competitive and open European market.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The plenary of the European Parliament adopted Ingeborg Grässle's report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 966/2012 on the financial rules applicable to the general budget of the Union. The aim of the proposal was to harmonise the financial regulation with the rules on new public procurement. In view of the fact that the aim of the report was to bring eu public procurement rules into line with the financial regulation setting out the rules governing the spending of the EU budget, the Hungarian People's Party delegation supported the adoption of the proposal in line with the European People's Party.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I strongly support this report as I am fully committed to the fight against fraud and corruption. This is also one of the main problems that Bulgaria still faces on a daily basis. If we are to tackle these problems, we need to be more rigorous and effective in monitoring the processes involved and raising awareness of the more technical side of such problems.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The financial implementing rules of the EU Budget should provide the appropriate means and resources for its simple, substantial, functional but above all flexible design and implementation. The existing format, including the attempt to amend it, is complex, technocratic and is far from adapting to the current requirements of the Union's critical situation.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The plenary of the European Parliament adopted Ingeborg Grässle's report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 966/2012 on the financial rules applicable to the general budget of the Union. The aim of the proposal was to harmonise the financial regulation with the rules on new public procurement. In view of the fact that the aim of the report was to bring eu public procurement rules into line with the financial regulation setting out the rules governing the spending of the EU budget, the Hungarian People's Party delegation supported the adoption of the proposal in line with the European People's Party.

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD)

Amendments relating to terrorism, human trafficking and child labour; we fully support these amendments that protect nations and individuals from danger. We do not agree with social and labour laws that are being imposed. We have to agree with the tightening of procedures that combat fraud, tax evasion and the embezzlement of union funds. There are a number of amendments that require contractors to adhere to EU policies relating to labour laws and environmental laws and require the Commission to have more empowerment to enforce certain articles. There is concern relating to amendments dealing with procurement issues. The Committee on Foreign Affairs has stated that procurement rules recognise the aims and objectives of the Common Security and Defence Policy so that EU Military and Civilian Operations have the resources to fulfil the objectives of the CSDP. The protection of whistle-blowers and their fundamental rights is something that we can support due to the fact that we can highlight the failings of the EU in certain matters relating to the management of the budget. UKIP voted to abstain.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as I believe the proposal provides for more transparency on how funds are spent.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The obligation to apply the general procurement rules of the European Union to crisis management measures under the common foreign and security policy, and in particular to civilian missions, is significantly delayed in the procurement of basic equipment and services and has a negative effect on the functioning of these missions. As a rule, missions operate in a crisis environment and only for a limited period of time. I therefore support the proposal to introduce specific rules for such missions in crisis or post-crisis environments and to bring the Financial Regulation into line with the provisions of the new public procurement directives for external actions.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal for a Regulation includes an amendment to Article 190 of the Financial Regulation on "public procurement for external actions". The motivation relates to the alleged significant delays in the acquisition of essential equipment and services, which condition the effectiveness of such crisis management operations under the Common Foreign and Security Policy (CFSP) and, in particular, civilian missions under the Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP). However, our assessment of this proposal cannot be dissociated from our assessment and our deep disagreement with these common policies, their objectives and consequences. This is not about easing procedures to more effectively assist refugees and migrants, for example, or other improvements in crisis situations. On the contrary, the content, guidance and objectives of the CFSP and CSDP themselves are seeds of crisis and not aid factors for their resolution.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report which aims to include the principles underlying the recent directives on public procurement and concessions among those intended to regulate the functioning of the European institutions.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 My vote is negative with regard to the budgetary rules applicable to the general budget of the Union. The financial rules for the implementation of the EU Budget should provide the appropriate means and resources for its simple, effective, functional but, above all, flexible design and implementation. The current form, including the attempt to amend it, is complex, technocratic and is far from being adapted to the current requirements of the union's critical situation.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This resolution supports the Commission Regulation proposal to the Financial Regulation applicable to the Union budget in accordance with the provisions of the new directives on public procurement and the awarding of contracts concession. It introduces many new, positive changes. I therefore supported adoption of the report in Plenary.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. – The plenary of the European Parliament adopted Ingeborg Grässle's report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 966/2012 on the financial rules applicable to the general budget of the Union. The aim of the proposal was to harmonise the financial regulation with the rules on new public procurement. In view of the fact that the aim of the report was to bring eu public procurement rules into line with the financial regulation setting out the rules governing the spending of the EU budget, the Hungarian People's Party delegation supported the adoption of the proposal in line with the European People's Party.

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council with the aim of ensuring that Union funds are used effectively, transparently and appropriately.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR)
text: Writing. I voted today in favour of the report on the Financial Regulation for the general budget of the Union. My principles are: austerity with taxpayers' money, transparency and efficiency. All this is taken into account in this report in a very balanced way, thanks in part to the impulses of my group's experts.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this proposal, which aims to align the Financial Regulation with the new directives on concessions and public procurements. Important elements included in this report include: principles of sustainability, alongside value for money; re-emphasis of environmental, social and labour law obligations established by Union or national legislation; implementation of recommendations by the Court of Auditors including more stringent measures to ensure greater added value and contribution towards policy objectives; and re-emphasis of exclusion criteria alongside protection for whistleblowers.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. I support the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending the Financial Regulation for the general budget of the Union. The report aims to ensure transparent, efficient and appropriate use of EU funds. It also includes important changes in the Financial Regulation, which are necessary, inter alia, to take account of the new Directive on public procurement and concessions.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ This report on the financial rules applicable to the EU budget aims to adapt the financial regulation of the EU to the new directives on public procurement. These provisions will also increase transparency, ease the procedures and reduce delay. I therefore welcome the adoption of this text.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the Grassle report in considering that it improves the control system in the granting of public procurement and contracts by clarifying and simplifying procedures, establishing clear exclusion criteria and generally improving transparency and efficiency in them.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which aligns the financial regulation with new directives on public procurement and on the award of concession contracts awarded by the European institutions.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The plenary of the European Parliament adopted Ingeborg Grässle's report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 966/2012 on the financial rules applicable to the general budget of the Union. The aim of the proposal was to harmonise the financial regulation with the rules on new public procurement. In view of the fact that the aim of the report was to bring eu public procurement rules into line with the financial regulation setting out the rules governing the spending of the EU budget, the Hungarian People's Party delegation supported the adoption of the proposal in line with the European People's Party.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it helps align the Financial Regulation with the provisions of the new directives on public procurement and the award of concession contracts. Rules such as the ones outlined in this report would ensure adequate protection of the Union’s financial interests in the context of the pursuit of the EU’s key security objectives, responding better to the imperative of sound, effective and efficient financial management as a result.

name: Roger Helmer (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We support amendments that relate to tackling fraud and meeting the criteria of transparency. Amendments relating to terrorism, human trafficking and child labour; we fully support these amendments that protect nations and individuals from danger. We do not agree with social and labour laws that are being imposed. We have to agree with the tightening of procedures that combat fraud, tax evasion and the embezzlement of union funds. There are a number of amendments that require contractors to adhere to EU policies relating to labour laws and environmental laws and require the Commission to have more empowerment to enforce certain articles. There is concern relating to amendments dealing with procurement issues. The Committee on Foreign Affairs has stated that procurement rules recognise the aims and objectives of the Common Security and Defence Policy so that EU Military and Civilian Operations have the resources to fulfil the objectives of the CSDP. UKIP voted to abstain.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. In the report we proposed to amend Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 966/2012 on the Financial Regulation for the general budget of the Union as follows. New provisions will be introduced, such as market advice, the new innovation partnership as a procedure, the introduction of compliance with environmental, social and labour law as an essential prerequisite, the evaluation of criteria in no particular order, price methodology on which the most economically advantageous offer is considered. In addition, for the first time, concessions for works and services are introduced in the Financial Regulation and are subject to the same types of procedures as public contracts. The reasons for the exclusion and the possibility of the remedies in question are clarified. Exclusions are clearly separated from rejection of a particular procedure in order to avoid confusion. The aim of the system is to ensure early identification and prevention of risks and the publication of information on an excluded economic operator; this serves to protect the EU's interests. With this in mind, I voted in favour of this report. Incidentally, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The plenary of the European Parliament adopted Ingeborg Grässle's report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 966/2012 on the financial rules applicable to the general budget of the Union. The aim of the proposal was to harmonise the financial regulation with the rules on new public procurement. In view of the fact that the aim of the report was to bring eu public procurement rules into line with the financial regulation setting out the rules governing the spending of the EU budget, the Hungarian People's Party delegation supported the adoption of the proposal in line with the European People's Party.

name: Pablo Iglesias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the Grssle report in considering that it improves the control system in the granting of public procurement and contracts by clarifying and simplifying procedures, establishing clear exclusion criteria and generally improving transparency and efficiency in them.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The aim of this proposal is to align the Financial Regulation with the new directives on concessions and public procurements. The Financial Regulation contains the rules of the establishment and implementation of the EU budget and is applicable to all areas of expenditure and all revenue.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. The first block of these financial rules applicable to the EU's general budget did not raise any major problems; I voted for it. With regard to the second bloc, part of the provisions envisaged applying the new 2014 public procurement directives to the procurement of EU bodies. If these provisions do not make major changes, they add questionable criteria such as "the allocation on the basis of the most economically advantageous offer".  I voted against it. For the second part of the provisions of the second bloc, they require the adjudicator power to justify the decision not to resort to the allotment of a contract, tax evasion being a ground for exclusion of the candidate. So I voted for it.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Report on the Proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and the Council amending Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 2012/2013. 966/2012 on the financial rules applicable to the General Budget of the Union (COM(2014)0358 - C8 0029/2014-2014/0180 (COD)) adopting the position at first reading, as those proposals improve the use of general Union budget funds. In particular, the procurement process should be taken into account in such a way as to ensure the use of Union funding in an efficient, transparent and appropriate manner. The rules should be such that maximum transparency is achieved in all respects, that entities using the funds have equal opportunities and rights, then that the mechanisms to achieve savings are used when using the funds, and that possible abuses or other forms of irregularity are avoided.

name: Marc Joulaud (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of my colleague Ingeborg's report on the new financial rules for the general budget of the Union. This is a necessary revision of the financial regulation applicable to the EU's general budget to take account of the adoption of directives on public procurement and the awarding of concession contracts, which aims to increase the transparency and efficiency of the budgetary procedure.  The report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report because it makes it possible to adapt the financial regulation applicable to the EU budget to the new European rules concerning, in particular, public procurement or the awarding of concession contracts.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. In her report, Mrs Gräßle makes very constructive proposals on how the EU can better protect its financial interests in public procurement, prevent corruption and also exclude formerly unreliable contractors from applicants. It is stricter than the Commission's proposal. I support her line and vote in favour of her report.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report, as the purpose of this proposal is to align the Financial Regulation with the new directives on concessions and public procurements.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. In the report we proposed to amend Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 966/2012 on the Financial Regulation for the general budget of the Union as follows. New provisions will be introduced, such as market advice, the new innovation partnership as a procedure, the introduction of compliance with environmental, social and labour law as an essential prerequisite, the evaluation of criteria in no particular order, price methodology on which the most economically advantageous offer is considered. The reasons for the exclusion and the possibility of the remedies in question are clarified. Exclusions are clearly separated from rejection of a particular procedure in order to avoid confusion. The aim of the system is to ensure early identification and prevention of risks and the publication of information on an excluded economic operator; this serves to protect the EU's interests. With this in mind, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 On 7 November 2015, in plenary of the European Parliament in Strasbourg, we voted on a report on a draft regulation amending the regulation laying down financial rules for the general budget of the EU. This is a very technical amendment, which had to be implemented in particular in order to make access to EU funds easier, more reliable, more efficient and, at the same time, to prevent the misuse of these funds more effectively. In addition, it was necessary to adapt this Regulation also to the new public procurement and concession directives of the EU institutions. I see the adjustments made rather positively, as they simplify overall the procedures and rules on the criteria of admissibility and inadmissibility for the award of concession contracts by the EU. In particular, I see positively that the criteria for excluding a participant from eu institutions' procurement procedures include past tax fraud, tax evasion, including tax evasion through un taxed offshore structures or embezzlement of public funds. The report goes into such detail that it addresses and distinguishes between different types of 'conflicts of interest' and serious professional misconduct by officials or representatives of the EU institutions. In view of these positive changes, I supported the proposal in the vote.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The plenary of the European Parliament adopted Ingeborg Grässle's report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 966/2012 on the financial rules applicable to the general budget of the Union. The aim of the proposal was to harmonise the financial regulation with the rules on new public procurement. In view of the fact that the aim of the report was to bring eu public procurement rules into line with the financial regulation setting out the rules governing the spending of the EU budget, the Hungarian People's Party delegation supported the adoption of the proposal in line with the European People's Party.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. Following the adoption of Regulation (EU) No 1303/2013 of the European Parliament and of the Council, it is necessary to amend Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 966/2012. This amendment may again make available the decommitted appropriations for the implementation of the performance reserve and the financial instruments for unlimited guarantees and securitisation for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). For these reasons, I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. This text aims to apply the new rules on public procurement adopted by the EU in 2014 (which are being transposed by Member States) to EU institutions and bodies. If the Commission's original text does not change much from the previous directives (although it strengthens the allotment rule allowing SMEs to more apply), it adds some critical criteria such as 'the allocation on the basis of the most economically advantageous offer', which favours the least-so-called 'local produce' and social or environmental criteria. However, the text amended by MEPs makes some interesting changes, such as the obligation for the adjudicator power to justify the decision not to use the allotment of a contract or the fact that tax evasion constitutes a reason for exclusion of a candidate. So I voted for this text.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. This is a proposal to adapt the Financial Regulation to the provisions of the new Directives on government procurement and the award of concession contracts. The amendments to the text of the Financial Regulation contain, inter alia, the adaptation to the Directive introducing new provisions, such as the introduction of compliance with labour, social and environmental legislation as a fundamental requirement and the award methodology based on the most economically advantageous offer. In addition, concessions for works and services, which are subject to the same types of procedures as public contracts, are introduced for the first time in the Financial Regulation. Agreeing with the proposal, I voted in favour.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. The proposal for a small European process aims to simplify and speed up disputes concerning such processes in cross-border matters and to reduce costs. In particular, it is designed to help consumers and small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) demand debt payment and consequently, by ensuring access to justice.   Several surveys have found that a high percentage of undertakings involved in cross-border litigation do not come to justice, either because of the disproportionate costs of legal proceedings in relation to the amount of the claim, or because the process would take too long. The report presented therefore aims to further reduce costs and length of processes and facilitate formalities for the parties involved.  Therefore, in view of the benefits that these measures will have in resolving such disputes, I am in favour of this report and I have expressed this with my vote.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. In the report we proposed to amend Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 966/2012 on the Financial Regulation for the general budget of the Union as follows. New provisions will be introduced, such as market advice, the new innovation partnership as a procedure, the introduction of compliance with environmental, social and labour law as an essential prerequisite, the evaluation of criteria in no particular order, price methodology on which the most economically advantageous offer is considered. In addition, for the first time, concessions for works and services are introduced in the Financial Regulation and are subject to the same types of procedures as public contracts. The reasons for the exclusion and the possibility of the remedies in question are clarified. Exclusions are clearly separated from rejection of a particular procedure in order to avoid confusion. The aim of the system is to ensure early identification and prevention of risks and the publication of information on an excluded economic operator; this serves to protect the EU's interests. With this in mind, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree with those parts of the text dealing with the transparency of EU finances. However, I am opposed to those parts that place the Commission's ideas on labour or environmental law on contractors. I therefore abstained in the final vote.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒I believe that these amendments will bring the rules of financial regulation in line with Directive 2014/24/EU on public procurement, thus contributing to improving the application of labour law, environmental and social policy legislation and stricter penalties in cases of conflicts of interest and serious unprofessional practices, fraud, corruption, money laundering, terrorist financing, tax fraud, tax avoidance and aggressive tax planning. As this Report calls for and encourages the use of online public procurement in order to manage the resources of the European Union as efficiently and transparently as possible, I supported the proposal for a legislative resolution of the European Parliament amending the Regulation of the European Parliament and Council No 1007/2013. 966/2012 on the financial rules applicable to the general budget of the European Union.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Financial stability in the 28-member European Union is vital. Given the impact of the EU budget on a mundane basis, it is very important to be perfectly clear how, to whom and how much is spent on a case-by-case basis. A large part of the amendments adopted today are precisely focused on the effective implementation of such principles. Agricultural policy, fisheries, culture, external relations and defence policy, industry, economy and finance, regional development and cooperation, as well as interregional cohesion – huge sums of money are spent each year in all these and a number of other areas inside and outside the European Union. It was our duty in this case to support amendments that would potentially lead to more efficient spending and its monitoring in the European Union, both at supranational level and nationally, when it concerns European funds and other sources, most of which are undoubtedly made up of contributions from European taxpayers, whether or not.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 1605/2002. 966/2012 on the financial rules applicable to the general budget of the Union, because it is sufficiently documented.

name: David Martin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Public procurement should serve to ensure that Union funds are used in an effective, transparent, and appropriate manner: that being the case, procurement procedures should be moved into cyberspace, as this would save a great deal of money compared with conventional public procurement procedures, as well as making such procedures more accessible for small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission has submitted to Parliament and the Council a proposal to amend Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 966/2012 laying down the rules applicable to the European Union budget. The priority objective of the Financial Regulation is the protection of the European Union's financial interests. Europe intends to combat fraud affecting its expenditure and revenue through sanctions in all the countries of the European Union. Protecting financial interests is a top priority for the European institutions.

name: Stefano Maullu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this legislative resolution as it improves the system of procedures and reduces delays in public procurement. I also agree that e-procurement improves access to public procurement for economic operators.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it respects the application of environmental and labour rules are upheld as well as respecting sustainability criteria.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The first block of these financial rules applicable to the EU's general budget did not raise any major problems. The congresswoman voted for it. With regard to the second bloc, part of the provisions envisaged applying the new 2014 public procurement directives to the procurement of EU bodies. If these provisions do not make major changes, they add questionable criteria such as "the allocation on the basis of the most economically advantageous offer".  The congresswoman voted against it. For the second part of the provisions of the second bloc, they require the adjudicator power to justify the decision not to resort to the allotment of a contract, tax evasion being a ground for exclusion of the candidate. The congresswoman voted for it.

name: Jean-Luc Mélenchon (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The Commission's proposal aims to adapt the regulation on the financial rules applicable to the EU's general budget to take account of the new directives on the awarding of public procurement and the awarding of concession contracts for contracts awarded by EU institutions on their own behalf. New provisions are introduced, such as the obligation to respect the provisions of environmental law, social law or the method of attribution on the basis of the most economically advantageous offer.  However, in a liberal logic, the text also favours public-private partnerships. The text also proposes to speed up the contracting procedure for external action and the Common Security and Defence Policy (PSDC).  For these reasons I abstain.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Regulation laying down the financial provisions applicable to the general budget of the Union.  The European Parliament has an important power to improve the rules for implementing the budget, with regard to increasing the visibility and benefits of Union funding for citizens.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this resolution as it would modify the financial regulation regarding the use of funds by the European Union, mostly focusing on the area of procurement. These changes ensure proper adherence to environmental, labour, and other social standards, efficient use of budget funds, and clarify the grounds by which firms are excluded from the procurement process.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposal for a Financial Regulation will aim at amending and guiding the applicable rules applicable to the general budget of the Union. At present, it is the duty to apply regulations and rules equally in all circumstances. However, these rules are not adapted to crisis and post-crisis situations where their application may have negative effects such as delay, incomplete equipment and malfunctioning within missions. It is necessary to adapt the existing EU financial rules and to introduce specific rules for common security and defence policy missions in order to increase their flexibility and efficiency. It is therefore appropriate to provide for greater flexibility of procedures by delegating powers of budget to the mandated Civilian Operation Commander, which will lead to effective financial management and protection of the Union's financial interests. I call for budgetary measures to be aligned so that csdp regulations are adapted to situations and adequate conditions. However, efficiency, efficiency and, above all, transparency must remain at the heart of the change in the general rules on public procurement.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. EURATOM was established in 1957 with the aim of developing the peaceful use of nuclear energy in Member States sharing this objective, preventing the proliferation of nuclear weapons and coordinating Member States' research programmes on the peaceful use of nuclear energy. I would like to vote in favour of this report which safeguards the fact that Union public procurement serves to ensure that European funds are used effectively, transparently and appropriately. It should also be stressed that e-procurement should contribute to better use of public funds and improve access to public procurement for all economic operators.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the proposed regulation of the European Parliament and the Council amending the financial rules applicable to the general budget of the Union. This text deals with the adaptation of the new European directives on public procurement and the awarding of concession contracts. The aim is to ensure that all economic players have access to these markets and provide them with greater legal certainty. In particular, I voted in favour of the amendment, which stresses the importance of the efficient, transparent and appropriate use of European funds when awarding such contracts. In times of economic crisis, it is essential not to deviate from rigorous management of public funds and to secure the companies that are the basis of wealth creation in Europe.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Financial Regulation contains the rules and principles of the establishment and the implementation of the EU budget and is applicable to all areas of expenditure and all revenue. I am in agreement with the financial rules applicable to the general budget of the Union and therefore I have voted in favour.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission has proposed specific provisions on general public procurement rules for the European Union, which will speed up these procedures according to the specificities of civilian crisis management and increase their effectiveness. I found the proposals useful and forward-looking, which is why I supported them.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This text aims to apply the new rules on public procurement adopted by the EU in 2014 (which are being transposed by member states) to the transfers of EU institutions and bodies. While the Commission's original text does not change much from the previous directives (although it strengthens the allotment rule allowing SMEs more to apply), it adds some critical criteria such as 'the allocation on the basis of the most economically advantageous offer', which favours the lowest-priced at the expense of 'local produce' and social or environmental criteria. However, the text amended by MEPs makes some interesting changes, such as the obligation for the adjudicator power to justify the decision not to use the allotment of a market or the fact that tax evasion constitutes a reason for exclusion of a candidate. So I voted for this text.

name: Claude Moraes (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report which aligns the financial regulation with new directives on public procurement and on the award of concession contracts awarded by the European institutions.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We have today voted in favour of adopting this Commission proposal to bring the Eu ropean Union's Financial Regulation into line with the provisions of the new directives on public procurement and the award of concession contracts.  In particular, with regard to crisis management measures under the common foreign and security policy and related civilian missions, the obligation to apply general UNION rules has often caused significant delays in the provision of essential equipment and services and has had considerable negative repercussions on the functioning of the missions. What is at stake here is the EU's credibility on the international stage, at a time when the Eu ropean Union is committed to peace and security.  We therefore believe that it is appropriate to introduce specific rules and more flexible procedures, which are different from the current case-by-case approach, and which can therefore ensure rapid deployment in accordance with logistical and security needs. These rules would also ensure adequate protection of the Union's financial interests in the context of the pursuit of the EU's key security objectives, better responding to the imperative of sound, effective and efficient financial management as a result.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report that will improve the financial rules applicable to the general budget of the Union. As shadow rapporteur on this report I have lowered the discrimination of diverse economic operators.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this text as I believe it is indeed very necessary to impose stricter limits on the financial operators the EU uses in its various projects. There are clearly severe problems, in several Member States, as regard to Union programmes. We finance, mostly indirectly, a huge amount of programmes and sometimes there is not nearly enough oversight of the achievements of those spent funds. At the same time, it important for many countries, Romania included, not to block but to facilitate more funding and better spending. The key is to impose better oversight and a more dynamic payment system that can lead to more money actually being spent and more efforts being finalised.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report as this report aimed to make access to EU funds simpler, more accountable and efficient whilst also addressing misappropriation and white-collar crime through the introduction of exclusion criteria and a panel to investigate claims. It also aligns the financial regulation with the new directives on public procurement and on the awarding of concession contracts by the EU institutions. Contracting authorities shall be required to take steps to ensure that, when executing contracts, operators comply with the environmental, social and labour law obligations established by the EU or national legislation, collective agreements or the international environmental, social and labour conventions. Regarding exclusion criteria, these were added to counter tax fraud, tax evasion – including tax evasion via untaxed offshore structures – the misuse of corporate assets and the embezzlement of public funds to exclude from participation in the procurement procedures of EU institutions.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the financial rules for the general budget of the Union, which, in my opinion, brings higher legal quality. I would particularly like to highlight the inclusion of fraud, tax fraud, tax evasion, including tax evasion through un taxed offshore structures, misuse of corporate assets and embezzlement of public funds among the grounds for exclusion from the public procurement procedures of the Union institutions. I consider this to be one of the evidence that the EU is serious about its fight against tax fraud and evasion and the grey economy.

name: Andrey Novakov (PPE)
text: in writing. – I congratulate Mrs Ingeborg Gräßle for her report showcasing professionalism. 80% of the EU budget is managed by the Member States under the Cohesion Policy. Therefore, the Union’s budget is a long-term EU growth engine. Key instruments for the achievement of this goal are the European Structural and Investment Funds (ESIF). In this regard, the European Parliament should be the watchdog guaranteeing that the EU budget is used in the best possible way. We should remain vocal on ensuring financial prudency and result orientation of the EU budget. Regarding performance, we should measure project outcomes (useful results for citizens and businesses). For example, measuring the economic benefits of a road, or a bridge, not their length and features. Improving financial management and performance is part of a larger effort – to cut the red tape in EU funding and to fight fraud.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. This report contains very constructive proposals on how to better protect financial interests in public procurement, prevent corruption and exclude formerly unreliable contractors from applications. On the basis of these facts, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. It aligns financial rules with the new Directives. These directives concern public procurement and the award of concession contracts, so foreign and security policy and defence policy facilitate the faster award of public contracts, which in turn ensures more efficient administration in the European Union.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I voted in favour of the report tabled.  The rules on public procurement and concessions must also apply to contracts concluded at the expense of the EU institutions. It is therefore appropriate to align the Financial Regulation with the provisions of the new Directives on public procurement and the award of concession contracts.  In order to ensure early detection and prevention of risks, the EU needs to have a common framework in place to ensure strict application of the exclusion. It should be noted that this system should be developed on the basis of the central database already available for exclusion. The protection of the Union's financial interests must remain a priority in achieving the objectives set. This protection must be continuously strengthened. In this context, I support the proposal to include tax evasion in the procurement procedures of the Union institutions as a basis for a ban on participation in the procedure.

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament's report on the financial rules applicable to the general budget of the Union, because I believe that the amendment of the EU Euratom Regulation is necessary, in order to ensure greater linearity in the procedures for the award of contracts by the European institutions.   The amendment of various articles of the regulation adds precise criteria for selection and access to European contracts to the procedure, automatically excluding from the tender administrations that have committed serious professional offences, fraud, corruption, participation in a criminal organisation, money laundering, non-compliance with obligations relating to the payment of contributions, taxes and charges, terrorist financing and child labour. In order to ensure a deterrent effect, and to ensure that the attempt to unduly obtain Union funds does not happen again, it is expected, as an alternative or in addition to exclusion from the tender, a financial penalty and, in the most serious cases, the publication of exclusion information. Particular attention is also paid to environmental protection and sustainable development by setting minimum standards to be respected in accordance with international environmental law and national environmental protection standards. European funds will therefore be better monitored in accordance with the principle of transparency and publicity.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support all the changes that have been made, especially with regard to transparency in the use of Union funds. For this reason, I have chosen to vote in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒The report on the proposal for a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council amending the Financial Rules Regulation applicable to the General Budget of the Union shows us that the members of the Committee on Budgets have understood the need to align the Financial Regulation with the new public procurement directives and to award concession contracts awarded by the European institutions for their account. That is why they proposed a number of amendments to the original Commission proposal with the apparent intention that the final appearance of the new regulation would best protect the financial interests of the Union. The opinions of the Foreign Affairs Committee and the Committee on Budgetary Control were also taken into account, which also proposed amendments to the Commission's proposal and called on the Committee on Budgets to take into account as the committee responsible what it had done. The principles applicable to public procurement, exclusion criteria for economic operators involved in tax fraud, the definition of conflicts of interest and serious misconduct, the provision of opportunities for economic operators to submit their observations prior to expulsion from a specific public procurement procedure, early detection and exclusion system for economic operators in the commission of an unlawful act and electronic procurement are some of the areas covered by this report. I believe that this report protects the interests not only of the European institutions but also of us as individuals and I will therefore support it.

name: Florian Philippot (ENF)
text: In writing. This text aims to apply the new rules on public procurement adopted by the EU in 2014 (which are being transposed by Member States) to the public procurement of EU institutions and bodies. While the Commission's original text does not change much from the previous directives (although it strengthens the allotment rule allowing SMEs more to apply), it adds some critical criteria such as 'the most economically advantageous supply', which encourages the lowest bidder at the expense of 'local produce' and social or environmental criteria. However, the text amended by MEPs makes some interesting changes, such as the obligation for the adjudicator power to justify the decision not to use the allotment of a contract or the fact that tax evasion constitutes a reason for exclusion of a candidate. So I voted for this text.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I welcome the Commission's efforts and proposed amendments aimed at harmonising financial regulation and provisions of new public procurement directives and the award of concession contracts. First of all, it is necessary to support the requirements to strengthen communication between contracting authorities and the European Parliament and the Council, as well as between the Commission and Parliament. I also welcome the demands for stricter scrutiny of the contracts with economic operators and the evaluation of their execution, with a view to increasing liability for any damages committed to the financial interests of the European Union, but also guarantees that the deals contribute to policy achievements and produce added value.  In addition, the amendments introduce important distinctions and more detailed definitions that make the text of the Commission itself more precise and clearer for interpretation. The specific proposed measures concerning the prevention of conflicts of interest, ensuring the fairness of tenderers' competition and the protection of whistleblowers are commendable. It also welcomes a greater emphasis on efficiency and transparency that should contribute to better use of public funds and increase the availability of public contracts to all economic operators. Finally, account should be taken of the need for some flexibility in the application of general procurement rules with regard to the Common Foreign and Security Policy, i.e. to prevent situations where harmonisation of regulation leads to delays in the procurement of highly important equipment for security missions, which may call into question the safety of personnel.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support the proposal to amend the regulation on financial rules applicable to the General Budget of the Union, which aims to bring financial regulations in line with the provisions of the new public procurement directives and the award of concession contracts. As Vice-Chair of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, I would like to highlight the change in Article 190 relating to the procurement of external action. Common Security and Defence Policy missions often operate in crisis areas within a limited timeframe. The financial rules so far, which have actually been created for a functioning and stable European internal market, cause delays in key materials that are very often submitted only six months after the publication of the public tender. This undermines the European Union's credibility internationally, given the fact that the EU is taking important commitments in peacekeeping and security activities around the world. For all of the above, I consider that the establishment of specific financial rules and more flexible procedures is necessary for the purpose of managing financial management as efficiently as possible and meeting the Union's objectives.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission has submitted to the European Parliament and the Council a proposal to bring the Financial Regulation into line with the provisions of the new directives on public procurement and the award of concession contracts.  This proposal includes an amendment to Article 190 on 'external action procurement'. Civilian missions under the Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP) normally take place in a crisis context and within a limited period of time. Their operational implementation is often delayed precisely because of general EU procurement rules that are not adapted to such situations. These delays make a major contribution to preventing the Union from expressing the full potential of its external action as effectively as possible. I therefore hope that specific rules can be adopted to ensure better protection of the Union's financial interests in the pursuit of the EU's key security and foreign policy objectives. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 In order to take account of the new directives on public procurement and concession contracts concluded by the EU institutions in their own name in Regulation No 966/2012 on the financial rules applicable to the general budget of the Union, the EP is making it impossible to determine the estimated value of the contract in order to circumvent the existing rules on public procurement or to divide the contract into lots for this purpose; extends the criteria for excluding eu institutions from participation in procurement procedures to include tax fraud, tax evasion and misappropriation of public funds, clarifies the distinction and strengthens the proposed system of early detection and exclusion, providing for the temporary exclusion or imposition by the relevant team of financial penalties on economic operators or the permanent exclusion of economic operators in serious cases such as corruption and terrorist financing. I voted in favour of the report in order to strengthen early detection and exclusion systems and to increase the fairness and transparency of the procurement and concession contracts of the EU institutions.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am a strong supporter of the transparency of public procurement and already as Czech Minister of Justice I have supported it universally. Today, however, we are discussing a situation where it is necessary to rationally allow for some simplification of procurement rules in resolution measures under the common foreign and security policy, and in particular in civilian missions under the EU's common security and defence policy. It is logical here that action must be among the priorities, and the rules must contribute to avoiding delays. For this reason, this proposal has my support.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I have spoken in favour of the revision of the financial regulation applicable to the general BUDGET of the Union following the adoption of directives on public procurement and the awarding of concession contracts. This text helps to simplify and clarify EU financial rules legislation.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. This report proposes to adapt the Financial Regulation to the provisions of the new Directives on government procurement and the award of concession contracts. A number of amendments are introduced such as the new innovation partnership procedure, the introduction of compliance with labour, social and environmental legislation as a fundamental requirement and the award methodology based on the most economically advantageous offer. It is important to note that concessions for works and services, which are subject to the same types of procedures as public contracts, are added to this Financial Regulation. Articles on exclusion have also been amended. The grounds for exclusion are clarified and harmonised with the Directive, as well as the possibility for the economic operator concerned to take corrective action. In order to avoid confusion, the exclusion is clearly separated from the dismissal of a particular procedure.  In addition, a number of provisions have been introduced that respond to clarifications in the text and simplifications. Public procurement provisions have been revised to ensure consistency in the terminology used in the title and clarify certain rules. I therefore support this EP report.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which concerns the proposed regulation of the European Parliament and the Council which amends Regulation 966/2012 on the financial rules applicable to the general EU budget. Protecting the UNION's financial interests is one of the essential principles and objectives of this financial regulation. The Eu has repeatedly expressed its intention to combat tax evasion and evasion. With the underground economy accounting for almost one-fifth of GDP in the EU and tens of billions of euros continuing to be held in extraterritorial structures, in many cases without being declared or subject to tax, strengthening the fight against tax evasion and evasion is not only a matter of revenue, but also of fairness. It is possible to better protect the Union's financial interests by incorporating tax evasion into the grounds for excluding public procurement procedures from EU institutions. The vote on this text is a part of this.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The purpose of this proposal for a Regulation is to amend the Financial Regulation on the financial provisions applicable to the general budget of the Union in order to take account of the new directives on public procurement and the award of concession contracts concluded by the European institutions.  In view of the alignment of the Financial Regulation with the new Directives, I welcome the changes that have been included, also stressing that, in accordance with the principle of sustainability, contracting authorities should take appropriate measures to ensure that, during the performance of contracts, economic operators comply with the obligations under environmental, social and labour legislation laid down in national and Community legislation. In addition, works and service concessions are now introduced for the first time in the Financial Regulation and are subject to the same types of public procurement procedures. Finally, like the rapporteur, I believe that Union public procurement should serve to ensure that Union funds are used effectively, transparently and appropriately and, to that extent, I have given my vote in favour of this report.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal for financial rules applicable to the general budget of the Union, which aims to revise the Financial Regulation following the adoption of the new directives on public procurement and the award of concession contracts.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of the Grassle report in considering that it improves the control system in the granting of public procurement and contracts by clarifying and simplifying procedures, establishing clear exclusion criteria and generally improving transparency and efficiency in them.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report, although it includes positive aspects on the control of the EU budget, because it refers positively to the implementation of public-private consortia with the Union budgets. This report proposes a relative improvement in the control system of the European Union budget, this improvement is reflected in the requirement of certificates demonstrating the sustainability of the money spent by the European Union, fraud reporting obligations, specifying the added value of each of the expenditure, etc. However, the report welcomes the development of public-private consortia developed under the EU budget, leading to a potential privatisation of many of the investments made by the EU. That is why I have not been able to vote in favour of this report.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 The measures approved today aim to improve fairness and transparency in the public procurement process and in the award of concession contracts by the EU institutions. I shared the European Parliament's position, because I believe that these new financial rules can effectively prevent cases of tax fraud and misappropriation of public funds.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this legislative resolution. I agree with the amendments that related to transparency. However, there are a number of amendments which would require contractors to adhere to EU policies relating to labour and environmental laws and would require the Commission to have more power to enforce certain articles.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The proposal that I voted for aligns the Financial Regulation with the new directives on concessions and public procurement. It will be good to see this enter into force at the beginning of next year.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the resolution that will increase transparency and fairness in public procurement and concession awards by the EU institutions. I also welcome the extension of the criteria for exclusion from participation in public procurement of EU institutions, such as tax fraud and tax evasion, or the misappropriation of public funds.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. ‒ This explanation of the vote comes as a criticism of the existing system of evaluation of the work of MEMBERS of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities potentiated in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual quality and quantity of work, efficiency and most of all the success of parliamentary action.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. In the report we proposed to amend Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 966/2012 on the Financial Regulation for the general budget of the Union as follows. New provisions will be introduced, such as market advice, the new innovation partnership as a procedure, the introduction of compliance with environmental, social and labour law as an essential prerequisite, the evaluation of criteria in no particular order, price methodology on which the most economically advantageous offer is considered. In addition, for the first time, concessions for works and services are introduced in the Financial Regulation and are subject to the same types of procedures as public contracts. The reasons for the exclusion and the possibility of the remedies in question are clarified. Exclusions are clearly separated from rejection of a particular procedure in order to avoid confusion. The aim of the system is to ensure early identification and prevention of risks and the publication of information on an excluded economic operator; this serves to protect the EU's interests. With this in mind, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. – The financial rules, like all other EU rules, must be respected if we are to ensure efficient and fair functioning. If the rules set do not comply, for example in crisis interventions in third countries under the common defence and security policy, they must, of course, be adapted to ensure the rapid and flexible implementation of operations.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. I support this Report because it would further protect the Financial Interests of the Union and should improve the exclusion rules for participation in procurement procedures. Thus, a single system should be put in place to increase the protection of the Union's financial interests, taking into account the central exclusion database. An economic operator which may demonstrate its reliability by taking corrective action should not be subject to an exclusionary decision. Furthermore, the contracting authority should exclude the economic operator from the proceedings and where a final administrative decision or judgment has been taken on the event of serious misconduct, non-compliance with obligations, money laundering, terrorist financing and the like. It is necessary to clarify which economic operators have access to the procurement procedure of the Union institutions itself depending on their place of establishment. In my view, any entity involved in the implementation of the budget should share information on the economic operator concerned in order to protect the Financial Interests of the Union when taking exclusion decisions taken under its own responsibility.

name: Catherine Stihler (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report which aligns the financial regulation with new directives on public procurement and on the awarding of concession contracts by the European institutions.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ This report represents a revision of the financial rules on the general budget of the European Union due to the adopted Public Procurement Directives and on the award of concession contracts.  Some of the changes adopted concern NGOs, and it was decided that assimilation of such organisations with international organisations would still be possible, but only in strictly defined circumstances. Furthermore, the method of sharing performance information in the annual work reports is expected to improve, including the European added value achieved.  Some of the changes also concern financial instruments and the European Parliament has thus ensured that non-payment of taxes and social security results in exclusion from these financial instruments. In addition, the revision of the rules reduced the processing time of the ECA's special reports.  I fully support this proposal as it is clear that the existing rules should always be adapted to the new situations and that the changes mentioned above, as well as many others set out in this report, will lead to improved efficiency of the Union and all its bodies.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the proposal as it introduces measures that can increase the efficiency of the use of funds from the European Union budget and reduce the amount of fraud. However, much more needs to be done to make the EU budget actually more efficient, as the vast majority of it still consists of Eu funds and subsidies to farmers, which do more harm than good.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the financial rules applicable to the general budget of the Union.
