The report brings the Financial Regulation into line with the provisions of the new public procurement directives and on the award of concession contracts. This will reduce the significant delays that arise in public procurement in the area of common security and defence policy. As an alternate member of the Committee on Budgetary Control, I also support the committee's amendments, which, with its proposals, draw attention to the need for the EU to combat tax fraud and tax evasion in order to protect its financial interests.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The financial rules for the implementation of the EU Budget should provide the appropriate means and resources for its simple, effective and functional but, above all, flexible design and implementation. The existing format, including the attempt to amend it, is complex, technocratic and is far from being adapted to the current requirements of the Union's critical situation.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The plenary of the European Parliament adopted Ingeborg Grässle's report on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 966/2012 on the financial rules applicable to the general budget of the Union. The aim of the proposal was to harmonise the financial regulation with the rules on new public procurement. In view of the fact that the aim of the report was to bring eu public procurement rules into line with the financial regulation setting out the rules governing the spending of the EU budget, the Hungarian People's Party delegation supported the adoption of the proposal in line with the European People's Party.

name: Claudia Tapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union budget is the main instrument by which we can, as European institutions, achieve our goals and have a direct impact on the lives of European citizens. Its expenditure requires compliance with mutually agreed rules, which must ensure the efficient use of funds to achieve the precise objectives and the optimal impact on the established target groups. From this point of view, the general EU budget is the most concrete expression of the principle of European solidarity. At certain times, however, the rules governing the general budget of the Union must be reassessed and improved in the light of new experiences in the practice of using these funds.  The European Commission's proposals are worth considering, given the institutional experience gained in carrying out projects with European funding. The position of the European Parliament, however, is at least as important, because it makes an important contribution from the direct representatives of the citizens of the Member States. This document is significant for the implementation of European programmes from next year and aims both at simplifying the rules, making the spending of European money more efficient, while at the same time achieving optimal control over compliance with the existing rules, so it must be adopted as soon as possible.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the european Parliament and the Council amending the regulation (EU, Euratom) no 966/2012 on the financial rules applicable to the general EU budget. These changes concern, among other things, the awarding of public contracts, a subject which is very close to my heart. It also outlines how contracting authorities can contribute to environmental protection and the promotion of sustainable development, while ensuring the ability to obtain the best value for money in their markets, which they can do, in particular by requiring specific labels or using appropriate allocation methods.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on amending Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 966/2012 on the financial rules applicable to the general budget of the Union. The proposal aims at aligning the financial regulation with the new directives on public procurement and on the award of concession contracts awarded by the European institutions on their own account. The European Parliament made several changes to the original proposal, recommending for example that the estimated value of a contract may not be determined with a view to circumventing the applicable rules, nor may a contract be split up for that purpose. It also agreed that tax fraud and tax evasion should be integrated in the criteria for exclusion from participation in procurement procedures of EU institutions.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the proposal to amend the financial rules applicable to the general budget, as new public procurement directives are taken into account and the objective is to make better use of public funds and greater availability of public contracts to economic operators.  In fact, I believe that the proposed measures, such as increased market advice and stricter provisions based on the most economically favorable decisions, will protect the financial interests of the European Union.  I believe that these amendments can ensure that the reasons for exclusion, the conditions of competence and criteria for selecting tenders in public procurement are more transparent and clearer to all entities, which is also seen in the extension of exclusion criteria to tax fraud, tax evasion and misappropriation of public funds.  I strongly support strengthening eliance and transparency in public procurement processes through early detection of irregularities and exclusion, so I voted for these changes.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 966/2012 on the financial rules applicable to the general budget of the Union by aligning the Financial Regulation with the provisions of the new Public Procurement Directives and on the award of concession contracts. The proposal contains an amendment to Article 190 on public procurement for external actions. The mandatory application of the EU general public procurement rules to crisis management measures under the common foreign and security policy, in particular civilian CSDP missions, causes significant delays in the purchase of emergency equipment and services, which has a very unfavourable impact on the implementation of missions. It is therefore right that the procedures should be simplified and that efficiency in the application of the existing rules should be increased.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the Grssle report in considering that it improves the control system in the granting of public procurement and contracts by clarifying and simplifying procedures, establishing clear exclusion criteria and generally improving transparency and efficiency in them.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the Grassle report in considering that it improves the control system in the granting of public procurement and contracts by clarifying and simplifying procedures, establishing clear exclusion criteria and generally improving transparency and efficiency in them.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this legislative report on the financial rules applicable to the general budget of the Union. The regulation lays down the rules for the establishment and the implementation of the general budget of the European Union and it also contains rules on public procurement. It respects the fundamental rights and observes the principles enshrined in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, in particular the need to ensure the legality and proportionality of sanctions, therefore I think it is needed in order to achieve greater transparency and accountability regarding financial allocations.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. We are talking about a revision of the financial rules applicable to the general budget of the union following the adoption of two directives on public procurement and on the award of contracts. It is therefore necessary to vote in favour of such an amendment in order to adapt in this way the financial rules applicable to the general budget of the Union.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the reform of the financial rules applicable to the general budget of the Union because the new text, revised in accordance with the Procurement Directive adopted in 2014, introduces significant improvements for the protection of the EU's financial interests, such as the possibility of negotiating contracts at interinstitutional level and the introduction of new criteria for compliance with environmental and social regulations.  The text of the reform inserts safeguard constraints to prevent the infiltration of organised crime into invitations to tender, thanks to the provision of criteria for exclusion from contracts for fraud, corruption and participation in criminal activities, thanks to the creation of a database for the detection of illegal practices, developed in collaboration with OLAF. This point was decisive for my voting position. In addition, the measures taken will improve the reports on the protection of the EU's financial interests and the performance of European funds, making the data more accessible and transparent. Finally, the reform optimises the deadlines for the transmission of reports made by the European Court of Auditors and rationalises the transmission of internal audit reports useful for discharge.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I have not been able to vote in favour of this report, although it includes positive aspects on the control of the EU budget, because it refers positively to the implementation of public-private consortia with the Union budgets. This report proposes a relative improvement in the control system of the European Union budget, this improvement is reflected in the requirement of certificates demonstrating the sustainability of the money spent by the European Union, fraud reporting obligations, specifying the added value of each of the expenditure, etc. However, the report welcomes the development of public-private consortia developed under the EU budget, leading to a potential privatisation of many of the investments made by the EU. That is why I have not been able to vote in favour of this report.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report shores up the importance of attaining value for money for the European taxpayer, while also highlighting the important roles of environmental, social and labour law obligations established by the Union and often enshrined in national legislation. It also reiterates the protection for whistle-blowers to ensure those who put their jobs on the line to alert their fellow citizens are not mistreated. This report also provides a definition of conflicts of interests and grave professional misconduct and procedures surrounding such cases in public procurement and concession contracts.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Following the adoption of new directives on the awarding of public contracts and the awarding of concession contracts, the rules had to be adapted to apply to contracts awarded by the institutions of the European Union. These amendments relate to the introduction of new provisions such as market consultation, better respect for environmental, social and labour law and control of the allocation method on the basis of the most economically advantageous offer by subjecting it to compliance with the above standards.  The European Parliament stressed the need for monitoring of public procurement procedures and concession contracts, including through the European Anti-Fraud Office, and called for tax evasion and evasion to be included in these controls. The European Parliament has thus put in place a number of safeguards, although it is regrettable that they are insufficient in terms of concession of markets relating to the common security and defence policy. So I voted for it.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal includes an amendment to Article 190 of the Financial Regulation on 'public procurement for external actions'. The motivation relates to the alleged significant delays in the acquisition of essential equipment and services that condition the effectiveness of crisis management operations under the Common Foreign and Security Policy and, in particular, civilian missions under the Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP). The motive is commendable. However, given the content of most specific missions, which reflects the political priorities of the current EU, it makes us uncomfortable with this easing of the rules. Whether the EU was more likely to help refugees, create humanitarian corridors, or contribute to peace initiatives in the Middle East, or to intervene in the decommissioned agricultural markets, and we would now be enthusiastically applauding this initiative.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. The EU's problem is that it will soon have used up citizens' money. In order to facilitate the protection of the financial interests of the citizens of the Member States in relation to the overall management of the Union, this resolution lays down the conditions for the preparation and implementation of the general budget in order to ensure sound and effective financial management, control and protection of the Union's financial interests and increasing transparency. I agree with that.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The new Procurement Directive was approved in 2014 and it was therefore necessary to revise the corresponding articles of the Financial Regulation in order to harmonise them with EU legislation.  Articles 101-120 have been revised with the relevant key points concerning the possibility of negotiating contracts at interinstitutional level, with criteria for compliance with environmental, social and legislative standards and exclusion for fraud, corruption and participation in criminal activities. During this review, Parliament also fought to open negotiations on certain articles of the Financial Regulation that needed to be revised after the 2012 approval. Improvement of reports on the protection of the EU's financial interests and the performance of European funds in the annual activity reports (Articles 58,60,66); reference to the transmission of documents useful for discharge (internal audit report) (Article 99) and rationalisation of the timing of the Court of Auditors' special reports (Article 163); optimization of discharge information procedures and follow-up reports (Article 166); alignment with public-private partnership (PPP) discharge procedures (Art. 209).  This has therefore been achieved by optimising the procedures currently under way, and that is why I voted in favour.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported this report and am unequivocally in favour of changes to the rules of the EU budget. I consider it particularly important to improve the internal and external controls on money from the EU budget. Very often we encounter inefficient treatment of EU finances, not only in the Member States, but also in the European agencies and the institutions themselves. I therefore believe that this report by Ingeborg Gräßle will lead to a substantial improvement.

name: Janusz Zemke (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I support the report on financial changes, as they concern the implementation of the new EU public procurement directives. These directives rightly do not focus only on the cost of the contract, but stress that social and labour rights and the need to protect the environment should also be taken into account in the public procurement procedure. Offers cannot be judged solely on whether they are the most economically advantageous. It is equally important whether the persons employed in the execution of tenders receive a decent wage and whether their workers' rights are respected. As the Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council goes in this direction, I supported it in the vote.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This proposal includes an amendment to Article 190 of the Financial Regulation on 'public procurement for external actions'. The motivation relates to the alleged significant delays in the acquisition of essential equipment and services that condition the effectiveness of "crisis management operations" under the Common Foreign and Security Policy and, in particular, civilian missions under the Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP). It is curious how quickly this change is provided - when it comes to actions that often, under a humanitarian mission cover, hide a deeply militaristic vocation - unlike so many other social needs that do not deserve the same attention.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I hereby close the explanations of vote.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the statements by Francois Hollande, President of the French Republic, and Angela Merkel, Chancellor of the Federal Republic of Germany, on the current situation in the European Union (2015/2878(RSP)).

name: François Hollande
text: President of the French Republic. Mr President of the European Parliament, dear Martin Schulz, I thank you for your invitation and for the words you have spoken to the victims of bad weather in the south of France. Mr President of the European Commission, Madam Chancellor, Ladies and Gentlemen of the European Parliament, it is true that a President of the French Republic, the Chancellor of the Federal Republic of Germany, speaking together before the European Parliament, is an exceptional fact and, at the same time, it is not unprecedented.  As you recalled, 26 years ago, almost to the day, Helmut Kohl and François Mitterrand were addressing European parliamentarians here.  At the time, a great wind of freedom was blowing on the continent. He knocked down walls, emancipated peoples and gave hope to nations. 26 years ago, François Mitterrand and Helmut Kohl, with the help of Jacques Delors, presented the solidarity actions that had to be taken to welcome people who were not called refugees, but who had convinced themselves that Western Europe could welcome them. And it is the whole of Europe that has thus been built raising considerable hope. The common conviction of François Mitterrand and Helmut Kohl was to build a political union of Europe, thus extending the mandate of the founders, to create a vast single market, with social rules, and to carry the project of a common currency. All of this had to be part of the same process and be conducted with the same determination.  Today, 26 years later, Chancellor Angela Merkel and I are addressing you. Firstly because it is the 25th anniversary of German reunification, but above all because Europe is resonating with new tragedies that pose new challenges to our continent. To tell the truth, Europe has been facing a succession of crises for years: the financial crisis, which was born outside our continent but has spread and has caused an economic crisis from which we are just emerging and a social crisis, with millions of young people out of work. Now it is a humanitarian crisis that we are facing with an influx of refugees, caused by the destabilization of entire regions in the Middle East, Africa, resulting from armed conflicts and with the resurgence of religious hatreds.  And I do not forget the security crisis, with a war that is not so far away, on the borders of Europe, in Ukraine, and then also terrorist attacks that have concerned several countries of our continent, including my own.  With each crisis, fears arise. You have to live with fear, but you must not live dominated by fear. Nevertheless, there is a temptation to withdraw nationally whenever there is an ordeal. Yet nothing is more futile than to seek to save yourself, to evade, to take shelter when major events occur all over the world. We have to talk about experience, it is history that tells us and confirms it. These questions may be sincere, but they cannot condemn Europe to complacency and impotence. On the contrary, they justify an offensive Europe, capable, at the same time, of ensuring the protection due to its citizens and of maintaining its rank, in accordance with its interests and values, values which have justified the unification of our continent. There is therefore no alternative but a strong Europe to guarantee our own sovereignty.  In recent years, in recent months, France and Germany have wanted to react together to the hardships we have been through in the last period.  We responded with simple and clear principles: solidarity, responsibility and firmness.  Solidarity in the face of terrorism, because each of the attacks in one of our countries targets the whole of Europe: its ideals, its culture, its ways of life. That is, the soul of our continent. And I thank the Heads of State or Government, but also many European parliamentarians who met on 11 January in Paris to show their solidarity but also their commitment to freedom, to what we represent, to defend ourselves in the face of terrorism which seeks to destroy the cement that unites us. (Applause) Solidarity with refugees who are victims of the convulsions of the Middle East, the tragedies of Africa. Solidarity with European states, which are under pressure on the front line because they are our borders. Solidarity with countries neighbouring places of conflict, which welcome refugees in large numbers. Solidarity with Africa, which is fighting for its development and to avoid precisely population movements. Let's face it. We are faced with the exceptional arrival of women and men since the beginning of the year. 600, 000, no doubt. Many have fled war and massacres, others seek a better life. All endured appalling conditions, were handed over to unscrupulous traffickers. Too many died in atrocious conditions. We now know a number of their faces. Europe has worked to save lives, first, to combat criminal channels through Frontex operations. But, I readily admit, Europe has been slow to understand that tragedies in the Middle East or Africa cannot be without consequences for it.  Europe has not measured the hope it arouses and will generate for a long time in the face of the dismay of those who, since the night that has opened for them for too long, are waiting for hope, for light.  Europe has not provided sufficient aid to countries that, however, were hosting ever-increasing populations in camps. It is therefore in a hurry that it has had to organize itself to be worthy of its asylum tradition and to organise the return of those who cannot be welcomed here, permanently. Europe, together with the European Commission - and I welcome President Juncker here - has put together a comprehensive plan to support Italy and Greece, which are on the front line and cannot be left alone in responsibility; to help Balkan countries that are also experiencing transits of populations that are particularly difficult to cope with; to engage in closer cooperation with Turkey - and we have discussions here that have begun and which will have to be concluded with clear rules, because it is in Turkey that refugees must, as far as possible, be welcomed. But the flip side is that we can help Turkey if we want it to help us, ourselves, and ensure that these refugees, whether they are in the camps or in the population, can work, feed their children, can have a future. If we don't, then they will come, inexorably, they will come.  We also need to set up reception and identification centres. This is the essential condition for our borders to be respected. Then, finally, we have to distribute asylum seekers among the Member States. That is what we have done, not without difficulty, but we have done it. 160 000. And we will have to make sure that the commitments that have been made are being implemented.  It is each of these components that the plan must now implement as quickly as possible.  These are the principles: solidarity, responsibility. These are the same principles that prevailed in dealing with the situation in Greece. Negotiations have been laborious. We have taken our part, Angela Merkel and myself, with the European Commission, with all the Member States. These discussions could have failed. It would have been much more than a failure, it would have been an abandonment. The abandonment of a country whose culture and civilization still enlighten us. This would have been the first breach in the integrity of the euro area, and other countries would have been under pressure. And then it would have been a resignation in front of our mutual responsibilities, European responsibilities, responsibilities of the Greek government.  The negotiations resulted in a comprehensive reform agenda and new financial support. I hope that this will now translate into a discussion on debt service. This is part of the overall resolution. Alexis Tsipras, the Greek prime minister, was courageous and wanted his people to be consulted after there was the agreement. Respect for democracy - and I say this here, also in the place of European democracy - is never at odds with respect for common rules: responsibility, solidarity. Always the same principles. (Applause) We must also demonstrate responsibility against terrorism. Vigilance must be required, but it will not be enough. We must equip ourselves with the necessary instruments for the work of the security services, while respecting freedoms. France has passed a law to be able to better know the activities and follow the terrorists. Europe must also take its share, and I am thinking of the long-delayed dossier of the European NRL. I ask, as far as possible, that the European Parliament should be able to adopt this text, which is essential, if we are to act.  (Applause) Europe also has a duty of firmness. In Ukraine, we had to respond to a brutal violation of international law and prevent a war at the gates of our continent. The Europeans have shown unity, the Twenty-eight, in the implementation of sanctions and there have been legitimate debates, debates on the effectiveness and the length of this sanctions mechanism.  Germany and France are particularly committed to concluding and sustaining the Minsk agreements. Just last week, Angela Merkel and I, together with the Russian President and the Ukrainian President, in what is known as the 'Normandy format', ensured not only that what had been concluded in Minsk was respected, but that other separation processes were avoided.  And in this respect, this format, this method and this pressure, exerted on behalf of Europe as a whole, were particularly effective since the elections that the separatists had planned to hold in mid-October were postponed, and the Minsk process was able to continue and the small arms were soon withdrawn, soon heavy weapons. , and that the war has stopped, without peace yet returned. This is what we are able to do on behalf of Europe, for Europe and I will also say in the interest of the world, because we are ready to show firmness, responsibility and solidarity.  Firmness also with regard to the Syrian tragedy. It concerns us all because Daesh and the jihadists resent what we represent. It concerns Europe because the regime of Bashar al-Assad has created and continues to feed this disaster. Even today, he bombs, he kills, he slaughters. Yes, what is happening in Syria is about Europe because what is being played out there will determine for a long time the balance in the region, throughout the Middle East region.  And if we let the religious clashes, sometimes between Shiites and Sunnis, often, always even, for a few months or a few years increase further, do not think that we will be safe. It will be an all-out war, a war that can also affect our own territories. Then we have to act. France has taken its military responsibilities in the face of the threat.  Europe as a whole must engage on a humanitarian, political and diplomatic level. We must build in Syria, with all those who can contribute to it, a political future that gives the Syrian people an alternative to Bashar or Daesh. It is our duty to the Syrians and it is our interest as Europeans.  I therefore call on the whole of Europe to push for this political transition to take place. And let us know, whatever the positions here, that it will not be possible to bring together the opposition - I am talking about the moderate, democratic opposition - with the executioner of the Syrian people. It will be necessary to act continuously to bring together all the nations that really want a way out, namely Russia, Iran, the Gulf countries, of course, the United States and Europe, and Europe, so that we can achieve this political outcome.  To sum up my thinking, as I said, we will have to show a lot of solidarity with others. That is why cooperation with African countries is essential. We will soon have the Valletta summit in November between Africa and Europe. It is by acting at the root of the difficulties that the candidates at the start, and there are many in Africa, can be convinced to stay in their region. It is up to us to provide them with the conditions to live there.  We have touched on a number of issues that concern Europe and, in fact, it is the same debate that we have. It exists here, it exists in each of our countries. This is the debate between sovereignism and sovereignty. Sovereignism in each country or sovereignty for Europe. It is the debate between renunciation or reinforcement, between division or union. The debate is not between less Europe and more Europe, it is between the affirmation of Europe or the end of Europe. Yes, the end of Europe. That is, the return to national borders, the dismantling of Community policies, the abandonment of the euro. (Protests in some groups) (Lively and prolonged applause)  I can see, Mr President, that the debate exists here as well. François Mitterrand, less than 26 years ago, when he left office, had come before the European Parliament to speak, to deliver what he thought were the lessons of his own experience and the lessons of history. He said that nationalism is war. His warning still applies today. (Applause) But I'll add, a codicille or a supplement. Sovereignism is declineism. And it is also dangerous not to give hope to a population, to build nothing together, in the name of a national retreat, without a future in the face of trials.  I am convinced that if we do not go further, then not only will we stop but we will back down. And that will be the end of the European project. And that is why I propose that the Economic and Monetary Union, and within it the Eurozone, can be consolidated and strengthened. Consolidated and strengthened to coordinate our policies, to promote convergence, to act on tax harmonisation, to combat tax and social dumping, to invest more even beyond what we are doing with the Juncker plan.  Institutional choices will be needed for the eurozone to be governed, for the rules to be respected, so that solidarity can benefit all. These choices will engage voluntary states. The European Parliament will exercise its control and ensure the overall coherence of a Europe that will progress according to differentiated integration.   We also need to strengthen what is called the Schengen area. To call into question the free movement of people by returning to internal borders would be a tragic mistake. (Applause) But to claim that Schengen, in its current operation, will be able to cope with the pressures at its perimeter would be another mistake. Effective control of the Union's external borders requires enhanced assistance to border states, states concerned and the establishment of a border guard corps, European coastguards as the President of the European Commission has proposed. Similarly, we need to define a more coherent asylum policy, which requires a common list of safe countries of origin, the reconciliation of procedures, the convergence of rights and conditions offered to beneficiaries of protection. That is, a genuine common asylum system within the European Union itself.  On all these subjects, we must make the choice, I repeat, of walking forward rather than going backwards, which would bring us back to impotence. We still need to make this courageous choice and we will have to make it at the Paris climate conference in December. I welcome Europe's commitments at this conference because they have been instrumental in taking China, the United States and many others towards the prospect of an agreement.  It's possible! It must be as ambitious as the need will be. Too many countries have not yet submitted their contributions. And we Europeans ourselves must be able to establish a large carbon market to direct investments towards the best technologies. And it will be up to you to make choices accordingly. I want to welcome the role of the European Parliament in the climate negotiations and, as long as you can, support the efforts of the countries, yours, and Europe as a whole so that we can have an agreement. We will also have that ambition in the funding. It is very important that we be able to raise the $100 billion needed for energy transition in the most vulnerable or developing countries. We are not there yet. We have two months to achieve this and, if there were no agreement, let us be aware of the disaster, let us realize what our responsibility would be for future generations. Let us realize that there will not be a new conference to decide. There is a time when you have to make your choice, make your decision, get involved. It is up to the governments, yes, the European governments first, and those who will be at the Paris conference to live up to the responsibility you have entrusted to us.  I wish one day to return to the European Parliament at least with this pride, not simply to have received a conference in Paris, but to have been there on the day when the States of the world, carried by local authorities all over the world, who will also be represented, together with all associations, organisations, companies and trade unions, will have been able, for decades to come. , to address much of the climate issue. This is the appointment for our generation that should not be missed. (Applause) We must also have for our agriculture, for food security, for the quality of our products, the same ambition, the same will. And I ask, in the context of the crisis that we are experiencing in a number of our productions, that, at the Commission level as well as at the state level, as at The level of Parliament, we can free up the necessary support to protect our products and to help the most vulnerable. Since I am talking about a trade treaty, I want to talk about the one that is being debated with the United States. France wants these negotiations to be a step forward and wants guarantees to be made, both for product identification, for appellations of origin, for reciprocity, for transparency and, more broadly, for investment protection mechanisms, in particular, for dispute resolution. We must have those guarantees if we are to have an agreement that can be useful to economies. I want to end with this reflection that concerns us all. I cannot imagine that there are parliamentarians here who are not European, who do not realize that we belong to the same group, that we are bound by so many common values, that Europe has a history to share and a future to engage.  So, 25 years after the continent has reunited, we still face challenges and therefore choices. We have to respond to the emergency. She is there and no one can turn a blind eye to the realities of the world. No one! There are no borders worth, no barbed wire to protect us from threats from outside. It's up to us to make the decisions. We must respond to the urgency and stay the course for the long term: that of a federation of nation-states that must remain our horizon. And, in a way, 25 years later, it is to another unification that must be carried out: that of the projects, that of the peoples, that of the common interests, with this one question: do we want to return to the old order, that of the twentieth century, and what it has carried? Or do we want to live in a coherent and voluntary whole for the coming century?  I made my choice, it's Europe's! I did so with the will, on every issue, to seek, as far as possible, the highest compromises and that was the sense of cooperation that we established with Angela Merkel and Germany to be with our partners up to the challenges of the century.  (Lively and prolonged applause)

name: Angela Merkel
text: Chancellor of the Federal Republic of Germany.– Mr President of the European Parliament, Mr Martin Schulz, President of the European Commission, Dear Jean-Claude Juncker, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the President of the European Parliament for his excellent work and for her excellent work. In November 1989, a French President and a German Chancellor spoke to the European Parliament for the last time. Francois Mitterrand and Helmut Kohl spoke here in Strasbourg shortly after the fall of the Berlin Wall. Both felt the looming upheavals in Germany and Europe. And both were deeply moved by these upheavals. Both pledged in these hours, with clear words, to find common European answers. Thus, the coming together of Germany was followed by the integration of Europe. And today, with great gratitude and pride, we can look back on the historic achievement that we Europeans have achieved in the process of our continent growing together. Today, a free and united Europe seems to us to be a matter of course. But this historic achievement required a lot of effort at the time. There were fears and scepticism in the old Member States, for example, about the fact that the number of Member States of the European Union should almost double. Many saw the free movement of millions of new EU citizens as a threat to their own jobs. New decision-making structures had to be developed. European funding had to be redistributed to the new Member States. Today we see that this effort has paid off for all of us. It has not helped us to be less, but has helped us to become more prosperous. It has not helped us to be less, but to more freedom. It has not helped us to be less, but to more diversity. (Applause) In short, it has helped us to have more Europe. Because we Europeans have learned in our history to make the most of our diversity. And the quality that enables us to do so, that enables us to have freedom in our responsibility, that is tolerance. And it is a valuable asset. Overcoming the contrast between East and West has proved to be a gigantic success story. It shows us what we Europeans are capable of, if we want only, if we show courage, and if we stick together. It also shows that there is absolutely no reason to be discouraged by setbacks, which are, of course, repeated. In a word, it shows us what is possible. This is what the drafting of the Charter of Fundamental Rights, the Lisbon Treaty, stands for, but for the experience of the international financial crisis, which we managed together and from which we emerged stronger than we entered it, that is what the European sovereign debt crisis, in which we acted together, stands for. Francois Hollande referred to the difficult negotiations. But by doing it together, we have been able to ensure the cohesion of the eurozone. (Applause) Ladies and gentlemen! Today, The French President, Francois Hollande, and I are allowed to speak to you. Mr President, thank you for this invitation. We are speaking at a time when Europe is once again facing a major challenge. And I say it's a test of historic proportions. These are the many, many people who are going on extremely dangerous routes to Europe to find refuge here. People coming to Greece from Turkey via the Mediterranean to Italy or via the Aegean Sea. People fleeing terrible civil wars, especially the war in Syria, which has already claimed more than 250 000 lives and turned more than ten million people into refugees. Refugees from Iraq, refugees coming to us from Africa via unstable Libya. And they have all seen that our diplomatic and political efforts, and those of our transatlantic allies, have so far failed to bring peace to Syria. The rise of the terrorist organization IS in Iraq and Syria could not be prevented. The power vacuum in Libya is not yet filled. To enable these people to live a decent life in their homeland again, without having to freeze in fear of bombs and terror: creating this is a European and, ultimately, a global task. (Applause) That is the message today. Europe will need a determined contribution to solving these crises, in the fight against wars and displacement, terrorism and political persecution, poverty and lack of prospects. With this determination, Germany and France have resolved the terrible conflict between Russia and Ukraine is trying to solve it. We have seen the annexation of Crimea, we have seen the destabilisation of eastern Ukraine, and I say quite frankly that, fortunately, we have acted together in Europe. We have jointly imposed sanctions and said that this is a violation of our principles, and we will not allow that to happen. (Applause) But now we are working to resolve this normandy-style conflict. And just last Friday, we had talks in France – in Paris – that give us hope that at least the ceasefire could hold. After all, the elections in Donetsk and Lugansk were postponed. But, ladies and gentlemen, this is one of many conflicts. I am convinced that we must focus our foreign and development policy much more on resolving conflicts and combating the causes of flight.  (Applause) We will also have to be much more financially involved than we do today. The necessary decisions must be taken quickly. All this will change Europe again. Just as Europe has changed profoundly after the upheavals in Central and Eastern Europe 25 years ago. Of course, we will continue to work to improve our competitiveness. Of course, we will deal with the digitisation of our societies, with sustainable development, with a common energy policy, with free trade agreements with other countries in accordance with our principles. Right now, an economically strong Europe that takes advantage of the opportunities offered by the internal market is needed more than ever. To this end, we must also improve economic policy coordination in the euro area and, on this basis, correct the founding mistakes of the European Economic and Monetary Union. And Germany and France will play their part. (Applause) But the huge number of refugees is changing Europe's agenda. It is changing it once again, and in a lasting way, because it challenges our values and interests as Europeans and globally in a special way. If it is said that the number of refugees is to be ordered and, as a result, contained, there is no way around where flight and displacement are caused. It goes without saying that this takes time, patience and a long breath. We in Europe , as we are witnessing in these months – are closely linked to global events, whether we like it or not. We can no longer decouple ourselves from global events.  Never since World War II have so many people been on the run as there are today – about sixty million. Only this one number reveals the full dimension of the task. And no one leaves their homeland lightly, not even those who come for economic reasons. (Applause) But we must also tell them that they cannot stay with us so that we can really help those who really need our protection from war and persecution. (Applause) To do this, we need a political process to resolve the crisis in Syria with all regional and international actors, with a stronger role for Europe. We must help the neighbouring countries of Syria to have an appropriate perspective for the millions of refugees. Europe has acted here. The European Commission has made proposals for better funding – I also thank Parliament for supporting this – and the nation states must play their part. And Turkey plays a key role. She is our immediate neighbour. It is the starting point for irregular migration. Turkey is doing extraordinary work for more than two million refugees. However, it needs more and more of our support in the provision of care, in the accommodation of refugees, in border security and in the fight against smugglers. That is precisely why the European Commission has begun the dialogue on migration policy with Turkey is so important. And Germany will support these Commission efforts bilaterally.  Equally important are all efforts in Libya to form a unity government. Europe supports the efforts of the UN envoy, Mr Leon. The whole of the European Union is in need of this task. In the refugee crisis, we must not succumb to the temptation to fall back into national action – quite the contrary! (Applause) Right now, we need more Europe! More than ever, we need the courage and cohesion that Europe has always shown when it mattered. Germany and France are ready to do so. And we agree with the President of the European Commission, who has put many important proposals on the table, which we must now implement consistently. We agree with the President of the European Council, who is working very hard to improve cooperation with countries of origin and transit. And we agree with the European Parliament, which, in its resolution of 10 September, reminded us that national solo action in the refugee crisis is not a solution. Mr President, we also thank you for unconventional, quick decisions. That was important. (Applause) Only together will Europe be able to reduce the worldwide causes of flight and displacement. Only together will we be able to combat criminal smuggling gangs effectively. Only together will we be able to better protect the external borders of the European Union with hotspots operated jointly and not to jeopardise a Europe without internal borders. And I would like to make it clear that the protection of external borders will only be successful if we do something in our neighbourhood to deal with the many crises that are taking place on our doorstep, so to speak. (Applause) Ladies and gentlemen, only together will we be able to agree on EU-wide return agreements in order to actually bring those who have no prospect of staying back to their home countries. Only together will we be able to achieve a fair and appropriate distribution of refugees among all Member States. A first step has been taken, and here too I thank Parliament, or the majority, for its positioning. Let us be honest: the Dublin procedure in its present form is obsolete in practice. It was indeed well-intentioned – without a doubt – but the bottom line is that it has proved unsustainable in the face of the challenge at our external borders. I am therefore committed to agreeing on a new approach to fairness and solidarity in burden-sharing. I welcome the work of the Commission, and I think it is good that Germany and France agree on this. And it is also only together that we will succeed in the enormous task of integration that still needs to be accomplished. It includes the fact that we in Europe can rightly expect people who come to us to integrate into our societies. This requires compliance with the rules in force here, as well as learning the language in each language. But conversely, we also have a duty to treat people who come to us from need with respect, to see people in them and not to see any anonymous mass, regardless of whether they have a prospect of staying or not. (Applause) That is precisely why it is so important that the minimum humanitarian standards that we have agreed on for the accommodation and care of refugees and for the implementation of asylum procedures are respected. We owe it to them, to the refugees, and to ourselves. Because Europe is a community of values, a community of law and responsibility, and that means, to me, that we must be guided by the values that we have enshrined in the European Treaties: human dignity, the rule of law, tolerance, respect for minorities and solidarity. For me, this means that pan-European challenges cannot be solved by a few Member States alone, but by all together. We must realise that even if we tried to completely isolate ourselves, even consciously at the cost of harming people at our borders, it would not benefit anyone. Not to the people concerned anyway, who would nevertheless seek and find ways to reach us, and not even ourselves in Europe. Foreclosure and closure in the age of the Internet are an illusion. No problem would be solved, but additional serious problems would arise, because the attachment to our values and thus our identity would be lost. If we disregard this, we betray ourselves – no more and no less. (Applause) If we bear this into account, we will be able to pass this historic test and, even more so, emerge from this crisis more than we have entered it. Then we will be able to represent our values and interests convincingly on a global and global way. And that, moreover, is what we are expected to do outside Europe. Ladies and gentlemen! We know all too well the motives for which people leave their homeland from our own European history. For centuries, our continent has not been a destination, but above all the starting point of flight and displacement and migration. Jean-Claude Juncker made an impressive reminder of this in his State of the Union address. Today, Europe is an area in which many people from all over the world are directed to their hopes and longings, a space that makes people dream. Just as I and millions of other people in Central and Eastern Europe 25 years ago were able to benefit from a free and united Germany and Europe. We must deal responsibly with Europe's appeal. And that means that we need to pay more care to those who are in need in our neighbourhood today. If we see this challenge as our common European and global challenge, we will also be able to recognise and take advantage of the economic and social opportunities of this test. And then we will see that, by the way, the chances are greater than the risks. We will have to continue to work hard to convince our Europe. I am pleased that, after centuries of war and hatred between our two peoples, Mr Hollande, we are both fighting together today for these same goals. (Applause) I invite you all here in this House to work together to convince our Europe. Every single Member has an important role to play in this. In your home countries, in your constituencies, in the face of the pan-European public. Let us work together on this, as Helmut Kohl proposed here in the European Parliament in 1989 with a view to the upheavals in Central and Eastern Europe – and I quote him: 'with wisdom and with a sense of proportion, with ingenuity and flexibility'. Thank you very much! (Applause)

name: Manfred Weber
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Dear Chancellor Merkel, President Hollande, Jean-Claude Juncker, Martin Schulz, ladies and gentlemen, Twenty-five years ago, your predecessors here in the European Parliament made a commitment that your two peoples stand for a democratic Europe. Today you have renewed this commitment with your presence. The german-French friendship, the responsibility that your two peoples bear and the statement of the future that France and Germany will see their future in a democratic Europe in the coming decades: I would like to begin by expressing my sincere thanks for this. (Applause) Twenty-five years ago, this continent was about the upheavals after the collapse of communism. Today, the refugee issue is a challenge ahead of us. If we have great tasks, we will find orientation in our Charter of Fundamental Rights. This is the place where the ideas, the experiences we Europeans have had in our history can be read in a concentrated manner. It says: 'The right to asylum is granted in accordance with the Geneva Convention on Refugees'. And it says: "Collective expulsions are inadmissible." Ladies and gentlemen, we are talking about people. That is why this Charter of Fundamental Rights is our orientation. We are talking about individuals. If Turkey, if Jordan, if Lebanon – partly poor countries – is able to offer shelter to millions of people fleeing civil war, then this rich Europe must also be able to make this effort. We need courage, we need encouragement for this task that is ahead of us. I would like to thank Germany in particular and you, Chancellor, for encouraging people on this issue. Thank you for that. (Applause) In terms of content, we have major tasks ahead of us. First of all, it is important to take seriously the fears of citizens, which of course also exist. One of the answers we can give people is: we are already acting. We don't just talk, we act. Who would have thought that German and French soldiers were on duty in the Mediterranean today and were saving lives? Who would have thought a few months ago that we could decide on a quota of 160 000 refugees? Who would have thought that a few days ago the European Council decided to properly protect the external borders and to carry out checks there accordingly? We are already acting! We in the European Parliament – and I must not hide this in the presence of the two leaders – are disappointed by the speed of the European Council and the members of the Council of Ministers of the Interior: we would like to see more speed. The Commission has already put forward proposals in the spring, and we in the European Parliament have already signalled support. And unfortunately, god, we have not been able to overcome the national selfishness, which unfortunately also exists, quickly enough. The deed now counts! We must act together. The ideas you have put forward, President Hollande, on the further development, for example, on the construction of a European border guard, must now be decided by the Heads of State or Government so that the Commission can get support for its work. We are facing enormous challenges. There has been talk of migration, also of the economy, of the fight against terrorism. We have two political realities that we also find in this European Parliament. One is the party dispute, the normal, right party dispute in democracy about the right way forward, and then the vote, which then produces the result. And the second reality is that there are political forces on the continent that scare people, who want to destroy something, who want to destroy something, namely what previous generations of elected politicians have built up over decades. These are forces that describe problems but have no idea how to solve problems. Unfortunately, this political reality is increasing; scepticism is growing in Europe. What is the answer? The answer is: leadership, courageous leadership. Just as previous generations of politicians have done. Without political leadership, we would not have seen eastward enlargement, without political leadership we would not have abolished border controls, if we had not built up a currency, and we would not have the prosperity that the internal market guarantees us. That is why today is the time for political leadership again. The last time your predecessors were here was 26 years ago. And we can say with pride: we are strong, we are great as a continent, what has been achieved in the last 26 years! And we must continue this story. Please show as the two leaders of the two great peoples Europe's ambition! We know that we need a strengthening, a strengthening of the euro area, a deepening of the eurozone, more ability to act in foreign policy. It is not acceptable for a country to be able to veto entire sanctions decisions. We need more military action, as everyone knows. We would spend the citizens' money in this European Union better if we spent it together. I therefore ask you to give you the courage to develop Europe. That is the task of the Heads of State or Government. Last but not least, why is it urgent? Why does it have to happen soon? Because the world is not waiting for us. While we are dealing with Greece, we have seen a major slump in the Chinese stock exchanges. It is there that the prosperity of tomorrow's world will be decided. As we talk about migration, Atlanta is entering into a trans-Pacific free trade agreement that reorganizes 40 percent of world trade. The world is not waiting for our internal debates! That is why Europe must lead by its committed approach. (Applause) Jean-Claude Juncker said here a few days ago that there is not enough Europe and there is too little Union. Ladies and gentlemen, Chancellor, President of the Republic, I would like to thank the President-in-Office of the Council for his excellent work and for her excellent work. We rely on your courage. Let us bravely stand up to the fear-mongers! Create more Europe! Create more union!

name: Gianni Pittella
text: On behalf of the Group of the Party of European People's Party (Christian Democratic And Social Party) and European Union, Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Chancellor Merkel, President Hollande, the fall of the Berlin Wall is, in my view, the birth certificate for the new Europe.  The lesson we still carry in us today is that the search for freedom is an unstoppable drive. Freedom is a human condition, before it is political. No wall can stop it. The second lesson concerns the fragility of political projects. Thirty years ago, no one would have thought that the Communist bloc would disappear. In two ways, major political projects die: when they are defeated by an external adversary – this is the case of the so-called real socialism defeated by liberal democracies – or they disappear when they no longer believe in themselves, when they lose their sense of history. That is the risk that Europe is running today and we must tell ourselves frankly, as we saw with the Greek crisis, you have talked about it.  The real tragedy was not the failure to pay an installment, but the fact that for a moment the sense of being together was lost. That is the risk we no longer have to take. Because if Europe is devalued to an aggregation of States held together by logics of pure convenience and power, then it loses its raison d'ion and the Pandora's box opens up, which is made up of selfishness, secession and forms of separatism.  First of all, the Union is a political project and it is history that tells us that in the past the Franco-German drive has served Europe because it has had a vision of Europe, that is, the idea that through reconciliation between peoples divided by centuries of war, the foundations for political integration would be laid.  Today we need a new beginning, a new project, a new vision that will give meaning to the Union and that will see all the Member States as protagonists. This Parliament and this European Commission, led by President Schulz and President Juncker, have shown that they are up to the challenge and if we are gathered in this body today it is also because the 2014 elections and the direct indication of the President of the European Commission have given this Parliament new energy and strong new leadership.  From above, Europe is not being built and – please let me say this, but clearly – the intergovernmental model is outdated.  The Europe of the people will not be made by rhetoric, but by concrete actions that help a facto solidarity. We started with immigration and we need to move forward consistently and firmly.  I very much appreciate what Chancellor Merkel has told us today, which we have been saying for a long time, welcome and security, responsibility, and I very much appreciate that you said very firmly that Dublin is outdated. Yes, Dublin is outdated! The Union must be made more democratic, and this is achieved through a reform of governance and economic and monetary union that strengthens the role of the European Parliament. This institution is already the Parliament of the whole Union and of the eurozone, and the Union must also be given the means to assert itself through a common fiscal capacity that can lead to a European unemployment insurance mechanism.  We must fight for greater tax justice, because it is unacceptable that, while citizens are being asked to make sacrifices, tax evasion and fraud take a trillion euros out of public finances every year. Taxes must be paid where profits are made!  We must ensure greater social justice. This continent, Europe, is being crossed by silent secession, poorer and richer and richer, social dumping must be wiped out!  And finally, compared to twenty-five years ago, we are faced with the challenge of climate change, François Hollande spoke passionately and firmly about it, thank you for this strong binding appeal for everyone to be a great success in Paris!  And then foreign policy, let's be honest about that. In the Middle East, the diversity of approach between Member States in defining who our main adversary, Isis or Assad, is weakening our diplomatic action. We need a common foreign policy of the European Union – ladies and gentlemen, I know that some European citizens, even among those present, think that the decline of the Union is inevitable. We must oppose this fatalism. The words of a great European, François Mitterand, are still valid today, words that he uttered in this Chamber, as you have been reminded: 'Our exhilarating role is to prevent the inevitable, to succeed the improbable and to realize hope'! (Applause)

name: Ryszard Antoni Legutko
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, many have said today that the joint appearance of President Hollande and Chancellor Merkel is historic because it shows that the Franco-German engine of Europe is still powering on and we have a radiant future in front of us. But do you not think, President Hollande and Chancellor Merkel, that it is at least a part of the problem that one or two countries decide for the rest? All together we are 28, and 28 is far more than two. Over the years, the EU of course evolved but my feeling is that its leadership has not. Chancellor Merkel, events have placed a burden of leadership on your shoulders. Your critics say, however – and they may have a point – that you sometimes forget about the difference between leadership and dominance. I get the impression that people across the European Union are concerned about that distinction, because it has become more and more a vital question, and that is part of the reason why we face this crisis over Europe’s future. People are concerned that their viewpoint does not matter. Some are ignored, others are bullied, others still are vilified. People are concerned because they hear this deafening federalist rhetoric, not rooted in reality, and through that thin veil of rhetoric they see a ruthless power-play with President Hollande and Chancellor Merkel as major actors, more powerful than those who hold formal positions allegedly higher in the political hierarchy.  Chancellor Merkel, you spent your early years in a communist country. So did I. I remember a saying from the bad old days that communism is a system which courageously solves the problem it itself created. Toute proportion gardée, I think that the same could be said about the European Union. We created the euro system, and since day one we have been wrestling with the problems it generated, and solving those problems has led to more dominance and more disregard for the elementary rules of cooperation.  Turning to the issue of migration and refugees: again a similar story. Of course the EU did not create the problem but it failed to identify it soon enough and, let me add, it has not yet entirely succeeded in identifying it. I am just wondering: why invite the immigrants and then cancel the invitation? Why play a cat and mouse game with the Schengen procedures? Why this absolutely unbearable confusion of humanitarian, moral and political arguments that obscure the gravity of the crisis we are faced with?  This is not the language of dialogue. This is a language to obscure things. We cannot really talk to one another using that kind of language. It is preaching. It is not a dialogue: it is preaching. And there has been a lot of preaching in this Chamber this afternoon – and, as a matter of fact, every day.  So, it was your decision to suspend the Schengen rules and to open the German border, and it was your decision to close the border again. As far as I know, you did not consult any government, or any European institution for that matter. If this is not proof of dominance, what is? If one wants to have more proof, look at what happened last month at the Home Affairs Council. This is not the right way of doing things. President Hollande, Chancellor Merkel, let me finish with the following plea, if you will. I urge you to be more responsive to reality. The more European hubris is riding high, the more people are being left behind, not listened to, and pushed outside a territory of respectability. This has lasted long enough and it cannot go on forever. European politics needs less self-adoration – of which you had an abundant sample of today – but it needs more freshness, clarity and fairness. Otherwise, the EU will increasingly be looked at with reluctance and disdain, if not outright hostility, and we do not want that, do we? (Applause)

name: Guy Verhofstadt
text: im Namen der ALDE-Fraktion. – Herr Präsident! Zuallererst geht mein Dank an Sie, Kanzlerin Merkel. Sie haben Mitgefühl, Verständnis und Führung in der Flüchtlingskrise gezeigt – und das in einer Zeit, in der es in Europa an all diesen drei Dingen mangelt. Danke dafür! (Beifall) Monsieur le Président, c'est toujours un honneur de vous voir ici, au Parlement européen. Vous venez ici plus souvent, je pense, qu'à l'Assemblée nationale. C'est mieux ici, au berceau de la démocratie européenne, et je dois vous dire que je partage pleinement l'analyse que vous avez faite. Chers collègues, nous vivons en fait une crise, profonde, comme le président l'a indiqué, que, moi, j'appelle une polycrise: c'est une crise des réfugiés, de l'économie, de l'euro, de la perte évidente de notre influence géopolitique. This crisis is an existential crisis. Let us face the reality, this multiple crisis – and I know that a number of people in this House will like this – puts the existence of the European project itself in danger. If tomorrow the euro disappears or if Schengen falls apart, then what are we left with in Europe? Only a loose confederation of nation-states? We will be weak economically, and insignificant on the world stage. That will be the result. (Applause)  And let us not be naive. It will be the Americans and the Chinese who will dictate our economic standards here in Europe; and it will be Assad and Putin who will decide on peace and stability in Europe. (As Putin already finances some right-wing parties in Europe, maybe that is the normal turn of events.) What I want to make clear in this debate today with you, Chancellor Merkel and President Hollande, is that the source and origin of every one of these crises is in fact exactly the same: it is a lack of common governance; it is a lack of shared sovereignty. It is the lack of unity in Europe that is the cause of the crisis.  (Applause) And Mr Legutko, you say ‘Yes, Europe is the problem’ and ‘Europe creates and solves the problems’, but when 20 million citizens in the 19th and 20th centuries were slaughtered in Europe it was not because of ‘Europe’, it was because of nationalism and populism. (Applause) We cannot overcome the refugee crisis and we cannot keep Schengen if we do not have a common asylum policy, a common migration policy and common border and coastguard control. We cannot overcome the euro crisis without one government for the euro and one treasury. We cannot overcome our economic weaknesses if we do not liberate ourselves of 28 national regulators in all the markets of the future – digital, energy and capital. And we shall not overcome our geopolitical insignificance if we do not embrace real foreign policy in Europe, a single representation in the international institutions and, at the very least, a defence community in the European Union. (Applause) To achieve this in the final years of this decade, and to make sure that this decade does not become a lost decade for a number of people and for the European project, I think we have to change three bad attitudes: firstly, l’Europe à la carte; secondly, the step-by-step approach that we embrace; and, thirdly, our clouded and outdated view of the world. First of all, l’Europe à la carte. There is not one Union. What are you talking about? There are at least 10 unions. There is ‘the 28’, there is Schengen, there is the euro, there is the patent, there are the opt-ins and the opt-outs, the enhanced cooperation, the derogations – it is chaos at the moment – and Europe needs one strong heart to survive in the future. Secondly, the step-by-step approach: maybe it worked in the good times in the past, but not in the modern world. It is always too little too late. From time to time, in every society, you have to take a big leap forward, to adapt yourself and to resolve all the resistance to necessary change – as France did, for example, after the Revolution when it kicked out an old autocratic regime and created the rule of law, and what Germany did when it created the Zollverein and became a modern economy, the powerhouse of Europe in the economic field. That is also what we need at the European level.  I have only one appeal to you, Chancellor Merkel and President Hollande, which might not be in the name of the whole Parliament but in the name of a big majority here: I call upon you to meet this challenge together with us, the European Parliament. It is your historic responsibility to do that, exactly like your predecessors did 25 years ago. Look a bit more closely into this historic task, even if you are facing some less important electoral challenges in the near future. (Applause)

name: Gabriele Zimmer
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, Chancellor, Mr President, I would like to thank the Rapporteur on the work she has Twenty-five years ago, your predecessors – Chancellor Kohl and President Mitterrand – took joint initiatives to advance the process of European integration, against the background of the Eastern European democratic movement. These were concrete proposals. We saw them on the table, I read them for myself. But times have changed. For many, in your function, you represent the old Europe that has failed. And, Mrs Merkel: I cannot take away from you the fact that you bear a significant responsibility for the fact that, for example, the Community method has been replaced by the Union method. This has contributed to a split within the European Union, a split into strong – economically strong, politically strong – and weak – politically weak and economically weak – countries. They both say that the EU has brought more prosperity. No! Most recently, the EU has brought more poverty to the south and the division of the EU. People reject an EU in which Eurogroup finance ministers dictate how solidarity and living conditions are to be defined. Such a union does not even give the appearance of Habermas's facade democracy. Have you ever wondered why, despite the hard-hitting blackmail by the Eurogroup, do the people of Greece once again trust Syriza and Tsipras, and not those who are part of the old system and thus part of the old Europe? The memoranda were about bailing out German, French and Dutch banks. The winners of the so-called euro rescue packages are these countries. That is why we are asking you to take initiatives to reduce the debt. And the crisis gains should go to a poverty reduction fund in the crisis countries. I could also envisage debt relief for investments in renewable energy and action on climate change. It is a moral and legal duty to accept refugees in a humane manner. This is not the practice in the EU. It is high time to put Dublin aside and develop a common European asylum/migration policy that really deserves the name. You said: tell those who cannot stay: return to safe countries of origin. So that includes Kosovo, Turkey. Will Eritrea also be part of this in the future? I would like to know that in concrete terms. It is logical and reasonable to determine the second intake by population and economic power in the countries. These proposals are on the table. But the way we deal with Greece and also with the refugees has brought this very failure of the European Union to our mind. Unfortunately, there can be no question of a community of equal sequalities in solidarity. European values cannot be defended under the sword of the dictates of cuts. That must be clear. So the policy of austerity must stop, this austerity policy must be at the expense of certain groups of the population. As a result, we are dealing with a retreat into the national, nationalist and xenophobic forces are on the rise, not only in France and Germany. In Germany, 200 refugee shelters have already burned this year. That is why it is so encouraging when, on the other hand, many people are standing there and being helpful, wanting to help, wanting to do something. But they must be encouraged by us – by the EU and by politics – and we must not leave them alone. That's how the community is broken! I would like to ask you: yes, perhaps you both wanted to summon the old axis again, but the german-French engine stutters. What now, Mrs Merkel and Monsieur Hollande? Your speeches should be encouraging. You have raised many important issues. But your speech also lacked any prospect of more democracy and for a social union within the European Union. This is a huge shortcoming. Please take up this challenge!

name: Rebecca Harms
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, Chancellor, I would like to thank the Rapporteur on the work she has I was pleased with the decision that you wanted to come to us to talk here in the European Parliament about the very difficult situation in which the European Union has not only got into the refugee crisis, but in which we have actually been stuck for some time. Guy Verhofstadt spoke of the political crisis. I would just say, German, that we have a whole series of crises that we are constantly talking about. And we will not make any progress if we leave behind what we had before and did not finish, whenever a new, major escalation takes place, such as now the one around the refugees, when we then leave behind what we had before on the wrap and did not finish. I believe that if you want to build confidence within the European Union, in its ability to act – and I really hope that this will succeed – then you must return to what has been left behind in terms of the stability of the single currency. If you follow the debates in the European Parliament seriously, you will see that we have long believed, by a large majority, that a common currency without a common fiscal and economic policy, without a government in this area, cannot function sustainably and permanently. And I think that both of you – Mrs Merkel and Mr Hollande – are sitting here exactly the right one to get us out of this gandging on this issue, because the French have recently re-launched this. The French had to move long on the matter of sovereignty. But the Germans also have to move in their fixation solely on the debt problem and the monetary stability. There are two worlds that need to be brought together, and if we do not succeed in doing so, we will not be able to achieve internal stability, and then we will never be able to tackle the major crises that are growing around us in the way that is actually to be expected of the still strong Europe. (Applause) Mrs Merkel, I was at the railway station in Budapest – Keleti – when you decided in Germany that Dublin was no longer working. I thought it was as great as the people who had been put in an insane situation at Viktor Orban's train station. I think it is right that you have come forward in this situation and then – supported by Austria, but also Sweden and a few others – have said that we need to redefine our refugee policy. I have now heard that you and Francois Hollande believe that what our President Juncker said in his State of the European Union address are the lines that you now share for a new refugee policy and immigration policy in the European Union. If we assume that European values and human rights should count, it is questionable to me that it now boils down to the fact that we do not control our external borders better, but that we are once again relying on isolation and, as it were, on militarisation at our external borders. That doesn't work. So we will not get out of these refugee dramas. I would also like to say to you that I think it is right to talk to President Erdogan, because I know that we cannot solve all the problems of refugees from Africa and Asia here with us. I think it is right to talk to him about the need for Turkey to play its part. But I think it is wrong not to say that its escalation with the Kurds exacerbates the region's problems and does not solve them. A better situation in Turkey can only be achieved if the internal escalation ceases and if you also persuade President Erdogan to return to the path of democracy in Turkey. Let me make one more point: uncertainty has brought you here, Mrs Merkel, Mr Hollande – uncertainty among citizens. At the moment, hundreds of thousands of workers in the European Union fear for their future. This does not only apply to employees directly at VW. This also applies to all those who work in the subcontracting industry, and they work not only in Germany, but in many European countries, including outside the European Union. This is the result of an incredible industrial scandal and a criminal energy at VW that has been scourged often enough. But I would like to use your presence here to tell you that a supposedly well-intentioned protection of the interests of the car industry, which you in particular, as the well-known auto chancellor, Mrs Merkel, has ensured – but on this matter Mr Sarkozy, most recently Mr Hollande, has repeatedly you – that this supposed lyre is a thing of the last. Extending industry's interests into European legislation when it comes to climate and the environment was wrong, and that it is precisely this protection that has fostered hubris in companies such as VW. The climate summit, Mr Hollande, which we Europeans are going to do with a sham anyway, because our 2030 targets are not enough to achieve the 2-degree target, must not be further burdened by the fact that we continue to stand by this old protection of the car industry. A new era must also be ushered in in the car industry.

name: Nigel Farage
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, nobody in their right mind would not agree that it was a sensible thing to do, back in the 1950s, to get France and Germany together round the table to break bread with each other, to have a trade deal and to work as sovereign democratic nations together for peace.
