All of that was absolutely right and high-minded. Sadly, the whole thing has become corrupted. Tony Blair said that the EU today is no longer about peace, it is about power. How right he was, and how that power has shifted. When Kohl and Mitterrand came here representing their countries 25 years ago, it was a partnership of equals. But no longer. France is now severely diminished, trapped inside a currency from which, frankly, it cannot recover and the French voice in this relationship and in Europe is little more now, frankly, than a pipsqueak. It is an irony, is it not, that a project that was designed to contain German power has now given us a totally German-dominated Europe. Just look at the euro. Germany has a currency that is undervalued by 20% with a growing and massive trade surplus. Most growth in the German economy since the collapse of 2008 has indeed been in exports to other eurozone countries, such as your very big arms sales to countries like Greece, Chancellor Merkel. And when we have a general election that says a country like Greece wants to change direction, well I am sorry, but that now must be brushed aside because the Germans do not want it.  In what must count as perhaps the worst piece of public policy seen in modern Europe for half a century, when you compounded the already failing and flawed EU common asylum policy by saying to the whole world ‘please come to Europe’ – and we saw, frankly, virtually a stampede, and we learn that 80% of those that are coming are not Syrian refugees – in fact what you have done is to open the door to young, male, economic migrants, many of whom, I have to say, behave in a rather aggressive manner, quite the opposite to what you would ever expect to see from any refugee. Yet when that failure is met by objections from countries like Hungary their opinions are crushed.  This is not a Europe of peace. It is a Europe of division. It is a Europe of disharmony. It is a Europe that is a recipe for resentment. And yet, faced with all this failure, both of you, President Hollande and Chancellor Merkel, said the same thing today. You said Europe is not working so we must have more Europe: more of the same failing. Well, there is, I think, a bright star on the horizon. It is called the British referendum and, given that none of you want to concede Britain the ability to take back control of our own borders, a Brexit now looks more likely than at any point in modern time. I hope and pray that Britain voting to leave the European Union will be the beginning of the end of a project which, however noble its original intentions, has gone rotten. (Applause from the EFDD Group)

name: Marine Le Pen
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Thank you Mrs Merkel for making us happy to come today with your Vice-Chancellor, Administrator of the province france.  Mr Vice-Chancellor, I would have liked to have been able to call you Mr President of the Republic out of respect for your office, but, no more than your predecessor, you do not hold this presidency. A President of the Republic could not say: "Sovereignism is declineism", as you have just done, because the President of the Republic is the guarantor of the French Constitution and the title I of the French Constitution is: "Sovereignty." A President of the Republic cannot consistently ignore France's interests. France's interest is not to blindly submit to a policy decided in Berlin, Brussels or Washington. Its interest and your duty is to defend its sovereignty. France's interest is not to give this distressing spectacle of a France to the back of Germany on the migration issue. When, in a perfectly irresponsible gesture, Chancellor Merkel says that 800,000 migrants should be welcomed with open arms, you applaud. When, a few days later, it suspends Schengen and wants to control its borders, you applaud again, giving France the desolate image of a country adrift, staggering on an issue yet so essential to security, prosperity and the defence of France's identity. France's interest is also not to abdicate in the face of Dr Schaeble when the economic policy of the continent is decided, even though this policy is synonymous with massive unemployment, precariousness and the collapse of our social protection system. On the contrary, it is to resist and prevent Greece, the other countries of southern Europe, and then France from getting stuck in an endless austere spiral, with the sole aim of saving the euro and the German economic model of low wages. You are both coming here for a catch-up session because your European Union is collapsing, exacerbating migration assaults such as economic onslaughts, and forced to continue through blackmail, threat and intimidation. Your model is vassalization in the United States, austerity, unfair competition, massive surveillance of citizens, social dumping, migration submersion. I carry another model that brings together the peoples of Europe today, that of independence, of the Europe of nations in a multipolar world, of intelligent protectionism - yes -, of individual freedoms, of the defence of our security and our identities by the total cessation of mass immigration. Some will sum up by saying that I am the anti-Merkel, I accept the augury.  I do not recognise, in fact, Madam, the right to dispose of us in an absurd attempt at German domination of Europe. The defence of German interests does not justify the vassalisation of the other peoples of Europe.  I am, in this Chamber, the voice of free Europeans, of our sovereign peoples who are turning away from the European Union, because they crave the nation. I am the representative of the French people who are turning away from you, Mr Hollande, as he turned away yesterday from Mr Sarkozy, because he is thirsty for France. (Applause from the ENF group)

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI).
text: Mr President, Madam Chancellor, welcome to Strasbourg, a symbolic seat, but I would like to point this very much at risk from this Parliament. You assume the overwhelming, theoretical at least, responsibility of the leadership of two major founding states of the Union. However, this Western Europe, and in particular France and Germany, are, alas, countries in decline. Demographic, economic, social, cultural, political, spiritual and, Mr Hollande, this is not the work of sovereignists.  Seeing, this noon, His Majesty the King of Spain, I thought, through to me, that the first of the great European civil wars to have pitted our nations against us was, precisely, in 1870 the candidacy of Prince Hohenzollern to the throne of Spain. It is good, as has been said to be, to be sat down, that these conflicts have subsided.  But what would have been the use of so much suffering, sacrifice, toil, hope, if it were to integrate into a space open to unfair competition of products manufactured, under conditions of slavery, by the labour of states without social laws, without minimum wage, without protection of workers and without freedom of association? What is the point of boasting of a hard-won independence, if it is to submit to the will of today's superpower?  You told us about guarantees, Mr Hollande. Have you forgotten, then, that this year the United States of America stole 9 billion euros from the French bank BNP Paribas, without a word of protest from you?  I heard President Schulz say before the King of Spain that the challenge of our time was immigration. When Jean-Marie Le Pen announced that this would be the case several decades ago, he was already accused of agitating unfounded fears.  You say you are satisfied that you have distributed 160,000 political or assumed refugees as such. However, this Europe, which has only human rights in its mouth, has closed the door to two indisputable refugees, who were wrong to inform us about the spying practices of the Washington government. They are Julian Assange and Edward Snowden, who are still being held outside our borders.  Never since the theoretical abolition of borders have so many walls, fences and barbed wire been built. Inconsistency is everywhere, as it is internationally. As for the U.S.-European policies, they are the ones that contributed to the destruction of Iraq and Syria.  In a word as in a hundred, we would like more respect for national identities, the will of peoples, more protection of our interests, more freedom, less bureaucracy and, above all, the restoration of the family, cultural and spiritual values that have made the greatness of our civilization great. Are you ready to hear the roar of the peoples rising? It's late, it's already very late. God wants it not to be too late. (Applause from non-registered MPs)

name: Angela Merkel
text: Federal Chancellor of the Federal Republic of Germany. Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has I would like to thank the speakers who encouraged us – courage to accept the challenges. Europe can only function if we have respect for each other's opinions. We are 28 Member States in the European Council. Germany and France can develop a common position. The good thing is that we often have to go some way to get this common position. The essence of the compromise lies in every german-French agreement. But, of course, we will only have an agreement if all 26 others join in. What you are giving in the European Parliament, the speakers who have encouraged us, we are trying to take on board. On the other hand, we are also representatives of our national states, of our national parliaments. That is why, at this point, I am once again advocating – and some of which is already working quite well – to keep seeking this contact with the national parliaments and with the ideas that are being expressed there, because without this bridge- to advance Europe. That is why parliaments are so important. And the Treaty of Lisbon has once again made the European Parliament more important. Secondly, I would like to point out that, as Europe – if you have listened to the last speakers, we must be careful not to become a little depressed – that we in Europe also have successes. (Applause) We have had successes, for example, in the preparation of the climate conference. The European decisions, which are also centrally supported by the European Parliament, give a tailwind to The Promotion of Ambitious Commitments internationally. And this COP 21 conference is being prepared very, very carefully, well and ambitiously, and we have a good chance, if we do this together, to achieve something in Paris that we were not yet able to achieve in Copenhagen. I would ask everyone to cooperate here, because that would be a good message for the international community and, incidentally, something that we are fighting for the causes of flight. Why are many fleeing Africa? Because they have no chance, not only because of war and terrorism, but also because of hunger and hardship. That is why we must do everything we can. And a good climate agreement is a contribution to preventing refugee crises. (Applause) Then I would just like to make two comments. One is that all those who have talked about border closures between Germany and Austria, I invite them to visit the german-Austrian border. Manfred Weber may be able to show certain points of crossing the border. There can be no question of closing a border. Only if this has not yet reached you, I wanted to point it out again. Mrs Harms, I have a request for you. There are many unemployed people in Europe, and you yourself spoke of how many people have jobs, especially through the car industry. And something has happened at VW that needs urgent clarification, where we need transparency and where I have the impression that the company is doing the same. But please do not use this matter to do something that you might like to do out of your political conviction, which is to condemn the car as a whole, so to speak, thereby jeopardising thousands and thousands of jobs in Europe! We should not do that. (Applause) Ms. Harms shakes her head. Then it is good, and then it is reasonable. We have too few jobs in Europe rather than too many. But I take that as i know and I'm happy about it. I would like to thank you for this discussion here and for the fact that you have received us here as guests, and I would also like to say for myself that I would like to continue to work with the European Parliament. Thank you very much! (Applause)

name: François Hollande
text: President of the French Republic. Mr President, I, in turn, would like to thank all those who have intervened in this debate, which, from this point of view, has been enlightening.  Why are we here, the Chancellor and I? Why the two of us? Because we would be the most populous countries in Europe? That is not even true. Because we would be the main economies? Probably. But because there have been two wars in the last century between Germany and France. And it was Germany and France, in the aftermath of this tragedy, that wanted Europe to be able to be made from what the continent had suffered as horrors.  That is why the leaders of our two countries, French and German, have always wanted to be at the initiative of new European constructions. This was the case for General de Gaulle and Konrad Adenauer, and together we reminded the Chancellor and I of what the Elysée Treaty had been. Then it was François Mitterrand and Helmut Kohl - not just them for that matter - who took Europe to take new steps. So that is why we are here, in fidelity to history and also to the responsibilities that must be ours. You wanted to talk about what the future of Europe could be, both of which. This future must be one of strengthening Europe. There are several ways and they have been mentioned here in one way or another. There is the way in between, what we know, namely to leave it at that, with a Europe of twenty-eight which is not easy to lead, in which it is not easy to organise deliberation. From this 28-year-old Europe, I have now experienced it for three years - less than Chancellor Merkel - but the decisions we take in the European Council are unanimous decisions. Even if France and Germany were to agree, but we still have to do so, the other 26 would still have to be convinced. On Greece, on refugees, we decided to twenty-eight and not for two. It is at twenty-eight that we have taken responsibility for asylum, because we are Europeans and we have values and principles, and no one can, moreover, under international conventions that go far beyond Europe, to prohibit those who are on the run, who are obliged to protect themselves, from being welcomed here in Europe. Those who refuse to do so would not simply be honoured to be Europeans but simply to their duty to the international community.  We are acting at twenty-eight, and so there is a second possible way in the face of this Europe, which is struggling to decide: the path of reinforcement. This is the one on which I think Mrs Merkel and I want to work with you. Because nothing will happen without the European Parliament. The way to strengthen the common foreign and security policy was mentioned by several speakers because, if there is not a European policy in the face of what is happening in Ukraine, in the face of what is happening in Syria and the Middle East, in the face of what is happening in Palestine, also in the face of the major continents, the great powers , which nation - even France, for which I not only have respect but whose greatness I also know - could decide for the rest of the world on its own?  Therefore, we need Europe and a Europe that is much stronger than it is today, provided that it too takes on responsibilities.  (Applause)  The first responsibility when it comes to having a foreign policy - and it is not easy and I know that here we can have debates - is the common defence policy and if we want to be an independent power, we must have this common defence policy. For now, it is often France that takes the initiative, sends its armies, sends a number of our soldiers to Africa to avoid the worst. Then, then, Europe joins us and so much the better! Because if there were no Europe in Mali, if there were not Europe in the Central African Republic, there would still be massacres today. Therefore, we need this European security policy and therefore a defence policy.  We need a migration policy, asylum policy, which can be common. This is what we have explained here: a common asylum system with a list of countries that we consider safe; the same policy for Turkey, the same policy to help countries like Jordan, Lebanon - I want to quote them all - who are suffering; because a country like Lebanon hosts half of its population. Here we have this duty to carry this asylum policy, to escort those who come here for economic reasons have no right to stay on our continent. We must do so with dignity and with firmness and together. If we do not do it together, then what does the Schengen area mean? Mrs Merkel was right to go back on the Dublin agreement because we cannot ask the countries that are on the border of Europe to pay for everyone else, because it would be unfair and because it would be unbearable. (Applause) Therefore, if we do not want the in-between, which we have been living for perhaps too many years, and if we do not want to strengthen Europe, then there is only one way. It was quoted, I heard what Mr. Farage said. The only possible way for those who are not convinced of Europe is to leave Europe. Simply! There is no other way! This one is terrible, but it is the one, finally, of logic: to get out of Europe, to leave the euro, to leave Schengen, and even, if you can, to get out even of democracy! Because sometimes, when I hear you, I ask myself this question: do you really want to participate in a common space?  (Great applause) What I call here is not the abandonment of sovereignty, it is sovereignty! And sovereignty has nothing to do with sovereignism. European sovereignty means being able to decide for ourselves and to avoid a return to nationalism, to populism, to the extremists who are forcing us today to go down a path we did not want! (Lively and prolonged applause)

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Thank you very much, Mr President. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report and for his excellent work. I would like to express my sincere thanks for this debate. Thank You very much, Mr Hollande, for coming to the European Parliament. As you can see, the place of vibrant democracy in Europe is this Chamber. (A woman places a European emblem on the square in front of Chancellor Merkel.) The honourable Member has been trying to do this for hours now. Mrs Merkel, do not be angry. I would like to thank you both of you for your encouragement. And I would like to say one thing to you, President Hollande: we thank you for your last comment. Those who allow themselves to be elected to this House in the belief that they can use the instruments of this House to destroy Europe from within have received a lesson in democracy today. Thank you for your visit! (Strong applause)

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: "I don't have the rules in front of me, I have a spontaneous request, but I don't know what point of the policy. I would ask that some authority or office observe who first stops clapping at important events such as the previous one, because we in socialism are used to being seen as enemies of the system, and that some serious sanctions should be applied to those who break the rules of dictatorships, stop applauding and standing up early. Those who saw the Congresses of the Soviet Union remember how long the applause lasted. We are similar in all respects to this, I propose that clapping should also be mandatory for a certain period of time.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Thank you for your comment. But the Rules of Procedure allow for applause. The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. Twenty-five years after the fall of the Berlin Wall, the German and French allies are meeting in Parliament to discuss the current situation of the EU. Except that France and its President François Hollande are no longer considered to be Germany's ally but as the vassal of Germany, the vice-chancellor in short. This situation has actually been ongoing since the introduction of the single currency and the ECB's control of inflation at all costs under the pressure of German directives and wills. France, which is a great nation, must not be diluted in this European magma and must not succumb to German desires.  Unlike the President of the Republic, I want to fight to defend our sovereignty and our identity. Our interest is not to bow to the American wills that want to suffocate us with TTIP and ultraliberalism that kills peoples. Our interest is also to fight against the migration and Islamist spill that is overwhelming Europe and to categorically reject the austerity imposed by Brussels and which governments apply without releverage (we see these effects in Greece). In the face of this situation, there is an urgent need for a radical change in policy and model.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – It was with great disappointment that I listened to the speech of Angela Merkel and Francois Hollande. It was a missed opportunity to address the current European crisis in any real substantial fashion. While a number of important issues were raised, the speeches lacked any prospect for real democracy or an emphasis on solidarity across the European Union. We must rethink our refugee policy and it cannot only be about militarising our outer borders. There must be a real emphasis put on solidarity and not just mere platitudes.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: Writing. – The joint appearance of Angela Merkel and Francois Hollande sends an important signal in these difficult times: if France and Germany pull together, we will meet the great challenges! The problems are obvious. Europe has already shown in the past that we are growing in the challenges we face. That is why I fully agree with the Chancellor when she calls on all of us to do more for Europe.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The invitation made to Merkel and Hollande, from the outset and on its own, shows the intention to devote a legitimizing vision of the directory that has essentially determined the course of the European capitalist integration process. For our part, of course, we reject, denounce and firmly reject this intention. But the speeches made here proved very enlightening. Enlightening on the situation of profound crisis in which the EU is plunged, on its insantable contradictions and its insurmountable historical limits. Enlightening about the responsibilities of the right and social democracy in this crisis, about their railway commitment to, before the abyss, prepare an escape forward, trying to imprison the Peoples of Europe between Scyila and Caribde. Clarification on the deeply negative role played by the EU in the world, on its criminal complicity with the US and NATO, as is evident in the situation in the Middle East, Africa and Ukraine. Perhaps without knowing it, Merkel and Hollande, no wonder they talk about the future, are already past. The disrespect for the sovereignty of peoples and democracy, the attack on fundamental rights and freedoms, the attempt to impose in Europe a setback of civilizational dimensions will, sooner or later, be unavariably defeated by the struggle of workers and peoples.

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – For the first time since 1989, we have had the honour of ing the leaders of Germany and France on the doorsteps of the European Parliament. 26 years ago, German Chancellor Helmut Kohl and French President François Mitterrand paid a visit here to seal the fall of communism in Europe and thus the collapse of the walls that divided Europe, literally and figuratively. Now Angela Merkel and François Hollande have faced the challenge of sustaining Europe's hard-won unity. The economic, social and, above all, migration crisis is exposing us all to a moment of truth. That is why they are so pleased with the arguments and facts of the heads of both countries. The real tragedy is not the unpaid Greek instalments or the deployment of refugees from the Middle East and Africa, but the fact that we have lost our sense of community for a while. This is a risk that we must beware of, because only a strong Europe will give us a chance to overcome our weaknesses. Guided only by a cool, balanced analysis, it is one step away from selfishness, populism and even separatism. This joint, historic visit to difficult times for all is proof of democracy, and I hope that it is an opportunity to strengthen cooperation between all Member States and more.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I fully agree with the call to unity made here today by such distinguished guests to deal with the refugee crisis. I would, however, go further and, recalling the spirit of today's speech also made by King Philip VI today, stress the need to achieve that unity in order to meet all the challenges facing the European Union today. As urgent as it is to give a common European response to the refugee drama, we must not forget that our efforts to create a Union with one voice must be extended to all material areas. As Merkel has said, we cannot think about nationalisms again, but quite the opposite. Hollande has said it even louder: nationalism is war. Let us work so that our Europe, that of 500 million citizens, economic and international power and desired destiny for those who yearn for our welfare state, is not blurred and disjoisted by short-term and provincial nationalisms, more concerned with dividing and subtracting than in adding and uniting.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. – The speeches by President Hollande and Chancellor Merkel to the plenary session of the European Parliament are very significant. I share with them the view that unity must be acted upon in the face of challenges, for as the President of the French Republic pointed out, "nationalism is war". Indeed, the European Union is the political innovation that has managed to maintain peace on the continent and has allowed decades of economic prosperity, even if nationalist populism wants to clear the path we have taken together since 9 May 1950. But it is not enough to say that we do not want to back down, because we need more integration, not less, to properly manage the refugee crisis, to get full employment, to ensure the stability of the euro, etc. It is therefore essential to overcome the intergovernmental method, national vetoes and to end the exclusion of the European Parliament from decision-making in policies as important as taxation. In short, the leaders of two Member States as relevant as Germany and France must say it clearly: we need the European Federation. A Union to Twenty-eight cannot function under the permanent threat of blockade by any of its members.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. – Today, the EU faces the greatest challenges in its history. The Greek debt crisis, Russia's possible withdrawal from the EU and the refugee crisis are the most pressing challenges of our time. The last time the French President and German Chancellor spoke together in the plenary session of the EP, the Berlin Wall collapsed, the single European currency was launched and the biggest enlargement in the history of the Union took place. Today, we expect similar historic steps. Europe is at a crossroads. Either we move forward on the path of the European state, or we fall back to the level of mediocrity. In the long term, the challenges facing the European community can only be effectively faced by closer integration and the creation of a United States of Europe.  Today, we must finally put an end to the fact that the EU is an economic giant and a political dwarf. The Greek drama has clearly shown that without a common tax and fiscal policy, Europe is tumbling from crisis to crisis. Without a common EU refugee policy, some national leaders are erecting unnecessary fences and breaking down European solidarity. Without a common foreign and energy policy, some Member State governments are bowing to Russia and building nuclear power plants that threaten European energy security. Today, we have two choices: sovereignty, called introverted nationality, insemination, then slow but surely irrelevance, or a federal European state and a competitive, liveable European Hungary. There is no doubt about the democratic coalition's choice.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. – The European Union is at a historic turning point. Having overcome the economic and financial crisis, it is currently facing a crisis of social and values due to the situation of refugees seeking Europe as a port of shelter. I would like to add that we must move towards a growing economic, political and social integration that addresses the constraints still in force throughout Europe. We must move towards the creation of the Digital Single Market that facilitates the sale of products online and streamlines startup activities, and it is essential to end cross-border links in the areas of transport and energy. Finally, I believe that the European Union must move towards increasing political integration, where everyone has the opportunity to actively participate in a greater number of activities at European level and solidarity between all 28 Member States is strengthened.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD)
text: in writing. With what right, in what institutional capacity, do Merkel and Hollande come before Parliament to talk to us about Europe and how to deal with the current challenges? In our opinion, no one , and that is why we have left the Chamber, because we do not want to legitimise in any way the dominance that France and Germany have been exercising over the rest of Europe for years, preventing it from getting out of the crisis and destroying the last remnants of the welfare state with suicidal economic recipes.  We do not want to leave the future of Europe in the hands of those who for years, outside the institutions, in the secret chambers, have been negotiating decisions that will determine the lives of millions of citizens, of those who impose maximum rigour on countries in difficulty, in compliance with socially unsustainable rules, which is then the first to violate, of those who have put European politics at the mercy of the interests of banks and markets. , of those who accept the misery generated in other States by their policies as inevitable, and who, indeed, want to profit from that misery.  I am not prepared to accept lessons in union and solidarity from those who systematically trample on any principle of loyal cooperation between Member States, putting national commercial and financial interests above all, including above human rights and democracy.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. – The European Union is experiencing a severe impasse. Although the European Union is, by its nature, a partnership between equals, the economic and political weight of France and Germany is decisive in its evolution. It has been so in the past and it will not cease to be so in the future. As François Hollande said, "The choice is not between more or less Europe. It is between Europe's affirmation or its destruction." We have to reject Europe at various speeds. On the other hand, the construction of Europe has to be done by various wills. The will of its peoples, working together for a new ambition and a new vision for the European project. Angela Merkel wants "the European Union to come out of this crisis stronger and more cohesive." The path of the future is the path of inclusion, growth and jobs.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Commission statement on the adopted decision on the Capital Markets Union package (2015/2767(RSP)).

name: Jyrki Katainen
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, today we are discussing the Capital Markets Union (CMU), which is part of the European Investment Plan. As we have said several times before, the Investment Plan has three parts – the European Fund for Strategic Investment (EFSI), the Project Portal and the Single Market – and the Capital Markets Union is part of this third pillar, deepening and widening the internal market. I personally believe that the third pillar of the plan is the most powerful when we are talking about job creation and economic growth in Europe. That is why the Capital Markets Union represents a very important part of the plan when we are trying to get more investment to Europe. A couple of figures to set out the scale of the challenge we have in creating a Capital Markets Union: Europe’s economy is about the same size as that of the USA but our equity market is less than half the size of theirs; in the USA, SMEs get about five times more funding from the capital markets or non-bank financing than they do here in the European Union; if our venture capital markets were as well developed as they are in the United States, companies could have raised an extra EUR 90 billion over the past five years; and, perhaps even more importantly, the differences between the EU Member States are greater than the differences between the EU and the United States. So everybody understands that there is a lot of work to be done here in Europe. Allow me now to draw your attention to the following three important points. First, we have been listening very carefully to the feedback provided to us by stakeholders and the European Parliament. The resolution you passed earlier this summer provided useful input, as did the consultation result from over 700 responses. Personally, I have visited 27 Member States in the context of the Investment Roadshow. I received important feedback as to what to fix in the single market and, more especially, in financial services. Many features of this feedback are addressed in the Action Plan. Second, this Action Plan is very ambitious. The plan will have a big impact, because we have adopted a holistic and inclusive approach, covering also the framework conditions as called for by the Five Presidents’ Report on EMU deepening. In addition to Commissioner Hill, who is the main contributor, other colleagues – Commissioner Jourová, Commissioner Moscovici and Commissioner Moedas – are playing important roles in the implementation of the plan. Next year we will be making concrete legislative proposals on the tax side, via the Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base (CCCTB), and on insolvency practices. Moreover, we are fully exploiting the synergies that exist when using the different tools at our disposal. It is therefore important to judge the measures not just in isolation but also as part of the comprehensive package. I will give you a couple of examples. With the EFSI we are financially supporting fresh investments in critical infrastructure projects. In parallel, the amendments to Solvency II that we are putting forward under CMU, to create a well-defined infrastructure asset class with appropriately calibrated capital requirements, should draw in long-term investors such as insurance companies. Risk charges on infrastructure investment will come down by some 30%. We are also acting to re-launch a European securitisation market, both via the activities of the European Fund for Strategic Investment and now through CMU. Last week we made a proposal for a new framework to encourage the take-up of Simple Transparent and Standardised Securitisation (STS). This will define when a securitisation counts as STS, and again it will set lower capital requirements that will apply when it meets those criteria. If we could rebuild the securitisation market to the levels it was at before the crisis that could add up to an extra EUR 100 billion of investment for the whole economy. With this in mind, I urge the Council and Parliament to take forward the proposed legislation without delay. Honourable Members, we managed to push the EFSI Regulation through in only six months. I hope Parliament and the Council can deliver as quickly on these proposals. These proposals are, in places, even more simple than the EFSI Regulation, so let us put private money to work for new jobs. Looking especially at SMEs, here too we are working holistically to devise measures to help SMEs get financing on capital markets. We are looking at the prospectus, which is what businesses have to publish when they want to list on a stock exchange. Unfortunately, they can be lengthy and expensive. So we will be bringing forward a proposal to modernise the Prospectus Directive so that these documents serve their initial purpose. They certainly need to provide clear information for investors, but they also need to be affordable for SMEs to produce. Meanwhile, the European Investment Advisory Hub, created under the umbrella of the EFSI, will explore how to provide advisory help to SMEs when it comes to market experience. Third, while ambitious, the Action Plan is credible and realistic. We are not making promises we cannot keep. We are not intervening or regulating where the case is not clear-cut and where national markets are working well. In areas where, for example, progress in the past has been difficult and where we feel more groundwork is still needed, or where the private sector is developing useful initiatives, we adopt a pragmatic step-by-step approach. This is, for example, the case for covered bond markets for private placements. Personal pensions are another example. Personal pensions have the potential to inject more savings into capital markets and to channel more of that money to productive investments. Yet the EU does not have a single market for voluntary personal pensions, limiting choice and putting up prices. Next year we will start work to determine exactly what is needed to establish a European market for simple personal pensions and we will clarify whether or not EU legislation could help to underpin that market. Finally, let me stress that we will be watchful of emerging risks to financial stability. The Commission is committed to working with the European supervisory authorities to strengthen supervisory convergence and to ensure that the rules of the game are interpreted with consistency across different jurisdictions. To conclude, the Capital Markets Union Action Plan is a major step towards completing the single market in capital. The Commission has delivered a comprehensive package on time. It is our strong desire now to work together with the Council and with Parliament to achieve swift agreements on our proposals for the benefit of the European economy and our citizens.

name: Gunnar Hökmark
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for this statement. As he touched upon EU–USA economic relations, I cannot but underline the fact that the European Union is the bigger economy – even the US Central Intelligence Agency recognises this. But, as the Commissioner has pointed out, we do not have the magnitude and the strength of the capital markets that the United States has, and that is where we need to proceed. That is why it is very good that the Commission has taken these initiatives. However, there are some things worth thinking about. The first is the gap between the liquidity we have in European markets and the lack of investments. In that perspective, something is wrong or missing. We need to look again at the regulations, and review what has been achieved over the last years in the area of regulation. It might be that some things can be done better, and it might be that some things are not as necessary as we thought they were. That is why a review is very important.  I would also like to underline a difference between the USA and Europe, and that is that we are, for historical reasons, more dependent on banks. That is why it is important to look upon European banks as part of the broader capital market. I would also like to say that it is important to look upon the fact that we have a number of well-functioning capital markets in the Union. So an important task is to get rid of the hindrances that are making it more difficult to facilitate all the things we could do.  Finally, we have a number of well-functioning markets that could be used as a template and that we could use as an example. Let us use them as an example and not over-regulate them. Let us see to it that we regulate on the basis of using the strength of the capital markets that we have and will get in the future. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Paul Rübig (PPE)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". I would like to ask Mr Hökmark how he actually sees the situation of small and medium-sized enterprises, because, of course, in America, companies usually have much higher equity capital and can therefore be much more able to withstand the risk that can arise from different market conditions. In Europe, small and medium-sized enterprises are very dependent on credit. Is there a way here to strengthen risk capital and equity, including for European companies?

name: Gunnar Hökmark (PPE)
text: blue-card answer. – Of course we need to do that and I think an important part of that is to ensure that we can have profitable investments in the European market because that is the way to build up capital. But I would also like to underline that it is very important that banks can fulfil the whole line of financing and investment-making and market-making. Because if we are changing the structures of European banks in order to reduce their opportunities to contribute to the financing of small and medium-sized enterprises, then we are making the problems worse. I think we should use what we have, but develop it and make it better.

name: Roberto Gualtieri
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Parliament welcomes the Commission's action plan and the first concrete legislative proposals on which we are committed to working quickly and efficiently.  Diversify sources of finance, knowing that capital markets and banks must be complementary, support access to credit and capital for small and medium-sized enterprises, encourage long-term and infrastructure investment, ensure real integration of financial markets, more efficient allocation of resources, offer more choice to savers, increase risk diversification and strengthen shock absorbing capacity These are the reasons which make the Capital Markets Union project strategic and make it a central component of the European strategy for growth and employment. For these reasons, Parliament supports the Commission's action, as already indicated in the resolution we adopted. For us, an efficient Capital Markets Union does not contradict and must not contradict a robust regulatory framework that prevents another financial crisis from happening again, and indeed we believe that a robust system of rules and increasingly integrated supervision are a condition for the success of the Capital Markets Union. At the same time, an analysis of the combined impact of the current regulatory framework and a calibration of capital requirements that incentivises long-term investment and the economy and the real economy are a useful exercise that the ECON Committee has urged and to which we intend to contribute. I welcome the fact that the action plan wisely proposes a pragmatic and gradual approach, but at the same time points to ambitious objectives such as insolvency proceedings, taxation, but also as the fund of funds for venture capital or the European personal pension.  There are also problems and challenges that need to be fully aware of. Market failures also need to be addressed for the CMU to work. , especially for small and medium-sized enterprises, which should not be undermined, but supported. In order to tackle these problems and challenges, the European Parliament will therefore do its part to the full.

name: Kay Swinburne
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank Commissioner Katainen for coming to present the Capital Markets Union (CMU) action plan today, a plan which sets out the ambition to free up capital flows across the EU, and a plan which encourages EU savers to become investors so that they can derive a sustainable income in their old age. Beyond all the detail which I am sure we will debate at length in the much needed review of the Prospectus Directive and the securitisation legislation we are expecting, are several other measures to ensure a more effective single market for financial services. I would suggest that the real measure of success of the CMU will be whether it becomes relevant to all 28 Member States, whether those countries of the EU that currently do not have an active and well-functioning capital market develop one, and whether all countries can nurture a culture of investment at both personal and institutional level to fuel investment in their businesses. The International Monetary Fund (IMF) recognised a long time ago that functioning capital markets are a precondition for a thriving economy, and it recognises this measure in its country-specific assessments on an annual basis. Therefore, including this kind of criterion in the European Semester in a way analogous to that of the IMF, will be really important. But the CMU should not solely be about legislation, nor should it be about spending money on new institutions to achieve single supervisors. It should be about cultural change so that investors can take appropriate risk, and so that companies do not see bank loans as the only way to finance investment and growth. Achieving diversity in retail financial products available cross-border will be important, but more time-dependent will be securing a more diverse array of funding models for our businesses to access capital, both equity and debt, via our broad capital markets. We need to ensure that while emerging companies do not always get bank financing they can access other forms of capital from our capital markets. European companies need to grow to be competitive. We need to seek best practice, wherever it may have developed, and remove all existing barriers to capital flow.

name: Sylvie Goulard
text: im Namen der ALDE-Fraktion. Herr President! Ich personlich habe kein Problem mit einem deutschen Vorsitz. Ich schàme mich for das, was in dieser Aula vorher vor Bundeskanzlerin Merkel gesagt worden ist.  Mr Vice-President of the Commission, dear Mr Katainen, we are always happy to see Lord Hill but we are happy that it is you today for a reason: you are in charge of investment, you have carried the Juncker plan, and the first difficulty I have with the capital markets union is that the title does not say what the objective is. The title is a tool, instead of talking about what we want to do together and I believe that at a time when citizens are questioning the meaning of the European Union so much, it would perhaps be important to offer them something a little sexier than 'capital markets union'. Other than that, I have three questions. Round first, can we really settle for - and I hope not - texts on prospectus and securitization? I remember that the Green Paper begins with the words: we want to support growth and jobs, which is the right goal. Honestly, we have to speed up the other steps, because if, in the end, it is on these two subjects that we have great success, I think that, again, we will have a little trouble with the citizens. Second, and Kay Swinburne just said, it is a real cultural change that we are trying to implement. Europe is not used to financing companies through the market, so we need to tackle the issue of taxation, which is decisive in moving the savings of individuals, in particular, but also of institutions, and then also the whole issue of the bankruptcy of companies which can help some to invest. Last thing I wanted to mention is the consistency of what we do. Are we not undermining the spirit of the capital markets union with the structural reforms in the banking sector? I think there is something important here, complementarity should prevail over the opposition. We are counting on you, Commissioner, to bring this information to Lord Hill, but also to make it your honey, so that inside the college, when there are discussions, you will plead for investment, investment and investment.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Thank you very much! Thank you also for the words before. Some of what has been said here before has been really hard to bear.

name: Fabio De Masi
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the The Bank for International Settlements and Alan Greenspan warn of new financial crises. The EU Commission wants to reopen the casino with the Capital Markets Union. Banks and insurance companies should invest in infrastructure. Taxpayers pay the return. The securitisation business – i.e. the packaging of junk loans – is to be revived, instead of using American mortgages now, for example, with European car loans. Volkswagen sends greetings. The investment – which Europe so desperately needs – will not bring this, because there is no lack of liquidity, but of demand. Companies only invest if they also find customers. But there is no such way because of the reduction in public expenditure, wages and pensions in Europe. The Capital Markets Union does not help small businesses in southern Europe that do not receive loans. The financing of investments in Europe depends on the banks. We are not the United States. Our markets are regional, our companies are medium-sized. There are different insolvency regulations. As a result, access to the capital market is too expensive for small and medium-sized enterprises. And even in the US, bank lending has become more dynamic than capital market business since the crisis. Europe needs reputable banks instead of gamblers who are too big to fail, too big to fail. That is why we should finally do our homework in the area of banking structural reform, like a public investment programme. Then we will invest again in Europe.

name: Sven Giegold
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has First of all, I would like to say that the idea of a Capital Markets Union is the right idea. Within the euro area in particular, we need more cross-border exposures, so that when individual countries are facing problems, we do not also have a unilateral burden on the capital markets. That is why the idea is right. It is also right that you want to create consumer-friendly products throughout Europe. It is also right that small credit unions should be allowed throughout Europe. There are right thoughts in the package. However, the package is linked to two false promises. Firstly, with the false promise that it could make a substantial contribution to re-entering investment in Europe. That is simply not right. Take a look at the situation on the capital markets! The drama is great. Even at the long end of maturities, we have very low interest rates. We have a high savings rate in relevant parts of Europe. And if we want to invest this money, we must make investments profitable, especially in the sectors of the future. There is still no offensive by the Commission for this project. If you want to repair the capital market, we do not need a capital markets union alone, but we need instruments that channel that capital into sustainable investment. I am waiting for an offensive from you. There is a second imbalance in this chapter, and that is the tone, as if we had created too much regulation. On the contrary, we have made many of the rules that we have created too complex and bureaucratic, while other parts of the financial markets are still not properly regulated. In the area of shadow banks, the promises to shed light there are unfulfilled. I would therefore ask you to continue with the Capital Markets Union, but do not stop there, but solve the substance of the problems we still have in the financial market, so that a new crisis does not worsen. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – A very simple question: you said that you believed that there is regulation which is far too complex. Can you give me a specific example of something which is costing taxpayers or perhaps businesses across Europe, stopping them from expanding? Can you give me one example of that and what you would do to simplify it please?

name: Sven Giegold (Verts/ALE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. I am happy to give you an example of what I find particularly problematic. Small banks, too, must be guided by relatively complicated rules when calculating liquidity and equity positions. But this is completely inappropriate for the business of a conservative lyrizing and well-capitalized bank. We therefore need simple and tough rules for the smaller institutions, while we need complex and elaboraterules for the big banks. And to this day we have not managed to anchor this distinction. With regard to the principle of proportionality, I am very concerned that the European Central Bank is not keeping its promises. And this House must also lag behind it, so that this is changing.

name: Patrick O’Flynn
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, opening up capital markets clearly has some potential benefits. If an SME in the east of England, for instance, is able to make its case for funds to a middle-sized German investment fund, or even if a young couple can make their case to a potential mortgage provider from France, then in both cases the consumer may, in theory, get a better deal. And it is also the case that capital may, in general, end up being more efficiently allocated, improving economic outcomes. But there remain many pitfalls in the Commission’s approach. Why, for instance the grandiose title of Capital Markets Union? There is clearly no realistic prospect of ending all geographic associations between the source of capital and where it is deployed. So to speak of a Capital Markets Union at all is to elevate federalist ideology above practical improvements. In addition, the legal and credit risks run by companies are very different in different EU countries, and disclosing them fully is going to be costly and cumbersome. The head of the German Savings Banks Association has pointed out that corporate bonds are not really worth doing for less than EUR 10 million, while large investors are rarely interested in projects under EUR 25 million. Anecdotal evidence suggests that companies need to be turning over EUR 1 billion before the market become seriously interested, so it is hard to make a case that SMEs will benefit much from a Capital Markets Union. It is the corporates who stand to gain at the margins, and forgive me for not punching the air in wild celebration at that prospect! Of course, any proposed financial transaction tax risks undermining even those incremental gains and certainly could harm Europe’s biggest and most successful capital market – the City of London. The dependency of the Commission’s plans on securitisation will also worry many citizens given that over-securitisation was a key factor in the great financial crash. One does not need a political union for trade, and one does not need it to enable investment across borders. I hope the Commission will put aside grandiose schemes and instead be a more modest facilitator for agreements on investment flows between European nations.

name: Bernard Monot
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the relaunch of securitisation is the first major project of the capital markets union. This priority, which was unanimously wanted by the European Union, the ECB and the Bank of England, is suspect. Is it necessary to recall that the securitisation mechanism is at the root of the subprime crisis? This sounds like a dangerous reopening of the big casino, the main cause of the global financial crisis of 2008. I note, at this stage, a great paradox: the union of capital markets is intended to be a set of measures to de-de-carfise the financing of companies. However, your first step is to relaunch securitization to free up banks' balance sheets and also improve their ratio, all to supposedly allow lending more. Now, we're back to square one. The banking system will receive juicy commissions to comply with solvency rules, but without any guarantee of financing the real economy. I still fear a mega game of dupes, especially since the past of Commissioner Hill, a former City lobbyist, makes him a close relay of financial and banking interests. But, beyond this, we must ask ourselves two questions: the first is whether the STS securitisation rules proposed by the directive are sufficient to avoid the abuses of the past and the second is whether this STS label will be enough to effectively boost the financing of local SMEs. On the first point, I would say that the text shows a seemingly solid framework: we need homogeneous credits, clear modelling of cashflows and a ban on the spread of risk in the investor chain. Two criticisms at this stage, I regret the level of 5% of the total securitized credits that must be retained by the issuer. It's obviously too low. It is necessary to ensure that this issuer is involved in financial risk by setting a much higher threshold and it must also be set with an overall limit so that the majority of a balance sheet is not fully securitized.  Secondly, on sanctions, the news shows that private banks only have billions in fines as long as they remain proportionately low in relation to the tens of billions of euros in profits they generate and realize. The amounts provided will not be a deterrent to the financial windfall that is opening up, especially since they are in fact left to the discretion of each Member State. However, it is not certain that countries accommodating with finance, such as the United Kingdom or Luxembourg, are taking very strict measures. Second question: what impact on the actual financing of the real economy? Easing the balance sheet of banks...    therefore that this STS securitisation label has mechanisms that require banks to lend in return. From the giving. For example, by requiring them to re-take back their claims due to what is not lent to businesses and individuals within a reasonable time. Unfortunately, the draft directive does not provide for this, but beyond securitisation, the real question is whether the economic environment is such that banks will want to finance projects to create value and jobs. This requires confidence, stability and hypervoltile capital markets as they are, mass unemployment, a high-risk geopolitical situation, over-indebtedness of states. The environment arising from the ultraliberal economic model of the European Union is still as negative as ever. The ENF Group will remain very attentive to the evolution of this market.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI).
text: Mr President, both the banking union for the dissemination and shielding of the banking system and the capital markets union for raising capital are becoming urgent for large companies, in view of the inability to overcome the capitalist crisis and the fear of a new one. One objective for the whole of the European Union: recovery, sacrificing popular rights and needs. Look at the thousands of layoffs in all the states. See what's happening these days with thousands of layoffs at Air France and elsewhere.  In Greece of the three memorandums, PASOK, New Democracy and SYRIZA, the recapitalisation of banks, in order to stand on the single capital market under discussion, pays the people with barbaric, without end, measures for wages, pensions, taxes, social expenditure, privatisations. Governments and the Union are brutally blackmailing with bankruptcy and in the coming months with the threat of the haircut of bail-in deposits.

name: Werner Langen (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Thank you, Vice-Presidents. The idea of a Capital Markets Union is to be supported in principle. However, I believe that there are significant risks in some of the proposals contained in the action programme. When I think, for example, of making securitisation easier again, which was one of the main causes of the financial market crisis. So we have to be very careful about that. It is also true that, in the context of the financial market crisis, many banks have retreated to their home markets and that financial instruments that were previously there are no longer available. I also think it is right to draw up an impact study of the previous regulations. However, if the purpose of this is to introduce over-regulation or deregulation through the back door, then we will be against it. And as far as the financing of small and medium-sized enterprises is concerned, the most stable factor is a regional banking structure, because in the countries where we have them, small and medium-sized enterprises have few problems. The European Central Bank's attempt to encourage investment with interest-free loans through cheap money has not helped in southern Europe. It is a mistake. And that is why I believe that we do not need to continue this aberration. In fact, greater Europeanisation would be needed on certain issues. These include insolvency law, shadow banks – as has already been mentioned – company law and tax law. Mr Hill has not made any proposals on this, because it would, of course, be a step too much Europeanisation that he can hardly sell to the City of London. So basic support, but certain reservations. I believe that, in the end, we will have to examine the Commission's proposals intensively and, if it goes too far, the Commission will have to leave its feathers there.

name: n/a
text: The question, of course, is: does the financial sector work in the interests of the customer? That has not been the case in recent years, of course. Profit and self-interest were paramount. Regulators, lawmakers and regulators did not make the decision. Joris Luyendijk, a columnist at The Guardian, compared the financial sector to a full plane and an empty cockpit. There was no sending and certainly not in the best interests of the customer.  The Socialists and Democrats see the capital markets union as an opportunity. There's no misunderstanding about that. You have also heard my colleague Roberto Gualtieri. It's an opportunity. And it is certainly possible to achieve more diversity where we see that the European sector is very focused on banks, while capital markets can be better developed. I think the comparison between the US and the EU is flawed. We are a landscape dominated by banks, but there is certainly more diversity possible.  The action plan on the Capital Markets Union is an opportunity. It is also an opportunity to tackle the lingering problems in Europe. That is why it is good that Commissioner Katainen is sitting here, because it is certainly in the European interest that there should be more opportunities for investment, that money be converted into investments. We want there to be a joint mission and that also means that investors and SMEs find each other again. This also means that the paperwork for SMEs is reduced. These are opportunities, but the burden of proof lies with the Commission, because the focus of the customer's interest has not been and will not be taken for granted. The Commission must demonstrate that the proposals are in the service of the real economy, in the service of ordinary people and small businesses. It must show that it contributes to the real economy and does not harm it.  The Commission's burden of proof also includes very clear choices. The Commission must demonstrate that securitisation works and take a stand against synthetic securitisation.  Junk mortgages in the United States have shown that financial products without underlying value do not contribute to the real economy but pose great risks. The Commission must also take a stand against the unfavourable tax regimes which favour debt and penalise equity, because it is also a question of companies having sufficient buffer and building up and the tax is not designed to do so.  Finally, the Commission must also opt for the completion of the banking union. That remains very important in Europe. The deadly embrace between governments and banks must be broken. This means, on the one hand, a fair evaluation of the national security paper and, on the other hand, a European guarantee system. Finally, Mr President, the Commission must choose servitude, because that must be the central word in the capital markets union. Financial institutions must serve the real economy again and put the interests of the customer first. The Commission must therefore take part in this and let Juncker and his team prove that this is the right team to get this right.

name: Stanisław Ożóg (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Boosting investment and financing by seeking to create a genuine internal market, capital markets in the European Union is a very good idea and not only for reforming, but even improving the Union economy. Until now, financing has mainly been made from bank loans. On the other hand, the idea would be to stimulate the retail market and finance from sources other than banking. This is particularly important in view of the possibility of financing the SME sector. With due care and respect for European local markets, the creation of a single capital market can be a real opportunity for the European economy.  My biggest concern, however, is the desire to expand, as if by the way, monetary union. I think that, in the current economic situation, however, it would be worth seriously examining the effects that the adoption of the euro by successive countries, which are not really ready to follow other European economies, might have.

name: Cora van Nieuwenhuizen (ALDE).
text: – I am a supporter of a football association whose motto is 'No words but deeds'. I am pleased that this proposal for the Capital Markets Union is an action plan. I therefore really hope that you will work to make these actions concrete as soon as possible. We must keep in mind what we are doing, which is to offer an alternative to companies for their financing, so that they are not just dependent on banks.  We have to look carefully at how this works in practice. We must ensure that we do not go through with new regulations and we must ensure that we also dare to review existing regulations and everything that is still in the pipeline about level-2 measures and see if they contribute to this. If I may mention one example: the securitisation that is being discussed here. If it were the case that a pension fund or another investor had to test 57 criteria before it could apply securitisation, Then I think there would be little enthusiasm for it and then we put the horse behind the cart. We certainly should not do that, because every step in the right direction is one.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, this Commission has a representative of the oil industry at the helm of the Energy portfolio and a former London city lobista at the helm of the Finance portfolio.  Looking at his proposal on capital markets, saying "old lobista" is a lot to say. Since taking over the portfolio, Mr Hill, he has continued to do what he has done so far, only from a much more privileged place: to advance the agenda of the great financial powers, the financial deregulation and the headlinery that triggered the current economic crisis. We can't bet once again on a casino economy where banking always wins. You, Mr Hill, are talking about serving the interests of citizens and small businesses; however, in his consultations, he has heard virtually no one but his fellow bankers. If they want to legislate, let them run for election; don't do it for them or, above all, for their interests.

name: Molly Scott Cato (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, the Commission package on the Capital Markets Union makes clear that securitisation is back on the agenda as a strategy for increasing investment in Europe – and, for those of us who are not yet ready to forgive and forget the financial crisis of 2008, this sets alarm bells ringing. Securitisation is a typical example of the mystification and misleading language in which finance markets abound. Rather than offering security, it has historically been used as a technique for concealing risk. It is also likely to serve the inner circle of financiers and to divert investment from the businesses that make up the real economy. With securitisation, market traders created a dangerous game of ‘pass the parcel’ where nobody could be sure whose parcel contained the toxic assets. This gave value to worthless assets, but at great risk to the financial system. This is securitisation: an attempt to pretend that hiding risk is really reducing risk, when it is nothing of the sort. As Greens, we will insist that safe securitisation means the loans on which it is based are sound, that it does not involve the tranching of assets with varying levels of risk, and that we do not allow the return of credit default swaps. Securitisation was central to the irresponsible and high-risk trading that led to the financial crisis. If we are to prevent such a crisis, with all its devastating consequences, from happening again we must not allow securitisation on the old model to infect our financial markets.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the intentions behind the Capital Markets Union are certainly good, at least in words, because the reality of the situation is unfortunately very different, as is the final objective of this proposal.  Its ultimate aim is new financial deregulation, on the basis of the bad decisions taken in this area over the last twenty years. I am not surprised that lord hill, an expression of the City of London's financial lobby, is pushing for this proposal. The constant references to the US model to be taken as an example are totally inappropriate and misleading, because we know how much difference there is between the entrepreneurial fabric of European SMEs compared to their American counterparts.  It is not by leading small savers to invest in financial products that problems are solved, if we ever start creating new ones, as happened in 2008. On one point, however, we agree, namely that there is a serious problem with access to credit, especially for SMEs.  For us, there is only one solution, which is for banks to return to their traditional role of deposit collection and lending, and this is only feasible through banking separation on the model of American Glass-Steagall. Only in this way can we distinguish between those who want to do speculation freely and those who have a much more important task, namely to finance the real economy.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has This action plan for the creation of a Capital Markets Union includes a number of measures, the most important and most urgent of which, in my view, is the widening of funding opportunities and easier access to finance for small and medium-sized enterprises. Small and medium-sized enterprises are of particular importance in Europe. Not only do they employ two-thirds of all workers across the EU, they also generate almost 60% of value added. And 75% of SMEs finance themselves with bank loans. We all know how difficult this is at the moment. The word credit crunch can be read in all media. Small and medium-sized enterprises have difficult access to capital, but start-ups also have this. Alternative forms of financing such as crowd funding are therefore of particular importance. In addition to these SMEs and alternatives, rapidly expanding companies with high growth potential also need attractive conditions for capital. Here, the financing system in Europe is not efficient enough. The market for equity financing and borrowing outside the banking system is underdeveloped. Risk and equity capital is particularly important when it comes to financing growth. However, European venture capital funds are relatively small compared to THEIR US competitors. The average European venture capital fund, with a capitalisation of EUR 60 million, is only half the size of a US fund, and around 90% of the investment in Europe backed by risk capital is made in eight Member States. This shows that venture capital markets appear to be underdeveloped in most Member States. If the venture capital market in Europe were as large as in the US, start-ups and the growth companies mentioned above would have had up to EUR 90 billion more in funding during the crisis years 2008 to 2013 – as the Commissioner has already mentioned today. And compared to US companies, European SMEs receive five times less capital market financing and rely on bank loans. Poor innovation is preventing growth and employment and preventing new business models. That is why Europe needs diversified capital markets, a stable financing system. This is the only way to create growth and jobs and to encourage investment.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: – Mr President, I would like to appeal to the European Commissioner present, and I would like to add a written submission to what has been said here today in relation to the banks. This written submission is a petition by hungarian foreign currency creditors, a little more commonly known as swissfrank-authentic, which was submitted to the European Parliament's Committee on Petitions more than six months ago. To this day, the heartless bureaucrats there have ignored it. I ask Commissioner, what do you know about so-called Swiss bank or foreign currency loans? Are you aware that the so-called forintification has not been a solution for the hundreds of thousands of Hungarian families affected? Are you aware that implementations have begun? Hundreds of thousands of Hungarian people could lose their homes because of the crimes committed by the banks. I ask the representative of the Commission of the European Union present what the European Union is doing in this connection, what enforcement can the Hungarian ...  (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain (PPE).
text: – Mr President, dear Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, no one doubts that SMEs are the main driver of growth and, more importantly, job creation in the European Union. No one doubts either that small and medium-sized enterprises have had serious financing problems, especially during the crisis, in some countries like mine, Spain. It is therefore clear that something must be done so that these problems do not occur again in the future. My colleague Gunnar Hukmark said that there is liquidity. There are still funding problems. It is therefore clear that we need to find solutions to this problem, because without funding SMEs will not be able to hire new people; without funding SMEs will not be able to drive new projects, and therefore we will be lasting growth and job creation. I therefore welcome, Vice-President, the initiative of the Capital Markets Union. We don't just have to settle for welcoming this roadmap, but we need to implement it as soon as possible. And a fundamental first step, no doubt, would be to boost securitisation. It is obviously quality, because we cannot repeat the problems of the past, but we do have to solve the problems of the past and the problems of the future, which, I stress, are the lack of funding. So, ladies and gentlemen, let's get to work now. We need European citizens to see the results by always ensuring improved funding for small and medium-sized enterprises, because this will boost growth and job creation.

name: Anneliese Dodds (S&D).
text: – Mr President, there is much within the Commission’s proposal which I believe is to be welcomed. It should be easier for investors to spend money on infrastructure, something my own Group has long championed. Measures to make it easier for businesses to provide information about themselves and for investors to access that information are also positive, and it does make sense to try and simplify the process for issuing shares. But, as many others have said, there are areas where caution is necessary. First, the vast majority of SMEs will continue to be best served by the banking system to provide financing, even with the Capital Markets Union (CMU), so I was encouraged to see the comment from Commissioner Hill, when he spoke to the Brookings Institution, that CMU is not and must not be explained as solely a set of measures that will benefit SMEs. However, in order to truly and sustainably boost growth, far more attention must be paid by the Commission firstly to those EU-funded mechanisms intended to support SMEs becoming investment-ready and, secondly, to the ability and, above all, the willingness of the banking system to finance SMEs. Second, when it comes to the Commission’s proposals on securitisation, safety, transparency and simplicity are all relative terms, given the carnage caused to our European finance markets by contagion from security-fuelled financial problems in the US. The Commission must err on the side of caution here. Third, given that Member States’ attempts to level the tax playing field for debt and equity have sometimes provided new mechanisms for tax avoidance, I will be scrutinising this proposal very carefully. Above all, the Commission should be very wary of those who are using their action plan as an opportunity to push deregulation. Some are desperate to return to what they see as the glory days of the 1990s and early 2000s. Those people have short memories and very little sense of responsibility.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I welcome the proposal on the Capital Markets Union made here in order to provide companies with more equity capital again. But we need to talk about why debt financing is so favoured. First, the cost of equity, as well as the cost of debt, must be deductible. Secondly, credit subsidies through the promotional banks must be stopped. Thirdly, most importantly, the zero weighting of government bonds must be stopped. Government bonds are high-risk bonds, certainly some of them, we know that at the latest today. Fourthly, we urgently need to talk about the uncovered credit money system, because that leads to the low interest rate environment that is also causing the crises. Because of all these loan subsidies, more debt is being made than there are real savings. If we really want to get the economy back on a healthy footing, we need bigger reforms than just the Capital Markets Union.

name: Philippe De Backer (ALDE).
