text: – Mr President, we obviously welcome the package and the roadmap that the Commissioner is presenting here today, but let us make a true union. We are not imposing a single model for the financing of companies or for the possibilities of investors. We are creating diversity. I think it is really important to mention this here. It is also important to mention that this package will require courage on the part of all the European institutions together to challenge the status quo and to take bold steps forward.  Look at how we are financing our economy today: we have a lot of savings, but they are not being channelled into the real economy; we have the potential of fast-growing companies, but they cannot find the risk capital that they need to grow fast like their American colleagues. And there is an elephant in the room: it is the national barriers – the double taxation of investment funds, insolvency law and also the regulators who slap on additional regulation and who are creating additional barriers to investment and capital flows in Europe. Therefore, Commissioner, we want to see ambition from your side; we want to see implementation from your side. And then, I think, you will have a lot of support, including from this Parliament, for financing companies and creating growth and jobs in Europe. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under rule 162(8))

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. - I'd like to ask you a simple question. Large international companies operate essentially tax-free in the European Union. The finance ministers decided last time that this would remain a secret, mysterious area. Do you think that capital markets are not covered by these insanely large moving capital ratios, which move through transfers in Europe?

name: Philippe De Backer (ALDE)
text: blue-card answer. – I think it is one of the cornerstones of our European Union and our internal market that there is a free flow of capital, and capital searches for the most productive investment. By removing barriers, all countries will benefit because they will attract a lot more investors including from foreign countries – and especially the smaller companies. The fast-growing companies are the ones which will benefit the most. And of course, multinational companies are also active across our internal market, but this Capital Markets Union is there in order to help them to create a level playing field.

name: Rina Ronja Kari (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President! You can get the feeling that the financial crisis has almost already been forgotten. A false capital market, as the Commission proposes, would mean reviving the worst tricks of speculation and, at the same time, giving new life to the unregulated shadow banks that were the main cause of the 2008 financial crisis. Of course, we must make it easier for SMEs to obtain finance, and we can all agree on this, but the lack of funding is primarily due to the EUROPEAN Union's economic reduction policy, which has created so much poverty and has stifled all growth and demand. If the Commission really wants to help SMEs, then drop the doctrine of reduction. A capital markets union will only benefit investment banks and speculators who make money from other people's misfortune. Society needs investment and tough control over the financial world. We do not need any more financial crises.

name: Othmar Karas (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which The Capital Markets Union is right and important because it strengthens the internal market. The Capital Markets Union is a necessary complement to the growing European credit market. More financing means more potential for growth, employment and investment. We do not want to Americanise the financing opportunities for companies, but we want the European capital market to function with the involvement of the banks. The core task of a European capital market is to finance the real economy, free SMEs from a potential credit crunch, promote entrepreneurship and stimulate investment. It is therefore very important that we define what we mean by Capital Markets Union, because otherwise there are too many who seem to be or are actually afraid. I would just like to give two figures: small and medium-sized enterprises receive five times more financing through the capital market in the United States than in Europe. Secondly, if the market for venture capital in the European Union had expanded as much as in the United States of America, an additional EUR 90 billion would have been made available for investment in Europe over the last five years. I believe that we should not miss this money. Effort is required!

name: Jonás Fernández (S&D).
text: – Mr President, welcome Commissioner. The truth is that my group and myself welcome the presentation of this action plan to bring forward a single capital market in the European Union. I think it's an ambitious proposal, but it should be more so and we should try to put it on the floor very quickly.  In any case, I had three comments on the initiative. The first is based on the difference within the Union between those countries that are in the euro area and those that are not in the euro area. Within this Capital Markets Union, we are debating the need for a Union-wide insolvency law and are also discussing what we can do to discourage the debt of SMEs and small businesses in order to make there more capital in businesses. But it is true that this debate is directly related to the discussion on the creation of a fiscal pillar in the euro area and, therefore, that game between the euro area and the rest of the Union should be more present in the draft.  The second comment is that it is true that we need to approve the regulation of financial markets in the European Union. We need to standardize the products: the securitisations, the set of goods and services of the capital market. But it is true that this standardization cannot lead to a lax or hyperlax regulation that somehow pushes us back to the problems we face in the financial chaos of 2007 and 2008 when the banking sector was poorly regulated. And this issue leads me to the third comment, which is that, if we make regulation for the capital market that is too lax, we can probably suffer some disintermediation of the financial activity of banks , which are currently regulated – to unregulated or underregulated activities and, therefore, instead of increasing the size, rather than increasing the capital tart in circulation in Europe , we could be shifting investment from one place to another and increasing the risks.  And one last comment, I think this initiative is very good, but we also need to improve the Union for households, for consumers, for example, with regard to credit cards, current accounts, commissions. On this issue, the Union still does not have a common market, and we need to address it as well.

name: Peter van Dalen (ECR).
text: – The objectives of the Capital Markets Union are sympathetic. More investment is good for small and medium-sized enterprises and that is the engine of our economy. And also make the European financial system more stable, fine, do. However, I have serious doubts about two resources that the Commission wants to use. Firstly, the Commissioner wants to go to private European pensions. That's a route I don't want. When it comes to pensions, Mr President, the Member States are, as far as I am concerned, on the move. Secondly, securitisations are being revived. I'm very surprised by that. These were the financial products that caused the biggest financial crisis since the Great Depression. So going that route seems to me to be very unwise. We need a strong economy, not a junk economy. Finally, Mr President, the best means of promoting investment are coherent legislation, good legal protection and enforcement and less bureaucracy. I support the Commission on these points.

name: Michael Theurer (ALDE).
text: Mr President, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for his excellent work. The Capital Markets Union wants to remove the barriers that still exist between Member States, especially as regards personal loans. That is also true, because the credit crunch in small and medium-sized enterprises does exist. We believe that, in the context of the Capital Markets Union, the bureaucratic burdens – especially for small and medium-sized banks – should also be re-examined, and what we also need is a different culture in Europe. We need more private capital. We need more risk-taking. Venture capital is less pronounced in Europe than in the USA. That is partly due to regulation, of course. But it is also due to the lack of risk and investment on our citizens. It is actually tragic that stock exchanges have made price gains in recent years, but that the majority of Anglo-Saxon investors have been active here, while our citizens are complaining about low interest rates. So we hope that these points will now be actively adjusted and improved with the Capital Markets Union.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I very much welcome the position that has been outlined by the Commission and I welcome Commissioner Katainen to the House this evening. I also welcome the roadmap that has been established.  There are clear timelines in the roadmap for the Commission and for Parliament, and we need to stick to those timelines, because I think the Capital Markets Union (CMU) is a crucial project in terms of the mandate of this Parliament and indeed of this Commission.  Of course Europe will still depend on its banks for funding to businesses big and small, but over a period of time we need to provoke more non-bank lending, and the way you do that is to have a harmonised approach across the European Union in order to encourage more funds to invest, especially in the equity markets. Since the crisis, we face a huge investment gap. In my own country, private investment is down 20%. That is not going to be filled by the banks. It certainly is not going to be filled by governments, who are already stretched for cash. So we need to find new ways to make sure that that funding gap is bridged. Half of all disposable assets in Europe are held in cash. If we can make sure that some of that saving can be used for productive purposes, people will go back to work and we can ensure that the economic cycle is put in place and is helped. We already have an awful lot of expertise within the European Union, as Gunnar Hökmark said. In my own country, in Dublin, we have a very significant securitisation market and the potential of that is crucially important in terms of encouraging a much wider Capital Markets Union. This is not just about SMEs. Of course SMEs are crucial, but it is also about establishing a financial escalator whereby businesses can grow quickly in Europe. We are losing out to the United States of America, especially when it comes to venture capital. Too many of our businesses are being lost as a consequence of failure to get necessary funding, in terms of making sure that investment pays off. There is great opportunity in this proposal. We need to work on it and we need to keep the timelines clear.

name: Jeppe Kofod (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his presentation today. In light of the financial crisis in Europe, we need at least two things. We need growth and jobs by increasing investment and access to capital, but we also need to ensure financial stability in Europe. The Capital Markets Union can help provide both if it is correctly handled. The financial crisis which continues to affect Europe has its roots, as we all have to remember, in bad, irresponsible financial products and greed in the financial sector. In many countries it has also led to a real estate bubble, and that is something we have to bear in mind. The answer, in terms of preventing future crises also must be found in identifying responsible financial products and in ensuring the systemic surveillance of the whole financial system. I want you to focus on covered bonds: they are secure; they are a cheap and transparent tool for financing loans, for consumers and SMEs and for long-term investments. So I agree with the Commission that is absolutely necessary to initiate a consultation on the issue of covered bonds, and I welcome the process that is now on the way. But I truly fear that the Commission will lack focus and commitment. I therefore ask you, Commissioner: how will the Commission make sure that covered bonds are maintained as a valid choice for financing? Will the Commission ensure that covered bonds are addressed independently when different types of loans are rated for risks? And will the Commission work with this Parliament to ensure that safe and affordable covered bonds are safeguarded with the Capital Markets Union and made available to all Europeans? The consultation must not be a dead end: it has to lead to something important. Commissioner, do you agree that we need real legislation to ensure that the market offers consumers the cheapest and most transparent loans, and that this market could also, of course, include covered bonds? I need to hear what you will do with the covered bonds discussion.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR).
text: – The Capital Markets Union is the right thing to do, especially when it comes to removing barriers to investment. The single common market is always better, after all, the free movement of capital is one of the fundamental pillars of the European Union. The problem is that the Commission is not just trying to remove obstacles in its proposal. The Commission is also entering into processes in which it should definitely not meddle. The processes she should leave on the market. The Commission is trying to manage the market through new regulations, with few regulations at issue, but many, not how well they were meant. If the Commission really wants to help private investment, let it immediately lift Juncker's $315 billion investment package. It is these investments, with the support of public resources, that will crowd out the real ones, the private ones, that we are interested in. However, the Commission would have to understand that it is not really here to regulate everything.

name: Theodor Dumitru Stolojan (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank the European Commission for putting this action plan on the table of the European Parliament, a solid, comprehensive action plan, an action plan to create a single capital market. I would like to draw attention to the fact that the success of this action plan depends on rebuilding trust between savers and those who invest, between those who mediate financially in capital markets, but this confidence, as you know, has been seriously shaken by the financial crisis. And when we talk about trust in the capital market, we are talking about transparency and integrity. And when we talk about transparency and integrity, we are talking about the quality of financial information in the single capital market.  I am glad that the action plan mentions one essential detail, namely that there is in fact no single financial reporting system for small and medium-sized enterprises. I would like this issue to be listed separately in the Annex to the action plan, which contains the list of actions and deadlines for implementation. Why am I asking for this? Because for years we have been discussing the need for this system of financial reporting standards for small and medium-sized enterprises, without having a result so far.

name: Alfred Sant (S&D).
text: – Mr President, we need to develop a better way of mobilising cash for investment on a national and European basis. The USA does this much better than Europe. It is claimed that opening up new ways of mobilising capital on a European scale will bring us closer to the American levels of getting cash to enterprises. But in parallel with this, capital markets need to be promoted on a national basis. Barriers, regulatory and cultural, need to be removed. Many SMEs and many start-ups would prefer to experiment and innovate with investment and expansion at home before they step outside their borders. If they make a success there, a move towards other European markets will be seen as achievable and attainable. Indeed, the cultural factors that define entrepreneurship cannot be ignored. It is necessary to define exactly what makes capital markets in the USA so much more dynamic. However, it would be unwise to implement a Capital Markets Union (CMU) simply by transposing the US model to Europe. The proposals made by the Commission do not go in this direction. Debt to finance investment is much more prevalent in Europe than elsewhere. Clearly we need to encourage a shift towards equity as contrasted to debt-based instruments in financing even small-scale projects. Again, that is best done by starting from a national level. I would in fact urge that, in this context, special attention is paid to promoting the financial organisation of equities to fund non-speculative investments by services and SMEs in peripheral, isolated and island regions of the Union. The Commission is doing the right thing by emphasising the digital sector. Here, a new generation of European innovators and entrepreneurs is emerging. They might be more willing to attempt new ways of meeting financial risks and challenges than their predecessors. In all this, the proposed step-by-step approach is praiseworthy. Too many new procedures and regulations to follow would, in the end, only increase barriers to entry and increase costs. Let us create and promote a common CMU, but let us use a light touch; one that makes a proper distinction between the need for regulation and over-regulation.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The Capital Markets Union is also intended to secure monetary union. Union means following common rules and standing up for each other. In this respect, it is also a kind of community of liability. Commission President Juncker calls for a common deposit guarantee scheme. Systems with high reserves and those with low reserves are thrown into the same pot. In Germany, savings banks and Volksbanken in particular are opposed to this. The reserves are fed up with deposits made by savers. A communitarization of national security systems is therefore a cold expropriation of German savers. The German Federal Government has therefore so far refused to communitarise – but for how long? Anyone who wants to hold together a misconceived monetary union cannot, in the end, escape the immanent logic of communitarisation. At some point, the chancellor will buckle. That is why I say with Hans-Olaf Henkel: Ceterum censeo – incidentally, I believe that the euro divides Europe and sows discord. The euro must be abolished.

name: Γεώργιος Κύρτσος (PPE).
text: Mr President, it is clear that the creation of a capital markets union will help the real economy a lot, we will have lower money costs, more investment, more growth and more jobs. But this is a medium-term plan and there are many difficulties and hesitations that need to be overcome in order to reach the target. Unfortunately, large projects can be cancelled by relatively small-scale failures. I mention, characteristically, that the various funds faced major problems in Europe during the second quarter because of the risk of grexit. Investors became more hesitant and thus limited the placement of funds.  I therefore believe that it is an important investment in the creation of the capital markets union, the immediate response to the problems of the Greek banking system which is unable to finance the real economy. Furthermore, we need to stabilise the Greek capital market which has entered a shrinking phase. These issues, in my view, cannot be dealt with effectively by the Greek government which is attempting a difficult shift, from the radical left, to a more realistic approach to the situation, but must be addressed by the European institutions involved in the management of the ongoing Greek crisis.  The situation in Greece, in terms of the capital market and the banking system, is a systemic instability that needs to be addressed here and now.

name: Arne Gericke (ECR).
text: Mr President, Commissioner Katainen, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done. The Capital Markets Union opens up capital throughout Europe. I agree with that in principle. But I do not want house builders and families, small and medium-sized enterprises and craftsmen or even small banks to be driven into debt far too quickly. Let us create a capital market culture! Let us promote the honourable merchant and real values in the economy. I know that young families who build a house need money. In the past – Angela Merkel was not yet chancellor – there was construction child benefit and home owner's allowance in Germany. A genuine, fraud-free family support. Today, families across Europe usually cannot avoid a loan. They need it, and all the more they need a capital markets union that is based on the interests of the people, not on the ideas of investment bankers. We cannot provide banks with cheap money at 0.05% of the key interest rate. It is not acceptable for bankers not to pay a penny of transaction tax while at the same time charging young families a discount rate of 8% to 12%. This is outrageous. This must be the subject of a Capital Markets Union.

name: Danuta Maria Hübner (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to join with colleagues in welcoming the launch of this long-awaited action plan, in particular the prospect of the variety of tools that this programme might bring about. I would like to raise three points in this context.  First of all, the launch of the call for evidence on the EU regulatory framework for financial services. I think it is an extremely good approach to look for feedback from the stakeholders not only on the cumulative impact of the financial services legislation and the possible gaps but also on how individual pieces of legislation interact. However, I believe that this impact assessment must be continuous and not a one-off exercise, because the Capital Markets Union (CMU) is a long-term project and its architecture will only be fully in place in 2019. Also, many new issues may arise in Level 2 legislation. The second point is related to the fact that the capital markets are transnational and global and therefore, even more so than in the case of banking regulation, particular attention should be paid to European legislation being consistent with the international and global framework and context. Regulation must be suited to a global business and, while reflecting the European specificities where necessary, it should also be compatible with regulation in other jurisdictions.  The third point concerns the fact that I understand that the CMU should be focused on end-savers and companies whose deposits currently do not find their way to the markets, but it should also encourage investors to commit funding to capital markets. This implies that investors must be protected throughout the process of constructively investing funds. In this context I find that an important element is the regime for Central Counterparty Clearing House (CCP) recovery and resolution, and I look forward to seeing this proposal prepared by the Commission soon.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, according to Steve Jobs success is about connecting the dots. I hope that you forgive me by starting off with a quote from an American and not a European entrepreneur, but actually this quote comes from a place where SMEs get about five times more funding from the capital markets than European companies do. The success of the European economy really does depend on connecting the dots between the individual markets and on unleashing the free movement of capital. This is how I personally see the Capital Markets Union (CMU), as the tool that connects the dots between the capital markets of 28 individual states. I would also like to emphasise three points, out of the six proposed immediate actions, that are particularly important in my view. The first is connecting the CMU with the Juncker plan. I am happy to see that support for the Juncker plan is priority number one. Only through the combination of both for Europe can we unlock and diversify financing quickly and as soon as possible. My second point is about connecting achievements and aspirations or, to put it differently, what we have done so far and what we aim at in the future. The call for evidence on the impact of existing reforms is, I believe, also a very important step. It will definitely create an overall regulatory environment that strikes the right balance between managing risk and supporting growth. My last point is connecting and analysing success stories. The Commission has proposed gathering best practices in non-bank SME funding, an exercise that I personally have been endorsing for a long time. That is why I would be curious to receive more information on the process and the timeline of the proposed research: it would be very much appreciated.

name: Markus Pieper (PPE).
text: – Capital Markets Union means facilitating financing for businesses. Simplified prospectus requirements for IPOs, new impulses through securitised loans and solvency, new ideas for venture capital – this will have its positive effects. But securitisation, IPOs, venture capital, that is only one side of the coin of a soundly financed economy. Much depends on the financing via the traditional credit market, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises. Are we really doing enough at this point? In Greece, 67% of all bank loans are rejected, and until there are sustainable reforms, that will not change. A Capital Markets Union without reforms will be fizzled out. What about SME loans in Italy, Austria or Germany? Attempts to increase the risk weighting of SME loans in the Basel criteria are now making it almost fatal. Counterproductive is also what the ECB means by the beautiful name Anna-Kredit – Anna is my daughter's name, but what is happening now is not so nice. With each loan of EUR 25 000, credit institutions are to provide 150 new data sets. This is the opposite of cutting red tape. And now the European Deposit Insurance Scheme: why for institutions that already have hedging systems in the banking network? The sedative pill for Germany, liability alliances only with euro area states, where the deposit guarantee has been proven. Do you know how much confidence we have in these proven deposit guarantee schemes and, unfortunately, in the Relevant Commission reviews? Let us, please, stop with proposals that will remove the funding culture of small credit houses and thereby weaken the financing base of small and medium-sized enterprises. The Capital Markets Union initially includes trust. These include national debt limits, including reform, reliability, and less bureaucracy. Only on this basis can we continue. But anyone who introduces liability alliances in the event of uncertainty and indebtedness is destroying the funding culture where it still works, and that is to the detriment of everyone.

name: Sirpa Pietikäinen (PPE).
text: – Madam President, quite rightly the Capital Markets Union initiative is one of the key initiatives of the Commission at the moment. We all know that we are a very capital-poor region compared with some other regions and very dependent on our innovation and growth and on bank lending. And if we want to grow, and if we want to put our efforts into innovation, we need a common Capital Market Union and much better efforts on raising private assets for investment. There are four points that I would like to raise in this context. Firstly, this is an issue about European fund structure, starting from venture capital to private investors, where we would need better initiatives at European level on the funds and incentives for creating those, plus linking public investments in the longer term, like the European Fund for Strategic Investment and national funds, in terms of fund structure. This is essential because quite often our upper limit of funds is below the lowest level for, for example, major Asian or Chinese investors. The second point that should be further developed from this Capital Markets Union paper is investor protection. If we are not more open – more of a level playing field – on investor protection in Europe, it is difficult to see how we can reach more private equity, especially from private individuals in this field. What that means is understanding and transparency – for example, through information leaflets for whatever type of investors in relation to stranded assets such as the ‘carbon bubble’. Then, last but not least, I would like to raise the need to create a kind of highway for our SMEs and small start-ups, to start raising private capital, with regulation requirements that increase gradually and lead to smooth transition to our exchanges, as nowadays the exchange step is too high for quite a number of our companies. So this is an issue that needs to be thought through more carefully.

name: Markus Ferber (PPE).
text: Madam President, Mr Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. Of course, this Commission started a year ago with the message that one of the key elements for these five years is the integration of capital markets. If I now look at the Commission's action plan, there is not much left of this great promise that we heard here from Jean-Claude Juncker in July 2014. Let me make this very clear: the proposals are very unambitious, they concern only a small area of issues that are addressed within the framework of a capital markets union. On the other hand, important aspects are not addressed at all. Just to address the topic of crowd funding: Maybe something will come sometime next year. How is consumer protection guaranteed here, how are uniform standards being established here? This is already an issue that we should address. Secondly, we are told here that this would be the great instrument for giving small and medium-sized enterprises access to the capital market. We must agree that not every baker around the corner will become a public limited company tomorrow – and he does not have to. But we should be honest with each other. Access to the capital market is an option, but it is not the only one. Instead, we must now use the time to stabilise structures, reduce risks and not pool risks. That is why I say very clearly that all the considerations that now go beyond the action plan, as I have also read in the five-presidents' report, worry me very much, because this is not about reducing risks and thereby bringing stability to the financial markets, but suddenly it is about pooling the risks, anonymising them, raising them to the European level without being able to guarantee them at all. , and thus perpetuate the errors. This, of course, cannot be supported. And that is why I hope that improvements will be made here. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Andreas Schwab (PPE)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr Ferber, I would like to thank Mr Ferber for his work on this I would ask you at one point to clarify your intervention. It is true that the size of the Capital Markets Union has been much smaller than expected. However, one point that worries me is the fact that the European Commission, Mr Juncker, is already making proposals for further integration in areas where the existing legal bases adopted by the European Parliament and the Council have not even been implemented in all the Member States. That is why I would like to ask Mr Ferber: what can we do to ensure that the European Commission ensures that the laws we have adopted are implemented first before new ones are adopted in the same area?

name: Markus Ferber (PPE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Mr Schwab is an experienced Member of Parliament who knows what instruments Parliament has. However, I would just like to remind you that, at the hearing of the Financial Markets Commissioner, Lord Hill, we in the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs dealt with the issue of deposit insurance. There was the clear statement by the Commissioner responsible: there is an existing directive which provides for an inventory analysis in 2019, and that is the basis for further decisions. I assume that Commissioner Hill will also stand by what he promised during the hearing before the European Parliament. Otherwise, we will unpack the whole toolbox at the disposal of the European Parliament in order to teach the Commission here what to do and what it does not have to do.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Firstly, I would like to express my disappointment at how the European Commission's capital market integration plan has really turned out. I don't think it's going well yet. I think that european businesses' access to credit, to enable financing, to higher growth and development, is only on paper so far, and that facilitating the financing conditions for businesses really lags behind our expectations. I would like to call on the European Commission to add in this effort that the administration and the difficulty in enabling European businesses to grow as much as possible, so that we can take an example of how financing good projects works, good businesses with our partners in the US. In this sense, I want to say that the European Commission will have my support, and certainly not just mine.

name: Renato Soru (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we must, of course, welcome this long-awaited project, which has as its main task the reduction of the economy's dependence on the banking system, thus improving the financing capacity of companies and supporting the fundamental objective, which is to restart the economy and create jobs.  I would, however, like to reiterate the need to focus attention on supporting small and medium-sized enterprises, which are the backbone of our economic system, but which all too often remain small precisely because of the lack of the necessary financial support both through debt capital and through risk capital. It is precisely small and medium-sized enterprises that suffer most from access to credit, sometimes from the high cost of credit, and often from the disparities in conditions in national markets.  I therefore hope that the CMU will finally be able to create a level playing field for European companies within the Community and also for the other more advanced economic and financial systems.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr Katainen, you have argued that the capital markets union will encourage investment. I would like to tell you that there will be no investment in the European Union until the debt issue is resolved. A debt that has hit all economies, not just the economies of the South, not only Italy, but even France. France now also has a debt problem, and from what you have heard earlier, Mr Hollande has tried to whisper something about regulating Greek debt which will reach 206% of GDP in 2016, but Mrs Merkel, who is at the helm of 'German Europe', was tacitly cold and meaningful.  Nor are investments going to be made, as long as 'merkelic' austerity continues, as long as we are underconsumption, as long as we are in poverty and from what you have seen, Again Mrs Merkel, despite the protests of the MEPs themselves, remains firm in the policy of austerity. Resolve these issues first and then you will have investments in Europe.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: - Madam President, the Capital Union market is certainly something that, combined with mr Juncker's plans on behalf of the Commission, can make a significant contribution to the atmosphere of good investment. Of course we need, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises and start-ups, new and innovative capital markets, how capital will be available and where our young and small entrepreneurs will have the opportunity to get money more easily. But here, Mr Katainen, I'd like to point out something else. I would like to emphasize the need that both municipalities and cities, i.e. local self-government units, can come up with more affordable and quality funds more easily than they can through bank loans. Municipalities, cities and regions in Europe can participate in transforming our economy and create investments, so I invite you to think carefully about how to include them in this capital markets union.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, today we are discussing the supposed union of capital markets, but the reality is different. These markets are fragmented in such a way that the cost of money is too high to prohibitive, in precisely those economies, in those very Member States of the Union, which have been worst hit by the economic crisis, such as Greece. The result is to remove the prospects of both the recovery of these economies and the reduction of dramatically high levels of unemployment.  In the face of these challenges, the European Commission's plan proposes some individual improvements, without addressing the root of the problem. The starting point must be a truly European deposit guarantee scheme in order to restore the confidence that has been shaken by decisions of institutions of the Union itself, such as the haircut of deposits in Cypriot banks. It is absurd to treat depositors as investors and to be threatened with the notorious bail in.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I am actually very pleased with this development and I think there is great credit due to Commission Vice-President Katainen who has worked very hard since he took over his brief, and no doubt European businesses will experience the positive effect of that in due course.  My colleague Brian Hayes spoke about this very clearly a few moments ago and I think it must be seen in the context of what has been done over the last four or five years in Parliament here with the previous Commissioner Barnier. This is in some respects, if not the final part of the jigsaw, certainly one of the final parts, and it will benefit particularly SMEs and start-ups, which often find it difficult to get finance. We have been dependent on banks for too long, and obviously there is far more venture capital in the USA than here: that is something we need to address.  All those points are mentioned in this proposal and I think it is going to be well received and will have great benefits for our economy and help us, into the future, to grow jobs and have a better quality of life. So thanks to Commissioner and thanks to everybody.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I am last but not least, I hope. Even though free movement of capital was one of the principles on which the EU was built, its capital markets infrastructure is characterised by fragmentation, caused mainly by factors with their origin in national laws, such as insolvency, tax and security laws. As its purpose is to overcome these obstacles, I believe the Capital Markets Union (CMU) has real potential in terms of jobs, growth and financial resilience. Stronger capital markets will unlock more investment from the EU and the rest of the world, and better connect financing to investment projects across the Union. I support the proposed innovative forms of business financing and the harmonisation of accounting standards for small and medium-sized enterprises. European small and medium-sized enterprises’ equal access to finance and thus to capital markets should be one of the leading principles of CMU. Although I welcome the initiatives of the CMU package, several of them could create additional risks for the economy by deregulating the financial sector if they undermine investor protection.

name: Jyrki Katainen
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, let me first thank Members for this excellent debate. I must say that I was positively surprised by the widespread support that the Capital Markets Union (CMU) initiative has received from the various parts of this House. I also recognise and acknowledge that we have to look at the proposals very carefully in order not to create new risks which may destabilise the financial sector in Europe. But I am also quite confident that we have learned a lot from the previous financial crisis, not only here in Europe but also in the USA and elsewhere. For instance, when it comes to securitisation, there were good points made to the effect that we have to be cautious. But I must say that we have been working very closely on this issue with the European Central Bank, with the European banking authorities and with the other central banks in Europe, so I am quite confident that we have managed to find a good balance between making it possible to take more risk while at the same time keeping a close eye on the stability side of things. So the basic idea of securitisation is, as many Members said, is to offer new sources of financing for SMEs and diversify the financial sector in Europe. Banks will play a central role in the CMU in the future. They will remain the main source of funding for small firms and entrepreneurs needing working capital or low-level funding. We are also exploring the possibility for all Member States to authorise credit unions which operate outside the EU framework on capital requirements for banks, in order to alleviate the regulatory burden on small banks. I would like to thank Kay Swinburne for her comment when she said that now we are dealing with the issues which are supposed to change the mind-set in Europe: let the people become the investor. In some of our Member States we have a political culture in which the capital market is seen as the exclusive domain of those who own a lot of capital. But there are other Member States in which the culture is more pragmatic, believing that the capital market is part of the market economy, and that we need a well-functioning capital market in order to finance the real economy with real private and public investment, and thus create new jobs. I was very happy to hear this pragmatic approach so strongly represented in this House today. Ms Hübner raised the issue of impact assessment. This is another example of the very pragmatic approach we have. Looking back, we have created around 40 new regulations for the financial sector in the last few years. It is only human and understandable that there may be some unintended side-effects which do not serve anybody’s interest, and therefore it makes sense to collect evidence from the market and from different stakeholders and look to see if there is something which we did not intend when we created new regulations – and if that is the case, we have to change those things. This is not a general policy to deregulate, not at all, but we just want to make sure that our regulations function as we wanted them to function. The SME side is very strong in our action plan. For instance, the proposals for a pan-European venture capital fund of funds and multi-country funds, and also our aim to revise the European Venture Capital Funds (EuVECA) and Social Entrepreneurship Funds (EuSEF) legislation are very important, because if you compare the average size of venture capital funds in Europe with those in the USA there is a big difference, and this is an unfortunate thing because it tells us directly that the venture capital market is not as well-functioning and developed in Europe as it is in the United States. The average size of a European venture capital fund is 60 million whereas the American peer is 280 million. This basically shows the difference and is the reason why – apart from what we are doing with the European Fund for Strategic Investment (EFSI), i.e. raising the amount of money which is channelled through the EIF to SMEs and start-ups – we want to look at this regulatory side in order to encourage venture capital funds to grow in Europe. Focus will also be put on long-term infrastructure investment, and there one of the first proposals is to adjust Solvency II calibrations for insurance investment in infrastructure and long-term investment funds. This, again, can be one of the quick wins which will release a large amount of capital for productive, concrete infrastructure projects that are desperately needed in Europe. Madam President, many colleagues mentioned something about the level of ambition. I would like to measure our joint level of ambition by how quickly we deliver. As I mentioned before, we managed to decide on the EFSI Regulation in only six months. Now we are dealing with the Solvency II framework proposal and the securitisation proposal, why should we spend more time with these proposals? I know that it does not depend only on this House but also on the political will of the European Council. So I hope that we can put these proposals as high up on our priority list as we put the EFSI a few months ago. Because these proposals create new opportunities, they create new markets, they will release a big amount of capital which already exists there in the market for productive investment. This is the cheapest way to stimulate the economy and that is why I hope that people like Mr Gualtieri, for example, who is Chair of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, will bring all their political weight to bear to deal with these important issues. I know that you understand the value of these proposals and I got the picture that many of our colleagues share our view.

name: President. –
text: The debate is closed.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, I did not wish to interrupt the debate previously so I saved these points of order until the end. I am rising under Rule 11(2) as interpreted in Annex XV of the Rules of Procedure, which is quite clear that the signs that are placed on desks are allowed, and indeed my colleague Mr Batten has a letter from Mr Schulz which confirms this. Earlier, after Mr Hollande left the Chamber, one of the MEPs from across the other side came across here, took signs from the Five Star Movement and from my party, UKIP, took them off the desks and threw them angrily on the floor. I would just ask whether it would be possible for you to look at the video of that, and – even if I understand it may not be something that requires a sanction – at the very least that an apology be requested and that the rules be respected in the future.

name: Puhemies. –
text: According to the rules of procedure, certain signs are permitted and this matter will be clarified.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, the second point along the same lines is that, following that situation, one of the ushers then came round and removed all of the signs from the desks and took them away. That included one that was right in front of me here in my seat, and she came through, took the sign as she had everyone else’s, and also took those of the GUE Group. That is not acceptable either, and I would just ask that, if possible, appropriate training be given. The ushers actually do a very good job in this place usually, but this is our private property which has been taken and we would like it back please.

name: Puhemies. –
text: On this point, just as in the previous case, I would like to say that, according to the rules of procedure, certain signs are allowed and this matter is also clarified. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. In 2008, the world financial system collapsed like a fragile paper castle, creating an unprecedented economic and social crisis. The savers who had entrusted the work of a lifetime to the financial markets found themselves on their hands only waste paper.  The atrocious discovery that, with the complicity of Europe and the financial lobbies, some national budgets have been rigged has confirmed the total lack of transparency in European markets. Liquidity has disappeared, demand has plummeted, businesses, even stronger ones, have gone bankrupt while miraculously surviving ones have relocated. In the face of this scenario, what is Europe doing? Adopt the German recipe, blaming the Member States and punishing them with austerity; it defends and imposes the euro, giving up resolving the crisis naturally through exchange rate flexibility. It abolishes fiscal sovereignty by imposing the ESM. Today, he is discussing a new liberalisation of the financial markets in order to shift citizens' savings into the pockets of those same lobbies for which European Commissioner Hill has worked.  The crisis caused by the uncontrolled expansion of finance and austerity-based care have starved our citizens. Enough of this Europe, where those who decide have not been elected and those elected have no say.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. The Capital Markets Union represents a positive opportunity for the whole of the European Union, and above all it is a challenge for the Italian economic and financial landscape. This is an ambitious project, one of the most important carried out so far by Commissioner Hill.  This text is a natural complement to the European investment plan presented by the Commission; In fact, both are trying to revive European growth from a better investment market in order to stimulate those companies that are most innovative and have a virtuous production cycle. Therefore, this text forms part of the framework of greater financial integration and at the same time tends to strengthen competition in the Union. An attempt is being made to standardise the capital market so that countries where the banking system is now highly blocked can benefit through a more dynamic and widespread model of recovery. In this dimension, however, it is important to remember that the work done to date by legislators on greater protection of depositors and risk reduction within the financial world must not be reduced.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The decision to further liberalise financial flows is another example of the Commission's return to "business as usual" following the emergence of the economic crisis. And with this, the EU sows the seed of a new recession, feeding bubbles and speculation in the face of the development of the real economy. If the banking of the European economy is greater than in the American economy, that is precisely because the EU has so far maintained a certain harmony between the development of finance and its productive economy - a harmony that is broken with the new proposal. It is fallacious to say that credit shortages can be filled with the emergence of new funds, as these are only a vehicle for pre-existing savings and only increase the complexity and opacity of financial transactions. On the contrary, the banking sector must be reformed, strengthening its public and industrial pillars and avoiding its excessive concentration, while increasing public spending and wages to reduce economic volatility and pull Europe out of recession.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. The recent crisis that began in 2008 has made it necessary to have a series of stricter regulations to protect citizens and savers. This crisis has also shown, however, that the special shape of the European credit market suffers from a severe imbalance in favour of traditional banks, which provide most of the outstanding credit. When they entered a liquidity crisis, on the one hand, and were subject to more stringent regulation, on the other, it was first and for all the real economy and, specifically, small and medium-sized enterprises and individual citizens that suffered.  Now that the recovery is beginning to show tangible signs, the Commission felt it necessary to support it with a greater flow of liquidity into the system, which means first of all diversifying the types of credit, reducing the role of banks, but above all breaking down national borders, resulting in a real single capital market. This is a decision that we cannot fail to welcome positively, inso far as the productive fabric, young people and families can really benefit from it. We are, however, waiting for reassurances regarding some key issues in this project, first of all the consequent increase in the risk of contagion.

name: Puhemies. –
text: The next item is the report by Antonio Tajan, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on the proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on payment services in the internal market, Directives 2002/65/EC, 2013/36/EU and 2009/110/EC and repealing Directive 2007/64/EC (COM(2013)0547 – C7-0230/2013 – 2013/0264(COD)) (A8-0266/2015).

name: Antonio Tajani
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Vice-President of the Commission, tomorrow we will approve the compromise text on the new directive on payment services in the internal market.  This directive is in addition to the regulation on interchange fees for which Mrs Zalba was rapporteur and complements the package of legislative proposals on the European payments market presented by Commissioner Barnier during the last parliamentary term, a package that I also shared and supported in my previous capacity as Vice-President of the European Commission. The final compromise received the support of all the political groups and was adopted unanimously in the ECON Committee. I would therefore like to thank the European Parliament's negotiating team which, under the leadership of President Ferber, achieved excellent results during the difficult negotiations with the Council. I would also like to thank all the shadow rapporteurs who have actively contributed to the drafting of a good legislative text.  In Europe, the retail payments market is dynamic and has been much revamped compared to recent years. 34% of European citizens now make almost exclusively online purchases and more than 50% own a smartphone that guarantees them access to the world of mobile payments. For some sectors of the economy, such as the travel industry, most sales now take place only via the Internet.  The measure we are about to approve will rule on payment services via the Internet, that is, those services that I intervene in the relationship between merchant and buyer's bank, allowing payments to be made without a credit card. The new rules will also govern the activities of current account information services. These services provide you with aggregated online information about one or more accounts used to make payments. It is a service that allows small businesses and craftsmen in particular to have an overview of their financial situation at any time.  The final agreement will also make it possible to reduce the risk of fraud. All payment service providers will be obliged to adopt secure, authenticated or encrypted communications technologies, which will be regularly evaluated and updated by the European Banking Authority. The main beneficiaries of the new directive, however, will be consumers, who will be able to benefit from reduced costs and greater legal protection.  Furthermore, thanks to the amendments proposed by the European Parliament and adopted, consumers will have a number of advantages: firstly, they will receive free information on transactions carried out; second will be entitled to an unconditional refund in the case of fraud and unauthorized payments. In addition, with this directive we are solving the problems that citizens and businesses encounter every day when making payments online or via mobile device.  Let us also open up the market to new operators and reduce the costs of an overly fragmented and expensive system, the total cost of which today amounts to around EUR 130 billion per year. The new directive that Parliament will finally approve tomorrow will strengthen the competitiveness of the European payments market, encouraging innovation and security in a sector that is constantly changing. Given the exponential growth of e-commerce, the new rules will give a decisive boost to the development of a single market that is ever closer to the needs of consumers and businesses.

name: Jyrki Katainen
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to acknowledge the effort and hard work of Vice-President Tajani in achieving a balanced, fair and forward-looking text that will allow for innovation and greater choice for consumers. I also wish to thank the shadow rapporteurs for their diligent and dedicated work: Olle Ludvigsson, Sophia in ’t Veld, Ashley Fox, Eva Joly, Matt Carthy and Marco Valli. Payments, particularly cross-border internet payments, are essential for our single market. What is happening in the field of payments is a striking illustration of digital revolution. The original Payments Service Directive (PSD I) was adopted in 2007 and has proved to be an enormous success. It has brought real benefits to all stakeholders, especially consumers, with faster payments and clear refund rights, and it provided the legal basis for the Single European Payments Area.  However, financial services have evolved since 2007. When the first PSD was adopted it created an opportunity for banks to provide payment services. These new players developed significantly to the extent that they are often the main innovators on the market. Now our mobile phone, our banking applications or a third-party provider may well be our favourite way of making payments. Digitisation, new players and new processes have brought real benefits to European citizens, but also new risks, notably in terms of security issues that have to be addressed. This is why the revision of the original Payment Services Directive is particularly timely.  What does the second Payment Services Directive (PSD II) bring to the European payments market? Firstly, it allows for further technological developments and new market entrants while increasing security of payments to prevent fraud. Secondly, it introduces enhanced consumer protection, for example in the case of loss or theft of a payment card. Thirdly, taken together with the regulation on interchange fees adopted in May 2015, it reduces costs for both retailers and consumers and contributes to the creation of genuine EU-wide payment markets. New, safer and cheaper services have emerged in the area of internet payments. These services have developed massively in some Member States, overtaking cards for internet payments, and I trust this will rapidly happen elsewhere. Other services known as account information services allow consumers to have a global view of their financial situation and thus help budgeting and financial planning.  The creation of a level playing field for newcomers and incumbents alike will ensure that all actors operate to the same standards under the same authorisation and licensing procedures. This directive represents a major step forward for the payments market in Europe. High security standards will need to be implemented by all payment services providers for electronic payment transactions. At the same time, security should not unnecessarily impair convenience. Some flexibility will be possible, in particular for low-value and low-risk payment situations. It will be the task of the European Banking Authority (EBA) task to prepare draft regulatory technical standards on security and the authentication of customers. The Directorate-General for Financial Stability, Financial Services and Capital Markets Union (DG FISMA) will work with Member States to ensure consistent transposition across the European Union and will hold transposition workshops starting early next year, 2016. I am very satisfied that the main objectives – competition, innovation and the development of the internal market in payments – are fully met in this text. I hope we have a very fruitful discussion, and once more I want to thank this House for the work done under the leadership of Vice-President Tajani.

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain
text: PPE Group. – Madam President, Vice-President Katainen, ladies and gentlemen, as Vice-President Tajani has rightly said, this Directive will complement the work done in the Rules of Procedure, of which I had the honour of being rapporteur. Let me therefore first congratulate the rapporteur, my dear friend Antonio, on the great work done, as well as the shadow rapporteurs. I would also like to thank our former colleague Diogo Feio for his work in the last parliamentary term and, of course, as Vice-President Tajani said, for the work that Commissioner Barnier did. When I started working on the Exchange Fees Regulation, we set ourselves a number of objectives. First, increase transparency throughout the card payment process. Secondly, for European citizens to pay fewer commissions when paying with their credit cards. Third, seeking to increase card payments, which would help fight tax fraud. A fourth objective, without a doubt, was to strengthen the single market. And finally, as Antonio has rightly said, to encourage and promote innovation in a field such as the means of payment, where we are continually seeing innovative new payment formulas. Today we can say that, once this Directive is implemented, supplemented by the Exchange Fees Regulation, these objectives will undoubtedly be met. Therefore, ladies and gentlemen, we can be satisfied.

name: Olle Ludvigsson
text: On the other: And on the S&D Group. Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for I welcome the agreement on the payment services directive that we are going to vote on tomorrow. The negotiations have been tough. I would have preferred a stronger internal market perspective and an even stronger consumer perspective. In terms of the whole, however, the final compromise is really good. I would like to point out three improvements brought about by the new rules. Firstly, competition will be intensified. Different types of bank-independent operators will be able to compete with banks in a fairer and more equitable way.  The so-called third-party operators, which offer payment initiation or account information, shall be included in the regulatory framework under virtually the same conditions as everyone else. It creates security and security for consumers. At the same time, it gives these actors the access they need for the business model to function. Banks should not be able to prevent them from delivering their services.  In addition, bank-independent payment systems should also be given more fair conditions. New information requirements shall ensure that such systems operate more efficiently.  All this will provide a healthier competitive situation in the payment market. This, in turn, will benefit both the consumer and society as a whole.  Secondly, legislation will promote innovation in both technological progress and business models. This will be an important effect of opening up the doors to new entrants.  We are now seeing the digital revolution sweeping the payment market as well. All the evidence suggests that much will happen in the next few years. The updated directive will serve as a solid basis for this development. Lots of consumers will be able to benefit from better payment services. In fact, I think that is excellent. Thirdly, the new rules will also strengthen the role of consumers in other respects. These include, for example, much tighter rules on surcharges, stricter requirements for undertakings in respect of transactions where the final amount is not first known, and reducing the liability of honest consumers in unauthorised transactions. Overall, the conclusion is clear. In a more competitive and innovative market, it will be simpler, cheaper, safer for the consumer to pay. It is clearly a step in the right direction. I would also like to take this opportunity to thank the rapporteur and all the shadow rapporteurs for their excellent cooperation during this process.

name: Stanisław Ożóg
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I believe that the objective of the action, which is to adapt the existing rules to the rapidly changing market for electronic payments, has been achieved. The new directive not only guarantees a regulated legal situation for many emerging forms of payment, enhances the security of the consumer who makes these payments, but above all regulates in many cases the situation of adequate competition on the payment markets, offering all operators on the market a level playing field. I particularly appreciate the fact that, in the work on this text, Parliament and the Council have tried to be careful to introduce legislation that is technologically neutral.

name: Cora van Nieuwenhuizen
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Perhaps some in this Chamber have experienced it. I recently wanted to make a purchase with a Dutch credit card on a website from another Member State and that payment was refused because I did not use a credit card from the country of that website. Not only when purchasing products, but also with online paid services this still happens far too often and that is of course terribly irritating. So I am hopeful that, partly on the basis of Article 64 of this payment services directive, these infuriating things will become a thing of the past.  The Payment Services Directive should improve access to payment services and reduce costs and risks for consumers. This fits perfectly with the objectives of the digital internal market for which the Commission will shortly come forward with proposals. I am therefore surprised that, within the whole story of the digital single market, there is not one reference in the initiative report to the payment services. I think it is very good that we also have special attention in this aspect in this digital internal market, and I call on all colleagues to look at it with vigour. I would like to end with the compliments to Mr Tajani and all the shadow rapporteurs for this excellent work.

name: Matt Carthy
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, just to record my thanks also to the rapporteur and his team for what was a very tedious and sometimes very technical set of trilogue meetings. This Payment Services Directive creates, in my view, some positive prospects, particularly for small and medium and budding start-up enterprises, by opening up the bank industry to third-party providers. Not only does this opening create possibly more employment and business opportunities but, very importantly, it allows for more consumer choice. Unsurprisingly, the European Banking Federation has vigorously opposed this directive, and their concerns have been couched under data protection or security fears. But in fact, to me, these issues are for the most part not only unfounded but are actually a ruse to deflect attention from the fact that vested financial interests do not wish to see their current dominant position put in jeopardy. The impact of the Payment Services Directive (PSD 2) when it becomes law will inevitably lead to increased competition for existing banks: the chance of collaboration for third-party providers on the creation of app stores, for example, leading to increased loyalty between collaborators and consumers and also, in some cases, to banks being cut out of the payment loop. Crucially, the regulation seeks to strengthen consumer protection and regulate operators who previously functioned with no regulatory or supervisory framework at all, so to speak. All players will now be forced to comply with financial regulation, which is crucial for any economic activity. I will be supporting this directive tomorrow.

name: Eva Joly
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Tajani, and the shadow rapporteurs, including Olle Ludvigsson and Sophie in't Veld, for their commitment to the issue.  The negotiating team seriously defended the good compromise that had been reached in the previous Parliament. Tomorrow, Parliament will be able to approve a text that advances consumer rights. By aligning itself with the Data Protection Directive, it will ensure greater protection of personal data. By framing the use of new means of payment and banning overcharging, the text will reduce the indecent annuities of some market players.  It is a pity, however, that the Council has still focused on defending a few exceptions which will reduce the scope of the new directive.

name: Marco Valli
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the aim of the revision of this 2002 directive on payment services is to increase competition and efficiency in the area of payments, ensuring fair conditions for consumer protection.  I therefore welcome the work that has been done by President Tajani, but unfortunately we were unable to follow it during the last parliamentary term, because we were unable to participate in the initial amending process, because of course we were not yet represented in this Parliament. However, we welcomed the text voted on by Parliament and its content and followed closely the trialogues that were made under the Latvian Presidency.  On the one hand, a number of steps have certainly been taken, both through the inclusion of additional payment service providers such as credit cards in the directive and in the area of access to information, providing for fraud and abuse. On the other hand, the negotiating team, in order to close, had to accept a few small watered-down compromises on certain points: an exemption for the telecommunications sector requested by the Council provided that the value of each individual operation does not exceed EUR 50, more than EUR 100 per month; the right of withdrawal for the consumer is free of charge and guaranteed only after six months, whereas Parliament would have liked it free of charge all the time; an increase in the threshold from EUR 1 million to EUR 3 million in annual transactions, such as the clause necessary to derogate from the provisions of the directive, thus increasing the number of suppliers eligible for exemption.  I am pleased, however, because I have to say that this Tajani has done a good job during the negotiations and so, compared to other negotiations, I have certainly seen good negotiation on the part of Parliament and therefore tomorrow we will see as a delegation whether to vote for or at most to abstain.

name: Markus Ferber (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Antonio, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work he has said. We wanted to find a balance in the negotiations that I thankfully led in the trialogue, that the new technological possibilities can be introduced, that we have a secure legal framework, that we guarantee optimal consumer protection, optimal data protection, but also that we also allow Internet providers to develop in the market and that banks are no longer able to develop in the market. to block such payment services and payment triggers. If I may summarise this with this heading, we have achieved great success together in ensuring that we have a single legal framework in Europe that makes these technical possibilities possible, but at the same time ensures consumer protection and data protection. And we have ensured that the supervisory authorities also have appropriate access to ensure that the rules of the game are respected. I think that is part of it and that it must be mentioned. Banks – and rightly so – are no longer allowed to automatically block payment requests, as they have done in the past, because the old Payment Services Directive dates back to a time when smartphones did not yet exist and at that time there was no need to work with this challenge at all. The consumer is only liable in the event of gross negligence. I think it is an important step forward for consumer protection to really be transferred to the levels that are responsible for it. Here, too, we had a gap in the old Payment Services Directive, which was not covered cleanly until now. In other words, we have created an incentive, on the one hand, for start-ups in Europe to be able to deal with the issue of payment services in the broadest sense, but at the same time a legal framework for ensuring that this does not take place on the backs of consumers or at the expense of security. This means that access to account data does not take place. That is why this is a very good compromise that has been reached here. Many thanks to Antonio Tajani! We will vote in favour tomorrow. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Paul Rübig (PPE)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr Ferber has described very well the advantages of the system. I would be particularly interested in what this looks like for small and medium-sized enterprises, because they are, of course, now also being given new opportunities. Could we perhaps find out briefly?

name: Markus Ferber (PPE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Mr Rübig, I would like to thank mr Rübig for his work on this I am, of course, a little overwhelmed to take over the work of the rapporteur or even the Commission. But All I can say is that a derogation is made for start-ups until they have three million sales, so that they can enter the market. I believe that this is the crucial point for young, innovative companies. It will also be interesting for small and medium-sized enterprises to use the Internet as a marketing tool, because payment systems are now also available, where you can rely on the fact that the bills are actually paid across borders. That is why I think there are a number of opportunities that innovative small and medium-sized enterprises can also exploit.

name: Renato Soru (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the rapid technological developments of recent years have certainly made it necessary to revise the rules governing this sector.  And this review also comes at a very opportune time given the emergence of new players in the electronic transaction market, I am thinking of the manufacturers of mobile devices or even the manufacturers of operating systems that now regulate our objects and which threaten to occupy a large part of financial transactions, so it was very important that the conditions were created for the creation and strengthening of a genuine European electronic payment system.  There are increasing opportunities and potential that are beginning to manifest themselves in terms of cost savings, efficiency and practicality of use for users, control of tax behaviors, security in logistics, but also some critical issues for which it has been good to increase the attention threshold, in particular with regard to data processing, transparency and information.  I agree that this is an excellent measure and I therefore congratulate the rapporteurs, the main rapporteur and all the shadow rapporteurs. I would like to remind you that it is currently under discussion in committee and will soon be coming to the House on the digital single market measure. It is clear that there is no Digital Single Market if at the same time there is also no digital payment system and the digital payment system therefore becomes essential that it is consistent and adapted to the high expectations that there are and that we all place in the Digital Single Market.  Europe believes that the Digital Single Market will play an important role in economic growth and job creation.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR).
text: – Every day more and more people make their payments electronically or via smartphone. However, there are 30 million people with visual impairments in the European Union who, despite the existence of modern technologies, cannot make full use of these services. I regret that there is no mention in the present report of the obstacles they face, but especially of measures that would help to eliminate them. I would like to recall that the European Union is a signatory to the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, and it is therefore our duty to remember this group of people and consumers as well. It is our duty to ensure that they, too, have seamless access to modern payment services in the 21st century.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, we are monitoring many of the concerns of economic operators, in particular the lack of transparency regarding the actual costs of payment cards, barriers to entry into the payment market and multilateral interchange fees. Data from the European Central Bank point to a huge disproportion between the costs of these operations and the amounts charged to beneficiaries and consumers. Further studies are therefore needed on the actual costs of electronic payment methods and the lack of transparency in this area. Having said that, it would be desirable for this directive to give every citizen the right to open an account with minimum and free banking services, taking into account the advantages it brings to society at large. Despite the effort of this legislative initiative, we still have a complex legislative product, where we want to move in one direction, but at the same time creating conditions to circumvent the legislation. The non-application of any limit to the fees charged by banks to third party payment service providers is just one example.

name: Theodor Dumitru Stolojan (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the proper functioning of payment services is a foundation of any efficient market, which is why I can only welcome the European Commission's initiative to come up with a new directive that creates a harmonised legal framework, to have an integrated payment services system in the European Union, and of course I thank Mr Tajani, as well as those who have worked on this very good report.  In recent years, the digitisation of savings has multiplied the number of payment service providers, especially those based on the Internet. We need transparency, security, fair competition and efficiency in payment services more than ever. We need the protection of consumers who use these payment services. Payment services are a public good, which is why there is also a need to strengthen the supervisory activity of payment service providers.

name: Emmanuel Maurel (S&D).
text: Madam President, Mr rapporteur, ladies and gentlemen, we are all in favour of the law accompanying technological innovation, accompanying the innovation of uses, such as the new online payment services we are talking about today.  I think we are all collectively pleased that Europe sees the emergence of players in this FinTech sector. But this satisfaction should not lead us to a somewhat blind form of enthusiasm.
