There are a number of policy objectives that we set ourselves: the security of purchases, equality between payment institutions and, of course, data protection, because we are regulators. It is important, as we discuss this directive, to remember that we say yes to innovation, but no to deregulation. That is what should guide our action.  From this point of view, even if it is a draft directive that has been discussed at length, at length, on this specific issue of data protection, the guarantees are not necessarily always sufficient.  We talked about the banks earlier, and I am not going to defend them, but we have legitimately put them on high demands. Payments through banks are more secure and when we do surveys, we notice that consumers, who make an online payment, have more confidence in their bank themselves.  There is another debate. We fought for data security and protection and, moreover, the European Court of Justice itself has finally agreed with us, with its ruling on the Safe Harbor agreement. What I mean, very simply and quickly, is that yes, we have to create definitions and statutes for these new uses but we have to be patient in the face of such transformations. Guarantees should not be erased to accelerate an evolution that still needs to be confirmed.  Therefore, I really think we need to create common rules and stick to them. Innovation, yes! Deregulation, no! (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. – Mr President, I would like to ask you about the time-resistance of our current efforts or achievements. I myself am one of those who think that the authors have done a very nice and really forward-looking work here. At the same time, you also referred to a number of tasks still to be done. By the time we are done with these future tasks, even as you indicate, will the time resistance of all this go away in the light of technological progress?

name: Emmanuel Maurel (S&D)
text: "blue card" answer. This is precisely the difficulty we find ourselves in. Things are moving very, very fast and, as a legislator, we must accompany this development and, at the same time, constantly establish rules, rules of conduct, new standards. So from that point of view, that's what I was saying, there are no rules if there are no guarantees, and in particular on a fundamental point: the guarantee of data protection. In any case, I think - but I am sure you do too - that this is our main objective. There is this conflict that we have to deal with between rapid technological innovations and our slower role as legislators. We have to adapt, but we must always adapt with our objective of ensuring that our fellow citizens, who are also consumers, are protected, and in particular in their fundamental freedoms.

name: Andreas Schwab (PPE).
text: Madam President, Mr Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. I believe that we in this House agree across party lines that thanks are due to the rapporteur, Antonio Tajani, and that we are also satisfied with the content of payment services in the internal market. I very much welcome this because I believe that we have achieved important successes in two places. Firstly, we have created a real level playing field for the new digital payment methods. Nevertheless, this will mean that the universal banking model that has been in place in Europe will continue to come under pressure at this point. And there will be more segmented sectoral bank offers, all of which, of course, will have to work under the same guidelines in the end, under the same security requirements, under the same competitive requirements as the existing providers, so that we can actually maintain a uniform level playing field. Secondly, it is important that we get the right balance between the directive on the Internet, IT security, cyber security, on the one hand, presented by the Commission in 2013, on the one hand, and the directive on payment services, because, of course, in the digital age, we must take special precautions at the interface between payment services and traditional critical infrastructures, including banks and insurance companies. As I myself am rapporteur for the IT Security Directive, I think I can say that the proposals that the requirements of this directive are absolutely exemplary. Finally, of course, I am pleased that consumers will end up with a significant advantage from this Payment Services Directive by protecting their data and, secondly, by being able to trust – as has already been mentioned before – that the services should protect them with a high level of protection and that they will only be liable for gross negligence. This creates an environment for consumers in Europe that strengthens the Internal Market, especially in the digital environment.

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her It is rare for us to discuss a report in which one, two or three hairs would not still be found in the soup. But it's really good. A great deal has been achieved for European consumers. In the future, the regulations will protect them from abuse and fraud in online retail and also protect their wallets. It is gratifying that the amount of abusive payments made with payment instruments has been reduced from EUR 150 to EUR 50. At this point, however, I would also like to draw attention to the consumer-friendly Austrian regulation. It is the case here that, if the consumer is not to blame, there are no costs for him in the event of a loss. Finally, I would like to mention another positive aspect, namely that we have not shaken up rules – such as the eight-week deadline for debiting direct debits – because this is an important right that consumers have known for years, and in this respect congratulations to the rapporteur.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, as has rightly been said, we must thank those who have dealt with this matter and, in particular, the rapporteur, Mr Tajani, for identifying one of the crucial points in terms of consumer protection for small and medium-sized enterprises within the great game of the Digital Agenda on which this Parliament and the Commission are measuring.  We know that the need to create a genuine single market in payments is hampered by a number of technical and legal barriers on which we cannot fail to intervene with the approach that has rightly been identified in the work of amending the payment services directive that we are dealing with today and which will be put to the vote tomorrow.  The costs of this delay are enormous. More than EUR 120 billion has been mentioned per year, which can be removed from a system that normally then charges these costs to the weakest people we mentioned at the beginning and there are many formulae, we have debit cards, mobile telephones, cards also issued by supermarkets. All this to prevent the most expensive way to make payments, namely the use of cash, from being slowly reduced to a minimum. The Commission – we have also discussed this several times in our working groups – has estimated that an electronic transaction costs a few cents, whereas a transaction made through cash payment can cost up to 55 cents a unit.  Well, we are sure that through these innovations the people mentioned will have real, concrete and expected usefulness that we often find ourselves discussing, on one condition, that the operators who will be called upon to deal with these services are placed in real competition and this will allow us to have those three major instruments that are transparency, speed and cost reduction. , which help the three big players who are nicest to us, namely consumers, start-ups and small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D).
text: – Is-servizzi ta' ħlas huma essenzjali u inevitabbli fil-ħajja ta' kuljum iżda minkejja dan, il-qafas leġiżlattiv attwali dwar il-pagamenti għadu fframmentat u għoli ħafna mhux bisħall-konsumaturi iżda wkoll għan-negozji. name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I welcome this report by my friend and colleague Antonio Tajani and I thank him for his good work, in particular in agreeing a text which, judging by comments and speeches from all sides of the House, will be met with approval tomorrow and voted on accordingly. It is important that the single market for payment services is modernised and strengthened, and this will bring significant added benefits in encouraging innovation, increasing competition and improving security. By improving cross-border payments in terms of harmonising a fragmented market for card, online and mobile payments, we can significantly increase the opportunities for SMEs and new entrepreneurial start-up companies to succeed and compete in the single market. This is vital. The proposal will widen consumer choice by ensuring that a payer using an online account has the right to use payment software devices provided by an authorised third party and have transactions executed on their behalf by the provider. It will also remove barriers to entry by reducing costs and moving us closer to a truly single market which we all hope for, and I think this will be a welcome step. I also think it will be wonderful for SMEs who are the drivers of the economy, and I have spoken already this week on the importance of giving indigenous SMEs the best possible chance to reap the benefits of the European market. As has been mentioned already, it will help us on the economic recovery front and particularly in stimulating competition. Where Europe is concerned, we need to emphasise competitiveness so that businesses will want to locate here. Finally, as rapporteur for the Data Protection Regulation for the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, I welcome in particular some key points in this report recognising that the user’s personal data is transmitted through safe channels and that it is shared only with the user’s consent and to the minimum possible extent. This will help to allay the fears of many and will help the whole business to grow. So I think this is a wonderful development. Well done Mr Tajani and everybody involved.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I would like to support this proposal from the European Commission. For me, it fits into other proposals that we have discussed here today or in previous days. Undoubtedly, this is a European order for payment, which aims to facilitate law enforcement in cross-border disputes. Undoubtedly, this is also the previous point concerning capital markets. On this point, I would like to highlight the truly greater security that european consumers will receive. This is, I think, a value worth fighting for and for which I welcome this initiative by the European Commission. Maximum cost reduction ceilings in terms of payments and, in general, the creation of a single type of payment is something that I think we should support regardless of political affiliation. I am in support of this responsibility and I very much welcome this initiative by the European Commission.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Madam President, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr Tajani, on the report on the creation of a Single Payment Area, in which citizens and businesses can make cross-border payments, with the same ease, security and efficiency as they can within their own countries, by paying the same fees.  The proper functioning of the internal market requires a secure payment system in order to support the development of the economy in the Union and to ensure that consumers benefit from transparency in payment services. It is therefore clear that all Member States should ensure that the rules on access to payment services are objective and non-discriminatory and that there is also security in electronic transactions. This will stop barriers between national markets while helping the internal market to create e-commerce. At the same time, however, I would like to point out that the European Union is not entitled to exclude the elderly, but also other portions of consumers from the single market, by imposing the compulsory use of cards and thus leading to a 'unnecessary' society.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, I see this new way of regulating payment in the internal market as strengthening the internal market. I also see it as a great help for medium and small businesses, craftsmen, natural persons. As one big victory for small consumers.  I think it's another important moment – the classic win-win situation where we get the extra security we need so necessary on the market when we talk about online payments where we are still experiencing various scams. We have lower costs, cheaper business, better quality information that we will be able to provide to all those who will use these services.  So congratulations to all those who worked on this document and for sure we will all vote yes tomorrow.

name: Jyrki Katainen
text: vice ordförande för kommissionen. – Fru talman! Först skulle jag vilja tacka alla ledamöter för denna debatt. Det här förslaget är ett bra exempel på saker som EU kan göra i varje dags utmaningar för vanliga människor och företag. Madam President, I have listened very carefully to what Members of Parliament have said here and there seems to be very wide agreement on the necessity to foster innovation and allow competition, while ensuring high levels of consumer protection and safe and secure payment transactions. This text is balanced and fair. I do not want to use too much of your valuable time, but I would just like to say that, because this issue is something that touches many people on the ground and also small and medium-sized enterprises, it would make a lot of sense if Members here who have participated in this work and who understand the value of the proposal can help to publicise this, to ensure that people really understand that there are new opportunities coming, and that this is one of the examples of where we need a more integrated Europe. This is a concrete issue that may sound very technical, and indeed it is quite technical, but its impact on everybody’s lives is not technical: it has a lot of impact. So I want to once more thank Mr Tajani, as rapporteur, and also Mr Ferber for chairing the trilogue on this very important topic.

name: Antonio Tajani
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I agree with Vice-President Katainen's analysis.  Tomorrow we will be give a positive signal to the citizens and entrepreneurs and small and medium-sized craftsmen of the European Union. The European Parliament, thanks to the joint work and strong support of the Commission that has created this initiative, is giving a positive signal. Europe is not the enemy of its citizens, Europe wants to be close to its citizens by trying to solve its problems. It is true that this is a very technical text, but the substance is very political. I therefore believe that it is right to take up Vice-President Katainen's call for this text to be publicized, especially for young people, for future consumers. Mr Rübig asked what the advantages are for small and medium-sized entrepreneurs; Especially for the very small, for the craftsmen, the benefits will be innumerable because the whole philosophy of this directive goes in this direction.  Vice-President Katainen, I remember your strong engagement during your work as Prime Minister in your country, where your work favored small and medium-sized companies. Now we need your strong engagement over the coming months and year.  It is important to control the implementation of this directive in every Member State. Your power and the European Commission's power is very important to us, as is the fact of having your engagement on this. People want your support and they want our support, but it is important that the implementation of this directive is controlled and checked each year.

name: Puhemies. –
text: The debate is closed.  The vote will take place on Thursday, 8 May 2008. Adopted on 10 October 2015.  Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – Without an integrated payments market on the European level, we cannot have a functioning internal market for goods and services, nor a digital single market or a truly competitive EU economy. In the new economic model and the modern European society, an increasing number of citizens prefer to shop online, yet only 1 in 7 completes purchases across borders. This is a consequence of the fragmentation along national lines we see in important areas of the payments market, such as card, internet and mobile payments. The revision of the Payment Services Directive will change that. It will also bolster e-commerce and provide significant advantages for the European consumers, whose interest is at the heart of every piece of legislation we in the EU institutions produce. I therefore welcome the new measures contained in PSD II, such as enhanced legal protection, information on transactions and unconditional refund in case of unauthorised payments and fraud. By creating a competitive level playing field we will provide consumers with greater choice, transparency and security when making retail payments. On the business side, this certainty and stability will allow for competition and innovation, and thus more opportunities for Europeans to reap the benefits of the digital single market.

name: Puhemies. –
text: The next item is the debate – Giovanni La Vian, György Hölvényin, Tibor Szanyi, Nikolay Barekov, the oral question to be answered to the Council by Gerben-Jan Gerbrandy, Merja Kyllönen, Benedek Jávor and Piernicola Pedicin, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, on the lessons learned from the beetroot disaster five years after the accident in Hungary (O-000096/2015 - B8-0757/2015) and – Giovanni La Vian, orally drafted by György Hölvényi, Tibor Szanyi, Nikolay Barekov, Gerben-Jan Gerbrandy, Merja Kyllönen, Benedek Jávor and Piernicola Pedicin, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, to the Commission the question to be answered on the lessons learned from the beetroot disaster five years after the accident in Hungary (O-000097/2015 - B8-0758/2015) (2015/2801(RSP)).

name: Giovanni La Via
text: Author. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner Cañete, red sludge is waste from industrial aluminium production, and the red sludge accident in Hungary five years ago is the basis of the oral question in this debate, because it was an environmental disaster of European dimensions and significance.  On 4 October 2010, the rupture of a catchment area in Hungary caused the spillage of about one million cubic meters of high-alkaline red sludge that flooded several villages, killed ten people and injured about 150 others, as well as polluting vast expanses of land, including four sites in the Natura 2000 area.  The accident highlighted the problems of waste disposal in the extractive industry, the shortcomings in inspections and also showed that these problems can lead to sometimes tragic consequences. There are also technical and economic difficulties which local authorities and civil society had to encounter during the clean-up phase.  I believe that many things need to be changed if we really want to prevent such disasters from happening again in the future. Of course, there will always be a risk, but our aim is to improve the efficiency of the extractive industry and significantly lower the possibility that events similar to what happened five years ago in Hungary could happen again.  As far as prevention is concerned, the Member States are called upon to review their authorisations for such industrial sites, in view of the correct classification of waste. Therefore, the directive on waste management and extractive industries must be fully implemented and we call on the Commission to ensure that it is fully implemented.  The Member States also need to strengthen their environmental inspections and monitoring systems, we have already asked the European Commission in 2008 to present a legislative proposal on environmental controls, and so we can only reiterate the same request on this occasion and more strongly, given also what happened since 2008.  Great importance must also be attached to research and development in the field of the prevention and treatment of hazardous waste in order to achieve a complete transition in a short time to new disposal technologies. We also need support from the Commission for some stress tests for mines with large decanting basins. We do not want problems similar to those of the disaster five years ago to arise from these decanting basins.  With regard to disaster mitigation and clean-up, we are still awaiting the publication of the European Commission's report on the implementation of the Environmental Liability Directive due in April 2014. We also believe that the financial instruments are of crucial importance and we therefore call for all possible aspects to be explored, both as regards the ceilings of the financial guarantee instruments already established, as well as for the instruments of compulsory financial guarantee, as well as for the greater concept of European sharing of risks from environmental disasters.  Finally, we must emphasise the role and financial transparency, the importance of civil society and access to justice, all of which deserve attention from the European institutions. In conclusion, Commissioner, only if we all step up our efforts will we have the right to say that we have finally learned our lesson from the red sludge disaster five years after the accident, by putting in place concrete measures to prevent such disasters and eliminate pollution from mining.

name: Nicolas Schmit
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, indeed, five years ago, you just said, a few days after the disaster, Hungary informed the Council of the red mudslides in the west of the country, their effects, the measures taken by the Hungarian authorities to deal with the consequences for man and for the environment.  Shortly after the accident, on 20 December 2010, the Council, in its conclusions on improving environmental policy instruments, called on Member States and the Commission to strengthen the implementation of EU environmental legislation. A considerable body of EU legislation to prevent accidents such as the one in Hungary is in place. It includes legislation on integrated pollution prevention and reduction and waste management in the extractive industry, I think you referred to it. Industrial accidents fall under the Environmental Responsibility Directive. The management and disposal of waste in a Member State is the responsibility of that Member State, and each Member State is responsible for the transposition and implementation of EU legislation, under the control, of course, of the Commission. Specifically, Member States must ensure that the relevant authorities monitor the operation of waste management facilities in the extractive industry. They must also ensure that the necessary measures to prevent contamination of water and soil have been taken and that regular checks are carried out to verify compliance with these measures. It is up to the Commission to ensure that Member States fulfil these obligations to implement EU legislation. It has the power to take legal action against a Member State that is in breach of its obligations. In addition, the Commission has the right of initiative to present new proposals to the Council and the European Parliament, if it believes that further measures at EU level are needed. It goes without saying that the Council will deal with any proposals with the necessary attention. I am sure the Commissioner will have an opportunity to speak on that. In particular, it is important to fully implement the existing environmental inspection rules, in close collaboration with the relevant stakeholders. Cooperation projects in the area of environmental inspections, including at the regional level, facilitate the full implementation of EU environmental legislation, particularly on waste. Ladies and gentlemen, the precautionary principle and the polluter pays principle, as well as the obligation to repair the damage done to the environment, are now part of the fundamental principles of international environmental law, on the one hand, and the acquis of the European Union on the other. Indeed, they were enshrined in the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. In the specific case of the 2010 disaster in Hungary, I draw your attention to the fact that, in according the polluter-pay principle, the company responsible for the disaster has been subject to heavy penalties.

name: Miguel Arias Cañete
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, as Mr La Via has stated, the red mud accident which happened on 4 October 2010 in Ajka had a very serious impact: 10 people died and more than 150 were injured; 400 houses were flooded, 40 square kilometres of land were affected. About one million cubic metres of red mud flowed downstream, causing the greatest environmental disaster in the history of Hungary. Relief and rehabilitation expenditure amounted to 35 billion Hungarian forints – that is to say about EUR 115 million. Today, five years later, the main lesson to be drawn is that, in order to prevent this kind of disaster, two conditions have to be met. First, we need to have good legislation in place. Secondly, the legislation then has to be fully and effectively implemented. And, of course, it is also important to keep legislation under review, to update it and to make sure it is fit to address new challenges. Although nobody can guarantee that other accidents will never happen, we are today in a better situation than five years ago, thanks to the improvements in our legislation. There is, indeed, a large and solid body of EU legislation applying to extractive activities, which includes measuring industrial emissions, preventing major accidents and managing extractive waste, as well as protecting water and natural resources. The Commission keeps the implementation of the legislation under close scrutiny and has proposed measures to update and enhance it. Since the red mud accident took place a number of legal changes have been adopted to reinforce the mechanisms available to address hazards and accidents in extractive industries. Today, the Industrial Emissions Directive and the Directive on control of major-accident hazards involving dangerous substances set out requirements on industrial inspections that are more stringent than those applicable at the time of the accident. They also include more detailed obligations to inform the public and to enable it to participate in relevant planning procedures. This will result in safer installations and will increase awareness and make for better preparedness. The Commission has been working with Member States to ensure the effective implementation of these new inspection requirements. The Commission is also cooperating with IMPEL, the network of European Environmental Inspectorates, to promote best practice in the conduct of inspections. The Commission has recently also considered the feasibility of an industrial risk-reducing facility or fund in the framework of the Environmental Liability Directive to deal with the environmental consequences of major accidents. An assessment of this option has been carried out with a high level of participation by stakeholders. In the opinion of the Commission, the results do not provide sufficient grounds to propose a new financial mechanism. However, the Commission wishes to underline that, although the Environmental Liability Directive in its current form does not impose mandatory financial security schemes at European Union level to cover for damage due to industrial accidents, it allows Member States to do so and obliges them to develop financial security instruments and markets. Extractive waste is one of the larger waste streams in the European Union. The transition towards a circular economy should therefore bring about significant improvements. Increasing the efficiency of extraction processes will help reduce waste generation and associated pollution. More efficient techniques will allow the remining and processing of quarrying waste. More efficient waste-recovery systems will reduce the pressures on our natural capital. We can reduce our dependence on extractive materials through urban mining – recovering valuable materials from the products we no longer need, for example by getting the gold from used mobile phones. Hungary was also devastated by the Baia Mare disaster of 2000 when cyanide used in gold mining in Romania leaked into the Danube River. If we can get more gold from used electronic equipment, we can use less cyanide. The revised Directive on Waste Electrical and Electronic Equipment will ensure that Member States collect 85% of such waste, increasing the potential supply of gold from recycling. Finally, the Commission is using Horizon 2020 funding to boost research and innovation, to develop clean and sustainable production of primary and secondary raw materials, to reduce waste generation and to develop environmentally-friendly technologies that prevent hazardous waste generation. In our 2014-2015 work programme we specifically allocated more than EUR 150 million to a focus area on waste: a resource to recycle, reduce and recover raw materials.

name: György Hölvényi
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, I thank the Commissioner, President La Via, for his thoughts and commemorations, and as a former resident of the area, I would like to recall very briefly the red sludge disaster that spilled from mal zrt.'s reservoir near Ajka exactly five years ago, on 4 October 2010, which flooded three municipalities: Kolontár, Devecser and Somlóvásárhely. As a result of the disaster, as mentioned here, it is fitting to remember that ten people have died, more than 200 have been injured and hundreds of houses have become uninhabitable. The unprecedented devastation has forced exemplary spite. In an extraordinary situation, Hungary simply stood up as a human being. The strong and professional action of the authorities has earned widespread international recognition. The standing of civilians has become a symbol of deep-seated solidarity in Hungarian society to this day. Kolontár, Devecser and Somlóvásárhely are symbols of cooperation. It is of the utmost importance to me that the decision on the lessons learnt from the disaster mentions all this.  Ladies and gentlemen, I am pleased that, with multiparty agreement in the Committee on the Environment, we have succeeded in adopting a draft that, in addition to sober consideration of the causes of industrial accidents, will also set out future tasks. For me, the real lesson of Kolontár is the failure of the polluter pays principle. Even if EU law provides for liability, without mandatory financial guarantees, the polluter will not be able to compensate for the damage caused by it. It is therefore essential that the European Commission continue to work on the creation of an EU disaster insurance system capable of applying the polluter pays principle even in the event of large industrial disasters. We have the European solution in our hands, and it is time for the Union to do its homework.

name: Tibor Szanyi
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, when we talk about this disaster, I think the first few thoughts should be about the population involved in the accident and thinking about the victims and their relatives. There is no doubt that this disaster has wreaked incredible havoc on one of the most beautiful areas of Hungary, defining the fate of this whole region for a very long time, including that of the surviving families. What we have done, and there have been many contributors to this report, I believe that everyone has done their job with sufficient self-control, and in that sense we have indeed managed to put our eyes on a slightly wider focus than just a single disaster, and perhaps it is true that we have managed to learn some lessons from what has happened. For me, there are two very important lessons: one, as Mr Hölöli said, is the application of the polluter pays principle. Indeed, this is yet another long-term task before we are able to develop at European level a safeguards system that can cope with any disaster on the territory of the Union. However, let us not forget that in this case, too, the Hungarian authorities saw this facility as perfectly fine a few days before the accident, and released the relevant documents. In other language, when there is control, it comes with responsibility, and that is a very, very important part of it.  The other very important lesson that I think is worth talking about here is that, yes, the whole country is moving at this time of year. That was a very nice example. Private people, institutions, corporations, companies, everyone was trying to help people in trouble somewhere. At the same time, the assistance that had otherwise been collected on the roads cared for by the State was no longer so clear in the matter of accounting, and it was not possible to see where the contribution of whom would go. I believe that these are extremely important lessons that should be heeded by all of us.

name: Gerben-Jan Gerbrandy
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – As far as I am concerned, man distinguishes himself from the other species on this planet by the ability to learn from his mistakes. The fact that we as human beings would not hit the same stone twice is also the essence of today's commemoration. Of course, we must reflect on the disaster of five years ago and its major consequences. I hope that we will learn from it, even after five years.  When I look at paragraph 4 of our resolution, in which we highlight the causes of this disaster, I would like to draw two things from it. That is, first of all, the poor implementation, especially at Member State level, of European legislation and, secondly, very poor inspection or even the lack of proper inspection. I have to say that, a day after the debate on the Volkswagen fraud, this is a very cynical observation, because here too we come to the same conclusion: extremely poor implementation of legislation by the Member States and the lack of inspection.  Since the previous speakers have already put so much emphasis on the 'polluter pays' principle, I would like to emphasise paragraph 17 in which we are talking about a European Commission bill to achieve environmental inspections at EU level, something we have already agreed on in the seventh environmental action programme. So I would like to call on the Commission to make a real move on this. It cannot be very difficult because there is a proposal on the shelf. Commissioner Potočnik has worked this in the past. It is completely ready, so I think snare around it and send it to the Council and Parliament.

name: Merja Kyllönen
text: On behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, five years have passed since the tragic event and there is still much to be done in dealing with the environmental affairs of mines throughout Europe. There are still shortcomings in the legislation and its application. Even there are complete shortcomings in understanding the current state of the mine waste basins. So it seems that little has been learned from what happened five years ago. It is therefore appropriate to ask both the Council and the Commission what has been and will be done, for example, for the safe treatment of waste water from mines in the coming years. The govs floating in the dam basins of the mines are like a slow-spinning screw that drills a hole in the edge of the dam basins. Accident prevention is the best way to take care of people and the environment and to ensure that accidents such as those that ever happen in Hungary never happen again.

name: Benedek Jávor
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, five years ago, perhaps the worst environmental and industrial disaster Hungary the history of the World War II occurred in Kolontár. Thus, on the five-year anniversary, the most important and first thing to do is to commemorate the 10 victims and the hundreds of injured who suffered this disaster. On the other hand, obviously, our job as politicians is to do everything we can to ensure that such a disaster does not happen again. The lessons learned from the colonial accident are diverse. We have found that eu legislation has been poorly transposed in Hungary, and the incorrect transposition of the Mining Waste Directive has also played a role in the disaster.  There were also serious problems with the implementation of the legislation, as well as the disaster due to the inadequate application of the hazardous waste legislation. And as mentioned, the poor performance of the authorities also played a very important role. The previous Commission prepared a substance for official environmental controls, which has not been found in the maze of the new Commission since. I think that on the five-year anniversary, we rightly expect the Commission to come up with a proposal on environmental controls. At the same time, as many others have said, a very important experience of the colonial catastrophe is that the 'polluter pays' principle cannot be applied effectively in Europe today.  There could be various instruments for this: a system of compulsory environmental liability insurance, the setting up of a common European industrial disaster fund. These need to be examined and the right means must be found to ensure that what happened in Hungary five years ago did not occur, that a damage of 40 billion forints, some 120 million euros, had to be covered by the Hungarian taxpayers, the Hungarian budget, and not a penny was contributed by those who caused the damage. The Commission is expected to make appropriate proposals for the establishment of a system to prevent those who are harming themselves from being held accountable. I ask the Commission not to wait for the next disaster.

name: Piernicola Pedicini
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to say that the terrible environmental disaster of red sludge in Hungary is yet another example for us of shortcomings in European legislation and serious shortcomings in inspections by the institutions.  Yet another example in which the European institutions themselves and the national governments did not listen to the citizens, whom they had desperately denounced, and for once again we had to witness the inability to protect their health. So, at the very least, let us learn from this experience in order to prevent it from happening again and involve the citizens in decisions concerning the management of hazardous waste, citizens who know much more than you think, for example, I am sure that they have understood much better than our Commissioner here who talks to us about the circular economy, but who at the same time also tells us that in order to increase and implement the circular economy we need to increase extractions. If I take a simple citizen, any knowledge of the circular economy is more than the Commissioner who is here. That is not possible, it is not acceptable.

name: József Nagy (PPE).
text: – Madam President, with regard to this resolution, I would like to highlight the disposal of the old unresolved environmental burdens that must be shouldered, otherwise the time bombs are ticking under us. In particular, I welcome the fact that the inaugural EU disaster insurance scheme will also apply to situations arising from old environmental burdens which still pose a threat to society, health and public health and which cannot be established under the current legislation. "Polluter pays" is a very important principle in the prevention of environmental disasters. However, due to unclear ownership structures and the lack of accountable persons, there are still cases where disposal simply cannot be solved.  It is time to create an autonomous instrument within the EU framework that also finances the disposal of old environmental burdens and can serve as a kind of immediate immersion mechanism for the response to ecological disasters. I think this is particularly important because of the existing neglected environmental time bombs in the new Member States of Central and Eastern Europe.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D).
text: " Madam President, every contemporary Hungarian lives deep in this great tragedy. That is why, in the next minute, I would like to highlight something other than the environmental and industrial approach. I am proud of what our Hungary has shown in those days and in the months that followed. I am proud of it because, as in recent months the civilian world has moved and done its job for the government in relation to refugees, it is incredible how many fundraisers, forint donations and other donations have been raised in Hungary. When red sludge swept away lives in and around Kolontár, solidarity, strength and humaneness were revealed. In a country where almost one in six people live in income poverty, more than EUR 2 billion, more than EUR 6.5 million, has been raised from public interest in this country.  It's a nice experience, but there's a negative one too. And this is about how, if you look at exactly how the government has spent the resources that society has put together. Some of it was given to the victims, but a large part of it was rested in a bank account, according to the communication at the time, to take advantage of bank interest. It was then used for so-called Community purposes. I do not deny, and I trust, that many municipalities could indeed benefit from the money put together by members of society in the Community institutions. Well, there are examples where they built a football field with artificial grass for 11 million forints. I'm not sure that we, the members of society who gave, wanted to spend the money on this. All such lessons are important on the basis of long-term considerations. I thank Parliament for addressing this issue and I am proud of the cooperation of Hungarian society.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, in fact the tragedy that struck Kolantár and Devecser five years ago was immense, with deaths, many hundreds of people injured or affected by being without housing and what we saw at the time was a total barrier of silence. In fact, the Hungarian government has done everything it can to conceal the effects of the tragedy. If we knew firsthand what happened was for the families of the victims we brought here to Parliament just a year later.  So don't say it's okay because I'd like to know exactly what standards are applied to this company today. Do not say that the polluter/payer principle is working and that many things have been done, because, frankly, you don't have to go very far. I can invite you to go to my country, to Portugal, to a small locality, to Ribeira da Patanha, to see how a multinational contaminams every day a community that can not survive beyond the land. So no, it's not okay. But above all we have an obligation not only to prevent, but to act and act, it is also to have a European Civil Protection Service that can act at the heights when disasters happen.

name: Davor Škrlec (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, she is 5 years old since the past environmental disaster in Hungary that caused human casualties, uneasy damage and long-lasting consequences in Hungary, but also showed that such disasters operate outside Hungary's borders. What I would like to draw our commissioner's attention to is to ask the Member States for an analysis of what environmental bombs they have within their borders, because here I will cite the example of Croatia having at least one more ecological bomb, also a pool of red mule unsuccessfully repaired, marked by corruption in the town of Obrovac next to the former clay factory. It is a potential ecological bomb that could threaten the Zrmanja River and the Adriatic Sea.  However, when it comes to cross-border influence, in Bosnia and Herzegovina near Mostar, Mr. Commissioner, we have 12 million tons in one pool of red mule that in the event of an accident can pollute the Neretva River and cause long-term pollution in Croatia in the Neretva Valley.  So, it is also worth looking at what is adjacent outside the EU Member States and reacting in a timely manner to avoid disasters such as this one that have occurred in Hungary.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I therefore very much agree with what has been said by my fellow Members this evening.  However, I wanted to highlight a point concerning the involvement of citizens in risk management, so in the planning of risk management measures it is essential that local and regional communities are involved in this activity, just as it is also essential to provide them with the clearest possible information of the dangers present in the territory, which is all too often not done clearly. One of the things that should be strengthened, which is also present in paragraph 14 of the resolution, is the strengthening of inspection activities. Well, we agree, it is absolutely the way to go. I am thinking of Italy, my country, where for these activities, the State Forestry Corps, which is the body prepared for the control and control of the territory, is about to be dismantled and therefore, unfortunately, in the way of what are the good intentions that come from Europe.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D).
text: – Madam President, five years have passed since one of Hungary worst industrial environmental disasters in the history of the Country. It was a disaster in which 10 people were killed, 150 people were injured, 300 houses became uninhabitable and immeasurable residential and environmental damage was caused in Hungary. However, this catastrophe was followed by a series of scandals and corruption cases in the years that followed. The scandalous rescue operation, the injustice of damage assessments, and the missing compensation money further underslested the terrible human tragedies that a series of people had to live in Kolontár and the surrounding area. Even this terrible human tragedy has been used by Viktor Orban's government to carry out corruption cases.  According to a Hungarian investigative portal specialising in the investigation of corruption cases, more than HUF 10 billion of the 38 billion HUF taxpayers' money intended for total damage has been found to have been put in the pockets of pro-government oligarchs and businesses. Most of the money was won by a company, a then oligarch, a pro-government oligarch, which is still the subject of many OLAF investigations today. On the other hand, my fellow Member has already referred to this, with fantastic national cooperation, 2 billion HUF has been raised by the Hungarian population to help with the rescue. Unfortunately, some of this HUF 2 billion has disappeared, and some of it has not been used to repair the damage and not to help the injured, but to invest in visuals. A FIFA-compatible football field was built, a memorial park was built, a nature trail was built and a housing complex was built, but half of its houses were unusable and the victims could not use it.  In other words, in addition to the environmental lessons and the industrial lessons, there is another lesson: unscrupulous politicians can use the terrible tragedies of other people to enrich their own political economic lunar yard. And that's unacceptable, it's impermissible. (The speaker agrees to answer a blue card question under Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Blue card question. "Well, you can say all this, and I would like to say nothing more than a good friend of that area: go there, I will gladly take you and look at those rebuilt villages, look at those areas. And I think the whole thing was completely unworthy of Mr Molnar's voice and his accusations in general. But I'm asking everyone to go over there and see how the restoration was done.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Blue card answer. – Honourable Member, what is unworthy is that the government you support has largely provided this money to its economic lunar yard. You have used the deaths of people, the tragedy of people, to give your oligarchs even more money. Lajos Simicska, whom you know well, you already do not like him, but he used to be your favorite oligarch, he has made over 10 billion forints. Look, the European Union anti-fraud office has now launched a series of proceedings against this company. Last week, the head of the European Union's anti-fraud office also made legal recommendations on these matters. You stole some of this money, and that's a shame.

name: Ulrike Lunacek (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, I was there in Kolontár five years ago, two weeks after the accident happened, and I could talk to people. I saw those who had been hurt, I spoke to those whose families had been killed in the accident. I saw the destroyed houses. And I was back there again, together with Benedek Jávor, last week to see that, yes, some houses have been rebuilt; yes the territory has been cleaned; yes, there is a memorial site; and yes also, it is not mud any more but a dry residue has been put there. But the basic thing has not been changed, neither in Hungary nor at European level, which is the ‘polluter pays’ principle that the European Union has as its basis. None of the people really responsible has been sentenced. There are some court cases but they are not finalised yet – and the fact is that the taxpayer had to pay for it, not the company. The insurance that the company offered was EUR 17 000. That is ridiculous. So what we need from you, Commissioner, is to make sure that inspections are being done, that there is a fund for industrial disasters and that there is obligatory and adequate insurance taken out by companies according to the risk of the production they have. Otherwise prevention will not happen; accountability will not be there; and, again, the taxpayers will have to pay, not the polluters. This has to change.

name: Nathan Gill (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, the 2010 red mud disaster in Hungary was a tragedy for the people affected and for the Hungarian nation, and on behalf of the EFDD Group I would like to express once again our sympathies for those still living with injuries, and our condolences for those who lost loved ones. As is always the case, whilst it would be easy to jump on the regulation bandwagon, we believe that we should be more cautious and objective in our analysis of how this disaster came to be. After any tragedy, the media attention and public outcry places a certain pressure on politicians to be seen to do something, and new regulation is the way that politicians traditionally respond. But introducing new regulation, whilst often the popular short-term solution, is often the most damaging thing that politicians can do for the long-term stability of an industry and the society that it serves. We remain committed to ensuring that every industry is as safe as it can be, but also recognising that risk requires an assessment, and any regulations imposed on an industry need to be measured, and the impact on that industry – indeed, whether it can actually survive the introduction of new regulation – needs to be carefully considered. The Hungarian people were the ones affected by this disaster, and it should be for their elected representatives in their parliament to determine how best to avoid a similar disaster in the future, and not for the unelected Commission to impose its will on an entire industry and an entire people, potentially at the cost of that entire industry and the jobs that it sustains. In this case the medicine will kill the patient.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Mr President, poor implementation of EU laws, deficiencies in inspections and gaps in the relevant EU legislation are issues that, if not addressed effectively, can lead to a situation similar to the one exposed by the red mud disaster in Hungary and in some neighbouring countries that were affected. It seems that even now, Hungary and other Member States with similar mining plants are not correctly implementing EU laws; that legislation needs to be reinforced and properly applied; and that nothing is being learned from the disasters of the past. I therefore strongly support the call for a stronger emphasis on disaster prevention through research and development into the treatment of hazardous waste, and for more stringent environmental inspections. The Commission and the Member States must step up efforts to ensure the proper implementation of the EU legislation governing the extractive waste industry to avoid a repeat of such environmental and human disasters. It is very important to better protect our environment, to fight pollution and to fight climate change. Ultimately, it is only one planet that we have to save.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I will admit that I only came forward after our colleague, Mr Ujhelyi, spoke here. For me, it is always important to talk about a problem from a European point of view, from a European perspective. And when such a debate degenerates into shelling from national positions, I think, it is always a weakening of that European perspective. Yesterday, after all, there was a similar case in the case of Spanish mortgages. I would also like to highlight what I think can be underlined and highlighted in this activity.  One of those circumstances is the sense of cooperation between the Hungarian people, their level of solidarity. These are, I think, values that, as a lesson and the impact of the whole activity, can be highlighted. That is why I myself would prefer the Hungarian Government to be more accommodating to the demand for European solidarity in the context of the refugee crisis.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the importance of proper treatment of hazardous waste, as Hungary has sadly witnessed, is unquestionable. I believe that the solution for the treatment of the majority of these pollutants is to include them in the circular economy, so that their value pays for their treatment and that this step is accompanied by a particularly efficient inspection.  However, in some Countries of the European Union, law enforcement forces related to environmental implementation are still struggling with a lack of human resources, technological resources and specific skills. This is another result of the concentration of economic efforts in the States on banking and financial matters. What is the point of having an excellent gross domestic product if the environment is not properly managed? The European Union needs to ask each Member State for information on the implementation of the funds in industrial environmental surveillance. From the analysis of this use should result in public reports escortinable by citizens in general.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, on the occasion of the five years since the enormous environmental disaster suffered by the Danube, I would like to take this opportunity to inform you of the contamination of many Greek rivers, mainly by industrial and urban sewage. Strymonas, Nestos, Axios, Loudias, French, Pinias, Aliakmon and, above all, Asopos are all rivers that face, each to a different degree, pollution problems. The problems are acute in Aliakmon and Pinies, in the wider region of Asopos, but the situation is dramatic and the problem is chronic. Measurements in the area indicate the presence of heavy metals and hexavalent chromium that are hazardous to public health.  Local authorities and, above all, residents have been fighting this environmental crime for years. This Saturday, October 10th, they are carrying out another mobilisation on the issue. I support their mobilisation and call on the Greek Government to take, here and now, all the necessary measures to stop environmental crime in Asopos, but also in the other rivers of Greece, otherwise it will, like previous governments, bear criminal responsibilities in this regard.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI).
text: – Mr President, I would like to mention a reason that has not yet been mentioned in relation to the red sludge disaster. It's a social cause. In the early 1990s, privatization took place in Hungary, huge public assets were placed in private hands, in the hands of people who, like the people of the old system, were in the right place at the right time. This layer is characterised by a chase for profit, irresponsibility and, of course, environmental regulations. The other fundamental issue is that, five years after the disaster, no first-degree verdict has been reached in the criminal case. So, there's no personnel responsible. What example does this set for other owners when they see that the behaviour that causes the most inappropriate catastrophe does not come with punishment?

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: – Mr President, continuing to raise the question of what needs to be answered in criminal proceedings. Firstly, what were the rules governing the workflow or storage? Has anyone broken these rules, if so, who? Did you break the rule knowing and intentionally breaking it, or by not knowing the applicable rule for some reason? If you knew the rule and broke it, did you foresee the possible consequences of your conduct and perhaps trust them lightly, or did you not foresee it because you failed to pay the attention and care you could expect? Relatives of the victims who died also have the right to answers to these questions. The injured have the right to receive answers to these questions, and so does hungarian society as a whole.

name: Miguel Arias Cañete
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I want to thank all the participants in this debate for the very constructive declarations. First of all, I will refer to a question from Mr Gerbrandy, Mr Jávor and Mr Frunzulică, which is the question of implementation of directives. The Commission is monitoring the implementation of the Directive on the Management of Extractive Waste – mainly on the basis of reported information submitted by Member States referring almost exclusively to legal adaptation processes, but the Commission services are exploring additional ways to obtain a more integrated and broader picture of the implementation of the directive on the ground. And, when needed, the Commission has launched legal proceedings to address identified shortcomings in the transposition or implementation of this legislation. Legal proceedings on extractive waste have been opened for Hungary, for instance, as well as for Denmark, Italy, Poland, Portugal, Romania and Spain, inter alia. The Commission is also in the process of identifying the main areas where further action may be required. As a first step, based on reporting from Member States, the Commission plans to submit a report on implementation of the directive to the European Parliament and the Council at the beginning of 2016. As a further step, the Commission will carry out a more in-depth assessment of the level of implementation of relevant provisions of the directive. All this information will allow the Commission to identify implementation gaps and best practices and take additional action to promote compliance with the objectives of the directive. As regards inspection issues, while acknowledging that enforcement and inspections remain key issues in the hands of the Member States, the Commission is currently considering the follow-up to be given in this respect and in the wider context of compliance assurance, as set out by the Seventh Environmental Action Programme. Specifically in answer to Ms Kyllönen on the question of legislation on hazardous waste, the European Waste List has recently been modified to ensure, inter alia, that red mud is assessed for hazardous properties. When classified by the Member States as hazardous waste it would be subject to strict control requirements, provided for in the Waste Framework Directive, for its management, labelling and transport.

name: Presidente. –
text: I have received one motion for a resolution1 pursuant to Rule 128(5) of the Rules of Procedure. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, October 8, 2015. ____________ 1 See Minutes.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on doubling the capacity of the Nord Stream gas pipeline and its consequences for the Energy Union and security of supply (2015/2880(SDR)).

name: Nicolas Schmit
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the issues of security of energy supply and the need for closer cooperation in this area, both internally and with our partners, have emerged at the top of the Union's political agenda. Energy is, in fact, a geostrategic sector and security of supply is a major issue for the European Union. In this regard, many measures have already been taken in the past. I would like, among other things, to mention the implementation of the third package on the internal market, the renewable energy and energy efficiency directives, which strengthen our independence, the Commission's communication to the European Parliament and the Council on the European Energy Security Strategy, cooperation with neighbouring countries within the energy community. At the end of 2014, the Energy Union was launched. The Presidency considers this to be a major step, a qualitative leap in the development of European energy policy and in strengthening security of supply. This Union has five dimensions of equal importance: security of supply, a fully integrated internal energy market, energy efficiency, emissions reduction and, finally, research and innovation.  On this last point, I would like to recall that the Presidency recently organised Energy Technology Week in Luxembourg, which brought together more than 500 experts from the sector, energy ministers and business leaders, including entrepreneurs in the field of renewable energy.  The Energy Union also highlights the strengthening of regional energy cooperation, which will strengthen market integration while achieving savings and creating energy in terms of investment. Furthermore, in the context of the implementation of the Energy Union and, in particular, the strengthening of the security of gas supply, the Council expects the European Commission to present a set of proposals on natural gas supply in 2016.  The Presidency is monitoring the preparatory work, including public consultations on these issues.  With regard to the Nord Stream pipeline extension project more specifically, the Commission has not yet adopted an official position. This is a commercial project between Russian and Western companies. The Presidency is fully aware that this project involves energy, economic, geopolitical and environmental issues. It raises questions, particularly with regard to the project's contribution to the diversification of the EU's roads and energy sources and its impact on other countries. For its part, the Commission, the guardian of the treaties and compliance with EU legislation, is tasked with examining this project in view of the established legal framework and, in particular, the rules relating to the internal market.  The Presidency would like to assure you that this matter is being followed up in the Council. It also continues to advance the implementation of the Energy Union and, in particular, the strengthening of the European Union's security of supply and energy independence, which also includes the development and promotion of renewable energies. Energy and climate - today we have heard a lot of messages about climate - are, in this respect, intimately linked.

name: Miguel Arias Cañete
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members allow me to start by reinforcing a key message: ensuring secure and resilient energy supplies to European citizens and companies is a top priority for the Commission. In the coming months alone we will put forward a review of the Gas Security of Supply Regulation, publish a new comprehensive liquefied natural gas (LNG) and gas storage strategy and propose changes to the intergovernmental agreements (IDAs) in order to make sure that they are in line with European security-of-supply objectives. That is also why we have committed to diversifying our energy sources, suppliers and routes. The goal is simple: putting an end to overdependence on a single supplier or route and giving Member States potential sources of gas, be it pipeline gas from different sources or energy storage. In this regard, we will tap into a rapidly growing energy market which will allow us to more than double our imports from around 40 million m3 to up to 90 million m3 by 2020.  We will invest in doubling our storage and accelerate the work on better interconnections between Member States. We are making good progress in this area. In fact, in the last few months alone we managed to have the first tangible results in regions that are still insufficiently linked within the internal market. Let me give you a few examples. The new High Level Group on Gas Connectivity in Central, Eastern and South-East Europe will increase interconnectors in that region in the post-South-Stream situation. The political agreement in July between Spain, Portugal and France on the development of the MidCat pipeline will increase gas interconnection capacity within the Iberian peninsula and the rest of Europe. We are hopeful that MidCat will be operational by 2020.  Work is also on track for our first delivery of 10 billion m3 per year of gas from Azerbaijan to Europe in 2020 through the Trans-Anatolian and the Trans-Adriatic pipelines. The restructured Baltic Energy Market Interconnection Plan (BEMIP) will be our key instrument for integrating the Baltic countries fully into Europe. We will see that come to fruition this week when the agreement on the gas interconnector between Poland and Lithuania (GIPL) will be signed. That project includes a planned contribution of almost EUR 300 million. I cannot stress how important that work is, because, as it stands, the European Union is still importing most of its gas from Russia, about half of which currently crosses Ukraine –and that brings me on to Nord Stream II. The Commission has taken note of the shareholder’s agreement to build further stretches of the Nord Stream pipeline. The first thing to say is that Nord Stream II remains a commercial project and of course it will be for the commercial party to decide which infrastructure is valuable for them. But let me be clear, as with any other pipeline in the European Union, this pipeline will have to comply fully with European Union law, in particular the Third Energy Package but also environmental, competition and public procurement rules. The Commission will assess it rigorously against the European regulatory framework, and that assessment will be done on its own merits. Transport capacity from Russia is currently at a rate of around only 50%, and that already well exceeds the likely future needs of the European Union in terms of supply. If constructed, according to our estimation, Nord Stream II will further increase the excess transmission capacity from Russia. I want to stress that the Commission actively supports efforts to ensure that Ukraine is and will remain a stable and reliable transit route.  Let finish by underlining the fact that the European Union remains open for Russian gas, and we would like to see Russia as a reliable supplier of natural gas in the future, but we would also like to see that the transport of Russian gas feeds into our diversification strategy and that the Russian supplier, like any other supplier in the European Union, plays to our competition and energy market rules.

name: Jerzy Buzek
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I respect economic freedom, in which companies are guided firstly by the desire for profit and, secondly, by the applicable law. In the case of Nord Stream II, however, I have doubts about both. Firstly, it is difficult to talk about profits, since the already existing infrastructure for the transmission of gas from the east is used only in half, and the location of pipes on the seabed is much more expensive than on land and can also have adverse environmental effects. Secondly, Nord Stream II is contrary to the energy security obligations adopted by all Member States and is part of the abuse of a dominant market position by a single supplier, which is currently being investigated in antitrust proceedings by the European Commission against Gazprom.  In conclusion, this project cannot be regarded as purely commercial, since it brings political tensions known from the construction of Nord Stream I, differentiates EU countries from the point of view of energy security, threatens our neighbourhood partners, divides us, does not unite us, and, in addition, is economically difficult to justify. We expect the European Commission to take all possible steps to stop the creation of Nord Stream II in the event of non-compliance, just as it managed to stop the creation of South Stream.  (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI)
text: Blue card question. – Mr Representative, the Nord stream supplies Germany directly with Russian gas. You also mentioned that the current capacity is half utilized. This means that building another pipeline is four times that. I ask whether it has not occurred to you that Germany, with this unjustified high capacity, is preparing for the end of gas supplies via Ukraine, where appropriate? Is it possible that he's going to do this?

name: Jerzy Buzek (PPE)
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. – Apparently the translation was imprecise. I said something quite different. Our current EU connections to the east are only used in about 50%. Half of the possibilities are in existing connections, so it seems very strange and unjustified to build new connections if we do not use the existing ones. Apparently something has been generated in agreement between us.

name: Flavio Zanonato
text: Mr President, Minister, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, on behalf of the Group of the Party of European People's Party (S&D) concerns the announced intention to double nord stream's capacity. Doing so, as has just been mentioned, would increase dependence on Russian gas and reduce transit routes from Russia to their point of origin in the countries of the European Union. Today there are three: Nord Stream not doubled, Yamal via Belarus, the Ukrainian transit network, and they would become two.  So there is a first problem with the diversification of transit routes. Reducing routes means questioning the already weak balance between Member States in energy supplies. This is a major problem, especially for those who are currently engaged in the construction of europe's most ambitious energy policy governance project, of which security of supply is a key component.  It is also a further serious problem for the Eu ropean Union as a whole, regardless of the exclusive dimension of energy policy, because cutting Ukraine off the gas routes means weakening ukraine's consolidation path and exposing Eastern Europe to heavy Russian influence. The Russian supplier has announced that supplies for the Ukrainian GTS will end in 2020, thus foreshadowing for Kiev the loss of many billions of euros that are paid to it each year in the form of transit tariffs; It is a threat to the economic and social stability of that country, but also to the energy and production resilience of much of Eastern Europe.  I will conclude by saying that the South Stream has practically been sunk by this hypothesis and has sunk with criticism that today also fits perfectly with the Nord Stream.

name: Marek Józef Gróbarczyk
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by A few years ago, during a debate, I asked Commissioner Oettinger why Germany was involved in the construction of the Nord Stream gas pipeline, although in its recommendation the European Parliament strongly opposed this investment. The Commissioner pointed out that, in the light of the regulations at the time, he would never again choose to support this investment. When I asked Commissioner Oettinger again a year ago why Germany had transferred the right to use the OPAL gas pipeline, which is an extension of the Nord Stream gas pipeline, to Gazprom, I received a disarming answer that this is a private initiative and that the German Government has no influence on its implementation. A few weeks ago, I asked you, Commissioner, about the Commission's attitude towards the construction of Nord Stream II in the context of the implementation of the 3rd Energy Package and the Energy Union that I am rapporteur for. The answer was similar to the previous ones, and today you also reiterated that this is a private initiative over which the Commission has no influence.  Nord Stream will supply 110 billion cubic metres of gas per year, which is more than 50% of its imports into the European Union. This completely esched the idea of diversification and security of supply in the light of the requirements of the European Energy Union. It particularly affects the countries of Central and Eastern Europe, which are left alone in the face of the dominance of supplies from the eastern direction.  The current situation provides the basis for member states to revise their climate protection commitments and implement implemented energy policies. Inadvisibility or consent to this investment will result in deepening divisions in the area of security of energy supply. Is the Energy Union and the European Union going in this direction?

name: Morten Helveg Petersen
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, the Nord Stream II project is vital for Europe’s future energy market and for the Third Energy Package and the energy union. Russia will be a key energy partner for the EU for decades to come. We are essentially interdependent and this should inform our deliberations on key infrastructure projects. But Russia and its leading gas exporter, Gazprom, have openly objected to EU efforts to liberalise energy markets and actively sought to undermine the diversification strategy. So we have every reason to bring the utmost scrutiny to bear on their proposals.  As you know, Mr Arias Cañete, Parliament is working on goals and objectives for the future energy union in Europe. I would like to hear your assessment about how the EU might proceed with discussions on Nord Stream II in the light of the European energy union’s guiding principles. For instance, Commissioner, can you tell us how many EU nations will conduct strategic reviews of the future Nord Stream expansion to assess the strategic and geopolitical implications of this project? I believe that most countries merely conduct environmental impact assessments, but these do not capture the broader political implications of critical energy infrastructure projects.  Therefore, I am calling on the Commission to enter into dialogue with the relevant Member States and to tell Parliament how many of them undertake geopolitical assessments of critical infrastructure. I would also like to know how the Commission approaches these questions and to ask it to conduct and publish a Europe-wide strategic and geopolitical study on the implications of an Austrian pipeline, particularly its impact on the European Neighbourhood Policy and the policy towards Ukraine.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, the doubling of the capacity of the Northern Pipeline comes in response to the Union's inability to address substantially the shortcomings concerning its energy security. However, the main problems relating to energy supply exist in the South of Europe and not in the North. Today, many are expressing concerns about the strengthening of the Northern Pipeline.  What really needs to worry the Union, however, is why there are still members who are isolated in the South. Also, that there are Member States in the South that have serious problems with energy efficiency. What should also be of concern is that these developments marginalise the Southern Pipeline and the Commission must realise that it must make more use of domestic energy sources. However, it continues to overlook the role of the recently discovered deposits in Cyprus, as well as the deposits that exist in the Eastern Mediterranean and more broadly in the Mediterranean and North Africa region.  We expect the Union to support energy investment in the Eastern Mediterranean, to promote the creation of a Mediterranean gas hub, with pipelines and the development of LNG production. At the same time, we call for an integrated strategy for the development of renewable energy sources and to ensure affordable prices for consumers. If this is done, no one needs to worry about the development of the Northern Pipeline.

name: Claude Turmes
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, first I want to thank my colleague Reinhard Bütikofer, whose initiative it was to have this debate this evening. Doubling the Nord Stream pipeline capacity between Russia and Germany is a very bad idea. We could even call it a provocation which threatens the unity of the European energy union and the EU’s neighbourhood policy. Russia’s and Gazprom’s strategy is clear: cutting off Ukraine from the energy transport network, with all the geopolitical and economic consequences that implies; hurting the Central and Eastern European countries and their citizens’ economies by making gas deliveries more difficult and more expensive; and creating a more dominant position, thus undermining competition.  This is against the interest of the European energy union, against European solidarity and against our geopolitical interest in Ukraine. I am sure that the majority of this House and the majority of governments wholeheartedly endorse these arguments. But there are important lobbies behind this. Representatives of the French Gaz de France Suez, now called NG, the German BASF Wintershall and the Dutch-British Shell are already hanging around our corridors to lobby us to be soft on it, arguing that it is merely a commercial project. They have very powerful allies: François Hollande and Angela Merkel, who are sitting here this afternoon, and David Cameron. So my question to these three leaders is: where is your coherence on Ukraine policy? Where is your solidarity with our neighbours in Central and Eastern Europe? Do not tell us this is a commercial project. It is a political project. It is a highly explosive, highly divisive, political project.
