Therefore, not only do I want the Commission to take a strong position – and I believe we have the right man sitting here – I also want Council President Tusk to stop hiding away. I am deeply sorry, but if this project does not make it on to the agenda of a forthcoming European Council then we should forget about the European energy union. So I want Ms Merkel, Mr Hollande and Mr Cameron to explain to the other prime ministers why they are hiding away and why they favour this project, which is so divisive and which has to be stopped.

name: Dario Tamburrano
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, many speakers have framed the doubling of Nord Stream as a problem, but let us also try to see it as a symptom of elements of other unresolved issues.  The Eu ropean Union is lagging significantly behind in the energy transition, so it still needs Russian gas, unfortunately. We have pointed this out several times in this institution without being heard. We suffer geopolitical choices that have even stimulated the alteration of very delicate balances, no one would have thought of doubling the Nord Stream if Ukraine had really been helped and if stabilisation had been initiated instead of fomenting colorful revolutions and a new Cold War on our borders.  It is clear that we are suffering from the well-clearly designed lack of a strong political and democratic union with certain hegemonic states which take decisions as they please, easily conditioned by the interests of financial and industrial giants and which do not act in the interests of all the citizens of the Union. Yet the majority of this Parliament still enthusiastically supports the austerity line and the Euro-mark, which have brought the social systems, the citizens and southern European businesses to their knees.  Ladies and gentlemen, this case is much more serious. We're still silent. What about the sanctions imposed on Russia as obligatory in any resolution on this subject? Who pays for the damage to our entrepreneurs in Southern Europe, Greeks and Italians in the first place? Germany perhaps with the future profits of the Nord Stream? And the Ukrainian people have forgotten that?  These are all colleagues that you are well aware of, and so let us try as good doctors of a sick union to act on the causes for the future of the Union itself and the well-being of our electors. We believe that we need not only an energy transition to decarbonisation in order to combine the highest geopolitical security and European sovereignty with the highest environmental climate security, but also a different foreign policy to affirm our path as a power committed to peace, to good proximity to all the nations around us, without being directed by anyone, and we strongly demand that no Member State be primus inter pares for a true community of all Europeans.

name: Nicolas Bay
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, when you want to kill your dog, you accuse it of having rabies, but in this case you are the one who has not stopped barking and biting your hand. Of course, I want to talk about Russia on which we are dependent.  Far be it from me to rejoice, but the observation is there and unanimous. Let me remind you of the final judgment of Jérôme Ferrier, President of the French Gas Association and the International Gas Union. In an interview with Le Figaro, which I have already quoted in this Chamber, published the day after Russia abandoned the South Stream project, Mr Ferrier said, and I quote: "Europe cannot get rid of Russian gas." Like it or not, it is a fact. This is undeniable evidence confirmed in particular by Fatih Birol, the new Executive Director of the International Energy Agency.  But in this whole matter, it must be recognized that it is the Ukrainians, or at least their current leaders, who have been the most enraged. Encouraged by you, the Ukrainian authorities have repeatedly accused Russia of all evils. But, in addition to failing to ensure the safety of the pipeline that runs through their country, with large gas capacities diverted, it must be remembered that, if Gazprom has often closed or threatened to close the floodgates, it is because the Ukrainian Naftogaz is constantly late for payment and does not pay its arrears. After numerous bilateral and trilateral negotiations between the European Union, Ukraine and Russia, the Commission announced in a statement on 25 September that it would pay Ukraine $500 million to source Russian gas this winter. Yes, $500 million! Because the Commission still prefers the dollar to the euro. Definitely, what a waste.  So much the better if Ukrainian households will be able to heat up this winter but, unfortunately for them, Ukrainians do not yet know your horse remedies. They do not realize all the rewards that will result from their rapprochement with the European Union, as it has been done, that is to say in a rag of hatred against Russia, their historical big brother and, indeed, their natural partner. All this could have been avoided for many countries in South-Eastern Europe that could have benefited from the tremendous economic benefits of the South Stream project, namely Bulgaria, Serbia, Hungary but also Italy and Greece.  To make up for this aborted project, the German groups BASF and E.ON, the French ENGIE, the Austrian OMV and the Anglo-Dutch Shell finally signed on 4 September a shareholder pact for the construction of Nord Stream 2. Gazprom will own 51% of the project, with E.ON, Shell, OMV and BASF each taking 10%. The French ENGIE will be associated with 9% of the project. This announcement was made at the Vladivostok Economic Forum and we welcome this project which will double current capacity. So let the Commission not yet come and ruin everything and not seek to defeat this project after forcing Russia to give up the ambitious South Stream. These are long-term contracts, guaranteeing stability. This is what we need more than ever if we are to regain a sustainable climate of peace in Europe, rather than this new cold war that you have initiated. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE)
text: blue-card question. – We heard a speech praising Gazprom as the most reliable supplier of gas to Europe. One might get this idea, but how do you explain the situation in Gazprom? This is probably the most corrupt major company in Europe, with its huge buildings, and owners or management with close ties to Moscow, and some ‘black’ deals made. Finally, how would you explain the fact that Gazprom charges Ukraine more than Germany? Is there anything political in this? Do you see this as purely economic and based on financial issues? How, if you are an economist and you base your thoughts on this, can you explain these higher prices for Ukraine than for Germany?

name: Nicolas Bay (ENF)
text: "blue card" answer to Petras Au-treviius. Your remark is emblematic of the position of hostility in principle towards Russia, which is often expressed in the European Parliament. Until demonstrated otherwise, Gazprom has never been lacking in gas supply. As for the differentiated tariffs you are talking about, they are probably largely explained by Ukraine's repeated and voluntary defaults on Russia and the absolutely considerable arrears of payment that have not been honoured.

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Please kindly acknowledge that it is private companies that are doing this gas pipeline, but it is, please do not make us crazy, that there is no blessing of the government here in Germany and Russia. Such things are not done without governments. Mr Arias Cañete is trying to explain to us that the second strand of Nord Stream is there to increase the diversification of supply. Well please, please don't make us crazy. It has nothing to do with it. Of course, Mr Zoltán Balczó is right. That was a bad translation, Professor Buzek. His point was that the latter thread plus half of the current transmission capacity is in order to possibly pass on the deliveries that are going through Ukraine.  Ladies and about! I want to say one thing. We are dealing with hidden agents of Gazprom everywhere, I suspect also in the European Commission. For example, I have noticed with astonishment that the Greens are fighting coal, atom and slate, that is, with everything gazprom does not provide, and strangely enough the Greens have a lot of money for their various actions. If you join the European Commission, which sees nothing wrong with poland being exposed to... (this Poland also bypasses). Running Nord Stream outside Poland offers opportunities for blackmail against Polish. Gazprom is not doing anything like this for now, but it can and Poland should protect itself from this at any time. In any case, I believe that if the European Commission does not see any threat here, Well, I would have to say that gazprom agents are also sitting in the Commission, if it were not for the fact that perhaps they are simply idiots.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur on her excellent work. The European Union has one major strategic weakness: our huge dependence on imports. It is in the field of energy, directly from one supplier, Russia. Our great weakness.  But we have a solution for this. This solution is called the creation of a European Energy Union, where, one might say, there are three main pillars. The first is to reduce import dependence, the second is to increase competition, and the third would be to diversify sources of supply (import sources).  This Nord Stream II project actually goes completely against the objectives we have set in the Energy Union. He will first increase our import dependence directly on Russia, he will reduce competition, and he will increase the supplier directly, as they say, from the same source– not to the different sources, but again to the same Russia. If we, in addition to this, take the fact that by doubling Nord Stream's capacity, Russia will effectively be able to cut out Ukraine as a transit country - Ukraine, which we, as Europe, are also trying to push economically, and she would lose terrible money, not to mention her energy security, this project should be stopped.  Now, how can i stop? The first is: politically, like the South Stream project was halted, in fact, for political reasons. The second is, also legally. And here we must give the European Commission the opportunity to investigate the content of this agreement, directly by allowing access to company contracts between large strategic companies with energy suppliers from third countries, in this case Gazprom. Thanks for the attention!

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D).
text: – Reducing the European Union's energy dependence on Russia is one of the main objectives of the energy union being created. Therefore, such a long-term agreement between European energy companies and Gazprom on doubling gas supply to the Nord Stream pipeline is clearly at odds with the European Union's energy policy. The agreement unfairly bypasses the central and eastern European Member States, which are still separated from Europe's energy gas and electricity networks. What situation are now being put to the most vulnerable Member States from Russia, which, with their own funds, like Lithuania, have built a liquefied gas terminal in addition to the European Union's financial assistance, with the aim of having at least one energy alternative and reducing the price paid for energy resources? If private companies can make decisions that may even harm the interests of individual Member States, our partners, such as Ukraine, and, consequently, the European Union as a whole, then the question arises as to what all our efforts to strengthen our energy independence, to distance ourselves more from Russia, to invest billions in missing infrastructure, etc. It is scandalous that, so far, we have not been able to ensure that the Commission is compulsorily informed of all energy agreements and to assess their impact. This case, like the Volkswagen scandal, raises serious doubts about the credibility of the Institutions of the European Union, Mr President. Commissioner.

name: Anna Elżbieta Fotyga (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The Northern Gas Pipeline has been and is a tool of Russian pressure on the countries of my region, including Ukraine. It degrades our security, and it's not just energy. On the EU side, it is a violation of the principle of solidarity. I have similar reservations about the newly created Turkish Stream. The duplication of the thesis of the economic nature of both projects is simply succumbing to Russian propaganda and should be of interest to the cells that we are creating and which are intended to counter Russian strategic communication.

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, back in July of this year a group of Members of the European Parliament, including myself, wrote to the Commission to ask it to assess the plans to double the capacities of the Nord Stream. I was rather shocked by the Commissioner’s written answer, I quote: ‘Adding capacity to the Nord Stream pipeline system is first and foremost a commercial decision.’ I call it business as usual, nothing new. Therefore, in addition to the many good opinions expressed by my colleagues, I wish to ask the Commissioner three simple questions.  Firstly, are you still sure, bearing in mind all the geopolitics, that bypassing Ukraine is first and foremost a commercial project? Secondly, do you not think that the expansion of Nord Stream inherently contradicts the EU energy security strategy and EU energy union? And thirdly, how can you see doubling the Nord Stream capacity as being consistent with reducing EU energy dependency on Russia?

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, the development of the so-called Energy Union will represent nothing other than the submission of this strategic and vital sector in modern economies and societies to the interests of the main European powers and their increasingly transnational economic groups, either from the point of view of infrastructure development or from the point of view of ambitious market integration.  The response to large and tiresome issues such as improving energy efficiency, diversifying sources, including the sustainable use of each country's endogenous potential, security of supply or energy isolation of certain Member States, among others, will all be relegated to the background. These are issues which can be properly addressed only in the context of democratic public control over the energy sector.  Energy is a precious public good that must be rescued from the hands of private monopolies in the sector — monopolies for the benefit of which this Energy Union is developing.

name: Indrek Tarand (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner Šefčovič’s initiative to investigate the legal aspect of Nord Stream II is very welcome because it is an open use of energy tools for geopolitical gain, and I would even call it part of a notorious ‘hybrid war’. Whatever the legal niceties invented by corporate lawyers in Russia, Germany and at Royal Dutch Shell, we will give you all our political support, Mr Arias Cañete, to overrun them. However, in order to avoid a possible lose-lose situation, we all know that our legislative triangle – Commission, Parliament and Council – can easily turn into a Bermuda Triangle where good intentions simply disappear. We need Mr Tusk to act and put the issue onto the agenda of a Council meeting. Only then can Frau Merkel and Monsieur Hollande see through the eyes of Robert Fico, Ewa Kopacz, Victor Ponta, Bohuslav Sobotka, Laimdota Straujuma and others and see what a fatal mistake it would be to have Mr Putin and Mr Schröder build this environmentally damaging and economically unviable gas pipeline. I think, Mr Arias Cañete, you were in the oil business. Well, I was in the gas business, as a builder in the Soviet Army of Soviet-German gas pipelines. So I would like to end on an optimistic note. Russian ability to deliver gas is actually a bluff. Gazprom may have a few millions for the National Front in France but that is all – 50% is unused for Nord Stream I. Stop the stupid plan to have another one which is aimed at killing Ukraine first and then the rest of us.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by A key element in building the European Union's energy security should be to reduce Europe's dependence on imports of energy sources, especially from one eastern direction. In such a situation, it is difficult to regard the Nord Stream II gas pipeline as an investment in line, firstly, with the interests of the Community, secondly with the foundations of the European Union and, thirdly, with the European Energy Security Strategy. So we are dealing with a bizarre situation. On the one hand, all the European Union strategy papers stress the need to significantly diversify energy sources and routes, but on the other hand, investment projects are undertaken and accepted, which will make Member States even more dependent on Russia.  The statements of some politicians, who claim that this is a private, commercial project that cannot be interfered with, also seem unequivocally unreliable in this context. It should be borne in mind that, for example, the German State co-owns some of the companies that signed the agreement with Gazprom. It is therefore difficult to believe that German companies have taken action on such strategic long-term issues without the knowledge and without the consent of the Government of the Federal Republic of Germany.  Nord Stream II will bring not only an economic and political threat to the Community, but also direct economic losses for some Member States, for example Polish and Bulgaria, and for associated countries such as Turkey and Ukraine. The latter already estimates its losses at around EUR 2 billion per year and refers to this project as, and I quote, 'a betrayal of the EU's ideas of solidarity'. For these reasons, Mr President, the European Union should have an influence to stop this project.

name: Adam Gierek (S&D).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The Energy Union is, on the one hand, a single market for competitive energy and, on the other hand, the achievement of the European climate target. Energy efficiency is the primary tool for this. Doubling the Northern Gas Pipeline could have a significant impact on the construction of the Energy Union as well as on security of supply.  Looking rationally and forward-looking – apart from political understatement, past disputes and fears from historical experience, which cannot last forever – it must be acknowledged that the construction of the second strand of the Northern Gas Pipeline is the right idea. Converting gas energy into electricity is at least 20% more efficient in physico-chemical terms than converting from coal, whereas CO2 emissions are 40% of that of its combustion. But there is another very important aspect – the high flexibility of electricity production, which works perfectly with wind energy. Gas turbines are an ideal way to be efficient during so-called peak conscripts.  The builders of the first Nord Stream understood this perfectly, they understood the geopolitical superiority of this project. For a new project, however, a Community method supervised by the European Union is necessary. An investment with offseas to EU countries in the Baltic region, which will enable Community exploitation and price fixing. I also consider it appropriate to consider a return to the idea of Yamal II.

name: Anneleen Van Bossuyt (ECR).
text: – The plans to double the North Stream pipeline are diametrically opposed to the targets we have set ourselves for the Energy Union.  The European Union must become less dependent on Russian gas in the coming years, not only by diversifying its suppliers, but also by looking for alternative energy sources. Moreover, the potential capacity today of the North Stream pipeline that already exists is only half used. A doubling of North Stream is therefore rather motivated by Russian geopolitical interests and not by market demand. What are we going to do if Russia turns off the gas tap? What sources are we going to be able to rely on? So that's why I'd like to ask you to take a really critical approach to this deal.

name: Jasenko Selimovic (ALDE).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr It has long been known that Russia has used gas energy to influence different countries and stop their possible turnaround towards the West and the EU. Some examples: in 2007, all supplies of oil products to Estonia were cut off in connection with the statue crisis. When the same country passed a law affecting Estonian Russians, there was a gas stop. When Georgia elected a pro-Western government: price increases. When Ukraine did the same thing: price increases. When the monetary union with Belarus did not happen: price increases. Baltic countries, Armenia, Kyrgyzstan, Transnistria, Georgia have all been subject to price increases. Now it's the Balkans' turn. Russia is in full swing in Bosnia and Serbia, locking up even these countries in dependence on the goal of dancing as the Kremlin wants.  Finally, we know that the planned expansion of Nord Stream will make the situation for Ukraine worse. My question is: how will the Commission ensure that this does not happen in the future? We've seen it yesterday, we see it today. By what means will the Commission ensure that we do not see it even more in the future?

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE).
text: Mr President, what I must stress is that we must all be objective and honest in this Chamber. At the very least, what I have been hearing, from the day I was elected as a Member of the European Parliament, from everyone, from the European Parliament, from the European Commission, from the Commissioner responsible, from everyone, is that the European Union must become energy self-sufficient, self-sufficient, that there should be a lot of energy sources of supply, that the European Union's energy supply should not be hostage and controlled and that all this we will try to ensure. I leave it to everyone to tell us whether all this is guaranteed through Nord Stream 2.  What I have to say is that, today, the Commissioner quite rightly said that the European Union must have many sources of gas supply. But how does this work? This is the time of judgment, the time of decisions, the time of proposals. We have suggestions. A proper proposal is to use domestic sources of supply. I believe that the Eastern Mediterranean and other regions offer for the European Union to make use of them and to become, as far as possible, self-sufficient and not dependent on one or two energy sources. I believe that the Eastern Mediterranean offers, also through Cyprus, which is a member of the European Union, to become an alternative energy supply arm, taking advantage of Cyprus, Israel, Egypt and Greece.  However, I believe that there are other regions that can provide alternatives and supply proposals. I believe, at the same time, that we must focus on solutions such that they will not make the European Union hostage to energy issues in the present and future. I believe that we must move objectively, with proposals that have a present, future and perspective, and such a proposal is, at last, to use the Eastern Mediterranean in the right direction and to invest in energy infrastructure for the benefit of the European Union, for the benefit of European citizens, for the benefit of energy supply and energy self-sufficiency for the European Union.

name: Jeppe Kofod (S&D).
text: Mr President! Commissioner! North Stream should not be extended. It can be said as simple as that. Our Energy Union must be based on solidarity, on cooperation and on renewable energy, and North Stream represents the total opposite of these goals. North Stream II bypasses our Baltic neighbours and Poland, and it will totally isolate Ukraine. Moreover, there is no need for it when about half of the current capacity of North Stream is not used! It will only strengthen and reward Putin - and weaken Europe - Putin, who has invaded Ukraine and is now bombing in Syria. He deserves no reward.  The expansion of North Stream will only strengthen, prolong and exacerbate our dependence on Russian gas. Instead, our energy investments must be spent on renewable energy, on energy efficiency and on developing a real and true internal European energy market, and I hope that the Commissioner will make every step of this.

name: Dawid Bohdan Jackiewicz (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I would like to remind you that my country, Poland, has been protesting against its implementation since the beginning of the nord stream project. We believe that this is an investment that undermines the energy security of Central and Eastern Europe. We believe that it is incompatible with the principle of solidarity, which m.in the European Union, in the field of energy. It must not be the case that entities governed by European law agree on a proposal which reconciles the cardinal principles of that law with those of a State which is not even a member of the European Union. And this is what is taking place today with the tacit agreement of some of the Countries of the European Union. Moreover, the construction of the Northern Gas Pipeline runs counter to efforts to increase the energy security of the EU economy. The Northern Gas Pipeline destabilises security and almost condemns the European Union market to a monopoly on gas supply. In practice, this means building energy security for only one member of the European Union. So where is the solidarity that we have heard so much about in the context of the refugee problem, especially from the mouths of German politicians? I have a brief question for the Commissioner: have nord stream been analysed for compliance with the requirements of the Third Energy Package?

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D).
text: – Mr President, there is no doubt that the long-term future of European energy supply must be built on renewable energies. This is not a mere environmental consideration or a hard-to-interpret 'green' ideology, but quite simply the key to Europe's energy security, the engine of job creation, industrial and economic development. Of course, we also need conventional energy sources, since we have not yet been able to replace them. Here, however, diversification is needed, because without diversification, the European Union's energy security in this matter is not sustainable. European energy prices have already fallen significantly thanks to diversification, according to official data from the European Commission.  Russian gas must obviously play a role in this diversification, but we must make it clear here that the European Union's dependence on Russia is not one-sided. The Russians need us, europeans, just as much, quite simply because, compared to their new partners in the Far East, we Europeans are much more reliable partners in the realisation of European energy security. It is therefore necessary to diversify both renewable energies and conventional energy sources.

name: Zbigniew Kuźmiuk (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. The Nord Stream 2 investment project is primarily a political rather than an economic project, as the existing capacity of Nord Stream 1 is only 50% used. Moreover, the implementation of this investment by large Western energy companies with Russia's Gazprom, which regularly abuses its dominant market position and against which the Commission has been conducting antitrust proceedings for several years, is a blatant disregard not only for European legislation, but above all for the principle of solidarity enshrined in the Energy Union project, supported, after all, by the governments of the 28 Member States.  If the governments of the largest EU countries demand solidarity from the countries of Central and Eastern Europe on immigrants, I, as the representative of the largest of these countries, Polish, demand that the principle of solidarity on energy security be respected, as enshrined not only in the aforementioned Energy Union proposal, but also in the Treaty of Lisbon and, consequently, that this russian investment be blocked.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D).
text: – Mr President, energy security is a major challenge for Europe. In the UK, dependency on imports, in particular of natural gas, has increased significantly over the last years. In this context, I would like to stress that solutions to energy security include deepening market integration, strengthening our efforts on energy efficiency and promoting the development of renewables. Doubling the capacity of the Nord Stream pipeline has several implications which crucially need to be evaluated by the Commission. First, Mr Arias Cañete, the Commission must ensure that the project complies with EU laws on energy markets. I am also urging the Commission to investigate urgently what the doubling of the pipeline’s capacity will mean for the central and eastern European countries. It is in our interests to find a comprehensive solution for energy security which will benefit all Member States. I am not convinced that this project is part of the solution.

name: Krzysztof Hetman (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I think everything has been said in this House today, and I will only limit myself to the most important thing: solidarity and respect for the law – the foundations of the European Union. Recently, there has been a lot of talk about them in Europe. Today, in this Chamber, these values have probably been changed by all cases.  Solidarity cannot be accepted as a signpost for all Member States in some cases and economic efficiency in others, as is the case with the Nord Stream 2 project. If it is otherwise, I, as a European and the majority of the fellow citizens of the European Union, will be denied any illusions.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Mr President, when the European Council of March 2014 concluded that we must elaborate a plan to reduce energy dependence on Russia, they were suggesting that, beyond strengthening our relationship with existing suppliers other than Russia, a new policy goal should also be to open the way for new energy resources. As a matter of fact, this expenditure on the Nord Stream pipeline would negatively affect the countries of central and eastern Europe, only favour the interests of certain EU countries and companies, and oppose the principle of solidarity and common action embedded in the guidelines of the common strategy that the Commission developed at the request of the Member States – a very negative move from some European Union countries with regard to EU solidarity and cohesion. I consequently believe that we ultimately need to stand by our European energy security strategy if we do not want to be vulnerable to supply disruptions, whether caused by political or commercial disputes, political instability or infrastructure failures.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, Nord Stream 2 shows that, also in the energy sector, the economy determines decisions. At the same time as Mrs Merkel assured that she would not leave Ukraine, German companies, along with other European multinationals, were closing the agreement with Gazprom to double Nord Stream's capacity. They are doing this because they think it is a cheaper solution. Businesses, but also above all, consumers need access to cheap energy. For this reason, it is important to diversify both providers and, above all, energy routes.  The strategy of the multiple southern energy corridors and their passage from my homeland, Greece, is central to this issue. With developments in Iran, the construction of TAP the discovery of deposits in Egypt, Israel, Cyprus and with deposits in Greece, the energy framework is changing dramatically. Greece must be a strategic energy hub and gateway to the new architecture by exploiting its energy reserves, away from the guardianship of the troika and the lenders, based solely on the benefit of our people and their prosperity.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE).
text: – The Commission should not see this project as a commercial idea, but look at the european Union's geostrategic interests in the context of security and climate objectives. This project does not meet the european Union's declared energy diversification objectives and does not create a new source or route. And it is not in line with the European Union's priorities for energy efficiency and energy independence. There is no need to build another infrastructure in the Baltic Sea region. Especially when gas consumption is steadily decreasing. There are already alternative sources, such as the Liquefied Gas Terminal built in Lithuania, unfortunately, due to the lack of grids and their lack of loads of only one third. I want to believe that Nord Stream 2 will not serve as another example of the failure of European solidarity, unlike its predecessor, the Nord Stream project, will not be recognised as a project of European interest. How much can one talk and the other do?

name: Miguel Arias Cañete
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank all the honourable Members for their comments, and I am glad that we are very much on the same line on this topic. Let me repeat that, in the context of energy security, diversification is the key, and this is the policy that the Commission is developing.  We are supporting all diversification projects. We will launch an energy, gas and storage strategy early next year. It will be of the utmost importance in view of the future evolution of liquid natural gas. We are supporting the developments in the Southern Corridor, because it is fundamental that the Trans-Anatolian and the Trans-Adriatic pipelines are put into production. Initially the capacity will be only 10 billion cubic metres (Bcms), but in the future we will have lines not only to Azerbaijan but also to Turkmenistan, and, when the conditions are right, we will begin importing Iranian gas. There are new developments in the Mediterranean: we are speaking about substantial amounts of gas: almost 3 000 Bcms in proven, discovered gas. Other possibilities are additional. We also want to connect the Iberian Peninsula with Central Europe; this will permit the flow of Algerian gas. So there are many diversification projects at the moment. Our strategy is diversification of sources and routes. Nord Stream II does not follow this core policy objective. On the contrary, if constructed, it would not only increase Europe’s dependence on one supplier, it would also increase Europe’s dependence on one route. More precisely, the project would dry out the transit through Ukraine, concentrate 80% of Russian gas imports on one route and would lead to a dominant position of Gazprom on the German market by increasing its share from 40% to over 60%.  Therefore the alignment of this project with our European energy strategy on security of supply raises serious doubts. In this spirit, it is crucial to preserve safe transit through Ukraine, which today represents about half of the Russian gas coming to the European Union. As I said before, there is overcapacity for transport of gas from Russia. For these reasons the Nord Stream II project cannot ever become a project of common interest. It cannot ever benefit from European Union financing or European Union support. I reassure you that we will continue our rigorous assessment of the Nord Stream II project, in particular to ensure full compliance with internal energy market legislation. We will get in touch with the designated pipeline operator and the German regulator in order to find out more about the details of the project. On that basis, the Commission will draw its conclusions on the legality of the Nord Stream II project and the next steps to be taken by the Commission. I will keep the Parliament informed about any major development on this matter. It is for companies to decide whether the Nord Stream project is commercially viable or not. But if the project is implemented, the task of the Commission is to ensure full compliance with EU acquis. As I said before, Nord Stream II will have to comply fully with European Union law, in particular the Third Energy Package but also environmental, competition and public procurement rules. I will pay personal attention to that.

name: Nicolas Schmit
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Mr President, very quickly the Presidency thanks the European Parliament for this very useful debate and for its interest in the issue of energy security, including the Nord Stream pipeline project. Indeed, energy security is a key issue for the European Union, its citizens and its economies. Energy security, as I think the debate has shown, incorporates a multiplicity of economic, environmental and geopolitical aspects. The Union must have a common vision and objectives and speak with one voice. The Energy Union provides a framework that should enable the Union to achieve these objectives. I would like, especially in view of what the Commissioner has just said, to quote what was adopted in the conclusions of the European Council of 19 and 20 March 2015. I quote paragraph 2, point d), which states: "to ensure that all agreements related to the purchase of gas from external suppliers are fully in line with EU law, in particular by increasing the transparency of these agreements and their compatibility with EU energy security provisions".  I believe that what the Commissioner has said is entirely in this direction and, therefore, the Presidency will not fail to convey the concerns that have been expressed this evening to whomever is entitled.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I close the debate. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. Mr President, colleagues, on 4 September, Gazprom announced the signing of an agreement for the construction of the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline, thereby increasing the capacity of Nord Stream, which is, it must be remembered, a pipeline directly linking Russia to Germany via the Baltic Sea and bypassing Ukraine. This project will increase the European Union's dependence on Russian gas by 55 billion cubic metres per year. Considering that the European Commission has made security and diversification of energy supply one of its priorities in the context of the Energy Union, I regret that this agreement goes against our interests. On the contrary, we need to develop our southern supply. In addition, instability among energy and transit-producing countries such as Ukraine, the Middle East and North Africa calls for more unity and solidarity between Member States. Europe now imports 55% of its gas, which is why we need to arm ourselves with a more coordinated energy policy and genuine energy diplomacy, in order to weigh more in the negotiations with our partners.

name: András Gyürk (PPE)
text: Writing. – I believe that there is no dispute between us that the definition of the composition of the energy mix is a matter for the Member States. However, the answer to the question of the scope of guaranteeing security of energy supply is no longer so clear. The development of a single internal market places more responsibility on the level of the European Union. I therefore believe that there are areas of energy policy where the EU's responsibility is decisive. Winter is approaching again, the "gas crisis period" is coming. The security of gas supply is more pronounced in our daily lives. The construction of new connectors and the development of bidirectionality is a slow process, so the indicators of unilateral dependency in the CENTRAL AND EASTERN EUROPEAN region are only slowly improving.  The Commission's role in the development of the 'winter package', which has already entered into force from 1 October, is to be welcomed, so we can be confident that the supply to both Ukraine and the Member States supplied through Ukraine will be solved next winter. On the basis of the above considerations, I have followed with interest the official launch of the Nord Stream II gas pipeline project, since the implementation of the project could have a significant impact on the Central and Eastern European region, both from a gas market and energy policy perspective. For the sake of clarity, I have the following questions for the Commission: On what basis does the Commission assess the shareholder agreement? Although the project is cited as a corporate issue by policymakers, gas market analysts say the current industry environment does not justify investment. How does the Commission see this situation?

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. – Despite all the inconveniences, doubling the capacity of the North Stream pipeline is a great opportunity for European energy security. Not only would the Union manage to bypass unsafe transit countries, which have repeatedly excelled by siphoning off gas destined for Europe, but doubling North Stream's capacity would also increase the supply diversification opportunities of those countries that themselves are heavily dependent on other regions. From a geopolitical point of view, this pipeline expansion opened up a good opportunity to re-engage in in-depth talks with Russia, normalize relations and revive the European-Russian partnership, in which Russia has always been a reliable supplier of gas on energy issues and Europe has always been a reliable customer. Dogmatic inflexibility, which denies these advantages, would have the exact opposite effect: Europe would itself severely restrict its energy security, especially in the field of gas, and once again unnecessarily strain relations with Russia. The price to be paid for such a strategy is not a real benefit, but only more self-created problems. Instead of continuing this cycle, Europe would do well to pursue pragmatic and proven solutions to Europe's energy security – not with regularity against, but with Russia.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE)
text: in writing. – Nord Stream 2 poses a principal dilemma to the EU. Are we following our own common policies or turning a blind eye? A consortium of five energy giants has agreed with Gazprom to increase the volume of Nord Stream by 55 cubic metres by 2019. As a result, the EU will significantly increase its energy dependence on Russia, whereas one of the main aims of the third energy package is to diversify energy sources. This is not an economic, but a political problem. The energy package also clearly foresees unbundling measures that in this case are clearly ignored. Gazprom, which has been the most ferocious opponent of unbundling has obviously achieved a victory over EU common policies. Nord Stream 2 aims at bypassing pipelines crossing Ukraine. This will result in weakening Kiev economically and promise more energy insecurity for central European states. Instead of eliminating energy islands in the EU, the latest developments will create new ones. I call upon the European Commission to investigate closely these developments and to rigorously apply the EU third energy package, ensuring full compliance with unbundling rules and energy diversification goals.

name: Eduard Kukan (PPE)
text: Writing. – The decision to build further lines of the Northstream pipeline is not good news either for the countries of a shoved Europe, nor for our partners in Ukraine, nor for a common European energy policy. The forthcoming project not only threatens the interests of some Member States of the Union, such as Slovakia, but directly interferes with the area of energy security and diversification of the supply of energy raw materials, on which our common energy policy should be built. I fundamentally disagree with this project, and I would like the European Commission to examine the merits of this project and take steps to suspend it.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. - Given the current international situation and the European Union's objective of increasing its energy security and reducing energy dependency from Russia, the plan to extend the Nord Stream gas pipeline project is in line with these objectives. There are many examples of Russia using energy to influence its neighbouring countries. The latest example of this is Ukraine. Plans to expand Nord Stream would also be an additional blow to Ukraine, as a significant proportion of gas imported from Russia now reaches Europe through Ukraine.

name: Julia Pitera (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Plans to build additional strands of the Nord Stream gas pipeline in a situation where the EU is so dependent on eastern gas supplies and the abuse of dominant market power by a single supplier have no justification. Their economic rationale is also questionable, since the decision to make this investment is purely political. After all, existing capacity is used at 50%. This project, apart from Ukraine as a route for gas transmission from the east, will negatively affect the already difficult economic situation of the country. It will also significantly weaken its negotiating position and indirectly weaken transit countries such as Slovakia. Moreover, this investment interferes with the energy union idea supported by all Heads of State at the March 2015 European Council on the basis of solidarity and reducing the EU's excessive dependence on energy supplies from the east. It was agreed that all gas agreements should be reviewed for compliance with EU legislation and energy security priorities across the EU, and that financial and regulatory support should only be provided to projects diversifying both sources, suppliers and gas supply routes to the eu as a whole and its neighbours. The energy security of EU countries and their neighbours should be strengthened by supporting, for example, the implementation of the Southern Gas Corridor, supplying the market with gas from the Caspian Region, or importing LNG from current and prospective suppliers such as the US.

name: Algirdas Saudargas (PPE)
text: Writing. – The project pushed by the Russian initiative for the second branch of Nordstream should be seen in the light of the current geopolitical perspective. Ukraine's fate is far from unresolved and the front, which is likely to have a major impact on the resolution of Europe's biggest security crisis, is likely to move to Syria. Russia continues to deepen tensions in relations with the West. Although the European Commission successfully suspended the Southstream project, we hoped that Russia's energy tentacles would not be able to lock up the whole of Europe, moscow agreed with Turkey on the implementation of the Bluestream project. However, we are now seeing that partners can also seriously clash with the gas pipe because of the difference in treatment for the solution to the Middle East crisis. In this context, the project of the second branch of Nordstream is therefore painted in new colours. I would like to draw attention to two points. Firstly, the implementation of the project would enable Russia to achieve its long-standing strategic objective of bypassing Ukraine, which is a transit state, by supplying gas to Europe. This would not only lose EUR 2 billion in Ukraine. the us dollars of annual revenue, but also the possibility of resisting Russia's "gas policy". Secondly, it is strategically convenient for Russia to have only its own corridors for transporting gas to Western Europe, without paying anyone for transport costs. However, this would only further consolidate today's and thus great influence of the Russian gas giant in Europe, which poses a serious threat to the energy security of the countries of Central and Eastern Europe and is fundamentally contrary to the idea of European solidarity.

name: Владимир Уручев (PPE)
text: in writing. – Dear Colleagues, the Russian side is strongly pursuing the stated intentions to build gas pipelines surrounding Ukraine to allow the cessation of gas transit through that country.  Gazprom's agreement with five European companies to double nord stream capacity is not only a step in this direction, but also poses a significant risk to the security of gas supply for the whole of southeastern Europe. The unilateral termination of the South Stream project and the serious difficulties encountered in the negotiation of Turkish Stream, not least because of the different positions of Russia and Turkey with regard to Syria, the missing gas links between the countries in this region and the weak progress in the realization of the Southern Gas Corridor make the transit of Russian gas through Ukraine the only alternative currently available.  At a time when we are building a European Energy Union, we demand a one-voice talk on energy security, we have clear priorities to follow with the vulnerable region of south-east Europe, the corporate bargaining for Nord Stream 2 puts pan-European energy policy to the test. Nord Stream 2 clearly shows that much greater coordination between Member States in energy relations with third supplier countries is needed, thus not allowing a reduction in the energy security of some regions of the European Union at the expense of corporate interests of companies in other regions.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item is the debate on the oral question to the Council and the Commission by Linda McAvan, on behalf of the Committee on Development, on the renewal of the EU Action Plan on gender equality and women's empowerment in the context of development cooperation (Council: O-000109/2015 - B8-0762/2015, Commission: O-000110/2015 - B8-0763/2015) (2015/2754(RSP))

name: Linda McAvan
text: author. – Mr President, we are here on the late shift but we are here to discuss what is still a very important issue, and I know you all agree about that.  We wanted this debate tonight because we want to see a real commitment from the Commission and the Member States to a step change on gender equality and women’s empowerment in development. We want to see agenda action taken seriously, not just paid lip service to by our institutions. We know we need a step change because the Commission’s own evaluation of the last programme says, and I quote, ‘the results were very patchy and poorly documented’, and ‘the results are the accomplishments of committed individuals, rather than an organisational response’. So we do need to see change, but I am afraid I have got to start tonight’s comments on a negative note. Our draft resolution called on the Commission to produce a new gender action plan (GAP) as a communication to give a strong political signal about that need for that step change; a message that gender matters and women’s empowerment should be higher on the agenda of development policy.  We also made that call about the need for communication because we heard rumours, which unfortunately turned out to be true, that the Commission wanted to publish the new GAP as a staff working document, not as a communication, as had previously been intended. Indeed, the day after our committee vote the Commission published a staff working document on gender.  Now I have spoken to people in the Commission and I have heard their arguments. They do not want to be seen to be churning out communications one after another, and some think that talking about the status of the document amount to quibbling. But when you turn to the evaluation of the last programme, I think you will see why we need to make sure the document is taken seriously: the evaluation says that incentives to motivate staff in the Commission and the External Action Service, both in Brussels and in the delegations, and to take gender and women’s empowerment seriously, were missing. There was a failure to do that.  If we had had a communication, it would have been adopted by the entire College of Commissioners: it would have sent a strong message to ambassadors in our delegations that this is a policy of the European Commission, not a staff working document. So downgrading the gender action plan, Commissioner, was not the wisest way in which to start a discussion within the Commission on streamlining your work. I suppose we are where we are tonight – and Commissioner Timmermans has assured us that he is a feminist and is fully committed to the new framework. I know that Commissioner Mimica, Commissioner Stylianides and the Presidency of the Council, indeed the Council as a whole, are very committed on this. So on the details of our resolution, what we want now are concrete policies, coupled with financial resources. We want gender equality to be a core business of the delegations, with more emphasis on reporting, monitoring and evaluation. We want it to be part of the human rights dialogue with third countries and we want action on programing on education, on violence against women and girls, on ending discriminatory practices, on equal pay and decent work. We want action on maternal health, access to health care and – I would personally add – a clear affirmation of sexual and reproductive health and rights. So Commissioner, what I want to hear from you is about how the plans for funding are going to be put in place and how we are going to do the concrete follow-up on this action plan, or framework as you are now calling it. Finally, we have got to see this discussion in the context of the wider work on the Sustainable Development Goals signed up to two weeks ago in New York. Goal 5 is about how to achieve gender equality and empower all women and girls, and there are nine targets. We need to translate those targets into actions here, and we need to add indicators in order to do that.  People are saying we need a data revolution and we need dis-aggregated data. If we do not count women and girls, if we do not know what is happening to them, we will not be able to change their lives. The real test of whether our policies work will be whether women and girls in developing countries feel the change. In New York we all pledged ourselves to leaving nobody behind, and now we have got an opportunity to put that into practice. I think you have the support of this House, Commissioner, to do the right thing on the gender action plan.

name: Nicolas Schmit
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Madam, I am making a confession to you, I too am a feminist because I have had the opportunity to deal with development cooperation in a previous life. I have earned the absolute conviction that development is through women, through the education of women and through the integration of women into economic life. I truly believe that the future of development is women. Equality, moreover, between men and women is at the heart of European values. It is an integral part of the legal and political framework of the European Union. The Union and its Member States are among the main actors in the protection and implementation of women's rights, which they also defend in their external relations. 2015 is an important year as it marks both the adoption of the post-2015 development agenda, the fifteenth anniversary of UN Security Council Resolution 1325 on Women, Peace and Security, and the 20th anniversary of the adoption of the Beijing Declaration and Agenda.  It is in this context that the Union and its Member States are continuing and intensifying their efforts on an issue which, for them, is a priority. During the second half of the year, the Luxembourg Presidency continues the work carried out in recent years in the Council on gender and development. It builds in particular on the conclusions adopted by the Council last May on gender equality in development. The Presidency will ensure that gender issues remain at the heart of the priorities of the Union and its Member States, both within the Union and in its foreign policy. In the Council bodies, we are currently working with the Member States, the Commission and the European External Action Service on the implementation of the new action plan for gender equality and women's empowerment.  Globally, significant progress has been made in gender equality and the empowerment of women and girls. Access to primary education for girls has improved significantly in recent years. Women's economic empowerment is on the rise. An increasing number of women now have access to modern health care and contraceptive methods, and maternal mortality has declined dramatically. However, it must be noted that progress is not as rapid as we want and that it is happening very unevenly across regions, in different countries, and sometimes within the same country. Every day, women's and girls' rights continue to be violated around the world: barriers to access to education, discrimination in employment, lower wages for equal work, discriminatory or vexatious laws, domestic violence, trafficking and sexual exploitation, genital mutilation. These are all examples that remind us of the importance of the European Union not slackening its efforts, if not to intensify them resolutely.  In this regard, we want the new action plan recently presented by the Commission to be an effective tool for promoting the rights of women and girls. It must make it possible to significantly improve the situation of women and girls, who are still victims of discrimination. We welcome the fact that the reports on the implementation of the new action plan are mandatory and planned as a joint exercise between the various actors of the European Union.  Another innovative approach is the Institutional Cultural Shift provided by the document which calls on European Union delegations, both at headquarters and on the ground, to integrate gender automatically and cross-cuttingly in all sectors.  In the coming days and weeks, we will continue to work actively within the Council on this issue. A "gender and development" item will also be on the agenda of the Foreign Affairs Council meeting, which will be attended by development ministers on 26 October. The Council will adopt conclusions and the new action plan for gender equality. Ladies and gentlemen, the European Union and the Member States must remain at the forefront of the fight for equality between men and women. Rest assured that the Presidency will make every effort in this direction.

name: Christos Stylianides
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I am here on behalf of my colleague Neven Mimica. I hope to meet Ms McAvan’s concerns by addressing her questions with the Commission’s position. Addressing the delay in the achievement of gender equality worldwide, the European Union wants to provide concrete, high-impact actions and measures, supported by more targeted funding, gender expertise and strong political leadership in all its external policies, including in international cooperation and development. We confirmed this intention in the recent global process of adoption of the new Sustainable Development Goals. This is exactly what the Commission’s services and the European External Action Service had in mind when putting forward the new framework for action on Gender Equality and Women’s Empowerment through EU external relations from 2016 to 2020.  Looking at its scope and substance, it is a more ambitious, robust and results-oriented successor to the current EU Gender Action Plan in Development, which will soon expire. Its ambition is clearly seen in its thematic and geographical coverage: it will apply in all EU external policies, including trade and, where relevant, humanitarian assistance. It will apply in all our partner countries, including in fragile and emergency situations. It will focus on transformative areas for girls and women, so as to eliminate all forms of violence or discrimination, to give them equal access to natural and economic resources and to empower them socially and politically.  Let me stress this: the level of ambition and commitment of this new framework have not been affected by its format as a joint staff working document. It is a positive step change that will ensure that the Commission’s services and the European External Action Service work together effectively, coherently and strategically, making sure that the fulfilment of girls’ and women’s rights are a tangible reality.  We expect the Member States to endorse our new approach soon through relevant Council conclusions, by making a widely applicable and coordinated effort at EU level. I would like to invite the European Parliament to join this collective endeavour, so we can maximise our impact and results on the ground.  I am convinced that the change has to start from home: shifting the institutional culture – including through dedicated leadership in all European Union institutions and Member States – is key to ensuring a more effective delivery of gender-sensitive outcomes.  Rest assured that adequate financial and human resources and gender expertise to implement the new framework will be provided. For instance, specific support will be provided to our staff in EU delegations and headquarters, through helpdesks and targeted training.  The Commission’s commitment is also quantifiable: the Development Cooperation Instrument has already earmarked around EUR 100 million for measures targeting gender equality. Much more is going to be spent by programmes tackling other sectors and priorities – like agriculture, energy, justice and migration – that consistently take women’s and girls’ perspectives into account. A strong monitoring and reporting structure is also being put into place to make all actors, at all levels, accountable for the results of implementation. In conclusion, let me reiterate our full commitment to the effective implementation of this new gender framework and to making the necessary changes happen. We hope to have Parliament’s support, and I personally am sure that Parliament will support this initiative for the Commission.

name: Davor Ivo Stier
text: on behalf of the PPE Club. - Mr President, first of all I would like to congratulate Rapporteur Linda McAvan and welcome the resolution on the renewal of the EU action plan as voted in the Committee on the Development of this Parliament. Now just some figures on why this issue matters and why it really deserves communication from the European Commission. Every year, 14 million girls are forced into marriage, 62 million do not attend school, many states still have discriminatory laws and practices denying women their rights, access to resources and jobs, participation in political and economic life.  In some countries, girls are selectively abacted simply because they are girls. Such harmful practices prevent development not only for women, but also for their nations and countries, as investing in women carries multiple returns invested. On average, women reinvest 90% of their income in family and community compared to 30-40%, invested by men. When only 10% more girls attend school, GDP grows by an average of 3% in developing countries. So we must point out here that when it comes to sustainable development, it pays to strengthen the position of women. That is why, in the resolution on the new global development framework adopted last year, we made it very clear that women not only need to achieve equality, but must play a central role in the new development plan.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, considering the importance of empowering women, not only as a self-standing human rights issue, but also as a precondition for achieving the post-2015 Sustainable Development Goals, I believe that the 2017 mid-term review of the Development Cooperation Instrument (DCI) presents a good opportunity to assess the impact of DCI-financed programmes on women and girls and make reallocations if necessary. Two of the Millennium Development Goals explicitly address women’s rights – namely promotion of gender equality and empowerment of women, and the improvement of maternal health – and they remain, unfortunately, largely unachieved. Moreover, progress towards gender equality and women’s empowerment has been slow and uneven in many countries. The conclusions of the evaluation of the 2010-2015 Gender Action Plan show the clear need for a change in EU action on gender equality and women’s empowerment, and that we need a renewed political commitment by the European External Action Service and the Commission to improve performance in this area. I therefore strongly support the call to put in place measures that will strengthen the leadership and participation of women and women’s rights organisations in both the public and private spheres. Combating violence against women, tackling pay gaps and ensuring that women can reach equal positions in the working world should be our priorities for the immediate future. We must make a greater effort towards preventing discrimination against women on the grounds of marriage or maternity, and ensuring their effective right to work, to be educated and to be free from any kind of oppression. The renewed gender action plan should focus on all aspects of EU external policy – development cooperation, humanitarian aid, trade, human rights and foreign affairs, migration and asylum – in line with the Policy Coherence for Development principle, and should apply to developing, neighbourhood and enlargement countries alike. It is fundamental that we cooperate with third-country governments and with all stakeholders indicated in regions where rape is used as a weapon of war and oppression to bring this practice to an end, to bring the perpetrators to justice and work with survivors, affected women and communities to help them heal and recover. Only when these issues are properly addressed by the decision makers and become part of the culture and social values will we be close to achieving a stronger, safer and more equal society for all.

name: Branislav Škripek
text: for the ECR Group. – It is commendable that the European Union is helping to solve the difficult problems of third world countries through development aid, but along with that help, gender ideology and a culture of death are increasingly aggressive for a sovereign state. It is conditioned by the adoption of new models of coexistence, so-called genders or sexual orientations, as well as the acceptance of the pro-abortion agenda. Pope Francis stressed recently at the UN that the people of the poorest third world countries need to ensure basic necessities of life and safety, such as home, work, land and freedom of spirit, but do not need all sorts of quotas or artificially induced combat against so-called stereotypes. When it is not about protection against violations of fundamental human rights, we are obliged to show respect for the law, history, culture and traditions of third countries. We have no right to seek ideological colonisation against them through the instilling of anomalous models and lifestyles of foreign identities of nations, as Pope Francis has stressed. The international institutions, and therefore the European Parliament, are also supposed to strive for genuine, integral human development for all. The primary condition for such development is the right to life of every human being, from conception to natural death. This should also be the motto of this institution, which is committed to being the guarantor of fundamental human rights.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, Mr Schmit, Mr Stylianides, thank you and congratulations, Mrs McAvan. The 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, Gender Equality and Empowering All Women and Girls: That Is Goal Five. Women account for at least half, almost always a little more, of our world: most, therefore. They are more vulnerable to poverty, food insecurity, climate change or lack of medical services. Gender equality is not only a fundamental right, but the basis for achieving the world we want: an egalitarian, prosperous and sustainable world. This is the objective to which the 193 signatory countries have subscribed, with a comprehensive and operational approach in the long term. See if it is important that we correctly update this Action Plan: it is called nothing less than to become the framework and support at European level to achieve the objectives we set ourselves just two weeks ago. The full elimination of all forms of violence against women and girls is undoubtedly one of the key aspects. Even today, one in three women in the world (and, yes, European women too) will experience sexual, physical or psychological violence at some point in their lives just because they are women. In addition to the hundred million who have already been earmarked to improve the rights of women and girls, I encourage the Commission to sign and ratify the Istanbul Convention. But, for me, the backbone is education. Achieving gender equality and empowering all women and girls is inescapably about education. This has a radical significance, because it means, de facto, putting women and, above all, girls where they need to be: at the heart of global sustainable development. To this end, I consider it essential to create and adequately provide a Global Fund for Education, which is available to a large global education agenda and objective number four: to ensure inclusive and equitable quality education, and to promote lifelong learning opportunities for all. As Jeffrey Sachs, a United Nations special adviser, proposes, ensuring secondary education for girls around the world is what will really make them the integral transformative agents we need: Doing the girls, the boys will get it.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, gender equality is a human right and a fundamental principle of the Union. However, women's wages are, on average, 30% lower than that of men. A woman is half as likely to find a job that a man and one in three women have been physically or sexually assaulted by their partner or have experienced sexual violence by a stranger. Ladies and gentlemen, in practice, women do not have the same rights as men. The evaluation of the first Action Plan on Gender Equality indicates shortcomings and lack of political will. The positive report voted on tomorrow calls for an ambitious and truly effective Action Plan on Gender Equality and we will therefore support it. We must promote gender equality and women's empowerment in all policies, especially development policies. We need to remove all barriers to equality between men and women. Social barriers, but also economic ones, which lead to the feminization of precariousness, poverty, and an inner exile of women. Enough austerity! Women are the most damaged.  We have to guarantee the right to abortion. Yes, free and free abortion. It must be guaranteed and without it there will never be equality. It is essential that this new Plan contains the form of communication and is supported by the entire college of commissioners. Without all this, barriers to women will continue to exist and we will remain second-rate citizens.

name: Jordi Sebastià
text: verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, it is a little sad to see this House so empty. I've never seen her so empty. It has happened again that, when we have dealt with some issue of equality, we always address it at the last item on the agenda, when we have fewer people. I hope it's just a coincidence because I think it's a fundamental issue.  We saloy this initiative as an urgent need. If we really bet on breaking the discrimination faced by women in most of the world, we must resolutely incorporate—and not just as a mere statement of intent—the gender perspective into our cooperation policies.  That is why, although this initiative is important, we cannot fail to regret that the text is a working document and does not have the value of an official communication to the Commission. Nor are we satisfied that it is not clear how this Plan will be financed, nor that there is no explicit commitment to increase funds for gender equality policies. Without a budget, ladies and gentlemen, good words are left to nothing.  We take a small step, but we still have a long way to go. We'll approve the text. We saloon your manager, but we're not going to settle. We want more, more budget, more commitment and more concrete lines of implementation. The fight for real equality must be a commitment to European policy in all its areas.

name: Mylène Troszczynski
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, here is again a catch-all legislative report. Parliament, with this motion for a resolution, is once again ruining the essential fight for women for the benefit of special and ideological interests.  In this report, you mainly denounce violence against women, while pointing out the shortcomings of the 2010-2015 action plan, particularly in priority areas such as ensuring the physical and psychological integrity of women and girls in developing countries. Only, you forget the essentials. Our peoples would be happy if you named the countries and regions of the world that are the main scene of all kinds of violence against women. Who do you want the Commission to send this message to? You may lack courage, but most of this violence originates in cultures dominated by Islamic fundamentalism that is spreading across every continent, and even here in Europe. I will quote the imam of the Brest mosque at the Salon of the Muslim woman of Pontoise, therefore in France, reported in various newspapers: "If the woman goes out without honor - that is, without the Islamic veil - she is not surprised that men abuse this woman". It is difficult to get any clearer. Our utopian desire for gender equality is light years away from what women are experiencing in these countries where forced marriage and sterilization, domestic violence, the sale of women in slave markets, and so on, have become their terrible daily life. We cannot talk about these horrors without mentioning these terrorist organizations, such as the Islamic State or Boko Haram, so powerful that they threaten the existence of many legitimate states, terrorist organizations whose power is largely the responsibility of the foreign policies of the European Union, the United States and the Gulf monarchies themselves, so actively opposed to the values you defend in this report. I myself have just returned from St. Petersburg, where the Eurasian Women's Forum was taking place. Seven hundred women from eighty nations, national MPs, representatives of executives, NGOs, businesses and universities, came to testify about the daily lives of women in their countries, both professionally and politically, as well as at the personal or physical level. Women in countries where Islamist terrorists reign in terror have witnessed atrocities that strike them, such as rape or physical torture, including the removal of their genitals, so that they can never give life again. What these women want is to come and help them in their country or to help their government fight these terrorists. As I said in the preamble, this is a legislative catch-all. In this report, you also call for specific actions to strengthen the rights of sexual minorities, such as LGBTI people. Do you think these developing countries really need this and how far will you go in your imperialist fantasies?

name: Julie Girling (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I fully support action for women’s empowerment and welcome the renewal of the EU Plan of Action on Gender Equality, and I would like to support Ms McAvan’s call to elevate its importance within the Commission’s administration. This is clearly vital if we are going to get action taken. The ECR Group and the UK Conservatives are committed to putting girls and women at the centre of international development. We believe that investing in girls and women has a transformative impact on growth, poverty reduction and achieving the critical Millennium Development Goals. While welcoming the renewal of the plan, I do have some reservations. I am not comfortable with over-emphasis on information and methodology: I would much rather see us spending our efforts – and indeed our money – on actual action. I firmly believe in the principle of aid effectiveness – that is, focusing on a results-based approach – and I support the approach of the UK Government as developed in its multilateral aid review, which identifies the need to strengthen gender mainstreaming in practice. This is the most important aspect.

name: Catherine Bearder (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank Linda McAvan for the work she has been doing. We have always seen European equality as including gender equality. So it is essential that we keep this is a central point of our strategies in developing countries, particularly this year as we come forward with the Sustainable Development Goals. Women must be free of the threat of violence, and we must plan for that in our strategies. We know of the sexual violence inflicted on women in conflict areas: in Nigeria by Boko Haram; in the Democratic Republic of the Congo; the rape and worse, in Syria, of women in refugee camps fleeing war. The list goes on. But it is a sad biological fact that many pregnancies result from this violence. The Commission has now confirmed to MEPs that international humanitarian law and/or human rights law may justify offering a safe abortion, rather than perpetuating what amounts to inhumane treatment. Women’s health and their ability to access support and protection include their ability to exercise their sexual and reproductive rights. This is essential to female freedom and empowerment. We must ensure that women retain access to sexual and reproductive rights and, if necessary, safe and legal abortions. This must remain part of the EU’s support for women in conflict areas and for women fleeing violence.

name: Eleonora Forenza (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, by virtue of the treaties and strategies that the European Union has drawn up and signed and by virtue of the 2030 Sustainable Development Goals that the United Nations has recently made public, I believe that the commitment of this Parliament and the resources it has at its disposal for better implementation of the second objective, both at Union and State level, is necessary. Sustainable is a development that monitors and increases access to education, services and health for girls, sustainable is a development that creates the conditions because women can choose a job that is rewarding and equally paid for them compared to their male colleagues.  Thanks to the European Institute for Gender Equality (EIGE), we have at our disposal an indicator of gender equality, the data of which, which can also be slow disaggregated, indicate the points where immediate action is urgently needed. I suggest we start there. I also suggest that all Member States, in particular the States of Southern Europe, draw up a gender equality indicator that can also read the situation at regional level, monitor and enable effective action to be taken.
