Among the Sustainable Development Goals, we also find the right to development, which partly translates into global goals between governments of so-called developed countries and developing countries. This concerns us.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the plan that took place between 2010 and 2015 has contributed to the development of a number of new policies in the field of cooperation and development. However, there are still a number of situations that need intensification and others that deserve more adjusted treatment or even new approaches. The plan that will be in place between 2015 and 2020 should be ambitious and coherent. It is intended to call for cultural change at the level of institutions. It must welcome the social and political objectives of the European Union, aligning them with what is our role in the world. The defence of gender equality, also in other geographies, must be a key component of this new plan.  I would like to point out the possibility of extending the objectives of this policy to the Union's commercial activity. Fair trade is an effective way of driving behavioural change by promoting development at source, trust in destiny and justice in economic and social relations.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, the European Union must combat gender discrimination in the workplace, while strengthening the empowerment of women in developing countries. At a time of global financial crisis, there is strong discrimination against women, as well as differences in wages and pensions between the sexes, all over the world. Moreover, women's unemployment levels far exceed those of men, which shows even more strongly discrimination in terms of the recruitment criteria for workers. In impoverished Greece, women are the biggest victims of the crisis. Thus, the unemployment rate for women in the first quarter of 2015 is 30.6% compared to 23.5% for men. The Member States of the European Union must fight to eliminate the gender pay gap between men and women in the developing world and to impose transparency on gender pension systems. They should also safeguard women's rights in relation to motherhood and oppose the unfair dismissal of female workers during their pregnancy.

name: Christos Stylianides
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, firstly allow me to congratulate again my colleague Linda McAvan on her dedication on this very challenging and demanding issue. Honourable Members, allow me to sincerely thank you for this fruitful debate in these circumstances and at this very difficult time, which shows how close to each other our positions and ambitions are when it comes to improving the lives of women and girls in our partner countries. I hope that your main concerns have been addressed in the new gender framework for action and that we can continue our dialogue on its implementation. I also want to thank you all for your overall dedication on gender issues, especially this year when we celebrate the 20th anniversary of the Beijing Platform for Action and the 15th anniversary of the UN Resolution on Women, Peace and Security, and the year in which we adopted the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development that should leave no one behind, women and girls in particular – if I may add.  The 2030 Agenda is a universal framework with ambitious goals and targets. It also reaffirms the role of gender equality and empowerment of women as keys to, and drivers of, sustainable development. As the European Union strongly conveyed in New York two weeks ago, we want to live in a world where the rights of girls and women are claimed, valued and respected by all, and where everyone is able to fulfil their potential and contribute to a more fair and just society for all. The Commission and the European External Action Service are eager and fully committed to make this pledge a reality, through effective implementation of the new gender framework, and in partnership with all the EU institutions, the Member States, partner countries, civil society organisations, international organisations, entrepreneurs and all other interested stakeholders. And of course, as the Commission, we count on this House to be our key partner.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I have received one motion for a resolution tabled in accordance with Rule 123(2) of the Rules of Procedure. I close the debate. The vote will take place on Thursday 8 October 2015 at 12.00.  Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. – Equal opportunities are a key factor for sustainable development, especially in areas where this inequality is more pronounced in developing countries, namely: employment and economic activities, governance, access to education, health, violence against women. I appreciate the fact that considerable progress has been made on gender equality in development cooperation, and I believe that coordination and harmonisation with the Member States is important through the exchange of best practices. I believe that the European Union must continue to promote gender equality at international and regional level, stressing in particular the importance of extending its application beyond the fields of health and education, thereby contributing to the full integration of gender equality into country strategies and the implementation of European Union development cooperation.

name: Arne Lietz (S&D)
text: Writing. – The renewal of the action plan on equality between women and men is an important step, and I welcome the mention of relevant points such as strengthening the economic situation of women and girls, access to the labour market and their participation in political and public life. However, key aspects are missing, such as the link between the sexual and reproductive rights of women and girls and access to the education system and the labour market. Some 222 million women in developing countries do not have access to safe and modern methods of family planning. Worldwide, 62 million girls do not have a school education. This affects their participation in the labour market. The action plan also neglects the role of men and boys. They are important players in gender equality policy. Particular importance must also be attached to coherence between eu policies and external policies. The EU's trade policy and its instruments also play an important role in this. In view of the complexity of this field, it is therefore necessary to give the action plan greater political weight and thus to upgrade it to a Communication from the Commission.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Writing. Institutional management of values and standards through development aid instruments is a specialty of the EU. The report on the "Renewal of the EU Action Plan on Gender Equality and Women's Empowerment in Development Cooperation" is, according to the Noichl and Tarabella reports, another example of nonsense for which the EU spends the money of the citizens of the Member States. The report not only supports gender manipulation by the information offices of the EU Foreign Ministry, but also promotes the presentation of marriage and motherhood as a state of discrimination. This is not just nonsense, it is total nonsense!
